editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: TO THE Mo≈øt Serene and Mighty MONARCH, WILLIAM III. King of England, Scotland, France, and Ireland.
div.p: I Bring to Your Maje≈øty a ≈ømall Work, a Series of Pre≈øcriptions in the Medical Art, yet po≈ø≈øibly the Greate≈øt in its Kind, for Excellency and ∆≤≈øefulne≈øs, that ever any Age produced: A Collected Summary of the Choice≈øt Secrets in Phy≈øick yet known; and what all the Profe≈ø≈øors thereof acknowledge as a Spontaneous Product from the ∆≤niver≈øal Stock of Experience.

I have Accomodated it for the Advantage of all Your Maje≈øty's Subjects, and made its ∆≤≈øe as ∆≤niver≈øal and Ea≈øie, as the Medicaments them≈øelves are General
and Good: Had not the Nece≈ø≈øity of ≈øuch a Work, prevailed with me, I had never put my Hand to this Plough, nor troubled Your Maje≈øty on ≈øuch an Occa≈øion.

Be plea≈øed therefore, Sir, to ca≈øt Your Favourable Eye, on the State of the Profe≈ø≈øion of Phy≈øick, and in particular on this Book, which thro' your Benignity cannot go without its hoped for Effects; for that thro' Your Royal Favour, it will not only live now in E≈øtimation and Re≈øpect, but ≈øtand as a Signal to future Times of Your Maje≈øty's extraordinary Goodne≈øs, fru≈øtrating the De≈øigns of evil Men.

You have, Sir, re≈øcued us not only from the Jaws of Lions and Paws of Bears, the brute≈øt of Bea≈øts, but from the In≈øuperable Chains of Popery and Slavery, and from the Dreaded Tyranny of Eternal Slaves, the Barbarous French: And re≈øtored our deare≈øt Liberties, ravi≈øht from us by ∆≤≈øurpation and Violence, thro' the Malice and Deceit of Treacherous and Ambitious Men; who not only ruin'd the Publick by their Follies, but
precipitated them≈øelves from the highe≈øt Acme of Glory, to the fathomle≈øs Aby≈øs of Di≈øhonour and Contempt.

Thus, Sir, becoming the Glory of the Diadem, and the Maje≈øty of Crowned Heads, You will out-do Royalty it ≈øelf; and by Your Magnanimity, build ≈øuch Monuments of Honour, which the Re≈øult of utmost Ages ≈øhall never deface, nor eternal Times ever wear out or alter.

Were my Abilities to write your Character but equal to the Greatne≈øs of Your Spirit; and could I but ≈øcetch out a faint Idea of Your Glorious Actions, I'd write in Everla≈øting Lines Your Immortal Life, and depict upon the Curtains of Eternity, not the Shadows of Royalty but the perpetual Sub≈øtance thereof, powerfully Arm'd with unlimited Goodne≈øs: A Prerogative that no Prince upon Earth, but Your Maje≈øty, can ju≈øtly Claim.

Terrible of the Earth, trampling under Your Feet the De≈øtroyers of the World: and being filled with the Spoils of Your Enemies, May You lift up the Standarts of Ju≈øtice and Truth, and by Your ∆≤nre≈øi≈øtable Power introduce Peace to your People And that a Pro≈øperous Conduct may attend You with Honour and Glory, thro' a long and happy Reign, is the perpetual Prayer of

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: I THE Original Author of this Book was the Eminent and Learned Dr. Bate, a Man who in his Station had been Phy≈øician to Two Kings of England, and a Protector; and of ≈øuch Approved Skill in his Profe≈ø≈øion, that to make any De≈øcants thereon, would be to draw a Vail over his Lu≈øtre, and blemi≈øh that Excellency, which in this following Work, gives a convincing Proof, that he was one of the greate≈øt Ma≈øters of his Art in the Univer≈øe.

II. His Arcana and Pre≈øcripts were Collected, as they appear in the Latin Copy, by that ingenious and indefatigable Gentlemen, Mr. James Shipton, who had the Happine≈øs of preparing and making the greater part (if not all) of them up: And by who≈øe Care and Indu≈øtry the World became ble≈øt with ≈øuch a valuable Production; which exceeds in its Benefit and U≈øefulne≈øs to Mankind, (we ≈øpeak it without Flattery) all the Di≈øpen≈øatories this day extant, in what Language ≈øoever.

III. Thus came out the fir≈øt Edition, with general Applau≈øe, which meriting ≈øo well in the World, Mr. Shipton was plea≈øed to make us happy with a Second, wherein he added above One hundred more of Dr. Bate's Recipes, and the Arcana Goddardiana, from the Authors Autograph, who being a Learned Man, and they no mean things, advanced very much the Value of the Book: So that in a very few Years, there were ≈øold of the Latin Copies to the number of (at lea≈øt) Six thou≈øand.

IV. The Work obtaining thus exceedingly upon the Publick, as having the general Liking and Approbation of all the Learned World, more e≈øpecially of the Gentlemen
of the Profe≈ø≈øion: And among the number of the re≈øt, falling into my Hands, upon view thereof, finding it ≈øo va≈øtly to exceed in U≈øefulne≈øs and Learning whatever had been yet extant of that kind before; and that it was entertained among Profe≈ø≈øors of Our Art (of what Quality or Education ≈øoever) with no common Friend≈øhip or Reception: It made me con≈øider it a little farther; and to draw an Argument from its general U≈øefulne≈øs and Entertainment; That if whil≈øt it wandred thro' the World in an unknown Tongue (as to the Vulgar) and was a Stranger, it became ≈øo de≈øirable and acceptable; how much more, if we indulg'd it, by making it a Free Denizon, or Native of our own.

V. Upon the≈øe Con≈øiderations, I immediately fell upon the Tran≈ølation, which I hope you will find done with all Faithfulne≈øs and Sincerity: And whereas the Arcana Godd. were for the mo≈øt part Nominal, without exhibiting their Preparations: We have in this Engli≈øh Edition, added them at large, and inter≈øper≈øt them for the Benefit of all the Lovers of this kind of Learning.

VI. And whil≈øt we were doing this, that we might yet lay a farther Obligation upon the Generous Lovers of Art; we have added to this Impre≈ø≈øion, the much e≈øteemed Goddard s Drops, and Ru≈ø≈øel's Pouder (neither of them in any printed Work before) the former of which was one of the accounted ine≈øtimable Jewels of K. Charles II. The other that Fam'd ∆≤niver≈øal, which for the≈øe twenty five Years la≈øt pa≈øt has obtain'd a general Reputation, from the Ea≈øt to the We≈øt-Indies, and in a manner thro' the whole World. You have al≈øo the Empla≈øtrum Febrifugum, which, tho' as to its Compo≈øition, it is a very ≈øimple thing, and whil≈øt not publi≈øhed, hugg'd as a great Secret, yet truly valuable as to its Vertues, for that it has ≈øcarcely been ever known to be applied without the de≈øired Succe≈øs; nor did I ever u≈øe it in vain. And to the≈øe we have added near half an hundred more, of con≈øiderable Recipes, out of the Collectanea Chymica, and other valuable Authors.

VII. We have not here given you a bare Tran≈ølation only, but be≈øides that, a large Comment upon each particular (as the Nature of the Subject would admit, or did require) more e≈øpecially upon all the Chymical Proce≈ø≈øes, which
are many, and the mo≈øt excellent, ≈øelected out of a large Farraginous heap; and made choice of from mighty Strength of Rea≈øon, and a long Series of Experiences, which has exceedingly added to their Credit and Reputation.

VIII. The≈øe We have almo≈øt every where ≈øearcht out, from their Original Fountains, and where need required, given a clear Explication of the Proce≈øs it ≈øelf, and added as a Supplement (to make the Work the more ab≈øolute and compleat) a Rationale upon the ≈øame.

And farther, We have examin'd the Pre≈øcripts and Opinions of the mo≈øt Learned Authors who have wrote thereof: Shewing, either their Proce≈ø≈øes at large, if new; Or, the particular Circum≈øtances wherein they chiefly differ, if material; and ≈øo repre≈øenting as it were in a Gla≈øs, a Summary of all that has been hitherto written of this kind.

IX. As to the Authors made u≈øe of in this Book; tho' we cannot have the Vanity to obtrude a va≈øt Catalogue or Heap, as is u≈øual with ≈øeveral Writers of Books (po≈ø≈øibly many whom they never lookt into, to con≈øult, but for O≈øtentation they enumerate) yet we think it nece≈ø≈øary to give an Account of the Chief of tho≈øe We were Beholden to, that we may put Our Arti≈øt into a Capacity to make a more exact and ≈øatisfactory Judgment of the following Di≈øcour≈øes.

X. The Chief of tho≈øe We con≈øulted in this Undertaking were either of the more Ancient; as, Paracel≈øus, Crollius, Hartman, Libavius, Beguinus, Sala, Faber, Myn≈øicht, Grulingius, ∆≤ntzer, Quercetan, Mylius, Sennertus, &c. Or of the Modern and more Late; as, Riverius, Schroder, Hofman, Hor≈øtius, Rolfincius, Marggrave, Maets, Le Mort, Ludovicus, Ettmuller, Junken, Tachenius, Glauber, Le Febure, Thibaut, Charras, and Lemery, with ≈øome others of le≈ø≈øer Note, who≈øe Performances in this kind (for ≈øo much as they wrote of) have been admirable above all the re≈øt of their Fellows.

XI. This being thus compleated, you may in a little time expect the Second Part of the ≈øame, which is now in in the Pre≈øs, viz. Our Officina Chymica, or Chymical Shop; being a compleat Body of Chymi≈øtry in all in its Parts: Wherein
you will find Explicated, 1. The Principles of Natural Bodies, in their received and genuine Sen≈øe. 2. The Fornaces and In≈øtruments of the Art particularly de≈øcribed with their Figures in Copper Plates. 3. The Operations of Chymi≈øtry per ≈øe, ab≈øtracted from the Preparation of any ≈øet Medicine. 4. The Preparation of Metals and Minerals deduced from all the Operations of Chymi≈øtry. 5. La≈øtly, The Preparation of certain Vegetable and Animal Sub≈øtances, according to all the more late Di≈øcoveries or De≈øignations.

XII. But from hence one Objection ari≈øes to be obviated, viz. That I have treated of many things in this Di≈øpen≈øatory, that I had handled formerly at large in my Pharmacopoeia Londinen≈øis and Doron, and therefore might very well have been omitted here. To which I an≈øwer, 1. That this is another Man's Book, and my ≈øelf but the Tran≈ølator thereof; ≈øo that I could by no means with Ju≈øtice and Honour have gelt the Text, or obliterated any part thereof, without a manife≈øt Wrong and Injury to the Author. 2. That I have done no otherwi≈øe with re≈øpect to the aforenamed Books, than Schroder did with his Quercetanus Redivivus when he wrote his own Di≈øpen≈øatory. 3. That notwith≈øtanding this ≈øeeming Repetition, or reiterating of the very ≈øame thing ≈øometimes, you may po≈ø≈øibly in this meet with that which is new concerning it, not contained in the other Books, which may recompence the Labour and Pains of a ≈øecond Review.

XIII. If any of the Gentlemen of the Profe≈ø≈øion, think, that in this Work or any other, we have done them Wrong or Prejudice, in di≈øcovering to the Vulgar, many of the Arcana of Our Art: We hope (as a Recompence for the ≈øame) to make them amends again, in divulging ≈øeveral other Secrets, which the mo≈øt of them were wholly ignorant of before. However as a general An≈øwer to this Objection, We think, that all particular Intere≈øts ≈øhould ≈øacrifice to the general, and that the Publick good ought ever to be preferred before the Private how dear and valuable ≈øoever.

XIV. It is my Opinion, that the Art of Phy≈øick is not any particular Man's or Societies proper Right, more than anothers; but that every Man has an equal ≈øhare in the ≈øame. But 'tis like Gold and Silver, he that wins it, or takes pains for it, ≈øhall have it. And as in one, every Man
has a Right by his Wit and Indu≈øtry, to get Gold, if he can, and having got it, to make u≈øe of it; ≈øo in the other, every Man has a Right to ≈øtudy Phy≈øick if he plea≈øes; and having once made him≈øelf Ma≈øter of the Knowledge of it, has as great a Right to u≈øe it as we. Nor can I ≈øee ought, which may entitle any one particular Per≈øon to an Original Intere≈øt in it, more than it can another, whatever ≈øome ≈øelf-ended Men may pretend to the contrary.

XV. It is generous to do good to Mankind; and the more voluntary is is, the more acceptable. For my part, I owe ≈øo great a Friend≈øhip to all the World, that I wi≈øh every Man under≈øtood the Art as well as I do. And I ≈øhould be content upon the Condition, that it would plea≈øe the mo≈øt Good and Infinite Being, to ble≈øs the Sons of Men with a perpetual State of Health, to ≈øeek out ≈øome other way of living. And as Health is the mo≈øt valuable of all Earthly Happine≈ø≈øes; ≈øo I am of Opinion, all other Intere≈øts ≈øhould vail to it. He can be no good Man, who de≈øires to build up his Fortunes from the Mi≈øeries and Calamities of others; or to rai≈øe an E≈øtate upon the Nece≈ø≈øities of the Mean, and the Ruins of ≈øuch as want Bread.

XVI. For this Rea≈øon ≈øake, I have for the≈øe Thirty Years together exerci≈øed my Art (as well as to live by it) as a nece≈ø≈øary piece of Charity. I know no poor Creature that ever came to me, in my whole time, that once went from me, without my de≈øired help Gratis. I have not only given them my Judgment or Opinion concerning their Di≈øea≈øes and Di≈øtempers; but if curable and Poor) have ≈øupplied them with all the Medical Nece≈ø≈øaries for the whole Cure, till they became perfectly well, without demanding or requiring one Penny for it afterwards. And I have accounted the Re≈øtauration of ≈øuch poor and wretched Creatures a greater Ble≈ø≈øing to me, than if I had gotten the Wealth of both the Indies. I can't ≈øo well expre≈øs my ≈øelf concerning this Matter, as I can conceive it; but I am ≈øure I ≈øhould have been more plea≈øed, and had a greater Satisfaction, in ≈øeeing ≈øuch a helple≈øs Creature, re≈øtored to its de≈øired Health, than if I had found a very valuable Trea≈øure.

XVII. There are ≈øeveral Hundreds in this Great City, can bear me witne≈øs to this Truth. And for all the pa≈øt
Good I have done in tho≈øe Ca≈øes; as I can never repent it; ≈øo I re≈øolve to continue it; for I certainly know, that I have had the ≈øignal Ble≈ø≈øing of God attended my Endeavours for it: For which, (with all humility) I here publickly acknowledge his Goodne≈øs; and ble≈ø≈øing his mo≈øt merciful Hand, with bended Knees give Thanks for the ≈øame. Nor ≈øhall I ever de≈øi≈øt the doing of what I have for thus many Years done in this kind, but am re≈øolved thro' the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the mo≈øt good God, to exerci≈øe the ≈øame Charity, and as largely extend it, to all the Poor and Mi≈øerable, who ≈øhall plea≈øe to make u≈øe of it, whil≈øt I have my Sen≈øe and Rea≈øon, and draw Breath upon Earth.

XVIII. I have begun to render the Arts of Phy≈øick and Chyrurgery with their Appendices, the Materia Medica, Anatomy and Chymi≈øtry into Engli≈øh; and in doing of which, by this pre≈øent Work, and Thirteen or Fourteen other Books, I have made a con≈øiderable Progre≈øs already; and intend not to de≈øi≈øt, till I have fully made them in all their parts, compleat and intire. 'Tis every Engli≈øh Man's Birth-right, and an un≈øpeakable Wrong to endeavour the keeping it from him.

XIX. Nor do I know why any ≈øhould be offended with me for thus doing, ≈øince it is but what Hippocrates and Galen, Cel≈øus and Paracel≈øus, with hundreds more, all did, writing the Sy≈øtem of Phy≈øick in their own Languages. Yea, and it is what the French (out of an Ambition of Glory) do at this day. I am ≈øure we are their great Admirers in mo≈øt things, and Ape them in what≈øoever is vitious and ridiculous: And why we ≈øhould not imitate them in a thing of ≈øuch an e≈ø≈øential Good I know not; unle≈øs you would oblige us to follow them only in their Vices, and e≈øchew them in their Vertues.

XX. I know that I have many Enemies in the World, and that the publi≈øhing this Work will create me many more, and tho≈øe powerful ones, and malicious too: But I have overlookt all this, and have directed my Eye to the Recompence of Reward. If herein I have ≈øerv'd my Country and Generation, I have what I aimed at, and I am ≈øure I ≈øhall have along with it the Defence of him, who≈øe Mercies are over all his Works, and the Ble≈ø≈øings of the Poor and Needy.

But that is e≈øteemed yet more excellent, which is di≈øtilled with Spirit of Wine, in≈øtead of Water, as being extracted with more ea≈øe, and rather of greater virtues and ≈øubtilty, after this-manner: ‚Ñû Full ripe Juniper-Berries, well brui≈øed lb vj. put them into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, filling it about half full: affu≈øe thereon Spirit of Wine well rectified, till but one third of the Cucurbit remains empty; cover it with its blind head, perfectly luting the Junctures: digest in a little Sand heat for three days, (which will be enough for penetration of the Berries, and di≈ø≈øolution of their volatile parts): this done, take off the blind Head, and put thereon an Alembick fitted, with its Receiver, and di≈øtil in B. M. or in a Sand heat with a gentle Fire, ≈øo will you have a ≈øubtil, volatile, and inflamable Spirit, repleat with the best and mo≈øt volatile parts of the Juniper-Berries. ¬ß 7. You may al≈øo obtain this Spirit in its perfection, by brui≈øing a good quantity of tho≈øe Berries, and then to fill about two thirds of one, or more Earthen Jarrs well leaded within, affu≈øing warm Water upon them, and then (without the addition of any ferment) ≈øtopping them clo≈øe up, and ≈øo let them ≈øtand about eight or ten days, in a gentle Sand heat, to di≈øtil in a Copper Ve≈øica tinn'd within, and covered,

The white Vapours are the fir≈øt and weake≈øt Spirit: the red ones are the latter, and ≈øtronge≈øt, coming forth from the mo≈øt fixt part of the Salt; where Note, That no kind of Salt yields red Vapours but Nitre only. ¬ß 6. This Spirit will di≈ø≈øolve, or rather corrode all Metals, except Gold, into which it cannot enter alone, by rea≈øon of the ≈ømallne≈øs of the Pores of that Metal; but if you add to it a fourth part of its weight of Sal Armoniack, or of Sea Salt, or of Sal Gem, it will give a new form to its particles, ≈øhaping them into more ≈øubtil points, capable of entering into the pores of the Gold, and to penetrate and di≈ø≈ølve its ≈øub≈øtance. ¬ß 10. It is highly good again≈øt Malign Feavers of all ≈øorts, and to ≈øuppre≈øs Vapours that ari≈øe from crude and tartarous humours, cea≈øes the ebilition of the humours, by rea≈øon of its volatile and ≈øulphurous Salt joyned with its acid; and is an excellent Remedy again≈øt the Colick. It opens Ob≈øtructions of the Liver and Spleen, and of all the Bowels, di≈ø≈øolves coagulated Blood, and therefore is ≈øingularly profitable again≈øt the Pleuri≈øie, whether true or ba≈øtard, expelling the Di≈øea≈øe either by ≈øweat, or in≈øen≈øible tran≈øpiration. It cures Rheumati≈øms, and all ≈øorts of wandering pains, and the Drop≈øie Tympanites. Be≈øides all which it changes the Emetick and Cathartick Virtues of ≈øeveral things into Diaphoretick, particularly Antimony.

div.head: XXI. Spiritus Nitri Bezoarticus, Bezoartick Spirit of Nitre.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû It is di≈øtilled from Spirit of Nitre rectified, and Butter of Antimony, ana; by a Retort, S. A. The Caput Mortuum ≈øerves to make Bezoar Mineral of.

Salmon.] It ought to be di≈øtilled in a Retort in Sand; whereof, if the Fire be ≈øpeedily urged, the Spirit will be red, and as Authors affirm, be able not only to di≈ø≈øolve Gold, but al≈øo to volatilize it. ¬ß 2. It ought to be made of rectified Spirit of Nitre; which is thus done: ‚Ñû Of the former Spirit of Nitre, at Sect. 20. q. v. put it into a Gla≈øs Body, and in an open Fire make it to evaporate, till the Vapours or Fumes begin to a≈øcend yellow; then remove it from the Fire, and keep it for u≈øe; this is rectified Spirit of Nitre. ¬ß 3. This Spirit of Nitre thus rectified, ought to be put upon the Butter of Antimony, ≈øo long till the Efferve≈øcence cea≈øes: then the mixture to be di≈øtilled to dryne≈øs; this Liquor thus di≈øtilled is the Bezoartick
Spirit, which indeed is nothing el≈øe but Aqua Regia, made by a conjunction of the Spirit of common Salt, which Spirit of Nitre, for which rea≈øon it di≈ø≈øolves Gold, and does other things which the vulgar A. R. does.

div.head: XXII. * Spiritus Nitri dulcis, Dulcified Spirit of Nitre.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Spirit of Nitre, p. j. Alcohole of Spirit of Wine, p. ij. Dige≈øt till they are joyned, and di≈øtil in Sand, cohobating twice, S. A. Do≈øe ad íj. in any convenient Liquor; it moves ≈øweat, takes away Ob≈øtructions of the Colick, Reins, Brea≈øt, &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This proportion of 1 to 2. is that which is ob≈øerved by Le Mort, Maets and Marg-grave; but Rolfincius, Charras, and Lemery, make the mixture in equal parts of each. ¬ß 2. In the mixing them you mu≈øt be very cautious, and do it lei≈øurely and by degrees: you mu≈øt not put the Spirit of Wine to the Spirit of Nitre, for then you will ≈øet it all in a flame; but you mu≈øt put in the Spirit of Nitre Gradatim into the Spirit of Wine, ≈øo will you prevent the flaming, but the mixture will grow ≈øo hot, that you will ≈øcarcely be able to hold your hand on the out≈øide the Ve≈ø≈øel. ¬ß 3. Being mixed together, dige≈øt for ≈øeven days, then put the mixture into a Gla≈øs Retort, and di≈øtil in Sand, fir≈øt with a gentle heat, and afterwards with a ≈øtronger, to drine≈øs: the Receiver let be very large, and the neck of the Retort fit for it, and ≈øo enter a good way in, and the Juncture to be well luted, for otherwi≈øe you will lo≈øe much of your Spirit. ¬ß 4. It is nece≈ø≈øary that the Spirit ≈øhould be cohobated twice at lea≈øt, ≈øome Authors advi≈øe thrice; for the oftner it is cohobated, the ≈øweeter it is. Le Mort al≈øo ≈øays, that the di≈øtillation may be performed upon the ≈øpot of the commixtion; and that if the dige≈øtion exceeds ≈øeven days before the di≈øtillation, the Union will be ≈øo firm that there will be no need of a di≈øtillation. ¬ß 5. The two Spirits mix and unite with an in≈øeparable Union, ≈øweet, or at lea≈øt not of ≈øo great an acritude as before, and of a very grateful odour. ¬ß 6. It ought to be an open Ve≈ø≈øel that the mixture is made in, for ≈øhould it be in a Gla≈øs Bottle, and ≈øtopt before the ebulition be over, it would hazard the breaking of the ≈øame. ¬ß 7. Lemery
advi≈øes to make the mixture in a Bolt-head ≈øet in ≈øtraw in the Chimny, without heat, letting it be open till the Ebulition is over, taking heed al≈øo to avoid the fumes, and then to put it into a Gla≈øs, and keep it without di≈øtillation for u≈øe. ¬ß 8. This Operation differs not much from that of mixing Oyl of Turpentine, and Oyl of Vitriol together: for the≈øe Liquors al≈øo heat and boyl together much alike. ¬ß 9. In this mixture the Spirit of Nitre joyns it≈øelf to the Sulphur of the Wine, and both being admirably volatile, they ≈øtrive to mount upwards, whereby the mixture is put into that mighty motion and efferve≈øcency; and from whence re≈øults a complicate Spirit, being mo≈øt fragrant, and having the greate≈øt volatility. ¬ß 10. Charras advi≈øes it to be di≈øtilled in a Sand heat in a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, covered with its head carefully luted, and to be repeated three times; from whence, ≈øays he, ari≈øes a compo≈øed Spirit, more agreeable in ≈ømell, more grateful to the ta≈øte, more gentle in all in operations, more fit for our bodies, and more admirably diaphoretick than the ≈øimple Spirit of Nitre can po≈ø≈øibly be. ¬ß 11. Rolfincius in Chimia, Lib. 3. Sect. 1. Art. 4. Cap. 11. advi≈øes after four days dige≈øtion to di≈øtil it in an Alembick; ≈øo, ≈øays he, will the Spirits in this Operation be united, and contract a Violet kind of odour, or ≈ømell, and a ≈øubdulce and grateful ta≈øte. ¬ß 12. It is a mo≈øt admirable Diuretick and Diaphoretick, quenches thir≈øts, re≈øi≈øts putrefaction of the blood and humours, and and powerfully attenuates and incides: It is a ≈øingular Febrifuge, cures all malign Feavers, even the Small-pox, and Plague it≈øelf. It abates Inflamations, even of the Lungs, and penetrates the whole Body, for it is indeed the highe≈øt volatile acid that is yet known in Rerum Natura. It is a mo≈øt ≈øignal Anticolick, curing the Di≈øea≈øe above all other Medicines, and many times when all other Remedies fail. It is a Specifick again≈øt the Pleuri≈øie, in which Di≈øea≈øe Rolfincius gives it with Syrup of Corn Poppies in a proper Volatile. It takes away all preternatural heat in any part of the Body to a Miracle: It is good again≈øt the Stone, Gravel, and all Ob≈øtructions of Urine what≈øoever, and indeed has not only all the Virtues of ≈øimple Spirit of Nitre, at Sect.
20. ¬ß 10. aforegoing, but al≈øo much exceeds that in every re≈øpect. ¬ß 13. It is a circulated Men≈øtruum, and by ≈øome is taken for the Circulatum majus Paracel≈øi; by it the Vertues of many things are momentarily to be extracted, much better than by ≈øeveral others, and ≈øome Chymi≈øts u≈øe it in the preparation of Tincture of Coral. Do≈øe is from gut. 10. ad 40. plusminus, in any proper Vehicle. Infinite Di≈øea≈øes almo≈øt, ≈øaith Marggrave, are cured by this Medicine.

div.head: XXIII. * Spiritus Rhoeados crapularius, the Surfeit Spirit of the Red, Wild, or Corn Poppy.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Corn Poppy Flowers new gathered lb j. Caraway≈øeeds ‚Ñ•ij. Nutmegs ‚Ñ•j. Ambergri≈øe gr. iv. Spirit of Wine lb iv. dige≈øt S. A. ≈øtrain out, and keep it for u≈øe. Do≈øe ‚Ñ•iv. at the hours of ≈øleep, or in the Morning after a Surfeiting. It is a Specifick al≈øo in the Pleuri≈øie.

Salmon.] 1. ¬ß 1. The body of the Ambergri≈øe ought to be opened as we have formerly directed at Sect. 4. aforegoing, whereby it will perform four times as much as it would otherwi≈øe. ¬ß 2. That the Spirit of Wine here intended, is only common Spirit of Wine or Brandy for otherwi≈øe it could not be, given in ≈øo large a Do≈øe as our Author here pre≈øcribes it in. ¬ß 3. That it is not only an excellent thing again≈øt Surfeiting and Drunkenne≈øs, as al≈øo the Pleuri≈øie, but al≈øo again≈øt all manner of Pains, and Stitches in the Sides, Brea≈øt, and Stomach, the Colick, and Griping of the Guts, Pains in the Back, Reins, and Bladder, but indeed again≈øt all manner of Pains in any part of the Body: it gently provokes Sweat, di≈ø≈øolves coagulated Blood, and gives relief again≈øt the ≈øtronge≈øt Agonies. ¬ß 4. The Do≈øe is from ‚Ñ•j. to iv. according to the Age, and Condition of the Sick; it may be given either alone, ≈øweetned with white Sugar; or in Ale, Wine, or Aqua Lactis Alexiteria, &c. chiefly at Night going to Bed.

div.head: XXIV. Spiritus Salis Armoniaci, Spirit of Sal Armoniack.
div.p:
Bate.] ‚Ñû Sal Armoniack p. j. Calx Vive, p. ij. Water p. iij. mix and di≈øtil in Sand, S. A. It is Diuretick, Diaphoretick, and Inciding; it
re≈øi≈øts putrefaction, and is mo≈øt powerful again≈øt Feavers; Do≈øe √† gut. vj. ad xij. &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Various are the Ways and Proportions which Authors have pre≈øcribed in the making of this Spirit, which becau≈øe we would not leave the Arti≈øt in the dark, and are willing to ea≈øe him of the labour of ≈øearching of many Books, we ≈øhall here take the pains to deliver the Summary of all together. ¬ß 2. Le Mort makes it thus: ‚Ñû Sal Ammoniacum lb j. Salt of Tartar lb j. ≈øs. (or in place thereof Pot-a≈øhes) common Water lb j. mix them. Or thus, from the ≈øame Author: ‚Ñû Sal Ammon lb j, Oyl of Tartar, per deliquium lb ij. mix and di≈øtil in a Gla≈øs, or glazed Retort in Sand, with a very gentle Fire, till the volatile Salt begins to ≈øwell, ≈øo will the volatile Salt a≈øcend, which in the following Flegm will be di≈ø≈øolved. Or thus: ‚Ñû Sal Am. lb j, in fine Pouder: Sal Tartari, or other Alcalious Salt lb ij. Water lb iij. mix and di≈øtil with a gentle Fire by a gla≈øed Retort, till about ‚Ñ•xij. is come forth, then cea≈øe. ¬ß 3. Where Note, That if Calx Vice be u≈øed in≈øtead of the Salt of Tartar, the Spirit will come forth much more volatile and fugitive: al≈øo if it be di≈øtilled from Minerals, as Iron, Lapis Hematitis, Calaminaris, &c. it comes forth mo≈øt penetrative. ¬ß 4. This is al≈øo to be noted, That if the Sal Amm. be mixed with Calx Vive, the Spirit goes forth in a mo≈øt volatile Liquor, but never in a volatile Salt, whereas if it be mixt with other Calxes or Salts, the volatile Salt come fir≈øt in a dry form, then the liquid Spirit together with the Flegm, in which the volatile Salt is di≈ø≈øolved. ¬ß 5. Sal Ammon. does ≈øeem to be nothing el≈øe, but a mixture of Sea Salt, and the volatile Salt of Urine, which here is reduced into a ≈øaline volatile Spirit, by the help of a fixt Salt, or other earthy Bodies being mixt. ¬ß 6. Rolfincius advi≈øes to take Sal Am. lb j. A≈øhes lb iv. ≈øo to mix and to di≈øtill by an Alembick in Sand, and then to rectifie the Spirit. ¬ß 7. The Rectification of the Spirit is thus done: ‚Ñû Of the ≈øaid Spirit lb ≈øs. Salt of Tartar, or of Pot-a≈øhes ‚Ñ•ij. mix them in a gla≈øs Retort, and di≈øtil again. ¬ß 8. Marggrave makes it thus: ‚Ñû Sal Am. Salt of Tartar, or a ‚Ä¢ y other Alcalious Salt, ana:
each being in Pouder mix them, and put them into a gla≈øed Retort, with Water q. s. and a very large Receiver well luted, and di≈øtil in Sand; and in three or four hours with a Fire of the third degree, you will have fir≈øt, the coagulated Spirit, or volatile Salt in a dry form, ≈øticking to the ≈øides of the Receiver like Snow: continue the di≈øtillation, that the Spirit may come over, till the ≈øaid dry volatile Salt is brought or di≈ø≈øolved into the ≈øaid Spirit. Then immediately take the Recipient away, keeping the ≈øaid Spirit in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe; what comes after over is only pure Flegm, of little or no u≈øe. ¬ß 9. From this Caput Mort. with Water you may extract a pure white Salt, which Sylvius calls, Sal Febrifugum: which being rightly prepared and ≈øublimed from an earthen Retort, in an open Fire, will go forth for the mo≈øt part, in mo≈øt white Flowers, very penetrating, but not urinous, and of a plea≈øant refrigerating ta≈øte; which ≈øome will have to be a volatile Salt of Tartar. ¬ß 10. Maets makes it thus: ‚Ñû Sal Am. Salt of Tartar, Pot-a≈øhes, ana; mix, (being in Pouder) put them into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, affu≈øe thereon Water, q. s. and di≈øtil with a gentle Fire: ≈øo will you have a potent Spirit of Sal Am. together with its volatile Salt in a dry form, ≈øticking to the ≈øides of the Ve≈ø≈øel. ¬ß 11. Le Febure makes it thus: ‚Ñû Sal Am. in Pouder, Salt of Tartar, ana, mix, put them into a gla≈øs Retort with a wide neck, fitting to it a large Receiver; give a gradual Fire, and in ≈øhort time you will have a volatile Spirit coming over the helm in Liquor, the Salt ≈øubliming into a clear ≈øub≈øtance as white as Camphir; which operation will be done in about four or five hours. The volatile Salt you may di≈ø≈øolve in its own Spirit, and ≈øo keep both together as Spirit of Sal Am. ¬ß 12. Now Sal Am. con≈øi≈øts of a double Nature, as we have above ob≈øerved, viz. of a kind of common Salt as it were fixt; and of a volatile Salt of Urine; the mixture and union of which Salts is ≈øo ≈øtrict, that it is very difficult, almo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible, to bring them over the helm into Liquor, ‚Ä¢ he one without the other, the urinous and volatile carrying along with it the common and fixt Salt; without the addition of ≈øome other Body as Salt of Tartar, Pot-a≈øhes, Calx Vive, &c.
which have the faculty to keep back the acid Salt, to let the urinous and volatile a≈øcend. ¬ß 13. But if you would extract the acid Spirit of the Sal Am. as well as its volatile; the ≈øaid Le Febure does it thus: ‚Ñû Sal Am. Quick-lime A. mix and make them into a pap with ∆≤rine: then di≈øtil in a glowing red hot Iron Retort, having a Tube with a wide Mouth, and an Iron ≈øtopple; put in the matter Cochleatim at the Tube, and immediately ≈øtop it, ≈øo will the Vapours pre≈øently go into the Receiver luted to the ≈øame, which Method continue till all the Ingredients are done: now take all this Liquor in the Recipient, put it into a gla≈øs Cucurbit a Cubit high, and narrow in the neck, cover it with an Alembick-head, and its Recipient, both well luted, and in B. M. give a gradual Fire, that all the volatile Spirit, and urinous Salt may a≈øcend; when no more will ari≈øe, put the remaining Liquor into a Retort, and rectifie it in Sand, ≈øo will you have an acid Spirit, much plea≈øanter than the Spirit of common Salt, and of the ≈øame Virtues; ≈øave, that being compared therewith, it as much exceeds that of common Salt, as a full-grown and perfect Man exceeds a Youth or Child. ¬ß 14. Lemery makes the urinous Spirit thus: ‚Ñû Sal Am. lb j. Calx Vive lb ij. Pouder them apart, and when you have mixed them in a Mortar, put upon them ‚Ñ•iv. of Water, which put pre≈øently into a Retort, who≈øe half mu≈øt remain empty: fit to it a large Receiver, lute the Junctures, and di≈øtil in Sand, beginning the di≈øtillation without Fire, for about a quarter of an hour, then make a gentle Fire, and increa≈øe it gradatim to the ≈øecond degree, and continue it till nothing more comes forth; take off your Recipient, pour out the Spirit immediately into a Vial, turning away your Head as much as may be, to avoid the ≈øubtil Vapours that continually ri≈øe: ≈øtop the Gla≈øs with a Gla≈øs ≈øtopple well ground, or with Wax. ¬ß 15. In this la≈øt Pre≈øcript here is to be ob≈øerved, That before di≈øtillation the Alcali of the Sea Salt had in a manner bound up the volatile Salt in the Sal Am. to loo≈øen which, the un≈ølakt Lime is added who≈øe Alcali de≈øtroys the Acid of the Sea Salt; whence it is, that as ≈øoon as they are mixed together, the volatile uririnous
Spirit begins to ari≈øe and di≈øtil; which Vapours come forth ≈øo plentifully, that you could never be able to put the mixture into the Retort, ≈øhould you not turn away your Head, while your Hands are at work. ¬ß 16. That the Water is added to moi≈øten it, (which Le Febure certainly forgot in his Pre≈øcript) and to liquifie the volatile Salts; for if there were nothing to moi≈øten them, they would ≈øuddenly ≈øublime to the neck of the Retort, and ≈øtopping it altogether, would break it to pieces: but the quantity of the Water ≈øeems to be too little by half: ‚Ñ•viij. of Water is the lea≈øt that ought to be u≈øed. ¬ß 17. By rea≈øon of the ≈øwelling of the Lime after wetting, and the great deal of room the Spirits take to rarifie them≈øelves in, the Retort mu≈øt not be above half full, and the Receiver mu≈øt be very large, that they may circulate with ea≈øe. ¬ß 18. This Spirit is nothing but a ≈øolution of the volatile Salt in Water: if you would ≈øublime and ≈øeparate this Salt there from, put the Spirit into a Matra≈øs with its head, and a Receiver, lute the Joynts with a wet Bladder, and in Sand, with a gentle Fire, you may make the volatile Salt a≈øcend white as Snow; for it will ≈øublime and ≈øtick to the top, and uppermo≈øt parts; which ≈øeparate and keep in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt with a Gla≈øs ≈øtopple. This Salt being dry, more ea≈øily flies away, than when you kept it di≈ø≈øolved in the Water, for which cau≈øe ≈øake it is be≈øt to keep it in a liquid form. ¬ß 19. This Spirit made with Quick-lime is ≈øtronger than that made with Salt of Tartar, &c. becau≈øe the fiery particles of the Quick-lime, quicken the motion of the volatile Salts, much more than the Salt of Tartar can do. ¬ß 20. It is al≈øo to be noted, That the Spirit of Sal Am. thus drawn with Quick-lime, being mixt with Spirit of Wine, will not coagulate; whereas that which is drawn with Salt of Tartar, &c. will. ¬ß 21. When you take away the Receiver from the Alembick, have in readine≈øs a wet cloth to ≈øtop its mouth, that its volatile Vapours may not ≈øtrike your No≈øtrils & Brain, and ≈øo hinder re≈øpiration, and cau≈øe ≈øwooning. ¬ß 22. This volatile Spirit is al≈øo an excellent Men≈øtruum to make precipitations with, it de≈øtroys acids, as do all other volatile Alcalies, and precipitates
Gold after it is di≈ø≈øolved. ¬ß 23. Charras makes it thus: ‚Ñû Good Sal Am. lb j. Salt of Tartar lb j. or in its place Oak A≈øhes lb iv. beat them in a Mortar, and put them in a Cucurbit, in Sand: Sprinkle the mixture with Water ‚Ñ•viij. then immediately, put on the Head with its Receiver, luting the Junctures well, kindle a gentle Fire, and continue it five or ≈øix hours, or till all the volatile Spirit is come over, and the Flowers are ≈øublimed partly into the Head, and partly to the upper part of the Cucurbit, which take and keep for u≈øe. ¬ß 24. Near as ≈øoon as the Water is put in, the Salt of Tartar joyns with the Acid of the Sea Salt, ≈øo that the Sea Salt di≈øingages it≈øelf from the Volatile Salt, thereby giving it the liberty of immediate ari≈øing, partly in the form of a dry Salt, and partly in the form of Spirit, ≈øo that you are forced as ≈øpeedily as may be, to cover the Cucurbit with its Head, &c. ¬ß 25. From all the≈øe Con≈øiderations it evidently appears, that ≈øhould Sal Am. be di≈øtilled alone in its own condition, when expo≈øed to the violence of the Fire, the volatile part of the Sal Am. would do violence to the acid, and ≈øublime it, or carry it up with it, ≈øo that you would have only a mixt Flower of Sal Am. or rather Sal Am. purified, not the pure volatile alcalious Salt alone, but mixed with all its acid, &c, ¬ß 26. It is al≈øo to be ob≈øerved, that th√¥ the mixture of Quick-lime, or a fit Salt, ≈øtops the Acid or Marine Salt from ri≈øing, letting the urinous, volatile part go alone, either in dry Salt or Spirit, yet the action would be very ≈ølow and feeble, did you not mix Water with them, the more firmly to di≈ø≈øolve the marine Salt, and the fixed Salt, and to mix them together, making their conjunction the more facile. So that it appears, the Spirit and volatile Salt are po≈ø≈øible to be ≈øeparated without Water; but then it is more ≈ølowly, and in this ca≈øe, be≈øides ≈øtrong luting of the Junctures, you mu≈øt leave at lea≈øt three quarters of the Cucurbit empty, &c. ¬ß 27. Be≈øides all the≈øe ways of di≈øtilling this Spirit, you may ≈øee ≈øeveral others in our Pharm. Lond. lib. 3. cap. 11. ≈øect. 30, 31, & 32. the la≈øt of which is the Colledge's own Pre≈øcription; but tho≈øe of our Author, and Lemery's ≈øeem to carry away the Bell from all the re≈øt. ¬ß 28. This volatile Spirit may be given a
gut. vj. or x. ad 20. and ≈øome Authors allow it given to 30, yea to 60, in any proper Vehicle, as Bawm, or Carduus Water, Aqua Lactis Alexiteria, &c. it is better given in ≈øome good or proper Cordial or Sudorifick Water than in Broath, becau≈øe Broath being taken hot, the heat would di≈ø≈øipate a good part of the volatile Spirits, before the mixture could po≈ø≈øibly be drunk. ¬ß 29. It is given with good ≈øucce≈øs in the Cure of Malignant Feavers, and all Di≈øea≈øes where Sweating is required. It is of a mo≈øt penetrating nature, revives Apoplecticks and Lethargicks, re≈øolves and attenuates the humours, takes away the ≈øtagnation of the Blood, and cau≈øes it to circulate; re≈øi≈øts putrefaction, takes away all manner of Feavers, ari≈øing from Ob≈øtruction, and powerfully removes the Ob≈øtruction it≈øelf: it cures Quotidians and Tertians, Plague or Pe≈øtilence, and other Di≈øea≈øes proceeding from malignity. It is ≈øaid al≈øo to cure the Epilep≈øie, Pal≈øie, Hy≈øterick Fits, Hypochondriack Melancholy, inveterate Headachs, Heart-burnings, Gouts, &c. It is attenuating, inciding, re≈øolving, penetrating, di≈ø≈øipating, and opening, prevalent again≈øt the Scurvy, and other Chronick Di≈øea≈øes ari≈øing from a morbifick acid, making all the humours fluid, and putting them into motion, whereby, what is preternatural, is the more fit for excretion. It is given al≈øo in Venereal Di≈øea≈øes, and e≈øpecially where Mercury has been given un≈øea≈øonably, unskilfully, or in too great a quantity, for that this Spirit drives and forces the ≈øaid Mercury, lodged in the ≈øeveral parts of the Body thro' the pores of the skin. It is good again≈øt Vapours ari≈øing from the lower parts, and a≈øcending up into the Stomach and Head, as well by ≈ømelling to it, as by taking it inwardly, whereby it removes Vertigo's, and other ill Accidents of the Head and Brain, which interrupt the proper cour≈øe of the Spirits, and the Functions of all the parts; for which rea≈øon it is proper in ≈øwooning Fits, weakne≈øs and palpitation of the Heart, and to di≈ø≈øipate Vapours ri≈øing from the Womb; it kills Worms, and above all things opens the pa≈ø≈øages of the Urine, provided it be mixt with ≈øome fixt Salt or Acid in a proper Vehicle. ¬ß 30. The volatile Salt has the ≈øame Vertues
with the Spirit, but mu≈øt be given in ≈ømaller Do≈øe, viz. √† gr. v. ad xij, plus-minus. div.head: XXXI. Spiritus Sanguinis, Spirit of Man's Blood.

M. ¬ß 2. M. ¬ß 4. div.head: XXXII. Spiritus Saturni, Spirit of Saturn.
div.p: Bate.] It is di≈øtilled by a Retor ‚Ä¢ from purified and rectified Saccharum Saturni, S. A. It is ≈øudorifick, good again≈øt the Plague or Pe≈øtilence, Hypochondriack Melancholy, Burning Fevers, French-Pox, and the like. Do≈øe gut. ij. or iij.

The Spirit of Saturn therefore is inflamable, becau≈øe it contains ≈øome Spirit of Wine, which remains ≈øtill involved in the Vinegar, and was carried with the Acids into the Pores of the Lead, when the Saccharum Saturni was made. This Salt being di≈øtilled, the force of the Fire breaks the Acid, and ≈øets the Spirit of Wine at liberty; ≈øo that the Spirit of Saturn has very little of an acid ta≈øte in it. ¬ß 6. It is al≈øo to be ob≈øerved, that if you take lbj. or ‚Ñ•xvj. of the Saccharum, you will have by di≈øtillation in the Retort, about 3¬º ounces of Liquor, or Spirit, and yet there will be left in the Retort (which is the wonder) about eighteen ounces of a blacki≈øh matter, ≈øo that here an augmentation is evident: Now „Äà math „Äâ the quantity of Lead in the Saccharum: And if you reduce the eighteen ounces of black Matter into Lead, in a Crucible, you will have of
Lead ‚Ñ•10¬æ; and ‚Ñ•ij. of a yellow Earth, like Litharge of Gold, which ≈øeems to be an impurity of the Lead. ¬ß 7. Hence it is apparent, that the Saccharum, as by di≈øtillation it lo≈øes its acid particles, it receives others, which are igneous, in; more in number, and greater in quantity or weight, as appears by the operation: but when again it is reduced in a Crucible into Lead, the particles of the Lead coming together into a Body, expel the fiery particles, ≈øo that the Lead reviving as before, recovers but its fir≈øt weight. ¬ß 8. The Retort ought ≈øcarcely to be ‚Öî full, and the Receiver ought to be very large, becau≈øe the≈øe volatile Spirits flying out with violence, if they ≈øhould not have room enough to play in, might po≈ø≈øibly break the Ve≈ø≈øels. ¬ß 9. Le Febure makes it after this manner: ‚Ñû Pure Cry≈øtalline Saccharum Saturni lb j. di≈ø≈øolve it ≈øeven times one after another in the best Spirit of Vinegar, evaporating every time: then in the hotte≈øt Sea≈øon of the Year di≈ø≈øolve it in a cold Cellar, per deliquium, this Liquor put into a Retort placed in a Reverberatory Furnace upon an earthen Pot, the bottom turned up≈øide down, having about an inch thickne≈øs of Sand or A≈øhes between the ≈øaid bottom and Retort: fit to the neck a very large Receiver, luting the Juncture with all po≈ø≈øible care; which being dry, make a gentle Fire at first, and very ≈ølowly increa≈øe it, till the Receiver is totally filled with white Vapours, but by degrees augment it to the height, and when you ≈øee heavy and red drops fall down, and that the Receipient grows clear of it≈øelf, (which will be in about twenty or twenty four hours) cea≈øe, or put out the Fire. ¬ß 10. This Liquor di≈øtilled over into the Receiver, is four-fold, viz. 1. A ≈øubtil and volatile Spirit. 2. A yellow Oyl. 3. A Phlegm. 4. A red Oyl, which you mu≈øt ≈øeparate one from another by rectification, thus: ¬ß 11. Put them into a clean gla≈øs Retort in B.M. or Sand, with its Recipient, changing the Receiver according to the change of the Liquors coming over. The Volatile and Aetherial Spirits come fir≈øt thr√¥ the neck of the Retort, without framing any Veins therein: next follows the yellow Oyl, which makes oblique and winding Veins; as ≈øoon as which ≈øign does appear, the Receiver mu≈øt be changed: After the yellow Oyl
comes the Flegm in ≈øtreight and direct Veins, which mu≈øt al≈øo be taken away by it≈øelf: And la≈øtly, In the bottom of the Retort you will find the red Oyl remaining. ¬ß 12. This Volatile Spirit of Saturn re≈øi≈øts putrefaction of the Blood and Humours, and cures Hypochondriack Melancholy (given for twenty or thirty days together); it is a wonderful Sudorifick, and therefore is excellent again≈øt the Plague, pe≈øtilential and burning Fevers, Pal≈øie, Epilep≈øie, Apoplexy, French-Pox, Frenzy, Madne≈øs, and other like Di≈øea≈øes afflicting Body or Mind, or both. Vaporo≈øo, in a Circulatory Ve≈ø≈øel hermetically ≈øealed, will become as red as Blood; and then be a great Arcanum again≈øt all Griefs of the Heart and Brain, being given √† gut. j. ad iv. in Spirit of Lilly Convally, Canary, or other proper Liquor. ¬ß 14. The red. Oyl being circulated with equal parts of Oyl of Camphir, and tartariz'd Spirit of Wine for fifteen or twenty days, or longer, and then the S. V. ab≈øtracted with a very gentle heat in B. M. you will have remaining a miraculous Bal≈øamick E≈ø≈øence, which will cure green Wounds in a day or two, at once dre≈ø≈øing, being only ≈ølightly be≈ømeared with a Feather dipt therein; and is be≈øides profitable for the cure of the mo≈øt inveterate Ulcers, di≈ø≈øolves and re≈øolves all Swellings, hinders Accidents in Wounds, wonderfully cures Fi≈øtula's, and growing Cancers, as al≈øo takes away Scurf, Morphew, and Lepro≈øie, and re≈øtores again pined and withered Members; for it is a kind of Mummial Bal≈øam impregnated with the Sulphur of Saturn.

div.p: Bate.] It is di≈øtilled from Sponges by a Retort, and rectified, S. A. It is a ≈øingular Lithontriptick.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû As much Sponge as you plea≈øe, cut it very ≈ømall, put it into a gla≈øs Retort, which place in a clo≈øe Reverberatory, with its Receiver; lute the Juncture well, and give Fire Gradatim, like as in the di≈øtillation of Tartar: and continue to increa≈øe it by little and little, till the white and oily clouds begin to come,
and that you ≈øee the volatile Salt does ≈øublime and ≈øtick to the ≈øides of the Receiver: continue the Fire in the ≈øame degree till all is come forth, and the Receiver grows clear of it ≈øelf. ¬ß 2. Then cea≈øe the Fire, and all being cold, take away the Ve≈ø≈øels, pour out the Spirit and volatile Salt together, and ≈øeparate the Oyl by a Funnel, or ≈øome Cotton, which keep in a Gla≈øs by it≈øelf. ¬ß 3. Put the Spirit and Volatile Salt into a low Gla≈øs Body, and rectifie them in Sand, keeping them together: The Sponge al≈øo calcin'd at the bottom of the Retort after di≈øtillation, you may ≈øave for to ≈øtop violent fluxes of Blood. ¬ß 4. This Spirit, volatile Salt, and Oyl of Sponges, are not only of excellent u≈øe again≈øt the Stone and Gravel, or any other Ob≈øtruction in the Reins and Bladder, or other pa≈ø≈øages of Urine, but are al≈øo profitable again≈øt ≈øtrumous or ≈øcrophulons Swellings, and the Di≈øea≈øe called, Broncoceles, which is a Bunch or Swelling in the Throat: for they not only admirably open, but al≈øo by their acuity of parts, attenuate and re≈øolve much. ¬ß 5. Again≈øt the Stone and Di≈øea≈øes of the Reins and Bladder, you may u≈øe them thus: ‚Ñû Of the Spirit, in which the volatile Salt is di≈ø≈øolved í j. Aquae Fabarum, or in place thereof Petro≈øelini, ‚Ñ•iij. Syrupus Nephriticus, or in place thereof Dialthaea í ij. Pouder of Winter Cherries í ≈øs. mix for three Do≈øes. ¬ß 6. But for a Broncoceles, or Kings-Evil thus: Fir≈øt, Purge the Patient with my Family-Pills, or Pilulae Panchymagogae, or Pilulae Mirabiles, or ≈øome other Purge proper in this ca≈øe, as this: ‚Ñû Fine Scammony gr. xvj. Re≈øin of Jallap, gr. viij. Colocynthis in Pouder ‚Ñàij. mix, and with extract of Colocynthis, make Pills for iij. Do≈øes. Or you may purge with a ≈øimple Extract of Colocynthis alone, made only with common Water, which is an admirable thing, and works well in gr. vj. or viij. This Purging is to be continued all along the Cure, every fourth or fifth day, till the Swelling is wholly gone. ¬ß 7. Then you mu≈øt anoint outwardly with this: ‚Ñû Oyl of Sponges í j. Oyl of bitter Almonds ‚Ñ•j. mix them to anoint with Morning and Evening, applying over all an Empla≈øter of Oxycroceum, or Diachylon, or ≈øome ≈øuch like. ¬ß 8. La≈øtly, Give the Patient every Morning fa≈øting, and every Night going
to Bed, the Spirit mixt with the volatile Salt, after this manner: ‚Ñû Of the Spirit √† gut. xij. ad xx. or xxiv. Ar≈ømart Water ‚Ñ•iij. Syrupi Volatilis í vj. mix for a Do≈øe: Or, giving the ≈øaid mixture at Night going to Bed, give the≈øe following Lozenges, one every Morning fa≈øting: ‚Ñû Of the ≈øtronge≈øt fine Sugar ‚Ñ•iv. Calx of the Sponge aforementioned í ij. Crocus martis a≈øtringens í iij. Long Pepper í j. mix, and make Lozenges, weighing each í ii≈øs. which dry and keep for u≈øe. By following this cour≈øe con≈øtantly, you will evidently and daily ≈øee the≈øe Scrophulous, Strumatick, and Bronchocele Tumours to decrea≈øe, and vani≈øh to nothing. ¬ß 9. In what Cla≈ø≈øis to place Sponge, Authors have ≈øcarcely determined; ≈øome thinking it to be neither Vegetable, Mineral, nor Animal; others thinking it to participate of them all: others place it between Animals and Vegetables, affirming it to partake of both of them; for that, ≈øay they, it has an active quality to dilate it≈øelf, and ≈øhrink up together when it is in the Sea, whereby it enjoys a tenebrous life, coming near to that of an Animal, and to that of a Plant, whence they will have it a Zoophyton, or Plant Animal.

div.head: XXXIV. Spiritus Tabaccae, Spirit of Tobacco.
div.p: Bate.] It is di≈øtilled as that of Amber, from the dried Leaves. Do≈øe √† íj. ad íiij. for Vomiting.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. In handling this Preparation, I hope we ≈øhall evidently demon≈øtrate, That Chimical Phy≈øicians are not contented ≈øimply with the ≈øuperficies, or out≈øide of things, but aim at a farther ≈øcrutiny, viz. to open them, and to penetrate into their in≈øides, and very centers, thereby to find out the whole of what they do contain, ≈øeparating the pure and virtuous parts, the Spirit, Oyl, and volatile Salt, viz. the Pote≈øtates, or Powers, from their impure, faeculent, and earthy parts, that ≈øo they may the more aptly be appropriated and applied to the cure of the Di≈øea≈øes of Humane kind. ¬ß 2. ‚Ñû Of the be≈øt Spani≈øh Tobacco cut ≈ømall lb j. or ‚Ñ•xvj. put upon it an equal weight of Flegm of Vitriol, put on the Cucurbit or Ve≈øica its Head, dige≈øt in Sand for a day or two; fit to it a Receiver, and di≈øtil about ten ounces of Liquor by a gentle Fire, which keep in a Vial by it≈øelf. This is a powerful Vomit, and may
be given √† íij. ad vj. in ≈øome fit Vehicle; outwardly it is good al≈øo to bathe Tettars, Ring-worms, Itch, and ≈øuch like with. ¬ß 3. Put the Magma in the Cucurbit into an Earthen, or Gla≈øs Retort luted, place it in a Furnace with a large Receiver, well luting the Juncture, begin with a ≈ømall Fire to rai≈øe the Flegm, which augment gradatim, and the Spirits will come forth confu≈øedly with a black Oyl; continue the Fire till all is come over, then cool the Ve≈ø≈øels, and unlute them: what you have in the Recipient, put into a Funnel lined with brown Paper, ≈øo will the watery and ≈øpirituous parts pa≈øs through, leaving the black foetid Oyl in the Paper or Filter. ¬ß 4. This Spirit is not u≈øual to be taken inwardly; outwardly you may u≈øe it thus: ‚Ñû Pure yellow Palm Oyl ‚Ñ•ij. of this Spirit í j. mix them. It cures Itch, Tettars, Ring-worms, by anointing therewith. ¬ß 5. The Oyl is too violent to be given inwardly, and therefore ≈øome u≈øe it outwardly thus: ‚Ñû Lapis infernalis q. v. Oyl of Tobacco, ≈øo much as will make an Oyntment, which keep in a dry place. Anoint the pit of the Stomach with gr. v. or vj. and the Patient will pre≈øently vomit; but if you would move the Body downwards, anoint about the Navel therewith, and the ≈øick will pre≈øently fall a purging; where note, 1. That the ≈øick ought to take ≈øome warm Broath, or Po≈ø≈øet-drink in the working. 2. That the Oyntment is not to lie ≈øo long as to cauterize the part to which it is applied. ¬ß 6. But the greate≈øt external u≈øe of this Oyl, is, to con≈øolidate new Wounds, and to cure Cacoethick Ulcers, and to remove all the Accidents of Contu≈øions: becau≈øe it potently re≈øolves the extrava≈øated Blood, and hinders the heat and inflamation, which are always previous to a putrefaction. It is good al≈øo again≈øt the Tooth-ache, and to di≈ø≈øipate the chalky knots proceeding from the Gout, and to di≈ø≈øolve pocky Gums, Nodes, and Tophs, thus: ‚Ñû Palm Oyl ‚Ñ•ij. Oyl of Tobacco í ij. mix for an Oyntment, for the afore≈øaid purpo≈øe. ¬ß 7. This Oyl is be≈øt unrectified, for now it contains both Oyl and volatile Salt, which in conjunction produce tho≈øe rare effects; whereas being rectified it lo≈øes much of the ≈øaid volatile Salt, and becomes le≈øs effectual. Dr. French makes Lozenges of

‚Ä¢ ng in≈øtilled into the Veins of „Äà‚óä„Äâ Dog's Leg, pre≈øently put ‚Ä¢ he Dog into Convul≈øions and Vomiting, and in a ≈øhort time ‚Ä¢ fter kill'd him; from which ‚Ä¢ t appears, that if it be ever given inwardly, it would doubtle≈øs be be≈øt to rectifie it by di≈øtillation, thereby to take away in a great mea≈øure its Empyreuma. ¬ß 10. Then (≈øay Authors) it may be given with happy ≈øucce≈øs again≈øt Suffocations, Fits of the Mother, Ri≈øings, Vapours, Inflations, and Irritations of the Spleen, which cau≈øe ≈øhortne≈øs of breath, by rea≈øon of the compre≈ø≈øion of the Diaphragma, or Midriff. It is good al≈øo again≈øt intermitting Feavers, given a little before the Fit comes; and is a good Antepileptick Remedy, exhibited upon the Full of the Moon, two or three days before and after in Spir. Theriacalis camphorated, volatile Spirit of Harts-horn, or Mixtura Simplex. ¬ß 11. In giving this Oyl, (if not made up into Lozenges) you mu≈øt drop it upon pure white Sugar, √† gut. ij. ad iv. and then mix it with any appropriate Vehicle; for example, again≈øt an Epilep≈øy: ‚Ñû Mixtura Simplex í j. of this Oyl gut ij. ad iv. dropt into white Sugar: Bawm Water ‚Ñ•iij. Syrup of Clove-gilliflowers í vj. mix for a Do≈øe. Again≈øt intermitting Feavers you may give it thus: ‚Ñû Spir, Theriacli í j. of this Oyl, gut. iij. or iv. Centaury Water ‚Ñ•iv. Syrup of Citron-peels ‚Ñ•j. mix for a Do≈øe. ¬ß 12. But as this Oyl is not often
given inwardly, except upon great nece≈ø≈øities, when no other Remedies are to be found; ≈øo being re≈øerved for external u≈øes, it is be≈øt without rectifying, and ≈øo is much more powerful to the intentions propo≈øed, as then comprehending within it, its volatile Salt, which being rectified, it will be in the greate≈øt part deprived of. ¬ß 13. From the Faeces in the Retort by Calcination and Elixiviation, &c. you may have a fixed Salt, or Alkali; but in making of it, it will be good to get a larger quantity of A≈øhes, that you may have it the more plentifully. ¬ß 14. This Salt is ≈øaid to po≈ø≈øe≈øs all the Virtues of the Plant, be≈øides which, it mundifies and heals, and is very gentle being applied to foul and running Ulcers, and upon their callous ≈øides, which hinder Cicatrizing: taken inwardly in Broath, it gently moves the Belly, kills Worms, and expels all other Corruptions in the Stomach and Entrails: It is Sudorifick, Diuretick, and Deopilative, removing all Ob≈øtructions in parts adjacent to the Ventricle, chiefly tho≈øe of the Me≈øentery and Pincreas, and takes away all the Impurities of the Womb. The Do≈øe is √† gr. iv. ad xx in any appropriated Liquor. ¬ß 15. Le Febure makes this Spirit and Oyl thus: ‚Ñû Tobacco cut ≈ømall lb iv. put it into a Gla≈øs Retort in a Reverberatory Furnace, upon the Cover of an Earthen Pot turned up≈øide down, and kept up upon two Iron Bars, putting two or three handfuls of Sand or A≈øhes thereon, to hinder the touching of the Earthen Pot and Retort, and prevent its breaking: cover the Furnace, and lute on the Recipient, which being dry, kindle the Fire, increa≈øing it gradually by little and little, till the Recipient begins to be filled with Clouds and Vapours; then keep the Fire in an equality till the Gla≈øs it freed from fumes, which done, give the last and extream degree of Fire, that the Tobacco may calcine, and no volatile, ≈øaline, or oleaginous ≈øub≈øtance may remain behind: when the Recipient grows clear, and no more comes over, let the Fi ‚Ä¢ e go out, take the Receiver, and ≈øhaking all together, pour it out into a Funnel lined with brown Paper, ≈øo will the Spirit filtrate through the Paper, leaving the Oyl behind, as afore directed. ¬ß 16. This Spirit you ought to rectifie in a Gla≈øs Cucurbit from its Flegm; and being ≈øo rectified, it is full of
volatile Salt, whereby it is powerful to deterge, attenuate, and di≈ø≈øolve whatever is again≈øt Nature, of what quality ≈øoever, and in what part ≈øoever contained. It is profitable again≈øt A≈øthma's, and other Oppre≈ø≈øions of the Brea≈øt and Lungs, proceeding from a tartarous matter, which it truly and ≈øpecifically di≈ø≈øolves. It works by Spitting, Urine, and Sweat, and al≈øo provokes Vomiting according to the matter it meets with: outwardly it purifies, clean≈øes, and heals callous and cancerous Ulcers; and above all, admirably cures Fi≈øtula's; it is al≈øo excellent above many other things for fre≈øh Wounds and Contu≈øions, if mixt with Urine, and then part wa≈øht therewith, and afterwards applied warm upon the wounded part. It al≈øo cures the Cry≈øtaline Bladder ari≈øing on the end of the Yard, in the French Di≈øea≈øe, which is one of the mo≈øt pernicious Symptoms that can happen, it appea≈øes the pain, re≈øolves powerfully the venemous matter which cau≈øes it, and prevents the mortal con≈øequences attending it. ¬ß 17. It may be given inwardly in any Specifick Decoction or Water, or in Broth, Hydromel, or Wine, as you ≈øee convenient; and the de≈øign is from gut. iij. ad xx. according to the age and ≈øtrength of the Patient. ¬ß 18. The Oyl aforementioned you may rectifie in this manner: ‚Ñû The Caput Mort. before the Salt is extracted, pouder it, and therewith mix the Oyl, till you have made it into a ma≈øs or lump; put it into a Retort, and in a Sand Furnace, draw off the Oyl; ≈øo will it be very pure and ≈øubtil; which keep for the inward u≈øes aforementioned. Tobacco is a wonderful Plant, and admirable u≈øes may be made of it in the curing of many Di≈øea≈øes, if a wi≈øe Man has it in hand. ¬ß 19. Cli≈ø≈øus Peti, The Powers of Tobacco, are made (according to Le Febure) out of the three Principles of the Plant, viz. the Mercury, or Spirit; Sulphur or Oyl, and Salt, mixt together in a fit proportion, and dige≈øted till an in≈øeparable union is made; which will be more ab≈øolute and perfect, if they be drawn over the helm together, and ≈øeveral times cohobated. This is a much more efficacious remedy than any of the three Principles ≈øeparated; and therefore the Do≈øe mu≈øt be le≈øs in proportion.

div.head: XXXV. Spiritus Theriacalis camphoratus, The Treacle Spirit camphorated.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Venice Treacle ‚Ñ•v. be≈øt Myrrh í x. Engli≈øh Saffron ‚Ñ•≈øs. Camphir í ij. be≈øt rectified Spirit of Wine ‚Ñ•x. dige≈øt and di≈øtil in B. M. cohobating thrice, S. A. It is of egregious u≈øe in all malign Di≈øea≈øes; it provokes Sweat, and re≈øi≈øt Poy≈øon. Do≈øe √† ‚Ñàj. ad íj. &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Rolfincius Artis Chimiae, Lib. 3. Sect. 1. Art. 2. Cap. 23. has this pre≈øcript in a differing proportion, viz. ‚Ñû Venice Treacle ‚Ñ•v. choice Myrrh, í xx. Saffron ‚Ñ•≈øs Camphir í ij. Spirit of Wine ‚Ñ•xx. by which you may perceive that in this the Myrrh and S. V. are compleatly doubled, and he makes the di≈øtillation in a Sand heat, but this in B. M. is much the be≈øt, for ≈øo the Spirit will have no Empyreuma or ≈ømatch of burning. ¬ß 2. It has the power of inciding, attenuating, and re≈øi≈øting malignity; by the tenuity and ≈øubtily of its ≈øub≈øtance it immediately penetrates the univer≈øal Body without any trouble. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
est, malignitatem per ≈øudorem di≈øpellens. It has a place among≈øt the greate≈øt of Cordials, is good again≈øt fainting and ≈øwooning Fits, Palpitation of the Heart, the Colick, Wind in the Bowels, and all ≈øorts of burning and malign Feavers, but chiefly again≈øt the Contagion of the Plague or Pe≈øtilence. ¬ß 3. The Do≈øe of it in way of Cure may be ad íij. but in way of Prevention ad ‚Ñàij. in generous Wine, or ≈øome other appropriate Liquor; but ≈øome Authors allow it to be given to an Ounce in a proper Vehicle. ¬ß 4. Charras in his Royal Pharmacopoeia makes a Treacle Spirit after this manner: ‚Ñû Of the be≈øt Venice Treacle ‚Ñ•v. Roots of Angelica, of Ma≈øter-wort, of Spignel Athamantick, and Valerian the greater, A. ‚Ñ•iij. í vj. Seeds of Bi≈øhops-weed, and Se≈øeli, A. í x. Spirit of Wine rectified lb ij. the Roots and Seeds brui≈øed, digest eight days in S. V. then di≈øtil in B. M. S. A. This, if you plea≈øe, you may make camphorated with three drams of Camphire. ¬ß 5. It has the Virtues of the former, and powerfully re≈øi≈øts and ≈øorts of Poy≈øons, and may be given a íj. ad íiv. in Canary, or any other Cordial Liquor: Some drops of it being dropt upon the palms of the hands, may be gently rubbed together, and then immediately
drawn up the No≈øtrils again≈øt the pain of the Head, Megrim, or other Di≈øtempers of the Brain, as al≈øo applied to the Temples and Sutures of the Skull, and Pit of the Stomach.

div.head: XXXVI. Spiritus Veneris, Spirit of Venus, or Copper.
div.p: Bate.] It is di≈øtilled by a Retort from the Vitriol of Venus, S. A. It is the greate≈øt Arcanum for the Cure of the Epilep≈øy, it corroborates the Ventricle, corrects Crudities, warms a cold Womb, cures the Suffocation thereof, or Fits of the Mother, moves or provokes the Cour≈øes, and ≈øtrengthens the Reins to perform their duty. Do≈øe √† gut. v. ad. x.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. In Our Doron Medicum, Lib. 2. Cap. 2. Sect. 19. we have given you a full and large de≈øcription of the Spirit of Venus, ≈øhewing you its compleat Preparation, as well as its Virtues, U≈øes, and Do≈øe. But there are ≈øeveral other ways of preparing thereof, which we now come to declare. ¬ß 2. Spiritus & Crocus Veneris Marg-gravii. ‚Ñû Verdigri≈øe in fine Pouder lb ≈øs. put it into a Gla≈øs Retort, and di≈øtil in Sand with Fire of the third degree, for five or ≈øix hours, or till no more will come forth; ≈øo will you have ‚Ñ•iv. of Liquor. Take this di≈øtilled Liquor, and di≈øtil it by a Gla≈øs Retort to drine≈øs, ≈øo have you Spirit of Venus rectified and pure, which Zwelfer calls the Liquor Alcahe≈øt. The Caput Mort. left in the fir≈øt di≈øtillation, edulcorate, or wa≈øh oftentimes with warm Water, and dry it; ≈øo have you Crocus Veneris. ¬ß 3. This Spirit or Alkahe≈øt or Zwelfer is an admirable di≈ø≈øolvent of Mars, Venus, Corals, and other Stones; being taken into the Body, it attenuates gro≈øs humors, and opens all manner of Ob≈øtructions, taking away the vi≈øco≈øity of the pa≈ø≈øages, it ≈øtrengthens the Stomach and created dries and a≈øtringes, ≈øtops Haemorrhagies, and is u≈øed in drying and a≈øtringing Oyntments and Empla≈øters. ¬ß. 4. Maets makes it after this manner: ‚Ñû Verdigri≈øe, or rather Cry≈øtals of Venus, q. v. to which add a half part of Alum calcined, (i. e. of the Caput Mort. after its Spirit is drawn off) mix and di≈øtil in an earthen Retort, or a Gla≈øs one well luted in an open Fire, till all the Fumes cea≈øe, which Spirit rectifie from its flegm, as before directed. ¬ß 5. This
Spirit is an egregious Men≈øtruum for extracting the Tinctures from the Gla≈øs of Antimony, as al≈øo from its Minera, and the Crocus's and Calces of other Metals, exceeding indeed all other Spirits of Vinegars. ¬ß 6. Lemery makes it thus: ‚Ñû Cry≈øtals of Venus q. v. put them into a Gla≈øs Retort, filling it ‚Öî full, place it in Sand, fit to it a large Receiver, lute well the Juncture, and give a ≈ømall Fire at fir≈øt, to drive out the in≈øipid Flegm, after which will follow a volatil Spirit. Augment the Fire gradatim, and the Recipient will fill with white Clouds; towards the latter end, kindle Coals round about the Retort, encrea≈øing the Fire to the la≈øt degree, to force over all the Spirits. When the Clouds di≈øappear, and the Recipient grows cool, put out the Fire, unlute and decant the di≈øtilled Spirit into a Gla≈øs Body, drawing off the Spirit again to drine≈øs: this is Spirit of Venus rectified. ¬ß 7. It is a Specifick again≈øt the Epilep≈øy, Pal≈øie, Apolexy, and other Di≈øea≈øes of the Head and Brain: it may be given √† gut. v. ad x. or xij. in any convenient Vehicle. The black ma≈øs at bottom may be revived into Copper, if put into a Cucurbite in a fire of fu≈øion, with a little Saltpeter, or Tartar. ¬ß 8. In making this Spirit from the Cry≈øtals of Venus, you will have ‚Ñ•viij. from xvj. of the Vitriol, ‚Ñ•viij. of Caput Mort. remaining behind. ¬ß 9. And th√¥ Zwelfer ≈øays, that this Spirit will di≈ø≈øolve Coral and Pearl without loo≈øing any thing of its force or ≈øtrength, ≈øo that when you would u≈øe the ≈øame numerical Spirit again, it ≈øhall do again the ≈øame operation upon new matter, yet Experience has not confirmed this a≈ø≈øertion; for th√¥ it may come off from the di≈ø≈øolved matter with a great deal of ≈øharpne≈øs, yet has it lo≈øt a great part of its acidity wherein the force of the Men≈øtruum lay: and by many reiterated Operations upon new matter Operations upon new matter, it will come off at length very weak, and almo≈øt in≈øipid. ¬ß 10. Charras makes it thus: ‚Ñû Cry≈øtals of Venus made of Verdigri≈øe, affu≈øe on them (in fine Pouder) S. V. rectified, ≈øo much as may overtop it four inches, which in a Sand heat ab≈øtract, and cohobate twice or thrice more, to qualifie the Acrimony of the Vitriol: then being dry, and in Pouder put it into a Retort, and di≈øtil as before directed in a clo≈øe Furnace of Reverberation, with a large Recipient: reiterate the di≈øtillation as al≈øo cohobation of the Spirit di≈øtilled upon the ≈øediment, and make a third di≈øtillation: ≈øo will you have a Spirit impregnated with the most e≈ø≈øential parts of the Crocus Veneris. ¬ß 11. This Spirit is a Specifick again≈øt the Epilep≈øy-Appolexy, Convul≈øions, Lethargy, Coma, Carus, and other Di≈øea≈øes of the Head, Brain, and Womb. It is highly e≈øteemed again≈øt the Jaundice, illne≈øs and weakne≈øs of the Stomach, want of Appetite, and to break the Stone in the Reigns and Bladder. Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The intention of this Pre≈øcription is perfectly

This Spirit is ≈øeldom u≈øed ≈øimply of it≈øelf again≈øt any Di≈øea≈øe, yet it mightily ≈øweetens the Blood, chears the Spirits, warms the chilled Blood and Humors, di≈ø≈øolves Coagulations of the Juyces, is good again≈øt the Scurvy, and provokes Urine. ¬ß 6. div.head: XXXIX. Spiritus Viperarum, Spirit of Vipers.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû Vipers Fle≈øh dried and ≈øhred ≈ømall, q. v. put it into an earthen Retort, or a gla≈øs one coated, place it in a clo≈øe Reverberatory with a large Receiver, lute the Juncture well, and di≈øtil fir≈øt with a very gentle Fire to warm the Retort, driving out the Flegm drop by drop; when no more drops fall, increa≈øe the Fire by little and little, ≈øo will the Spirit come forth, filling the Receiver with white Clouds, and afterwards a black Oyl, and the volatile Salt ≈øticking to the ≈øides of the Receiver. Thus have you a mo≈øt excellent Medicine, and one of the mo≈øt abominable ≈øcents upon Earth, made one of the greate≈øt Fragrancies in the whole World: it may be given from gut. xij. ad xxx. in Wine, or any other proper Liquor again≈øt fainting of the Spirits, Weakne≈øs, Con≈øumptions, Epilep≈øies, Apoplexies, and in a word, again≈øt all Di≈øea≈øes the volatile Spirit or volatile Salt are prevalent again≈øt. ¬ß 7. Now in the di≈øtillation of Vipers this is to be noted, that the Receiver mu≈øt be large, that the Spirits may circulate with the greater ea≈øe, and the Fire gentle and gradual, lea≈øt the too ha≈øty ru≈øhing forth of the Spirit ≈øhould break the Ve≈ø≈øels. ¬ß 8. This e≈ø≈øentificated Spirit of Vipers has all the Virtues of the volatile Salt, and this advantage over and above, that it may better be pre≈øerved, being one of the be≈øt and noble≈øt Antidotes in the World, worthy the Clo≈øets of the greate≈øt of Princes. Salmon.] ¬ß 1. In our Pharm. Lond. lib. 3. cap. 11. ≈øect. 78. you have the Colledge's way of di≈øtilling this Spirit and Oyl, with our Annotations thereon, which in that re≈øpect are enough: but by rea≈øon ≈øeveral Men have ≈øeveral ways or methods of doing the ≈øame, from whence new Ob≈øervations may ari≈øe, and that they are al≈øo equally nece≈ø≈øary to be known to the ingenious Phy≈øician, we ≈øhall take the pains here to relate them. ¬ß 2. From Marg-gravius. ‚Ñû Vitriol calcined and poudred lb x. put it into a ≈øtrong earthen Retort, or a gla≈øs one well covered with lute; di≈øtil in an open Fire for twenty four hours, ≈øo will you have Flegm and Spirit come over together: which by rectification you mu≈øt ≈øeparate: then change your Receiver, and di≈øtil with a Reverberating Fire for twenty four hours more, ≈øo will you have a mo≈øt potent and ≈øtrong Oyl, which is the Oleum Vitrioli verum Paracel≈øi; which being mixt with Water will make an Efferve≈øcence. ¬ß 3. Now here is to be noted, that in the beginning of this di≈øtillation, the Fire ought to be ≈ømall for the fir≈øt ≈øix or eight hours, this brings off the Flegm: then it ought to be increa≈øed by degrees to the ≈øecond and third degree of Reverberation for eight hours more, and then urged for the next eight hours to the fourth degree, ≈øo have you Spirit and Flegm in one ma≈øs together, which (as I ≈øaid before) by rectification are to be ≈øeparated: la≈øtly, for the other twenty four hours, the Fire is continued in that ≈øame fourth degree for eliciting the Oyl of Paracel≈øus. ¬ß 4. ¬ß 5. According to Maets thus: ‚Ñû Engli≈øh or Hungarian Vitriol calcined to whitene≈øs, put it in gro≈øe pouder or bits into an earthen Retort, di≈øtil in an open Fire fir≈øt with a gentle heat, ≈øo have you Flegm with a volatile Spirit: then increa≈øe the Fire till the Retort grows red hot, ≈øo have you the volatile acid Spirit. Le Mort's Oleum Vitrioli martis. ‚Ñû Vitriol of Iron lb v. calcined and poudred put it into a Retort ≈øo as it may not be above half full, (which thing you ought to ob≈øerve in the former) add a large Receiver, luting the Joynt well, and then di≈øtil: Flegm comes first, then the Spirit and Oyl, the ≈øign of which is, that the Recipient will be full of white Vapours: continue the Fire in the highe≈øt degree; ≈øo in the ≈øpace of eight hours you will have a pound of Oyl or more, according to the goodne≈øs of the Vitriol. ¬ß 7. Now to rectifie this, put all into a gla≈øs Retort, and di≈øtil fir≈øt with a gentle Fire, ≈øo will a little Flegm come forth, with a ≈øulphurous volatile Spirit: next comes forth the acid Spirit, leaving the mo≈øt ≈øharp Oyl, like limpid Water in the bottom. ¬ß 8. In this operation you mu≈øt note, that if your Vitriol be not well calcined, you will have ≈øo much the more Flegm, and it will need ≈øo much the more rectification: be≈øides, in the fir≈øt di≈øtillation it will endanger the breaking of the Ve≈ø≈øels. ¬ß 9. That the Vitriol of Mars yields more Oyl, and le≈øs of the volatile Spirit, whereas the Vitriol of Venus yields a much le≈øs plenty of Oyl, and a far greater quantity of a mo≈øt grateful Spirit, like Spirit of Sulphur per Campanum. ¬ß 10. That the whole quantity of Oyl of Vitriol may according to Le Mort be converted into Spirit after this manner: ‚Ñû Oyl of Vitriol ‚Ñ•j. Common Water ‚Ñ•iv. mix, and put them into a gla≈øs Retort, di≈øtil in Sand, and the Flegm will come forth; then a
volatile Spirit, leaving a heavy Oyl in the bottom, a third, or at lea≈øt a quarter part dimini≈øhed: Repeat the di≈øtillation, by mixing more Water with the Oyl, and ≈øo often repeat this work till the whole Oyl is converted into Spirit. ¬ß 11. Le Febure having drawn off his Ros Vitrioli from the crude Vitriol, ≈øo long till no more will come, as we have already taught, places the Cucurbit in a Sand heat, with an Alembick Head and Receiver, and increa≈øes the Fire till the Head of the Alembick is filled with white Vapours, and continues it till no more drops of Liquor will fall from it: this acid Liquor he al≈øo ≈øaves, being a Flegm of Vitriol mixed with ≈øome of the volatile Spirit, which, ≈øays he, is not to be de≈øpi≈øed, for th√¥ it has but little acidity in it, yet it partic ‚Ä¢ pates of the volatile, aperitive, and anodyn Virtue of the Vitriol, which makes it ≈øucce≈øsfully u≈øed for clean≈øing the Reins, and healing all inward Corro≈øions, quenches Thri≈øt in Feavers, and provokes Urine abundantly. If you add a little Saccharum Saturni to it, it will take away Inflamations, Pains, and ≈øharpne≈øs of the Eyes, heal malignant Ulcers in them, they being wa≈øht with it warm. Then he proceeds to making the acid Spirit and Corro≈øive Oyl thus: ‚Ñû The matter la≈øt left in the Cucurbit, beat it into a gro≈øs Pouder, put it into an earthen or gla≈øs Retort well luted, place it in a clo≈øe Reverberatory, with a capacious Receiver, well luting the Juncture, give a gradual Fire, as in di≈øtilling Spirit of Salt, but higher and longer, with the flame of dry Wood for the ≈øpace of three days and nights without cea≈øing, viz. till the Receiver (filled with white Clouds and Vapours in the di≈øtilling) grows clear: the di≈øtilled Liquorice put into a gla≈øs Retort, and di≈øtil in Sand with a gradual Fire, till the drops begin to fall, which ta≈øte from time to time, to change the Recipient as ≈øoon as you perceive them to have an acidity: having drawn off two parts of the Liquor, remove the Fire, ≈øo have you three ≈øeveral Liquors. 1. An almo≈øt in≈øipid Liquor, containing the volatile Spirit with a ≈øulphurous ≈ømell. 2. A plea≈øant acid Liquor, called the acid Spirit of Vitriol. 3. The remaining Oyl in the Retort, which you may purifie by filtrating
it through Gla≈øs beaten into fine Pouder, (for it would corrode all other ≈øub≈øtances) commonly called Oyl of Vitriol. ¬ß 13. Le Febure's ≈øweet Spirit of Vitriol. ‚Ñû Vitriol calcin'd between yellow and red lb iij. put it into a Cucurbit in Pouder, add Spirit of Vinegar ≈øo much as to reduce it to a pa≈øte: ≈øtir without cea≈øing putting in ≈øtill new Spirit of Vinegar, till it is three inches high: put the Cucurbit into B. Vaporo≈øo, cover it with a blind head, and dige≈øt in a gentle heat for three whole days: the fourth day decant the Vinegar, and add more fre≈øh Spirit in the room of it; dige≈øt again three days and decant; thus proceed ≈øeven times, every time adding fre≈øh Spirit of Vinegar: at length filtrate all the Spirit or Tincture, put it into a Cucurbit in A≈øhes, and draw off the ≈øuperfluous Men≈øtruum by di≈øtillation with a ≈ølow and gradual Fire, till the Magma is as thick as Honey: this make into a ma≈øs with calcin'd Pebbles, which put into a Retort, and with a gradual Fire, in twenty four or thirty hours ≈øpace, draw off an Oyl and Spirit, which rectifie in a Gla≈øs Retort in Sand, and keep it for u≈øe. ¬ß 14. This Spirit or Oyl, is of a plea≈øant ≈øweeti≈øh ta≈øte, having in it the Virtues of the Vitriol, mixt with tho≈øe of the Spirit of Vinegar. It may be given in all Di≈øea≈øes proceeding from a Tartarous matter, as the Stone, Gravel, Scurvy, Gout, Rheumati≈øm, Catarrhs, French Pox, and generally in all Di≈øea≈øes proceeding from gro≈øs and ≈øharp Sero≈øities, as Lepro≈øie, Scabs, Herpes, Itch, Tettars, Ring-worms, &c. for this wonderful Spirit rectifies the whole Ma≈øs of Blood, by Urine, Sweat, and in≈øen≈øible tran≈øpiration.
