Charras after he has drawn his Ros Vitrioli, and acid Water following it in a Sand heat, Takes the Vitriol in the Cucurbit, beats it into Pouder, and fills an earthen Retort three quarters full with a large Receiver, and in a clo≈øe Reverberatory with a gradual Fire increas'd to the utmo≈øt violence, draws forth the Spirit. ¬ß 16. This Spirit he rectifies, by putting it into a gla≈øs Cucurbit covered with its Head and Receiver, di≈øtilling in Sand fir≈øt with a gentle heat, by which the volatile, ≈øubtil, penetrating, ≈øulphurous Spirit is drawn off, and kept in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt by it ≈øelf: then continuing the Fire the Flegm ari≈øes:
after that, an acid Spirit, leaving at the bottom of the Cucurbit the heavy Spirit, commonly called Oyl of Vitriol. ¬ß 17. According to Rolfincius: ‚Ñû Roman Vitriol lb xxv. calcine to whitene≈øs, and the ab≈øumption of its humidity, the Ve≈ø≈øels being cold, take the ma≈øs, which will be about lb xiv. and put it into an earthen Retort in a Reverberatory Furnace, with a large Receiver, ob≈øerving degrees of Fire for the ≈øpace of three or four days, till all the Spirit and Oyl is come over, which rectifie in a Cucurbit, ≈øeparating the Spirit, Flegm, and Oyl, as before directed. ¬ß 18. Zwelfer ≈øays, That the Retort is to be filled not above half full, and that the Receiver ought to be long, and have a large neck, becau≈øe of the violence and impetuo≈øity with which the Spirits come forth; that the Fire is to be very gentle while the Flegm is a coming forth, which ought to di≈øtil drop by drop, for the ≈øpace of ten or twelve hours: then the Fire by degrees being increa≈øed, white Clouds will break or come forth, which will fill the Retort, and Receiver al≈øo; and that this di≈øtillation is to be continued with the highe≈øt violence of the Fire for the ≈øpace of two days, till the whole radical humidity, viz. Spirit and Oyl (improperly ≈øo called) are come forth, and all the ≈øaid white Clouds cea≈øe to appear. ¬ß 19. Lemery makes it thus: ‚Ñû Vitriol calcined to whitene≈øs lb viij. put it into an earthen Retort, ≈øo as to fill it about three quarters full: place it in a clo≈øe Reverberatory, with a very large Receiver: give a very ≈ømall Fire to make the Flegm come forth which remained yet in the Vitriol. As to the choice of the Vitriol, Lemery advi≈øes to take green Engli≈øh Vitriol, ≈øuch as (≈øaith he) being rubbed upon Iron, does not at all change colour, which ≈øhews that it does not partake of Copper, as the German does, that looks a little blewi≈øh, and is more acrimonious. ¬ß 22. When the volatile ≈øulphurous Spirits come, you mu≈øt then be very careful of the Fire, for they come with a great deal of violence, and will break the Retort, if driven too furiou≈øly. They being come forth, you mu≈øt then augment the Fire to the highe≈øt and la≈øt degree of all, for the acid Spirit will not part with its Earth, unle≈øs forced by an extraordinary heat. ¬ß 23. From lbviij. of Vitriol calcin'd (≈øixteen Ounces to the pound) you will have of Flegm ‚Ñ•xvij. of the volatile ≈øulphurous Spirit, and acid Spirit together ‚Ñ•xxii≈øs. of which twenty two Ounces and half, there will be of the volatile ≈øulphurous Spirit about four or five Ounces: and in the Retort you will have lbv.‚Ñ•v. of Colcothar. ¬ß 24. That if you u≈øe German Vitriol in≈øtead of Engli≈øh, you may have a little more Spirit than the proportion named, by rea≈øon of the Copper particles contained in the Vitriol, it would ≈ømell ≈øomething like A F. and the matter remaining in the Retort would be of a brown or darker colour. ¬ß 25. That no other Body is added to Vitriol in di≈øtillation, as in the di≈øtillation of Nitre, becau≈øe its own Body contains Earth enough. ¬ß 26. the Fire being little or none of it lo≈øt through the pores, may the better act upon the Retort. ¬ß 27. That ≈øome in di≈øtilling Vitriol continue the Fire for four or five days together: and that if it ≈øhould be continued for three or four days longer, there would come forth a congealed Oyl of Vitriol, and Cau≈øtick, which is nothing but the more fixt part of the Spirit of Vitriol, or common Oyl. ¬ß 28. That all acid Spirits are only salts made fluid by force of Fire, they thereby being di≈øengaged for their terre≈øtious parts; and that they may again be revived by affu≈øing them upon ≈øome proper Alcali. If into a Tincture of Violets, or of the Sun-flower, you drop Sp. Vitrioli, it will pre≈øently make it red; put into it Ol. Tartari, or of Pota≈øhes, and it will recover its former colour again. Vitrioli, and it will be an ob≈øcure red. So al≈øo, a decoction of Brazil, Logwood, or Brazilletto, being very red, if you drop into it Spirit of Vitriol, it turns it yellow; and then if you add Volatile Spirit of Sal Armoniack, it will become black: if al≈øo you drop Oyl of Tartar into Claret, it becomes greeni≈øh, but adding a little Spirit of Vitriol it returns to its former colour again, &c. Some
Authors put Vitriol into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit in an A≈øh heat, covered with its Head and Receiver, and well luting the Junctures, with a moderate heat they draw off the Flegm and acid Spirit, or Ros Vitrioli, as much as they can force to a≈øcend; then they cohobate the di≈øtilled Liquor upon the Paeces, di≈øtilling and cohobating ≈øeven or eight times and redoubling the heat in the la≈øt di≈øtillation, they at length draw forth a Flegm mixt with much acid Spirit, which is of a very grateful odour, being circulated in a Sand heat with a Fire of dige≈øtion, in a Gla≈øs well clo≈øed. ¬ß 33. The Virtues of the volatile ≈øulphurous Spirit of Vitriol. It is good again≈øt Pal≈øies, A≈øthma's, and Di≈øea≈øes of the Lungs, it al≈øo di≈ø≈øipates pains of the Head, ea≈øes the Megrim, and cures the Epilep≈øy, and Apoplexy, and indeed mo≈øt Di≈øea≈øes of the Head, Nerves, Brea≈øt, and Lungs, it opens, cuts, attenuates, ab≈øterges, re≈øolves vi≈øcous humors, re≈øi≈øts putrefaction, and heals Ulcers of the Lungs, and Spitting Blood. The Virtues of the acid Spirit of Vitriol. It is Diuretick, Diaphoretick, Aperitive,
and Inciding, re≈øi≈øts Putrefaction, and allays Inflamations, wherefore it is of great force again≈øt all burning Feavers, occa≈øioned by putrid and malignant Humours, as al≈øo again≈øt Ob≈øtructions of the Liver, Spleen, and Me≈øentery; it re≈øtores Appetite when lo≈øt, ≈øtrengthens the Faculties of the Stomach, correcting its defects It ea≈øes the Tooth-ache, if mixt with White-wine, and held in the mouth: and if mixt with Water or Juyce of Celandine, it cures the Scurf, Scab, and Scald of the Head, by wa≈øhing it therewith, de≈øtroying it in its root, and killing that ≈øharp, acid, corro≈øive and malign humour which cau≈øes it: in a word, it is a perfect Cure for the Scurvy, and a mo≈øt admirable thing given dietetically again≈øt a Gonorrhoea, and the Reliques of the French Di≈øea≈øe: I ≈øpeak by the Experience I have had of it in many Patients, in tho≈øe Di≈øea≈øes. ¬ß 35. The Virtues of the Corro≈øive Oyl of Vitriol: Le Mort, and mo≈øt other Authors, ≈øay, it is not given inwardly, by rea≈øon of its corro≈øive and catheretic quality, &c. but now with us it is daily given as the acid Spirit, being mixt with fit and appropriate Vehicles, and has all the ≈øame medical Virtues. div.p:
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. There are ≈øeveral ways to di≈øtil the Spirit of Guajacum, of which the two following are chief: ‚Ñû Ra≈øpings of Guajacum, q. v. ≈øo much as may fill your Ve≈ø≈øel two thirds full, pour upon it Rain-water, ≈øo much as may nearly fill the Ve≈ø≈øel, and with Sugar make it to ferment eight or ten days: Or, ‚Ñû Ra≈øpings of Guajacum, q. v. put upon them White-wine, or other ∆≤rine q. s. dige≈øt forty eight hours: Or, ‚Ñû Ra≈øpings, q. v. Or thus: ‚Ñû Guajacum ra≈øped, or cut into ≈ømall bits or chips lbvj. put them into an earthen Retort, in a clo≈øe Furnace of Reverberation, with a large Recipient; make a very ≈ømall Fire at fir≈øt, only by degrees to heat the Furnace and Retort, for about an hour; then increa≈øe it by degrees, till you ≈øee the watery part of the Wood to come over into the Recipient; continue and increa≈øe the Fire a little more, till you ≈øee white Vapours come out of the Retort like Clouds, which are a Sign that the acid Salt and oily parts of the Guajacum begin to come forth: at which time open the Cover to the Duomo, and increa≈øe the Fire more and more, till your large Receiver looks clear, at what time your di≈øtillation will be compleated; thus have you an acid Spirit repleat with a volatile Salt of Guajacum, and a blacki≈øh ≈øtinking Oyl. ¬ß 3. Lemery advi≈øes to fill a a large Retort three quarters full of the ≈øhavings or chips of Guajacum, and in a large Reverberatory with a great capacious Receiver, di≈øtil, fir≈øt with a very gentle Fire, only to warm the Retort, and to di≈øtil the Water or Flegm, continue it in this condition till there comes no more drops, which is a ≈øign that all the Flegm is come off: fit again the Receiver to the neck of the Retort, luting the Juncture well, then increa≈øe the Fire gradatim,
≈øo will the Spirit and Oyl come forth in white Clouds, continue the Fire till no more will come, let the Ve≈ø≈øels cool, and unlute them. ¬ß 4. Then put that which is in the Retort into a Funnel lined with brown Paper, ≈øo will the Spirit pa≈øs through, leaving the thick, black, and very fetid Oyl behind in the Paper, which being ≈øet into another Bottle, and the lower part of the Paper being pierced with a Bodkin, the Oyl will al≈øo drop through, which you may keep for u≈øe: Or you may rectifie it by mixing it with as much Sand, Bone-a≈øhes, or Tobacco-pipe-Clay in Pouder, as will make it into a Pa≈øte, and then putting it into a Retort, place it in a Furnace in a nacked Fire; you may draw off the Oyl by a moderate Di≈øtillation, which will be much more pure than it was before. ¬ß 5. If you make the Spirit by ¬ß 2. it ought to be rectified in a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, over a Sand heat, with its Head and Receiver; and having ≈øeparated the almo≈øt in≈øipid Water, which will fir≈øt a≈øcend, receiver and keep a part the ≈øpiritous and volatile acid and ≈øalt part, which will ≈øucceed, and be attended with an o ‚Ä¢ y Volatile, which contains al≈øo itts part of the volatile Salt, and may al≈øo be ≈øeparated and kept apart as well as the acid, and be admini≈øtred inwardly, being mixed with fine poudered Sugar, and given in any fit Liquor. ¬ß 6. This is al≈øo to be ob≈øerved, That during the Di≈øtillation of the Spirit (after the Flegm is come off) you mu≈øt not make the Fire too ≈øtrong, for they coming forth with a great deal of violence, would then be apt to break either the Retort or Receiver. ¬ß 8. Guajacum al≈øo, th√¥ a dry Body, yet yields a great quantity of Liquor: for from 64 Ounces of the Wood, you will have 39 Ounces of Spirit and Flegm, and five Ounces and half of Oyl, and nineteen Ounces of Coals, from which you may extract four or ≈øix Drams of an alcalious or fixt Salt, which Salt is aperitive and ≈øudorifick, and may ≈øerve to fortifie any Vehicle again≈øt the French Di≈øea≈øe, being given from 10. gr. to 30.
¬ß 9. The Spirit of Guajacum is nothing but a di≈ø≈øolution of the e≈ø≈øential Salt of the Wood in a portion of its Flegm. It is Sudorifick and Nephritick; it is much applauded in Di≈øea≈øes of the Bladder, to purifie the Ma≈øs of Blood, ≈øo that ≈øome affirm, that by continuing the u≈øe of it for ≈øeveral Weeks √† íj. ad iij. plus-minus, in its own Water, from four to eight Ounces, it is able to expel and carry off, through the pores of the skin, the Venereal Venom, e≈øpecially if not too inveterate, without making u≈øe of Mercury. The Oyl ≈øtinks above mea≈øure, and therefore is ≈øeldom u≈øed inwardly by rea≈øon of its ill ≈øcent; but outwardly it is ≈øucce≈øsfully u≈øed for the cure of all ≈øorts of Ulcers, chiefly Venereal, to clean≈øe Wounds, and con≈øume proud Fle≈øh, as al≈øo for the opening and exfoliation of Bones, and to re≈øi≈øt Putrefaction. V. rectified, it may be taken inwardly with other Sudorificks, and Alexipharmicks again≈øt the Plague and malign Feavers, as al≈øo again≈øt the French-Pox, Pal≈øie, Apoplexy, Epilep≈øy, Hy≈øterick Fits, Vapours, Pains of the Teeth, and the like; and Authors affirm, that ≈øome have been cured of the Pox, by the con≈øtant u≈øe of this Oyl for ≈øome Weeks, from four to ten or twelve, drops, in a ≈ømall Decoction of the Wood. Inwardly given, al≈øo, it drives forth the Afterbirth: outwardly it is indeed a good thing for rottenne≈øs of the Bones, and to clean≈øe old Ulcers, as I ≈øaid before; al≈øo to ripen Apo≈øthumes and Venereal Bubo's, and re≈øolve cold Tumours. ¬ß 11. Le Mort rectifies the Spirit by its≈øelf in a Retort, and ≈øays, it contains a double Spirit, viz. a volatile and an acid Spirit: both which you may ≈øeparate after this manner: ‚Ñû Spirit of Guajacum lbj. put
it into a Cucurbit, and in B.M. ab≈øtract ‚Ñ•iv. which is the volatile Spirit: what remains in the Cucurbit put into a Gla≈øs Retort, and di≈øtil in Sand; ≈øo will there come forth, fir≈øt an in≈øipid Flegm, which ca≈øt away, then follows the acid Spirit. The volatile Spirit you may again rectifie in B. M. by mixing it with A≈øhes of Guajacum calcined to whitene≈øs, ≈øo will it come forth mo≈øt ≈øubtil and efficacious: Do≈øe of the volatile Spirit is √† gut. vj. ad xxx. of the acid Spirit √† í≈øs. ad íij. or iij. ¬ß 12. div.head: LIV. ‚Ä† Spiritus Lavendulae florum, Spirit of Lavender-flowers.
div.p:
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. You may make this Spirit two ways: 1. By Fermentation: ‚Ñû Green Lavender-flowers, q. s. brui≈øe them, add to them to every lb of the Flowers lb iij. of warm Water; and to every lb iij. of Water, a pound of Sugar, or Melu≈ø≈øos, cau≈øe them to ferment in awooden Ve≈ø≈øel, till it has a kind of Win ‚Ä¢ -like ≈øcent; then di≈øtil, and draw off a third part for Spirit of Lavender: and a ≈øecond third part for Lavender-flower Water, which keep for u≈øe. ¬ß 2. Without Fermentation it is made thus: ‚Ñû Lavender-flowers lb vj. Spirit of Wine lb xviij. mix and dige≈øt twenty four hours, then di≈øtil in a Gla≈øs Body in B. M. drawing off the Spirit to drine≈øs: So will you have a ≈øubtil Spirit endowed with all Properties of the Lavender-flowers. ¬ß 3. The Spirit and the Water have one and the ≈øame Virtue, but differ onely in ≈øtrength, the Spirit having thrice the efficacy of the Water; and therefore may be given in treble Do≈øe. ¬ß 4. This Spirits is hot and dry, Cephalick, Neucrotick, and of thin parts: good again≈øt Di≈øea≈øes of the Head and Nerves, and is u≈øed chiefly in Epilep≈øies, Apoplexies, Pal≈øies, Cramps, Catarrhs, Megrims, Vertigo's, Lethargies, and Trembling. It provokes Urine and the Terms, expels both Birth and After-birth, ea≈øes the Wind; and outwardly applied takes away Pains in the Head, Joynts, and Nerves proceeding from a cold cau≈øe. ¬ß 5. Do≈øe of the Spirit íij. of the Water ívj. in any fit Liquor. ‚Ñû Of this Spirit ‚Ñ•ij. Spirit of
Saffron í j. Poppy and Angelica-water A. ‚Ñ•ij. White Sugar-candy í iij. mix and di≈ø≈øolve for a Do≈øe again≈øt Fainting and Swooning. ¬ß6. You may make this Spirit al≈øo after this manner: ‚Ñû Lavender-flowers lb vj. Manna, Sugar, or Honey lb j. White-wine, in which a little Leven is di≈ø≈øolved, enough to make them into a ≈øoft ma≈øs (the Manna and Flowers being fir≈øt beaten together well in a Mortar) put all into an earthen Pitcher or Jarr, filling it well, and pre≈ø≈øing it down; carefully ≈øtop the mouth with Cork and a little Wax melted, then ≈øet it by to ferment, till it has gotten a Wine-like ≈øcent, or is become ≈øomewhat ≈øour; then take all out, and put it into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit with its Head and Receiver; and di≈øtil in B. M. ≈øo you will have an Ardent Spirit, repleat with the Odour of the Flowers, this, if you ≈øo plea≈øe, you may cohobate upon fre≈øh Flowers, by which means it will become ≈øtronger and more efficacious. ¬ß 7. Now becau≈øe Flowers are very apt to a di≈ø≈øipation of their parts, by rea≈øon of the tenuity of their ≈øub≈øtance, Authors ≈øtrive to recompence this by the addition of ≈øome other parts of the Plant, adding, for Example-≈øake, to Ro≈øes their Hip: To Orange, Lemon, and Citron-flowers, the Fruit well ≈øtampt: To Flowers of Sage, Ro≈øemary, Marjoram, Mint, Bawm, Lavender, Thyme, Stechas, Je≈øamine, &c. their Seeds, well brui≈øed: To the Flowers of Lilly, Flower-de-luces, Peony, Angelica, &c. their Roots and Seeds brui≈øed: To Flowers of Petty Muget, Elder, Dwarf-Elder, &c. their Berries, ¬ß8. Others moi≈øten the Flowers with All-Flower-water, and then di≈øtil in B.M. (after a previous Fermentation) cohobating upon fre≈øh Flowers as often as they plea≈øe. Some u≈øe Spirit of May-dew, in≈øolating fir≈øt, then di≈øtilling and cohobating upon fre≈øh Flowers; affirming, That Spirit of May-dew, and Cowsdung, are very nece≈ø≈øary in the fir≈øt di≈øtillation of Flowers, but not in the latter di≈øtillations, by which means you will have Water perfectly odoriferous, of which one Ounce will be more fragrant than ten Ounces di≈øtilled the ordinary way.

div.head: LV. ‚Ä† Spiritus Limomum, Spirit of Lemon-peels.
div.p:
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It is made exactly as the Spirit of Orange-peels, at Sect. 50. aforegoing,
to which we referr you. In making this Spirit, you mu≈øt be ≈øure to take only the outward yellow rind, which you may pare off with a knife. ¬ß 2. You mu≈øt take this rind while it is yet recent and ≈ømooth, retaining its fragrant ≈ømell, not when it is faded, grown rugged, and half dry: for being fre≈øh, the≈øe rinds have a ≈øubtil and volatile Spirit, which in≈øinuates it≈øelf into the Brain, ≈øtrengthning and recreating both it and the Nerves; whereas being withered and ≈øhrunk, the ta≈øte is unplea≈øant and bitteri≈øh, and void of that vivacity and plea≈øantne≈øs it had before: This being di≈øtilled with rectified Spirit of Wine in B.M. gives you a mo≈øt admirable Spirit beyond all compari≈øon for fragrancy and delicacy: the ≈øame may be done in a Copper Ve≈øica from White-wine, drawing off the one half. ¬ß 3. This Spirit is a mo≈øt excellent Cephalick and Neurotick, curing mo≈øt cold Di≈øea≈øes of the Head and Brain, as Apoplexies, Epilep≈øies, Megrims, Vertigo's, Lethargies, Pal≈øies, Tremblings, &c. being taken √† í≈øs. ad íij. even to ‚Ñ•≈øs. in a Gla≈øs of Wine, or mixt with ≈øome other Cordial Water. ¬ß 4. Outwardly it may be u≈øed again≈øt Pains and Aches from a cold Cau≈øe, cold Gouts, and Headachs, Brui≈øes, and ≈øuch like. It comforts weak and feeble Joynts and Limbs, adding ≈øtrength and agility to them, and this by being u≈øed both outwardly and inwardly. It is a Specifick in Di≈øea≈øes of the Womb, and is reported by ≈øome Midwives to cure Barrenne≈øs. ¬ß 5. You may make in Elixir of it after this manner: ‚Ñû Of this Spirit ‚Ñ•viij. of the outward rind ‚Ñ•ij. Ambergri≈øe ‚Ñàj. Oriental Musk gr. vj. (both the Perfumes ground with white Sugar-candy í ij.) mix and dige≈øt for ten days, then filter and keep it for u≈øe. After the ≈øame manner you may make an Elixir both of Orange and Citron-peels. ¬ß 6. This Elixir is a choice Cordial which has few equals; it is good again≈øt Faintings and Swoonings, Sickne≈øs at Heart, Deliquium of the Spirits, and chiefly in ≈øudden Accidents after violent exerci≈øe. It is good both for Men and Women, except ≈øuch as are apt to be troubled with Vapours and Hy≈øterick Fits: In tho≈øe Ca≈øes it may be made without the Musk and Ambergri≈øe, and then this, as al≈øo that made with Orange-peels, you will find to be a Specifick to facilitate
and ha≈øten the Birth of Women in Labour, &c. Do≈øe √† ‚Ñàj. ad íj. or more in a Gla≈øs of Wine, or ≈øome Cordial-Water.

div.head: LVI. ‚Ä† Spiritus Menthae, Spirit of Mint.
div.p:
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû A good quantity of Mint newly gathered, brui≈øe it, and put to it (in a wooden Ve≈ø≈øel) a good quantity of warm Water, or rather of Mint-water; in every three quarts of which di≈ø≈øolve a pound of Sugar, or rather as much Manna: let them lie to ferment till they have acquired a vinous ≈øcent; then di≈øtil in B.M. drawing off the third part for Spirit of Mint: the ≈øecond third part for Mint-water: what remains in the Still may be ca≈øt away. This Spirit and Water by cohobating again upon fre≈øh Mint, may yet be made ≈øtronger. ¬ß 2. Or thus: ‚Ñû Fre≈øh Mint lb vj. rectified Spirit of Wine lb iv. mix, dige≈øt twenty four hours, then draw off lb iv. of Spirit in B.M. or if you plea≈øe you may di≈øtil to drine≈øs, which then may be coholobated upon fre≈øh Mint, and repeated again if you ≈øee fit. It is an excellent Spirit. ¬ß 3. To make the Mint-water aforementioned. ‚Ñû Fre≈øh Mint, q. v. beat it well in a Mortar, put it into a long earthen Pot, and make it ≈øufficiently moi≈øt with Juyce of other Mint; cover it, and leave it ≈øo about two days in dige≈øtion, then put the matter into a large Copper Ve≈øica, with its Head and Refrigeratory, as al≈øo its Receiver, luting well the Junctures with a wet Bladder: make a Fire of the ≈øecond degree, and di≈øtil off about the one half of the Juyce which you added, then cea≈øe di≈øtilling; ≈øo will you have a good Mint-water, repleat with the odour and flavour of the Herb. Put it in a Bottle, and expo≈øe it open to the Sun five or ≈øix days, then ≈øtop it up and keep it for u≈øe. ¬ß4. Now here is to be noted, that in the di≈øtillation of this Water, we add a good quantity of the Juyce of Mint, becau≈øe there would be no good di≈øtilling of the Herb it≈øelf, without it was fir≈øt moi≈øtned with ≈øomething, and in my Opinion, the Juyce of the ≈øame Plant much exceeds fair Water, which other Authors u≈øe. And be≈øides, this Juyce which is added ≈øerves to imbibe the volatile parts of the Herb, in the fermentation, and when the Matter is heated, the more ≈øpiritous part, as being the lighter, ri≈øes fir≈øt and ≈ømells le≈øs of the Empyreuma,
than if the Herb was di≈øtilled without being moi≈øtned with the ≈øaid Juyce. ¬ß 5. In the≈øe and the like di≈øtillations you mu≈øt given Fire from the ≈øecond to the third degree, becau≈øe if it ≈øhould be too little, none of the e≈ø≈øential or volatile Salt of the Plant would ri≈øe; but if it be too ≈øtrong, the Water will ta≈øte of an Empyreuma, do what you can: therefore, if you would proceed rightly, di≈øtil ≈øo as to make one drop only to follow another. ¬ß 6. The≈øe Waters ≈øo ≈øoon as they are di≈øtilled have no great ≈ømell; but having lain ≈øome time in the Sun, the ≈øpiritous parts will exert their activity in the aqueous, and the Water will become fragrant which was not ≈øo before. ¬ß 7. What remains in the Still after the Water is drawn off, ≈øtrain out by pre≈ø≈øing, and evaporate with a gentle heat, till it comes to the con≈øi≈øtency of an Extract, which does contain almo≈øt all the e≈ø≈øential Salt of the Plant, and therefore is of greater Virtue than the Water before di≈øtilled, for in this Salt the principal Virtue of the Plant does con≈øi≈øt. This Extract is ≈øtomatick and Cardiack, opens Ob≈øtructions of the Lungs, Reins, and Womb, working by per≈øpiration, and may be given √† í≈øs. ad íij. di≈ø≈øolved in its proper Water. ¬ß 8. The Virtues of the Spirit of Mint. This Spirit is chiefly ≈øtomatick, cephalick and uterine, of thin parts, and ≈øuba≈øtringent. It is u≈øed mo≈øtly again≈øt Vomiting, and debility of the Stomach, Crudities, hicket, nau≈øeating Wind, faintings, Ob≈øtructions of the Liver, Pains of the Guts, and the Belly-ache in Children, Megrim, Vertigo, Lethargy, Coagulation of Milk, Colick, &c. it opens, attenuates, di≈øcu≈ø≈øes, cures Di≈øea≈øes of the Womb, provokes the Terms, ≈øtrengthens the Liver, and re≈øi≈øts Poy≈øon, and particularly the Narcotick quality of Opium; outwardly by bathing on the Region of the Abdomen it ea≈øes the Colick, and takes away the hardne≈øs of Womens Brea≈øts, from curdling of the Milk, by bathing the part, and taking it al≈øo inwardly: Do≈øe √† íij. ad vj.

div.head: LVII. ‚Ä† Spiritus Nucis Mo≈øchatae, Spirit of Nutmegs.
div.p:
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Th√¥ Spirits of Nutmegs is a thing ≈øeldom made, nor pre≈øcribed in any Author, yet for the Publick good ≈øake (≈øince it is a thing
of mo≈øt excellent u≈øe) we ≈øhall take the pains to de≈øcribe it here. ‚Ñû Of the be≈øt Nutmegs ‚Ñ•viij. grate them on a Grater, or beat them very ≈ømall in an Iron Mortar, put them into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, and affu≈øe thereon tartari≈øed Spirit of Wine or Alcohol of S.V. lb v. mix and dige≈øt forty eight hours, then di≈øtil in B. M. to drine≈øs. ¬ß 2. This is an excellent Spirit of Nutmegs‚ñ™ but if you cohobate it upon the faeces three or four times, it will be much ≈øtronger, and more ≈øubtil, and contain more of the oily particles di≈ø≈øolved in its≈øelf. The Feces you may re≈øerve for other Extractions, to be made u≈øe of when you extract a Chymical Oil, the which, in its place, we ≈øhall ≈øhew. ¬ß 3. It is Cephalick, Stomatick, Cardiack, Neurotick, and Uterine; it warms and cheri≈øhes a cold and afflicted Brain, and Habit of Body; comforts the Nerves, ≈øtrenghens the Stomach, and cau≈øes a ≈øweet Breath. It di≈øcu≈ø≈øes Wind, ea≈øes the Colick, and Gripings of the Guts, ≈øharpens the Eye-≈øight, comforts the Liver and Spleen, provokes Urine, is good again≈øt the Whites, and a cold Di≈øtemper of the Womb, it chears the Heart, revives the Spirits, is good again≈øt the Pal≈øie, Cramp, Tremblings, and other weakne≈ø≈øes of the Nerves, and prevails again≈øt the Apoplexy, Vertigo, Megrim, Head-ache, from a cold Cau≈øe, Lethargy, and other the Di≈øtempers of the Head. ¬ß 4. Modus Utendi. ‚Ñû Aqua Lactis Alexiteria ‚Ñ•ii≈øs. Spirit of Nutmegs í ij. ad ‚Ñ•≈øs. Spirit of Saffron í ≈øs. Syrup of Citrons or Lemons í vj. mix for a Cordial draught. Or thus: ‚Ñû Aqua Lactin Scorbutica ‚Ñ•iii≈øs. Spirit of Nutmegs í ij. Volatile Spirit of Vitriol í ≈øs. mix for a Do≈øe to be given in the Morning fa≈øting, again≈øt Di≈øea≈øes of the Head.

div.head: LVIII. ‚Ä† Spiritus Opii, Spirit of Opium.
div.p:
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is a Pre≈øcript which no Author, that we know of, or have ≈øeen, has in the lea≈øt treated of; and becau≈øe the Medicament is excellent, and there are, or may be various ways of preparing it, ≈øome of which exceed others, we ≈øhall do our endeavour to exhibit here the be≈øt Methods of its Preparation; which becau≈øe we write them out of the Fire, and not from any Author,
we hope will be the more acceptable to all the Sons of Art. ¬ß 2. ‚Ñû Choice Thebian Opium lb j. cut it into bits, and with your hand di≈ø-di≈ø≈øolve it in a quart, or more, of pure rectified Spirit of Wine, over a gentle heat: what is di≈ø≈øolved decant, and add more rectified Spirit, di≈ø≈øolving and decanting ≈øo long, till all the Opium is di≈ø≈øolved, and till you have mixed with it five or ≈øix quarts of the ≈øaid Spirit, and nothing but a little ≈øtraw, dro≈øs, leaves, and feces to be left behind, which ca≈øt away: Put all the≈øe di≈ø≈øolutions of Opium into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, with its Head, Worm, and Receiver, and in B.M. draw off the Spirit by a gentle heat to drine≈øs, which that it might comprehend the full of the Opium, cohobate it again upon the Magma or Feces; dige≈øt it in a very gentle heat for three or four days till the Magma is di≈ø≈øolved, and in like manner di≈øtil again, thus cohobating, dige≈øting, and di≈øtilling, three or four ≈øeveral times, you ≈øhall have a mo≈øt excellent Spirit repleat with the Powers and Virtue of the Opium, a thou≈øand times tran≈øcending for plea≈øantne≈øs all the Tinctures that can be made of it in the World. ¬ß 3. Or thus: ‚Ñû Thebian Opium lbj. di≈ø≈øolve it in Vinegar lbiij. dige≈øt a Week, and decant the Tincture: to the Magma add Vinegar lbiij. more, dige≈øt and decant as before, not troubling the ≈øediment. To the Magma put Tartari≈øed S. V. lbiij. mix and dige≈øt three days, then gently decant the Tincture: upon the Magma put tartari≈øed S.V. lbiij. more, mix, and dige≈øt again three days more, then decant the Tincture as before, ca≈øting away the dregs: put the≈øe Tinctures of the Vinegar and Spirit of Wine together, mix, and dige≈øt in a very gentle heat for three Months, that they may unite and meliorate together: then put them into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, and draw off the fir≈øt volatile Spirit in B. M. ≈øo much as will ea≈øily come over: cohobate the Spirit upon the Magma, and di≈øtil again, cohobating and di≈øtilling thus four or five times to drine≈øs, ≈øo will you have a volatile Spirit repleat with all the Virtues and Powers of the Opium, as afore≈øaid. ¬ß 4. Or thus: ‚Ñû Thebian Opium lb j. di≈ø≈øolve it in this following Men≈øtruum lb x. (‚Ñû Tartari≈øed S. V. p. 16. Spirit of Nitre, or Oyl Vitriol, p. j. mix, dige≈øt, and unite them by drawing them over the
Helm) Put them into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, dige≈øt two or three days then in B. M. di≈øtil to drine≈øs, cohobating and di≈øtilling three or four ≈øeveral times. This is a noble Spirit of Opium, and not inferiour to any of the former. ¬ß 5. Or thus: ‚Ñû Thebian Opium lbj. of the Spiritus Intimus (in our Sepla≈øium, lib. 2. cap. 6. ≈øect. 19.) lbvj. cut into bits the Opium and di≈ø≈øolve it, dige≈øt three or four days, then di≈øtil it in a Gla≈øs Cucurbit in B. M. to drine≈øs, cohobating thrice: ≈øo will the Spirit a≈øcend with the volatile Salt of mo≈øt admirable u≈øe, and for ≈øome purpo≈øes much tran≈øcending any of the former. ¬ß 6. Or thus: ‚Ñû Thebian Opium in bits lb j. Powers of Turpentine lb x. mix, di≈ø≈øolve, dige≈øt three or four days, and draw off the Spirit in a Gla≈øs Cucurbit in B. M. cohobating thrice. This is a noble Spirit, and of great Virtues. ¬ß 7. Or thus: ‚Ñû Thebian Opium cut in bits lb j. Rain-water lb iv. mix: put them into a Gla≈øs Matra≈øs, and di≈ø≈øolve over a gentle heat in twenty four hours, ≈øtirring it often, increa≈øing the Fire at the end, that it may ju≈øt boil; being a little cooled and ≈øetled, decant the cleare≈øt of it, which filter through brown Paper while warm: to the remainder put Rain-water lb iv. more, with which proceed as with the former, decanting and filtering. To the remaining Sediment in the Matra≈øs, put of rectified S. V. lb iv. mix, dige≈øt clo≈øe ≈øtopt for forty eight hours, then decant the Tincture, which al≈øo filter as before: to the feces in the Matra≈øs add again tartarized S. V. lb iv. mix, dige≈øt, and extract the Tincture as before, which filter al≈øo, ca≈øting away the faeces in the Matra≈øs, as now of no u≈øe. Put all the≈øe Tinctures both aqueous and ≈øpiritous together into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, with its Head Serpentine and Receiver, and in a Sand heat draw off a pure Spirit of Opium lb x. which keep for u≈øe. What remains in the Matra≈øs evaporate to the con≈øi≈øtency of an Extract, of which you may make a mo≈øt excellent Laudanum. ¬ß 8. There is al≈øo a way of extracting the Spirit with pure Wine Vinegar after this manner: ‚Ñû Of the be≈øt Thebian Opium in bits, di≈ø≈øolve it in ≈øtrong Vinegar, ca≈øting away the filth, then di≈øtil it in an Alembick with a ≈øtrong Fire to drine≈øs, cohobating thrice, and di≈øtilling in like manner. ¬ß 9. But Opium as it contains, 1. A Flegm. 2. A Spirit and volatile Salt.
3. A black ≈øtinking Oyl; ≈øo by di≈øtilling it per ≈øe, may they be ≈øeparated thus: ‚Ñû Opium, put it into a Gla≈øs Retort with a large Receiver, and di≈øtil in Sand, fir≈øt with a gentle Fire, afterwards increa≈øing it gradually to the third degree, cau≈øe the Flegm, Spirit, or volatile Salt, and la≈øtly be thick black ≈øtinking Oyl to come over the Helm: all which ≈øeparate and rectifie according to Art. In the bottom of the Retort you will have a Caput Mort. containing a ≈ømall quantity of fixed Salt, of the nature of other fixt alcalious Salts, and a u≈øele≈øs Earth, which is to be ca≈øt away. ¬ß 10. Where note, That this Spirit thus di≈øtilled by a Retort, is a volatile urinous Spirit, which is followed by a copious Sulphur, or oleaginous inflamable ≈øub≈øtance: this urinous Spirit is indeed diaphoretick, and by its exceeding ≈øubtilty in penetrating, cau≈øes Sweat. However this is not the Spirit intended by our Author, but rather ≈øome one of the former of a ≈øulphurous, or ≈øulphurous ≈øaline nature di≈øtilled as afore≈øaid in a Cucurbit. ¬ß 11. One Preparation more remains, which becau≈øe ≈øome may value before all the re≈øt, we ≈øhall be willing to in≈øert. ‚Ñû Opium in bits lb j. di≈ø≈øolve by gentle boiling in a gallon of Water, then ≈øtrain and ca≈øt the filth or feces away: to this add another gallon of fair Rain-water: add Sugar, or Melu≈ø≈øos lb iv. and a good Leven; di≈ø≈øolve, and being warm, cau≈øe the Liquor gently to ferment for ≈øome days, till it becomes of a vinous ≈øcent; then put all into a Copper Ve≈øica, with its Head, Serpentine and Receiver, di≈øtil and draw off lb viij. or ix. of Spirit, which keep for u≈øe. What remains in the Ve≈øica pour out, and in an earthen Pan evaporate to the con≈øi≈øtency of an Extract, of which you may make Laudanum. ¬ß 12. The Magma left at the end of the di≈øtillation, at ¬ß 2. may be ab≈øtracted to the thickne≈øs of an Extract for the making of Laudanum: for the ≈øame purpo≈øe the dry Magma at ¬ß 3. may ≈øerve, but it has not altogether the ≈øame ≈øtrength and virtue, becau≈øe many of the volatile ≈øaline particles are carried off by the Spirit. The Magma al≈øo at ¬ß 4. may ≈øerve as an Ingredient for Laudanum, ≈øo al≈øo tho≈øe at ¬ß 5, 6, & 7, 8, & 11. as at the end of the ≈øaid 7, & 11 Paragraphs we have hinted. ¬ß 13. From hence it appears, that the Spirit drawn only with
≈øulphurous Spirits, or that Spirit drawn only with acid or ≈øaline Spirits, cannot be altogether ≈øo forcible as Tinctures drawn with the ≈øame; for the fir≈øt contain only an Opiate Sulphur, with little or none of the volatile Salt: and the other contains chiefly a volatile opiatick Salt, with little or nothing of an opiate Sulphur. But that Spirit which is drawn with a ≈øulphurous acid Spirit, or ≈øulphurous ≈øaline Spirit, contains both an opiatick Sulphur, and an acid volatile or urinous volatile Salt, almo≈øt in the ≈øame proportion that the Tincture does, whether it be made with a ≈øulphurous, acid, or ≈øaline Men≈øtruum. ¬ß 14. The≈øe Spirits are all of them much plea≈øanter than either the Tinctures or Extract of Opium, or any preparation of Opium which contains the Body of the Concrete; for they never make the ≈øtomach ≈øick; as tho≈øe other oftentimes do; nor yet di≈øturb the Head otherwi≈øe than it is po≈ø≈øible Spirit of Wine may do, which is a con≈øiderable advantage in their Operation. And altho' they are not altogether ≈øo ≈øtrong and forcible as is Tincture or Extract of Opium, yet they operate with much more ≈øpeed and ≈øafety than po≈ø≈øibly the others can; for they fly like lightning through the whole Body, and give ea≈øe and relief not only to the Spirits, but to the whole Body almo≈øt in a moment. ¬ß 15. div.head: LXV. ‚Ä† Spiritus Succini, Spirit of Amber.
div.p:
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Spirit of Amber is al≈øo twofold: 1. The Acid Spirit. 2. A Sulphurous Spirit made with Spirit of Wine. ¬ß 2. ‚Ñû Amber gro≈øly beaten, put it into an Earthen Retort, ≈øo as to fill it Two Thirds full; fit to it a large Receiver, luting the Juncture clo≈øe: Make a gentle fire fir≈øt

Put all this Liquor into a Gla≈øs Alembick, fit to it a Receiver, and luting well the Junctures, make fir≈øt a very gentle fire, which augment by degrees, ≈øo will the Flegm and Spirit a≈øcend, carrying with them a little White Oyl; Continue the fire till no more ari≈øes, ≈øo will the thick Oyl be left at bottom. ¬ß 3. Separate the Flegm and Spirit from the White Oyl; and the Black Oyl (if you ≈øo plea≈øe) you may rectifie from Colcothar or Bone-A≈øhes, as is often afore-directed. Where note, That there is little rea≈øon for this trouble of evaporating the Flegm; for you cannot ≈øo ≈øecurely do it, but that ≈øome of the Volatile Saline Particles will go along with it, which will be a lo≈øs to you: And what need is there of thus ≈øeparating its own natural Flegm from it? for that when it is done, the Spirit cannot be given alone, but mu≈øt be mixt with ≈øome other Flegmatick Vehicle to convey it in: And if ≈øo, why ≈øhould not its own Flegm be as good as any thing Forreign, for that a le≈øs quantity of another Vehicle would then ≈øerve the turn? ¬ß 5. The Black Oyl remaining in the bottom of the Cucurbit, by rea≈øon of its fetidne≈øs is ≈øcarcely fit to be given inwardly without rectification; but it may be kept for outward u≈øe to anoint the No≈øes and Wri≈øts, of Women troubled with Vapors and Fits of the Mother. ¬ß 6. But if you would rectifie it, mix it with ≈øo much Sand as is nece≈ø≈øary to make it into a Body, which put into a Retort, place it in a Furnace, and force over the Oyl, ≈øo will it come over-red, but exceeding clear, which is to be kept by it ≈øelf, and may ≈øerve in≈øtead of the White. ¬ß 7. This, as al≈øo the White Oyl, may be given inwardly in all Hy≈øterick Di≈øtempers, Pal≈øies, Apoplexies, Epilep≈øies, Vertigo's, Lethargies, and other
Di≈øtempers of the Brain, Nerves and Womb. Do≈øe √† gut. ij ad x. ¬ß 8. The Spirit is an excellent Aperitive, and is ≈øucce≈øsfully given again≈øt all the afore≈øaid Di≈øtempers, but chiefly again≈øt the Epilep≈øie, Jaundice, Stoppage of Urine, Ulcers in the Neck of the Bladder, Scurvey, Cachexia, Drop≈øies, Rheumati≈øms, and other the like Di≈øea≈øes; for that this Spirit is only the Volatile Salt of Amber, di≈ø≈øolved in ≈øome of its Flegm, and may be given √† gut. xij. ad xxx. in ≈øome convenient Liquor. The Oyl may be di≈ø≈øolved with the Yolk of an Egg, by grinding them together, whereby it will ea≈øily mix with any Water, Wine or Broath. ¬ß 9. If you would ≈øeparate the Salt from the Flegm, you may do thus: Evaporate about a third part of the Spirit over a very gentle fire, then put the remainder into a cool place, leaving it there ten or twelve days without ≈øtirring it, ≈øo will it cry≈øtallize, which you are to take and keep in a Vial clo≈øe ≈øtopt. ¬ß 10. But here is to be noted, that it is much better to keep the Salt with its Flegm, for in Evaporation (tho' with never ≈øo gentle a Fire) ≈øome part of it will fly away; be≈øides, it is ea≈øier kept with its flegm, than apart from it, becau≈øe it will be apt to di≈ø≈øolve. ¬ß 11. This Salt is acid, and like unto the e≈ø≈øential Salt of Plants, and being le≈øs volatile than that of Animals cannot ri≈øe ≈øo high in rectification, and being heavier than the flegm, lets the flegm ri≈øe fir≈øt, for which rea≈øon we chu≈øe the method of cry≈øtallizing it, rather than that of ≈øubliming it. But there is an excellent and ≈øubtil volatile Salt of Amber to be made by ≈øublimation from the Amber it ≈øelf, of which we ≈øhall ≈øay nothing here, but re≈øerve you to its determined place: The≈øe Salts of Amber have the Virtues of the Spirit aforementioned. ¬ß 12. The ≈øulphurous Spirit of Amber, made with Spirit of Wine, is done as we have taught in our Pharmacopoeia Londinen≈øis, lib. 4. cap. 3. ≈øect. 39. where Amber in Pouder, p. i. is mixt with rectified S. V. p. ij. them put into a Retort ≈øo as to fill it not above half full, to which is fitted a large Receiver, without luting (for that if luted, the S. V. would break all the Ve≈ø≈øels) and then di≈øtilling with a gentle fire, increa≈øing it gradatim, and at la≈øt giving a fire of ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion; you will have the ≈øulphurous,
≈øpirituous and volatile Spirit of Amber, equal in quantity to the Spirit of Wine, and a black fetid Oyl, equal to half the weight of the Amber, which you must ≈øeparate. ¬ß 13. This ≈øulphurous volatile Spirit has all the Virtues of the former Spirit and Oyl, and infinitely more plea≈øant to be taken inwardly, being a Specifick again≈øt Hy≈øterick Fits, Epilep≈øies and all cold and moi≈øt Di≈øtempers of the Head, Brain, Nerves, Womb, and Joynts: and may be given √† ‚Ñài. ad íi. in any proper and ≈øpecifick Vehicle. ¬ß 14. Outwardly, it is a mo≈øt admirable thing again≈øt the Pal≈øie, Lamene≈øs, Numbne≈øs, Trembling of the Limbs, or Weakne≈øs of any ≈øingular Part, the Cold Gout, and all manner of Aches and Pains proceeding from a cold Cau≈øe, and Brui≈øes or Hurts of the Nerves, it is of very thin and ≈øubtil parts, and by rea≈øon of its penetrative faculty is re≈øolutive and di≈øcu≈ø≈øive: It cures Contractions and Sinews ≈øhrunk up, from its bal≈øamick property, and re≈øtores ≈øuch as have lo≈øt the u≈øe of their Limbs: drawn up the No≈øtrils often at one time, and the Head well bathed therewith al≈øo, gives immediate ea≈øe in the Head-ache, tho' never ≈øo extream, and that even upon the ≈øpot.

Others calcine either with Beach Charcoal, or with Nitre, and elicit the Salt with ≈øome proper Diuretical Water, or Spring-water, or with Flegm of Nitre or Allum, then filtrate, evaporate, and melt per deliquium. And becau≈øe this matter is full of an impure Sulphur, it may be doubly calcin'd, filtrated, and evaporated as afore≈øaid, ≈øo will the Oyl, per deliquium, be yet pur ‚Ä¢ r. ¬ß 5. La≈øtly, being put into a Gla≈øs Retort and di≈øtilled as you do Hartshorn, you will have a volatile Salt ≈øticking to the Neck of the Retort, and Sides of the Receiver, a Urinous Spirit, and a little quantity of ≈øtinking Oyl; all which may be rectified as other Oyls, Volatile Salts and Spirits, &c. The≈øe have the ≈øame Virtues with the Oyl per deliquium, but much more powerful; and all of them ≈øpecifick again≈øt the Epilep≈øie, Apoplexy, and Fits of the Mother. ¬ß 6. Let the Salt be di≈ø≈øolved in the Spirit, and ≈øo kept, of which you may give √† gut. x. ad xxx. or more, in any proper Liquor: the Oyl may be given √† gut. ij. ad iv. or viij. fir≈øt mix with a little of the Yolk of an Egg, and then with the Vehicle.

div.head: IX. Oleum Lumbricorum, Oyl of Earth-worms.
div.p: Bate.] It is di≈øtilled in a Sand hea ‚Ä¢ from Earth-Worms wa≈øhed in Spani≈øh Wine, S. A. It wonderfully prevails in the Cure of the Pal≈øie.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Worms ought to be carefully dried with a very gentle heat beforehand, that they may be dive≈øted of the greate≈øt part of their flegm, ≈øo will the Operation be the ≈øooner performed. ¬ß 2. Then being cut into pieces, put them into an Earthen Retort, or a Gla≈øs one coated, which place in a Reverberatory Furnace, fit to it a great capacious Receiver, luting the Juncture clo≈øe; begin the di≈øtillation with a ≈ømall Fire to warm the Retort, and drive out the remaining part of the flegm gutatim; when no more drops fall, increa≈øe the fire a little, and the Spirits will come forth, filling the Receiver with white Clouds, and at la≈øt a black Oyl and volatile Salt, ≈øticking to the ≈øides of the Receiver: continue the fire till all is come forth that will; then cooling the Ve≈ø≈øel,
and unluting, ≈øhake the Receiver, to loo≈øen and mix the volatile Salt with the aqueous and ≈øpiritous Matter, put all into a Bolt-head, with its Receiver, luting the Junctures well with a wet Bladder, then with a gentle Fire in a Sand heat, the volatile Salt will ≈øublime to the top of the Bolt-head, which ≈øeparate and keep by it ≈øelf. ¬ß 3. What remains filter through brown Paper, ≈øo will the Flegm and Spirit pa≈øs, leaving the Oyl behind; keep each by them≈øelves for their particular u≈øes. The Spirit, you may, if you ≈øo plea≈øe, rectifie from its Flegm, ca≈øting the Flegm away. ¬ß 4. The Oyl is fetid, and ≈øtinks ≈øo abominably, that it is ≈øcarce po≈ø≈øible to be u≈øed alone, e≈øpecially unrectified. To rectifie it, you mu≈øt mix it with Pouder of Bone-a≈øhes, or Colcothar, and draw it off from them, ≈øo will it be pure, and dive≈øted much of its ≈øtinking ≈øcent, but ≈øcarce tolerable to be u≈øed by ∆≤nction. ¬ß 5. The Spirit, volatile Salt, and Oyl, have all one and the ≈øame Virtues, ≈øave the volatile Salt is the more powerful, the Spirit next in virtue, then the Oyl: the two fir≈øt are to be given inwardly, the Oyl only to be u≈øed outwardly by Unction, as we ≈øhall pre≈øently teach you. ¬ß 6. The Spirit is given √† gut. xx. ad xxx. or xl. The volatile Salt √† gr. iv. ad xij. or xiv. in any Specifick Vehicle again≈øt the Pal≈øie, Apoplexy, (for which they are Specificks) Epilep≈øie, Vertigo, Lethargy, Con≈øumptions, and all other cold and moi≈øt Di≈øea≈øes of the Head, Brain, and Nerves, as al≈øo again≈øt the Pleuri≈øie, and all Di≈øaffections of the Lungs, and Womb, as Vapours, Hy≈øterick Fits, and ≈øuch like. ¬ß 7. Outwardly, the Paralytick Parts are to be anointed with the rectified Oyl, as al≈øo the Sutures of the Head, Temples, No≈øtrils, &c. But becau≈øe it is ≈øo odious by rea≈øon of its ill ≈øcent and na≈øtine≈øs; we ≈øhall here teach you to convert it into the Pote≈øtates of the ≈øame, which are a Medicine ≈øo near and cleanly, that it will ≈øcarcely foul the fine≈øt and cleane≈øt Linnen. ¬ß 8. The≈øe Pote≈øtates are thus made: ‚Ñû Of the be≈øt rectified Spirit of Wine lb ij. Volatile Salt of Earth-worms í j. mix and dige≈øt two Months, till the Spirit is impregnated with the Salt: decant it from the remaining Salt (for all of it, it will not ≈øuck up) and add thereto of the former rectified Oyl ‚Ñ•j. mix by ≈øhaving them well together, dige≈øt
two Months, and then draw them off together in an Alembick, ≈øo will they be intimately united and remain together for ever; and thus have you the Powers of Earth-worms, having all the Virtues of the Spirit and Salt aforementioned; and may be given inwardly √† í≈øs. ad íi. in any fit Liquor, and bathed withal outwardly for the Cure of the Pal≈øie, as our Author has directed, being ten times more effectual than his di≈øtilled Oyl pre≈øcribed, which ≈øtinks (as I ≈øaid before) ≈øo egregiou≈øly, that it is ≈øcarcely po≈ø≈øible to be u≈øed.

div.head: X. Oleum Martis, Oyl of Mars, or Iron.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of the Ru≈øt of Mars, contracted by ≈øprinkling it with Aqua Stygia, then wa≈øhing it with Water, filtring and exhaling it to an Oleagnio≈øity, S. A. It is one of the greate≈øt Deob≈øtructors in the World. Do≈øe gr. iv. or v. &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is not Oleum Martis, for that is Oyl made of the Vitriol of Mars, of which we have nothing to ≈øay here, for that there is no difference in the preparation thereof, from that of the preparation of the Common Oyl of Vitriol, all the ≈øame Rules, Directions and Cautions being to be ob≈øerved in the one, that is ob≈øerved in the other. ¬ß 2. This here is rather a Tincture of Mars extracted with common Water, the Body of the Mars being beforehand opened with Aqua Fortis, or Spirit of Nitre, by virtue of which the Tincture of the Mars is extracted by the Water; which being filtred and ab≈øtracted to the thickne≈øs of Oyl, receives its denomination from the likene≈øs which it has thereto. ¬ß 3. Le Mort makes it after this manner: ‚Ñû Filings of Mars ‚Ñ• xiv. Spirit of Common Salt ‚Ñ•j. fair Water ‚Ñ•viij. mix, and dige≈øt for three or four days, ≈øtirring it twice a day: then add Cry≈øtals of Tartar in fine Po ‚Ä¢ der ‚Ñ•viij. mix them well again; and add fair Water again a ≈øufficient quantity, boyl them together for an hour in an Iron Pot or Kettle, continually adding fre≈øh Water, as the Matter evaporates; then filter, or let it ≈øettle, pouring off the clear Liquor, which evaporate to the con≈øi≈øtency of a thin Syrup: add an half part of rectified Spirit of Wine, and keep it for u≈øe. ¬ß 4. Lemery makes it thus: ‚Ñû Ru≈øt of Iron ‚Ñ•xij. White Tartar lb ij. Pouder and mix them together, then boyl
them in an Iron Pot with lb xij. or xv. of Rain-water for 12 hours with a ≈øoft fire: ≈øtir the matter with an Iron-≈ølice often, of almo≈øt continually, taking care to put in more boyling Water into the Iron Pot, according as it con≈øumes: then leave it for a while to ≈øettle, and you will have a black Liquor, which filtrate and evaporate in an Earthen Pan over a Sand heat to the con≈øi≈øtence of a thin Syrup, or till a little pellicle ri≈øes upon it. ¬ß 5. Now here is to be noted in this Preparation, that Water alone would not be ≈øtrong enough to penetrate the Iron, ≈øo as to make a Tincture, tho' it ≈øhould be boyl'd for a year together; and therefore our Author in his way, makes the Ru≈øt with Aqua Stygia. ¬ß 6. Le Mort u≈øes Spirit of Salt, and a ≈ømall proportion of Tartar; but Lemery, becau≈øe he u≈øes no Aqua Fortis, nor Sp. Salis, takes ≈øo much the larger a proportion of Tartar; with the≈øe things the Water being impregnated it di≈ø≈øolves the Mars very ea≈øily, and gives it ≈øtrength enough to extract almo≈øt its very Soul. ¬ß 7. But you mu≈øt not think that this Oyl-like Body is a perfect ≈øolution of Mars; for if there was an intire ≈øolution of it, there would appear no more Tincture than there does in the Solution of it, with Spirit of Vitriol and Water; but becau≈øe the ≈øoluble parts of the Tartar, which is the Agent in this Operation is only an impure acid Salt, it can but gro≈øly rarifie or open the Mars, and after mixing with it, keep it ≈øu≈øpended in the Water. ¬ß 8. After the Tincture is drawn, there remains a whiti≈øh matter, which may be ca≈øt away as nothing worth, being a mixture of the gro≈ø≈øer and unclean parts of the Tartar and Mars. and the Tincture has a ≈øweetne≈øs in it, from whence, as al≈øo from its Con≈øi≈øtence or Body, ≈øome are plea≈øed to call it a Syrup: Others an Oyl, tho' in truth, it is neither. ¬ß 9. It is brought by evaporation to the con≈øi≈øtency of an Oyl or Syrup, that it might keep the better; but Le Mort thought good to add to it Spirit of Wine for its greater ≈øecurity and pre≈øervation.

div.head: XI. Oleum Polypodii, Oyl of Polipody.
div.p: Bate.] It is made from the dryed Roots, di≈øtilled by a Retort in Sand, S. A. It ≈øerves for catching of Fi≈øhes.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It is found on Beech and Hazel-Trees,
and ≈øtony Places, but that from the Oak is be≈øt. ¬ß 2. The Root in form of a Decoction, purges Melancholy, and tough Flegm, and opens Ob≈øtructions of the Liver, Spleen, Womb, and Me≈øentery, but becau≈øe it is but a ≈ølow Purge it is ≈øeldom given alone, but with other ≈øtronger Purges. ¬ß 3. Being di≈øtilled its Cathartick Virtue is totally de≈øtroyed; you having in≈øtead thereof a ≈øharp, opening Spirit, and a fetid Oyl: The Spirit is profitably given again≈øt Venereal Defedations, and Dietetically; you may give it √† íi. ad íij. or more in Drink, or Decoction of Guajacum. ¬ß 4. The Oyl is ≈øo fetid, that it is not po≈ø≈øibly to be taken inwardly without rectification, and then at be≈øt it is a loath≈øome Medicine; which tho' it may be good again≈øt the Venereal Di≈øtemper, Lepro≈øie, and other Impurities of the Blood, is ≈øeldom or never taken; for that many other Medicines, a thou≈øand times more grateful, and po≈ø≈øibly more efficacious, are ever ready at hand to be had: what its other Properties are, our Author has told you, which is the Catching of Fi≈øh, which it does by drawing them together after it, by rea≈øon of its ≈øtrong ≈øcent. ¬ß 5. As for the way and manner of making it, there is no difficulty in it; being cut into bits, you may fill an Earthen Retort full thereof, and having luted thereto a Receiver, you may perform the di≈øtillation in Sand, fir≈øt with a gentle fire, then with a ≈øtronger, augmenting it even to the la≈øt degree, in all re≈øpects as we have before taught you in the di≈øtillation of Guajacum.

div.head: XII. Oleum Sacchari Simplex; Oyl of Sugar ≈øimple.
div.p: Bate.] It is made with Sugar-candy, and Spirit of Wine, ana, being mixed and di≈ø≈øolved in the heat of B. M. then by burning the Spirit away to the Con≈øi≈øtence of a Syrup, S. A.

It was de≈øigned again≈øt Coughs, Colds, Wheezings, A≈øthma's, Shortne≈øs of Breath, Difficulty of Breathing, and other Di≈øtempers of the Bre≈øt and Lungs. ¬ß 3. div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Dates cut into pieces ‚Ñ•ij. Figs ‚Ñ•iij. Hy≈ø≈øop, M. j. Liquorice, Ani≈øeeds, Cotton-≈øeeds, A. í vj. Roots of Florentine Orrice ‚Ñ•j. Elecampane in fine Pouder, Ani≈øeeds, ana ‚Ñàj. Pepper in fine Pouder, gr. x. mix for a Do≈øe to be taken Morning and Evening, and to be lickt of in th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ as need requi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢

Sand, or wa≈øhed A≈øhes lb iij. mix them, and put them into a Gla≈øs Retort, and di≈øtil with a very gentle fire in Sand, at la≈øt increa≈øing the fire almo≈øt to a red hot heat, ≈øo have you Oyl and Spirit, which you may ≈øeparate. ¬ß 4. The Spirit opens Ob≈øtructions of the Brea≈øt, Lungs, and urinary parts: The Oyl is Pectoral, and may be mixt with other Pectorals, and ≈øo given. Do≈øe of the Spirit, ≈øo much as to give any Wine, Ale, or Cordial Draught a plea≈øant acidity: the Oyl may be given √† gut. vj. ad xij. or more, mixed with proper Pectorals as afore directed.

div.head: XIV. * Oleum Saponis, Oyl of Soap.
div.p:
Bate.] It is made of Venetian Soap thin ≈øliced or ≈øcraped, and Spirit of Wine, of each a like quantity, being di≈øtilled by a Retort, first with a gentle fire, then increa≈øing it gradatim. Let the Oyl ≈øwimming upon the Green Water be ≈øeparated. It is good again≈øt Convul≈øions and Pains of the Head, being anointed upon the Temples, Nape of the Neck and No≈øtrils. It helps al≈øo again≈øt the Gout, Contu≈øions, and Worms, being
anointed upon the place affected, and then a Colwort-leaf applied over them.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Rolfincius, Art. Chimiae, lib. 3. ≈øect. 2. art. 1. cap. 15. makes it after this manner: ‚Ñû Venice Soap thin ≈øliced or ra≈øped lb j. Calx Vive finely pulverized lb ij. mix them well, then ≈øprinkle them with White-wine: put all into a ≈øtrong gla≈øs Retort: begin the di≈øtillation with a very gentle fire, increa≈øing it to the third degree, ≈øo will you have Flegm and a rubicund Oyl, which keep in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe. ¬ß 2. It re≈øolves and di≈ø≈øipates cold Tumors; helps the Spleen and Vapors, being anointed upon the Region of the Spleen; and anointed upon the Joynts it ea≈øes the Gout, and di≈ø≈øolves the Tartarous Nodes thence ari≈øing. ¬ß 3. It ≈øtinks much, and therefore it is nece≈ø≈øary that it ≈øhould be once or twice rectified from Colcothar, or Bone-a≈øhes, for by that means it will be finer and ≈øubtiller, and lo≈øe much of its Empyreuma. ¬ß 4. A warming and ≈øtrengthning Empla≈øter, and good again≈øt Fits of the Mother, you may make after this manner: ‚Ñû Galbanum, Ammoniacum, A. ‚Ñ•ij. Wax, Oyl of Soap, A. ‚Ñ•j. mix and make an Empla≈øter.

div.head: XV. Oleum Tabaci, Oyl of Tobacco.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of the dryed Leaves by a Retort, or from the Seeds brui≈øed, by expre≈ø≈øion. It is of u≈øe again≈øt Pains of the Gout, Rheumati≈øm, Toothache, Worms, &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. By the leave of our Author, there is a va≈øt difference between a di≈øtilled Oyl drawn by a Retort from the dryed Leaves, and the expre≈ø≈øed Oyl from the Seeds: An Ounce of the latter is not equal in Virtue and Power to ten drops of the former. ¬ß 2. How this Oyl is particularly to be made we ≈øhall not here repeat, fora≈ømuch as we have largely performed that task in Chap. 2. Sect. 34. ¬ß 3. & 15. where al≈øo we have amply ≈øhewn its rectification, and ≈øeveral u≈øes, with the way of its exhibition or ‚Ä¢ pplication. ¬ß 3. In making of this Oyl you have al≈øo a Spirit fill'd with volatile Salt, which you are to rectifie, as (in the place cited) you are directed, which has admirable Vertues, and in my Opinion, much tran≈øcending the Oyl. ¬ß 4. To make the Oyl of the Seeds by expre≈ø≈øion: Let them be ground in a Mu≈øtard-Quern as

Now here is to be noted, that if the Seeds be heat in an Earthen Pan, or Frying-pan, till they be pretty warm, before they are put into the Bag, (which ought to be wetted and wrung hard out of hot Water) you will have the more of Oyl. 2. That if you pre≈øs ≈øtrongly at fir≈øt, ≈øome particles of the Seeds will be apt to come through the Bag, whereby your Oyl will be thick and filthy, which otherwi≈øe would be pure and clear.

div.head: XVI. * Oleum Vitrioli ‚Ä¢ ulce, Sweet Oyl of Vitriol.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Rectified Oyl of Vitriol j. part: Alcohol of Wine lb iv. dige≈øt thirty or forty days, and then di≈øtil by a Retort, cohobating three or four times till they are united, S. A. It is profitable again≈øt the Stone, Tartarous Di≈øea≈øes, Catarrhs, &c. Do≈øe ‚Ñàij. in ≈øome proper Liquor.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. By j. part in this place is intended lbj. and it is the ≈øame proportion which is limited in our Pharmacopoeia Londinen≈øis, lib. 3. cap. 11. ≈øect. 94. where the Proce≈øs is amply explicated, together with its ≈øeveral Virtues and U≈øes. ¬ß 2. But Mon≈øieur Charras alters the proportion, and makes it by mixing the two inequal proportions, and then di≈øtilling the mixture in a Gla≈øs Alembick in an A≈øh heat with a moderate fire. By this inward Union (≈øays he) of the acid of the Vitriol, with the volatile Sulphur of the rectified Spirit, there ari≈øes a compo≈øition much more ≈øweet in ≈øavour, and gentle in all its effects, than was the Oyl of Vitriol before its conjunction. ¬ß 3. And tho' we mu≈øt confe≈øs, that this Spirit is compo≈øed of two; neverthele≈øs, we have a better Opinion thereof, becau≈øe they unite without the de≈øtruction of each other, and that by this new di≈øpo≈øal of their parts through this Union, that which both of them had of Violent, is qualified, and their joynt operation much more proper and fitted to our Nature. ¬ß 4. So that the u≈øe of this Spirit is of much more advantage, than that of
the unmixed Spirit, e≈øpecially to tho≈øe Per≈øons to whom Acids are injurious, and that it is much more proper for ≈øeveral Di≈øea≈øes, e≈øpecially the Scurvy; for the Spirit of Wine imparts to the Oyl of Vitriol a Diaphoretick Virtue, yet does not deprive it of its quality or property it has to open Ob≈øtructions, and ≈øtrengthen the parts. ¬ß 5. Maets takes Oyl of Vitriol lb j. Tartari≈øed S. V. lb iij. dige≈øt them together for a Night, and in the Morning di≈øtil them by a Retort, and De Nova, dige≈øts for a Night again, reiterating this Work three or four times, till the Acrimony of the Oyl of Vitriol is apparently abated. Thus, ≈øaith he, you have a mo≈øt temperate Men≈øtruum for extracting the Tinctures of multitude of Vegetables. ¬ß 6. This Spirit allays the febrile heat and ardours of the Blood, powerfully cuts tough Flegm, and opens the mo≈øt obdurate Ob≈øtructions; it breaks and di≈ø≈øolves the Stone and Gravel, whether in the Reins or Bladder, expelling the ≈øame by Urine. ¬ß 7. From the Caput Mort. an acid Spirit, but much le≈øs violent than that which is drawn from Vitriol after the ordinary manner, may be extracted by laying it in a place where it may receive the Beams of the Sun, Influences of the Moon and Heavenly Bodies, with the Moi≈øture of the Air, but yet ≈øo that no Rain may fall upon it, and leaving it there for about a Year. ¬ß 8. By this means the Terra Damnata (being deprived of its own natural Salt, but not of its Ferment) will be impregnated with the acid Salt of the Air, and become in a ≈øort a new kind of Vitriol, from whence by the ordinary method, in about twelve hours time, you may draw an acid Spirit very plea≈øing (called by ≈øome Spiritus Vitrioli Regeneratus) which being compared with the former ≈øtrong Oyl of Vitriol, may well be accounted among the number of the ≈øweet Spirits of Vitriol, for which rea≈øon ≈øake, we have di≈øcour≈øed it here. Do≈øe ‚Ñàij. ad íj. ¬ß 9. A ≈øweet Spirit of Vitriol compound. ‚Ñû Vitriol calcin'd to redne≈øs in Pouder lb iv. Flints calcin'd, and in Pouder lb v. Salt of Tartar calcin'd to whitene≈øs lb j. mix and put altogether into a Retort, which place upon a naked fire in a clo≈øe Reverberatory, with a very large Receiver, and di≈øtil as for the common Spirit and Oyl, till all is come forth. This done, cohobate the Liquor
upon the Caput Mort, reiterating the di≈øtillation, and repeating this cohobation and di≈øtillation three times. ¬ß 10. Thus have you a Spirit powerful to open Ob≈øtructions of Liver, Spleen, and Bowels, profitable e≈øpecially in Drop≈øies and Jaundice, being u≈øed as you u≈øe the former. ¬ß 11. Spiritus Vitrioli Dulcis Paracel≈øi: ‚Ñû Common Oyl of Vitriol, cohobate it upon the Caput Mort, and di≈øtil, reiterating the Cohobation, and di≈øtilling nine times; with this la≈øt Spirit mix the Caput Mort. again, and affu≈øe thereon ≈øo much tartari≈øed S. V. as may make the whole into a Pa≈øte, which put into a Retort, di≈øtilling with a gradual fire as before, ≈øo have you Paracel≈øus's corrected ≈øweet Spirit of Vitriol. This he commends again≈øt the Epilep≈øie, given √† vj. ad xij. drops, or more in any Antepileptick Water. ¬ß 12. Hartman's dulcified Antepileptick Spirit of Vitriol. ‚Ñû Hungarian Vitriol, Children's ∆≤rine: mix and dige≈øt for ≈øome days in B. M. then draw off in the ≈øame Balneo the Water or Flegm to drine≈øs, (which Water is good against the Gout, and a peculiar Remedy for most Di≈øea≈øes of the Eyes) pouder the feces, put them into a Retort, with a very large Receiver, and with a naked and gradual fire, forces over the Spirit of an au≈øtere ≈øavour, and ≈øulpherous ≈ømell, which rectifie twice. ¬ß 13. This (≈øays he) is an infallible Remedy and ab≈øolute Cure for the Epilep≈øie in Children. Do≈øe ‚Ñàj. with a little Water and Spirit of Peony-Roots and Flowers, giving it in the Fit, and continuing the u≈øe of it ≈øo long as need requires.
