Or thus: ‚Ñû Fine Pouder of crude Antimony, q. v. to which put by degrees Aqua Regia, in a Gla≈øs Retort, ≈øo long till the efferve≈øcence cea≈øes, then draw off the Aqua Regia, by a gentle di≈øtillation in a ≈øoft fire, but exciting it vehemently towards the end, ≈øo in the neck of the Retort, you will find the inflamable Sulphur of Antimony ≈øublimed of a ≈øubcitrine colour, which take and keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 3. Otto Tachenius in his Hippocrates Chymicus, cap. 23. ≈øaith, Simple Aqua Fortis of Nitre and Alum, or Vitriol, corrodes not, nor di≈ø≈øolves crude Antimony; but adding to this Water ≈øo much fine cleanly poudred fu≈øed Salt, as it can di≈ø≈øolve; if it be then ≈øuperfu≈øed on the Pouder of crude Antimony, it will with a gentle heat pre≈øently act on the Antimony, and corrode the Regulus of it, on which pre≈øently pouring cold Water, you will ≈øee the Sulphur ≈øeparated and ≈øwimming upon the top of the Water like Pitch: where note, That at one Operation you mu≈øt not di≈ø≈øolve above íij. or thereabouts, for in a greater quantity, the Sulphur will al≈øo be corroded by the Water, and turn to feces: dulcifie this Sulphur with cold Water, and it will look like the common Sulphur, only a little greener.

¬ß 4. In making the Bal≈øam you ought to ≈øtir the mixture continually till the Sulphur is di≈ø≈øolved in the Oyl, for otherwi≈øe it will coagulate and ≈øettle to the bottom into a ma≈øs, and never di≈ø≈øolve ≈øo as to bring the Oyl into a Bal≈øam: the fire must be gentle and not extream, and you mu≈øt be cautious, that it kindle not, lea≈øt you ≈øet the Hou≈øe on Fire: the Sulphur being once di≈ø≈øolved, it ought to digest for a Week or more in a gentle heat, to perfect the ∆≤nition.

¬ß 5. This Sulphur is an excellent thing again≈øt all Wounds and Ulcers what≈øoever, and ≈øtops Bleeding admirably. It is al≈øo good again≈øt Coughs, Colds, A≈øthma's, and all Oppre≈ø≈øions and Ob≈øtructions of the Lungs, Difficulty of Breathing Shortne≈øs of Breath, &c. Do≈øe √† gut. vj. ad xij.

div.head: VIII. * Bal≈øamum Sulphuris Ani≈øatum, Bal≈øam of Sulphur Ani≈øated.
div.p:
Bate.] ‚Ñû Flowers of Sulphur ‚Ñ•ij. Oyl of Ani≈øeeds ‚Ñ•viij. mix and digest till the Sulphur is di≈ø≈øolved, and the Bal≈øam
becomes of a rubicund colour. It is of admirable u≈øe again≈øt Catarrhs, or Defluxions upon the Bre≈øt and Lungs, Coughs, A≈øthma's, Phthi≈øicks, Pleuri≈øies, Colick, the Plague or Pe≈øtilence, Epilep≈øie, and all ≈øorts of Apo≈øtemes, and Putrefactions of the Body. Do≈øe ad ‚Ñàj.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It is only a ≈øolution of the oily parts of the Sulphur in the Oyl of Ani≈øeeds: put the Ingredients into a Gla≈øs Matra≈øs in Sand, and give a dige≈øting fire for two hours; afterwards increa≈øe it a little for four hours more, ≈øtirring it very often; the Ve≈ø≈øel being cold, ≈øeparate the clear Bal≈øam from the Sulphur that will not di≈ø≈øolve.

¬ß 2. In this our Pre≈øcript the Proportion is as j. to iv. but Grulingius, and Mon≈øieur Charras in his Royal Pharmacopoeia, makes it as j. to vj. ‚Ñû Flowers of Sulphur ‚Ñ•j. Oyl of Ani≈øeeds by Expre≈ø≈øion ‚Ñ•vj. put them into a Matra≈øs, which ≈øtop exactly, and ≈øet it in dige≈øtion over a moderate fire till the Flowers of Sulphur are almo≈øt all di≈ø≈øolved in the Oyl; take off the Matra≈øs, and when the Ingredients are cool, ≈øeparate the Bal≈øam by inclination from the feces, which keep in a Bottle clo≈øe ≈øtopt.

¬ß 3. Now here is to be noted, that the volatility of the Oyl of Ani≈øeeds requires that the Matra≈øs ≈øhould be well ≈øtopt; but you mu≈øt be careful in the time of dige≈øtion to ≈øhake the Matra≈øs often, to ha≈øten the di≈ø≈øolution of the Flowers.

¬ß 4. It is al≈øo to be ob≈øerved, that the Oyl by Expre≈ø≈øion may make a di≈ø≈øolution of the Sulphur; yet the Oyl by di≈øtillation would do better, (and that is it which is intended by our Author) but being more volatile, it is ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary, that the Ve≈ø≈øel ≈øhould be well ≈øtopt.

¬ß 5. Le Mort makes it after this manner: ‚Ñû Sulphur, or its Flowers ‚Ñ•ij. Salt of Tartar ‚Ñ•j. mix and melt them together exactly, till they become of a darki≈øh purple colour; this done, pouder them, and to two Ounces of the Ma≈øs add Oyl of Ani≈øeeds ‚Ñ•iij. boyl them in B. M. for eight hours often ≈øtirring the Materials: then the Ve≈ø≈øel being cold, decant the tinged ≈øupernating Oyl, and keep it for u≈øe.

¬ß 6. This you ≈øee is made by the help or addition of Salt of Tartar; which th√¥ it may be made without it, yet by this means the Body of the Sulphur is not only prepared, and ≈øomewhat opened
beforehand, but al≈øo the acid particles thereof, are corrected, ≈øo as they may not hurt the Lungs.

¬ß 7. But in our Phylaxa Medicinae, cap. 55. ≈øect. 1. we have taught you to make it from Lac Sulphuris, for that the Body of the Sulphur is yet better opened by the Alcali, and Experience has confirmed the Effects thereof to be more excellent, than that otherwi≈øe prepared.

¬ß 8. Our Author thinks this Bal≈øam to be little inferiour to Natural Bal≈øam, for that it moderately heats and dries and pre≈øerves from Corruption. It is highly recommended again≈øt Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Lungs, as Coughs Colds, A≈øthma's, Pleuri≈øies and Ulcers of the Lungs. It is very good again≈øt the Colick, Oppre≈ø≈øions of Wind, Gripings of the Guts, Weakne≈øs and Indige≈øtion of the Stomach, want of Appetite, Heart-burnings, &c. It is al≈øo good again≈øt the Plague or Pe≈øtilence, and all Epidemick Di≈øea≈øes, continual and intermitting Feavers.

¬ß 9. Grulingius, par. 17: cap. 5. pag. 385. Florilegii, calls it the mo≈øt perfect of Bal≈øams, and ≈øays it has all the Virtues of the Natural Bal≈øam, and the greate≈øt Con≈øervative Power in pre≈øerving from putrefaction; and be≈øides all the former Di≈øea≈øes for which it is good, he commends it as an excellent thing again≈øt the Lues Venerea, and all Apo≈øtemes proceeding from putrefaction. Do≈øe a gut. iv. ad xij. or xvj.

¬ß 10. If you would take it in a Potion, it will be be≈øt to di≈ø≈øolve it fir≈øt in a little of the Yolk of an Egg, and then to mix it with the Broath, Wine, or Waters which you de≈øign as a Vehiculum. For the Colick anoint it on the Navel and Belly.

div.head: IX. Bal≈øamum Sulphuris Benzo√Ønatum, Benjamin Bal≈øam of Sulphur.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of the Flowers of Sulphur, and Oyl of Benjamin, in like manner as the Ani≈øated Bal≈øam. It is a wonderful Pulmonick and Antia≈øthmatick, and ≈øtrangely prevails in drying up Catarrhs.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. What this Oyl is, and how it it is di≈øtilled, we ≈øhall here ≈øhew. Having made the Flowers of Benjamin, as we ≈øhall hereafter (in this Book) declare; you are to take what remains after the Flowers are ≈øublimed and put into a little Gla≈øs Retort,
and then to di≈øtil with a fit Sand heat a thick and fragrant Oyl, continuing the di≈øtillation till no more will come forth, and nothing but a ≈øpongy Earth remains behind in the Retort.

¬ß 2. Grulingius in Florilegium teaches you to mix the Benjamin with Sand, and to fill the Retort half full, then to di≈øtil with degrees of Fire; ≈øo have you a Water and Oyl thick like Butter: But this is fetid, and not fit for our purpo≈øe, and therefore he pre≈øcribes a rectification; this, tho it renders it more grateful, yet is unfit for this work.

¬ß 3. Charras makes it thus: ‚Ñû Benjamin lb j. in Pouder put it into a Gla≈øs Retort having a longer neck then ordinary; add rectified S. V. lb iij. mix them well, and lute to it a Ve≈ø≈øel of Rencounter, ≈øetting the Retort upright for twenty four hours, upon a very gentle Sand heat, ≈øtirring the Sub≈øtances from time to time to ha≈øten the di≈ø≈øolution of the Benjamin: this done, place the Retort in a Sand heat, take off the Ve≈ø≈øel of Rencounter, and fit to it an half Ball, luted with a wet Bladder, and with a moderate Fire di≈øtil off the Spirit of Wine, after which the Flowers will ri≈øe: as ≈øoon as you ≈øee them appear, ≈øet to a new Receiver, in the place of the former, luting the Juncture ≈ølightly, that you may take out from time to time, the Flowers that ≈øhall fall into it, and ≈øuch as ≈øtop the neck of the Retort, keeping them by them≈øelves for their particular u≈øe. The Flowers being pa≈øt Lute to another Receiver, ≈øo will you have at fir≈øt a thick Liquor or Oyl. 2. An acid Water. 3. A yellow, clear, and odoriferous Oyl, (which is the thing de≈øigned in our Pre≈øcript.) 4. And by continuance a fat and thick Oyl; which is only of u≈øe to clean≈øe and heal old Ulcers.

¬ß 4. We will yet (becau≈øe of the excellency thereof) ≈øhew another way of di≈øtilling our intended Oyl, which is thus: ‚Ñû Benjamin in Pouder, ≈øo much as may fill the third part, or le≈øs, of the Retort, (which if of Gla≈øs mu≈øt be coated) affu≈øe thereon Spirit of Salt, q. s. but ≈øo as the Retort may not be too full, least the matter ≈øhould flow over: place it in Sand, and give Fire by degrees, ≈øo will you have, 1. A Flegm. 2. A clear tran≈øparent Oyl together with the Spirit of Salt, which mu≈øt be kept by it≈øelf. 3. A yellow Oyl, which is to be kept by it≈øelf, and is that intended in the Pre≈øcript. 4. A thick fat Oyl; which,
th√¥ it is not to be ca≈øt away. yet is very unlike to the former, and ≈øerves only for outward u≈øes, to be mixt with Oyntments and Empla≈øters.

¬ß 5. The Water or Flegm is very ≈øubtil and penetrating, good again≈øt Contractions of the Nerves, Pains, Aches, Pal≈øies, &c. The clear Oyl is more powerful, and does Wonders in cold Di≈øea≈øes of the Nerves. The yellow Oyl which is the intended matter of the Pre≈øcript, is yet more powerful than either of the former, and a Specifick in the Pal≈øie, &c.

¬ß 6. Having gotten this yellow odoriferous Oyl of Benjamin, you are to put into it a fourth part of the Flowers of Sulphur, in a Gla≈øs Matra≈øs, which being ≈øtopt up clo≈øe, you are to pur≈øue the Operation in all re≈øpects in the former Ani≈øated Bal≈øam of Sulphur.

¬ß 7. This Bal≈øam is ≈øingularly good for A≈øthmatick Per≈øons, and ≈øuch as Wheeze, are Short-winded, and cannot ea≈øily fetch their Breath; and is e≈øpecially good for ≈øuch as have a vehement Catarrh, which falls violently upon the Bre≈øt and Lungs: It is good again≈øt a Phthi≈øic, or Ulcer of the Lungs, and by its Bal≈øamick property, quickly heals and cures it: It is al≈øo good again≈øt the Colick, and Griping of the Guts, more e≈øpecially if it proceeds from a Dy≈øentery or Bloody-flux. Do≈øe √† gut. vj. ad xij. or xvj.

¬ß 8. Outwardly it is vulnerary, and ≈øpeedily cures any green Wound, or old Ulcer, being applied either alone, or with ≈øome other proper Bal≈øam or Empla≈øter. It cures the Gout, as al≈øo old Aches and Pains proceeding from a cold Cau≈øe, the places afflicted being often anointed therewith, and Cloths dipt in the ≈øame laid thereon, at lea≈øt twice a day.

div.head: X. Bal≈øamum Sulphuris Knoephelii, Knephely his Bal≈øam of Sulphur.
div.p:
Bate.] It is made from the Hepar Sulphuris poudered, p. 4. fre≈øh Lin-≈øeed Oyl, p. iij. and then boiled to a thickne≈øs, and cautiou≈øly di≈øtilled by a Retort; then mixing the Oyl (fir≈øt ≈øeparated from the Water) with half the quantity of the Colcothar of Vitriol, upon a gentle Fire; which being cooled are to be put into a Gla≈øs Retort in Sand, to be di≈øtilled, or rather rectified: this rectified Oyl is to be mixed with half the quantity of Oyl of Ani≈øeed, and to
be dige≈øted, S. A. into a red Bal≈øam. It is a mo≈øt excellent Bal≈øam for the Lungs, drying up Catarrhs, helping A≈øthma's, Coughs, Phthi≈øicks, the Colick, &c. It helps Expectoration, ≈øtops Defluxions to the Joynts, di≈øcu≈ø≈øes Vento≈øities, and prevents them. Do≈øe √† gut. iv. ad xij.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is taken out of the Me≈ø≈øis Medico-Spagyrica, or the Edition of Schroder in Folio, pag. 733. from whence we ≈øhall a little explicate the proce≈øs: moreover, in the original Pre≈øcript the Sulphur and the Lin≈øeed Oyl are in equal quantities.

¬ß 2. ‚Ñû The be≈øt yellow Sulphur finely poudred, fre≈øh made Lin≈øeed-Oyl, A. lb iij. mix them together, and boyl them in a very large Copper Ve≈ø≈øel, but upon a very gentle fire, continually ≈øtirring them with a wooden Spatula, till they begin to grow thick: then remove the Kettle or Skellet from the fire, and put it into a great Ve≈ø≈øel filled with cold Water, ≈øo will the matter a≈øcend, and be conden≈øed like Liver, but all ≈øpongy; which being cooled, and taken out upon a wooden Table, let it be cut into little bits, which put into a ≈øtrong Retort, well luted and coated; then put it into a Reverberatory, affixing a proper Receiver, and di≈øtil with degrees of fire: for the fir≈øt five hours, there comes forth Flegm; after that, a milkie Liquor, which will al≈øo continue for ≈øix or ≈øeven hours: cautiou≈øly proceed farther to fifteen hours, prudently managing the Fire (if you would ≈øave your Receiver, and not take pains in vain, which you are friendly advi≈øed of) till little white Clouds begin to come forth, then increa≈øing the Fire (by adding more Coals) a mo≈øt red Oyl will di≈øtil forth; in which degree of heat continually keep it, till the whole radical humidity is di≈øtilled over, and till no more Clouds appear, then exciting the fire to the highe≈øt violence, ≈øo as the Retort may be red hot, the thick Oyl, like to Butter, will come forth, but yet in ≈ømall quantity.

¬ß 3. In this la≈øt di≈øtillation, you ≈øhall ≈øee the whole Furnace (chiefly in the Night) of a Cerulean colour, for that all the Sulphur being kindled does burn, and the whole Hou≈øe will be filled with a Sulphurous Odour; and almo≈øt all Metalick Ve≈ø≈øels, chiefly ≈øuch as are made of Silver and Copper, or Iron, ≈øpotted and blemi≈øhed, or changed into divers colours, as if they had been ≈øtained
with Verdigri≈øe, ≈øo ≈øubtil is this Spirit, to pierce all the Ve≈ø≈øels, the Walls of the Furnace, and the ≈øeveral Coatings. This Butter, like Oyl being come forth, the Fire is to be removed or dimini≈øhed, that every thing may cool.

¬ß 4. The di≈øtillation being done, the milkie Liquor is to be ≈øeparated from the Oyl, which is wont to coagulate it≈øelf into a thick and ≈øtiff Ma≈øs, which yet notwith≈øtanding, upon the Fire is again ea≈øily melted, and it is to be rectified after this manner:

¬ß 5. ‚Ñû Of this coagulated Oyl p. ij. Colcothar of Vitriol, p. j. mix them upon the Fire in a large Pan, ≈øtirring them with a wooden Spatula: being mixed and cooled, break it into ≈ømall bits, put them into a Gla≈øs Retort, and di≈øtil in Sand, and again in the ≈øpace of twenty four hours the Flegm will come forth with Oyl; then augmenting the Fire, there comes forth together with the Spirits a thick Oyl, not much unlike Glew, which being all come forth, is again to be ≈øeparated from the Flegm.

¬ß 6. ‚Ñû Of this Oyl ≈øeparated from the Flegm; for Example ≈øake, ‚Ñ•iv. Oyl of Ani≈øeeds ‚Ñ•ij. mix them in a Phial hermetically ≈øealed, and dige≈øt for forty days in a gentle and Philo≈øophick dige≈øtion, and ≈øo long till they are perfectly united, ≈øo have you the true Antihectick Tincture, red like a Ruby.

¬ß 7. It is one of the greate≈øt Arcanums that is, for the Cure of the Phthi≈øick, and all Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Lungs, ≈øo that in the World a greater or better is ≈øcarcely to be found (for which the Name of the mo≈øt great and good God be eternally ble≈ø≈øed and prai≈øed). In the Plague it is as it were a Divine Remedy, as well for the pre≈øervation from, as the Cure of that Di≈øea≈øe. And as it is a Bal≈øam for both Lungs and Liver, ≈øo al≈øo it is an excellent Antepileptick and Antilunatick. Do≈øe √† gut. iij. ad x. in any fit Vehicle.

¬ß 8. Now here is to be noted, That the Work will the better ≈øucceed, if ≈øome Salt of Tartar be added by mixing it with the crude Sulphur in the fir≈øt work, before you mix it with the Lin≈øeed Oyl. Agricola in his Tract of Sulphur, pag. 397. and Joh. Poppius in Hodegetico, make mention of this Oily Medicament. So al≈øo Paracel≈øus, Libro de Naturalibus rebus, cap. 8. ¬ß 7. And Rolfincius Artis Chymiae, lib. 4. ≈øect. 1.
art. 1. cap. 2. de≈øcribes it from Paracel≈øus.

¬ß 9. It does wonders in the Colick, Stone, Pal≈øie, Contractions of the Limbs, in expelling Worms, and in healing, old, fetid, and rebellious Ulcers. The white Liquor ≈øeparated in the fir≈øt di≈øtillation (which has no internal u≈øe) is a ≈øingular thing again≈øt the P≈øora, Scab, Lepro≈øie, and an Alopecia Lepro≈øa, or Leprous Falling of the Hair. It is good for Pu≈øtuls, and other Breakings out in the Face and Skin, Scurf, Morphew, Gutta Ro≈øacea, being mixt with other Liquors; and ≈øome ≈øay it is profitable for ≈øuch as labour under an Hydrophobia.

div.head: XI. * Bal≈øamum Sulphuris Succinatum, Bal≈øam of Sulphur with Amber.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of the Flowers of Sulphur with Oyl of Amber, in all re≈øpects as you make the Ani≈øated Bal≈øam. It prevails again≈øt the Colick, &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Vulgar Chymi≈øt has another way of making this Bal≈øam, be≈øides the common way of the Terebinthinated, or Ani≈øated Bal≈øam, and it is thus: ‚Ñû Of the thick Terebinthinated Bal≈øam of Sulphur (the Preparation of which ≈øee in Sect. 12. next following) ‚Ñ•j. Pure Oyl of Amber ‚Ñ•ij. mix them well together, by ≈øhaking them in a Vial, then put them into B. M. and gently boyl them, ≈øo will the Oyl di≈ø≈øolve the Bal≈øams, enter into it, and mix with it, and this is Bal≈øamum Sulphuris Succinatum.

¬ß 2. Other Authors advi≈øe not to boyl the Terebinthinated Bal≈øam, and the Oyl of Amber together, but only to dige≈øt them together in a boyling B. M. till the Bal≈øam is di≈ø≈øolved in the Oyl: but by this way it will be thinner, and want of the true Con≈øi≈øtency of the Bal≈øam of Sulphur.

¬ß 3. It is a good Vulnerary; both inwardly taken, and outwardly applied heals Ulcers of the Lungs; it heats, attenuates, incides, dries, re≈øolves thick Flegm both in Stomach and Lungs, is of good u≈øe again≈øt the Jaundice, Coughs, Colds, and Shortne≈øs of Breath, allays Vapors, and helps Hy≈øterick Fits; and in a word, it is good again≈øt mo≈øt Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt, Lungs, and Womb. It al≈øo kills Worms, and ≈øtrengthens the Bowels. Do≈øe √† gut. iv. ad xx. mixt with ≈øome proper Syrup.

div.head: XII. * Bal≈øamum Sulphuris Terebinthinatum, Bal≈øam of Sulphur Terebinthinated.
div.p: Bate.] It is made with Oyl of Turpentine, as that with Oyl of Ani≈øeeds aforegoing. See the Virtues of the Ani≈øated Bal≈øam.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû Sulphur in fine Pouder, or rather Flowers of Sulphur ‚Ñ•iv. pure Oyl of Turpentine ‚Ñ•xvj. put them into a Gla≈øs Matra≈øs, which place in Sand with a dige≈øting fire for two hours; then increa≈øe it a little for four hours, ≈øo will the Oyl di≈ø≈øolve part of the Sulphur, and extract out of it a red colour: let the Ve≈ø≈øel cool, then ≈øeparate the clear Bal≈øam from the Sulphur that will not di≈ø≈øolve.

¬ß 2. Now here is to be noted, that in making this Bal≈øam, the Matra≈øs ought not to be above half full: and whereas, we here pre≈øcribe it to be made in a Sand heat, ≈øome make it in a boyling Balneo, and fit another Matra≈øs to it, thereby making a double Ve≈ø≈øel.

¬ß 3. In this heat (whether in B. M. or Sand) the Spirit will begin to ≈øimper, and pre≈øently after the Sulphur will melt, and ting the Oyl of a deep red colour: the fire is to be ≈øo govern'd as to hinder the Oyl from boyling, and in about two hours time the Operation will be done; yet it will be better to keep it in the ≈øame heat for three or four hours longer.

¬ß 4. This done, decant the di≈ø≈øolution while it is hot, into an Earthen white Ware Ve≈ø≈øel, ≈øo will the undi≈ø≈øolved Sulphur as it grows cold, ≈øettle to the bottom in a yellow Lump, the pure Bal≈øam remaining above, which then you are to pour off by inclination, and keep in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 5. There is no need of a great Fire for this operation, becau≈øe the Sulphur being a fat Body, does ea≈øily incorporate with Oyls, and commonly gives them a red colour, that which remains undi≈ø≈øolved in the Matra≈øs, Lemery ≈øays, is the acid or ≈øaline part of the Sulphur, and is found cry≈øtallized.
¬ß 6. In this Operation the Oyl draws with the colour the odour al≈øo of the Sulphur, ≈øo much, as almo≈øt to lo≈øe all its own ≈øcent.

¬ß 7. Le Mort fir≈øt mixes the Flowers, p. ij. with Salt of Tartar, p. j. by exactly melting them together, till they are of a blacki≈øh purple colour, then poudering the
Ma≈øs, adds to it double the weight of the Flowers of the Oyl of Turpentine, and then boyls them in a Gla≈øs Matra≈øs in Sand for three hours, after which being cold, he ≈øeparates the clear Bal≈øam for u≈øe.

¬ß 8. And this addition of Salt of Tartar may ≈øeem nece≈ø≈øary, for that thereby the Body of the Sulphur is in a great mea≈øure opened, whereby it the ea≈øier di≈ø≈øolves and yields its Tincture to the Oyl: and tho' without the Salt of Tartar the ≈øub≈øtance of the Sulphur will di≈ø≈øolve in the Oyl; yet by the help thereof, the Bal≈øam is made much more efficacious. So that this Bal≈øam thus made, is nothing but a conjunction of the Sulphur, or its oily parts, with di≈øtilled Oyls, which by the addition of a fixed Salt is accelerated, for that it breaks the Chains of the acid, which holds the particles of the Sulphurous Body together.

¬ß 9. It is a mo≈øt excellent Anodyn and Healer of Wounds and Burns of the Nerves, and Nervous parts: It cures al≈øo Ulcers of the Bre≈øt and Lungs, and is admirable again≈øt Coughs of all ≈øorts, Colds, Hoar≈øene≈øs, Lo≈øs of Voice, Shortne≈øs of Breath, Difficulty of Breathing, and other Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Lungs. It cures al≈øo the Pain of the Ears, being dropt into them. It heats, dries, attenuates, incides, re≈øolves, and provokes both Sweat and Urine. Do≈øe √† gut. iv. ad xx.

¬ß 10. Modus Utendi. ‚Ñû Of this Bal≈øam q. v. mix with it ≈øo much double or treble refined Sugar, as will make it into a kind of a rough moi≈øt Pouder: to which add ≈øo much pure fre≈øh Butter, as may make it into the Body of a Bal≈øam fit to be cut like Butter, of a perfect bright golden colour.

¬ß 11. By this means the Bal≈øam is rendred plea≈øant both to the Eye and Palate, ≈øo that the mo≈øt delicate Stomach will hardly refu≈øe it, it having lo≈øt all the ≈øcent both of the Sulphur and the Oyl, and acquired by the mixing of the Sugar, the true ≈øcent of Lime-Juyce, or Juyce of Limons: but that it may have this ≈ømell certainly, it is requi≈øite that in the fir≈øt making of the Bal≈øam, you never give it ≈øo great a heat as to make it boyl. Of this Bal≈øam thus compounded, the Patient may take the quantity of a pretty large Che≈øtnut, three or four ≈øeveral times a day, and particulary, fir≈øt in the Morning fa≈øting, and la≈øt at Night going
to Bed. It is an admirable thing, and does wonders. Thus compounded, it is given to Children for the Worms.

¬ß 12. The Bal≈øam of Sulphur may al≈øo be reduced to the Con≈øi≈øtence of an Unguent, by evaporation, and then it is of u≈øe to clean≈øe and heal Wounds, e≈øpecially of the Nerves and Nervous parts, and to cure old Ulcers, Running Sores, and Fi≈øtula's. See our Pharm. Lond. lib. 3. cap. 12. ≈øect. 12.

div.head: XIII. Bal≈øamum Tartari, Bal≈øam of Tartar.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Oyl of Tartar per deliquium ‚Ñ•ix. Cremor Tartari poudred ‚Ñ•viij. digest and evaporate to drine≈øs; affu≈øe thereon Spirit of Wine or Vinegar, with which extract a Tincture, filter and ab≈øtract to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Honey, S. A. It is a mo≈øt powerful Medicament again≈øt the Gout and Stone, and loo≈øens the Belly. Do≈øe ad í≈øs. Outwardly parts pained are anointed therewith: It is good al≈øo again≈øt all chronick and ≈øtubborn Di≈øea≈øes.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is the Bal≈øamum Samech Paracel≈øi, who≈øe u≈øual preparation is this: ‚Ñû Of the best Salt of Tartar lb j. and with a ≈øufficient quantity of Water make of it a ≈øtrong Lixivium: take al≈øo Cremor Tartari lb j. and di≈ø≈øolve is in Rain-water by boyling: mix the≈øe Solutions together guttatim, ≈øo long till you ≈øee all the Efferve≈øcence cea≈øe, then immediately filter it, and evaporate to the form of a Salt. To this affu≈øe the be≈øt Tartari≈øed S. V. ≈øo much as may cover or over-top it three or four inches; let it ≈øtand in dige≈øtion, ≈øo long till the S. V. has contracted the highe≈øt redne≈øs; then decant the S. V. and affufe-new S. V. as before; this Work continue till you have extracted all the Tincture out of the Salt: mix the≈øe Tinctures together, and in a Gla≈øs Alembick in B. M. draw off the one half of the Spirit, ≈øo will the Bal≈øam remain at the bottom.

¬ß 2. Now here is to be noted, that the fir≈øt part of the preparation, where the two Liquors being mixt together, till the Efferve≈øcence cea≈øes, then filtrated and evaporated to the form of a Salt, is that which is properly called the Bal≈øamum Samech, and is given √† ‚Ñà≈øs. ad í ≈øs. in ≈øome Diuretick Liquor.

¬ß 3. It is a Medicine that powerfully educes the Tartar of the Blood by Urine, and
effectually expels Sand, Gravel, and Stone from the Reins and Bladder, for which rea≈øon it is e≈øteemed as a potent Medicine again≈øt the Gout. It is exhibited as a Specifick again≈øt the Drop≈øie, Podagra, Scrophula, and Ob≈øtructions of the Terms, Green-≈øickne≈øs in Virgins, &c.
¬ß 4. The Tincture (which is the latter part of the Preparation) has all the ≈øame Virtues with the Salt, but is much more powerful to the ≈øaid intentions, and may be given √† ‚Ñàj. ad íj.

div.head: XIV. Bal≈øamum Veneris, Bal≈øam of Venus.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of Plates of Copper, dige≈øted with Oyl of Turpentine, till a green Bal≈øam is formed, S. A. It chiefly clean≈øes Wounds, Ulcers, Fi≈øtula's, &c. being mixed with other convenient Medicaments.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Schroderus in Pharm. lib. 3. cap. 12. ≈øect. 4. ¬ß 3. advi≈øes to take Filings of Copper, and to add to them Spirit of Turpentine, then to dige≈øt till it is green, ≈øo have you a thing u≈øeful in Chirurgery.

¬ß 2. But the be≈øt way of making this Bal≈øam is thus: ‚Ñû Verdigri≈øe, and di≈ø≈øolve it in Spirit of Vinegar, filter, and ab≈øtract to drine≈øs, or let it cry≈øtallize, ≈øo have you a pure Verdigri≈øe: of this take í j. Spirit or Oyl of Turpentine ‚Ñ•vj. mix and dige≈øt, till the Oyl has drawn the Tincture of the Verdigri≈øe into its Body.

¬ß 3. It is of excellent u≈øe in all inveterate running Sores, old Ulcers, Fi≈øtula's, the Synovia, or Running of Water from Wounds and Ulcers in the Joynts, and all other ≈øtubborn and rebellious Maladies of like nature, doing that which ≈øcarcely any other Medicine will do be≈øides; but it is not u≈øually applied alone. ¬ß 4. The be≈øt way is to mix it with ≈øome other proper Oyntment or Bal≈øam, and ≈øo apply it. It is a Medicament not to be de≈øpi≈øed, tho' it is compo≈øed of things of ≈ømall price, and ea≈øily made.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of ESSENCES, Or POWERS.
I. E≈ø≈øentia Ab≈øinthii, Powers of Wormwood.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû THE Spiritus Ardens, or burning and inflamable Spirit di≈øtilled from the green fermented Herb ‚Ñ•xij, di≈øtilled Oyl of the ≈øame í ij. of the thick Extract of the ≈øame, Salt of Wormwood, A. ‚Ñ•≈øs. dige≈øt them S. A. till they are united, then filter and keep them for u≈øe. After the ≈øame manner you may prepare E≈ø≈øences of other Vegetable Productions.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Ardent or Inflamable Spirit of Wormwood is thus made: ‚Ñû A good quantity of Wormwood newly gathered, brui≈øe it, and put to it (in a wooden Ve≈ø≈øel) a good quantity of Wormwood-Water, or rather Juyce of Wormwood, in every lb vj. of which di≈ø≈øolve lb j. of Sugar, or rather as much Manna, or Honey, let them lie to ferment, till they have acquired a Vinous ≈øcent, then di≈øtil in B. M. drawing off the third part for Spirit of Wormwood, and the ≈øecond third part for Wormwood-Water: what remains in the Still may be cast away.

¬ß 2. This Spirit of Wormwood you mu≈øt Tartari≈øe, or rectifie upon Salt of Tartar, till it is ≈øo pure as it will fire Gunpowder, and is perfectly dephlegmated, otherwi≈øe it will be wholly unfit for this Work.

¬ß 3. The Extract mu≈øt not be made of what remains in the Still after the u≈øual manner; for ≈øeeing it is the Remains of a fermented matter, after the volatile and ≈øubtil Sulphur and Spirit is drawn out of it; it is rea≈øonable to believe the be≈øt parts of it are lo≈øt; and therefore it behoves you to make an Extract of fre≈øh Wormwood, or its Juyce, which yet never pa≈øt any fermentation, for by this means, the Aqueous parts will only a≈øcend, leaving the e≈ø≈øential, ≈øpiritous, and ≈øaline parts behind in the Extract.

¬ß 4. It is thus done: ‚Ñû Juyce of Wormwood, q. v. evaporate in Sand, or B. M. to
drine≈øs: this beat into fine Pouder, and keep for the u≈øe intended.

¬ß 5. The Salt must be made of green Wormwood well calcined to pure white A≈øhes, (for being dryed, it will yield but very little Salt, as that which is once rotten will yield you none). The≈øe A≈øhes you must make a Lixivium of with Wormwood-Water, or Spring-Water, then filtrate and evaporate to drine≈øs, gently calcining of it till it is of a blew colour.

¬ß 6. This being done, you are pre≈øently in an Iron Mortar almo≈øt red hot, to beat it to a ≈øubtil Pouder, mixing it with four or ≈øix times the quantity of fine Pouder of Bone-a≈øhes; and then immediately to put all into the Spirit, with the Oyl of Wormwood, ≈øo will the Oyl joyn with the Spirit, and together extract the Tincture out of the Salt, which by long dige≈øtion will be of an inten≈øe red colour.

¬ß 7. The Spirit Oyl and Salt having been mixt and dige≈øted together a Month, (for in much le≈øs time the Tincture of the Salt will not be drawn out) you are to put in the Pouder of the Extract, which being dige≈øted about ten days, ≈øhaking it well once every day, you may then decant the clear Tincture of the Extract, which you are to filter, and keep in a Bottle clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe. This is the ESSENCE, or rather POWERS of Wormwood.

¬ß 8. And this is the common way of making the Pote≈øtates, or Powers of Vegetables, which is with the Spirit, Oyl, and fixt Salt of the Plant; but there is a better way of doing it, with Spirit, Oyl, and Volatile Salt of Plants, (which Volatile Salt all Plants have) which how that Volatile Salt is to be made, we ≈øhall in its proper place teach.

¬ß 9. The Virtues: The≈øe Pote≈øtates, or Powers are po≈ø≈øibly the greate≈øt Stomatick Medicament that is in rerum Natura, for they clean≈øe, ≈øtrengthen, and fortifie the Stomach to a wonder, making it able to dige≈øt Food, th√¥ almo≈øt never ≈øo weak; I ≈øpeak what I know by Experience upon my own Body, be≈øides the u≈øe of the Medicine a thou≈øand times in other Patients. It is clean≈øing, yet a little Styptick, Stomatick, Splenetick, Hepatick, Opening, Attenuating, Di≈øcutient, Sudorifick, Antifebritick, Hypnotick, and Strengthning.

¬ß 10. It prevents and helps Surfeits and Feavers, chiefly Tertians, opens Ob≈øtructions of the Liver, Womb, and Reins; it is Alexipharmick, re≈øi≈øts Poy≈øon, and cures the Plague, and all Malign and Pe≈øtilential Feavers, as al≈øo the Cachexia, Drop≈øie, and Jaundice.

¬ß 11. It is Sudorifick, expelling watry Humors thro' the pores of the skin, expels Wind, and gives ea≈øe in the Colick and Griping of the Guts‚ñ™ It is a Pre≈øervative from ill Airs and Scents, and again≈øt Pe≈øtilential Infection, for that it wonderfully re≈øi≈øts Putrefaction: It cures ≈øtinking Breaths, evacuates Choler, and kills Worms in Children. Do≈øe √† gut. xx. ad lx.

¬ß 12. Utendi modus. ‚Ñû Pote≈øtatum Ab≈øinthii í ≈øs. Spirit of Saffron ‚Ñàj. Tincture of Musk and Ambergri≈øe gut. iv. Damask Ro≈øe-water ‚Ñ•iij. Syrup of Poppies í iij. mix for a Cordial Do≈øe, for a Man or Woman, or for two Do≈øes for a Child. This mixture is good again≈øt any Deliquium of the Spirits, as fainting and ≈øwooning Fits ≈øickne≈øs at Stomach, Vomiting, Palpitation of the Heart, and other Di≈øea≈øes of like kind. See our Doron Medicum, lib. 2. cap. 5. ≈øect. 1. where the Virtues of the≈øe Powers are more fully explicated. Price Eighteen-pence an Ounce.

div.head: II. E≈ø≈øentia Cardui Benedicti, Powers of Carduus Benedictus.
div.p: Bate.] This E≈ø≈øence is made in all re≈øpects like that of Wormwood aforegoing.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Powers of Carduus Ben. are not to be accounted among the number of mean Remedies, for that they have an admirable force again≈øt all putrefactive and contagious Di≈øea≈øes, and therefore are ≈øaid to be a ≈øure Antidote again≈øt the Smallpox, Mea≈øles, Spotted Feaver, Callentures, Plague and all malign and pe≈øtilential Di≈øea≈øes.

¬ß 4. They are Cephalick, Neurotick, and Antihy≈øterick, cure Head-achs, Lethargies, Vertigo's, Lo≈øs of Memory, Deafne≈øs, and Dimne≈øs of the Sight; they are ≈øaid to cure Quartans, allay Vapours, and re≈øi≈øt Hy≈øterick Fits. Do≈øe √† ‚Ñàj. ad í j. or ‚Ñàiv.

¬ß 2. They are al≈øo good again≈øt inward Brui≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Stomach, Spitting of Blood, Apo≈øtems, Tumors, and Ulcers of the Lungs, as al≈øo a Peripneumonica, or Inflamation of tho≈øe parts: they are of thin and ≈øubtil parts, and as they open Ob≈øtructions, ≈øo likewi≈øe they clean≈øe and dige≈øt, and ripens Tumours in the Mouth, Throat, and Bre≈øt.

You may mix them with any Vulnerary, Lotion ‚Ñ•ij. to a pint, and ≈øo wa≈øh therewith, by which means the healing will be advanced more than five to one. Do≈øe inwardly √† í ≈øs. ad í j. or ‚Ñàiv.

div.head: IV. E≈ø≈øentia Martis, E≈ø≈øence of Mars.
div.p:
Bate.] ‚Ñû Filings of Mars ‚Ñ•iv, put them into a long, or capacious Gla≈øs, and affu≈øe thereon Spirit of Nitre ‚Ñ•iij. rectified Oyl of Vitriol ‚Ñ•ij. ≈øtirring

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This Recipe is taken from Grulingius his Florilegium, par. 19. cap. 2. ≈øect. 3. where he advi≈øes to take ‚Ñ•iv. or vj. of the pure Filings of Mars, and to put in the Spirit of Nitre, and Oyl of Vitriol by drops, and lei≈øurely, lest there ≈øhould be too great an Efferve≈øcence, and the Matter ≈øhould be as it were inflamed, then to ≈øtir the Matter with an Iron Spatula, lest it ≈øhould grow hard and break the Ve≈ø≈øel: and the Spirit being all dropt in, to dilute the Ma≈øs (before it is too compact) with Flegm of Vitriol ‚Ñ•x. or as much of the Flegm of the acid Spirit of Sal Armoniack by which a rubicund or highly yellow E≈ø≈øence will be made.
¬ß 2. Now here is to be noted, That this E≈ø≈øence may be made only with Spirit of Nitre, and Flegm of Vitriol, the Oyl of Vitriol being omitted.

¬ß 3. It is a powerful Opener of all Ob≈øtructions of the Liver, Spleen, Me≈øentery and Womb, in≈øomuch, that tho≈øe who look like Death it≈øelf, and are ≈øcarcely able to go the length of an ordinary Room, or move or ≈øtir about, it gives relief to in three or four times taking, in≈øomuch, that it ≈øeems to be a Miracle of a Medicine; nor will any Man ≈øcarcely be able to believe what a mighty alteration it will ≈øo ≈øuddenly make, in the mo≈øt deplorable Objects of that kind, that ≈øhall not behold the ≈øame with his Eyes, as we have done, ≈øo that to ≈øay all that has been truly done with it, would be to an incredulous or ignorant Man, only a kind of a farfetcht, or ≈øtrained Romance.

¬ß 4. It provokes the Terms in Women, and cures all the other Di≈øea≈øes mentioned by our Author; and mo≈øt effectually ≈øoftens and re≈øolves the harde≈øt external Tumors, e≈øpecially ≈øuch as proceed from a ≈øcrophulous Humour, or Habit of Body.

¬ß 5. Grulingius in the place cited, gives us a Hi≈øtory of a very hard Tumor of the nature of a Wen, which was in his Wri≈øt near his Hand, which by the only application

¬ß 6. But if you would render this E≈ø≈øence more efficacious in Di≈øea≈øes of the Liver, and Di≈øaffections of the Womb, he advi≈øes you to compound it after this manner: ‚Ñû Zwelfer's true ≈øoluble Magi≈øtery of Red Coral (prepared with the Spirit of Venus, ≈øee pag. 54. of his Appendix) í vj. di≈ø≈øolve it in the best Cinamon-water ‚Ñ•i≈øs. then add of this E≈ø≈øence of Mars ‚Ñ•ij. mix them, ≈øo have you a deob≈øtructive hepatick E≈ø≈øence, which contains both the Virtues of the ≈øaid Tincture of Mars, and Magi≈øtery of Coral, both thing and name.

¬ß 7. In this fir≈øt E≈ø≈øence of Mars, this is to be ob≈øerved, That if the humidity be ab≈øtracted by di≈øtillation, none of the Vitriol will be left behind, but it will al≈øo a≈øcend and come over the Helm; whereas in other Solutions of Mars, made with Spirit or Oyl of Vitriol alone, it will not; by which it is evident, that this Preparation is much more ≈øubtil and volatile, and con≈øequently more penetrating, than any of the≈øe Preparations can po≈ø≈øibly be.

¬ß 8. Marggrave makes the E≈ø≈øence of Mars after this manner: ‚Ñû Pure Filings of Mars í ij. Spirit of Vinegar ‚Ñ•iij. put them into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, and digest in Sand for a Day and Night, increa≈øing the Fire to the ≈øecond and third degree, and in twenty four hours time you will extract a most red Tincture, which decant and filter: add to this double or treble refined Sugar, ≈øuch a quantity as may bring it to the con≈øi≈øtency of a Syrup, and Aromatize it with two or thre ‚Ä¢ drops of Oyl of Cinamon, or Cloves.

¬ß 9. This E≈ø≈øence attemperates the Acrimony of acid Humors, and melts them though never ≈øo tough and obdurate, opens Ob≈øtructions, ≈øtimulates the Womb to action, cures Cachexies, Jaundice, Scurvy, &c. Do≈øe half a ≈øpoonful in Wine or Ale.

div.head: V. E≈ø≈øentia Pulegii, Powers of Pennyroyal.

div.head: ESSENCES added by the Tran≈ølator, out of Collectanea Chymica.
VI. ‚Ä° E≈ø≈øentia Regia, The Royal Powers.
div.p: ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû Musk ‚Ñà≈øs. Civet gr. v. Bal≈øam of Peru, gut. xij. Oyl of Cloves, gut. iv. Oyl of Rhodium, gut. ij. Salt of Tartar í ≈øs. mix them all well together, and digest till they are well united; then add Tartari≈øed S.V. ‚Ñ•ij. keep them together in a warm Plate for three days, ≈øtirring or ≈øhaking them twice a day; after, ≈øeparate the clear from the faeces by inclination, ≈øo have you a most odoriferous E≈ø≈øence.

div.head: VII. ‚Ä° E≈ø≈øentia Metallica ad Vermes, Metallick Powers again≈øt Worms.

¬ß 3. Le Mort makes it of Flowers of Benjamin, thus: ‚Ñû Flowers of Benjamin ‚Ñ•j. rectified S. V. twice di≈øtilled from Carminatives ‚Ñ•iv. mix and dige≈øt with a gentle heat, in a Vial with a long Neck, or Bolt-head, till the Spirit is tinged of a deep yellow colour.

¬ß 4. This, ≈øays he, contains much greater Virtues than the ≈øimple Flowers of Benjamin. It di≈øcu≈ø≈øes Wind, cures an inveterate A≈øthma and Cough, and helps the ≈øhortne≈øs of Breath, and difficulty of Breathing, as al≈øo gives pre≈øent ea≈øe in the Colick. Do≈øe √† gut. vj. ad xx. or xxiv.

¬ß 5. Or thus, from the ≈øame Le Mort: ‚Ñû Tartari≈øed S. V. ‚Ñ•iij. or iv. Benjamin in fine Pouder ‚Ñ•i. Oyl of Rhodium gut vj. dige≈øt till the Spirit is tinged of a rubicund colour. Take of this ≈øome drops, and mix it with an Ounce of Damask Ro≈øe-water, and it will become like Milk; it helps Spots and Pimples in the Face, Redne≈øs of the Eyes, and is good again≈øt all ≈øorts of Inflamations. Inwardly you may give it mixt with Syrup of Hy≈ø≈øop, Liquorice, or Coltsfoot, and exhibit it to ≈øuch as are A≈øthmatick.

¬ß 6. He prepares it al≈øo thus: ‚Ñû Tartari≈øed S. V. ‚Ñ•ij. Flowers of Benjamin í i≈øs. Styrax Calamita, í ≈øs. Oyl of Rhodium, gut. vij. Musk gr. iij. Civet gr. ij. mix and dige≈øt, till the Tincture is of a rubicund
colour; then decant the clear from the feces.

¬ß 7. Of this he makes a Lac Virginale thus: ‚Ñû Of this Tincture í i. Water of white Lillies, or white Ro≈øes, or of Damask Ro≈øes ‚Ñ•ij. mix them: It cures Inflamations of the Eyes, and an Ery≈øipelas, &c. It is a mo≈øt precious thing even for the mo≈øt noble and delicate ≈øort of People.

¬ß 8. It is al≈øo thus made: ‚Ñû Flowers of Benjamin ‚Ñ•j. Styrax Calamita ‚Ñ•≈øs. Oyl of Rhodium, or of Je≈ø≈øamy, gut. viij. Civet gr. viij. mix the Civet and Styrax together, then add the Oyl of Rhodium, and after that the Flowers of Benjamin, to which affu≈øe the S. V. and dige≈øt two or three days, then decanting the clear from the feces.

¬ß 9. This la≈øt Preparation is an excellent Perfume, for Gloves, Cloaths, Linnen, &c. in this manner: ‚Ñû Damask Ro≈øe-water, or other perfumed Water ‚Ñ•i. of this Tincture forty drops, in which let them be dipt or be≈ømeared, and then gently dried in the ≈øhade: It is al≈øo accounted an excellent Co≈ømetick, wa≈øhing the skin therewith; and allays Inflamations, more e≈øpecially if a little Camphir be added to the Tincture.

¬ß 10. This of our Author's Pre≈øcription (as well as all the Preparations following it) is an admirable Pectoral, and Antia≈øthmatick, helping ≈øuch as are troubled with difficulty of Breathing, or ≈øhortne≈øs of Breath. It is Cordial, moves Sweat, and by rea≈øon of its fragrant Odour wonderfully comforts the Animal Spirits, ≈øuppre≈ø≈øes noxious Vapors, and re≈øi≈øts the malignity of Contagious Feavers. Do≈øe √† gut. x. ad xxx. in any proper Vehicle.
¬ß 11. Locum Ambrae-gry≈øieae obtinere pote≈øt, ≈øi loco Spiritus Vini & Olei Ligni Rhodii, ≈øub≈øtituatur Spiritus Ro≈øarum Dama≈øcenarum fragranti≈ø≈øimus & Oleum Cinnamomi eadem proportione.

div.head: III. * Tinctura Antimonii Emetica, Vomiting Tincture of Antimony.
div.p:
Bate.] It is extracted out of the Gla≈øs of Antimony with Spirit of Vinegar, then filtring and exhaling to drine≈øs. The Matter di≈ø≈øolved in Water, filtrated, and again ab≈øtracted to drine≈øs, dige≈øt with [Tartariz'd] S. V. till it is of a rubicund colour, which filter. A Tincture may al≈øo be extracted from the Scoria of the Regulus
of Antimony, with Tartari≈øed S. V. dige≈øted and filtred. Or you may extract a Tincture from the Vitrum Antimonii, with rectified Spirit of Venus, which being decanted, may be ab≈øtracted in an Alembick, but not to drine≈øs; then extract the Tincture therefrom with rectified S. V. which filter, and exhale to a convenient thickne≈øs. Do≈øe to gr. x.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The≈øe Preparations are in general Terms; but becau≈øe the Medicine is admirable beyond many others of much greater Names and Account, and becau≈øe by the≈øe general Pre≈øcriptions (for want of Proportions) the young Tyro may ea≈øily err in the Proce≈øs, we ≈øhall take the pains to explicate every thing more particularly.

¬ß 2. Maets makes it thus: ‚Ñû Alcohol of Vitrum Antimonii q. v. affu≈øe thereon rectified Spirit of Venus drawn with Mineral Sulphur, ≈øo much as may over-top it three inches: ≈øet it in a continual dige≈øtion, ≈øtirring it with a wooden ≈øtick two or three times a day, ≈øo long till the Men≈øtruum has extracted a mo≈øt yellow Tincture from the Antimony: decant the Tincture, and if you think good, affu≈øe more fre≈øh Men≈øtruum, extracting as before: mix the Tinctures, and by a Gla≈øs Alembick ab≈øtract the humidity, till the Magma is of the thickne≈øs of Oyl: to this Magma affu≈øe Alcohol of S. V. ≈øo much as may over-top it the depth of three inches; ≈øet it in a warm dige≈øtion, till the Spirit is impregnated with the Tincture of Antimony; which decant, and in a Gla≈øs Alembeck in B. M. ab≈øtract the S. V. to one half, ≈øo will the Tincture of Antimony remain behind.

¬ß 3. This Tincture, if you would have it high coloured, and more efficacious, you mu≈øt impregnate it with the Crocus of Sol thus: ‚Ñû Of this Tincture of Antimony p. iij. Croci Solis p. j. mix them in a Porcelane Ve≈ø≈øel, and over a gentle Fire evaporate to drine≈øs. This is a dry Tincture, and is given √† gr. ij. ad vj. again≈øt all Di≈øea≈øes which are to be cured by Sweat, as Mea≈øles, Small-pox, Spotted Feaver, Plague or Pe≈øtilence, and all kinds of Pe≈øtilential and Malign Di≈øea≈øes, but chiefly in the French-Pox, Lepro≈øie, profound Scab, inveterate Herpes, Apoplexies, Contractures, &c.

¬ß 4. This Crocus of Sol is thus made: ‚Ñû Pure Sol purged by Antimony p. j. purified Mercury p. vj. make S. A. an
Amalgama, which commix with double its whole quantity of Sulphur: mix them well, and calcine them upon a Tile, continually ≈øtirring it, till all the Sulphur and Mercury are gone; ≈øo have you the Crocus Solis, which wa≈øh, and dry for u≈øe.

¬ß 5. Le Mort makes it thus: ‚Ñû Alcohol of Vitrum Antim. q. v. ≈øweet Spirit of Salt. to which a few drops of Spirit of Nitre are added: mix and dige≈øt for ≈øome days, till a very yellow Tincture is extracted: this decant, and draw off the Spirit in B. M. till a fourth part only remains, to which affu≈øe Alcohol of S. V. ‚Ñ•xij. and dige≈øt as before, ≈øo have you a Tincture of great Virtues.

¬ß 6. Or thus: ‚Ñû Rectified Spirit of Salt ‚Ñ•iij. rectified Spirit of Nitre ‚Ñ•ij. Alcohol of S. V. ‚Ñ•xij. dige≈øt, and then di≈øtil, cohobating twice, till the Spirits are well united, with which extract a Tincture as before. This Tincture, ≈øays he, is like a Panacea in all Di≈øea≈øes which are to be cured by Sweat, which it performs with much le≈øs labour and time, than the Tincture which is made by the help of di≈øtilled Vinegar, and may be given √† gut. j. ad x. or xx. in Wine.

¬ß 7. He al≈øo has this: ‚Ñû ‚Ñû Antimony, Nitre, A. p. j. Salt of Tartar p. ij. mix them well, and put them by ≈øpoonfuls into a large red hot Crucible, letting them melt together for at lea≈øt half an hour: then being cooled, let the matter be poudred, and with Tartariz'd S. V. q. s. or ≈øo much as may over-top the Pouder three or four inches, extract a Blood-red Tincture, by dige≈øting for ≈øome days in a Phial clo≈øe ≈øtopt: this Tincture decant, and affu≈øe new Spirit upon the feces, dige≈øting as before, and thus continuing till the matter will yield no more Tincture: all the≈øe Extractions mix, and ob≈øtract the Spirit in B. M. till one half only remains.

¬ß 8. Marggrave makes it thus: ‚Ñû Alcohol of Vitrum Antimonii ‚Ñ•i. put it into a Gla≈øs Matra≈øs, to which put rectified Spirit of Venus ‚Ñ•iv. ≈øtop it clo≈øe, and dige≈øt fourteen days in a gentle heat, till the Tincture is of a Blood-red colour: this decant gently from the feces, and ≈øo often till it is perfectly fine and pure: then put it into a Gla≈øs Retort, and with a gentle Fire (or if it may be in B. M.) draw off the Spirit of Venus to drine≈øs: ≈øic recuperabitur Spiritus Veneris:) in the bottom you have a rubicund Pouder, to which affu≈øe Tartari≈øed S. V. ≈øo much
as may over-top it the depth of four inches: dige≈øt for ≈øome days, till you have a red Tincture, which decant, and by a Gla≈øs Retort ab≈øtract the Spirit to one half; ≈øo will there remain a rubicund Liquor, fat like Oyl, which Chymi≈øts call the Gemuine Tincture of Antimony.

¬ß 9. Charras extracts the Tincture thus: ‚Ñû Alcohol of Vitrum Antimonii ‚Ñ•ij. put it into a Matra≈øs; and affu≈øe thereon rectified Oyl of Amber, or of Juniper Berries, or of Turpentine ‚Ñ•xx. cover it with its blind Head, lute the Juncture, and dige≈øt in a ≈øtrong Sand heat, till the Liquor ≈øeems ready to boil, which continue till it is very deeply coloured. This Tincture works by Stool, or by Sweat, and is given √† gut. ij. ad v. or vj. in any proper Liquor.

¬ß 10. Le Febure has two ways of making this Tincture, First, With the Spirit of Venus, as we have taught from Marggrave at ¬ß 8. above. Secondly, With this following Men≈øtruum: The Men≈øtruum: ‚Ñû Choice Vitriol, pure common Salt, Quick-lime A lb j, Sal Armoniack ‚Ñ•iv. make each feverally into Pouder, then mix them, and put them into a Cucurbit, adding good Spirit of Vinegar lb iij. cover it with its blind Head, which lute on, and dige≈øt with a ≈ølow heat twenty four hours, which done, put all into a Report, and with degrees of Fire, draw the Spirit in about twenty four or thirty hours: weigh the Spirit di≈øtilled, and add its equal weight of common Salt to it, and rectifie it in a gradual heat, ≈øo as what di≈øtils may come over fair and clear, and nothing of troubledne≈øs in it.

¬ß 11. Then take Alcohol of Vitrum Antimonii lb j. put it into a large Matra≈øs, upon which affu≈øe the former prepared Men≈øtruum: mix them together, and put them into dige≈øtion in A≈øhes, in an equal heat, till the Vitrum is di≈ø≈øolved: decant the clear by inclination, and filter the remainder; put all into a Cucurbit, which cover with its Head: lute and place it in B. M. and di≈øtil to drine≈øs with a gentle heat: at bottom of the Cucurbit will be a thick blacki≈øh matter, which in a cold Cellar upon a ≈øquare Gla≈øs will di≈ø≈øolve into an oily or red Liquor, which Liquor put into a ≈ømall gla≈øs Cucurbit, and in A≈øhes ab≈øtact the moi≈øture to drine≈øs; this done, immediately (before it takes air) affu≈øe thereon Alcohol of S. V. put all into a Pellican, or double Dige≈øter, lu ‚Ä¢ e the Joynts,
and dige≈øt in a very gentle Bal. Vap. till the Spirit is tinged of a fair high red colour, which decant, and add more Spirit, thus continuing till the Spirit will be no more tinged: tho≈øe Tinctures mix, filtrate, and ab≈øtract from them two thirds of their Spirit, in a gentle B. M. ≈øo will the wonderful, and almo≈øt invaluable Tincture be left at the bottom for u≈øe.

¬ß 12. Now here is to be noted, That this red Liquor made in the Cellar upon a ≈øquare Gla≈øs, is one of the be≈øt Bal≈øams in the World, for curing of Wounds, and all kind of malignant Ulcers, be they never ≈øo inveterate or dangerous, but chiefly tho≈øe which proceed from the Pox, Kings-Evil, Cancers, &c. It is al≈øo good agan≈øt Pocky Nodes, for which rea≈øon it is nece≈ø≈øary always to be kept in the form ready prepared.

¬ß 13. The Virtues of the≈øe Tinctures of Antimony. Le Febure ≈øaith, They are endowed with infinite Virtues; for they are Soveraign Remedies again≈øt all inveterate Ob≈øtructions of the Liver and Spleen, and all other parts of the inferiour Ventricle; they open Ob≈øtructions of the Lungs, provoke the Terms, cure the Green-≈øickne≈øs, Yellow and Black Jaundice, Drop≈øy, Phthi≈øick, A≈øthma, Difficulty of Breathing, Pleuri≈øie, Cachexia, and Hypochondriacal Melancholly.

¬ß 14. They are excellent again≈øt all manner of Ulcers, both internal and external, th√¥ in the Lungs, Stomach, Reins, and Ureters, or Bladder, are good again≈øt the Lepro≈øie, Plague, Great and Small-pox, and all ≈øorts of Pe≈øtilential and Malignant Feavers, as Mea≈øles, Spotted Feaver, &c. They are good again≈øt all kinds of Itch, Scabs, and Breakings-out, and generally all ill Humors and Habits of Body which de≈øtroy Health.

¬ß 15. They purge and drive away whatever is hateful to the Body, by Sweat, Urine, and in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration, and ≈øometimes by Vomit: The Do≈øe in general may be from gut. iij. ad x. or xij. in Spani≈øh Wine, or Canary, or Mead, Hydromel, or other Analagous Liquor. Let it be taken in Bed, the ≈øick expecting its Sudorifick operation, reiter√†ting it every day, or every ≈øecond or third day, as need requires: but for prevention of any Sickne≈øs, once a week will be enough, or ≈øeldomer.

div.head: IV. Tinctura Antimonii Purgans, Purging Tincture of Antimony.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Gla≈øs of Antimony finely poudred ‚Ñ•i. Spirit of Vitriol not rectified ‚Ñ•viij. dige≈øt in B. M. till the Tincture becomes of a black red colour. It is accounted as a Panchymagogon for the cure of all Di≈øea≈øes: it ≈øtrengthens the Stomach, opens Ob≈øtructions, cures the Green-≈øickne≈øs, Cachexia, &c. Do≈øe √† gut. vj. ad x.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This Tincture is drawn from the Sulphur of the Antimony, which in its own nature is an Emetick, and ≈øo would be now, were it drawn with many other Vehicles, or not corrected with the Spirit of Vitriol, which Spirit does two things at once, viz. both draws the Tincture, and corrects it.

¬ß 2. The ≈øame may al≈øo be done with Spirit of Sulphur in like manner, and it will have the ≈øame operation downwards which this has, whereas that which is drawn with Spirit of Vinegar, is for the mo≈øt part wholly Emetick.

¬ß 3. It may al≈øo be made with Spirit of Venus drawn from Vitriol of Venus, or from Verdigri≈øe, in all re≈øpects as you make common Oyl of Vitriol, and with this Men≈øtruum it is that Maets makes it, who ≈øaith, It is good again≈øt all Di≈øea≈øes which are to be cured by Sweat, and is of principal u≈øe again≈øt the Lepro≈øie, and French Di≈øea≈øe, as al≈øo again≈øt inveterate Fevers, Apoplexies, &c.

¬ß 4. Le Mort makes it with ≈øweet Spirit of Salt, adding only a few drops of Spirit of Nitre: But that the Nitre does little, I am very well ≈øatisfied, for putting the Spirit of Nitre alone upon the Pouder of the Vitrum, it makes no alteration at all, whereas if to the Spirit of Nitre you add as much Spirit of Vitriol, it will ≈øo di≈ø≈øolve the Vitrum, as the whole will become a Pulp, and drink up all the humidity, and this it will continually do, till the Vitrum has drunk up ≈øeven or eight times its weight of the Spirit of Vitriol; this Ma≈øs being wa≈øhed with fair warm Water, ≈øeveral times, till it is freed from the Salts, leaves a Milk or rather Cream white Pouder behind it, which will work both upwards and downwards in a ≈ømall Do≈øe, (th√¥ mo≈øtly downwards) and in a very ≈ømall Do≈øe, viz. √† half gr. ad gr. ii≈øs. but generally
gr. j. will be Do≈øe large enough for any ordinary Per≈øon; or gr. i≈øs. at mo≈øt, very few Con≈øtitutions being able to bear gr. ij. and a half, or gr. iij.

¬ß 5. This Tincture is accounted as a Panacaea again≈øt all Di≈øea≈øes, which require much labour and time in curing: I know it to be a Specifick again≈øt the Kings-Evil, and in that Di≈øea≈øe I have done wonders with it: it is a Specifick al≈øo again≈øt all ≈øorts of Feavers, and powerfully opens all Ob≈øtructions in both Reins and Bladder; and cures the Green≈øickne≈øs in Virgins. It re≈øi≈øts Putrefaction, and the Plague, and all manner of Infection and Poy≈øon. It purifies and corroborates the Blood, and frees it from all Impurities, rendering it, as ≈øome Authors ≈øay, incorruptible. Dicitur curare Elephantia≈øin, Lepram, omne≈øque alios in≈øanabiles morbos. Collect. Chym. pag. 48.

div.head: V. Tinctura Armoniaci, Tincture of Sal Armoniack.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Sal Armoniack lbij. [Filings] of Mars lbj. mix them well together by beating and grinding, and di≈øtil them by a Retort with a gradual heat: ≈øave the Spirit of Sal Armoniack by it≈øelf: The Mars remaining at the bottom of the Retort, pouder and ≈øweeten it by manifold wa≈øhings with fair Water: after add Spirit of Wine lbij. and dige≈øt warm for eight days: decant the Spirit, and affu≈øe new Spirits, dige≈øting as before eight days: then ab≈øtract the Spirit of Wine lbiij. in B. M. ≈øo that lbj. only may remain, which is the Tincture. It prevails wonderfully in opening all Ob≈øtructions of both Liver and Spleen; al≈øo again≈øt Hypochondriack Melancholly, Quartane Agues, the Cachexie, Drop≈øie, Green≈øickne≈øs, Scurvy, Stoppage of the Terms, and their too much overflowing. Do≈øe √† gut. vj. ad xij. in any convenient Liquor.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is rather a Tincture of Mars, than a Tincture of Sal Armoniack, the chief work of the Salt being to open the Body of the Mars, that it may the better yield its Tincture.

¬ß 2. But Le Febure makes it of Vitriol of Mars after this manner: ‚Ñû White Vitriol of Mars (prepared as we ≈øhall hereafter teach) ‚Ñ•ij. in fine Pouder, and as much Sal Tartari foliated (but ≈øome ≈øay Sal
Saturni, others Sal Armoniack) in Pouder: mix them in a Marble Mortar, ≈øo will the Salt on a ≈øudden, after a wonderful manner, draw forth the Soul of the Mars, or its Sulphur, out of the Center of its Vitriol; for altho' this Vitriol is white, and this Salt al≈øo, yet in an in≈øtant will a deep red predominate, higher in colour than that of Saffron: this Ma≈øs ≈øtir ≈øo long till it is reduced to a pap, then expo≈øe it to the moi≈øt Air, that the whole may be re≈øolved into a Liquor, which is already an Aperitive and Deopulative Remedy, and may be given again≈øt all manner of Ob≈øtructions, and again≈øt the coagulation of Tartar in Man's Body, from gut. vj. ad xvj. in any Broth or proper Vehicle.

¬ß 3. But this is not the perfection Le Febure aims at: To this end, ≈øaith he, weigh this red matter or ≈øub≈øtance, after mixing in the Marble Mortar, and note the weight: weigh it al≈øo after the di≈ø≈øolution in the open Air; to draw off by di≈øtillation in B. M. the weight of the moi≈øture it has attracted, and to pour upon it as much Spirit of Venus, as that moi≈øture weights: then dige≈øt in Bal. V. in a dige≈øting or double Ve≈ø≈øel for twenty four hours, after which draw off the Spirit with a Still-head, till the remainder is of the con≈øi≈øtency of a Syrup, upon which put Tartari≈øed S. V. to over-top it four inches; clo≈øe up the Ve≈ø≈øel with a blind Head, dige≈øting three days; after which filtrate the Tincture cold, and then draw off half of the Spirit in B. M. with a ≈ølow heat, ≈øo have you a noble Tincture, as well plea≈øant in Ta≈øt, as excellent in Virtue.

¬ß 4. This excellent Tincture of Le Febure's does re≈øolve all ≈øorts of Tartar in Mans Body, (the cau≈øe of all Ob≈øtructions) opens Opilations of the Liver and Spleen, and may be ≈øafely and profitably given again≈øt all Di≈øea≈øes proceeding from Stoppages in any part; but the mo≈øt wonderful thing of all is, that it bears no weight upon the Stomach, as mo≈øt Medicines prepared from Mars do; but on the contrary, it ≈øtrengthens the Ventricle, purifying it from tartarous, coagulated, and clammy Humors and Vi≈øco≈øities, which are for the mo≈øt part the cau≈øe of the Scurvy, lo≈øs of Appetite, Di≈øaffections of the Spleen, Putrefaction of the Blood, Gout, Stone, Jaundice, Drop≈øie, Rheumati≈øm, and many other pernicious Di≈øea≈øes. Do≈øe √† gut. vj. ad
xxx. in ≈øome proper Liquor.

¬ß 5. But the Tincture of our Author is exactly taken from Myn≈øicht's The≈øaurus ≈øect. 2. pag. 49. of the Leyden Impre≈ø≈øion; who commends it as a ≈øingular Experiment again≈øt all Ob≈øtructions, Hypochondriack Di≈øaffections, &c. being given in Wine, or ≈øome proper Syrup or Decoction, by means of which Vehicle it will the more ea≈øily penetrate to the more remote parts and corners of the Body: but in the u≈øe hereof this is to be ob≈øerved, that the Body ought often to be purged from the peccant Humors, and a good Diet to be ob≈øerved.

¬ß 6. Rolfincius in his Art. Chym. lib. 4. ≈øect. 1. art. 3. cap. 11. has it exactly according to Myn≈øicht, and our Author's, but in cap. 13. almo≈øt after Le Febure's Method, thus: ‚Ñû Vitriol of Mars in Pouder, but not calcined, Terrae foliatae Tartari, A. ‚Ñ•i. mix and place them in a cold and moi≈øt Cellar for three days; the colour being changed, and the mixture rendred fluid by the intromi≈ø≈øion of the Air, let it be ≈øtrained, and add thereto Spirit of Wine. Do≈øe. gr. xx. ad xxx in Wine, or Broth, again≈øt Ob≈øtructions of the Vi≈øcera, and other the aforenamed Di≈øea≈øes.

div.head: VI. Tinctura A≈øae fetida, Tincture of ≈øtinking A≈ø≈øa.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû A≈øa fetida ‚Ñ•ij. Alcohol of S. V. lb j. mix, and extract a Tincture. It is Uterine, Traumatick Splenetick. Do≈øe √† íj. ad íij. &c. in any proper Liquor.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It is hot and dry in quality, and therefore of excellent u≈øe to dry up the Humidities of the Brain, and is u≈øed chiefly in the Suffocation of the Womb, Peripneumony, and Wounds, whether inward or outward; as al≈øo again≈øt the Epilep≈øie, Vertigo, Apoplexy, and other Di≈øea≈øes of the Head.
¬ß 2. It is good again≈øt √† ≈øwoln Spleen, Suffocation of the Womb, Vapors, &c. being bathed upon tho≈øe parts. Ulcers al≈øo being wa≈øhed with it, it di≈øpo≈øes them to a more ≈øpeedy healing.

¬ß 3. But for the Epilep≈øie, and other Di≈øea≈øes of the Head and Womb, it would be better if it be thus prepared: ‚Ñû A≈ø≈øa fetida, Wood≈øoot of a Pitch-like con≈øi≈øtency, A. ‚Ñ•ij. Tartariz'd S. V. lb ij. mix, dige≈øt, make a Tincture, filter, then add Vol. Salt of Mans Skull ‚Ñ•i. and keep it for u≈øe.

¬ß 4. ¬ß 6. div.head: XVII. * Tinctura Ferri, Tincture of Iron.

¬ß 5. This is indeed the nature and property of this Medicament; if then it does thus much at two or three times taking, what may it be thought to effect, if its u≈øe be continued for ≈øome rea≈øonable time? ¬ß 6. ¬ß 7. In ≈øuch ca≈øes as the≈øe it is requi≈øite, that the Sick ≈øhould begin as at fir≈øt, and then to continue the taking of it ≈øo long, till it is evident a perfect Cure is compleated.

The remaining Salt mix with Tobaccopipe-clay, or Bole Armoniack, and di≈øtil in a Gla≈øs Retort almost to a red-hot heat, ≈øo will an Acid Spirit come forth de≈øcending in ≈øtreaks almo≈øt like S. div.head: XXIII. Tinctura Lunae, Tincture of Luna, or Silver.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Luna precipitated ‚Ñ•i. Common Salt ‚Ñ•ij.
