Its chief u≈øe is in Di≈øea≈øes of the Head, and more e≈øpecially against the Epilep≈øie: and it dries up the Water in Drop≈øies. Do≈øe gr. 4, 5, 6, &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Either you ab≈øtract the humidity wholly, or not; if wholly, it is to be accounted nothing but a Tincture, and ≈øuch are many of the Tinctures of Metals. But the Liquid Tincture we have taught you two ways of making in Our Doron Medic. lib. 1. cap. 25. ≈øect. 143. And lib. 2. cap. 7. ≈øect. 28. Clo≈ø≈øaeus has another way: So al≈øo Beguinus, Kel≈øer, and Ba≈øil Valentine; all which you may ≈øee in Our Pharm. Lond. lib. 3. cap. 2. ≈øect. 8, 9, 10, 11, 15.

¬ß 2. The making the Luna into Calx, Lime, or Precipitate is thus: ‚Ñû Refined Leaf Silver ‚Ñ•i. choice Sp. Nitri ‚Ñ•iij. put them into a Gla≈øs Matra≈øs, and digest in a moderately hot Sand Furnace, till the Silver is di≈ø≈øolved: then impregnate Water lb j. with Sea Salt, as much as it wit ≈øuck up, filter it, and affu≈øe it on the di≈ø≈øolved Luna; ≈øo will the fixt Salt unite with the volatile ≈øaline Sulphur of the Spirit of Nitre, and make the Spirit quit its hold of the Silver which it had di≈ø≈øolved, and make it precipitate to the bottom; which it will al≈øo the
better do, if you pour on a good quantity more of fair Water, whereby the Spirit being weakned in all its parts, all the Particles of the Silver will more ea≈øily and perfectly fall down.

¬ß 3. Now here is one thing to be ≈øpecially noted, that the Tincture of Luna is colourle≈øs; for the more it contains of a Cerulean, or Azure colour, the more it has of Copper in it; and if it is perfectly free from Copper, it will be perfectly free from that blew colour, as Le Mort has well ob≈øerved: Si Argentum (≈øaith he) in Aqua Forti di≈ø≈øolvatur, qu√¥ liquor magis caerule≈øcit, eo impurius est Argentum: Luna enim per ≈øe coloris est expers.

¬ß 4. Having drawn what quantity of Tincture you plea≈øe out of the Calx of your Silver, you may if you ≈øo plea≈øe, reduce it into a Ma≈øs of Silver again, thus; ‚Ñû Tartar, Pouder of Flints, A. ‚Ñ•i. Nitre ‚Ñ•iv. Charcole in Pouder í ij. put them all into a red-hot Crucible, and let them fulminate a little; then pour them melted into a hot Mortar: when they are cold; then take the ≈øaid Calx of Silver, and mix therewith, its equal weight of the afore≈øaid mixture, and put them into a Crucible upon a melting Fire, ≈øo will the Calx re≈øume its former Body of Silver.

¬ß 5. The fixed Salts of Tartar and Nitre, are here ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary, to hinder the volatility of the Salts of Tartar and Urine, wherewith the Calx of Luna was dige≈øted, and to fix the parts of tho≈øe Salts, which carry away ≈øome part in evaporation; and the Pouder of Flints and Coals ≈øerve to cau≈øe the fulmination, and make the volatil Spirit of Nitre exhale.

¬ß 6. Etmuller, Tom. 2. pag. 256. extracts the Tincture from the Calx of Luna di≈ø≈øolved in AF. and calcin'd, with a Men≈øtruum, or Liquor extracted by the help of a ≈øtrong Fire, from Sal Am. and Calx Vive, ana, or from Sal Armoniack p. j. and Calx Vive p. ij. from this Tincture, the Men≈øtruum being extracted, with Tartari≈øed S. V. the Lunar Tincture is at lengh exalted to its highest perfection.

¬ß 7. Neudorfferus extracts it from the Calx of Luna with this Men≈øtruum: ‚Ñû Oyl of Tartar per deliq. Sal Arm. an q. ≈ø. mix and di≈øtil gently in A≈øhes; ≈øo will you have a ≈øubtil Spirit with a volatile Salt, which mixed with Tartari≈øed S. V. and well united, will extract a Tincture out of
the ≈øaid Lunar Calx: from this Tincture, the Men≈øtruum is ab≈øtracted till it is as thick it Honey; after which fair Water is added; and by a fourth di≈øtillation the Salts of the Men≈øtruum are drawn forth: and from what remains with Tartariz'd S. V. the Tincture is extracted, who≈øe Do≈øe is √† gut. x. ad xx. Morning, Noon before Dinner, and at Night again≈øt the Epilep≈øie, and other Di≈øea≈øes of the Head. It is an elegant Preparation, but not the true Tincture.

¬ß 8. Le Febure fir≈øt makes an Amalgama of the Luna with Quick≈øilver, then ≈øeparates the Mercury with a little Salt, and a gradual Circulatory Fire, grinds then the Calx on a Marble with Rain-water, and with it wa≈øhes it from the Salt, then di≈ø≈øolves it in three times of its weight of Spirit of Nitre, after ab≈øtracts the Men≈øtrum by di≈øtillation in A≈øhes to drine≈øs, and perfectly ≈øweetens the Calx with di≈øtilled Rain-water, and dries it: which done, he affu≈øes thereon Spir. Veneris, ≈øo much as to ever-top it four inches, covers it with a blind Head, l ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es the Juncture, and dige≈øts in a continual and gentle heat for fifteen days; decants the Tincture which will be (≈øaith he) blew, and thus goes on dige≈øting and extracting, till the Men≈øtruum takes no more colour: the≈øe Tinctures are mixed together, filtrated, and the Men≈øtruum drawn off in B. M. to the Con≈øi≈øtence of a thick Syrup: upon this he affu≈øes rectified S. V. accuated with a ≈øixteenth part of its weight of Volatile Salt of ∆≤rine, and putting to a blind Head, luting the Juncture, he dige≈øts in Bal. Vap. for twenty one days, and ≈øo extracts a Tincture; which (≈øaith he) contains the Centeral Sulphur of Luna; from whence ab≈øtracting in B. M. the two thirds of the Spirit, you have remaining the true Antepileptick Tincture or E≈ø≈øence, which is the grand Specifick again≈øt all Di≈øea≈øes of the Head, Brain, and Womb. Do≈øe √† gut. ij. ad x.

¬ß 9. The ≈øame Le Febure makes another Tincture of Luna, after this manner: First he makes a Men≈øtruum of pure Sal Arm. p. j. of Minium or Red Lead, p. ij. mix and put them into a Retort in Sand, with a Receiver luted to it, the Retort having a wide Neck, that if any ≈øublimation ≈øhould happen, the Spirit might yet have a free pa≈ø≈øage, and not ≈øtop in the Neck, to hazard the breaking the Retort: give a gradual fire, and continue
it till the Vapors and Drops be over, the Ve≈ø≈øel being cooled, take this Spirit, and rectifie it in A≈øhes for u≈øe. ‚Ñû Calx of Luna (made with Sp. Nitri, precipitated with ≈øalt Water, edulcorated and dried) p. j. of the afore≈øaid recitified Spirit p. vj. digest in Bal Vap. till it has drawn the Tincture, which decant; putting fre≈øh rectified Spirit in the place, continue the dige≈øtion, till you have a ≈øufficient quantity of Tincture: then put them all together, filtrate and ab≈øtract the Men≈øtruum to drine≈øs: upon the bottoms affu≈øe di≈øtilled Rain-water to cover it three inches high, which ab≈øtract by di≈øtillation; affu≈øe new digefied Rain-water, and ab≈øtract in like manner, till the Lunar Pouder has lost its ill ∆≤rineus ≈ømell, made by the Sal Arm. put this dried Feces or Pouder into a Circulatory Ve≈ø≈øel, and affu≈øe thereon the Alcohol of S. V. to over-top it three inches: ≈øtop exactly, and digest in Bal. Vap. till the Spirit has drawn the Tincture, then ab≈øtract the half of the Spirit, and keep the remainder for u≈øe.

¬ß 10. This la≈øt Tincture, (≈øays the Author) is the true E≈ø≈øence of Silver, and very excellent again≈øt all Affections of the Brain, particularly again≈øt Madne≈øs, or Maniacal Pa≈ø≈øion, Apoplexy, Epipilep≈øie, and Pa≈ø≈øie, given √† gut. j. ad viij. in ≈øome fit Liquor, as Spirits of Black Cherries, or of Elder-berries.

¬ß 11. Another Tincture of Le Febure's, more Philo≈øophical than the former: ‚Ñû Pure fine Silver in very thin plates, q. v. which put in a Crucible, ≈øtratum ≈øuper ≈øtratum, with very dry Vitriolated Salt of Tartar (prepared with pure Salt of Tartar, and rectified Oyl of Vitriol): begin and end the lays with the Salt, cover and lute the Crucible, and let it dry, and then calcine in a Circulatory Fire for four hours: take then the Luna which will be calcin'd and brittle, and of a Gla≈øs colour: beat it to Pouder, which put into a Cucurbit, affu≈øe thereon Spirit of Vinegar to over-top it three inches: digest in a moderate A≈øh heat, for eight or ten days, to extract the Tincture, which decant, and affu≈øe new Spirit, decanting and affu≈øing in like manner till you have enough: put all the Tinctures together, and filtrate them. The Sediment in the bottom of the Ve≈ø≈øel of a yellowi≈øh colour, is the remainder of the Silver, and its Earth dive≈øted of its Sulphur. Put the filtrated Liquor into a Cucurbit, and in
B. M. with a gradual heat, draw off the Men≈øtruum, till the Magma is of the Con≈øi≈øtency of a thick Syrup, upon which S. V. Tartari≈øed, to over top it four inches: cover the Cucurbit with its blind Head, and circulate in B. V. in Sawdu≈øt for forty days: decant the pure Tincture impregnated with the Centeral Sulphur of Luna; and in a Cucurbit in B. M. draw off two thirds of the Spirit, the remainder is the Tincture of Luna.

¬ß 12. The Virtues of this are the ≈øame with the former, but by him e≈øteemed more excellent; for it is an excellent Remedy to evacuate in≈øen≈øibly Water in a Drop≈øie. Do≈øe √† gut. j. ad viij. in Broth, or White-wine, or in any proper Vehicle.

¬ß 13. La≈øtly, That th√¥ we have declared the Tincture of pure Luna (if free from all mixture of Venus) to be colourle≈øs, yet it many times contracts an adventitious colour to it, from the quality of the Men≈øtruum u≈øed in the Extraction: for the Luna, as fine Luna only, has a fixt Body, and a fixt Mercury, with a white Sulphur, void of all Tincture, whether Blew or Green, yet it is apt to admit of different appearances, from the differing Particles of tho≈øe Saline Men≈øtruums, whether of Sal Arm. Niter, Aqua Fortis, or Vitriol, &c. being after a new manner joyn'd with it, in mo≈øt Minute Particles.

div.head: XXIV. Tinctura Martis, Tincture of Mars or Iron.
div.p: Bate.] It is extracted from Flowers of Sal Arm ≈øublimed from Mars, by the help of the Alcohol of Wine, S. A. It has the ≈øame Virtues with the Tincture of Sal Armoniack.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. How this Sal Arm. is to be ≈øublimed from the Mars, you may ≈øee in Our Pharm. Lond. lib. 3. cap. 11. ≈øect. 28. where you are to note, That you may as well make u≈øe of Filings of Iron corroded with the Salt, as of the Martiated Salt, ≈øublimed from Gads of Iron; for that the Salt ≈øuffidently enough opens the Body of the Mars, ≈øo as it may ea≈øily yield its Tincture to other Men≈øtruums.

¬ß 2. Myn≈øicht has another Preparation, which differs ≈øomething from this of our Author, yet in the main is very like it. See it in Pharm. Lond. lib. 4. cap. 7. ≈øect. 34. which is only the Body of Steel or Iron opened with the
Sal Arm. and extracted with S. V.

¬ß 3. A Tincture of Mars from Maets, which is called Potable Mars: ‚Ñû Niter, Tartar, A. q. v. both in Pouder, mix, and kindle it with a red hot Iron, ≈øtirring till it is calcin'd: of this take lb j. fre≈øh ∆≤rine lb iv. digest in Hor≈øe-dung three Months; then in a Gla≈øs Cucurbit with its Alembick, and a very gentle heat, draw off the Spirit, which will be watery and fiery, and ≈øerves principally to draw the Tinctures from calcin'd Metals. This Spirit is able to draw from the Crocus of Sol a yellow Tincture, which being freed from the ≈øame Men≈øtruum by di≈øtillation, till it comes to the form of an Oyl, will then yield its Tincture, by dige≈øtion to the Alcohol of S. V. with which it will unite, whereby you have an Aurum Potabile of great Virtue; but this by the way.

¬ß 4. After the ≈øame manner from Crocus Martis (made by the Vapours of Vinegar, or otherwi≈øe) you may extract a Tincture with this Men≈øtruum, which being ab≈øtracted by di≈øtillation, you may then with the Alcohol of S. V. draw forth a very fine Tincture of Mars, called by ≈øome Mars Potabilis. Do≈øe √† gut. vj. ad xxx. in any proper Liquor.

¬ß 5. Some make an A≈øtringent Tincture thus: ‚Ñû Scoria of Mars in Pouder q. v. to which affu≈øe Spirit of Vinegar to over-top it four inches: digest fourteen or twenty days, or till the Spirit has contracted a blood-red colour, then decant, it from the Feces, filter, and keep it for u≈øe. This is A≈øtringent, and cures Spitting of Blood, or other Fluxes of Blood, whether in the Bowels or Womb, after an admirable manner. Do≈øe íj. ad íij.

¬ß 6. An opening Tincture from Le Mort. ‚Ñû Vitriol of Mars calcin'd to redne≈øs, q. v. affu≈øe thereon Sp. Aceti, ≈øo as to over-top it two inches: which dige≈øt till it is of a blood-red colour, decant, filter, evaporate to the Con≈øi≈øtence of Honey, and with tartariz'd S. V. extract all the Tincture, which S. V. ab≈øtract in B. M. till only one third, which is the Tincture of Mars remains.

¬ß 7. This Tincture of Mars is a Specifick again≈øt the Worms in Children, the Cachexia and Chloro≈øis in Maidens, and the Drop≈øie, and Suppre≈ø≈øion of the Terms in Women. It opens Ob≈øtructions in Liver, Spleen, and
Me≈øentery, and cures Di≈øea≈øes thence ari≈øing. Do≈øe √† gut. iv. ad ‚Ñàij.

¬ß 8. Rolfincius Art. Chym. lib. 4. ≈øect. 8. art. 3. cap. 6. gives us from Hartman a Tincture of Mars, made with Malaga Wine, thus: ‚Ñû Filings of Mars (ru≈øted with moi≈øture) lb ≈øs. Malaga Wine lb j. mix and dige≈øt in a Sand heat, for ≈øome days, ≈øo will the opening Virtue of Mars by degrees be tran≈øplanted into the Wine. It opens all Tartarous Ob≈øtructions, and ≈øweetly cures both the Drop≈øie, and Yellow Jaundice; and is profitable again≈øt Tertian and Quartan Agues. Do≈øe √† í ij. ad ‚Ñ•≈øs. in the Morning Fa≈øting, at Noon before Dinner, and la≈øt at Night going to Bed.

¬ß 9. In the next Chapter he makes the ≈øaid Tincture in the ≈øame manner (which he calls his Black E≈ø≈øence) with Wine-Vinegar: this, he ≈øays, has a ≈øingular Virtue of opening, di≈ø≈øolving, inciding, and removing all Ob≈øtructions from thick and melancholly Humors, purifying al≈øo the Blood and Juyces, Do≈øe √† ‚Ñà≈øs. ad ‚Ñàj.

¬ß 10. In the next Chapter he prepares it after the ≈øame nanner, by a gentle dige≈øtion in the depurated Juyce of Sorrel, or Wood-≈øorrel, p. vj. depurated Juyce of Tumerinds p j. or ≈øomemhat better, being mixt together, who≈øe Virtues and U≈øe is like the former.

¬ß 11. In the next Chapter he prepares it with recent Juice of Apples (but Cyder to my knowledge will do as well) in which dige≈øting the Filings for ≈øome days, and ≈øtirring the mixture often with a wooden ≈øtick, or Iron pin, he at length decants the Tincture, filtrates, and keeps it for u≈øe: but he extracts continually with fre≈øh Juyce, till he has Tincture enough, or the Sulphur is wholly extracted, conjoyns the extractions, and ab≈øtracts the humidity to the half, or better: and then to make it the more penetrating, he takes of this Tincture ‚Ñ•vj. Ani≈øated Spirit of Wine ‚Ñ•ij. Spirit of Scurvy-gra≈øs ‚Ñ•i. mixes them together, dige≈øts and keeps it for u≈øe.

¬ß 12. This Tincture (≈øaith he) is of great Virtues; it re≈øolves thick and feculent Humors, which are mixt with the Ma≈øs of Blood, expels tho≈øe which are acred and ≈øerous, and cures the Scurvy. Do≈øe √† í i. ad í ij. in Wine.

¬ß 13. And in his twelfth Chapter following, he makes it of the Scoria of Antimonial Regulus of Mars, thus:
‚Ñû Scoria of Antimonial Regulus in fine Pouder, Sal Arm. A partes equales; by ≈øublimamation rai≈øe the Salt into Flowers: extract from the Caput Mort. in fine Pouder with Rain-water, a Lixivium: this Lixivium exbale, but very gently, not calcining it to drine≈øs: upon this Coagulum affu≈øe S. V. ≈øo will it extract a yellow Tincture, which opens, incides, and cures Hypochondriack Melancholy. Do≈øe √† ‚Ñà≈øs. ad ‚Ñàj.

¬ß 14. From what has been ≈øaid, it appears that the Body of Mars is apt to be penetrated and di≈ø≈øolved, not only by corroding Spirits, and by volatile and fixed Salts, but al≈øo by Dew, by Wine, and other Juices of Vegetables, provided, that being in ≈ømall filings, the Men≈øtruums may be allowed a due time to work upon, penetrate and di≈ø≈øolve the parts.

¬ß 15. And th√¥ neither Water nor Wine can totally di≈ø≈øolve Mars, nor operate upon it with that force and celerity as corroding Salts and Spirits; yet neverthele≈øs they are able to di≈ø≈øolve a con≈øiderable quantity of its parts, of which the ta≈øte of the Tincture by them extracted, is an evident demon≈øtration.

¬ß 16. Water with which Filings of Mars are penetrated, converts them into Ru≈øt, which you may afterwards di≈ø≈øolve in a larger quantity of Water, and change into a yellow Tincture, of great u≈øe to open Ob≈øtructions.

¬ß 17. But Filings being dige≈øted (tho' cold) for ≈øome weeks in White-wine or Cyder, in a double Gla≈øs well ≈øtopped, will extract a much better Tincture than could ever be po≈ø≈øible to be drawn by Water; for the Acid and Volatile Salt of the Wine, will make a larger di≈ø≈øolution of the parts of the Mars, and ≈øo thereby extract a ≈øtronger, deeper, and more effectual Tincture; which may be given from one ≈øpoonful to two or three ≈øpoonfuls in the Morning fa≈øting (to be continued for many days) again≈øt all ≈øorts of Ob≈øtructions of Liver, Spleen, and Womb.

¬ß 18. Or you may make a Syrup of it with fine Sugar, which may be given ab ‚Ñ•i. ad ‚Ñ•iij. at a time, either alone by it≈øelf, or mixt in a Gla≈øs of White or Rheni≈øh, or Malaga Wine, or Cyder. But to make the Tincture of Mars by the≈øe Men≈øtruums, it will be long, and that is the chief rea≈øon that we u≈øe other
≈øtronger di≈ø≈øolvents, as is above declared.

¬ß 19. The Pre≈øcript of our Author is exactly from Marggrave, who≈øe words are the≈øe: ‚Ñû Batiturae Martis, Sal Ammoniacum in fine Pouder, A. ‚Ñ•iv. mix, and from a earthen Cucurbit on a naked Fire, a Gla≈øs head being applied, ≈øublime for a while what will a≈øcend, ≈øo will the Mars be volatalized, and a≈øcend with the Sal Armoniack of a r ‚Ä¢ ddi≈øh yellow‚ñ™ colour, which are commonly called, Flores Salis Ammoniaci Martiales: and from the≈øe it is, that with S.V. he extracts his Tincture.

¬ß 20. Hofma ‚Ä¢
in his Notes upon Schroderus, gives us this caution, That if we would extract a Tincture of Mars with S. V. from Crocus Martis, that it will not well ≈øucceed, unle≈øs the Crocus made by reverberation be fir≈øt di≈ø≈øolved in ≈øome Saline Men≈øtruum, as Spirit of Salt, Spirit of Nitre, Spirit of Verdigri≈øe, or Venus, &c. and then reduced to a Crocus again.

¬ß 21. Ba≈øil Valentine's Tincture of Mars, which you may ≈øee in my Pharm. Lond. lib. 3. cap. 4. ≈øect. 20. made of Filings, red Spirit of Vitriol, and Spirit of Vinegar, &c. is commended al≈øo by Hofman, (Me≈ø≈øis medico Spagyrica, pag. 248.) as a pre≈øent Remedy again≈øt the Megrim, Epilep≈øie, Stone, internal Ulcers, to clean≈øe them, and to purifie the Blood. But, ≈øaith he, Ba≈øil's Tincture may be better made thus: ‚Ñû Vitriol of Mars calcin'd to redne≈øs, or Caput Mort. thereof, q. v. and with repeated affu≈øions of Spirit of Vinegar, extracts all its ≈øaline particles; the≈øe Extractions filtrate, and in an Alembick extract in B. M. to the thickne≈øs of Honey: with this mix Sand, put all into a Gla≈øs Retort well coated, and with a naked Fire (augmenting it by degrees) di≈øtil a most rubicund Liquor. But by this Learned Man's favour, I take this to be rather a di≈øtilled Spirit of Vinegar, than an extracted and dige≈øted Tincture of Mars.

¬ß 22. It is evident then, in the Preparation of this Tincture, that acid Salts, and ≈øuch as are purely Salt, di≈ø≈øolve Mars with equal force; and that Mars thus di≈ø≈øolved before-hand, and prepared, is more fit to be given into Man's Body, than that which is Crude; fora≈ømuch as the Crude Mars can do nothing in the Stomach, till it, by its acid Juices has di≈ø≈øolved and opened it, ≈øo that the Stomach and its Juices mu≈øt
fir≈øt prepare and cure the Medicine, before the Medicine can prepare the Humours, and cure the Di≈øea≈øe.

¬ß 23. So that by being fir≈øt di≈ø≈øolved by an acid ≈øaline Salt, it is prepared aforehand to remedy more effectually the Di≈øorders of the Microco≈øm, produced by Ob≈øtructions, and the Scorbutick taint of the Blood and Juices; and this Tincture is ≈øo much the more able to open all the Ob≈øtructions of the Vi≈øcera, and their Ve≈ø≈øels, by rea≈øon of the Auxillary help it receives from its Di≈ø≈øolvents, which not only open the Body of the Mars, but without dimini≈øhing any of its good qualities; ≈øtrengthens all the parts through which the ≈øaid Tincture pa≈ø≈øes, and thereby helps al≈øo to di≈ø≈øolve the ob≈øtructing matter, and to carry it off by the ordinary ways.

¬ß 24. The Tincture al≈øo which is extracted from the Crocus which Alcohol of S. V. is a more particular Specifick in the Drop≈øie, to comfort and ≈øtrengthen the Tone of the Bowels, weakned by the long continuance of the watry humor; for it re≈øtores the Lymphatick Ve≈ø≈øels, (now as it were relaxed) by which they let loo≈øe the Sero≈øities over the whole Habit of the Body.

¬ß 25. La≈øtly, By putting Filings of Steel into an Iron Pot, Kettle, or Pan, and moi≈øtening them with Vinegar, drying it over the Fire, and ≈øtirring it often with an Iron Spatula, with ≈øeveral repetitions of this operation, the Body of the Mars will be ≈øo well opened, that by being dige≈øted ≈øome days in Canary, (≈øtirring it once or twice a day) a very good Tincture will be extracted, which may be given from one ≈øpoonful to two or three, every Morning fa≈øting, again≈øt the Green≈øickne≈øs in Virgins, and all the Ob≈øtructions of Womankind.

div.head: XXV, Tinctura Martis Aurea, The Golden coloured Tincture of Mars.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Crocus of Mars ‚Ñ•i. Spirit of Salt ‚Ñ•iv. infu≈øe two days, often ≈øtirring of it: then add rectified S. V. ‚Ñ•iv. digest warm for three or four days more, then filter, and the Tincture will be of a Golden colour. Do≈øe ad gut. 20.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The only difference between this and the former Tincture of Mars, is chiefly, that this is made of the Crocus of Iron, the≈øe of the
Filings, or Filings ru≈øted with Water, and the difference of the Saline Men≈øtruum, this being Spirit of Salt.

¬ß 2. Zwelfer Manti≈ø≈øae Spagyricae, par. 1. cap. 3. makes it of the Crocus, with Spirit of Venus, thus: ‚Ñû Crocus Martis Cachecticus q. s. to which affu≈øe Spirit of Venus ≈øo much as may over-top it three or four inches: digest in a gentle heat, till the Spirit is imbued of a rubicund colour, which decant, and affu≈øe more fre≈øh Spirit, and that ≈øo often as need ≈øhall require, till the Spirit will be tinged: put all the≈øe tinged Spirits together, and in B. M. ab≈øtract to an oleaginity. To the remaining thick Matter put Tartarized S. V. and extract a Golden coloured Tincture, which ab≈øtract in part again, leaving the yellow Tincture at bottom.

¬ß 3. Grulingius in his Florilegium, pag. 262. advi≈øes to di≈ø≈øolve them in Spirit of Vinegar, dige≈øting them in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt in Sand for ≈øome days, then decanting the Spirit, and a≈ø≈øu≈øing new, and reiterating this work, till the Pearls are all di≈ø≈øolved, and the Shells only as it were remain, then joyning the di≈ø≈øolutions, and in B. ¬ß 5. It is a Noble Cordial, excellent again≈øt Phren≈øies, Convul≈øions, Contractions,
and Re≈øolutions of the Nerves; it comforts the Brain and Memory, chears the Heart, pre≈øerves from Apoplexies and Vertigo's, dries and con≈øumes up evil Humors, and de≈øtroys the Tartarous Matter which breeds the Gout, Stone, and pernicious Feavers.

¬ß 6. div.head: XXXV. * Tinctura Piperis, Tincture of Pepper.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Something like this you may meet with in our Doron Medicum, lib. 2. cap. 7. ≈øect. 14. only there is added a ≈ømall proportion of Cardamons, viz. ‚Ñû Tartariz'd S. V. lb ij. Black Pepper in fine Pouder ‚Ñ•vj. Cardamoms in Pouder ‚Ñ•i. mix and digest to a kind of redne≈øs, &c.

¬ß 2. Now here is to be noted, That the be≈øt rectified S. V. extracts only an Amber coloured Tincture, unle≈øs it continues ≈øome Months in a very gentle warmth upon the Feces; if ≈øo, the Tincture at length becomes of a reddi≈øh colour, like the colour of Blood mixt with Water; and this I have only done with Black Pepper; from White, or Long Pepper, th√¥ I have dige≈øted never ≈øo long, no ≈øuch Tincture will ari≈øe, which makes me think that that Red colour proceeds from the Husk of the Black Pepper alone.

¬ß 3. It is an excellent Stomatick, cau≈øes an Appetite and a good Dige≈øtion, expels Wind admirably, and gives ea≈øe in the Colick, almo≈øt to a Miracle; it provokes Urine and the Terms, ha≈øtens the Labor, and facilitates both Birth and Afterbirth.

¬ß 4. It is an excellent thing again≈øt Coughs, Colds, Catarrhs, Sore and Swell'd Throats, Tumors of the Amygdalae, &c. and is an approved thing again≈øt Pinings and Con≈øumptions, whether in Old or Young. Do≈øe √† íj. ad íiv. in a Gla≈øs of Ale: it may ≈øeem tedious, and very hot indie Mouth and Throat at fir≈øt: but as the Medicament is without danger, ≈øo the a≈ø≈øiduous u≈øe thereof takes away much of the ≈øen≈øe of its heat.

div.head: XXXVI. Tinctura Proprietatis, Tincture of Property.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Best Aloes, choice Myrrh, ana, í vj. Best Engli≈øh Saffron í iv. being reduced into Pouder, add Oleum Tartari per deliquium ‚Ñ•ij. digest in a clo≈øe Ve≈ø≈øel twenty four hours; then add of the Alcohol of S. Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is nothing but Elixir Proprietatis dulce, made with an alcalized Salt, by which the Bodies of the Ingredients are not only better opened, and the bitterne≈øs ≈øomewhat abated, but the Griping property of the Aloes is in a good mea≈øure corrected.
¬ß 2. It is good again≈øt the Plague, and all ≈øorts of Malign and Pe≈øtilential Feavers, ≈øtrengthens and fortifies a weak Stomach, cau≈øes a good Dige≈øtion, and an excellent Appetite.

¬ß 3. It is a good Hy≈øterick, provokes the Terms in Women, opens Ob≈øtructions of the Womb, and is prevalent again≈øt the Green-≈øickne≈øs in Virgins, more e≈øpecially if in giving of it, you mix it with an equal part of the Tincture of Mars, &c.

¬ß 4. It is al≈øo a kind of Specifick again≈øt all Oppre≈ø≈øions of the Spirits, Hypochondriack Melancholly, Ob≈øtructions of the Me≈øentery, and Hypoga≈øtrick Di≈øea≈øes, being daily taken in the Morning fa≈øting √† í ij. ad í vj. or more, in a Gla≈øs of Ale.

div.head: XXXVII. * Tinctura Rabarbari, Tincture of Rhubarb.
div.p:
Bate.] ‚Ñû The best Rhubarb, Liquorice A. ‚Ñ•ij. Rai≈øons ≈øtoned no 60. Ani≈øeeds ‚Ñ•j. Sugar-candy ‚Ñ•vj. S. V. lb ij. digest S.A. and ≈øtrain out. Do≈øe two, three, or four ≈øpoonfuls in a Morning, again≈øt Colick,

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It ought to be dige≈øted eight or ten days in a very gentle heat, ≈øhaking it two or three times a day, then letting it ≈øettle, decant the clear, and keep it in a Bottle clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 2. It purges gently, and collects and expels the acrid and tartarous humor, which adhering to the Tunicles of the Vi≈øcera, cau≈øes violent Pains and Gripings; for which purpo≈øe it is indeed a Specifick, and one of the greate≈øt things in Nature again≈øt all the Weakne≈ø≈øes and Di≈øtempers of the Bowels, e≈øpecially if accompanied with painful Dejections.

It is al≈øo of ≈øingular u≈øe to purge ≈øuch as are troubled with any ≈øimple Gonorrhea, Weeping, or Glee ‚Ä¢ ; as al≈øo the Whites in Women, Univer≈øals being premi≈øed; for th√¥ it gently purges, yet it ≈øtrengthens admirably, and ≈øtops all ≈øorts of Fluxes, as Diarrhea's, Dy≈øenteria's, and Lienteria's, to a wonder.

div.head: XXXVIII. *Tinctura Ro≈øarum, Tincture of Ro≈øes.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Red Ro≈øes exungulated ‚Ñ•≈øs. Fountain-water boiling hot lb ii≈øs. Oil of Vitriol gut. xxx. digest three hours, ≈øtrain out, and to the clear add white Sugar-candy in Pouder í iij. Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It is a plea≈øing Julep to allay the heat in Fevers, and quench Thir≈øt: and is of good u≈øe to be given in the Mea≈øles or Small-pox, if any Flux be pre≈øent or feared. ¬ß 2. It may al≈øo be given as a Cordial after this manner: ‚Ñû Of this Tincture or Julep ‚Ñ•iij. Aqua Mirabilis ‚Ñ•j. Tincture of Coral compound, gut. xij. mix for a Draught again≈øt Faintings, Swoonings, Sickne≈øs at Stomach, Palpitation of the Heart.

div.head: XXXIX. * Tinctura Sa≈ø≈øafras, Tincture of Sa≈ø≈øafras.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Sa≈ø≈øafras Bark ‚Ñ•iv. dried Sage ‚Ñ•ij. Nutmegs ‚Ñ•j. Cinamon ‚Ñ•≈øs. Ambergrice ‚Ñà≈øs. extract the Tincture with S. V. lb ij. S. A. Do≈øe two ≈øpoonfuls: it gives ea≈øe in the Running Gout.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Tincture ought to be extracted with Tartari≈øed S. V. at lea≈øt, for thereby the Sulphur of the Medicaments are the more firmly embraced; and it will yet be more excellent, if it be done with Tincture of Salt of Tartar.
¬ß 2. It is an excellent Cordial Medicament, fortifies Nature, ≈øtrengthens the Faculties, chears the Heart, revives the Spirits, ≈øweetens the Juices, and re≈øtores ≈øuch as are in Con≈øumptions.

¬ß 3. It is an excellent thing again≈øt Rheumati≈øms, for which it ≈øeems to be de≈øigned, as al≈øo again≈øt the Gout in Hands or Feet; and for ≈øuch as have got any Venereal Di≈øtemper, an Old or New Clap, Kings-Evil, Scurvy, and other like Di≈øea≈øes in which there ≈øeems to be an univer≈øal taint of the Blood.

¬ß 5. Or you may give it thus: ‚Ñû Decoction of Rai≈øons ≈øtoned in Water, or in Barleywater ‚Ñ•viij. of this Tincture ‚Ñ•i≈øs. ad ‚Ñ•ij. mix for a Draught to be taken twice or thrice a day.

div.head: XL. Tinctura Saturni, Tincture of Saturn or Lead.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Thin Leaves of Lead, extract a Tincture with Spirit of Saturn e≈ø≈øentificated; filter and ab≈øtract S. A. It chiefly conduces to the cure of Madne≈øs, Melancholy, Quartans, Phthi≈øicks, &c. Do≈øe √† gut. j. ad v. &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is the ≈øame Medicine which is called Manna of Lead by Schroder: and it is extracted with that Spirit of Saturn which is impregnated with its E≈ø≈øence; which is not ≈øo well done, as ≈øome think, with the ardent Spirit of Saturn, which is little more than the pure Sulphur of Vinegar or Wine,
and can but meanly operate upon the Crude Lead, as with the yellow, red, or purple Liquor or Spirit, which ≈øome (th√¥ improperly) call Oyl of Lead.

¬ß 2. But Tincture of Saturn is made almo≈øt as many other ways be≈øides this, as there are Authors, as Clo≈ø≈øaeus's Tincture made with Red Lead; Ke≈øler his Tincture made with Cry≈øtals of Lead; and the Sulphur Saturni made with this Tincture or Manna, from Ke≈øler: all which ≈øee in our Pharm. Lond. lib. 3. cap. 6. ≈øect. 11, 12, 13, 14.

¬ß 3. Tinctura Saturni Clo≈ø≈øaei, from Cream of Lead: ‚Ñû Spirit of Vinegar ‚Ñ•x. Sp. Salis ‚Ñ•ij. Lead Ore in fine Pouder ‚Ñ•j. mix, digest eight days in A≈øhes, or longer, till the Spirit is ≈øweet: filter the ≈øolution, and exhale; in the exhaling, with a gla≈øs ≈øpoon take off the Snow-like Cream as it ari≈øes, till you have enough, (the rest Cry≈øtalize for other u≈øes) put this Cream into a fixing Ve≈ø≈øel, luted, in A≈øhes; first with a gentle Fire for forty days, taking heed that it melt not, (as in the common Salt of Lead it is inevitable) try then upon a red-hot Plate if it flow with fume; if ≈øo, continue the dige≈øtion longer, till it fumes not, and begins to be yellow, then increa≈øe the Fire till it be a Red Pouder, from which with Tartari≈øed S. V. make a Tincture. The Virtues are the ≈øame with the former.

¬ß 4. Another Tincture: ‚Ñû Cry≈øtals of Lead, q.v. Rain-water eight times di≈øtilled, q.s. mix and di≈ø≈øolve as much as may be: decant and di≈øtil the Liquor to drine≈øs: then add Spirit of Honey, circulated forty days, and di≈øtil, often cohobating: ab≈øtract the Spirit of Honey, and to the remaining add the Common Salt from the Caput Mort. of Lead: circulate eighty days with Alcohol of S. V. then ab≈øtract the Spirit, ≈øo have you a Magi≈øtery, or red Tincture of Lead. This is an excellent Medicine again≈øt Madne≈øs, Melancholly, Quartans, Con≈øumptions, and removes Ob≈øtructions of the Spleen, and Oppre≈ø≈øion of the Hypochonders.

¬ß 5. Ba≈øil's Tincture from the Gal≈øs of Lead: Lead by force of Fire, and Bellows, on a Test is brought to a yellow Gum or Gla≈øs of an Orange colour, tran≈øparent and meltable, not fuming in the Fire, but a most noble Body, which ≈øays Rhodian draws the Colours, Scents, and Ta≈øts of all Metals to it, with a con≈øervation of

Mix the Cals of any Metal with this Gum, and bring the mixture into a Smaltus or Enamel, which pouder finely: from which with Spirit of Vinegar extract a Tincture: if the Calx mixt therewith was of Lead, the Tincture will be of a green yellow: if of Tin or Silver, a yellow Tincture: if of Copper a dark green: if of Iron, a Blood colour: if of Gold, a Hyacinth colour: the Solvent being ab≈øtracted, the remainder is di≈øtilled in a Retort, ≈øo have you a white fume coming forth cold, which at length turns to Oyl of a Vegetative Nature.

¬ß 6. Le Mort's Tinctura Saturni: ‚Ñû Litharge of Gold ‚Ñ•viij. Spir. Aceti ‚Ñ•xx. mix and dige≈øt together twenty four hours: decant the ≈øweet Vinegar, and evaporate to an oleaginity: to this put Rain-water ‚Ñ•viij. that it may be white like Milk; the Milky Liquor decant gently, and again evaporate, this ≈øo often repeat with Water, till the Odour of the Vinegar is plainly gone, and the Liquor comes forth ≈øweet: evaporate to the con≈øi≈øtence of Honey ad rectified S. It cools, a≈øtringes, extingui≈øhes Lust, it allays all Inflamations whether internal or external: it cures al≈øo malignant and eating ∆≤lcers, ≈øuddenly clean≈øing, and healing them.
¬ß 7. There is yet another Tincture of Saturn made with our Spiritus ∆≤niver≈øalis, the making of which you may ≈øee in our Sepla≈øium, lib: 1. cap. 21. ≈øect. 6. which is a thing of good u≈øe.

¬ß 8. The E≈ø≈øentificated Spirit of Saturn: ‚Ñû The pure yellow Oyl of Saturn, and digest it upon Crocus of Sol, or Calx of Gold well opened in a gentle heat of a Bal. Vap. in a Circulatory Ve≈ø≈øel Hermetically ≈øealed for a hundred days, ≈øo will it become as red as Blood, and with this fortified Spirit you may extract a Tincture out of Crude Lead, as our Author teaches. It is a great Arcanum again≈øt all Di≈øea≈øes of Head, Brain, and Heart, as Vertigo's, Apoplexies, Fren≈øie, Madne≈øs, Headach, Megrim, Faintings, Swoonings, Palpitation, &c. div.head: XLI. * Tinctura Scorbutica, Tincture again≈øt the Scurvy.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Scurvy-gra≈øs, Water-cre≈ø≈øes A. M j. Hor≈øe-Radi≈øh-roots íij. Rhubarb íiv. Polypody of the Oak ‚Ñ•i≈øs. Sena. ‚Ñ•i Spirit of Wine lb ij. mix, infu≈øe two days, then ≈øtrain. Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Th√¥ the Scurvygra≈øs and Watercre≈ø≈øes be u≈øed green, yet the Spirit ought to be rectified or tartari≈øed, for by that means it will be the ≈øtronger (being mixt with the Flegmatick part of the Herbs) to extract the Tinctures of the other things; for otherwi≈øe, were it common Spirit, the Flegm of the Herbs would ≈øo much weaken it, that it would ≈øcarcely have force enough to reach the internal ≈øaline and ≈øulphurous Principles of the Ingredients.

You mu≈øt al≈øo allow it a longer time to dige≈øt in, viz. ≈øeven or eight, or ten days, the longer the better; unle≈øs you dige≈øt warm, (which I pre≈øume our Author intends not) then indeed a much ≈øhorter time might ≈øuffice; the Potential heat of the Men≈øtruum being a≈ø≈øi≈øted with the actual heat of the Fire, Vis unita fortior.

¬ß 3. It is really a very good Cathartick to purge all ≈øuch Bodies as abound with ill Humors, or are gro≈øs and and pur≈øie, and cannot move up and down without puffing and blowing; as al≈øo for ≈øuch as are Scrophulous, or troubled with the King's-Evil, or affected with ≈øtubborn and rebellious, or ill natured Sores, old running Ulcers, or Fi≈øtula's, which are hard and difficult to heal.

¬ß 4. It is al≈øo a ≈øingular thing for ≈øuch as are troubled with old Coughs, Colds, A≈øthma's, Shortne≈øs of Breath, Ob≈øtructions of the Lungs, Liver, Spleen, Womb, or Ureters; and for all ≈øuch as are troubled with the Scurvy, Drop≈øie, or Gout, carrying forth the Wind, Water, and Tartarous Matter, both by Stool and Urine.
¬ß 5. And given by a prudent Hand, and in a due Do≈øe, it perfectly cures the Rickets in Children, and kills Worms, whether in the Stomach or Bowels.

div.head: XLII. * Tinctura Serpylli, Tincture of Wild Time, or Mother of Time.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of the Herb, whil≈øt in Flower, being dried, and dige≈øted in Tartari≈øed S. V. in the ≈øame manner as we have taught to make Tincture of Wormwood. It is Diuretick, Hy≈øterick, Stomatick, &c. Do≈øe √† gut. v. ad xv.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. That is, you ought to take to every Ounce of the Herb, and its Tops freed from the Stalks, ≈øix Ounces of Tartari≈øed Spirit; le≈øs quantity of the Spirit will not do well.

V. will draw a very good Tincture, yet it is certain from real experience, that the Tincture of the Salt of Tartar will do it va≈øtly beyond the other, and make the Medicine much more powerful to all the purpo≈øes it is intended for, and not much inferiour to that, will the Tincture be, if drawn with the Pote≈øtates Thymi, fill'd with the volatile Salt.

¬ß 3. Be≈øides what our Author a≈øcribes to it as its Virtues, this we know experimentally, that it is an excellent Cephalick, Neurotick, Arthritick, Carminative, and Anti≈øcorbutick; for it comforts the Head and Brain to a wonder, is good again≈øt Megrims, Head-achs, Vertigo's, Lethargies, Apoplexies, Pal≈øies, Convul≈øions, Cramps, weakne≈øs of the Back, Nerves, and Joynts: Gouts, whether in Hands or Feet, and the mo≈øt vehement Colicks: It is al≈øo of ≈øpecial u≈øe to all ≈øuch as are troubled with the Scurvy, in a cold and moi≈øt Habit of Body, for weakne≈øs of the Stomach and Indige≈øtion, Do≈øe √† gut. xv. ad xxx. or xl. in a fit Vehicle.

div.head: XLIII. * Tinctura Stomachica, Stomach-Tincture.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Species Hiera ≈øimple ‚Ñ•i. Cochinel í j. Spirit of Wine lb ij. digest and filter, S. A. Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This differs from the Tinctura Sacra, or Hierae aforegoing chiefly in the Men≈øtruum, which is, that this is extracted with
Spirit of Wine, that with Sherry-wine; and are therefore both good for the ≈øame Di≈øea≈øes: ≈øave, that whereas this is extracted with the hotter Men≈øtruum, it ought to be given to the colder Con≈øtitution.

¬ß 2. It is a good Stomatick, warming a cold Ventricle, and expelling Cold and Flegmatick Humors out of the Stomach and Guts, and carrying off the Crude Humors, which cau≈øe Pains, Gripings, and the Colick.

¬ß 3. And therefore for the ≈øame rea≈øon, it is an ab≈øolute and ≈øpecifick Anti≈øcorbutick and Antiarthritick, in all cold and moi≈øt Habits of Body, for that it effectually carries off the ≈øcorbutick taint, and tartarous mucilage, with which ≈øuch People are afflicted, warming the Stomach and Bowels, rectifying the Blood and Humors, and ≈øtrengthning all the vitiated and weakned parts.

div.head: XLIV. * Tinctura Succini, Tincture of Amber.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû White Amber in fine Pouder ‚Ñ•iv. Alcohol of Wine lb j. mix and digest to the ≈øolution of the Amber: decant, filter, and ab≈øtract the third part in B. M. It is a Cephalick, Hy≈øterick, Anticolick, Nervous Medicament, &c. Do≈øe √† íj. ad íiij. &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Several Men have taught the making of this Tincture, and not much differing, among whom you have that of John Dan. Hor≈øtius, in our Pharm. Lond. lib. 2. cap. 7. ≈øect. 46. But a more ample Proce≈øs you have from Charras, in our Doron Medicum, lib. 2. cap. 7. ≈øect. 20. which agrees both with the Proce≈øs of Le Febure, and Lemery.

¬ß 2. The≈øe differ little from this of our Author, ≈øave in the ab≈øtraction of the Spirit or Men≈øtruum, which they advi≈øe to be done to a half part; but our Author more prudently, only to a third part, le≈øt if too much of the Spirit ≈øhould be drawn off, the di≈ø≈øolved ≈øulphurous particles of the Amber ≈øhould ≈øub≈øide.

¬ß 3. In this Operation you mu≈øt be ≈øure that the Amber be finely poudred, for then the Men≈øtruum will the better open its Body, and extract its Tincture, which is nothing but the ≈øulphurous or oily parts of the Amber, joyned to, or impregnating the S.V. or Sulphur of Wine.

¬ß 4. A Liquor ≈øtronger, and not ≈øulphurous, might perchance di≈ø≈øolve the Amber in ≈øub≈øtance, and thereby make it the more impure, whereas a ≈øulphurous Men≈øtruum only di≈ø≈øolves and extracts the more pure and ≈øulphurous, or re≈øinous parts thereof, rendering the Tincture more ≈øubtil: for this is a Rule, To u≈øe always a Men≈øtruum of the ≈øame nature, with the nature of the ≈øub≈øtance you would extract: So that if you would have a ≈øulphurous Tincture, you ought to u≈øe a ≈øulphurous Men≈øtruum; if a Saline, a Saline, &c.

¬ß 5. And after the Method of Hor≈øtius aforementioned, Grulingius in his Florilegium, par. 12. cap. 2. teaches the making of this Tincture, but as was ≈øaid before, 'twill be to the advantage of the Medicine, to ab≈øtract but only a Third part of the Spirit.

¬ß 6. Marggravius teaches to extract it with the fixed Liquor of Nitre, or Glawber's Alcahe≈øt, which they call, The ∆≤niver≈øal Men≈øtruum; this di≈ø≈øolves the Particles of the Matter, which afterwards by the affu≈øion of the Alcohol of Wine, and a gentle dige≈øtion, a new and e≈ø≈øential Tincture is produced.

¬ß 7. Maets and Ettmuller makes it thus: ‚Ñû Amber in fine Pouder q. v. Flowers of Sal Armoniack, a half part: beat and mix them well together, upon which affu≈øe the Alcohol of S. V. ≈øo much as to overtop it four inches; which let ≈øtand in dige≈øtion, till a yellow Tincture is extracted, which decant and keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 8. This Tincture, ≈øaith he, has the greate≈øt ≈øucce≈øs in the Colick, proceeding from an acrid, au≈øtere, and pituito≈øe Humors; and above all things in the Ob≈øtructions of Womens Cour≈øes; as al≈øo in Deafne≈øs, occa≈øioned from a Catarrh or Flux of Humors to the Ears, being dropt into them, and and then ≈øtopt with a little Lint or Cotton dipt in the ≈øame. Do≈øe √† gut. xv. ad xl.

¬ß 9. Another way: ‚Ñû Amber in fine Pouder q. v. Oleum Tartari per deliquium, q. s. let them ≈øtand in dige≈øtion twenty four hours; and then add Alcohol of S. V. ≈øo much as to overtop them four inches; which dige≈øt together, till the Spirit extracts a rubicund Tincture.

¬ß 10. Or thus, according to Le Mort: ‚Ñû S. V. (thrice rectified from Sal Armoniack) ‚Ñ•iv. yellow Amber in ≈øubtil Pouder ‚Ñ•i. mix and dige≈øt in B. M. for three days, till the Tincture is extracted, and becomes clear, which keep in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 11. The Sal Armoniack is here added, that the Spirit may thereby be accuated, and made the more penetrating, to promote the di≈ø≈øolution of the Sulphur, and unle≈øs the Spirit be rectified to the highe≈øt, you can do nothing; for if there be any Flegm in it, it leaves the Amber untouched. It is given to the mo≈øt delicate, again≈øt Hy≈øterick Fits, and the Colick, and provokes Urine and Sweat. Do≈øe √† gut. viij. ad í ≈øs.

¬ß 12. Otherwi≈øe from the ≈øame Le Mort: ‚Ñû S. V. tartari≈øed q. v. and put thereto ≈øo much of the best rectified Spirit of Salt, till the Efferve≈øcence cea≈øes, let it remain a while, till the Salt ≈øhall ≈øub≈øide, and the Spirit becomes clear: ‚Ñû Fine Pouder of yellow Amber ‚Ñ•i. of the former Men≈øtruum ≈øo much as to over-top it three or four inches; and digest four days, till the yellow Tincture is extracted, which ≈øeparate, affu≈øing upon the Feces new Men≈øtruum, ≈øo long till the Amber will give no more Tincture.

¬ß 13. This, they ≈øay, is a mo≈øt egregious Diuretick; allays the Hy≈øterick Pa≈ø≈øion, breaks the Stones, kills Worms and cures the Plague: and may be given √† gut. x. ad í j. in any Specifick Vehicle.

¬ß 14. But Paracel≈øus takes Amber in fine Pouder, and affu≈øes upon it his Circulatum, which he dige≈øts in A≈øhes for ≈øome days, then ab≈øtracts and cohobates, till the oily Tincture appears at bottom, Archidox. lib. 6. p. 1.
¬ß 15. This, ≈øaith Hoffman, (Me≈ø≈øis Medica Spagyric. pag. 344.) is a Noble Medicament for the Head, Stomach, Bowels, and whole Nervous Sy≈øtem, and a mo≈øt efficacious thing again≈øt the Stone.

¬ß 16. And this Medicament, ≈øaith Schroder, as it is only the purer fulphurous, or re≈øinous part of the Amber, ≈øeparated from the gro≈ø≈øer and more terrene by ≈øolution, ≈øo it has not only the ≈øame, but ≈øtronger Virtues than the Amber it≈øelf hath.

¬ß 17. Nor is this Tincture to be de≈øpi≈øed, th√¥ it ≈øeems to be only a part of the Amber di≈ø≈øolved: as Ettmuller rationally enough ≈øugge≈øts,
Tom. 2. pag. 548. from the affu≈øion of an Aqueous Body thereon, for that a kind of Cream in a ≈øhort time ≈øupernates upon it, (he rather approving that made by the Alcahest of Glawber) for the impalpable Pouder of Amber, ground upon a Porphiry, is of excellent u≈øe, being given in Di≈øea≈øes of the Brain, Stomach, Bowels, Womb, and Joynts, and in lo≈ø≈øes of Blood, where there is a nece≈ø≈øity of clo≈øing the parts, as al≈øo in malignant Feavers, Pleuri≈øies, and the like.

div.head: XLV. Tinctura Sulphuris, Tincture of Sulphur.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Liver of Sulphur ‚Ñ•ij. S.V. lb j. digest and filter. You may al≈øo extract it by the means of S. V. from the Bal≈øam of Sulphur Terebinthinated, boyled or ab≈øtracted to drine≈øs in B. M. It is a very great Pectoral. Do≈øe ad gr. xij.

Salmon. ¬ß 1. The fir≈øt way is exactly that which is taught by Le Mort in his Chym. Medico-Phy≈øica, pag. 201. The Spirit, ≈øaith he, will be coloured of a ≈øubrubid Tincture, which by dige≈øtion will become deeper and deeper. And it is the ≈øame with that of Zwelfer, in Phar. Aug. Reformat. pag. 859. ≈øave that at la≈øt be advi≈øes to free the Tincture from that great plenty of Spirits, which is done by ab≈øtraction in B. M.

¬ß 2. This Tincture, ≈øaith Zwelfer, is a mo≈øt excellent thing again≈øt contagious Di≈øea≈øes, and the very Plague it≈øelf, from which it is a Pre≈øervative; it opens Ob≈øtructions of the Vi≈øcera; and cures mo≈øt Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Lungs, as Coughs, Colds, Wheezings, ≈øhortne≈øs of Breath, difficulty of Breathing, Ulcers of the Lungs, Con≈øumptions, &c.

¬ß 3. But Paracel≈øus, from a mixture of Salt of Tartar and Flores Sulphuris, with Lin≈øeed-Oyl, extracts a Bal≈øamick Tincture by boyling, it being cautiou≈øly to be done, lest it runs over in the operation, and ≈øo hazards the firing of the Hou≈øe. This is in colour red like Blood.

¬ß 4. This oily Tincture takes the place of a Bal≈øam, and is profitable in all Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Lungs: and th√¥ Lin≈øeed-Oyl ≈øeems to be an abject thing, and of ≈ømall price, yet notwith≈øtanding this Tincture is of great value, for it is a Specifick in Pleuri≈øies, and a pre≈øent cure for a Dy≈øentery, or Bloodyflux;
it al≈øo ≈øtrengthens the Joynts, and is good again≈øt the Gout, being anointed. In Cly≈øters it cures Ulcers of the Guts.

¬ß 5. Rolfincius in Art. Chym. lib. 4. ≈øect. 1. art. 4. cap. 2. makes the Tincture of Sulphur after this manner: ‚Ñû Liver of Sulphur q. v. Caput Mort. of Vitriol q. s. mix them to a more ≈øolid con≈øi≈øtence; di≈øtil by Retort fir≈øt a milky Liquor, then a blood-red Oyl. But this, with that learned Man's leave, is rather a Spirit than a Tincture, and without doubt he only called it a Tincture from its red colour, not its way of making.

¬ß 6. This, ≈øaith he, cures a Phthi≈øis, or Con≈øumption of the Lungs, and purifies the whole entire Body, even as Antimony purifies Gold: it cures al≈øo Epilep≈øies, and other Di≈øea≈øes of the Brain.

¬ß 7. The ≈øecond way of our Author is Le Mort's Tinctura Dia≈øulphuris, where he advi≈øes the Bal≈øam only to be made thick: Yet doubtle≈øs if it be ab≈øtracted to drine≈øs, the S. V. will extract a more excellent Tincture.

¬ß 8. This, ≈øays he, is a mo≈øt admirable Nephritick; it provokes the Terms, gently loo≈øens the Belly, cures all Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Lungs, Phthi≈øicks, Con≈øumptions, and the like: if it be farther prepared with Honey, it becomes an excellent Antia≈øthmatick. Do≈øe √† gut. x. ad xxx. See our Pharm. Lond. lib. 3. cap. 12. ≈øect. 16. And Sect. 17. of the ≈øame, where you have two other ways of preparing it, both from Clo≈ø≈øaeus.

¬ß 9. Beguinus makes it after the ≈øame manner as Le Mort. But his Commentator will have it to be made thus: ‚Ñû Flowers of Sulphur q. v. melt them in a Crucible; but that they may not grow hard, put in guttatim Oyl of Tartar per deliquium, as much in weight as the Flowers, ≈øtir them together and mix, till they become of a dark red, or Liver colour: beat this to fine Pouder in a very hot Mortar, and immediately affu≈øe thereon tartari≈øed S. V. ≈øo will you have in a ≈øhort time a mo≈øt rubicund Tincture.

¬ß 10. It is indeed an excellent thing again≈øt the Phthy≈øick, and heal Ulcers of the Lungs, and to pre≈øerve from the Plague, and all contagious Di≈øea≈øes: it prevails again≈øt Coughs Colds, Rheums, Hoar≈øne≈øs, Wheezing, and ≈øhortne≈øs of Breath. Do≈øe √† gut. viij. ad xx.

¬ß 11. The making of the Liver of Sulphur we ≈øhall ≈øhew in its place, in the mean ≈øea≈øon we mu≈øt tell you, that as it is only compo≈øed of Flowers of Sulphur, and Salt of Tartar, yet notwith≈øtanding they very much differ in the Proportions of the mixture. Some will have Sulphur p. ij. and Sale of Tartar p. j. Others, as Ettmuller, Tom. 2. pag. 502. Flowers of Sulphur, Salt of Tartar, ana: And Zwelfer, Manti≈ø≈øae Spagyricae, pag. 859. has it Fl. Sulphuris, p. j. Salt of Tartar p. j. or rather, if you plea≈øe, ≈øaith he, p. ij. melt them gently together in a Ladle, or Earthen Pan, continually ≈øtirring them till they are mixt, and taking great care withal, that the Sulphur may not be inflamed.

¬ß 12. This latter proportion, in my Opinion, is to be cho≈øen, for that the Salt of Tarter ≈øo divides the Particles of the Sulphur, and opens its Body; and therefore the more of the Salt, the better it will perform its work.

¬ß 13. Hofman's Tincture of Sulphur (Me≈ø≈øis Medico-Spagyric. pag. 341.) ‚Ñû Choice Sulphur Salt of Tartar, Nitre, ana, make them to flow in a Crucible, (but without inflaming them) then putting them out into a hot Mortar, beat them into a fine Pouder, and with tartari≈øed S. V. extract a rubicund Tincture.

¬ß 14. The Volatile Tincture of Sulphur from the ≈øame Hofman: ‚Ñû Sulphur in fine Pouder: Sal Armoniack, A. í v. Calx Vive ‚Ñ•vj. mix and put them into a Retort, and di≈øtil in Sand, with degrees of Fire; at length increa≈øe the heat, and there will come forth the red volatil Tincture of Sulphur, of wonderful u≈øe again≈øt the Plague, and in all Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Lungs, not ≈øufficiently to be prai≈øed. Do≈øe √† gut. vj. ad xx. where note, that it colours the Fingers black.

¬ß 15. Le Febure's Tincture of Sulphur: ‚Ñû Choice Sulphur ‚Ñ•iv. pure Nitre in fine Pouder lb j. mix, put them by ≈øpoonfuls into a Crucible, red fire hot on all ≈øides, renewing it after every detonation is pa≈øt, till all is put in, and then increa≈øing the Fire till it be reduced into a red ma≈øs or lump, which pouder in a hot Mortar, put it into a Matra≈øs affu≈øing thereon Tartari≈øed S. V. and extract a Tincture as before directed, ab≈øtracting afterwards half the Men≈øtruum.
¬ß 16. It is a Specifick again≈øt the Plague, Agues, Scurvy, Ob≈øtructions of the Liver, and all Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Lungs. Do≈øe √† gut. iv. ad xij.

¬ß 17. In our Text, our Author's ≈øecond way is extracting it from the Bal≈øam of Sulphur, which we ≈øhall here a little explicate, and ≈øhew the be≈øt way how the Bal≈øam may be ab≈øtracted to drine≈øs: Put the Bal≈øam into a Cucurbit p. j. di≈øtilled Rain-water p. ij. and in B.M. di≈øtil, ≈øo will the Aetherial Spirit, or Oyl of Turpentine a≈øcend with the Water, and leave the true Bal≈øam of Sulphur in the bottom, from which, with Alcohol of S. V. you may extract the Tincture as our Author directs: and then at least to ab≈øtract one half, or two thirds of the Spirit, leaving a thick Tincture at bottom.

¬ß 18. This Tincture exceeds all the Bal≈øams of Sulphur, becau≈øe it is more open, and more exalted through the help of the Tartariz'd Spirit, and as it is more volatil, ≈øo al≈øo more able to penetrate into the inward rece≈ø≈øes of the afflicted parts; and therefore is u≈øed with a quite different ≈øucce≈øs from that of the ≈øaid Bal≈øams. Do≈øe √† gut. iv. ad xij. in ≈øome Pectoral, or Alexiterical Syrup.

¬ß 19. From this la≈øt Tincture of Sulphur you may make Cry≈øtals, and of them a more excellent Tincture thus: ‚Ñû The last mentioned Tincture, ab≈øtract the one half of its humidity, and then ≈øet it into a cool Cellar, and it will Cry≈øtallize. The≈øe Cry≈øtals contain in them≈øelves all the E≈ø≈øential and Central Virtues of the Sulphur. ‚Ñû The≈øe Cry≈øtals from their Liquor, di≈ø≈øolve them in new S. V. and ab≈øtract one third part by di≈øtillation: ≈øet them to cry≈øtallize again, and di≈ø≈øolve again in new S. V. repeating this Cry≈øtallizing, and di≈ø≈øolving till ≈øeven times is compleated, ≈øo have you a true dry Tincture of Sulphur, freed from all its evil ≈ømell and ta≈øte, and u≈øeful in all re≈øpects as any of the former. Do≈øe √† g. iij. ad xij. in ≈øome fit Vehicle, Liquor, Lozenge, Con≈øerve, or Electuary.

div.head: XLVI. Tinctura Veneris, Tincture of Venus.
div.p:
Bate.] It is extracted by the help of Spirit of Wine from the Flowers of Verdigri≈øe, p. j. Sal Armoniack p. ij. being mixt in a Crucible upon the Fire, S. A. It is a mo≈øt
powerful Remedy again≈øt the Falling-≈øickne≈øs, Hy≈øterick Pa≈ø≈øion, &c. being given in any convenient Liquor.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Flowers of Verdigri≈øe are made by ≈øubliming it with Sal Armoniack, and edulcorated, or thus: ‚Ñû Quick-Lime lb ij. Sal. Armoniack lb j. mix, coagulate, mix with Bole Armon, p. iij. and di≈øtil an Aqua Fortis with degrees of Fire, which rectifie: of this Spirit take p. iv. Verdigri≈øe, p. j. mix and di≈ø≈øolve over a gentle heat, put in more, till only light black Feces remain, ab≈øtract the Water, and what remains force in an open Fire in a Still, ≈øo will the Verdigri≈øe be elevated in Flowers, which are tho≈øe to be made u≈øe of in this preparation.

¬ß 2. Hence it appears, that the Men≈øtruum mu≈øt be made of volatile urinous Salts, which impregnate them≈øelves with the Flowers of the Verdigri≈øe, and prepare them for ≈øublimation: this is indeed pretious.

¬ß 3. And the≈øe Flowers may be u≈øed externally in Oyntments, Plai≈øters, Cerecloths, &c. The≈øe Flowers are very carefully to be edulcorated with fair warm Water, that no corro≈øivene≈øs of the Men≈øtruum may remain in them, or as little as may be: Thus after all, the Flowers are only Verdigri≈øe purified, and the Body opened, and made more ≈øubtil, that it may yield its Sulphur the better to the S. V.

¬ß 4. Flowers by Precipitation from Hofman: ‚Ñû Vitriol of Verdigri≈øe q. v. Flegm of Vitriol, ≈øo much as to overtop it four inches, to which add an eighth part of Spirit of Vitriol: dige≈øt warm for three days and nights, then filter and precipitate with Oyl of Tartar per deliquium, and ≈øweeten the Flowers by many ablutions in warm Water.

¬ß 5. The≈øe Flowers will ≈øerve for this Tincture as well as the former: be≈øides which, they are an Arcanum again≈øt Worms; they move Vomiting; but being joyned with common Salt and Nitre, they are commended again≈øt Quotidian and Tertian Agues. Do≈øe of them √† gr. iij. ad x. in ≈øome fit Vehicle.
¬ß 6. As for this pre≈øent Tincture, you may ≈øee the whole proce≈øs more at large in our Pharm. Lond. lib. 3. cap. 3. ≈øect. 14. and is given inwardly √† gut. iv. ad x. in any proper Vehicle.

¬ß 7. Utendi modus: ‚Ñû Spirit of Lavender, or of Limons í j. Black-cherry, or Lilly Convally-water ‚Ñ•iij. Syrup of Peony-flowers ‚Ñ•i. of this Tincture of Venus gr. viij. or x. mix for a Do≈øe, to be given in the Morning fa≈øting, and la≈øt at Night going to Bed: the Stomach being fir≈øt clean≈øed with a Do≈øe of Tartar Emetick of Myn≈øicht. It prevails again≈øt the Epilep≈øie, and mo≈øt other Di≈øea≈øes of the Head.

¬ß 8. Maets makes it thus: ‚Ñû Verdigri≈øe, or Copper calcin'd with Nitre to redne≈øs, in ≈øubtil Pouder ‚Ñ•j. of the be≈øt Nitre í xij. put them into a ≈øtrong Crucible, and with degrees of a naked Fire calcine till it turns into Scoria's of a ≈øubvirid or greeni≈øh blew colour, upon which affu≈øe the following Men≈øtruum, which will extract a mo≈øt rubicund Tincture, which ≈øeparate, add more of the ≈øame Men≈øtruum, dige≈øt and ≈øeparate, which repeat ≈øo often till all the Tincture is drawn forth: mix the≈øe extractions together, and ab≈øtract till they come to the form or thickne≈øs of Oyl: upon this put S.V. tartari≈øed, which keep in a warm dige≈øtion, till the ≈øulphurous parts of the Verdigri≈øe is united with the Sulphur of the Spirit, which is a Specifick again≈øt the Epilep≈øie, and mo≈øt other Di≈øea≈øes of the Head and Brain, and is given √† gut. vj. ad x.

¬ß 9. The Men≈øtruum aforementioned is thus made: ‚Ñû Nitrated Salt of Tartar lb j. new made ∆≤rine lb iv. dige≈øt in Hor≈øe-dung for three months, then with a gentle fire ab≈øtract the volatile Spirit, which is highly both watry and fiery, and is able to extract the Tinctures from the Calces of all Metals. From the Crocus or Calx of Sol, it extracts a yellow Tincture, which by di≈øtillation is freed from the Men≈øtruum, and brought to the form or body of an Oyl; from which with tartari≈øed S.V. in a gentle dige≈øtion, you may extract the Tincture of Sol, the Sulphur of the Spirit uniting it≈øelf with the Sulphur of the Gold, as we have before declared, in the extraction of the Tincture of Verdigri≈øe.

¬ß 10. Marggrave's Tincture of Venus. ‚Ñû Filings of Venus, or pure Verdigri≈øe ‚Ñ•≈øs. Spirit of ∆≤rine made by fermentation ‚Ñ•viij. or x. dige≈øt ≈øome days, ≈øo have you an excellent Tincture for outward u≈øes, th√¥ ≈øome give it inwardly again≈øt divers fermentations of the Ventricle; outwardly it kills an ulcerated
Cancer, a Gangreen, and a Sphacelous, or Mortification.

¬ß 11. The ≈øame thing may be done with the Calx of Venus calcined to redne≈øs; this ≈øome give inwardly to de≈øtroy an acid ferment in the Stomach, but 'tis not very ≈øafe: It is powerful again≈øt mo≈øt Affects of the Eyes, as Rheums, Inflamations, Blood-≈øhot, Pearls, Films, &c. in curing old and inveterate Ulcers, and in ea≈øing the pains of the Gout. It is al≈øo of u≈øe to Anatomi≈øts, to demon≈øtrate the Capillary Ve≈ø≈øels.

div.head: XLVII. * Tinctura Virginiana, Tincture of Virginian Snake-root.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Virginian Snake-root in fine Pouder ‚Ñ•ij. Tincture of Salt of Tartar ‚Ñ•xvj. extract a Tincture by dige≈øtion, S. A. It is an Alexiterick, Cardiack, Sudorifick, Anti≈øcorbutick, &c. Do≈øe √† í j. ad í iij. &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The common way of making this Tincture is with rectified S. V. but this of our Author is va≈øtly to be preferred before that, for that the ≈øharp particles of the Sulphur of the Salt of Tartar, more effectually open the Body of the Ingredient than ≈øimple S. V. can po≈ø≈øibly do.

¬ß 2. It re≈øi≈øts Poy≈øon, cures the Bites of the Rattle-Snake (the mo≈øt poy≈øonous of all living Creatures) Vipers, and other Serpents, the Biting of Mad Dogs, the Malignity of the Plague, and of all other contagious or infectious Di≈øea≈øes.

¬ß 3. And by rea≈øon of its ≈øubtilty and volatility, it powerfully provokes Sweat, expelling all noxious Vapors from the Heart: It chears the Spirits, comforts Nature, and prevails again≈øt Fainting and Swooning Fits, Palpitation of the Heart, and other Di≈øea≈øes of the Precordia.

¬ß 4. As it is al≈øo a high Alcaly, ≈øo it encounters and re≈øi≈øts all Di≈øtempers proceeding v from Acids, and the putrefaction of Humours, the chief of which are the Scurvy, Gout, Surfeits, and ≈øuch other as proceeds from a Tartarous Mucilage: It is al≈øo commended again≈øt intermitting Feavers.

¬ß 5. Modus Utendi. ‚Ñû Of this Tincture í i≈øs. ad í ij. Aquae Bezoartiae no≈øt. ‚Ñ•≈øs. Mint-water ‚Ñ•iv. Syrup of Clovegilliflowers ‚Ñ•i. mix for
a Do≈øe, the Patient being in Bed, and covered warm, to ≈øweat upon it.

div.head: XLVIII. Mars Potabilis, Potable Mars.
div.p: Bate.] Di≈ø≈øolve tartari≈øed Chalybs, in fair Water filter coagulate, S. A. It is mo≈øt powerful again≈øt the Cachexia, Drop≈øie, Scurvy, Green≈øickne≈øs, Quartan Agne, &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is a dry Tincture of Mars; but in my Opinion will be better to be kept in a liquid form, which it may be, by adding to it a quarter part of good Spirit of Wine, and ≈øo it will be always the more ready for u≈øe.

¬ß 2. It opens all Ob≈øtructions of the Vi≈øcera, th√¥ of never ≈øo long ≈øtanding, and cures many ≈øeeming incurable Di≈øea≈øes: yet it ought not to be given to Bodies which are apt to be Co≈øtive, nor to have ≈øuch as are troubled with a Scirrhus, which is bred or produced from the highe≈øt Stypticity in Nature; fora≈ømuch, as th√¥ this Medicine is extreamly opening, yet it is of a vehement Styptick quality, which is ea≈øily di≈øcerned by ta≈øting it upon the Tongue.

¬ß 3. It cures Fluxes of the Belly of all ≈øorts, as Dy≈øenteries, Lienteries, and Diarrhea's, by Virtue of its Stypticity, ≈øtrengthning and comforting all tho≈øe parts, making them able to re≈øi≈øt, or with≈øtand Di≈øea≈øes.

¬ß 4. It has much the Nature, Properties, and Virtues of the Tinctura Martis Tartari≈øata, at Sect. 26. aforegoing, and therefore to that I refer you. If given in a ≈øolid or dry form, it may be given √† í ≈øs. ad í i≈øs. or more: if in a liquid form, according to our Advice, from one ≈øpoonful to three or four, in any convenient Vehicle.

div.head: XLIX. ‚Ä† Tinctura Ab≈øinthii, Tincture of Wormwood.
div.p: Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Dried Tops of Common Wormwood freed from the Stalks ‚Ñ•v. Tincture of Salt of Tartar, or Powers of Wormwood ‚Ñ•xxx. mix, dige≈øt for ≈øome days, and then decant the Tincture, being of a reddi≈øh colour.

¬ß 2. It is highly Stomatick, and cau≈øes a good Appetite to Food, curing the Scurvy in a cold and moi≈øt habit of Body, as al≈øo the Cachexia, and is a very good thing in a Leucophlegmatia, after due Purging.

¬ß 3. It comforts and ≈øtrengthens all the inward parts;
and re≈øtores ≈øuch as are in a Con≈øumption, from Ob≈øtructions created thro' cold.

¬ß 4. You may give it √† gut. xv. ad xxv. or xxx. or more, in a Gla≈øs of Ale or Wine; it will make it ta≈øte like Wormwood-Ale, or Wine, and be very grateful and plea≈øing to the Stomach: The con≈øtant u≈øe of it for ≈øome time, warms the whole Ma≈øs of Blood, pre≈øerves Health, and makes ≈øuch as look ≈øickly, pale and wan, to be ≈øtrong and lu≈øty, and to have a ruddy and florid Countenance.

div.head: L. ‚Ä† Tinctura Amara Compo≈øita, The Bitter Tincture compound.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It ought to be extracted with Tartari≈øed S. V. at lea≈øt; but if you do it with Tincture of the Salt of Tartar, it will be ≈øo much the better, for that ≈øulphurous Tincture is better able to unlock, or open the Bodies of the Ingredients.

¬ß 2. ¬ß 3. It is a great Cordial, revives all the Spirits, Natural, Vital, and Animal, chears the Heart, recreates Nature, and re≈øtores in deep Con≈øumptions. It comforts the Brain beyond mo≈øt other things in the World, and is a mo≈øt admirable Neurotick, ≈øtrengthning and confirming the Nerves, and therefore a mo≈øt excellent thing again≈øt Convul≈øions and Pal≈øies.

¬ß 4. It is good again≈øt any Deliquium of the Mind, Fainting, and Swooning Fits, Palpitation of the Heart, mo≈øt cold Di≈øea≈øes of the Head, as Head-aches, Vertigo's, Megrims, Apoplexies, Lethargies, and the like, which may proceed from Cold, Weakne≈øs, or Ob≈øtructions of the parts affected; but it ought not to be given to Women ≈øubject to Hy≈øterick Fits, or Vapors, becau≈øe it is apt to excite them in ≈øuch Per≈øons.

¬ß 5. Do≈øe √† gut. vi. ad xij. or xv. in any convenient Cordial, thus: ‚Ñû Of our Aqua Bezoartica, or Aqua Mirabilis ‚Ñ•i. Syrup of Red Poppies, Syrup of Citrons, A. í iij. Borrage-water ‚Ñ•ij. of this Tincture gut. x. or xij. mix for a Do≈øe, to be given in a Fainting Fit, or Sickne≈øs at Heart. Or thus: ‚Ñû Aq. Bezoartica ‚Ñ•j. Tincture of Cochinele í ≈øs. Syrup of Citrons í vj. ≈øimple Angelica-water ‚Ñ•ij. of this Tincture gut x. mix for a Do≈øe.

div.head: LII. ‚Ä† Tinctura Ammoniaci, Tincture of Gum Ammoniacum.
div.p: Salmon.] ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû Gum Ammoniacum q. v. di≈ø≈øolve it in Water or Wine-Vinegar, by a gentle boyling, and ≈øtrain it through a thin cloth, and then in≈øpi≈ø≈øate to a fit thickne≈øs. ‚Ñû Of this in≈øpi≈ø≈øated Gum ‚Ñ•ij. Tartari≈øed S. V. lb iij. mix, and digest till the Body of the Spirit is full of the Ro≈øin, then decant the Tincture, and keep it for u≈øe.

¬ß 4. You may al≈øo make it thus: ‚Ñû Of the prepared or in≈øpi≈ø≈øated Gum ‚Ñ•ij. Spiritus Intimus lb iij. mix, digest, di≈ø≈øolve, and extract a Tincture, which decant and keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 5. div.head: LIII. ‚Ä† Tinctura Seminum Angelicae, i. Cele≈øtis, Tincture of Angelica-Seeds, or the Heavenly Tincture.
div.p: Salmon.] ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû Angelica-Seeds brui≈øed ‚Ñ•i≈øs. Tincture of Salt of Tartar lb j. mix, dige≈øt a week, then decant the clear and keep it for u≈øe.

and fortifies the Stomach, ≈øweetens the Blood and is good again≈øt all tartarous Mucilage in the Lungs and Precordia, and is an excellent thing in good earne≈øt again≈øt the Scurvy, continual Fevers, as al≈øo putrid and contagious, not excepting the Plague it≈øelf.

Syrup of red Poppies í iij. mix for a Do≈øe, to be given the ≈øick being in a naked Bed, gently to ≈øweat upon: but if the Small-pox is feared, or the Plague is pre≈øent, you may add to the Do≈øe, gr. xij. of Bezoar Minerale.

div.head: LIV. Tinctura Antiemetica, vel Menthae, Tincture again≈øt Vomiting, or Tincture of Mint.
div.p: Salmon.] ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû Mint gathered in its prime, and carefully dried ‚Ñ•i. V. but that if you are obliged to u≈øe the ≈øaid tartari≈øed S. ¬ß 4. Some make it thus: ‚Ñû Tartari≈øed S. V. ‚Ñ•xij. depurated Juyce of Limons ‚Ñ•vj. mix them, then add the dried Mint ‚Ñ•i≈øs. dige≈øt ten days, decant the clear, and add more dried Mint ‚Ñ•i≈øs. dige≈øt forty days, and decant the clear for u≈øe.

¬ß 5. As to the length of the time of dige≈øtion, 'tis po≈ø≈øible that the Tincture may be extracted in much le≈ø≈øer time, and may be nearly as effectual in all ca≈øes in which it is u≈øed, as if it had ≈øtood the full length of 40 days: But this is certain, it will not be ≈øo plea≈øant to the Eye; for, being kept dige≈øted upon the Feces 6 or 7 weeks or more, yea, 10 or 12 if need be, it acquires a much greater Purity and Clarity, and withal, a kind of reddi≈øh colour, which without that long dige≈øtion upon the Feces it will never attain; whereby it appears, that ≈øomewhat more of the internal Sulphur of the Ingredients is attracted by ≈øuch a long dige≈øtion, than if it had ≈øtood a ≈øhorter time.

div.head: LV. ‚Ä† Tinctura Antepileptica, i. Lavendulae florum, Antepileptick Tincture, or Tincture of Lavender Flowers.
div.p: Salmon.] ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû the be≈øt rectified Spirit of Lavender, or Tincture of Salt of Tartar ‚Ñ•xiiij. dryed Flowers of Lavender ‚Ñ•i. mix, dige≈øt 10 days, then decant the clear from the feces; add more dryed Lavender-flowers ‚Ñ•i dige≈øt again 10 days; decant again, and la≈øtly add again more Flowers ‚Ñ•i. dige≈øt 40 days, and keep the Tincture for u≈øe.

div.p: Salmon.] ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû Juniper-berries well brui≈øed, grains and all, Bone-a≈øhes, ana, ‚Ñ•iiij. be≈øt rectified Spirit of Juniper-berries, made by fermentation, or Tincture of Salt of Tartar made therewith, lb j. ‚Ñ•iiij. mix, dige≈øt 20 days. and then decant the clear for u≈øe.

div.head: LVII. ‚Ä† Tinctura Antihydropica, i. Jalapii; Tincture again≈øt the Drop≈øie, or Tincture of Jalap.
div.p:
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû Aqua Vitae, or rectified Spirit of Wine, lb j. Jallap in fine Pouder ‚Ñ•ij. put them into a Matra≈øs, which ≈øtop with another who≈øe Neck enters into it, lute well the Junctures with a wet Bladder, dige≈øt 3 or 4 days in a gentle Sand-heat, till the Spirit

Phalaja Rhumelii, which, ≈øays he, is an Infu≈øion of Jalap in Spirit of Wine; which being afterwards affu≈øed on Citron-peels, or Damask Ro≈øes, (or otherwi≈øe, if ≈øome part of their Spirits be added to it) it becomes a mo≈øt plea≈øant Purge.

Elixir Citri, q. s. (or about ‚Ñ•xvi. mix and extract a Tincture, to which add a little ≈øtrong Cinnamon-water, and Syrup of the juice of Citrons. Do≈øe √† í ij. ad í iij.

div.p: Salmon.] ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû bark of black Hellebor, and ≈øtrings, white Hellebor A. í iiij. Ani≈øeed-water ‚Ñ•viij. white-wine lb iij. mix, digest in a clo≈øe Ve≈ø≈øel, and extract a Tincture in two or three days, which decant, filter, and keep for u≈øe.

This is the be≈øt Tincture of the Hellebors, and in my Opinion much exceeds that made with Spirit of Wine (tho' it may be done with that too) becau≈øe it con≈øi≈øts of but little Re≈øinious and many Aqueous parts, ≈øo that it was thought fit to be done with a more flegmatick Men≈øtruum, for that being but a little acuated with S. Now becau≈øe Vegetable Sub≈øtances di≈ø≈øolve not in it, like Animal Sub≈øtances, it may be good in this ca≈øe to acuate the Spirit of Wine with the Spirit of Nitre, and with that mixture to extract a Tincture after this manner.

¬ß 5. ‚Ñû Spirit of Wine lb ij. Spirit of Nitre lb j. mix, dige≈øt, and if you plea≈øe di≈øtil them together, cohobating twice: To this Spirit put of both the Hellebors, Ana ‚Ñ•iiij. mix well, dige≈øt 8 or 10 days, and then

¬ß 6. The Title ≈øhews you its Virtues, or what it is chiefly good again≈øt, which is Melancholy, and that whether Hypochondriack or Cerebro≈øe, the which I have had particular experience of, and have not only given it ≈øucce≈øsfully to ≈øuch as have been Spleenetick, and vehemently troubled with Vapors from the Hypochonders, but al≈øo to ≈øuch as have been troubled with a mad Melancholy, and even to ≈øuch as have been afflicted with an exqui≈øite Mania, or Madne≈øs it ≈øelf.

The fir≈øt Tincture may be given √† í j. ad í ij. iij. or iiij, as the Sick is in Age and Strength, but you ought to begin with the ≈ømaller Do≈øe fir≈øt, and encrea≈øe it gradually, as you ≈øee the ≈øtrength of the Patient is able to bear it: Of the other Tincture, prepared with S.V. acuated with Spirit of Niter, you may give √† í ≈øs ad í j. or more, encrea≈øing the Do≈øe gradually, as before directed.

But for the meaner ≈øort of People, the Phy≈øician may prepare it with Spiritus Intimus, which though it will be much cheaper, yet I do not think is any whit inferior to either of the former Preparations: ‚Ñû black and white Hellebor in fine Pouder, A. ‚Ñ•iiij. Spiritus Intimus lb iij. mix, dige≈øt 24 or 48 hours, let it ≈øettle, and decant the clear for u≈øe: Do≈øe √† í j. ad í iij, as the Pati ‚Ä¢ nt is in Age and Strength.

div.head: XC. ‚Ä† Tinctura Quartanaria, i. Peruviana; Tincture for Quartans, or Tincture of the Je≈øuite's Bark.

¬ß 6. The fir≈øt Tincture may be given in ≈øimple Claret Wine, or a Decoction of the le≈ø≈øer Century, √† í j. ad í iij. ad iiij. the latter from 4 to 6 ounces alone of it ≈øelf.

¬ß 7. But before you u≈øe this Remedy ≈øome Cautions are nece≈ø≈øary to be premi≈øed: I. That you never u≈øe it to ≈øuch Women who have an Ob≈øtruction of the Men≈øes, or are troubled with the Green-≈øickne≈øs, nor to other per≈øons who are frequently afflicted with a Con≈øtipation of the Bowels, or have a continent or continual Feaver, whether putrid, malign, or pe≈øtilential; for in the ca≈øe of all tho≈øe kinds of Feavers, it is commonly mortal, and does the work as ≈øurely in a manner as if the Hangman did it.

¬ß 8. About the time of the writing of this, I knew four men ≈øeiz'd with a continual Feaver, two were highly malignant, and the other two more apparently the Spotted-Feaver; two Doctors, of great names, but no Phy≈øicians, were ≈øent for, who pre≈øently pre≈øcribed the Pulvis Patrum, and in three days time the Victim yielded to the fatal blow. Afterwards to the ≈øecond they gave the ≈øame in like manner, who died the fourth day. To the third they gave it al≈øo, who had the Spotted-Feaver, and he died in 2 days. ¬ß 9. Another Youth fell ≈øick (after the other four) with the Spotted-Feaver, to whom the ≈øame per≈øons pre≈øcribed the ≈øame cour≈øe, (≈øo ≈øencele≈øs, or rather wilful and ignorant, were tho≈øe Coblets and Botchers in Phy≈øick, tho≈øe Legal, as they ≈øay, and Priviledg'd Quacks:) but the Relations of the Youth having the Ma≈ø≈øacres of the other four ju≈øt before their Eyes, would not yield to it, but forbad their fatal Proceedings; and having ≈øome knowledge of me, immediately came to me, and carried me to the Sick; I view'd the Patient, and they told me what had been pre≈øcrib'd; I confe≈øs I forbad it, as they valued their Sons and Relations Life, and coun≈øelled to other things; my Advice was followed, and the young man recovered, did well, and is now abroad and healthy again, tho' in the Opinion of all that ≈øaw him, the Hope of Life was pa≈øt. ¬ß 10. I give this Relation of the≈øe Experiences to convince, if po≈ø≈øible, tho≈øe Homicides of their Barbarity and Male practi≈øe, and to give the unthinking World a Caution to be no more impo≈øed upon for the future, by ≈øuch ba≈øe, ignorant, mercenary and mercile≈øs, yet vainglorious Pretenders to Phy≈øick. ¬ß 11. II. ¬ß 13. What mu≈øt become of the Venom in a malign and pe≈øtilential Feaver, when by this Medicament it is lockt up within the Body? ¬ß 14. It now remains, that we ≈øhew for what Intentions this Remedy is u≈øed, and the Order, Method, and Rea≈øon of taking it. ¬ß 15. Univer≈øally being thus premi≈øed, you may come to the u≈øe of the Cortex, or this Tincture. ¬ß 17. Many after the fir≈øt taking of it have had no more Fits, ≈øo powerful and ab≈øolute a Remedy it is; but if it ≈øhould ≈øo chance, that the Paroxy≈øm or Fit ≈øhould return again, you mu≈øt again repeat the whole former cour≈øe (the purging excepted) and you may be ≈øure that it will not fail to produce the de≈øired effects, viz. ≈øo perfectly to cure the Ague, that it ≈øhall no more return upon
