It provokes Urine admirably, di≈ø≈øolves tartarous Mucilage in the Stomach, Reins, and other parts, and expels with the Urine, Sand; Gravel, Stones, &c. giving ea≈øe in the mo≈øt intolerable Pains of that kind.
¬ß 3. It is given al≈øo in a virulent Gonorrhoea, Ulcers of the Urethra, and the the French Pox; for it is an incomparable Vulnerary, hot, di≈ø≈øolving, mollifying, and clean≈øing.

¬ß 4. It is a good thing al≈øo to provoke the Terms, comfort and warm a cold and weak Womb, and to induce Conception, being daily taken √† í ≈øs. ad í j. thus: ‚Ñû choice Tent, or Mallago Sack ‚Ñ•iij. or iv. of this Tincture ‚Ñàij. mix for a Do≈øe, to be taken at night going to Bed.

¬ß 5. Outwardly, it ea≈øes all manner of Pains and Aches proceeding from a cold cau≈øe; is a famous thing in the Gout and Sciatica; di≈ø≈øolves Tumors, and is prevalent again≈øt Numbne≈øs, Cramps, Convul≈øions, Pal≈øies, and other Di≈øea≈øes of like kind, being only bathed Morning and Evening upon the parts afflicted: Given inwardly in a Cly≈øter √† í j. ad í ij. it gives ea≈øe in the Colick, Stone, and Griping of the Guts.

¬ß 6. But Schroder makes it thus: Put the Turpentine into an earthen Di≈øh, and with a gentle Fire under it, make the Oyl to evaporate till there remains only a very red Colophony, of which draw a Tincture with Spirit of Wine, and at the bottom there will remain a Bal≈øam to anoint the Reins again≈øt the Stone.

¬ß 7. This Tincture has the Vertues of the former, but not altogether ≈øo powerful,
and may be given in the ≈øame Do≈øe. In mo≈øt ca≈øes the other is be≈øt, but in a Gonorrhoea, whether ≈øimple or virulent, or in an Ulcer of the Reins, Ureters, or Bladder this much exceeds that.

div.head: CII. ‚Ä† Tinctura Thymi Citrini; Tincture of Citron, or Limon-Time.
div.p: Salmon. ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû Citron or Limon-Time carefully dryed and reduced into a fine pouder ‚Ñ•ij. pure Salt of Tartar ‚Ñ•i. mix them in a hot Iron Mortar, and grind them well together; then put them into a Gla≈øs Matra≈øs, affu≈øing thereon of tartari≈øed S. V. ‚Ñ•xvj. cover it with its blind Head, and dige≈øt 14 or 20 days in a very gentle heat; ≈øo will you have a pure red Tincture, having wonderful Vertues, which keep for u≈øe.
¬ß 2. Or, to the pouder of the Time ‚Ñ•ij. you may put Tincture of Salt of Tartar ‚Ñ•xvj. mixing and dige≈øting as before directed, and decanting the Tincture for u≈øe.

¬ß 3. It is cephalick, neurotick, pectoral, ≈øtomatick, cardiack, uterine, and arthritick: It incides, attenuates, di≈øcu≈ø≈øes, is alexipharmick, and an excellent Antiparalitick. It ea≈øes Pains of the Head, Nerves, Joynts, Stomach, Bowels, Gripings of the Guts, Colick, Womb, and Joynts; helps the Gout, and Sciatica, bathed on the part, as al≈øo Contu≈øions, Brui≈øes, and cold Tumors.

¬ß 4. It prevails again≈øt the Vertigo, Apoplexy, Lethargy, Pal≈øy, Cramp, Convul≈øion, Coughs, Colds, A≈øthma's, Ob≈øtructions of the Lungs, Catarrhs, Fainting, Swooning and Palpitation of the Heart: It warms, comforts and ≈øtrengthens any cold, debilitated and weak part, fortifies the Stomach, creates an Appetite, helps Dige≈øtion, provokes the Terms, opens all Ob≈øtructions, and helps mo≈øt Infirmities of the Womb.

¬ß 5. It is good again≈øt Poy≈øon, bitings of Serpents, mad Dogs, or other venomous Creatures, and expels the malignity and venom of the Spotted-Feaver, Plague, &c. through the Pores of the Skin. Do≈øe ad í j.

div.head: CIII. Laudanum liquidum Cydoniatum; Liquid Laudanum with Juice of Quinces.
div.p:
Bate.] ‚Ñû Opium corrected ‚Ñ•iv. Saffron ‚Ñ•ij. Juice of
Quinces lb ii≈øs. Ale-ye≈øt 4 ≈øpoonfuls; mix, and let them ferment together in dige≈øtion till the Saffron and Opium have ≈øub≈øided, then expre≈øs and filter. To the Liquor add Cinnamon ‚Ñ•ij. Cloves, Xylo-aloes, yellow Sanders A. í j. dige≈øt 14 days, then filter, and evaporate to one half. Willis. It wonderfully ea≈øes Pains, induces Sleep, ≈øtops all Fluxes, takes away Angui≈øh, comforts Nature, compo≈øes the unquiet Spirits in the Frenzy, alleviates the Gout, Epilep≈øy, &c. and being applyed, it admirably takes away the pains of the Gout.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. If the Opium be choice Thebean, it is much better without any ≈øuch correction; as we have ≈øufficiently proved in our Sepla≈øium, lib. 9. cap. 41. ≈øect.
‚Ä¢ . for being corrected by drying it upon hot Iron plates, as is the u≈øual way, a great part of the volatile Sulphur (and Salt too) is lo≈øt, in which lies the be≈øt and mo≈øt valuable part of the Opium: And of this Opinion we are not alone, but al≈øo Thibaut, Lemery, and Charras do all of them maintain the ≈øame.

¬ß 2. Liquid Laudanum is often made with S. V. but this is done with an Acid, for another intention: If the de≈øign be to ea≈øe the Headach, correct In≈øomniums, or vehemently to ≈øtupefie, then that made with S. V. is be≈øt: But if it is to ≈øtop a Diarrhoea, Dy≈øentery, or Lienteria, or to a≈ø≈øwage the pains of the Colick, pain of the Stomach, Spleen or Hypochonders, then this made with the Juice of Quinces is to be preferred.

¬ß 3. Be≈øides this advantage, there is in a Laudanum made with an Acid, that it never makes the Stomach ≈øick, or cau≈øes vomiting; whereas that made with S.V. often does ≈øo, in≈øomuch that 'tis impo≈ø≈øible for ≈øome con≈øtitutions to bear it.

¬ß 4. If your Opium be very clean, and without filth, it will convert almo≈øt all of it into Tincture, and leave but little Feces, not above an eighth part of the whole Ma≈øs will be left in the Caput Mortuum.

¬ß 5. It is a mo≈øt certain Somniferick and Sudorifick; it allays all pains which proceed from the motion and activity of Humors, ≈øtops ≈øpitting of Blood, and all other Fluxes of Blood, the Men≈øes, and all other Fluxes of the Bowels, gives immediate ea≈øe in the Colick and Stone, ≈øtops Defluxions of Rheum on the Eyes, No≈øe,
Teeth, Jaws, and other parts; and provokes Sweat, by opening the Pores after a ≈øingular manner.
¬ß 6. Do≈øe √† gut. 10 ad 20 or 30. ‚Ñû Blackcherry water ‚Ñ•iv. Tincture of Ca≈øtor í ≈øs. of this Laudanum gut. 20 or 25, Syrup of Limons í vj. mix for a Do≈øe, to stop Fluxes of the Bowels, &c.

div.head: CIV. Laudanum Liquidum Tartari≈øatum; Liquid Laudanum tartariz'd.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Opium ‚Ñ•ij. Saffron ‚Ñ•i. Cinnamon, Cloves, Mace, Nutmegs, Xylo-aloes, A. í j. Tincture of Salt of Tartar lb ij. mix, dige≈øt ≈øome days, filter and exhale to one half. The Vertues and Do≈øe are the ≈øame with the former.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is better to induce Sleep than the former, quiets the Archeus after a wonderful manner, by ≈øweetening the Juices and Humors, and taking away their acidity and arimony; it makes tho≈øe ≈øleep who are troubled with continual Watchings.

¬ß 2. It a≈ø≈øwages great Headachs, thickens and ≈øoftens all har≈øh and ≈øharp Humors flowing to the Bre≈øt and Lungs, ≈øtops Fluxes, as Diarrheas, Dy≈øenteries, and Lienteries; helps a bilious Colick, ≈øtops the mo≈øt vehement Cough and Catarrh, or any Flux of Humors upon the Lungs or other parts.

¬ß 3. But in giving of this and all other Laudanums you ought to be cautious, and not to give them while the Body is full, and has not been evacuated ≈øufficiently by proper Emeticks, Catharticks, or Cly≈øters, by ≈øome of them or all of them, as the Prudence of the Phy≈øician ≈øhall determine; nor while there is a copiousfluxion upon the Bre≈øt, cau≈øed by thick Humors; nor when there is pain and ≈øtoppage of Breath; or when the Patient is very weak, the Pul≈øes low and ≈ølow, and the natural heat but little, or almo≈øt extinct. Do≈øe √† gut. xii. ad 24 or 30.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of EXTRACTS.
I. Laudanum ≈øine Opio; Landanum without Opium.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû THE be≈øt Myrrhe, Mummy, red and yellow Sanders, A. ‚Ñ•i≈øs. Mace, Cardamoms, Pepper, Galangal, A. ‚Ñ•iv≈øs. S. V. lb iij. mix and extract a Tincture according to Art; filter and add thereto the narcotick Sulphur of Vitriol lb iij. mix and dige≈øt for a month. If you plea≈øe you may evaporate to a mellaginous ≈øub≈øtance, to which you may add Saffron ‚Ñài≈øs. Salt of Pearl ‚Ñ•i≈øs. compleating the mixture S. A. It is a mo≈øt powerful Anodyn, ≈øtops all ≈øorts of Fluxes, Catarrhs, Rheums, Coughs, &c. and has the ≈øame Vertues with the two former.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This Medicine is much better in Tincture than in the Extract; for being extracted with Spirit of Wine, the Sulphur of the Wine in evaporation will certainly carry off ≈øome of the be≈øt, mo≈øt volatile and ≈øubtile Particles of the Ingredients, and leave the Medicine much weaker and di≈øpirited; and therefore I ≈øhould chu≈øe to add the Saffron, viz. í ij. in the fir≈øt Dige≈øtion, and after decanting and filtering, to add the Salt of Pearl, mo≈øt of which will di≈ø≈øolve in the Tincture, becau≈øe it is made with common S. V. not rectified.

¬ß 2. This Preparation is taken from Tilingius's Prodromus, cla≈ø. 2. tit. 8. p. 463. but differs ≈øomething both in the number of Ingredients and their Proportions. Tilingius has it thus: ‚Ñû Red Myrrh, Egyptian Mummy, A. í j. extract a Tincture with Succory water. ‚Ñû Pouders of red and yellow Sanders, A. ‚Ñ•i. Mace, Pepper black and long, Galingal, A. í iij. Xylo-aloes, Cardamoms greater and le≈ø≈øer, A. ‚Ñ•ij. mix, and with S. V. extract a Tincture as is u≈øual;
both the≈øe Tinctures filter apart, and conjoyn, and add narcotick Sulphur of Vitriol ‚Ñ•ij. circulate all in a Ve≈ø≈øel clo≈øe ≈øtopt for five days, then ab≈øtract the S. V. by di≈øtillation in a gentle B. M. to the thickne≈øs of Honey, to which add Extract of Saffron ‚Ñ•≈øs. Salt or Magi≈øtery of Pearl and Coral, A. ‚Ñ•i. mix, and make a Ma≈øs. Do≈øe √† gr. vi. ad x.

¬ß 3. But how this narcotick Sulphur is to be made is next to be enquired into, which Tilingius makes two ways: I. ‚Ñû Filings of Mars, p. j. Hungarian Vitriol, or Vitriol of Venus, p. ij. mix them well, put them into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, upon which affu≈øe Spirit of Vinegar, ≈øo much as to overtop it half an inch; boyl and coagulate in a Sand-heat to dryne≈øs, and urge the Fire yet more till it grows red: To this pouder affu≈øe more Spirit of Vinegar, ≈øo as to overtop it four inches; dige≈øt ≈øome hours in a warm place, and the Tincture will ari≈øe, which decant, filter, and upon the Feces affu≈øe more Spirit, dige≈øting, decanting and filtering as before, continuing this Work till all the Tincture is extracted; put the≈øe Extractions together, and drop in Gutatim, Oleum Tartari q. s. and the Sulphur will immediately precipitate; the ≈øupernating Spirit of Vinegar decant and ca≈øt away, and ≈øweeten by many ablutions in warm Water; ≈øo have you the Anodyn and fixt Sulphur of Vitriol before mention'd.

¬ß 4. II. Or thus: ‚Ñû Vitriol in fine pouder, and by a gentle heat evaporated to whitene≈øs lb ≈øs. S. V. tartari≈øed ‚Ñ•xxx. mix and dige≈øt for a month in Hor≈øe-dung; decant from the Feces, and di≈øtil in B. M. till the re≈øidence is of a yellow colour, and of the ≈øub≈øtance of ≈øome di≈øtilled Vegetable Oyl, as Oyl of Ro≈øemary, Limons, &c. this keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 5. If following the Pre≈øcript of our Author, you keep it in Tincture, you may give it √† í ≈øs. ad í j. but if you reduce it to an Extract according to the Pre≈øcript, you may give it √† gr. viij. ad xvj. or to ‚Ñàj. Authors ≈øay, it is a famous, great, and mo≈øt powerful Anodyn, ea≈øes all Pains, induces Sleep, and may be given in all ca≈øes in which Laudanum Opiatum is exhibited.

div.head: II. * Extractum Ab≈øinthii; Extract of Wormwood.
div.p:
Bate.] It is made of a Tincture drawn forth from the Tops of Wormwood dryed, which being filtrated, is evaporated to
the con≈øi≈øtency of an Extract; to every ounce of which there is to be added í ≈øs. of the fixed or elementary Salt: You may al≈øo prepare this Extract from the deparated Juice by evaporation in B. M. S. A.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. In making the Tincture you ought to grind the dryed Wormwood p. ij. with Salt of Wormwood or Tartar, p. j. in a hot Iron Mortar, and then putting them into the Matra≈øs, affu≈øe your tartari≈øed S. V. for by this means the Tincture will be the ≈øooner and more ea≈øily elicited.

¬ß 2. As to the choice of the Extracts, which is mo≈øt valuable, whether that made by Tincture, or that by the Juice: I mu≈øt confe≈øs, the fir≈øt is the ≈øiner Medicine in ≈øome re≈øpects, but I cannot be beaten out of this Opinion, That the Spirit of Wine carries away with it ≈øome of the fine≈øt, ≈øubtile≈øt, and mo≈øt valuable parts of the Wormwood, and therefore in that re≈øpect ≈øhould rather chu≈øe the latter.

¬ß 3. That in making the Extract with S. V. it is better to ≈øave the Spirit than lo≈øe it by evaporation, which you may do by drawing it off in a gentle B. M. and it may well enough go for Spirit of Wormwood; or (being dulcified with Syrup made of double-refined Sugar and ≈øimple Wormwood-water) it may go very well for a ≈øtrong Wormwood-water.

¬ß 4. Either of them are admirable ≈øtomatick Medicaments, ≈øtrengthen and fortifie the Ventricle and all its Faculties, cau≈øe a good Appetite and an excellent Dige≈øtion, heat, dry, comfort, and take away the debility and waterine≈øs thereof: It is good again≈øt nau≈øeou≈øne≈øs and vomiting; kills Worms, and opens Ob≈øtructions of the Me≈øentery, and is an excellent thing again≈øt the Scurvy in a cold habit of Body.

¬ß 5. Do≈øe √† í ≈øs. ad í j. either in a Bolus, with Con≈øerve of Wormwood, or in a Pill made up with Pouder of Wormwood, or di≈ø≈øolved in ≈øome of the afore≈øaid Wormwood-water and ≈øo taken. It is a good thing again≈øt intermitting Feavers or Agues.

div.head: III. Extractum Alhandal; Extract of Coloquintida.
div.p:
Bate.] ‚Ñû Pulp of Colocynthis, choice, freed from the Seeds, and in fine pouder ‚Ñ•iv. Liquorice, Ani≈øeeds √† ‚Ñ•≈øs. Lime-water filtred lb iv. dige≈øt 20 days, expre≈øs out, and evaporate
to a due con≈øi≈øtency, S. A. Do≈øe √† gr. v. ad xv. and beyond.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It is a famous Purge, and not inferior to any other in the World; for it univer≈øally purges all Humors, and carries off the Recrements from all parts of the Body, and attracts even from the mo≈øt extream even from the mo≈øt extream parts, as Head, Fingers, Toes, Joynts, Skin, &c. It prevails again≈øt the Drop≈øy, Cachexy, Jaundice, and Green-≈øickne≈øs in Virgins, and is a famous Remedy again≈øt the Gout, Sciatica, Rheumati≈øm, Kings-evil and the Scurvy in a cold and moi≈øt habit of Body; it provokes the Terms, and brings away both Birth and Afterbirth, expels the Mola or dead Child; and is excellent again≈øt all Di≈øea≈øes of the Brain, Nerves, Joynts, and Lungs, and is therefore of ≈øingular u≈øe in Vertigo's, Apoplexies, Lethargies, Epilep≈øies, Megrim, and inveterate Headachs.

¬ß 2. It is the only Specifick Purge in all Venereal ca≈øes, and may be given for that purpo≈øe √† gr. vi. ad ‚Ñàj. made up into Pills, or into a Bolus with the Pulp of Prunes or of a ro≈øted Apple, after which the Sick may drink a draught of warm Ale, or Metheglin, or choice Canary. I mu≈øt confe≈øs, I can ≈øay by experience, it does more in Pocky Di≈øtempers than any other vegetable Purge what≈øoever, its Effects in that Di≈øea≈øe being admirable, yea, ≈øometimes ≈øtupendious, ≈øo that a man may tru≈øt to what it will do.

¬ß 3. Le Febur's Extract of Colocynthis: ‚Ñû the white≈øt and lighte≈øt Colocynthis in gro≈øs pouder (but he takes of the Pulp, p. ij. of the Seed p. j. which I approve not of) imbibe it by little and little with Spirit of Vinegar impregnated with half an ounce of Sennertus's Salt of Tartar to every pound of the Spirit, and put on ≈øo much of this Spirit, that it may overtop the moi≈øtened Ma≈øs 4 inches; dige≈øt in a gentle A≈øh or Sand-heat for 8 days, ≈øhaking the Gla≈øs three or four times, or oftener, every day; let the Matra≈øs be ≈øo large, as not to be above half full, becau≈øe the Pulp will ≈øwell extraordinarily, and hazard the breaking of the Gla≈øs; this done, ≈øtrain out by pre≈ø≈øing the Tincture, and filter through a Linnen Cloth: To the Cake affu≈øe more fre≈øh Men≈øtruum, ≈øhaking and dige≈øting as before 8 days renewing the Men≈øtruum even the third time; by which means you will extract
the whole vertue and power of the Colocynthis: Joyn the≈øe Tinctures together, and gently evaporate to the con≈øi≈øtency of a ‚Ä¢ Extract.

¬ß 4. It may be given alone in mo≈øt ordinary Di≈øea≈øes √† gr. iij. ad ‚Ñà≈øs. even to ‚Ñàj. after which let the Sick drink a draught of Malm≈øy, Canary, or Malago Sack, or ≈øtrong Mead, or other generous Wine: Or you may mix it with ≈øome Mercurial Preparation, ≈øuch as is Aurum Vitae, the Prince's Pouder, or the like, to be given again≈øt the French Pox, or any Reliques of the ≈øame; as al≈øo again≈øt Drop≈øies, Kings-evil, Rheumati≈øms, and all arthritical and paralytical Di≈øtempers; after which let the Patient drink warm Broth in which a little Mace has been boyled.

¬ß 5. But he proceeds to perfect his Extract after this manner. ‚Ñû of the former Extract ‚Ñ•iij. ≈øoluble Magi≈øtry of Coral ‚Ñ•i. tartari≈øed S. V. ≈øo much as to overtop it 4 inches; dige≈øt 30 or 40 days in a very gentle B. M. then add to it Oyl of Nutmegs by expre≈ø≈øum í iij. mix'd with doublere ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed Sugar in pouder ‚Ñ•vj. all being well mixt together, ab≈øtract the S. V. by di≈øtillation, and then evaporate to the con≈øi≈øtency of an Extract. It has all the former Vertues, but is more corrected, and may be given √† ‚Ñàj. ad ‚Ñàij.

¬ß 6. Charras his Extract of Colocynthis. ‚Ñû Pulp of white and pure Colocynthis cut very ≈ømall lb j. put it into a very large Cucurbit on a Sandheat, and affu≈øe thereon good new Whitewine 6 pints, cover it with its Head and a Receiver, luting well the Junctures, and dige≈øt with a gentle fire for 12 hours, after which ≈øtrain out the Infu≈øion by pre≈ø≈øing: Put the Sediment into the Cucurbit, and affu≈øe upon it a pint or two of good S. V. cover the Ve≈ø≈øel with a blind Head, luting the Juncture, and dige≈øt again 12 hours more, but with a little more heat, then ≈øtrain and pre≈øs forth the Tincture with a good strength; mix it with the former, and filter both thro' brown Paper; put it again into the Cucurbit, and ab≈øtract in B. M. or a gentle Sand-heat the S. V. which will ≈øerve again for the like work; then put all the remains into a glaz'd earthen Pipkin, and in a gentle Sand-heat evaporate all the remaining humidity, till it comes to the con≈øi≈øtency of a Rob or Extract, which keep in a wide-mouth'd Bottle clo≈øe ≈øtopt, to mix with
other purging Extracts.

¬ß 7. This Extract is proper to expel the Sero≈øities of the remote parts of the Body, and therefore is very good for Drop≈øies, where gentle Medicines will not prevail: It is al≈øo an excellent thing in Di≈øea≈øes of the Joynts and Rheumati≈øms, e≈øpecially again≈øt the Gout, Sciatica, and Kings-evil, and all ≈øorts of ≈øtrumous Swellings, mixing it with other Extracts, as that of Rhubarb, to qualifie its activity, and fortifie the Bowels at the ≈øame time. Do≈øe alone in Pills √† gr. iij. ad. x. and accordingly to be proportion'd, with re≈øpect to the ≈øtrength of tho≈øe it is mixt withal.

¬ß 8. Or thus, according to Le Mort. ‚Ñû Pulp of Colocynthis q. v. affu≈øe thereon boyling Water, which dige≈øt thereon in a Sand-heat 24 hours; expre≈øs the Liquor, and put on more boyling Water, which dige≈øt and expre≈øs, as before; and continue this operation ≈øo long, till the Water be no more coloured: Put all the≈øe tinged Liquors together, and evaporate to the con≈øi≈øtency of Honey, to which put a half part of rectified S. V. and keep it in a wide-mouth'd Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe. It is more gentle than other Preparations, and works in le≈øs do≈øe.

¬ß 9. I now come to propo≈øe an Extract of my own. ‚Ñû choice white Pulp of Coloquintida cut ≈ømall with a pair of Sizers lb j. Rain or Spring-water lb xij. mix and boyl all in a large Earthen or Iron-pot for 6 or 8 hours, then expre≈øs strongly: To the Feces put Water lb xij. more; boyl again 10 or 12 hours with a good Fire, and whil≈øt hot expre≈øs again ≈øtrongly: To the Feces put more Water lb vj. or viij. and boyl again for 14 or 16 hours, and ≈øtrain out again ≈øtrongly: Mix all the≈øe Decoctions together, and boyl them till half the liquor is evaporated; this being cold, will be a perfect Liver or Gelly, which you may cut: Continue a gentle evaporation, till it comes to the con≈øi≈øtency of an Extract to be made up into Pills: But if you determine it for any long keeping, you mu≈øt evaporate mo≈øt of the humidity, and then moi≈øten it with Chymical Oyl of Limons, or Caraways, and ≈øo keep it in a Jar-gla≈øs or Gallypot, tyed clo≈øe over with a wet Bladder for u≈øe. It has all the before enumerated Vertues, and may be given √† gr. iij. ad x. more or le≈øs, according to Age, Strength, and the Di≈øea≈øe.

div.head: II. * Magi≈øterium Benzo√Øni; Magi≈øtery of Benjamin.

¬ß 2. Le Febur makes it thus: ‚Ñû Benjamin ‚Ñ•ij. in fine pouder, put it into a Matra≈øs, upon which affu≈øe Alcohol of S. V. prepared upon Salt of Venus ‚Ñ•vj. ≈øhake them together nimbly, and dige≈øt a while in a warm B. V. would make but a ≈øimple Extraction of it, not a perfect Di≈ø≈øolution:) This Di≈ø≈øolution, which will be red and tran≈øparent, mu≈øt be filtrated into a Vial or Gla≈øs; the one half you may keep for Tincture, the other for Magi≈øtery, or precipitate, which is done by affu≈øion of a good quantity of common fair Water, then in B. M. ab≈øtract the S. V, in a ≈ømall Cucurbit, ≈øo will the Magi≈øtery be left at bottom, with the Water upon it, which you may decant by inclination, and if you plea≈øe, wa≈øh it with Damask-ro≈øe-water, then dry and keep it for u≈øe.

¬ß 3. The Tincture, to ≈øpeak the Truth, is only a di≈ø≈øolution of the Benjamin, yet however, its Vertues is encrea≈øed by rea≈øon of the excellency and noblene≈øs of the Men≈øtruum, for which rea≈øon it may be u≈øed inwardly for Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Lungs, as well as outwardly for a Wa≈øh; as in its proper place we have declared.

¬ß 4. However, this we add concerning this Tincture, That outwardly applyed, it is ≈øaid to be a wonderful Co≈ømetick, clean≈øing the Skin beyond any other thing, taking away all Spots and Pimples, as al≈øo other Tumors, Pu≈øtles, Buds, or redne≈øs in the Skin, and di≈ø≈øipating all har≈øh, virulent, and malignant Sero≈øities, with which it is many times infe≈øted. You mu≈øt apply it towards Bedtime upon all the places which you find wanting it, and the next day wa≈øh the ≈øame places with Barleywater, in which Veal has been boyled, which you ≈øhall turn to a Milk-colour with ≈øome few drops of this Tincture, and then wipe the Skin (whether of Hands or Face) with a very dry, ≈øoft Linnen Cloth. And as the Tincture, u≈øed ≈øimply or alone, will cure the Defects of the Skin aforementioned, ≈øo wa≈øhing with the white Water made by this Tincture will prevent for the future the coming again of other Pimples, Redne≈øs, Pu≈øtles, &c.

¬ß 5. Inwardly, it may be given √† gut. iiij. ad xx. mixt with the Yolk of an Egg, or in a ≈øpoonful of Syrup of Hy≈ø≈øop, again≈øt A≈øthma's, Shortne≈øs of Breath, Phthi≈øicks, old Coughs, &c. in the morning fa≈øting, and an hour before Supper.

¬ß 6. The Magi≈øtery is a Specifick for Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Lungs, and by rea≈øon of its ≈øubtile, volatile, and bal≈øamick parts, is appropriated, by the help of the Archeus, to the dige≈øtions of the di≈øea≈øed parts, and is given in≈øtead of the Tincture, to ≈øuch as have an aver≈øion to Spirit of Wine, for all the purpo≈øes afore≈øaid.

¬ß 7. It may be exhibited in the Yolk of a newlaid Egg, or ≈øome pectoral Con≈øerve or Syrup √† gr. x. ad xx. or xxv. Or you may give it in Tablers, or Lozenges, or mixt with ≈øome proper Electuary, and ≈øo made up into a Bolus.

¬ß 8. To make excellent Wa≈øhballs: Your Soap being prepared, and brought to a due con≈øi≈øtency with new Milk, feed it for ≈øoone days with Tincture of Benjamin, adding al≈øo to each pound of Soap of the Magi≈øtery ‚Ñ•≈øs. or more, and a few grains of Musk and Ambergri≈øe, then frame it into little Balls each weighing ‚Ñ•ij. or iij. „Äà‚óä„Äâ yo ‚Ä¢ like be≈øt your ≈øelf, which carefully lay to dry, and then keep them for u≈øe.

¬ß 9. The≈øe Wa≈øhballs, for their ≈øweetne≈øs and excellency, in clean≈øing and pre≈øerving the Skin both of Face and Hands, much exceed the Bolonian Wa≈øhballs, which have had ≈øuch a great repute in the World.

div.head: III. Magi≈øterium Bi≈ømuthi; Magi≈øtery of Marca≈øite or Tin-Gla≈øs; or, Spani≈øh White.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Marca≈øite in fine pouder, p. j. Spirit of Nitre, p. iij. mix and di≈ø≈øolve, precipitate with Salt water, edulcorate and dry, S. A. It is good again≈øt the Vices of the Skin, as Freckles, Lentils, Impetigo or Ringworms, Scabbine≈øs of the Hands, and the like, for which intentions it is a mo≈øt ab≈øolute Co≈ømetick or Beautifier.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Rolfincius Art. Chym. lib. 5. ≈øect. 2. cap. 34. makes it thus: ‚Ñû Of the Marca≈øite of Lead, which they call Bi≈ømuth, and by us Tin-Gla≈øs, q. v. Aquaefortis made with Alum and Nitre, A. q. s. mix and di≈ø≈øolve in a gentle heat; what is di≈ø≈øolved pour off, and precipitate with Oleum Tartari per diliquium, ≈øo in a moment you will have the Alcohol of Bi≈ømuth, mo≈øt pure white, like the new-faln Snow: Dulcifie it by many ablutions in fair water, which will free it from all its ≈øaltne≈øs and acrimony, and then dry it.

¬ß 2. This (≈øays he) is a mo≈øt wonderful Co≈ømetick, freeing the Face and Hands from Freckles, Spots, and other Defedations. In u≈øing it to cleanie the Face, let it be applyed with Bean-flower-water; to take away the Freckles and Spots of the Hands with ∆≤nguentum Pomatum, or Hogs Lard well wa≈øhed, for by this means it removes Lentils, Freckles, Ringworms, Tetters, and all ≈øorts of Scabs what≈øoever.

¬ß 3. But the way mo≈øt agreeable with the Proce≈øs of our Author you may ≈øee explicated at large, with a Rationale thereon, in our Pharm. Lond. lib. 3. cap. 10. ≈øect. 6. wherein you have many Ob≈øervations in the making thereof worthy of noting.

¬ß 4. Lemery's Magi≈øtery of Bi≈ømuth. ‚Ñû Bi≈ømuth in pouder ‚Ñ•i. put it into a Gla≈øs Matra≈øs with Spirit of Nitre ‚Ñ•iij. put the Di≈ø≈øolution into a clean white Ware Ve≈ø≈øel, and affu≈øe thereon five or ≈øix pints of Fountain-water, in which you have di≈ø≈øolved beforehand an ounce of Sea-≈øalt, ≈øo will you have a white Pouder, precipitate to the bottom; decant the Water by inclination, and wa≈øh the Magi≈øtery ≈øeveral times, drying it in the ≈øhade.

¬ß 5. This is that which is called Spani≈øh White, and is a mo≈øt excellent Co≈ømetick, for that it ≈øerves to clean≈øe the Skin and whiten the Complexion; and it is u≈øed mixt either with Pomatum or Lilly-water.

¬ß 6. Now, in the making of this, you mu≈øt be ≈øure to u≈øe a very large Bolthead to di≈ø≈øolve the Bi≈ømuth in, becau≈øe of the great Ebulition; for as ≈øoon as the Spirit of Nitre is put upon it, it takes up much room to move in, ≈øending forth many Vapors, of which beware, for they are very pernicious to the Head, Brain, Bre≈øt and Lungs.

¬ß 7. Now this great Ebulition proceeds from the Acid's penetration of the large Pores of the Bi≈ømuth, which violently divide all that oppo≈øe their motion: In this operation the Bolthead grows ≈øo hot, that a man can't endure his Hand upon it, which comes from the points of the Acid chafing again≈øt the ≈øolid body of the Bi≈ømuth, which makes a heat much after the manner, as when two ≈øolid Bodies are rubbed hard one again≈øt another: And the great ≈øtore of Igneous Particles contained in the Spirit, help much al≈øo to encrea≈øe this Heat.

¬ß 8. If the Di≈ø≈øolution becomes troubled thro' ≈øome Impurities in the Bi≈ømuth, you mu≈øt put into it twice as much Water and filter it, for if you ≈øhould filter it without Water, it would coagulate in the filter like Salt, and not pa≈øs through. This Coagulation proceeds from the acid Spirits of the Nitre, included in the Particles of the Bi≈ømuth, which having not room or moi≈øture enough to ≈øwim in or di≈øper≈øe, do gather together when the Di≈ø≈øolution is cold, into Cry≈øtals.

¬ß 9. The Impurity which commonly ≈øwims upon the Di≈ø≈øolution of the Marca≈øite is a fat or bituminous matter, which the Spirit of Nitre is not table to di≈ø≈øolve; and indeed Marca≈øite is nothing but an Excrement of a Metal, or a fat Earth impregnated with metalick parts.

¬ß 10. That is, it is a ≈øulphurous Sub≈øtance found in the Tin Mines, (thought by ≈øome to be an imperfect Tin, which partakes of good ≈øtore of Ar≈øenick) but its Pores are di≈øpo≈øed in another manner than tho≈øe of Tin; which is evident from the operation of the Men≈øtruum, for that it perfectly di≈ø≈øolves Bi≈ømuth, but has nothing near ≈øuch an operation upon Tin.

¬ß 11. This Magi≈øtery may al≈øo be made by affu≈øion of a great quantity of Fountain-water into the Di≈ø≈øolution, without any Salt, but it is made the quicker when you do it with Salt, and the Precipitation is the better, becau≈øe the Salt Particles do encounter and break the Acids, which Water alone was not ≈øufficiently able to enervate or weaken. Thus you ≈øee the Acid of the Salt overcomes the Acid of the Spirit of Nitre.

¬ß 12. Now how fair Water alone ≈øhould be able to precipitate Lead, Antimony, and Marca≈øite, being di≈ø≈øolved by the Acid, and yet cannot precipitate Gold, Silver, or Mercury, without the help of ≈øome Salt or other Body, is worthy to be enquired into: Without doubt the largene≈øs of the Pores of the former give the Water a greater liberty to pervade them, and force away the Acids, which cannot ≈øtick ≈øo clo≈øe as they do in Gold, Silver, and Mercury, where the Pores are very much finer and ≈ømaller, by which rea≈øon the Acid ≈øticks not only the clo≈øer, but the Water for the ≈øame rea≈øon is denied that ea≈øie entrance, and ≈øo can make no ≈øeparation, without
the help of a more piercing and active body.

¬ß 13. In making of this Magi≈øtery there is a con≈øiderable augmentation of the Bi≈ømuth, but this proceeds from part of the Spirit of Nitre remaining in it, and which cannot be ≈øeparated by the precipitation nor lotion, tho' never ≈øo often repeated.

¬ß 14. And what we have here taught you from Bi≈ømuth, or the Marca≈øite of Load, or Silver, as ≈øome call it, the ≈øame you may do from Zinck, or the Marca≈øite of Gold, which much re≈øembles Bi≈ømuth; and the operation is performed in like manner in all re≈øpects: But in the whole operation avoid the u≈øe of AF. (made with Vitriol) for that, by rea≈øon of the Vitriol, will blacken or foul the Precipitate, do what you can.

¬ß 15. Modus ∆≤tendi. You may mix í j. of this Magi≈øtery with Orange-flower-water or Damask-ro≈øe-water ‚Ñ•iv. Or with choice Pomatum, or well-wa≈øhed Hogs-Lard ‚Ñ•i. It ≈øoftens the Skin very much, and is al≈øo good again≈øt the Itch, becau≈øe it feeds upon tho≈øe Acids or Salts which cau≈øe and nouri≈øh this Di≈øea≈øe.

¬ß 16. Le Febur makes it thus: ‚Ñû A. F. made of equal parts of Nitre and common Salt, lb ≈øs. Bi≈ømuth in pouder ‚Ñ•iv. mix and di≈ø≈øolve, and if there be any foulne≈øs in it, filter it, then precipitate with tartarized S. V. ab≈øtract the Liquor ≈øwimming above the Magi≈øtery, and wa≈øh it with di≈øtilled Rain-water, till it is ≈øufficiently dulcified. Thus Schroder and Beguinus.

¬ß 17. It is, ≈øays he, a very good Remedy for all the Vices and Eruptions of the Skin, and above all again≈øt the Itch: It takes away Spots and Freckles in it, and ≈ømooths the roughne≈øs of the Face and Hands: But if you would make there with a pure and white Co≈ømetick, and u≈øe it either with or without Pomatum, he advi≈øes to precipitate with Oyl of Vitriol, (tho' I think Oyl of Sulphur would be better) ≈øo (≈øays he) you ≈øhall have an almo≈øt incomparable White, which you mu≈øt dulcifie, dry; and keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 18. Charras makes it in all re≈øpects, as does Le Febur, in a large Gla≈øs Cucurbit, but with this difference. That whereas Le Febur allows for the Bi≈ømuth, but p. ij. Charras allows the full tripple quantity, and then when the di≈ø≈øolution is perfected, precipitates with the be≈øt tartarized

¬ß 19. This (≈øays he) is a very white Magi≈øtery, fit for all Deformities of the Skin, and to beautifie the Complexions of Ladies, mixing it with proper Waters and Pomatums. And here note, that the Water of the fir≈øt L ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ion is very good to cure Tetters Ringworms, and the Itch.

¬ß 20. This Bi≈ømuth is a Mineral Body, half metalick, compo≈øed of Mercury, or the fir≈øt maner of Tin ill dige≈øted, a ‚Ä¢ oul terre≈øtial Sulphur no ‚Ä¢ ripened, and an impure Ar≈øenical Salt, as afore≈øaid, which Ar≈øenical Salt making one part of the Compo≈øition, is the rea≈øon that no Preparations made thereof are ever taken inwardly.

div.head: V. * Magi≈øterium Jovis, Magi≈øtery of Jupiter or Tin.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of the Flowers of Jupiter, di≈ø≈øolved in Water and filtred, precipitating with Oyl of Tartar per deliquium, or a di≈ø≈øolution of Alum, edulcorating by many ablutions in warm Water, and drying it again. Do≈øe gr. 4, 5, 6, &c. See the Vertues of the Salt of Jupiter.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This Pre≈øcript is from Lemery, but by all that is ≈øaid, it does not appear of what kind the Flowers are, of which this Magi≈øtery is to be made; they are twofold, viz. a ≈øublimation of Tin, either with Sal Armoniack or with Nitre: What the latter is, we ≈øhall ≈øhew in its place; what the former is (which without doubt is the Subject of this Pre≈øcript) we ≈øhall here ≈øhew.

¬ß 2. Flowers of Tin, with Sal Armoniack, from Lemery. ‚Ñû Tin, p. j. Sal Armoniack in pouder p. ij. mix them well together, put them into a ≈øtrong earthen Cucurbit, ≈øo large, as that not above a third part may be full, fit to it a blind Head, luting the Juncture, and place the Ve≈ø≈øel on the Grate in a ≈ømall Fornace and a naked Fire, and only ≈øo open, as that the Fire may pa≈øs through the Regi≈øters, for which rea≈øon you mu≈øt ≈øtop up the top of the Fornace with Bricks and Lime, leaving ≈øome holes in the ≈øides, which are called Regi≈øters, and let the Cucurbit enter a third
part of its height into the Fornace; then make a Fire ≈ømall at fir≈øt, and encrea≈øe it by degrees, till the bottom of the Cucurbit is red hot, which Fire continue till nothing more will ≈øublime, which you will know by the Heads growing cold, and then the ≈øublimation will be at an end; the Flowers will ≈øtick to the Head, and to the top of the Body, which take and keep for the making of the afore≈øaid Magi≈øtery.
¬ß 3. The≈øe Flowers are nothing but ≈øome Particles of the Tin, rai≈øed up by the volatility of the Sal Armoniack, and at the bottom of the Body you will find ≈øome of the Tin revived.

¬ß 4. But that this may be the more effectually done, your Tin ought fir≈øt to be reduced into a Calx by the means of Fire, for the better mixing it with the Sal Armoniack, which is thus done: Put Tin into a large unglaz'd earthen Pan, place it in a circular Fire, ≈øo will the Tin melt, then stir it with a Spatula, till it comes into a pouder, continue a great Fire to it 36 hours, stirring it from time to time, ≈øo will you have the Calx of Tin fit for ≈øublimation.

¬ß 5. In this Operation an unglaz'd Earthen Ve≈ø≈øel is u≈øed, le≈øt the Lead with which it is glaz'd ≈øhould mix with the Tin, and hurt its Purity; and the Ve≈ø≈øel is broad, that it might by ≈øtirring be the ≈øooner reduced to Pouder, in which it will be ea≈øier done in 36 hours, than in 4 or 5 days in a Crucible.

¬ß 6. It is impo≈ø≈øible to make Tin a≈øcend in Flowers without any mixture; and therefore, tho' the mixture of Salts may be found fault with, yet ≈øince it is not to be ≈øublimed without them, it mu≈øt be born withal, but the fault is the le≈øs, by rea≈øon of the facility of ≈øeparating the ≈øaid Salts again from the Metal by Lotion, of which our Author's Pre≈øcript here gives the Example.

¬ß 7. Some take equal quantities of Tin and Sal Armoniack; but Charras takes Calx of Tin, ‚Ñ•iij. Sal Armoniack ‚Ñ•xij. and being mixt in fine pouder, he ≈øublimes in a good Aludel upon a proper Fornace, covered with 3 or 4 of its pots, one upon another, and the Junctures well luted, and the uppermo≈øt covered with a little Head, then kindles a Coal-Fire under the Aludel, encrea≈øing it by degrees, till the Aludel is red hot in all its lower parts, at which time he throws in at the hole about ‚Ñ•≈øs. of the
pouder, and then clo≈øes it immediately, by which means the Tin and Sal Armoniack ri≈øe together in Vapors, which conden≈øe in Flowers, on the in≈øides of the Pots; then throws in another like quantity at the hole, and repeats this Operation till all the pouder is ≈øpent, keeping a good Fire under the Aludel, to facilitate the ≈øublimation of the Tin which by this means will be all ≈øublimed.

¬ß 8. Now, ≈øhould you take equal parts of Tin and Sal Arm. the Tin would remain almo≈øt all at the bottom of the Aludel: Nor is it to be wonder'd at, ≈øince it is impo≈ø≈øible to make Metals a≈øcend in Flowers, without the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of 3 or 4 times their weight of volatile Salts mixed with them, or at lea≈øt without ≈øeveral con≈øtant Cohobations, directed to be made u≈øe of.

¬ß 9. This Magi≈øtery is a delicate White, being mixt with Pomatum, and ≈øerves for a Paint: The Precipitate thus wa≈øh'd, is in order to deprive the Flowers of Jupiter of the volatile Salt which they derive from the Sal Armoniack in ≈øublimation: It is de≈øicative, and is u≈øed in Pomatums, for that purpo≈øe of drying up running Sores and Ulcers, and it is found to be of good u≈øe to repre≈øs Vapors, and re≈øi≈øt Fits of the Mother.

div.head: VI. Magi≈øterium Saturni; Magi≈øtery of Saturn or Lead.

¬ß 2. It is u≈øed for a Fucus, like Bi≈ømuth, and it is likewi≈øe mixed in Pomatums for Tetters, Ringworms, Pu≈øtles, and other breakings out of the Face and Skin.

¬ß 3. Here is to be noted, that if you ≈øhould u≈øe only Water, you would make but a kind of Virgins Milk, and the Saturn would not di≈ø≈øolve but precipitate, leaving ≈øome particles of its Body yet in the Water; wherefore it is better to take equal quantities of Water and Spirit of Vinegar, for thereby the Salt will be di≈ø≈øolved, into which dropping the alcalious Oyl of Tartar, the edges or points of the Acid are de≈øtroyed, which held up the Salt, and the matter precipitates by its own weight.

¬ß 4. In this Operation there is no efferve≈øcency, for the Acids of the Vinegar being broken and weakened, it has not ≈øtrength nor activity enough left to enter the Pores of the Salt of Tartar, ≈øo as to make ≈øuch an operation; and it is the ≈øame in all other ≈øub≈øtances di≈ø≈øolved by Vinegar; but if the Di≈ø≈øolution be performed with ≈øtronger Acids, as Oyls of Vitriol or Sulphur, Spirit of Nitre, &c. an Ebulition is made.

¬ß 9. div.head: VII. Magi≈øterium Sulphuris, i. Lac Sulphuris; Magi≈øtery or Milk of Sulphur.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Flowers of Sulphur p. j. Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is explicated at large in our Pharm. Lord. lib. 3. cap. 12. ≈øect 8. from Quercetans Pre≈øcription: Clo≈ø≈øaeus has another done with Quick-lime, and precipitated with Pi≈øs, which you may ≈øee in the ≈øame place.

¬ß 2. Lemery and Charras makes it al≈øo almo≈øt exactly according to this Pre≈øcript of our Author; but to di≈ø≈øolve the Flowers, he boils 5 or 6 hours with Water, lb ii. to every ounce of Sal ‚òø, or Salt of fixt Nitre, and ≈øo drys it in the ≈øhade.

¬ß 3. Now here is to be ob≈øerved, that as ≈øimple Water is not able to di≈ø≈øolve the Sulphur, but an alcalious Salt is made u≈øe of, to divide it into imperceptible Particles; ≈øo on the contrary the Acid afterwards pierces the Alcali, and by ≈øeparating its parts, makes it let go its hold of the Sulphur, whereby it falls down in a white Pouder, which being edulcorated, may be ≈øaid to be only Flowers of Sulphur Alcoholiz'd.
¬ß 4. And the change of the colour into a white, comes from its being more rarified, and obtaining a ≈ømoother Surface than it had before, to reflect the light in a direct line to our Eyes.

¬ß 5. And this operation (≈øays he) may give us an Idea of Chylification and Sanguification; for as the Sulphur becomes white in the Magi≈øtery, ≈øo the Aliments being fermented, and their ≈øub≈øtance attenuated in our Stomachs, are in part reduced into Chyle of a white colour; and as the Sulphur when entirely di≈ø≈øolved, turns of a red colour, ≈øo the parts of the Chyle being exalted and di≈ø≈øolved by repeated Circulations, become red, and turn into Blood, which Blood in Apo≈øtems turning into Pus, becomes white again, by rea≈øon of the praeternatural Acid a≈ø≈øi≈øting anew in that operation.
¬ß 6. Al≈øo when you make this Preparation, let no Ve≈ø≈øels of Silver be near where it is perform'd, for the Vapors proceeding from the Sulphur and Alcali, with the Acid, will make it black.

¬ß 7. As to the Do≈øe, our Author limits it in the large≈øt to 20 grains; whereas Lemery limits it to 15, becau≈øe (≈øays he) 15 grains of this Pouder will do as much as double the quantity of Flowers of Sulphur, in Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt, and yet it does not heat ≈øo much: But notwith≈øtanding this, I have given it to ‚Ñàj. yea, to gr. xxv. with very good ≈øucce≈øs.

¬ß 8. ¬ß 9. Le Mort makes it with Flores Sulphuris p. j. Quick-lime p. ij. which he boyls in Water to redne≈øs, then filter the Water, and precipitates with Spirit of Vinegar, which he edulcorates with many wa≈øhings. The ≈øame he al≈øo does with Cineres Clavellatorum or Pot-a≈øhes.

¬ß 10. Rolfincius, lib. 5. ≈øect. 2. cap. 35. Art. Chym. ≈øaith, That in the preparation thereof there are four di≈øtinct Operations; 1. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , by Solution, which is done in ≈øome fit ≈øaline Men≈øtruum, as an alcalious Salt, with which the fat or oily parts of the Sulphur will mix ea≈øily; this is twofold, viz. either vulgar as a Lixivium of Quick-lime alone, or with Tartar; or ≈øingular, as Salt of Tartar: But the fir≈øt of the≈øe he ≈øu≈øpects, for (≈øays he) the Atoms of the terra damnata of the Calx will in≈øeparably unite them≈øelves with the Lixivium and pa≈øs through the filter: The other, which is a ≈øolution of the Salt of Tartar, is much the more noble. 2. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , by precipitation, which he performed by Spirit of Wine-Vinegar. 3. Edulcatione, ≈øweetening by wa≈øhing
with much Water. 4. Ex≈øiccation, by drying, as is before taught.

¬ß 11. To this Opinion of Rol≈øincius, Le Febur ≈øeems to a≈ø≈øent, for (≈øays he) we recommend the Purity of Materials, which makes us make choice of Salt of Tartar in the di≈ø≈øolution of Sulphur, notwith≈øtanding ≈øeveral Authors content them≈øelves with A≈øhes of Wine-lees or Sandiver; but as the≈øe Salts have not the penetrating and fiery Vigor which is required for the di≈ø≈øolution of Sulphur and maturation of that Mineral, ≈øo neither can they make the Medicament ≈øo good nor ≈øo fai ‚Ä¢

¬ß 12. The≈øe things being con≈øidered, he takes Flowers of Sulphur ‚Ä¢ wice ≈øublimed, and di≈ø≈øolves the Salt of Tartar in in 15 parts of di≈øtilled Rain-water; but before the affu≈øion of the Water, he grinds the Flowers of Salt of Tartar together dry‚ñ™ in a warm Marble Mortar, then affu≈øes the Water, and boyls 5 or 6 hours to the di≈ø≈øolution of Sulphur; this done while hot, he only decants the clear Solution, (but filtrates not, becau≈øe it cannot be ≈øoon enough performed, for that as ≈øoon as the Men≈øtruum begins to co ‚Ä¢ l, the Sulphur returns into a body again) and then precipitates with Spirit of Vinegar, performing all the re≈øt of the Operation as before directed.

¬ß 13. ¬ß 14. This Remedy is called the Bal≈øam of the Lungs, which con≈øumes and drys up all malignant, ≈øerous, and watery Superfluities, for which rea≈øons it is exhibited in melting and ≈øuffocating Catarrhs, A≈øthma's, Phthi≈øicks, and to ≈øuch as are afflicted with old and inveterate Coughs, Colicks, Vento≈øities, or Wind, malignant Humors and Sero≈øities in the Joynts; it hinders and di≈ø≈øipates Vapors, facilitates Expectoration, and wonderfully ≈øtrengthens the Bre≈øt and Lungs.

¬ß 16. ¬ß 17. And Le Febur ≈øays, Tho' this Remedy is highly celebrated by Authors, it is better rather to tru≈øt to the Tincture extracted from it, than to this body, yet too cour≈øe and material, to hope from it all the good and commendable effects which are attributed unto it.

¬ß 18. However we cannot rely wholly upon what the≈øe Gentlemen ≈øay, for the Medicine is not ≈øo de≈øpicable as they would make it, tho' it be none of the highe≈øt Preparations; and notwith≈øtanding Le Febur ≈øays, it is yet too cour≈øe and material, we ≈øay it is much more ≈øubtile than a thou≈øand other Medicaments much e≈øteemed above it, and will do that by touching only outwardly with it, which other more e≈øteemed ≈øublime Medicines will not do neither by inward nor outward application.

div.p:
Bate.] ‚Ñû Salt of Tartar q. v. impregnate it with the be≈øt Vinegar ≈øo long, till the Tartar will receive no more acidity, then affu≈øe thereon S. V. and ab≈øtract again, cohobating ≈øeveral times, at length place the Tartar ≈øo as it

¬ß 3. Another proce≈øs of the ≈øame Le Mort. ‚Ñû Cry≈øtals of Tartar ‚Ñ•vj. ¬ß 5. We will now deliver you the Proce≈øs of Sennertus's Magi≈øtery or purgative Salt of Tartar, which is the very thing with which Le Febur makes his Armoniack Tincture of Mars, the Pre≈øcript of which you have in Chap. 7. Sect. 2. aforegoing. The ≈øaid Magi≈øtery of Sennertus is thus done.

¬ß 6. ‚Ñû Pure Salt of Tartar lb ij. put it into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, affu≈øe thereon ≈øtrong Spirit of Vinegar lb iv. ≈øtir them together till the Salt is well di≈ø≈øolved, place the Cucurbit in a Sand or A≈øh heat, and ab≈øtract the humidity, which will come off ta≈øtle≈øs as fair Water; put on more Spirit of Vinegar, and continue to di≈øtil ≈øoftly; and ≈øo often repeat this work, till what you di≈øtil off comes forth with the ≈øame ≈øtrength as when it went on, which will happen after you have reitterated the operation about 20 times: The Salt remaining after all this work will be very black, but have lo≈øt all its lixiviate ta≈øte, and become of a plea≈øant acidity. In this Operation the change which happens in the ta≈øte of this Salt, proves this Truth, that acid and alcalious Salts convert one another into a neutral ≈øub≈øtance, which is no more either the one or the other, and yet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes a le≈øs hurtful and more excellent vertue than the Bodies of which they have been compounded.

¬ß 8. This evidently appears in the Example of Tartar Vitriolate, for Oyl of Vitriol is a very ≈øtrong and fiery Corro≈øive, like an all-con≈øuming Fire; and ≈øtrong Oyl of Tartar per deliquium, or Soap-boilers ≈øtronge≈øt Lees, is a very fine Alcali, of a biting, urinous, and unplea≈øing ta≈øte; neverthele≈øs the Re≈øult of both being mixt, makes a very plea≈øing Magi≈øtery, containing no more the ≈øimple qualities of either of the Bodies of which it is compounded, except that of a penetrative, ≈øubtile, and di≈ø≈øolutive property.

¬ß 9. And this appears in our pre≈øent Magi≈øtery, in that
the Vinegar lo≈øes all its acidity, and turns into an in≈øipid Water; and this volatile-acid Salt of the Vinegar (for ≈øuch it is) checks, and turns the edge and ill ta≈øte of the Alcali, or Salt of Tartar, and makes it to become an extraordinary Remedy.

¬ß 10. We cannot chu≈øe therefore but recommend this magi≈øterial Salt in the highe≈øt manner con≈øidering the wonderful effects it is able to produce, for it is beyond mo≈øt other Remedies in opening the Ob≈øtructions of all the Vi≈øcera, or in any other part of the Body, (for which rea≈øon it is an excellent thing again≈øt the Pal≈øie) and to evacuate gently any morbifick matter lodged in the ≈øaid Vi≈øcera, and parts adjacent to the ≈øame.

¬ß 11. It purges gently, and without violence, through all the Emunctories and prevails again≈øt all chronick and de≈øperate Di≈øea≈øes, which have been of ≈øo rebellious a nature, as to yield to no other Remedies.

Do≈øe √† ‚Ñà≈øs. ad ‚Ñàj. if dry, or from ‚Ñàj. or 20 drops, to ‚Ñàij. or 40 drops, if liquid: You may give it in Veal or Chicken Broth, or Veal boiled with Par≈øly-roots, or White-wine in which Damask-Ro≈øes have been infu≈øed and aromatiz'd with a little Cinnamon: Give it fa≈øting in the morning, and if need require, reiterate it at night going to Bed.

div.head: XIII. * Arcanum Corallinum; The Coralline Secret.

¬ß 7. The white Ma≈øs which remains after the fir≈øt evaporation of the humidity, is a mixture of Mercury with a great many acid Spirits, for it weighs three ounces more than the crude Mercury did; and it is extreme corro≈øive and fiery, if applied to the Fle≈øh.

¬ß 2. ¬ß 3. ¬ß 4. This Arcanum or Matter being put into a Crucible, in a melting Fire, turns

¬ß 5. que ade√≤ expurgantur, ut locus illi morbo ampli√πs non detur: in i≈øto ≈øiquidens Corallino, quod ex e≈ø≈øentia Auri preparatum e≈øt, facultas ade√≤ in≈øignis latet, ut impo≈ø≈øibile ≈øit, Medicum citra illam purgationem Podagram inquirere, &c. And De Vita Longa, lib. 2. cap. 1. he ≈øaith, Tria quae ad perfectam podagrae curam requiruntur; purgatio, apertio, deinde Cura in hanc ≈øententionem: Principio purgetur omnis podagricus plena ac perfecta purgatione, & id ip≈øum Arcano Corallino, quo interveniente, eliciuntur fluxus podagriae, ade√≤ ut ne locus porro relinquatur podagrae: In hoc Corallino quod ex e≈ø≈øentia Auri e≈øt, tanta vis, ac virtus ine≈øt, ut eam, ni≈øi hac purgatione √† medico deprehendi impo≈ø≈øibile ≈øit: fiat i≈øta purgandi ratio ≈øexies, aut ≈øepties, pro vetu≈øtate ≈øive duritia, ≈øive natura podagrae. ¬ß 6. However, this of our Author's, going under the Name of Paracel≈øus, is taken from Crollius, and by Hartman attributed to Paracel≈øus, tho' he confe≈ø≈øes it is no where to be found in his Works. ¬ß 7. In this Preparation the crude Mercury ought to be purified, which is done with a Lixivium of Calx Vive, and Pota≈øhes, 6 or 7 times repeated, and afterwards wa≈øh'd with Salt and Vinegar ≈øo long, till it has a coele≈øtial colour, ≈øo will it be fit for ≈øublimation.

¬ß 8. Or thus: ‚Ñû Crude Mercury, put it into a long Gla≈øs, no part cut off, put on it the be≈øt S. V. ≈øo much as to cover it 2 inches; keep it well ≈øtopt with your Thumb, and ≈øhake the Gla≈øs between your hands very well, ≈øo will the Mercurial blackne≈øs be ≈øeparated in the Spirit of Wine, and to the ≈øides of the Ve≈ø≈øel; the S. ¬ß 9. The Saltpeter or Nitre mu≈øt be al≈øo diligently purified, and ≈øeparated from all vulgar Salt, otherwi≈øe the Sublimate or Arcanum will be above mea≈øure corro≈øive. ¬ß 10. ¬ß 15. Hartman has another Arcanum Coralinum of his own, much of this kind, which (≈øays he) is more ea≈øie to make, and more excellent than the former of Paracel≈øus, and it is thus: ‚Ñû Salt (extracted out of the Caput Mort. of AF. made of Vitriol and Nitre) ‚Ñ•vj. and Mercury well purged ‚Ñ•ij. mix and grind them well together, imbibing them with Vinegar until in tho≈øe Salts the Mercury be quite con≈øumed, then in a Cucurbit, with its Alembick, ≈øublime after the u≈øual manner: Some will be white, ≈øome yellowi≈øh Saffron like, and ≈øome of it will be mo≈øt red, without any corro≈øion. div.head: XVI. Arcanum Duplex, ≈øeu Sal Duplex; The Duplicate Secret, or Salt.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. What the ≈øingle Aquafortis is, you may ≈øee in our Pharm. Lond. lib. 3. cap. 10. ≈øect. 48. the Double here intended is de≈øcribed in cap. 1. ≈øect. 27. of this Book aforegoing.

Schroder depurates the Salt by many Solutions and Coagulations, till it is white, then pouders it, and puts it into a luted Cucurbit or Still, calcines and melts, and for the better melting, adds ≈øome Sal Nitre, to make it melt the ea≈øier, which work he repeats four times, but after the ≈øecond or third time depurates the matter again from the feces,

¬ß 12. ¬ß 14, He a≈øcribes to it all the Vertues before enumerated, and ≈øays, that its manner of operating cannot ≈øufficiently enough be prai≈øed, for that it ≈øweetly provokes Sleep, and ≈øettles the Archaeus of the Ventricle in its ordinary ≈øtate and calmne≈øs when it is out of order.

div.head: XVIII. Arcanum Scriptorium, A Secret for Writing, or The Sympathetical Ink.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of the Salt of Saturn í j. di≈ø≈øolved in an ounce of Water, for the Writing Liquor, and of Ar≈øenick or Orpiment in pouder, mixed with Quick-lime, A ‚Ñ•≈øs. dige≈øted in Water ‚Ñ•iv. for the oblineatory Liquor.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Proce≈øs from Le Mort, who calls it Atramentum Sympatheticum. It is compo≈øed, ≈øays he, of two liquors the fir≈øt of which is thus made: ‚Ñû Litharge of Gold ‚Ñ•j. Spirit of Vinegar ‚Ñ•iij. mix and boil a little, till the Spirit of Vinegar grows ≈øweet, or has extracted the ≈øalt of the Lead, then let it be filtred, and kept for u≈øe.

¬ß 2. The ≈øecond Liquor is thus made: ‚Ñû Auripigment in fine pouder ‚Ñ•j. Calx Vive about ‚Ñ•ij. mix and boyl 'em well together in a ≈øufficient quantity of Water, till the Liquor acquire a ≈øubvirid colour, then filter, and keep it for u≈øe.

Orpiment in fine pouder ‚Ñ•≈øs. mix them together, put the mixture into a Matra≈øs, and pour upon it water ‚Ñ•v. or vj. ≈øo that it may be three inches above the pouder; ≈øtop the Matra≈øs with Cork, Wax, and a Bladder, and ≈øet it in dige≈øtion in a gentle ≈øand-heat for 10 or 12 hours, ≈øhaking the Matra≈øs often; then let it ≈øettle, that the liquor may become clear, like common Water.

¬ß 7. The fir≈øt Experiment. Dip a little Cotten in the third or la≈øt Liquor, being fir≈øt filtred, or very clear, and rub the place you wrote upon with this Cotton, ≈øo will that which before appeared, being written with the Cork-Ink, immediately di≈øappear; and that which was written with the Impregnation of Saturn, and not to be ≈øeen, will immediately appear, and be vi≈øible.

¬ß 8. The ≈øecond Experiment. Take a Book four inches in thickne≈øs, or thicker if you plea≈øe, write on the fir≈øt leaf with the Impregnation of Saturn, or el≈øe lay a Paper which you have written in the ≈øame place, then turn the other ≈øide of the Book, and having ob≈øerved as near as may be, the oppo≈øite place to your Writing, rub the la≈øt leaf of the Book, or another Paper, with the third Liquor made of Quick-lime and Orpiment, which lay in the place of that la≈øt leaf, and leave the Cotton on the place, clap a folded Paper pre≈øently upon it, and ≈øhutting the Book quickly, ≈øtrike upon it with your Hand 4 or 5 good ≈øtrokes, then turn the Book, and put it into a Pre≈øs for half a quarter of an hour, take it out and open it, and you will find the place appear black, where you had wrote with the fir≈øt Liquor or Impregnation of Saturn: And the ≈øame thing would be done, was the thickne≈øs of 2 or 3 Ream of Paper between, provided they were in like manner pre≈øt, to hinder the evaporating of the Spirits.

div.head: XIX. Aurum Fulminans; Lightning or Thundering Gold.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of Sol di≈ø≈øolved in A. R. and precipitated with Oyl of Tartar per deliq. then edulcorating and drying, S. A. They u≈øually give 3 or 4 grains thereof to provoke Sweating.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Maets makes it in this proportion; ‚Ñû Filings of fine Gold, p. j. Aquae Regiae p. iij. or iv. di≈ø≈øolve the Sol in a gentle ≈øand-hea ‚Ä¢ to which di≈ø≈øolution affu≈øe Oyl of Tartar per deliquium, drop by drop, till the efferve≈øcence of the Salts ≈øhall cea≈øe. This is made a regeneration of Nitre, for the mo≈øt ≈øubtile parts of the Nitre intimately mix them≈øelves with the Particles of the Gold, in ≈øuch ≈øorts, that if they be affected with too great a heat, they break forth into a flame with a thundering noi≈øe.

¬ß 2. Lemery makes it thus. ‚Ñû Gold in thin Plates or Leaves, q. v. put it into a Vial or Matra≈øs, and affu≈øe thereon gradatim, 3 or 4 times as much A. R. dige≈øt on warm Sand till the Gold is di≈ø≈øolved, or the A. R. has ≈øwallowed up as much of the Sol as it can hold, which you may know by the cea≈øing of the Ebulition. Decant the ≈øolution into a Gla≈øs Ve≈ø≈øel, and affu≈øe thereon five or ≈øix times as much common water, then drop into this mixture Gutatim, volatile Spirit of Sal Armoniack or Oleum Tartari per deliq. ≈øo will the Gold precipitate. After a good while ≈øettling, that all the Gold may fall down, decant off the Water by Inclination, wa≈øh the Precipitate with warm Water, till it grows in≈øipid, and ≈øo dry it in a Paper at a gentle fire, becau≈øe it is apt to take fire, and fly away with a noi≈øe and violence like Thunder and Lightning.

¬ß 3. Now here is to be noted that Plates or Leaves of Gold are u≈øed in this Operation, that its di≈ø≈øolution may the more ea≈øily be performed: And you mu≈øt put on the A. R. gradatim, to avoid the mighty efferve≈øcency, which would po≈ø≈øibly drive it out of the Matra≈øs; which efferve≈øcency proceeds from the violent divi≈øion of the metalline Particles, for when it finds no more Particles to work upon, having divided the body of the Gold into as many Atoms as 'tis po≈ø≈øible, the Ebulition cea≈øes, and the Sol remains in the A. R. imperceptible to us, ≈øo that the Water ≈øeems not to be changed
from what it was before, it is, ≈øo perfectly clear and tran≈øparent, except that it has received a golden colour, and is become yellow.

¬ß 4. This di≈ø≈øolution of Gold is only a ≈øu≈øpen≈øion of the Particles of the Metal in the Water, made by the Points of the A. R. for it is not enough, that the A. R. does divide the Gold into ≈øubtile Particles, but it is farther requi≈øite that the ≈øaid points or edges ≈øhould hold up the Atoms, otherwi≈øe they would alwaies fall to the bottom in a Pouder, though never ≈øo ≈øubtile.

¬ß 5. The≈øe acid edges are bodies exceeding light, in compari≈øon of the Particles of Gold, and they have their ≈øuperficies more extended, con≈øequently take up more room in the flegm, and this is that that holds them up, and makes them ≈øwim; for as a piece of Wood will ≈øwim in Water, and a piece of Metal ≈øink, yet if the Metal be fixt on the Wood, or ≈øu≈øpended by it, they both will ≈øwim together.

¬ß 6. The Oyl of Tartar, or Spirit of Sal Armoniack u≈øed in this Precipitation, contain each of them an alcalious Salt, which being mixed with Acids, cau≈øes an immediate fermentation, in which the Parts of the A. R. which held up the Particles of the Gold, do grow weak, and ≈øo weak, as to be able to hold them no longer; by which means, through their own weight, they precipitate.

¬ß 7. Now the rea≈øon why the volatile Spirit of Sal Armoniack weakens the A. R. which is compounded of Sal Armoniack, is this; The ≈øtrength of the A. R. not proceeding ≈øo much from the volatile part of the Sal Armoniack, as from the Sea-≈øalt, which in great plenty is mixed with it, and from which indeed the mighty force of the A. R. proceeds, it follows that as the only Sea-≈øalt which is a fixed Acid, can ≈øtrengthen it, ≈øo what≈øoever is oppo≈øite to it, ≈øuch as is a volatile Alcali, (and ≈øuch is the volatile Spirit of Sal Arm.) mu≈øt in like manner weaken and de≈øtroy it, by ab≈øorbing in ≈øome mea≈øure its acidity: And indeed, both Sea-≈øalts and Sal Gem may either of them be indifferently ≈øub≈øtituted in the place of Sal Armoniack for making Aqua Regis, as I may el≈øewhere ob≈øerve and demon≈øtrate.

¬ß 8. From what has been ≈øaid it appears, that this Operation is only Particles of
Gold, impregnated with acid Spirits, which cau≈øes it, when ≈øet over the Fire, to give ≈øuch a loud or thundering crack.
¬ß 9. And it is al≈øo ob≈øervable from the preci≈øe weighing the Gold, that from í iij. of fine Gold, you will have í iv. of Aurum Fulminans, when well dryed.

¬ß 10. Now the rea≈øon why the di≈ø≈øolvent quits the Body it di≈ø≈øolved and held up, is the adding ≈øome Body which by its motion and figure is able to engage the Acids, ≈øo much as to break them, whereby the Particles of Gold being at liberty, through their own weight they ≈øub≈øide; and this is done through any alcalious Salt: And ≈øuch are Oyl of Tartar. and volatile Spirit of Sal Armoniack, which being very active Salts in their kind, and finding Bodies at re≈øt, pre≈øently move them, and by a quick and rapid motion ≈øhake them ≈øo violently, as to break the Points by which the metalline Particles were ≈øu≈øpended; which fragments of Points being thus di≈øengaged from the Gold, act now upon the alcalious Salt, piercing and dividing their Particles a≈øunder, which are much more ≈øoluble in their nature than the Gold; and from hence proceeds this new Ebulition, &c.

¬ß 11. By this means the remaining A. R. is rendered uncapable of di≈ø≈øolving any more Gold, becau≈øe it has no more power left of making a penetration: And the precipitated Gold is impregnated with ≈øome parts of the Di≈ø≈øolvent, for that the ≈øharpe≈øt part of the≈øe points remain within the Particles of the Precipitate, in which they are ≈øo clo≈øely lock'd up, that though it be ≈øeveral times wa≈øhed in warm Water, they cannot po≈ø≈øibly be di≈øengaged from their hold.

¬ß 12. And this is plainly apparent, when put upon the fire, from the great detonation or noi≈øe which is made, which can proceed from nothing el≈øe but the enclo≈øed Spirits, which violently break the mo≈øt compact body of Gold, to get ≈øpeedily out, when they are forc'd to it by the vertue of Fire.

¬ß 13. This Aurum Fulminans has a force va≈øtly ≈øtronger than Gunpouder, viz. as 1. to 200. for í j. of this Fulminant Gold put into a Silver Spoon or Ladle, and held over the Fire, will give a louder bounce than í 200 or ‚Ñ•xxv. of the fine≈øt and be≈øt Gunpouder.

¬ß 14. But from this Violence no Fear need to ari≈øe; as to the taking of it inwardly, tho' much heated by the Stomach, for the humidities thereof mixing with it, hinder it from making ≈øuch a thundering noi≈øe, as when ≈øet over the Fire in a Spoon; for ≈øo much the more moi≈øture comes to it, ≈øo much the le≈øs noi≈øe it does make.

¬ß 15. This Medicine cau≈øes Sweat, and drives out malign and pe≈øtilential Humors by tran≈øpiration, and may be given in the Small Pox √† gr. ij. ad vj. in Con≈øerve of Ro≈øes, or Electuary, or ≈øome proper Syrup: It ≈øtops Vomiting, and moderates the activity of Mercury; and ≈øome Authors think it to be the be≈øt Medicine in the World to expel Mercury out of the Body by Sweat, when it has been given by unskilful Hands: And as Gold repre≈ø≈øes the violence of Mercury, becau≈øe it does amalgamate with it, ≈øo Aurum Fulminans does it much better; for being volatile, it is more ea≈øily carried through all the Body, and fails not to find out the Mercury, where-ever it lies.

¬ß 16. And as taken inwardly it cau≈øes Sweat, becau≈øe the heat of the Body volatilizes it, and forces it through the Pores; ≈øo al≈øo, if the Pores are very open, it will only cau≈øe an in≈øen≈øible tran≈øpiration, for from the clo≈øene≈øs of the Pores, it remains a longer time before it can pa≈øs through, whereby the vaporous humidity which accompanies it conden≈øes upon the Skin, and is that which we call Sweat.

¬ß 17. That the Gold and Spirit of Nitre, jointly together, cau≈øes this Operation, is almo≈øt manife≈øtly apparent, for 'tis very probable that the≈øe Spirits do carry with them ≈øome parts of the Gold, with which they are ≈øo intimately mixed; and being thus armed (as it were) with the Particles of the Gold, it is made the more powerful, to conquer and overcome what ≈øhall oppo≈øe in its Pa≈ø≈øage, than if it were ≈øingly given of it ≈øelf.

¬ß 18. Charras ≈øays it mu≈øt not be wa≈øhed above once or twice, if you intend to pre≈øerve the Purgative faculty, which the Salts impart to it: It is, ≈øays he, very diaphoretick, and may be given √† gr. iij. ad vj. in ≈øome Con≈øerve or Confection.

¬ß 19. The violent and wonderful effects of this Aurum Fulminans ought to oblige
the Arti≈øt to great circum≈øpection in the drying of it, as al≈øo in the keeping and giving of it. 'Tis true al≈øo, that its fulminating or thundering force may ea≈øily be obtunded, by moi≈øtening it with Spirit of Vitriol, Salt, or Sulphur, before it be wholly dryed, becau≈øe tho≈øe Acids joyning them≈øelves to the Particles of the other Acids, which were intimately mixed with the Precipitate of Gold, break the Union, and hinder the violence which they would exert in taking fire.

¬ß 20. By this means you may afterwards dry this Precipitate over the fire without any danger, yea, and make it red hot in a Crucible, o ‚Ä¢ melt it without fear of any fulmination; but then it would be a que≈øtion whether it would be ≈øo efficacious to the purpo≈øes intended, as it was before; and therefore, in my opinion, it is better to have it according to its genuine proportion, though it co≈øts more care and circum≈øpection in the performance thereof.

div.head: XX. Aurum Vitae; Living or Vital Gold.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of fine Gold í ij. and purified Mercury ‚Ñ•ij. each di≈ø≈øolved by them≈øelves in their proper Men≈øtruums, then mix'd together and di≈øtilled in a Retort to dryne≈øs: This remaining Calx is to be calcin'd, and edulcorated by ablution in Water and Accen≈øion of S. V. S. A. It is ≈øaid to excel, and is preferred before all other kinds of Catharticks; it kills Worms, cures the French Pox, and overcomes the Spotted Fever, Plague, Quartan Agues, &c. Do≈øe √† gr. iij. ad vj. vel viij. in Sugar of Ro≈øes, or in the yolk of an Egg. or in Broth, or in Pills, more e≈øpecially if mix'd with Scammony, and moi≈øtened with burnt Aqua Vitae.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. We have given you ≈øeveral Preparations of this Medicament, from divers Authors, as from Bovius, Hartman, and Sennertus, all which you may ≈øee in our Pharmacop. Londinen≈øis, lib. 3. cap. 7. ≈øect. 37, 38, 39. but this of our. Author differs from them all, as we ≈øhall anon ≈øhew.

¬ß 2. Others makes it thus: ‚Ñû Fine Gold in Filings or
Leaves ‚Ñ•ij. Aqua Regis ‚Ñ•viij. mix and di≈ø≈øolve, keeping the di≈ø≈øolution in a hot place: Take al≈øo crude Quick-≈øilver well clean≈øed ‚Ñ•xij. common A. F. lb ij. ‚Ñ•xxiv. mix and di≈ø≈øolve; mix the Solutions together, and in a little time all will appear very black; by an Alembick in Sand di≈øtil it with a gentle heat, encrea≈øing the fire gradually, till what is in the bottom begins to be red, and the Spirits are ≈øeen to evaporate, afterwards encrea≈øe the heat, that the Cucurbit in the bottom may be very hot; this done, take it out, and if any thing ≈øhall be ≈øublimed, take it al≈øo and mix with the other, put all into a Crucible, and calcine it till the Spirits be well ≈øeparated, ≈øtirring it with an Iron Rod, then edulcorate it by wa≈øhing it in warm Water, and draw off from it rectified S. V. with many cohobations.

¬ß 3. This of our Author is thus to be done: The Gold í ij. „Äà‚óä„Äâ to be di≈ø≈øolved in the A. R. ‚Ñ•iv. de≈øcribed in the afore-cited Chapter, ≈øect. 27. The≈øe two Solutions you are to mix together, and perfect the Precipitate by di≈øtillation, calcination, ablution, and accen≈øion of S. V. „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Pre≈øcript directs.

¬ß 4. The difference of all the≈øe five Pre≈øcripts has relation either as to the manner of making, or to the Proportions: As to the manner of making, Bovius, Hartman, Bate, and the Pre≈øcript aforegoing, agree, in di≈ø≈øolving the Gold and Mercury apart: Sennertus alone makes fir≈øt an Amalgama, and then di≈ø≈øolves it in A. F. As to the Proportions, they all differ; Bovius has p. j. of Sol to p. iv. of Mercury; Tilingius and the Pre≈øcript we have here in≈øerted, has 1 of Gold to 6 of Mercury; Bate, our Author, has 1 of Gold to 8 of Mercury; Sennertus has 1 of Gold to 10 of Mercury; la≈øtly, Crollius and Hartman have one of Gold to 12 of Mercury.

¬ß 5. Without doubt, as it has the ≈øuffrage of the greater number, to di≈ø≈øolve each Metal apart by it ≈øelf, ≈øo it ≈øeems to be the more natural way, notwith≈øtanding the ≈ømallne≈øs of the Particles, which ≈øome think the Mercury by amalgamation reduces the Gold to, the A. F. only acting upon the Mercury in this Preparation, and not upon the Gold at all; whereas in the other Preparations the Gold receives a ≈øingular volatility and openne≈øs from the A. R. as upon occa≈øion I am

able to demon≈øtrate, and has ≈øuch a union with ≈øome parts of the Armoniack Salt, as can ≈øcarcely ever be ≈øeparated from it again, without lo≈øs of ≈øome parts of the Gold.

¬ß 6. As to the proportions, if it be made after Sennertus's way, the longer proportions are the better; but in the other methods, that in a mean between 4 and 12, is in my judgment to be cho≈øen, which is the proportion a≈ø≈øigned by our Author; for if you amalgamate, the more the Mercury is in quantity, the more minute Particles it reduces the Body of the Gold into; but if you di≈ø≈øolve apart in Strong-waters, you do two things at once, in ≈øome mea≈øure volatilize the Gold, and make more fixt the Mercury, by a unition of di≈ø≈øolved Particles in their Men≈øtruums, and a gentle fixation together in a calcinatory heat.

¬ß 7. The Vertues of this Medicine are many and great, (take which Preparation you plea≈øe) it ea≈øily, ≈øafely, and ≈øpeedily roots out any old, malign, rebellious, ‚Ä¢ or deplorable Di≈øea≈øe; it cures the French Pox, with all its ≈øymptoms, to a wonder, kills Worms in old or young, cures the King's-Evil, Drop≈øie, Gout, Sciatica, Lepro≈øie, Scurvy, Tetters, Ring-worms, rebellious Herpes, Plague, Poy≈øon, and all ≈øorts of Fevers, whether continual or intermitting: It al≈øo cures the Green-≈øickne≈øs in Virgins, the Cholick, from what cau≈øe ≈øoever, Cancers in any part of the Body, di≈ø≈øolves Scirrhus Tumors, and removes all manner of Ob≈øtructions, in what part of the Body ≈øoever; and it is ≈øaid in the≈øe Di≈øtempers to begin, continue, and perfect the Cure alone. Truly, I can ≈øay upon my own large experience, it performs wonderfully in all long, old, rebellious, and undetermin'd Di≈øea≈øes, performing Cures many times beyond all expectation.

div.head: XXI. Aethiops Minerale; The Mineral Black.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Flowers of Sulphur p. ij. crude Mercury p. j. mix them exactly, and kindle or fire them, ≈øo as they may be made into a mo≈øt black pouder, S. A. It is of u≈øe in the French Pox, Drop≈øie, &c. and fluxes not.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Some make the mixture with Flowers of Sulphur, and crude Mercury, ana. But a late Writer will have it to be Flowers of Sulphur í vj. crude Quick-≈øilver ‚Ñ•j

This thus made, and in this proportion, he gives √† gr. xxv. ad xxx. Morning and Evening (gently purging the Body the fourth day) to kill Worms, for which 'tis doubtle≈øs a good Medicine.

But that it may be alwaies given ≈øafely, without danger of fluxing or ≈øalivating, I dare not affirm; for my ≈øelf, who have u≈øed it above this twenty years with extraordinary ≈øucce≈øs, (prepared only by grinding together) altho' I often u≈øed it without any ≈øear of Salivation, yet ≈øometimes, contrary to my expectation, it would rai≈øe a gentle Flux or Spitting.

¬ß 3. My u≈øual proportion was this: ‚Ñû Crude Quick-≈øilver, Flowers of Sulphur, ana. mix them together ‚Ä¢ y grinding in an Iron or Marble Mortar, till the Mercury di≈øappears, and becomes with the Sulphur an impalpable Pouder‚ñ™ as black as Jet, which by much rubbing in this Mortar it will ea≈øily be made.

¬ß 4. The fir≈øt Light I had for making this Medicine, I received from the Learned Barbet, by reading of his Chyrurgery; and ≈øome little hint I gave of ≈øu ‚Ä¢ h a like Medicine (made of Sulphur and Mercury by grinding) about ten years ≈øince in my Doron. ¬ß 5. And this Medicine made of the two Ingredients in equal proportion, I have all a long u≈øed, and do ≈øtill, not e≈øteeming it much inferiour to many other Preparations of Mercury, much more famed than it; but where I meet with fluxile and tender Bodies, and where the Humors are apt to be put into motion, I alwaies take the Proportions of our Author, but compleat it without deflagration, thus: ‚Ñû Flowers of Sulphur ‚Ñ•ij. crude Quick-≈øilver ‚Ñ•j. mix by grinding in an Iron or Marble Mortar, till the Mercury di≈øappears, and with the Sulphur becomes an impalpable pouder of a deep black colour.

¬ß 6. The Medicine made according to this la≈øt Pre≈øcript, I take to be very ≈øafe, and have given it often with all the de≈øired effects imaginable; nor do I remember that it ever produced a Salivation, or any thing like it, in any per≈øon I ever gave it to, whether old or young.

¬ß 7. If you ≈øhall yet ≈øcruple to u≈øe this mean Preparation, but rather make choice of that of our Author, made by deflagration, you have your liberty, and may do it, but for my part, I ≈øhall alwaies u≈øe that made by ≈øimple grinding, &c.

¬ß 8. That with double quantity of Sulphur I give √† ‚Ñàj. ad ‚Ñàij. but that with equal quantities √† ‚Ñàj. ad í ≈øs. and according as the Patient is ≈øtrong, and able to bear Medicines: The Do≈øes of each may yet be encrea≈øed to ‚Ñà≈øs. more, but this is to be limitted and directed according to the Prudence of the Phy≈øician.

Be≈øides the killing of Worms in Children, and elder per≈øons al≈øo, it is an excellent Remedy again≈øt the French Di≈øea≈øe, and all its Attendants, cures Pocky Scabs, Ulcers, Impetigo, Serpigo, and other defedations of the Skin, proceeding from a Pocky Venom: It is al≈øo good again≈øt Nodes, Gums, Tophs, Nocturnal Pains, and the like; for being taken inwardly, (con≈øtantly for ≈øome time) in ≈øome proper Con≈øerve or Bolus, it gives relief almo≈øt like Opium, and makes that Herd of Symptoms vani≈øh, as if it was done by Enchantment. div.head: XXIII. * Antihecticum Poterij; The Antihectick of Poterius.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of Regulus of Antimony, of Mars and Engli≈øh Tin, ana. melting and detonating them with a treble quantity of Sal Nitre, and edulcorating with Water, S. A. Do≈øe gr. vj. ad xx. in the Pox, Drop≈øie, Scurvy, Con≈øumption.
