¬ß 2. His ≈øecond way is thus: ‚Ñû Regulus of Antimony ‚Ñ•xij. Engli≈øh Tin ‚Ñ•vj. melt them together, and being cold, reduce them into a fine pouder, to the which add an equal weight of pure Sal Nitre, viz. ‚Ñ•xviij. beat and mingle them well together, and make the detonation in a red-hot Crucible, as you do in making Antimony diaphoretick; when all is well calcin'd, take it out of the Crucible, break it and reduce it to a ≈øubtile pouder, affu≈øe thereon warm Rain-water, ≈øtirring it up and down with a Pe≈øtel, ≈øo will the Rain-water grow
white, which lei≈øurely and gently decant: To the remaining bottom put more fre≈øh Rain-water, proceeding as before, and thus continue ≈øo long, till nothing but a thick Gummous Matter or Sordes remain: The≈øe white or milky Liquors put all together, which put in a ≈øtill quiet place, free from dirt or A≈øhes, ≈øo will a very white pouder precipitate to the bottom, the Water ≈øwimming above, which has imbibed in it ≈øelf all the nitrous Salt: This Pouder oftentimes wa≈øh even ≈øo long, till the Acrimony of the Nitre is wholly taken away, then dry, and keep it for u≈øe.

¬ß 3. This Pouder, ≈øays he, Is exhibited in hectick Fevers, and in Drop≈øies with Rob of Elder-berries; chiefly it is u≈øed in malign and inveterate Ulcers, and in the Scurvy, which neither by Decoctions (of Guajacum) nor by any other more benigh Gallenical Medicaments, are po≈ø≈øible to be cured; in all tho≈øe ca≈øes it is a mo≈øt powerful Medicament.

¬ß 4. In ≈øome it operates by Vomit, if the Stomach be very foul and ob ‚Ä¢ tructed, for for then po≈ø≈øibly it may give a Vomit or two, in others it works by Sweat, in ≈øome by Urine, and in ≈øome by ≈øtool: It is given in the beginning of a Hectick, and in Ob≈øtructions of the Womb; in each Body it operates according to the habit and di≈øpo≈øition.

¬ß 5. Methodus Exhibendi. Fir≈øt begin with four or five grains, and encrea≈øe the do≈øe gradually, till it begins to nau≈øeate the Stomach, then dimini≈øh that larger do≈øe a little, and proceed in the u≈øe of it in that proportion for ≈øeveral days.

¬ß 6. Modus ∆≤tendi. In the French Pox, and in inveterate Ulcers, let it be exhibited in Decoction of Guajacum, Sar≈øaparilla, Sa≈ø≈øafras, &c. where it operates by Urine, you will pre≈øently ≈øee inveterate and malign Ulcers, in ≈øuch Per≈øons, to remit of their violence and malignity, and to ≈øubmit to Ointments, Bal≈øams, Empla≈øters, &c. Outwardly, It is ≈øucce≈øsfully ≈øprinkled upon Ulcers, or mixed with Emp ‚Ä¢ a≈øtrum Dia≈øulphuris Ru ‚Ä¢ andi.

div.head: XXIV. * Antimonium Diaphoreticum; Diaphoretick or Sweating Antimony.
div.p:
Bate.] It is made of Antimony p. j. Sal Nitre p. iij. detonating and edulcorating with Water, S. A. Do≈øe ‚Ñàj. twice a day for many days, augmenting the quantity daily
grada ‚Ä¢ im, till it comes to í j.
‚Ä¢ or a Do≈øe, Its u≈øe is to purifie the Blood in Cachexies, Drop≈øies, the Scurvy, French Pox, &c.

Salmon] ¬ß 1. Having poudered and mixt the Ingredients well together, and having a Crucible heat red hot in the Coals in a readine≈øs, ca≈øt into i ‚Ä¢ a ≈øpoonful of the mixture, which will pre≈øently make a thundering noi≈øe; which being done, ca≈øt in another ≈øpoonful, and this continue till the whole quantity of your Pouder is done; then make a great fire about it f ‚Ä¢ r about 2 hours, after which ca≈øt the white matter into an earthen Pan‚ñ™ almo≈øt full of fair Water, where leave it for 12, 14, or 16 hours, that the Nitre may di≈ø≈øolve in the Water, which ≈øeparate by inclination, and wa≈øh the white Pouder which remains in the bottom five or ≈øix times with fre≈øh warm Water, and then dry it.
¬ß 2. This is a Preparation of Antimony, who≈øe Sulphurs are fixt by the Nitre, and are thereby hindered from working otherwi≈øe than by Sweating.

¬ß 3. The fir≈øt ≈øeparated Liquor may be evaporated, and a fixt Nitre will be found at bottom of the Ve≈ø≈øel, which is much of the nature and will work much like the Sal Polychre≈øtum. This fixt Nitre unites it ≈øelf in the operation with the Antimony, making the volatile Parts thereof to ‚Ä¢ y away, and thereby hinders the Antimony from being emetick.

¬ß 4. This Medicament is ≈øudorifick, re≈øi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s Malignity and Poy≈øon, and therefore is ≈øaid. „Äà‚óä„Äâ be good again≈øt the Mea≈øles, Small Pox, Spotted Fever, Plague, and all other malign Contagions, and pe≈øtilential Di≈øtempers‚ñ™ Do≈øe √† gr. 10 ad 30. and by a gradual encrea≈øe to í j. in ≈øome ≈øpecifick or appropriate Liquor.

¬ß 5. It is ordered to be 5 or 6 times wa≈øhed, but ≈øhould the Lotions be never ≈øo manifold, they could never wa≈øh away all the Salt which had joyned it ≈øelf to the Antimony ‚ñ™ for each Particle of Antimony is ≈øo clo≈øely united to as many Particles of fixt Nitre, that they can never be ≈øeparated therefrom, without recour≈øe to ≈øome reductive Salt, which is the rea≈øon that this Preparation is ≈øaid to be not at all vomitive, but only ≈øudorifick, tho' in my opinion this latter Effect is not very ≈øen≈øibly apparent; but all Authors, affirm it, and ≈øo we ≈øubmit? And po≈ø≈øibly
≈øome of its Sulphur may be ≈øeparated by the heat of the Body, which not being ≈øtrong enough to be emetick, may have a force by Tran≈øpiration, either ≈øen≈øible or in≈øen≈øible, as the Pores of the Body may be more or le≈øs open.

¬ß 6. Some will have this Antim. Diaphoreticum to be a fixt Alcali, like Pearl, Coral‚ñ™ calcin'd Hartshorn, Chalk, Crabs-eyes, &c. and ≈øo like them, to ab≈øorb ≈øharp and acid Humors, which are the Cau≈øes of many Di≈øea≈øes: But in this doubtle≈øs they are mi≈øtaken, for put any Acid upon it, it will never di≈ø≈øolve at all, nor ab≈øorb the Acid, though after a long Infu≈øion, but let it remain as ≈øtrong as ever; which is a demon≈øtration ≈øtrong enough, that it is no Alcali.

¬ß 7. It may be quaeried, why a treble quantity of Nitre being mixt, will not make ≈øo great a detonation, as if it was mixt in equal quantities with the Antimony? But this is eafily an≈øwered; for that there is too little Sulphur in the Antimony, for ≈øuch a great proportion of Nitre, and that ≈øome parts of the Sulphur of the Antimony remain unactive in the fixt Nitre, which admits not of flagration, the volarile parts of the Nitre not burning, but according to the proportion of Sulphur with which it is mixt.

¬ß 8. There is another Preparation of this Medicament in our Pharm. Lond. lib. 3. cap. 8. ≈øect. 57. with double Nitre, and a treble Calcination, and that either with crude Antimony, or with its Regulus; which ≈øee in the place cited.

¬ß 9. Maets takes fir≈øt equal parts of crude Antimony and Nitre, and therewith makes a Crocus Metallorum; this Crocus, in fine pouder, he again mixes with an equal quantity of pure Nitre, and calcines as before, by which repeated calcination, ≈øays he, the Sulphur and volatile Salts of the Antimony are made to fly, whereby the remaining Calx of the Antimony becomes totally deprived of its Emotick and Cathartick Properties. After the ≈øame manner Beguinus makes it al≈øo, as he has taught in his Tyrocinium Chymicum, lib. 2. cap. 12.
¬ß 10. Marggrave takes equal quantities of Antimony and Nitre, and makes the proportion by a treble detonation, adding equal parts of fre≈øh Nitre each time.

¬ß 11. Le Mort makes it thus. ‚Ñû Crude Antimony p j. pure Nitre p. iij. mix in fine
pouder, and make the detonation as before directed, keep it in the fire for half an hour, but ≈øo as it may not flow or melt, then ca≈øt it into a Pot almo≈øt full of warm Rain-water, ≈øo will the Salts upon the Spot be di≈ø≈øolved, which with the ≈øupernating Water are to be poured off, and new or fre≈øh Water is to affu≈øed, ≈øtirring all together, till the Water grows white like Milk, from a good quantity of the pouder ≈øwimming in it, which decant, and affu≈øe more Water again, ≈øtirring and decanting it as before, and repeating this Operation ≈øo long, as the affu≈øed Water will grow white. Put all the decanted Liquors together, which let re≈øt for a while, that the Pouder may ≈øettle, which carefully dry, and keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 12. Where note, that Le Mort u≈øes a broad Earthen Pot or Pan, rather than a Crucible, which Bla≈øius the Commentator upon Beguinus would have to be large, for the more ea≈øie ≈øeparation of the matter.
¬ß 13. Secondly, if the Nitre be not pure, the Antimonium Diaphoreticum will be of a yellowi≈øh colour.

¬ß 14. It ought not to be too long detained in the Fire, becau≈øe the longer it is calcin'd, it is not made the better, but the wor≈øe, for then the Nitre will degenerate into an alcalious nature, and the Antimony be apt to a fu≈øion, from the fu≈øion and coalition of which, ≈øome reguline Particles will be formed, which will cau≈øe a revivification of the emetick Property of the Antimony, which in this Preparation we ought by all means to avoid.

¬ß 15. The more pure the Mineral of the Antimony is, the purer and whiter will be the Antimonium Diaphoreticum; from whence it is, that that which is made of the Regulus is judged to be better than that which is made of the crude Antimony.

¬ß 16. Le Feburc takes to pure crude Antimony p. j. mo≈øt pure Nitre p. ij. mixes them in ≈øubtile Pouder, and detonates in a red-hot Crucible, as before directed; by which Operation (≈øays he) the Nitre does forcibly carry away and expel the impure Sulphur of the Antimony, and its Mercury is dige≈øted, ripened, and forced by the property of the fixt Salt of Nitre, and the action of the Fire: Being thus once calcicined, he adds another like quantity of pure Nitre, to what is in the Ve≈ø≈øel, that it may flow with the Matter, and perfect the coction and fixation of
it, by the penetration and action of the Spirits of Nitre, which by their ≈øubtilty and quickne≈øs in≈øinuate them≈øe ‚Ä¢ ves into the lea≈øt Atoms of the Antimony, by which it concocts, purifies, and fixes it in a white friable ≈øub≈øtance; and in this heat he keeps it one or two hours, which pa≈øt, letting the Crucible cool, and free ‚Ä¢ ng it from all the filth hanging to it, he puts it into a Pot full of boiling Water, which di≈ø≈øolves the whole ma≈øs from which he ≈øeparates the Antimony Diaphoreticum, as is taught at ¬ß 11. aforegoing, then dries it, and keeps it for u≈øe.

¬ß 17. The decanted clear Water containing the fixed Salt of Nitre, which is impr ‚Ä¢ gnated with the internal Sulphur of Antimony, and is of a penetrating and igneous nature (but not corro≈øive) is a truly-fixt and Solar Sulphur, well concocted and dige≈øted by the action of the Fire and Nitre. This Water, I ≈øay, containing a Salt impregnated with ≈øuch a Sulphur, tho' it appears clear, has a weight and ≈øolid ≈øub≈øtance in it, which with Spirit of Vinegar may be precipitated, (the Water turning white as M ‚Ä¢ lk, and of a plea≈øing acid ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ l)

¬ß 18. This Precipitate, which is called Ceru≈øe of Antimony al≈øo, is a Diaphoretick proceeding from the fixed internal Sulphur now mentioned, (Do≈øe √† gr. iij. ad xx.) whereas the Sulphur Auratum precipitated with the like Spirit of Vinegar, has a very unplea≈øing ≈ømell, becau≈øe it is nothing el≈øe but the external, impure, and volatile Sulphur, which the Salt had drawn to its ≈øelf, not being able to force it away, or fix it, the parts in the Nitre and Antimony to make the Crocus Metallorum being equal; whereas in this Preparation there is three parts of Nitre to one of Antimony, which does perfect the maturation and fixation of the remaining crude and indige≈øted Sulphur.

¬ß 19. And it is this Author's opinion, that whatever mu≈øt fix a volatile ≈øub≈øtance ought to be in triple proportion to what is to be fixed; and contrariwi≈øe, what is to be volatilized, mu≈øt in the ≈øame proportion be le≈øs than that which is to volatilize it, and ≈øometimes the proportion is to be quadruplicated, as ‚Ñ•iij. or iiij. of Spirit to volatilize ‚Ñ•j. of Salt, and ‚Ñ•iij. or iiij. of Salt to fix ‚Ñ•j. of Spirit, &c.

¬ß 20. This Diaphoretick Antimony, faith Le Febure, is ≈øaid to be fixed only comparatively to other Antimonial Remedies, which are violently Cathartick or Emetick, this being ≈øudorifick by an irradiation of vertue and efficacy, ≈øtrengthening the internal Archaeus, which is the principal director of all the functions of Life, both in Health and Sickne≈øs, for which cau≈øe its u≈øe mu≈øt be continued, without irruption, for the ≈øpace of 40 days, ≈øince in that time it is able to alter and change the habit of the whole humane frame, for the better.

¬ß 21. It re≈øi≈øts Corruption, rectifies the whole ma≈øs of Blood, and is capable to open the mo≈øt inveterate Ob≈øtructions of the Liver, Spleen, Lungs, Pancreas, Me≈øentery, and all the other Vi≈øcera, provokes the Terms, cures the Green≈øickne≈øs, Drop≈øie, Hypochondriacal Melancholy, Pox with all its ≈øymptoms, clean≈øes and heals inward and outward Ulcers, and is ≈øingular again≈øt all ≈øorts of malign and pe≈øtilential Fevers of what kind ≈øoever, as Mea≈øles, Small Pox, Spotted Fever, and the very Plague it ≈øelf, as afore≈øaid.

¬ß 22. Rolfincius Art. Chym. lib. 5. ≈øect. 7. cap. 2. agrees in the manner of the Preparation with Le Mort and others, as al≈øo in the triple proportion of the Nitre to the Antimony, but ≈øaith, that the decanted clear Water being evaporated, the one half is an egregious Anodyn; and the evaporation being continued to a ju≈øt degree, it will in a cool Cellar ≈øhoot into Cry≈øtals which he calls Nitrum Anodynum, but Schroder, Lapis Prunellae Antimonialis. This, ≈øays Rolfincius, is impregnated with many Atoms of the fir≈øt Ens of Metals, cools the Blood, and as a Gargle, helps the Inflamation of the Fauces and the Quin≈øey, prevails again≈øt the Pleuri≈øie, expels Urine, gently loo≈øens the Belly, and di≈øcu≈ø≈øes ≈øerous Humors by Sweat, and is given in ≈øub≈øtance ad gr. vj.

¬ß 23. Charras takes equalquantities in fine pouder, which gradually be puts into a red-hot Crucible (in the mid≈øt of the Fireplace of a Wind fornace) fitted with a Cover, into which putting it by ≈øpoonfuls; after each ≈øpoonful he covers the Crucible at the ≈øame time, leaving the Pouder to fulminate, and thus continues the calcination till all the ma≈øs is gone, adding afterwards, by degrees, the two other
parts of the Nitre, ≈øtirring it each time with a long Iron Spatula, and keeping a good fire for two or three hours, or till the Antimony and Nitre have lo≈øt their fluidity, and are reduced in the Crucible to a white and ≈øolid ma≈øs, after which he perfects the Preparation according to the Method of Le Mort, at ¬ß 11. aforegoing; yet ≈øtops not there, but puts it into a Crucible, and holds it over the fire for two or three hours, after which he burns off from it good S.V. and then keeps it clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 24. From what has been ≈øaid, it appears, that mo≈øt Authors agree to three parts of Nitre to one of Antimony, only ≈øome would have all the Nitre mixt at once with the Antimony, others but two parts at fir≈øt, others but one part, adding the other one or two parts ≈øucce≈ø≈øively to the Ma≈øs. Now 'tis true, the event of all the≈øe various Proportions differs not much, provided the triple quantity of Nitre be u≈øed; yet Charras thinks it much better to mix but a third part at fir≈øt, which will make a fulmination violent enough to rai≈øe the gro≈øs Sulphur of the Antimony, tho' not able to di≈ø≈øipate the volatile parts, and then to add afterwards by degrees the other two parts of the Nitre, which tho' they cau≈øe no more fulmination, yet will con≈øume the re≈øt of the volatile and impure parts of the Antimony, for that the ≈øpirituous and fixt parts of the Nitre have now the liberty to u≈øe all their time and force upon the Antimony, to change its emetick and cathartick qualities into diaphoretick, and to fix the e≈ø≈øential Properties of this Mineral.

¬ß 25. Lemery gives us another Preparation, by which he ≈øaves the volatile parts of the Antimony, which ≈øublime from it, and it is thus: Take an unglaz'd earthen Pot (able to re≈øi≈øt the Fire) with a hole in the middle of its height, and a ≈øtopple to it, ≈øet it in a fit and proper Fornace, and fit to it three earthen Pots more, all three open at bottom, and a gla≈øs Head to the uppermo≈øt Pot, with a Vial or Receiver, luting all the Junctures well, let the Fire tran≈øpire through ≈øome proper holes in the Fornace, but be only ≈øo ≈øtrong as to warm the bottom of the lowermo≈øt Pot, then give Fire by degrees, heating the ≈øaid Pot gradatim, till it is red-hot.

¬ß 26. Then take your mixture made of three parts of Nitre, and one of Antimony, and
ca≈øt it into the red-hot Pot, through the hole, by ≈øpoonfuls, ≈øtopping it again immediately till the detonation is over, after which ca≈øt in another ≈øpoonful, and thus continue till your whole quantity is ≈øpent, then encrea≈øe the Fire to the utmo≈øt for half an hours time, after which let it go out: When the Ve≈ø≈øels are cold, you will find a little Spirit of Nitre in the Receiver, white Flowers in the three upper Pots, and a white Ma≈øs in the lowermo≈øt, which you mu≈øt wa≈øh, as afore directed at ¬ß 1. or ¬ß 11. to make your Antimonium Diaphoreticum, which dry and keep for u≈øe; which is full as good as any of the former.

¬ß 27. In all the≈øe Operations it appears, that tho' Antimmy is naturally black, it becomes altogether white, when it is well rarified; for whatever is ≈øeen in this Operation is a pure-white (if the Nitre he pure) as well the volatile as the fixt; which ≈øhews, that Colours have only an accidental, not an e≈ø≈øential Being.

¬ß 28. In this la≈øt Preparation the Sulphurous or volatile parts of the Antimony, which ≈øtick to the ≈øides of the Pots in Flowers, tho' unwa≈øht, will not be ≈øo emetick as other Flowers of Antimony, becau≈øe the Acid of the Nitre, which ari≈øes with them, hinders their activity.
¬ß 29. In the Receiver an Acid Spirit will be found which is only Spirit of Nitre, and is of good u≈øe in the Colick, being given √† gut. iv. ad. viij. in Broth, or ≈øome other fit Vehicle.

¬ß 30. In this Operation you have of Antimony Diaphoretick ‚Ñ•v. after it is well wa≈øh'd and dried; of fixed Nitre ‚Ñ•x. after it is cry≈øtalized; Spirit of Nitre ‚Ñ•≈øs. and Flowers of Antimony wa≈øh'd and dried í ij. out of a mixture of five ounces of Antimony, and 15 ounces of Nitre; but this cry≈øtalliz'd Nitre will not be above half fixt, for being thrown upon Coals, it will flame. By this it appears there is lo≈øt in this Operation ‚Ñ•iv. and better of the whole, which may come from what it lo≈øes by the hole of the Pot through which it is ca≈øt in the detonation; for ≈øtop it as well as you can, much fume will come forth that way; which the Arti≈øt ought to beware of, le≈øt it hurt him.

¬ß 31. Tho' the volatile parts of the Antimony ari≈øe with the volatile parts of the Nitre, in the detonation, yet the Antimony Diaphoretick
will weigh as much as the Crude Antimony, becau≈øe that in place of the volatile parts of the Antimony, as many fixt parts of the Nitre do in≈øeparably joyn them≈øelves with the remainder, whereby it becomes fixt, and is hindered from being emetick.

¬ß 32. An Antimony Diaphoretick made with a Sulphur of Antimony, which will burn like common Sulphur. ‚Ñû Crude Antimony in fine pouder ‚Ñ•viij. Aqua Regis ‚Ñ•xxiv. mix them in a Gla≈øs Body (within a Chimney) ≈øo will there be a ≈øtrong ebulition with red fumes (which are to be avoided) and the Antimony will di≈ø≈øolve; being di≈ø≈øolved, affu≈øe thereon a great deal of Water, ≈øo the Aqua Regis being weakened, the whole will become milky or white, and a Precipitate in a white Pouder will fall to the bottom; upon the top of the Water a grey ≈øcum will ≈øwim, which gather and dry in the ≈øhade: This is inflamable Sulphur of Antimony, and burns like common Sulphur, having the ≈øame vertues and effects, and therefrom a Spirit of Sulphur may be drawn: Decant the water from the Precipitate, and wa≈øh the Precipitate divers times, till it is ≈øweet, then dry it, and you have Antimony Diaphoretick, of the ≈øame vertues and u≈øe with the former, and by ≈øome preferred before all the other Preparations.

div.head: XXV. Antimonium Diaphoreticum fixum; Fixed Sweating Antimony.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Antimony and Nitre, A. make the detonation, wa≈øh and dry; with this Pouder mix again an equal quantity of Nitre, calcine again, wa≈øh and dry; la≈øtly, mix again with that Pouder an equal quantity of Nitre, make the detonation or calcination, put this into boiling Water, filter and precipitate with Spirit of Vinegar, then ≈øweeten by wa≈øhing it, and dry it. It has the ≈øame vertues with the former, and to be u≈øed in the ≈øame do≈øe.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This differs little or nothing from Le Febure's Precipitate at ¬ß 17. of the former Section, it being properly a Diaphoretick made of the internal Sulphur of the Antimony.

¬ß 2. Modus ∆≤tendi. ‚Ñû Of this Precipitate ‚Ñàj. ad í ≈øs. Syrup of Clovegilliflowers or Citron-peels ‚Ñ•≈øs. Aquae Cera≈øorum nigr. ‚Ñ•i≈øs, mix for a do≈øe, to ≈øweat upon, in the Mea≈øles, Small-Pox, Spotted Fever, Calenture Plague, or any malign or pe≈øtilential Di≈øtemper.

div.head: XXVI. Antimonium Medicamento≈øum; Medicinal Antimony.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Antimony in pouder p. v. Common Salt p. iv. Nitre, Tartar, p. j. mix, melt into a Regulus, and edulcorate. It differs little from the former in vertue.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Hartman in his Chymical Di≈øputations has ≈øomething like this, and it is thus made: ‚Ñû Antimony, Common Salt, Sal Nitre, Ana. pouder them a≈øunder, and put them into a Ve≈ø≈øel well luted, with a hole left at the top, and ≈øet them in a Wind-fornace, blow with Bellows till all melt, and till it cea≈øes to ≈ømoke, then for a quarter of an hour encrea≈øe the fire, after which take it off‚ñ™ and you ≈øhall have Antimony like Cinnaber-gla≈øs at the bottom ≈øeparated from the Salts like a Regulus from the Scales, and ea≈øie to be broken with a Hammer.

¬ß 2. This of Hartman purges mo≈øt downward, and is good again≈øt Epilep≈øies, Pleuri≈øies, Ob≈øtructions and Foulne≈øs of the Stomach, Melancholy, Fevers, Plague, congealation of the Blood, and Gout.
¬ß 3. But let Hartman ≈øay what he will, my Experience has told me, that it will ≈øometimes vomit, e≈øpecially if the Stomach be ob≈øtructed and foul.

¬ß 4. The Do≈øe is from gr. iij. ad x. but it will be prudent to encrea≈øe the do≈øe gradually, till you ≈øee what the ≈øtrength of the Patient will bear: It may be given in Cly≈øters √† ‚Ñàj. ad í j. boil it in proper Water or Wine, ≈øtrain, and add emollient Herbs, to be given again≈øt a Collick.

¬ß 5. This of our Author's is ≈øaid to be ≈øudorifick, and to agree in nature and vertue with Antimonium Diaphoreticum; but this I can a≈ø≈øure you al≈øo upon Experience, that it has the vertue of the Regulus with it; and though in ≈øome ≈øtrong Con≈øtitutions it may provoke ≈øweating, yet in weaker it gives both Vomits and Stools, and therefore the Do≈øe is with Art and Caution to be proportion'd: Begin with gr. v. or vj. and ≈øo encrea≈øe it gradually, as you ≈øee the Body of the Sick is able to bear it.

¬ß 6. La≈øtly, this of our Author's is of that nature, that having freed the Stomach and Body from the peccant matter, it will not then operate at all, whatever the Operation of it was before, which
≈øingle Property is enough to commend it to the con≈øideration and u≈øe of all the lovers of Art.

div.head: XXVII. Antimonium Re≈øu≈øcitatum; Antimony revived.
div.p: Bate.] Sublime Antimony, and Sal Armoniack, of each equal parts, with a triple cohobation; dige≈øt the Sublimate with Spirit of Vinegar, exhale, and ≈øweeten by wa≈øhing S. A. It is ≈øaid to be diaphoretick, and gently to provoke Vomit.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Learned and Ingenious Dr. Gideon Harvey is ≈øaid to be the Author of this Medicine; and that you may be ≈øure to have the true Recipe, we will give you it from him≈øelf, as he has publi≈øhed it in his Di≈øcovery of the Venereal Evil, lib. 2. Art. 10. pag. 141. word for word.

¬ß 2. ‚Ñû A ≈øufficient proportion of Hungarian gli≈øtering Antimony, add thereto an anatick quantity of Sal Armoniack, grind them well together in a Mortar, put the mixture into a ≈øublimatory, and ≈øublime it into yellow and red Flowers, the≈øe conves into a Bolthead, affu≈øe upon them Acetum di≈øtillatum ad eminentiam Palmae Unius, after 7 or 8 days dige≈øtion, ab≈øtract the Liqu ‚Ä¢ r by di≈øtillation or evaporation, grind the whiti≈øh re≈øidue, and edulcorate it with warm Water, whereby it's ultimately reduced to its pri≈øtine colour.

¬ß 3. This having left behind it its ferocity, malignity and venom, re≈øults a mo≈øt gentle Vomitory, Dejectory, and Diaphoretick, accommodated to all Ages, Sexes, and Climes, radically curing all Opilations, Jaundices, Fevers, Drop≈øies, initial Phthi≈øes, Convul≈øions in Children; But more particularly (≈øays he) we have removed with it ≈øeveral Agues in Children, Ob≈øtructions of Cour≈øes in Women, and incipient Con≈øumptions in Men. In ≈øhort, Crocus Metallorum, or Vitrum Antimonii, are Poy≈øons in compari≈øon to this Preparation.
¬ß 4. Than this (≈øays he) in a frontier Pox, no Cure is more admirable: Or, in ≈øhort, this, if parallelling it with other Cures, is the ≈øole Method that cures tut√≤, cit√≤ & jucunde.

¬ß 5. His way of pre≈øcribing it is thus: ‚Ñû Antimonium Re≈øu≈øcitatum, from gr. iv. ad viij. or x. Mercurius Dulcis √† gr. 15 ad 25. fre≈øh Con≈øerve of Ro≈øes a ≈øufficient
quantity, mix, and make a Bolus; Capiat cum Regimine. Let this be reiterated thrice, for three days ≈øucce≈ø≈øively, or intermitting every other day, if the Patient's Strength counterindicates.

¬ß 6. This he calls The Hermaphrodite Cure of the Venereal Lues, from the Commixture of Heterogeneous Minerals, and Grand from the Regimen or Cu≈øtodia, the Patient being obliged to confine him≈øelf within doors. Its duration is ≈øeldom protracted beyond twelve or fourteen days.

¬ß 7. His Dyet is required to be thin and dry; his u≈øual Drink Fountain-water boiled with a ≈ømall quantity of Sa≈ø≈øafras and Liquorice: After this cour≈øe is over, the re≈øt of the Cure is to be pur≈øued with this Pre≈øcript: ‚Ñû Antimonium Diaphoreticum √† gr. vj. ad x. Oyl of Juniper √† gut. ij. ad iv. Syrup of Bawm q. s. mix, and make Pills, No. 3 or 5, which let be gilded, or rouled in Liquorice-pouder, for one do≈øe, to be taken in the morning, and the Patient well covered for ≈øweating.

¬ß 8. The≈øe are to be continued four days together, the Patient compo≈øing him≈øelf to ≈øweat after them; but if he be too much enervated by the Precedents, the fir≈øt Sweat may be remitted to him: If his Strength can bear another at night, he may propo≈øe to him≈øelf a ≈øecurer and ≈øhorter cure.

¬ß 9. The fifth or eighth day, if you compute from the commencement of the Cure, the Patient mu≈øt breakfa≈øt with his purgative Bole, and be re-acquainted with his Antivenereal Pills, for the four next en≈øuing days, afterwards let him take his farwel of his Bole, by repeating it once more.

¬ß 10. Marggrave has an Antimonium Regeneratum, which he makes after this manner: ‚Ñû The Caput Mortuum left in the di≈øtillation of the Butter of Antimony, put it into a Gla≈øs Retort coated, and di≈øtil in an open Fire, ≈øo as the Retort may be throughly red fire-hot, and in an hour, or hour and half, the whole Caput Mortuum will be ≈øublimed into the neck of the Retort, leaving in the bottom of the Retort a little crude Antimony, which Chymi≈øts call Antimonium Regeneratum. What a≈øcends or ≈øublimes is Cinnaber of Antimony, which being reduced into pouder, may be ≈øeveral times rectified and ≈øublimed by it ≈øelf, &c.

div.head: XXVIII. Aurum Mo≈øaicum; Mo≈øaick Gold.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of Jupiter, Mercury, Sal Armoniack and Sulphur, mixed and ≈øublimed S. A. It is a noble Sudorifick. Do≈øe ad gr. x. vel xij.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Our Author here gives you the matter of the Compo≈øition, but not the proportions thereof; ≈øeveral men have given them directly, but tho≈øe proportions are the be≈øt which bring the Preparation neare≈øt to the colour of Gold.

¬ß 2. In our Doron Medicum, lib. 2. cap. 21. ≈øect. 40. you have the≈øe Proportions: ‚Ñû Crude Tin ‚Ñ•ij. crude Mercury q. s. or ‚Ñ•j. mix and make an Amalgama; Flowers of Sal Armoniack, Flowers of Sulphur, A. ‚Ñ•j. mix and ≈øublime.

¬ß 3. But this Proportion is ≈øaid to be better, and more natural: ‚Ñû Block Tin, crude Mercury, A. ‚Ñ•j. make an Amalgama, then mix therewith Flowers of Sal Armoniack flower of Sulphur, A. ‚Ñ•j. mix and ≈øublime with a very ≈øtrong fire.
¬ß 4. Or thus, from Maets. ‚Ñû Tin ‚Ñ•j. crude Mercury ‚Ñ•ij. mix, and make an Amalgama, to which add Sulphur and Sal Armoniack, Ana. ‚Ñ•j. mix, and ≈øublime, as before.

¬ß 5. Or thus, from the ≈øame Maets: ‚Ñû The Marca≈øite of Gold, crude Mercury, A. ‚Ñ•j. mix, and amalgamate, to which (being in fine pouder) add Sulphur and Sal Armoniack, A ‚Ñ•j. then mix and ≈øublime in a coated Gla≈øs Cucurbit.

¬ß 6. Or thus, from the ≈øame: ‚Ñû The be≈øt Engli≈øh Tin ‚Ñ•j. Mercury purified from its blackne≈øs ‚Ñ•≈øs. Sulphur in fine pouder, Sal Armoniack. A. ‚Ñ•≈øs. make an Amalg. of the two fir≈øt, which reduce into fine pouder, which mix with the other in pouder, and ≈øublime.

¬ß 7. In making this Preparation you mu≈øt fir≈øt make the Amalgama, which is done by putting the crude Mercury to the melted Tin, and ≈øtirring them together, till they are mixed, and the Mercury coagulated, then being well poudered, they are to be mixed with the other Ingredients in fine pouder.

¬ß 8. Here you ≈øee ≈øome prepare it with Flowers of Sulphur, and Flowers of Sal Armoniack, others with the crude Sulphur and un≈øublimed Salt, but without doubt the purer the Sub≈øtances are, the better will the Preparation
be, and the finer the colour.

¬ß 9. Some al≈øo take a double quantity of Tin to the Mercury; others take them in equal quantities, and ≈øay, that ≈øuch a Proportion gives the mo≈øt orient and true colour; but my Experience tells me, that the colour ari≈øes in the main from the goodne≈øs and purity of the Ingredients, for I have produced good from both the proportions, and ill-coloured too; ≈øo that by choice of the Maner, and many Tryals, you may find out the exact Truth only; and therefore it will be good to make Tryals but in ≈ømall quantities fir≈øt.

≈øect; 10. It is a good Sudorifick, and may be given ad ‚Ñàj. in ≈øome proper Con≈øerve, Electuary, or Bolus, again≈øt Fits of the Mother, Wind, Vapours, and Hypochondriack Di≈øaffections, as al≈øo again≈øt Di≈øea≈øes from a foul cau≈øe, and of a malign nature.

div.head: XXIX. Bezoar Animale; Animal. Bezoar.
div.p:
Bate.] ‚Ñû Harts-horn cal
‚Ä¢ in'd to the highe≈øt whitene≈øs, and pouder'd ‚Ñ•iv. levigate it ‚Ä¢ pon a Marble, till it becomes an impalpable pouder, affu≈øing thereon Guttatim, Spirit of Vitriol q. s. or ≈øo much as will make it into a Pa≈øte, of which make little Balls, which let be forthwith dryed. It is an Alexipharmick, Sudorifick, and De≈øtroyer of Worms; ≈øtops the flux of the Whites, quenches Thir≈øt, &c. it is a Medicine for Infants, Second to none.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It ought to be done with pure rectified Oyl of Vitriol, or rather Sulphur, and ≈øtirred with an Ivory Spatula, unle≈øs you mix them in a Gla≈øs Mortar with a Gla≈øs Pe≈øtel.

¬ß 2. The burning of Harts-horn is thus: ‚Ñû The Caput Mortuum of the Horn, left after the di≈øtillation of the Spirit and Oyl, put it into an open Fire, and leave it there for one or two hours, or till it becomes mo≈øt pure and white, which is the ≈øign of its perfect calcination.

¬ß 3. This is the thing intended by our Author, but Charras thinks when it is thus calcin'd, it has but all its chief and e≈ø≈øential vertues, at lea≈øt, its volatile Properties; yet in my opinion it has that left which an≈øwer the intention of the Medicine.

¬ß 4. Le Febure is al≈øo for the Philo≈øophick Calcination,
becau≈øe, ≈øays he, by the former way it is deprived of its Spirit and volatile Salt, whereas by this way its Vertue is pre≈øerved; and it is thus done:

¬ß 5. ‚Ñû Choice Harts-horn ≈øaw it in pieces of the length of a Pan about the ends, then putting two ≈øticks cro≈øs-ways, towards the top of ≈øuch a Gla≈øs Body as u≈øually ≈øerves for di≈øtillation of Spirits and Waters, there ≈øu≈øpend with a Packthread the cut pieces of the Horn aforementioned, when you are to di≈øtil any Cordial-waters, or rather Spirits, which ≈øend forth mo≈øt penetrative and ≈øubtil Vapours; cover the Gla≈øs Body with an Alembick, and give the ≈øame degree of Fire, as for the di≈øtillation of Aqua Vitae, ≈øo ≈øhall the≈øe Vapours penetrate into the very Center of the Harts-horn, and make it ≈øo brittle, as that it may be reduced into as fine a Pouder as if calcin'd with open fire.

¬ß 6. But this Work of Di≈øtillation mu≈øt be pro≈øecuted 4 or 5 days without intermi≈ø≈øion or opening the Ve≈ø≈øel, for which rea≈øon the Gla≈øs Ve≈ø≈øel mu≈øt have a hole towards the upper part, placed ≈øide-wi≈øe, whereby to recruit it with warm Water, proportionably as it dimini≈øhes by di≈øtillation.
¬ß 7. But in this Work you mu≈øt take care that the Liquor touches not the ≈øu≈øpended Horns, nor yet come near them by at lea≈øt half a foot.

¬ß 8. If it be objected, that the Vapors may carry along with them the mo≈øt ≈øubtile Spirits and volatile Salt, it is an≈øwered, That ≈øome part of the Spirits may po≈ø≈øibly be lo≈øt, but the volatile Salt is held in too ≈øtrong a Pri≈øon, to be with ≈øo ea≈øie a force and heat ≈øet at liberty, not being yet di≈øunited with its oily and earthy Particles.

¬ß 9. And therefore if this Preparation be u≈øed to make this Animal Bezoar with, it will be yet more powerful to the Purpo≈øes intended, both to provoke Sweat, and to ≈øtrengthen, as al≈øo to give to Children again≈øt the Worms, and hinder all tho≈øe Corruptions which breed for the mo≈øt part in their tender Stomachs.

¬ß 10. It is good al≈øo again≈øt all manner of malign and pe≈øtilential Di≈øea≈øes, the Spotted Fever, Calenture, yea, and the Plague it ≈øelf; Do≈øe √† gr. iv. ad ‚Ñàj. in ≈øome proper Vehicle, Con≈øerve, Pre≈øerve, Electuary, Bolus, „Äà‚óä„Äâ Cordial and Antipe≈øtilential Water.

¬ß 11. There is another Bezoarticum Animale, made of the Fle≈øh of Serpents, or rather Vipers, the Preparation of which ≈øee in our Pharmac. Lond. lib. 2. cap. 5. ≈øect. 23. ¬ß 6. which has all the Vertues before mentioned, be≈øides which, it is an Antidote again≈øt Poy≈øonings of Mad Dogs, Serpents, or other venomous Bea≈øts, French Pox, and Lepro≈øie, and a Cure for Con≈øumptions. Do≈øe ad í j.

div.head: XXX. * Bezoarticum Joviale; The Bezoartick of Tin.
div.p:
Bate.] ‚Ñû Regulus of Antimony ‚Ñ•iij. which melt in a Crucible to which add Engli≈øh block Tin ‚Ñ•ij. in like manner ‚Ä¢ elted, ≈øo as thereof to make a ‚Ä¢ ew Regulus; this Regulus ‚Ä¢ eat into fine Pouder, or levigate, and mix therewith Mer
‚Ä¢ ury ≈øublimate ‚Ñ•vj. di≈øtil by a Retort, ≈øo will you have a Butter, which fix with Spirit ‚Ä¢ f Nitre by a threefold di≈øtillation, afterwards calcine, and being red-hot, extingui≈øh it in ‚Ä¢ . V. and dry it, ≈øo will you ‚Ä¢ ave a grey pouder. It is a ‚Ä¢ upendious Diaphoretick, and ‚Ä¢ revails again≈øt all Di≈øea≈øes ‚Ä¢ f the Womb, and many ‚Ä¢ ther Di≈øea≈øes of Women
‚Ä¢ ind: It prevails al≈øo again≈øt Fevers, Plague, Scurvy, &c. Do≈øe √† gr. iij. ad vj.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is exactly the ≈øame with that in our Pharm. Lond. lib. 3. cap. 7. ≈øect. 13. excepting in the quantity of the Mercury, which there (to the ≈øame proportions) is but ‚Ñ•v.

¬ß 2. You may, according to Maets, either fir≈øt melt the Tin in a Crucible, and then pre≈øently put in the Regulus of Antimony in fine Pouder, and make them flow together: Or the Regulus being in Pouder, may be put into a red-hot Crucible fir≈øt, and then the Tin in a lump may be added, which in a moment will flow with the Regulus, which being poured out into a fu≈øory Cone, or other clean Crucible, you will have the Regulus of Jupiter, in a hard and white Ma≈øs, but brittle.

¬ß 3. Rolfincius, in Art. Chym. lib. 5. ≈øect. 6. cap. 10. makes it thus: ‚Ñû Engli≈øh Tin, Mercury Sublimate, A. lb ≈øs. mix, and di≈øtil by Retort a Butter or Gummy Liquor, upon which put Spirit of Nitre, q. s. which the Ebulition cea≈øing, draw off by an Alembick with a trebble di≈øtillation; the pouder remaining calcine in a Crucible, till it becomes a white Pouder.

¬ß 4. In this Recipe the Regulus of Antimony is forgotten, which whether it was the Author's or Printer's fault I cannot tell, but po≈ø≈øibly it might be the Printer's; however, without the Regulus of Antimony the Medicine cannot be made.

¬ß 5. It is diaphoretick, u≈øed chiefly in Di≈øea≈øes of the Womb, and to expel noxious and ≈øerous Humors there, as al≈øo to comfort the part. It is given ad gr. vj. and in ≈øome ca≈øes to viij. or x. in ≈øome proper Water, or Syrup of Mugwort.

¬ß 6. Tilingius makes it with ≈øimple Regulus of Antimony ‚Ñ•vj. Engli≈øh Tin ‚Ñ•iv. which he amalgamates, and reduces it into a ≈øubtil Pouder, and adds thereto of the be≈øt Sublimate Mercury ‚Ñ•x. and then by Retort di≈øtils a Butter, which with Spirit of Nitre he fixes by a threefold di≈øtillation, then calcines, extingui≈øhes in S. V. and dries.

¬ß 7. This (he ≈øays) is a potent Sudorifick, and a kind of Univer≈øal De-ob≈øtructor of the Liver, the Do≈øe being but from gr. j. ad ij. but I am confident he has under-do≈øed it. I have many times given it to gr. vj. vij. or viij. according to the di≈øpo≈øition of my Patient.

¬ß 8. Beguinus makes it exactly after the ≈øame manner as our Author here pre≈øcribes, but differs in the proportion of the corro≈øive Sublimate, which is double to the joynt-quantity of the Regulus and Tin; ≈øo that if the Regulus be ‚Ñ•iij. the Tin ‚Ñ•ij. the Sublimate is ‚Ñ•x. &c. And with him agrees Grulingius.

¬ß 9. Zwel≈øer, Manti≈ø≈ø. Spagyr. par. 1. cap. 5. makes it thus: ‚Ñû Tin finely filed ‚Ñ•iv. Corro≈øive Sublimate ‚Ñ•ij. mix them exactly, put them i ‚Ä¢ to a Gla≈øs Retort, and di≈øtil i ‚Ä¢ Sand by degrees of Fire, ≈øo will you have a Buttery Substance, like Butter of Antimony, which di≈ø≈øolve in the be≈øt Spiritu ‚Ä¢ Nitri, q. s. dropping it in Guttatim, till the noi≈øe and ebulition cea≈øes; this done, ab≈øtract in an Alembick to dryne≈øs, leaving a white Ma≈øs, which grind on a Porphory, and put it again into the Gla≈øs Cucurbit, affu≈øing thereon fre≈øh Spirit of Nitre, and di≈øtil again to dryne≈øs, encrea≈øing the Fire at length to the highe≈øt degree, that the bottom of the Ve≈ø≈øel may be red-hot; la≈øtly, take the Ma≈øs at bottom, grind it a afore≈øaid, edulcorate by wa≈øhing with Water, and calcine it i ‚Ä¢ a Crucible for an hour or t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ with a red-hot heat, and keepi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ for u≈øe.
¬ß 10. It is a Specifick in Hy≈øterick Fits, or Suffocation of the Womb, and cures burning Feavers by Sweating. Do≈øe gr. vj. ad x. & xij. in ≈øome proper Liquor.

¬ß 11. We ≈øhall give you Charras's way of making it, and ≈øo conclude this Section. ‚Ñû Regulus of Antimony ‚Ñ•iij. Pure Tin ‚Ñ•ij. melt them in a Crucible, and ca≈øt them in an Iron Cone grea≈øed within, beat this into fine Pouder, and mix it with double its weight of corro≈øive Sublimate; put all into a Gla≈øs Retort coated, and draw off as well the Butter as the Mercury, and precipitate with fair Water, which Precipitate wa≈øh and edulcorate, after which you may, if you plea≈øe, keep ≈øome part of the Pouder for u≈øe, to purge gently upwards and downwards in Hy≈øterick Di≈øea≈øes, giving it from gr. ij. ad v. in ≈øome proper Con≈øerve or Confection.

¬ß 12. But to compleat the Bezoartick of Jupiter, weigh the remaining pouder, put it into a ≈ømall Gla≈øs Cucurbit, and affu≈øe thereon be≈øt Spirit of Nitre, three times its weight, and in a Sand-heat, over a moderate fire, evaporate the Spirit of Nitre to dryne≈øs, which pouder edulcorate by many wa≈øhings, dry it, and keep it in a Gla≈øs well ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 13. This Jovial Bezoartick is one of the be≈øt Preparations that can be made of Tin, for it is not only a Specifick again≈øt all Di≈øea≈øes of the Womb, but a famous Sudorifick in all malignant, pe≈øtilential, and venereal Di≈øtempers, where the malignity is to be ca≈øt out by Sweat. Do≈øe √† gr. vj. ad ‚Ñàj.

div.head: XXXI. Bezoarticum Lunare' The Lunar Bezoar, or Silver Bezoartick.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of Luna di≈ø≈øolved in Spirit of Nitre and Butter of Antimony proceeding as above with the Jovial Bezoar. It is a Specifick in the Epilep≈øie, Convul≈øions, Megrim, Apoplexia, &c. it is anodyn and ≈øudorifick, and prevails admirably in the cure of an Ery≈øipelas. Do≈øe √† gr. vj. ad xij.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Zwelfer, Manti≈ø. Spagyr. par. 1. cap. 2. makes it thus. ‚Ñû Fine Silver, or in Leaves, ‚Ñ•j. Spirit of Nitre q. s. mix and di≈ø≈øolve. Again, ‚Ñû Butter of Antimony rectified from its Cinnaber, ‚Ñ•ij. or iij. Spirit of Nitre q. s. mix and di≈ø≈øolve, putting on the Sp. Nitri on the Butter gutatim, ≈øo long till all the
efferve≈øcence and noi≈øe cea≈øes, which is the ≈øign of a perfect di≈ø≈øolution; the≈øe two ≈øolutions joyn together, and ab≈øtract by di≈øtilling in a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, in a ≈øand-heat, to a dryne≈øs, ≈øo will you have a greeni≈øh white ma≈øs: To this Re≈øidence put again fre≈øh Spirit of Nitre, and ab≈øtract, repeating this three or four times, at the la≈øt time augment the fire to the highe≈øt degree, that all the corro≈øive Spirits may be forced away, then beating the ma≈øs into a ≈øubtile pouder, wa≈øh and edulcorate with fair warm Water, till it is perfectly freed from the Acrimony of the Spirits of Nitre, after which put it into a Crucible in a naked fire, calcine it for two hours, and keep it for u≈øe. Where note, that every time after the ab≈øtraction of the Sp. Nitri, you are to grind it on a Porphyry, before the affu≈øion of new or fre≈øh Spirit.

¬ß 2. This (≈øays he) prevails again≈øt all Lunar Di≈øea≈øes, viz. Di≈øea≈øes of the Head and Brain, and the Epilep≈øie, Apoplexy, Pal≈øie, Melancholy and Madne≈øs: It is al≈øo a mo≈øt powerful Alexipharmick, or Re≈øi≈øter of Poy≈øon. Do≈øe ‚Ñàj ad í ≈øs.

¬ß 3. In our Pharm. Lond. lib. 3. cap. 7. ≈øect. 18. we have given you ≈øeveral other ways of making this Lunar Bezoartick, which are taken from Schroder, and therefore ≈øhall not be here again repeated. But here is to be noted, that in the third of tho≈øe ways, Hofman, in≈øtead of that Sky-colour'd Tincture there mentioned, takes the Magi≈øtery of Silver, which with the Butter of Antimony he di≈ø≈øolves apart, not in AF. as Schroder pre≈øcribes, but in Spirit of Nitre, then joyns the ≈øolutions, and perfects the Medicine according to the Pre≈øcript. Now here is to be noted, that this Magi≈øtery may be made from the Tinctura Lunae, by the affu≈øion of Oleum Tartari per deliquium, &c.

¬ß 4. Grulingius Florileg. par. 8. cap. 3. makes it thus. ‚Ñû Luna, di≈ø≈øolve it in Spirit of Nitre, ≈øo as the weight thereof may be well augmented, and reduce it by dige≈øtion into a vi≈øcid Water, to one part of which put ten parts of the Gummy Liquor (i. e. Butter of Antimony) well rectified and liquified, and upon this mixture the Spirit of Nitre; which ab≈øtract from it two or three times, giving towards the end agreat fire; after which calcine it in a Crucible for an hour and a half, then pouder it finely, and burn from it S.V.

¬ß 5. Rolfincius, Art. Chym lib. 5. ≈øect. 6. cap. 8. prepares it as Zwelfer afore≈øaid, in all re≈øpects, excepting the triple affu≈øion and ab≈øtraction of the Sp. Nitri, but after all, di≈ølikes it; fir≈øt, becau≈øe of the ingrateful Vitriolick ta≈øte, from which it cannot be freed, cau≈øing nau≈øeating and vomiting: Secondly, becau≈øe of its colour, appearing blacki≈øh in ≈øuperficie, (though inwardly in it ≈øelf white) which is not to be mended. Therefore he prefers it to be made of the Magi≈øtery of Luna (of which opinion Hofman is, as aforementioned) perfectly freed from its corro≈øive Salts.

¬ß 6. This Magi≈øtery he thus makes: ‚Ñû Leaf-≈øilver ‚Ñ•j. AF. ‚Ñ•iij. mix and di≈ø≈øolve, precipitate with Oleum Tartari per deliquium, affu≈øed gutatim, in a large quantity, that all the corro≈øive Salts may be ab≈øorbed and the Water may come forth ≈øweet; the pouder edulcorate with many affu≈øions and lotions of warm Water.

¬ß 7. Tilingius. Prod. Chym. Cla≈ø≈ø. 3. Tit. 2. has it word for word from Zwelfer, but without ≈øo much as naming his Author. From all the≈øe De≈øcriptions the proportions of the Ingredients, and the method of preparing it, is manife≈øt; but that without doubt is be≈øt, which makes the Di≈ø≈øolution the mo≈øt perfect, and frees the Bezoartick the mo≈øt ab≈øolutely from the Salts

¬ß 8. As to its Vertues, Zwelfer has been large and plain, and 'tis doubtle≈øs a famous Cephalick. div.head: XXXIII, * Bezoarticum Minerale; The Mineral Bezoar.
div.p:
Bate. It is made of the Butter of Antimony lb j. and Spirit of Nitre lb iij. vel q. s ('tis Spirit of Salt in the Latin Copy, I ≈øuppo≈øe that is a Mi≈øtake) mixt and di≈øtilled by a treble cohobation, as in the Jovial Bezoar. Or it may be prepared from the Caput Mortuum of the Bezoardick Spirit of Nitre. It is a great Alexiterick, or Re≈øi≈øter of Poy≈øon. and a mo≈øt ≈øaluberrious Remedy, which Effects it demon≈øtrates by powerfully
provoking Sweat in all pe≈øtilential, and venene or malign Di≈øaffections. Do≈øe √† gr. vj. ad xij. and more.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Colleges way and method of preparing this Medicine, with ≈øeveral Notes and Animadver≈øions thereon, you may ≈øee in our Pharm. Lond. lib, 3. cap. 7. ≈øect. 11. to which we refer you: What other Authors ≈øay upon the matter, we now come to examine.

¬ß 2. Rolfincius, lib. 5. ≈øect. 6. cap. 6. Art. Chym. makes it of the Butter of Antimony, with Spirit of Nitre, a ≈øufficient quantity, (but not limiting the proportion) which he di≈øtills Guttatim, till the Ebulition cea≈øes, then di≈øtils by an Alembick with a treble cohobation, then calcines it for 6 hours in a Crucible, till it becomes a Chalk like pouder, and ≈øometimes of a ≈øubincarnate colour.

¬ß 3. What the Bezoardick Spirit of Nitre is, you ≈øhall have from Marggrave, viz. That it is that Spirit with which the Bezoar Mineral was prepared, or which was thrice ab≈øtracted from it: Hic dicitur Bezoardicus, non qu√≤d vim Bezoardicam contineat, ≈øed quia √† Bezoardico minerali aliquoties abstractus e≈øt.

¬ß 4. Le Mort makes it thus: ‚Ñû Butter of Antimony q. v. put upon it Spirit of Nitre q. s. till the noi≈øe or efferve≈øcence cea≈øes; this mixture evaporate, or ab≈øtract by Retort to dryne≈øs, then put into a Crucible, and calcine it, fir≈øt with a gentle fire, till the pouder appears of a Citrine colour, after augment the fire, till the Crucible and that within it is red-hot, then let it cool, and keep the white pouder for u≈øe.

¬ß 5. The efferve≈øcency is cau≈øed from the occur≈øe of the greater and le≈ø≈øer Acid, viz. from the concentrated Spirit of Salt, and common Spirit of Nitre, concurring with the Antimonial Particles, which the Spirits of Vitriol and Salt were neither ≈øtrong enough, nor in quantity enough to make an entire Solution of, but only gnawed them into ≈ømaller bits, with a light adhe≈øion; but tho≈øe Spirits of Vitriol and Salt being once concentrated with the Spirit of Nitre, they act with much more force, dividing every Particle, and rendering them almo≈øt imperceptible, and uncapable of receiving a more perfect di≈ø≈øolution.

¬ß 6. Now, by rea≈øon of the great efferve≈øcency the Sp. Nitri ought to be put in Guttatim, for fear the matter ≈øhould ri≈øe or ≈øwell above the Ve≈ø≈øel; and this efferve≈øcency proceeds in part from the re≈øi≈øtance which the points of the Sp. Nitri meet with, entering into the narrow Pores of the Antimonial Particles, in order to their di≈ø≈øolution, for as ≈øoon as that is performed, the ebulition and noi≈øe cea≈øes.

¬ß 7. How the Butter of Antimony (which was a vehement Cau≈øtick, from the acid Spirits with which it was fill'd) ≈øhould by means of another acid Corro≈øive, (≈øuch as is Spirit of Nitre) ≈øuffer ≈øuch an exceeding change, and become one of the ≈øweete≈øt and milde≈øt Medicines that is; or how Spirit of Nitre ≈øhould be able to ≈øweeten ≈øuch a corro≈øive matter, is difficult to conceive.

¬ß 8. This Doubt receives a twofold Solution; fir≈øt, that as Acids and Alcalies are Oppo≈øites, and de≈øtroy one another, ≈øo al≈øo in the Acid kingdom there are oppo≈øite Acids, which have like effects, by mixing one with another, the points of the one entering into the ≈øheaths of the other. Secondly, That as the fir≈øt Acids did but adhere ≈øuperficially to the Antimony in its Butter, and adapted to the motion of the Antimonial Particles, which ≈øerved them as a Vehicle, to di≈øplay their points, ≈øo being di≈ø≈øolved by the Spirit of Nitre, they jointly fix the Antimony, and de≈øtroy its motive quality, and ≈øheath them≈øelves in the ≈øulphurous parts thereof, whereby they lo≈øe all their corro≈øion.

¬ß 9. The ab≈øtracted Liquor called Bezoardick Spirit of Nitre, (ut ≈øupr√†) is nothing el≈øe but an Aqua Regia from the conjunction of the Spirit of Common Salt with the Nitrous Spirit; for which rea≈øon it di≈ø≈øolves Gold, and will do all other things which Aq. Regis can. In ab≈øtracting this Liquor, much of the Sulphurs which were in the Butter of Antimony are lo≈øt.

¬ß 10. I know Authors require a reiteration of the Spirit of Nitre, but this ≈øays Le Mort (Chymic. Medico phy≈øica, pag. 238.) is needle≈øs, for that the fluid Salts require no more thereof to make them let go their Pouder, and then by con≈øequence this Work has no more need of Correction.

¬ß 11. This ≈øame Le Mort in the place cited, has another Bezoardicum Minerale, made without Sublimate, after this manner: ‚Ñû Regulus of Antimony in pouder ‚Ñ•j. Spirit of Salt prepared with Oyl of Vitriol ‚Ñ•iij. mix them as before; dige≈øt them in a Sand for two days, till the Regulus is di≈ø≈øolved; decant the clear Liquor, (which will be as limpid as it was before the affu≈øion) and evaporate the one half of it away by a gentle fire, then affu≈øe Guttatim Spirit of Nitre, and proceed as before, &c.

¬ß 12. Or thus, from the ≈øame Le Mort. ‚Ñû Regulus of Antimony freed from its Scoria ‚Ñ•j. Aq. Regia ‚Ñ•iij. mix them together, and dige≈øt them for two days, till all the Regulus is brought to a very white pouder, upon this put a great quantity of fair Water, ≈øo will the white pouder precipitate, which edulcorate by many wa≈øhings. Both this and the la≈øt are egregious Sudorificks, and Bezoardicks, curing all Di≈øea≈øes that are to be cured by Sweat, and in particular they re≈øi≈øt Plague and Poy≈øon. Do≈øe √† gr. iv. ad xij.

¬ß 13. Lemery makes it thus: ‚Ñû Butter of Antimony ‚Ñ•ij. put it into a Bolthead and melt it, put to it guttatim Spirit of Nitre, ≈øo much till the Butter is perfectly di≈ø≈øolved, which will be about the weight of the Butter) in the di≈ø≈øolution fumes will ari≈øe, which to avoid place the Ve≈ø≈øel in a Chimney; decant the Solution into another Gla≈øs Body or Earthen Di≈øh, and evaporate in a gentle ≈øand-heat to dryne≈øs; the white ma≈øs being cooled, affu≈øe thereon fre≈øh Spirit of Nitre ‚Ñ•ij. and evaporate in Sand as before to dryne≈øs; again affu≈øe fre≈øh Spirit of Nitre ‚Ñ•ij. and evaporate again, and encrea≈øing the fire a little, calcine the matter for half an hours time, then take it from the fire, ≈øo will you have a white pouder, (which is Bezoar Minerale) this keep in a Vial clo≈øe ≈øtopt. Do≈øe √† gr. vj. ad ‚Ñàj.

¬ß 14. This Preparation is only an Antimony fix'd by Spirit of Nitre, and render'd ≈øudorifick; or ≈øo many Transformations of the Regulus, made by acid Spirits, or by Fire; ≈øo that by fu≈øion, or by means of ≈øome reductive Salt, they may be recovered into a Regulus again, by de≈øtroying tho≈øe Salts which kept them under this form.

¬ß 15. Zwelfer, Manti≈ø≈ø. Spagyr. par. 2. cap. 8. p. 837. makes it in all re≈øpects as Lemery, but orders the dryed ma≈øs to be ground each time upon a Porphyry, into a ≈øubtile
pouder, before the affu≈øion of fre≈øh Spirit of Nitre, and then calcines it (after the third affu≈øion of Spirit) for an hour or two, and ≈øo keeps it without any other Preparation.

¬ß 16. Charras makes it of Mercurius Vitae, after this manner: ‚Ñû Mercurius Vitae ‚Ñ•j. Spirit of Nitre ‚Ñ•iij. put them into a ≈ømall Gla≈øs Cucurbit, on a ≈øand-heat, which ≈øtir with a wooden Spatula ≈øteeped well in the Spirit; evaporate all the humidity to dryne≈øs, then wa≈øh and perfectly dulcifie it, keeping the white pouder in a Gla≈øs Bottle well stopt.

¬ß 17. This Bezoar, ≈øays he, is given to good purpo≈øe in all Di≈øea≈øes where the Bezoar-≈øtone is u≈øed: It ≈øtrengthens very much all the noble parts, and defends them again≈øt Malignity and Poi≈øon. It purifies the ma≈øs of Blood, and drives from thence, as well as out of the whole habit of the Body, all tho≈øe ≈øharp Sero≈øities which offend Nature, and are to be expelled through the Pores of the Body, driving them forth either by Sweat or in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration.

¬ß 18. For which rea≈øon it is very highly commended again≈øt all Di≈øea≈øes proceeding from corruption or depravation of the Blood and Juices, chiefly the Scurvy, Cachexia Small Pox, Mea≈øles, Plague, Spotted Fever, and all ≈øorts of malign and pe≈øtilential Di≈øtempers.

¬ß 19. By rea≈øon of the weight thereof it is ≈øeldom given in Liquors, becau≈øe it is apt to de≈øcend, unle≈øs in ≈øome thick Syrup, but for the mo≈øt part in a Bolus or other proper Electuary or Con≈øerve, √† gr. viij. ad xx. or xxx.. It is al≈øo ≈øometimes mixed with Catharticks and Aperitives, to fortifie the noble parts during their operation.

¬ß 20. Le Mort prepares it al≈øo at once, by affu≈øing a triple quantity of Spirit of Nitre at fir≈øt, then evaporating and calcining as before taught; affirming (as afore≈øaid) that there is no need of a triple affu≈øion or repetition of the Spirit of Nitre, as mo≈øt Authors require, becau≈øe, ≈øays he, all the Bodies are ≈øaturated with the Acid, ≈øo as they can no more be changed or altered.
¬ß 21. He al≈øo prepares it from Flowers of Antimony, di≈ø≈øolving them with Aqua Regis, as before with the Regulus, at ¬ß 11 & 12 aforegoing, and calcining, &c.

¬ß 22. Marggrave makes it exactly after Zwelfer's method, with a double or treble cohobation, and gives it √† gr. v. ad xv. vel xx after this manner, ‚Ñû Bezoar Mineral, Saffron, A. gr. viij. Salts of Wormwood and Carduus, A. gr. xij. Crabs-Eyes and Coral prepared, A. gr. v. Laudanum Opiatum gr. i≈øs. Confectio de Hyacintho, or Dia≈øcordium, q. s. mix, and make a Bolus.

¬ß 23. Le Febure puts the Antimonial Butter into a large Matra≈øs, affu≈øing guttatim its equal weight of good Spirit of Nitre; the Liquor being defecated and clear, he decants it into a Cucurbit in a ≈øand-heat, and evaporates to dryne≈øs, repeating twice again the ≈øame quantity of Spirit of Nitre, evaporating it the third time, till the ma≈øs becomes fair, white, dry, brittle and in≈øipid, which is the Bezoar Mineral.

¬ß 24. In this (≈øays he) ≈øhould there remain yet any plea≈øant ≈øharpne≈øs, can be no prejudice, wherefore it will be needle≈øs to urge the Fire higher, but contrariwi≈øe to take off the Ve≈ø≈øel, and let the matter cool, and taking the Pouder at bottom, to keep it in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 25. The Epithite Minerale is added, to difference it from the Stone Bezoar and the Animal, for that the vertues of tho≈øe is not only attributed to it, but it every way exceeds them in vertue and goodne≈øs, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing many other e≈ø≈øential Properties. that they have not, by rea≈øon of the Solar Sulphur that is in it, the efficacy whereof is not to be exhau≈øted.

¬ß 26. For this rare Medicine does potently expel by Sweat and Urine, but chiefly by in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration, all the hurtful and poy≈øonous Humors lurking in the Bodies both of healthy and unhealthy per≈øons, e≈øpecially in all tho≈øe malign and pe≈øtilential Di≈øea≈øes where Sweating is ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary.

¬ß 27. And this I can affirm from a Thirty years continued Experience, That who≈øoever makes u≈øe of it in all the afore-named ca≈øes, ≈øhall never find him≈øelf deceiv'd, nor di≈øappointed of the help (≈øooner or later) which he expected: I, who have for ≈øo many years tryed, can tell more e≈øpecially where malignant Sero≈øities have abounded, as in the Scurvy, Cachexies, Scabs, Itch, French Pox, &c.

¬ß 28. Who con≈øtantly u≈øes it, ought al≈øo to have a Dyet of Veal and Chicken-Broth,
with Scorzonea and Sar≈øaparilla in it, and to keep their Bodies ≈øoluble, by adding every third day to the Broths ‚Ñàj. or í ≈øs. of Salt of Tartar of Sennertus, or otherwi≈øe with proper Cly≈øters.

¬ß 29. And as this Remedy is in kind univer≈øal, ≈øo it may be ≈øpecificated and appropriated to ≈øome particular parts, by adding any of the Metals, as Sol, Luna, Venus Jupiter, the eighth part of any of which may be added to the Regulus of Antimony, with three times as much corro≈øive Sublimate, and then di≈øtilled into a Butter, to be fixt with Spirit of Nitre, as before directed, in making the ≈øimple Bezoar Minerale.

¬ß 30. Moebius makes it of Mercurius Vitae, as Charras does, afore-declared. Hofman exactly follows Zwelfer, with a gentle calcination at la≈øt for an hour. Beguinus is exactly the ≈øame with Lemery, ≈øave that in the ≈øecond and third affu≈øions of Spirit of Nitre, he u≈øes but half the fir≈øt quantity of the Spirit.

¬ß 31. From all that has been ≈øaid, it appears with Le Mort, that a ≈øingle affu≈øion of Spirit of Nitre is ≈øufficient, becau≈øe what is after added is nugatory and void, as having no operation: Of which Opinion al≈øo is Bla≈øius, the Commentator upon Beguinus; and al≈øo with Le Febure, that a ≈øimple drying of the Calx, without calcination or wa≈øhing, ≈øuffices to bring the Medicine to the perfection de≈øired, and indeed leaves it more efficacious than it would be otherwi≈øe with it.

¬ß 32. Hic notandum quod Bezoarticum hoc minerale longe antecellat Bezoar Animalis, ≈øicut id expre≈ø≈øe fatetur Dn. Crato in Epi≈øtola medicinali dum inquit; Lapis Bezoar Animalis in febribus pe≈øtilentialibus nobis nihil profuit, quod ≈øane de hoc minim√® pronunciandum.

div.p:
Bate.] It is made by drawing forth the Tincture from

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Our Author here u≈øes Copper, but Schroder does it with Scales of Bra≈øs; which Preparation has a Power (be≈øides the Vertues before a≈øcribed by our Author) to cure the French Di≈øea≈øe, virulent Gonorrhoeas, Exulcerations of the Reins and Genital Parts, with other like Di≈øea≈øes, for which it is an egregious Medicament, as Hofman affirms.

div.head: XXXVIII. Calx Lunae; Calx of Silver.
div.p: Bate.] It is made by di≈ø≈øolving Lunae in A. F. and precipitating it with ≈øalt Water. Or, by amalgamating it with an equal quantity of Mercury, with the addition of a fourth part of Salt. Or, by cementing it with Tartar Vitriolatum, or Sal Gem, or Sulphur, &c. Or, by reverberating it for 8 days with Salt, Sulphur, Sal Armoniack, &c. S. A. It is profitable again≈øt Hy≈øterick Fits, Epilep≈øies, Apoplexies, &c. Do≈øe ad gr. x.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Here is to be noted, that your Silver ought to be fine Silver, and totally freed from any mixture of Copper with it, for otherwi≈øe being u≈øed phy≈øically, it will cau≈øe vomiting.

¬ß 2. The fir≈øt way by A. F. from Thibaut: ‚Ñû A little Matra≈ø. with a ≈øtrait long Neck, put into it A. F. ‚Ñ•ij. Leaf-≈øilver ‚Ñ•j. ≈øet it upon a round, covered with ≈ø ‚Ä¢ nd in a
little Wheel-fire Fornace, giving a ≈ømall Fire to help the di≈ø≈øolution of the Silver, and to con≈øume the Di≈ø≈øolvant, ≈ø ‚Ä¢ as after a gentle boiling, your Matter may dry and change in to a black skum, not unlike a Pumice-≈øtone then encrea≈øe your Fire to melt this skum half petrified, and continue your Fire till the boiling cea≈øe, and that there ari≈øe no more Vapours, then take it off the Fire and let it cool ≈øo will the matter be reduced to a white pouder, which is the Calx of Luna.

Now here is to be noted; that if to this Calx of Silver you give a violent fire, and a ‚Ä¢ d to it half a ≈øpoonful of B ‚Ä¢ rax, it will return again to i ‚Ä¢ s fir≈øt m ‚Ä¢ tallick nature, and be Silver again in form‚ñ™ hardne≈øs, and con≈øi≈øtency, becau≈øe the violence of the Fire and Borax will carry away the lea≈øt Particle of the A. F. which kept the Silver in the form of a Calx.

F. ‚Ñ•iij. mix, and put them for a night in dige≈øtion‚ñ™ till the Silver is wholly di≈ø≈øolved, (unle≈øs by chance any Gold be mixt with it‚ñ™ which will not di≈ø≈øolve, but fall to the bottom:) the Solution evaporate te dryne≈øs, or if you would ≈øave the A. ¬ß 5. Where note, that if the Luna be pure from any mixture of Venus, the Solution will be white; but if any Allay of Copper be in it, it will be green.
¬ß 6. This Calx ≈øerves for preparing the Tincture of Luna with, be≈øides the other Vertues a≈øcribed to it by our Author.

¬ß 7. Schroder ≈øays, That being di≈ø≈øolved in A. F. or Sp. Nitri, the Calx may be made by precipitation with Salt-brine, Salt-water, or a piece of Bra≈øs or Copper ca≈øt in, the Water being put in to a three, four, or ≈øixfold quantity.

¬ß 8. Le Febur takes fine or cupulated Silver ‚Ñ•j. A. F. ‚Ñ•iij. or as much good Spirit of Nitre, di≈ø≈øolves in a gentle heat in Sand or A≈øhes, then precipitates with ≈øalt Water, edulcorates with fre≈øh Water, and dries it for u≈øe, which is Calx of Silver.

¬ß 9. Lemery and Charras al≈øo u≈øe a treble proportion of A. F. to the Luna, in di≈ø≈øolution, which is generally received by mo≈øt other Arti≈øts, Thibaut (who u≈øes but a double quantity) and Marggrave
(who u≈øes a ≈øixfold quantity) only excepted.

¬ß 10. The ≈øecond way is by Amalgamation with Quick-≈øilver. ‚Ñû Fine Leaf-≈øilver, Quick-≈øilver depurated, ana, mix and make an Amalgama, adding a fourth part of Common Salt, or Salt of Vitriol, then exhale the Mercury at the Fire, or bring it over the Helm and wa≈øh the remainder: Where note, that if a double quantity of Mercury be u≈øed, the Calx will yet be the better, or more ≈øubtile.

¬ß 11. The third way by Cementation. Be≈øides Tartar Vitriolate and Sal Gem, which our Author pre≈øcribes, it may be cemented with Precipitate and Sublimate Mercury, Common Salt, Crude Tartar, Vitriol, &c. thus: ‚Ñû Plates of Silver, or Leaf-≈øilver p. j. Mercury ≈øublimate p. ij. mix and exhale at the Fire, ≈øo will you have the Silver remaining like Ro≈øin, Sennert. In≈øtitut.

¬ß 12. But Hofman ≈øays it is better done thus: ‚Ñû Leaf-≈øilver, Corro≈øive Sublimate, Sal Armoniack, ana. ¬ß 14. It is al≈øo cemented with twice as much Sal Gem, or four times as much Common Salt, in 7 or 8 hours.

¬ß 15. Or thus: ‚Ñû Filings of Silver ‚Ñ•j. Flowers of Sulphur ‚Ñ•ij. Common ≈øalt ‚Ñ•≈øs. mix and ≈øublime ≈øeven times, as you make Flowers of Sulphur, ≈øtill adding to the Sublimate the remaining matter; ca≈øt away the Sublimate the la≈øt time, and wa≈øh the remaining Calx.

¬ß 16. But ≈øays Hofman, the calcination will be better done in this la≈øt if the Salt be omitted, and therefrom you may extract and egregious Tincture of Luna with Spirit of Lilly Convally, and urinous Spirit of Sal Armoniack, adding al≈øo a little Spirit of Vitriol.

¬ß 17. And thereof a Water of Luna may be thus made. ‚Ñû This Calx (calcin'd with Sulphur) and affu≈øe thereon ≈øome cephalick Water, Simple, or Compound, as of Ro≈øemary,

¬ß 20. The fourth and la≈øt way is by Reverberation: Now, becau≈øe Silver does more ea≈øily obey the Fire and Calcination than Gold, ≈øo it needs not a very tedious Work: Nor indeed ought it (as Hofman ≈øaith) be too much calcin'd, for thereby‚ñ™ in≈øtead of having a good and valuable Medicine, you will only have a vulgar and common one, apt to cau≈øe nau≈øeating and vomiting, from its Vitriolick Sapor.

div.head: XXXIX. Calx Jovis, Calx of Tin.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of Tin melted, and continually ≈øtirred with an Iron Rake, or ≈øome ≈øuch-like thing, till it is perfectly reduced into A≈øhes: Or, it may be prepared from Jupiter di≈ø≈øolved in A. Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Calx of Tin is made ≈øeveral ways, as by, 1. Incineration, according to our Author's method. 2. Reverberation, which is done by putting the former Calx into a Reverberatory, and continually ≈øtirring of it. 3. Vapor, which is hanging Plates of

Immer≈øion, which is done by dipping Plates of Tin into corro≈øive Liquors, as in Sp. of Lead, but u≈øually in Spirit of Vinegar: And from this Calx by Immer≈øion is made, fir≈øt, a Salt of Tin, ≈øecondly, a Magi≈øtery of Tin.

¬ß 2. Be≈øides what our Author has ≈øignified as to its Vertues for the ≈øuffocation of the Womb, which it is ≈øaid admirably to cure, this is certain, that outwardly it is good for all manner of old Sores, putrid Ulcers, weeping Fi≈øtulaes, Cancers, and other rebellious Di≈øea≈øes of like kind.

¬ß 4. ‚Ñû Calx of Tin ‚Ñ•j. Oyl of Hypericon q. s. mix and make an Ointment for old Ulcers. ‚Ñû Calx of Tin ‚Ñ•j. Bal≈øamum Lucatelli, Honey A. q. s. mix for a Bal≈øam, to cure Blindne≈øs, which it has done to a Miracle.

div.head: XL. * Ceru≈ø≈øa Antimonij; Ceru≈øe of Antimony.
div.p: Bate.] It is made out of the Regulus of Antimony in≈øtead of crude Antimony by burning, &c. S. A. It has the Vertues of Antimonium Diaphoreticum.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Regulus is to be calcin'd with a treble quantity of Cry≈øtals of Nitre, for half an hour or more, then ≈øw ‚Ä¢ eten, and take away the dro≈øs at bottom, dry it, and the pouder is called Ceru≈øe; then calcine it with Nitre, or reverberate it without, melting till it be yellow, ≈øo will it be diaphoretick.

¬ß 2. This, ≈øays Knuffelius, is the white Sulphur of the Philo≈øophers: And, ≈øaith Hofman, to one part of the Regulus you mu≈øt have 3 or 4 parts of the depurated Cry≈øtals of Nitre, otherwi≈øe you will have no Ceru≈øe.
