¬ß 5. If it be given for the purifying of the Blood, it ought to be taken continually for 30 days, or more; if for Wounds and Ulcers, it ought to be admini≈øtred with vulnerary Drinks and Decoctions, tho' in truth it much exceeds them all.

¬ß 6. Outwardly it dries much, and is u≈øed in Co≈ømetick Waters, as of Bean-flowers, of Solomon's Seal, and ≈øuch-like, for taking away Deformities of the Face and Skin, which it renders very pure and clean; and it is mix'd with Co≈ømetick Ointments to heal Fi≈øtures, Chaps, and the like.

¬ß 7. It is (Univer≈øals being fir≈øt premi≈øed) thus u≈øed to ≈øtop a Gonorrhoea. ‚Ñû Ceru≈øe of Antimony ‚Ñàj. Roch Alum in fine pouder ‚Ñà≈øs. Catechu in fine pouder gr. 15. mix, and give it in Jelly of I≈øing-gla≈øs made in Milk for a Do≈øe, which repeat as long as need requires.

¬ß 8. The Do≈øe is √† gr. x. ad xxx, but ≈øome give it ad ‚Ñàij. yea, to í j. augmenting the Do≈øe gradually. Schroder ≈øaith it works diver≈øly; for in ≈øome the two or three ‚Ä¢ ir≈øt days it cau≈øes a loathing and ≈øpitting, at other times it works in≈øen≈øibly; in ≈øome it gently loo≈øens and in others it ≈øweats, and not but at the conclu≈øion perceived. It may be given at night going to Bed, or in the morning fa≈øting, but Schroder pre≈øcribes it four or 5 hours before Dinner.

¬ß 9. Charras makes it of the fir≈øt decanted Liquor of the Antimonium Diaphoreticum, according to Le Febur's method, precipitating it with Vinegar, very white, which he wa≈øhes and dries: Which, ≈øays he, fortifies Nature, and di≈øpo≈øes it to expel ill Humors by all ≈øorts of ways, but chiefly by Sweat, and in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration: It is proper to mortifie corro≈øive Salts, e≈øpecially Acids, and to prevent fermentation of the Humors, the Corruption whereof it al≈øo hinders clean≈øes the whole ma≈øs of Blood, and gives wonderful Rel ‚Ä¢ ef in ≈øcorbutick Maladies, if
its u≈øe be continued for ≈øome time.

¬ß 10. And though it may ≈øeem a≈øtringent, as well in regard of its ≈øub≈øtance, being altogether terre≈øtrial, as in re≈øpect to its operation, being di≈øabled from purging either upwards or downwards, yet being mixed with Catharticks or Openers, it then ≈øeems to a≈ø≈øume their Qualities and Operations, by a≈ø≈øi≈øting their activity, and therefore is often mixed with Aperients to open the Ob≈øtructions of the Bowels and Womb.

¬ß 11. Le Mort makes it thus: ‚Ñû Regulus of Antimony ‚Ñ•j. A. R. ‚Ñ•iij. dige≈øt them together till the efferve≈øcency cea≈øes, then dige≈øt again for one day, ≈øo the Regulus corroded will remain in the bottom, the A. R. ≈øupernating, which will be tinged of a yellow colour, decant the A. R. and edulcorate the ≈øub≈øiding pouder by many affu≈øions of fair Water, which dry upon Chalk, and keep for u≈øe.
¬ß 12. It is diaphoretick and ≈øudorifick, and emulates (≈øays he) the Vertues of Bezoar Minerale, the Do≈øe being from gr. iv. ad x. or xii.

¬ß 13. Ceru≈ø≈øa Antimonii ≈øolaris Schroderi, a Solar Ceru≈øe of Antimony: ‚Ñû Regulus of Antimony ‚Ñ•j. fine Gold í j. Sal Nitre ‚Ñ•iij. mix, calcine them without melting in a Crucible, ≈øo the Regulus will be a yellow Pouder, but the Sol will lo≈øe of its weight; edulcorate the pouder, and if you plea≈øe calcine again. It has the Vertues of the former, but is more cordial.

¬ß 14. The Ceru≈ø≈øa Solaris is al≈øo made by a calcination by the Sun-beams, thus: ‚Ñû Pouder of Antimony, or Regulus, or Flowers thereof, and concentrate the Beams of the Sun thereon by a Burninggla≈øs, ≈øo in a ≈øhort time will the Fumes a≈øcend from the Antimony, and it will turn white.

¬ß 15. Where note, 1. That the Flowers are ea≈øier to calcine than either the Crude Antimony or the Regulus. 2. That the weight of the Antimony is rather encrea≈øed after calcination than dimini≈øhed.

¬ß 16. This Preparation Schroder calls Magical; Bartholettus, in Meth. Med. Heavenly and Phy≈øical; and Poppius, in Ba≈øilic. Antimonii, pag. 21. commends the ≈øame; and Le Febur ≈øaith, That the Sun-beams does purifie and fix Antimony much better, and with much more efficacy than Nitre can po≈ø≈øibly
do; which, ≈øays he, is a kind of Calcination Philo≈øophical, and worthy indeed of a Son of Art, who de≈øires to ≈øearch into the Wonders of Art and Nature.

¬ß 17. Behold and contemplate the rare Effects of Magical and Coele≈øtial Fire, drawn from the Rays of the Sun by the help of a Burning or Refracting-Gla≈øs, which but few apprehend, and fewer yet believe what may be done and performed thereby.

¬ß 18. And whereas common Fire and Salts do alter and de≈øtroy the ≈øub≈øtance of Antimony, this noble and miraculous Fire pre≈øerves and encrea≈øes it; which Wonder will cea≈øe, as ≈øoon as you do but con≈øider, that this noble Mineral has a kind of natural Magnet in its ≈øelf, which makes it capable to attract from the Heaven it ≈øelf a noble and familiar Sub≈øtance which is Light and Fire, by which both its Sub≈øtance and Vertues are depurated, exalted, and augmented.

¬ß 19. ‚Ñû Antimony in fine pouder gr. xij. calcine it either by ≈øimple common Fire, or by Salts, and it yields a ≈ømoaky Vapor, unplea≈øant and heavy, (which being pre≈øerved in a ≈øublimatory, would be flowers of Antimony) and you will have a Calx of not above ≈øix or ≈øeven grains, which will have a purging and emetick quality.

¬ß 20. ‚Ñû Again, Antimony in fine pouder, gr, xij. and calcine it by the Sun-beams with a Burning-Gla≈øs, which may concentrate the Light and Beams of the Sun, ≈øo as to work upon the matter, then will the Mineral yield Vapors al≈øo, as when calcin'd in a common Fire; and one would think that it ≈øhould decrea≈øe in like manner in the ≈øame proportion, but it is otherwi≈øe, for the calcination being often reiterated, and the Antimony turned into a white Calx, you will find it to weigh gr. 15 in≈øtead of 12, which is eight or nine grains more than by the former Operation.

¬ß 21. And a thing more to be admired and le≈øs conceivable, is, that the≈øe fifteen grains of Solar Ceru≈øe are neither Emetick nor Cathartick, but contrariwi≈øe Diaphoretick, or Sudorifick, and Cordial; Do≈øe √† gr. iij, ad xij. in all the Di≈øea≈øes before enumerated; and we know that Experience has made it appear, that this Remedy is incomparably better, and much more excellent than the other Ceru≈øe prepared by
common Fire, or the Vulgar Diaphoretick. How this Operation is to be performed, we ≈øhall hereafter ≈øhew in our Officina Chymica, now in the Pre≈øs.

div.head: XLI. Ceru≈ø≈øa Martis; The Ceru≈øe of Mars or Iron.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of the Regulus of Mars, in all re≈øpects as in the Ceru≈øe of Antimony. It is al≈øo prepared with a ninefold quantity of Nitre. It is Diaphoretick, like the Ceru≈øe of Antimony.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It has all the Vertues of the Antimonial Ceru≈øe added to the nature of Mars; ≈øo that it is not only ≈øudorifick from its Antimonial Property, but it is al≈øo opening and ≈øtrengthening from its Martial; for which rea≈øon it is of good u≈øe to be given to ≈øuch as have been troubled with a Chloro≈øis, (Univer≈øals having been fir≈øt premi≈øed) for it confirms the healthful tone of the parts, and prevents the Sick for falling into the like Di≈øtemper again.

¬ß 2. Modus ∆≤tendi. ‚Ñû Ceru≈øe of Mars gr. xij. ad xx. Cochinele in fine pouder gr. vj. Saffron in fine pouder gr. iij. Mithridate ‚Ñàj. or. í ≈øs. mix for a ≈øweating do≈øe, to be given at Bed-time.
¬ß 3. ‚Ñû Ceru≈øe of Mars gr. xij. Salt of Harts-horn gr. vj. Laudanum Volatile nost. gr. ij. mix, for a do≈øe again≈øt the Bitings of mad Dogs, Serpents, and other venomous Creatures.

¬ß 4. ‚Ñû Ceru≈øe of Mars, gr. x. ad xx. Ro≈øin of Chio Turpentine ‚Ñàj. Roch-Alum in fine pouder gr. vj. mix for a Do≈øe, again≈øt the Whites in Women, and Gonorrhoea in Men, or a continual Gleet, to be given after due purging and taking away the malign cau≈øe with proper Antivenereals.

¬ß 5. Or thus: ‚Ñû Ceru≈øe of Mars, Ro≈øin of Chio Turpentine, A. ‚Ñàj. Catechu in fine pouder gr. xv. Roch-Alum in pouder, gr. iv. Volatile Laudanum gr. j. ad iij. Marmalade of Quinces q. s. mix, and make a Bolus, to be taken every night going to Bed, in the ca≈øes la≈øt mentioned, after due purging, as afore directed.

div.head: XLII. Chalcanthum Rubefactum; Rubified Vitriol.
div.p: Bate.] It is made by calcining the Vitriol to redne≈øs. It wonderfully a≈øtringes and dries, being good again≈øt Dy≈øenteries, Haemorrhagies, &c. In pulling out of Teeth (if a great flux of Blood ≈øhould happen) it is ≈øucce≈øsfully applied with Vinegar and Lint.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. You may take in place thereof the Caput Mortuum of the Oyl of Vitriol, which does the ≈øame thing; where note, that if it be for inward u≈øes, the Vitriol ought to be purified and clean≈øed by di≈ø≈øolution, filtration, evaporation, and cry≈øtallization, and then prepared according to Art.
¬ß 2. Modus ∆≤tendi. ‚Ñû Dia≈øcordium í ≈øs. Rubified Vitriol gr. xij. Catechu gr. viij. mix and make a Bolus, to be given Morning and Evening, drinking after the ≈øame a Gla≈øs of red Wine.
¬ß 3. Or thus: Mithridate í ≈øs. Rubified Vitriol, Bezoar Minerale, A. gr. xij. mix and make a Bolus, to be given as afore directed.

¬ß 4. ‚Ñû Rubified Vitriol, Red Coral levigated, Ana. mix them for a Dentifrice, to clean≈øe the Teeth; be≈øides which, it al≈øo ≈øtrengthens, nouri≈øhes, and re≈øtores the Gums. Note. Before the inward u≈øe of this Medicine, let Univer≈øals be premi≈øed.

div.head: XLIII. * Chalybs Sine Acido; Chalybs prepared without an Acid.
div.p: Bate.] It is prepared by moi≈øtening Mars ten times with Salt of Wormwood di≈ø≈øolved in Cichorf-water, and drying it again in a dry and warm Air; after which it is reduced into a ≈øubtile pouder. It powerfully opens Ob≈øtructions. Do≈øe ‚Ñàj. ad í ≈øs.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. In order for the more ea≈øie performance of this, you ought to take Filings of Iron, not Gades, &c. and Iron is better than Steel, becau≈øe not only its Body is more porous and open, but it al≈øo contains in it a larger proportion of Sulphur and Mercury.

¬ß 2. Whereas our Author pre≈øcribes the Reduction to be done with Salt of Wormwood, it may as well be done with Sal ‚Ä¢ of Tartar, or the
Salt of any other Vegetable, or in≈øtead of any of them, with Salt of Pot-a≈øhes, which may be di≈ø≈øolved in any other di≈øtilled Vegetable-Water, or in Rain-water or May-dew, &c.

¬ß 3. This Preparation is indeed only a Ru≈øt of Iron, contracted from the moi≈øture. Lemery makes it thus: ‚Ñû Filings of Iron, put them into a broad flat earthen Pan unglazed, and expo≈øe it to the Rain till it turns into a Pa≈øte, then ≈øet it to dry in the ≈øhade, and it will ru≈øt; pouder it, and expo≈øe it to Rain, as before, and ≈øo let it ru≈øt; pouder again and reiterate this Operation for 12 times, then reduce it into ≈øubtile pouder, and keep it for u≈øe.

¬ß 4. Or thus: ‚Ñû Thin Plates of Iron, wa≈øh them well, and expo≈øe them to the Dew for a good while, till they ru≈øt, which ≈øcrape off; put them again to receive the Dew, and gather the Ru≈øt as before; which Work continue till you have gotten ≈øo much as you de≈øire.

¬ß 5. This Preparation (≈øaith Lemery) is really better than all the Preparations of Iron, which are called Crocus, and is an excellent thing for opening of all Ob≈øtructions what≈øoever, but more e≈øpecially of the Liver, Spleen, Pancreas, and Me≈øentery.
¬ß 6. It is u≈øed very ≈øucce≈øsfully again≈øt the Green-≈øickne≈øs, to remove the ≈øtoppage of the Terms, cure Drop≈øies, Jaundice, and other Di≈øea≈øes which proceed from Oppilations.

¬ß 7. The Do≈øe √† gr. iv. or vj. ad ‚Ñàij. in a Bolus, Lozenges, or Pills: In a Bolus you may give it thus: ‚Ñû Lenitive Electuary í j. of this Crocus √† ‚Ñà≈øs. ad ‚Ñàj. mix and make a Bolus, to be given at night going to Bed, and to be continued for a month together, or as long as need ≈øhall require.

¬ß 8. This Preparation of the opening Crocus of Mars is out of the common Road, and much longer a doing than the re≈øt, but it is the be≈øt of all that ever were invented; the Dew is impregnated with a Di≈ø≈øolvent that very much opens the Pores of the Iron, and incorporating with it, renders it more active and ≈øoluble than it was before.

¬ß 9. This Medicine al≈øo opens Ob≈øtructions, by vertue of its Salt, which being a≈ø≈øi≈øted with the ≈øolid parts of the Metal, penetrates farther than other Salts can; but you ought alwaies to purge
and moi≈øten the Body you give it to with Broths, before you pre≈øume to give it, becau≈øe ≈øhould it find the Pa≈ø≈øages of the ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels filled and ob≈øtructed with gro≈øs Humors, it would „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ op and cau≈øe In ‚Ä¢ an ‚Ä¢ nations whence the Colick would be excited.

¬ß 10. How Iron performs its Operation many have doubted, yet it ≈øeems clear, that it opens Ob≈øtructions as an Alcali, by ab≈øorbing the Acid, which cau≈øes the Coagulum: But if any one ≈øhould object, That Iron does only act according to the Preparations which the different Juices it meets with in the Stomach do make, for that the≈øe acid Juices not failing to encounter with, and to di≈ø≈øolve it, there may re≈øult from this di≈ø≈øolution a liberty to the parts of the Body where this Action might be and ≈øome other parts adjacent thereto, and con≈øequently their Re≈øtauration.

¬ß 11. To which we ≈øay, that though Mars may act in the Body, ≈øometimes as an Alcali, by ab≈øorbing and ≈øweetening the acid Humor which it meets with, as it does ab≈øorb and ≈øweeten the acid Liquors which are poured upon it: Yet we conclude not from hence, that its aperitive faculty does alwaies con≈øi≈øt in this effect, for that the Water in which Iron has been put to boil is aperitive, and yet there is no Alcali in it, to ≈øweeten the Acids of the Body when it is drunk.

¬ß 12. That though Steel is alwaies u≈øed in Chymical Preparations for Phy≈øick and commonly preferred before it, yet it is neverthele≈øs certain that Iron is much more fit for that intent than Steel, becau≈øe it is more ≈øoluble; for if the Action of Iron proceeds from nothing but its Salt (as 'tis certain) the Salt of Iron mu≈øt be much more ea≈øily ≈øeparated than that of Steel becau≈øe the Pores of the latter are more clo≈øe than the Pores of the former, and therefore this mu≈øt have quicker effects.

¬ß 13. But the rea≈øon which has induced People to believe that Steel is better for Phy≈øical u≈øes than Iron, was its being thought to be deprived of many Impurities by calcination; but that which they call the Impurity is the more open part of the Iron, and therefore the more to be cho≈øen, and the more effectual.

¬ß 14. And therefore as Iron by calcination being turned
into Seeel, is freed from its Scories, and al≈øo deprived of its more volatile Salt, ≈øo it is made wor≈øe for our U≈øes by that Change; for the Impurities, which is called the Scories, is the better part of the Iron, that has been rarified by its Salt; and tho' ≈øome call the Ru≈øt of Iron its Dro≈øs, the whole Metal may receive the ≈øame appellation, every Particle thereof being capable of the ≈øame change, if but laid in the open Air.

div.head: XLIV. * Chalybs Tartari≈øatus; Steel tartari≈øed.
div.p: Bate. ‚Ñû Mars clean≈øed from filth, white Tartar in pouder, A. ‚Ñ•vj. Fumitory water q. s. mix, and make a Ma≈øs like Pa≈øte or an Electuary; boil it in an earthen Ve≈ø≈øel in Clibano, with a gentle heat, to dryne≈øs; make it into a ≈øubtil pouder, to which add Fumitory water q. s. and boil again to dryne≈øs; which repeat again the third time, reducing it at la≈øt into a ≈øubtil pouder, S. A. Of this is made Potable Mars.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is the Arcanum of which Dr. Willis his Tincture of Steel was made, which made ≈øo great a noi≈øe, and obtained ≈øo great a Reputation in the World.

¬ß 2. The Pouder may be given again≈øt all manner of Ob≈øtructions of the Bowels, but chiefly tho≈øe of the Liver, Spleen, Stomach, Womb, Pancreas, and Me≈øentery; it is indeed a good thing again≈øt the Scurvy, Drop≈øie, Gout, but chiefly again≈øt the Green ≈øickne≈øs in Virgins, which it ≈øcarcely ever fails to Cure, as al≈øo the Rickets in Children, though in the latter ca≈øe (in my opinion) it is better given in a Tincture than in Sub≈øtance, in which latter form it may be given √† ‚Ñ•≈øs. ad ‚Ñàij. more or le≈øs, in a fit Vehicle.

¬ß 3. From this Pouder a Tincture may be made, 1. by boiling it in fair Water till the Liquor looks black, which may be filtrated and evaporated in an earthen Pan, to the thickne≈øs of a Syrup. This is a famous thing again≈øt the Green-≈øickne≈øs, and may be given from one ≈øpoonful to two, in a Gla≈øs of Ale, every night going to Bed.

¬ß 4. Or, 2. by infu≈øion in White or Rheni≈øh-wine, thus. ‚Ñû White or Rheni≈øh-wine lb viij. of the former Crocus lb j. mix, and dige≈øt in a very gentle heat, for a month, ≈øo will you have a famous Tincture of Mars, good for all the Purpo≈øes afore≈øaid, and may
be given at night going to Bed, ab ‚Ñ•≈øs. ad ‚Ñ•j. in a Gla≈øs Bv Ale or Wine.

¬ß 5. Or, 3. by Infu≈øion in tartari≈øed S. V. or as ≈øome will have it, in Tincture of Salt of Tartar, thus: ‚Ñû S. V. &c. lb iv. of the former Crocus lb j. mix, dige≈øt for a month in a gentle heat, and decant, and affu≈øe fre≈øh ≈øpirit ≈øo long as it will yield any Tincture; put all the≈øe Tinctures together, and ab≈øtract one half or three parts of the ≈øpirit, according to the quantity which you u≈øed in extracting the Tincture.

¬ß 6. The latter is more ≈øpirituous and penetrating, and has all the Vertues of any of the former, and may be given √† ‚Ñ•j. ad ‚Ñ•ij. more or le≈øs, in any convenient Vehicle, and that as well in the morning as at night.

div.head: XLV. Cinnabaris Antimonii, Cinnabar of Antimony.
div.p: Bate.] It is made by ≈øublimation of the Caput Mortuum left, after the di≈øtillation of the Butter of Antimony, then rectifying it, S. A. It provokes Sweat plentifully, and prevails again≈øt the Gout, French Pox, Falling-≈øickne≈øs, Pal≈øie, &c. Do≈øe √† ‚Ñà≈øs. ad ‚Ñàj.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Having prepared all the Matter for di≈øtillation of the Butter of Antimony, (the making of which we ≈øhall ≈øhew in its place) and the Gummy or Glacial Liquor being come off, you mu≈øt give by little and little a Fire of ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion, till the red Liquor al≈øo comes forth, then remove the Recipient, and ≈øub≈øtitute another, and with a fire of ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion, for an hour or two, (as Beguinus directs) or four hours, (as Roifincius, Chym. lib. 5. ≈øect. 5. cap. 5. will have it) or eight hours, (as Bla≈øius the Commentator on Beguinus advi≈øes) encrea≈øing towards the end, for ≈øome time, till the Retort gr ‚Ä¢ ws red-hot; continue the di≈øtillation ≈øo will you have the Cinnabar ≈øticking to the neck of the Retort, and in the Receiver a little running Mercury.

¬ß 2. From a pound and half of each of the Ingredients, viz. from lbiij. of the fir≈øt matter, you will have ≈øays Rolfincius, a glaciale Butter: an elegant ≈øhining Antimony in the bottom of the Retort lbi¬æ: in the latter Receiver running Mercury a little: and Cinnabar in the neck of the Retort but íiij. But in the latter I know he was mi≈øtaken, for if you work rightly, you will have of Cinnabar ‚Ñ•xiii≈øs.

¬ß 3. Thibaut, in his Art of Chymi≈øtry, ≈øays, If you would have the Cinnaber of Antimony, you mu≈øt towards the end of the fir≈øt di≈øtillation in your luted Retort, give a violent fire of ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion, and (≈øays he) without any Receiver to your Retort, which is to be continued till your Retort be ≈øunk and almo≈øt melted: This fire will drive the Mercury to the end and middle of the neck of the Retort, and when the Operation is done, it will, either be revived into Quick≈øilver, or turned into a grey or blacki≈øh Pouder; and at the mouth of the Retort you will find an Antimonial ≈øub≈øtance, which at the end of the operation will appear in the form of a Cru≈øt, as thick as the Back of a Knife, and which outwardly is of a grey colour, but being pared, is within red, and called Cinnabar of Antimony; and in the bottom of the Retort a congealed Lump, which is the re≈øt of your Antimony revived.

¬ß 4. If, ≈øays he, you weigh your Mercury, (both the revived and that which is in pouder) you will find that they weigh little more than the corro≈øive Sublimate fir≈øt u≈øed. And if you weigh the Cinnabar and the Antimony at bottom of the Retort, you will ≈øee that they will weigh little le≈øs than the Antimony fir≈øt taken.

¬ß 5. That when you intend to make Cinnabar of Antimony, you mu≈øt alwaies take the be≈øt crude Antimony, and not its Regulus; for th√¥ from the latter you will have a better and more gentle Mercurius Vitae, yet from it you will have no Cinnabar of Antimony at all, becau≈øe the Regulus has lo≈øt a great part of its Sulphur.

¬ß 6. Le Mort, Chymic. Medico-phy≈øicae, pag. 169. ≈øaith, That if after the di≈øtillation of the Butter of Antimony, you make the fire more inten≈øe, you ≈øhall have a Cinnabar; But if you would have it In greater abundance, you are to make the ≈øublimation in an earthen Retort, with a naked fire; and being made red-hot, the Work is to be continued for two hours, (Collect. Chym. cap. 53) ≈øo will all the Mercury mixt with the Sulphur of the Antimony a≈øcend in the form of Cinnabar.

¬ß 7. Marggrave makes it thus. ‚Ñû The Caput Mort‚ñ™ left in making the Butter of Antimony, make it into pouder, and put it into a Gla≈øs
Retort coated, which place upon a naked fire, ≈øo as the Retort may be made throughly red-hot, and ≈øublime for the ≈øpace of an hour or two.

¬ß 8. The Work being fini≈øhed, break the Retort, you will find in the fir≈øt part of the neck a black matter, which by wa≈øhing in fair Water will become Quicksilver; in the other part of the neck you will have a kind of grey Sublimate, which being freed from its Scoria, and reduced into ponder, will be red, which is the Cinnabar of Antimony; and in the bottom of the Retort you will have a little crude Antimony, which Chymi≈øts call Antimoninm Regeneratum.

¬ß 9. The Cinnabar being reduced into ponder, is to be ≈øeveral times rectified, by ≈øubliming it per ≈øe, in a Gla≈øs Retort in ≈øand, by which means it will become very pure and red. Chymi≈øts advi≈øe a ≈øeven-fold rectification or ≈øublimation; but Marggrave is of opinion, that three are enough.

¬ß 10. From this Cinnabar it is that the Philo≈øophers make an augmentation of Gold , and ≈øome di≈ø≈øolve it in Spirit of common Salt, and then di≈øtil it to dryne≈øs, obtaining a mo≈øt white pouder, which they call Chaos Mercurit.
¬ß 11. Zwelfer performs the Operation the ≈øame way, in the ≈øpace of one or two hours, but advi≈øes that the neck of the Retort ≈øhould be large.
¬ß 12. Schroder ≈øays, That if you de≈øire Cinnabar rather than Butter of Aniimony, you mu≈øt at fir≈øt give a ≈øtrong Fire: This Cinnabar, ≈øays he, may be purified with one or two ≈øublimations.

¬ß 13. Lemery makes it after this manner: ‚Ñû Crude Antimony, corro≈øive Sublimate, Ana. in fine pouder, mix them well together, and therewith fill a Retort half full, ≈øet it in ≈øand, in a ≈ømall Fornace, and fit thereto a Receiver, luting the Juncture; di≈øtil fir≈øt with a ≈ømall fire, ≈øo will a clear Liquor di≈øtil, then augment the fire a little, and the Butter of Antimony will come forth white and thick (which will ≈øtop the neck of the Retort and break it, if you take not care to ≈øet live Coals near it, that it may melt and run into the Receiver) continue the di≈øtillation till red Vapors begin to appear, then take away the Receiver, and put another in its place, without luting the Juncture; encrea≈øe the Fire by little and little, till the Retort becomes red-hot; continue it ≈øo three or four hours, then letting the
Retort cool, break it, and you will find the Cinnabar ≈øublimed and fixed to the neck, which ≈øeparate and keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 14. From ten ounces of crude Antimony, and ten ounces of corro≈øive Sublimate, you will have of Butter of Antimony ‚Ñ•v. of Cinnabar of Antimony ‚Ñ•vii≈øs. of Quicksilver ‚Ñ•i. and of Antimony regenerate (which remains in the Retort) ‚Ñ•v. ≈øo that it ≈øeems there is ‚Ñ•i≈øs. of the Matter lo≈øt in the Operation, which po≈ø≈øibly might happen while the Cinnabar was ri≈øing.

¬ß 15. The Ma≈øs at bottom of the Retort, Lemery ≈øays, may be flung away, as being the more terre≈øtrious part of the Antimony; the Quicksilver is found as well in the neck of the Retort, as in the la≈øt Receiver; and at the end of the neck of the Retort, there is ≈øometimes a Mo≈ø≈øy Sub≈øtance found, which repre≈øents many little figures, and is the more rarified Cinnabar.

¬ß 16. Now the rea≈øon why Running Quicksilver is found in this Operation, is, from the paucity of the Sulphur in the Antimony, there being not enough in that quantity for the Mercury to adhere to, for that to make Cinnabar, Mercury, and Sulphur mu≈øt be ≈øublimed together.

¬ß 17. Take this Cinnabar in fine pouder p. j. Salt of Tartar p. ij. mix, and put them into a Retort, and di≈øtil with a great fire into a Receiver filled with Water, ≈øo will the Mercury come forth, and the Sulphur will remain in the Retort with the Salt of Tartar, which you may thus ≈øeparate.

¬ß 18. Boil what remains in the Retort in a ≈øufficient quantity of Water, filter the Decoction, and affu≈øe thereon ≈øpirit of Vinegar ≈øo will a grey pouder precipitate, which edulcorate with Water, and dry; thus have you done the Sulphur of Antimony, which is much e≈øteemed for Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Lungs, being given √† gr. v. ad viij. in ≈øome pectoral Vehicle.

¬ß 19. Le Febure differs little in the form of the Preparation, but much in the proportion of the Ingredients, for to lb j. of crude Antimony he takes lb iij. of Corro≈øive Sublimate, which he puts into a Retort ≈øo large, as that ¬æ of it may be empty, and lutes the Juncture only with Paper and Pa≈øte made of Flower, performing the Operations as afore directed.

¬ß 20. This Cinnabar, ≈øays he, may be u≈øed for a Fume to ≈øuch who are in a cour≈øe of Cure for the Pox, but is mo≈øtly u≈øed as an Internal in the Venereal Di≈øea≈øe and all its Retinue, becau≈øe this Antimonial Sulphur, (which cleaves to the Mercury, and coagulates it) is of a much-more exalted Vertue than common Sulphur, and therefore this Medicament does more effectually ab≈øorb Acids, purifies the ma≈øs of Blood, and hinders the corruption and putrefaction of all the Humors and Juices of the Body, removing the malignity, and de≈øtroying the Venereal Venom.

¬ß 21. Authors pre≈øcribe it √† gr. vj. ad xv. or xx. but my Experience has told me, it may ≈øafely be given for a Month together aÃÑ. ‚Ñàj ad ‚Ñàij. yea, ad í j. in a proper Bolus, or made up with Chio Turpentine, or Bal≈øam of Peru, or other ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t Vehicle.

¬ß 22. Marggrave, Le Mort, and indeed mo≈øt Authors who have wrote of it, commend it as a famous thing for the cure of the Epilep≈øie‚ñ™ and other Di≈øea≈øes proceeding from an Acid ferment, it being of an alcalious and ≈øulphurous nature: But in re≈øpect to the Epilep≈øie, it mu≈øt proceed from an Acid cau≈øe, el≈øe it will not have that famed effect.

¬ß 23. How this Cinnabar of Antimony may be made in a greater plenty we will here ≈øhew from Rolfincius, Chym. lib. 5. ≈øect. 5. cap. 6. thus: ‚Ñû Crude Antimony, Corro≈øive Sublimate, Ana. mix in fine pouder, and di≈øtil off the Butter, as before directed; which cea≈øing to di≈øtil, take the Caput Mort. or Matter remaining in the Retort and mix it again with an equal quantity of Mercury Sublimate, which put into a new Retort, having a much longer and wider neck (that the Cinnabar may have a ≈øpacious place to be lodged in) begin fir≈øt with a gentle fire, then with a more inten≈øe, and la≈øtly, with a fire of ≈øuppre≈ø≈øi ‚Ä¢ n, ≈øo will the Cinnabar ≈øublime in a much greater plenty, &c.
¬ß 24. Modus ∆≤tendi. ‚Ñû Cinnabar of Antimony, Magi≈øteries of Coral and Pearl, ana. gr. xv. mix for a Do≈øe, again≈øt the Falling-≈øickne≈øs. Hartman.
¬ß 25. Or thus: ‚Ñû Cinnabar of Antimony, Mi≈ø≈øelto of the Oak, Elks-hoof, A. ‚Ñ•≈øs. Man's-skull filed, or calcin'd without Fire, ‚Ñ•i. mix them. Do≈øe √† ‚Ñà≈øs. ad ‚Ñàj. or ‚Ñàij. Myn≈øicht.
¬ß 26. Or thus: ‚Ñû Cinnabar of Antimony, crude Man's skull, Magi≈øteries of Coral and Pearls, ana. mix, and make a pouder. Do≈øe √† gr. 10, ad 20, ad 30. in any convenient Liquor. Sennertus.
¬ß 27. ‚Ñû Cinnabar of Antimony, Magi≈øtery of Elks-hoof, A. í ij. Eleo≈øaccharum Citri, Angelicae, A. í j. mix, for 12 or 18 Do≈øes. Rolfincius.

¬ß 28. Or thus: ‚Ñû Cinnabar ‚Ñ•≈øs. Magi≈øteries of Pearl and Coral, A. ‚Ñàij. Saffron ‚Ñàj. Aurum Fulminans gr. x. mix them. Do≈øe √† ‚Ñà≈øs. ad ‚Ñàj. or í ≈øs. in Lilly-convally-water, &c. Quercetan.

div.head: XLVI. Coleothar Vitrioli; Caput Mortuum of Vitriol.
div.p: Bate.] It is nothing el≈øe but Vitriol calcin'd to redne≈øs; or the Caput Mortuum left in the bottom of the Retort after the di≈øtillation of the Oil of Vitriol. Vide Chalcanthum Rubefactum.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. You may ≈øee the thing more at large in Sect. XLII. aforegoing of this Chapter, with the Vertues and U≈øes thereof.

¬ß 2. Be≈øides what we have there ≈øignified, this take notice of, That a Salt may be extracted out of it, which is indeed a famous Styptick, and ≈øtops Bleeding above any other thing in the World; of which we fully and plainly ≈øpeak in its proper place.

div.head: XLVII. Corpus ≈øine Anima; A Body without a Soul.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Roots of Florentine-Orrice í i≈øs. Musk gr. iij. Sugar ‚Ñ•vj. mix, and make a pouder. It is of u≈øe to di≈ø≈øolve Tartar in the Lungs, help Coughs, A≈øthma's, &c. and takes away the ≈øtinking of the Mouth or Breath.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The name of this Recipe is not ≈øtranger to me than the rea≈øon for which it was given: But that it will do ≈øomething, is certain: If you add to it ‚Ñ•≈øs. of Tartar Vitriolate‚ñ™ it will more compleatly cut tartarous Humors in the Lungs, or el≈øewhere, and remove Ob≈øtructions which cau≈øe A≈øthma's, Shortne≈øs of Breath, &c.

¬ß 2. The Acid of the Tartar will al≈øo in ≈øome mea≈øure open the Body of the Musk, and makes its redolency ≈øo much the greater, by which means it will be much more effectual in curing ≈øtinking Breaths.

¬ß 3. It may be taken either alone, or di≈ø≈øolved in Ale, Wine, Water, or o ‚Ä¢ her
proper pectoral Vehicle: Do≈øe (the Tartar Vitriolate being added to it) √† í j. ad í ij. or iij, fir≈øt in the morning fa≈øting, and la≈øt at night going to Bed.

div.head: XLVIII. Corvus Epilepticus; The Antepileptick Crow or Raven.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû The greater Crow, deplumate and evi≈øcerate it, ca≈øting away its Feet and Bill, put into its Belly the Heart, Liver, Lungs, Bladder of the Gall, with Galangal and Ani≈øeeds, A. ‚Ñ•iv. bake it in a new earthen Ve≈ø≈øel well ≈øhut or clo≈øed in an Oven with Hou≈øehold-Bread; after it is cooled, ≈øeparate the fle≈øh from the ≈øides, and repeat this Operation of baking the ≈øecond or third time, but taking great care that it may not be burnt, then reduce it into a fine pouder S. A. Do≈øe í j. every day to ≈øu ‚Ä¢ h as are afflicted with the Falling-≈øickne≈øs. It is a famous Remedy.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It may be doubtful, what Bird is here intended by our Author, whether it be the Rook‚ñ™ common Crow‚ñ™ or Raven, the Fle≈øh of all the≈øe being reported by Authors to be good again≈øt the Falling-≈øickne≈øs: But if we may make our Conjecture from the Epithite [Majorem] which is added, we po≈øitively conclude, that the Corvus Leguminalis, or Rook, cannot be it, becau≈øe it is the lea≈øt of all the Crowkind; the Doubr then lies between the common Crow and the Raven.

¬ß 2. Since the Crow and the Raven are each indifferently called in Latin Corvus, (which is the Term our Author has u≈øed) the former being much the le≈ø≈øer, the latter much the greater; and ≈øince the Crow has a peculiar Name, proper to its ≈øingular kind, and cannot be applied to the Raven, viz. Cornix, which he has avoided, and u≈øed only the common Name Corvus, (the common Appellation of both kinds, but proper al≈øo to the Raven) and ≈øince to the common Appellative Corvum he added Majorem, we may rea≈øonably conclude, That he intended nothing more nor le≈øs than our common Raven.

¬ß 3. That this Recipe is an excellent good thing again≈øt the Falling-≈øickne≈øs, we doubt not, nor are we willing to que≈øtion the Authority which has confirmed it, ≈øince we know 2 or 3 Experiments which have ≈øealed to the truth thereof.

¬ß 4. But that there may be a more excellent Compo≈øition than this, we doubt not, and are confident that it may be improved to a greater advantage: The Compo≈øition in our Sepla≈øium, lib. 6. cap. 21. ≈øect. 11. ≈øeems to excel it, which is this: ‚Ñû Of Ravens fle≈øh in pouder (as the former Pre≈øcript advi≈øes) í iij. Viper-pouder í j. Native Cinnabar ‚Ñàj. mix, and make a ≈øubtile pouder for two Do≈øes, to be given at night going to Bed.

¬ß 5. If ≈øuch be the Vertues of the gro≈øs Fle≈øh, what would it be if it was Spagyrically prepared? Since it is the Volatile Salt, Oily parts, and Spirit which performs the≈øe things if they were freed and ≈øet at liberty from their more gro≈øs and terrene parts, which are the Chains which hold the active power of the Concrete in Bondage, what might not this ≈øo excellent a Medicine perform? Since therefore it is the volatile part which performs the≈øe things, we will here ≈øhew you how to ≈øeparate them.

¬ß 6. ‚Ñû A whole Raven gently dried, chop all into bits (Head, Bill, Feathers, Claws, Bones, and Intrails) and put them into an earthen Retort, or a gla≈øs well coated, which fix in a Reverberatory Fornace, with a large Receiver, luting well the Juncture; di≈øtil fir≈øt with a very gentle fire to warm the Retort, and bring forth the Flegm drop by drop; when all that is come over augment the fire a little, and the acid Spirits will come, filling the Recipient with white Clouds; encrea≈øe the fire now to the third degree, ≈øo will you have a blacki≈øh fetid Oyl, with a volatile Salt ≈øticking partly to the neck of the Retort, and partly to the ≈øides of the Receiver; encrea≈øe the fire to the highe≈øt degree, and continue it till no more will come forth.

¬ß 7. Shake all together in the Receiver, to loo≈øen the volatile Salt, and put all (Flegm, Spirit, Oyl, and Salt) into a Matra≈øs or Bolt-head with its Alembick and a ≈ømall Receiver, luting the Joints with a Bladder met in the Glair of Eggs; di≈øtil in ≈øand in a gentle heat, ≈øo will the volatile ≈øalt a≈øcend pure and white to the top of the Ve≈ø≈øel, which ≈øeparate, and keep in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 8. The matter remaining in the Matra≈øs filter through brown Paper, ≈øo will the flegm and ≈øpirit pa≈øs, leaving the fetid Oyl at bottom: The ≈øpirit you may rectifie by a gla≈øs Alembick in B. M. drawing off the
one half thereof; which is the volatile acid Spirit repleat with volatile Salt, ca≈øting the other half away.

¬ß 9. The fetid Oyl you may mix with Colcothar or Bone-a≈øhes, and put it into a Gla≈øs Retort coated, and by a di≈øtillation in Sand you may rectifie it, and make it very pure, freeing it from its thick blackne≈øs.

¬ß 10. This Salt is one of the be≈øt Medicines again≈øt Epilep≈øies, Apoplexies, Pal≈øies, Lethargies, and other Di≈øea≈øes of the Head, Brain, and Nerves, as al≈øo again≈øt Di≈øea≈øes of the Womb, as Vapors, Hy≈øterick Fits, Fainting, Swooning, &c. Do≈øe √† gr. viij. ad xvj. vel xx. in any proper Vehicle.

¬ß 11. The Spirit may begin √† gut. 10, ad 30, in Water of Lilly-Convally, or the like. And the Oyl is to be ≈ømelt to and may al≈øo be given inwardly again≈øt Fits of the Mother, and mo≈øt Di≈øea≈øes of the Brain and Head, √† gut ij. ad iv. being fir≈øt dropt into Sugar, and then di≈ø≈øolved in the Vehicle you intend to give it in.

¬ß 12. Modus ∆≤tendi. ‚Ñû Con≈øerve of Ro≈øemary-flowers í ij. Eleo≈øaccharum Citri ‚Ñà≈øs. ad ‚Ñàj. volatile Salt of Ravens gr. xvj. mix for a Do≈øe, to be given la≈øt at night going to Bed, and fir≈øt in the morning ri≈øing.

div.head: XLIX. Crocus Jovis; Saffron of Tin, or Jovial Crocus.
div.p: Bate.] Make an Amalgama of Jupiter or Tin ‚Ñ•≈øs. and of Mercury ‚Ñ•i≈øs. from which (evaporating the Mercury) you will have left the Crocus of Jupiter. It is a great Sudorifick. Do≈øe √† gr. iv. ad x. It prevails wonderfully again≈øt the French Pox, Gout, Plague, Suffocation of the Womb, &c. Outwardly it is u≈øed again≈øt inveterate Ulcers, Cancers, Fi≈øtula's, &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. You mu≈øt fir≈øt melt your Tin by it ≈øelf, then add your Mercury, ≈øtirring them about continually, till ≈øuch time as they are throughly mixed together: This done, you may ab≈øtract your Mercury by a Retort in Sand, for otherwi≈øe by an open evaporation it would be all lo≈øt.
¬ß 2. It is a Specifick again≈øt Di≈øea≈øes of the Womb, particularly ≈øuch as proceed from Ob≈øtruction, Wind, Vapors, and the like.

¬ß 3. You may u≈øe it thus. ‚Ñû Con≈øerve of Peony-flowers í ij. Crocus of Jupiter gr. viij.
Filings of Hor≈øe-hoofs gr. vj. mix for a Do≈øe, to be given at night going to Bed. Or thus: ‚Ñû Mithridate í j. Crocus of Jupiter gr. x. or xij. Salt of Harts-horn gr. vj. mix for a Do≈øe, to be given as afore≈øaid.

div.head: L. Crocus Veneris; Saffron of Venus or Copper.
div.p: Bate.] It is made by reverberation of the Vitriol of Venus, S. A. It is Diuretick‚ñ™ Anticolick, Uterine, and a Febrifuge. Do≈øe gr. x.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Lemery makes a Crocus of Copper after this manner: ‚Ñû Copper calcin ‚Ä¢ d S. S. S. with Sulphur, q. v. heat it red-hot in a Crucible, and ca≈øt it red-hot into a Pot of Lin≈øeed Oyl, containing ≈øo much as may overtop it four inches, (covering the Pot immediately, for otherwi≈øe it would take fire) in which let it lye till it is nearly cold: Take the Copper again, and heat it red-hot, extingui≈øhing it as afore≈øaid; which Work repeat nine ≈øeveral times, ≈øo will you have a Copper well purified: Calcine it once again, to con≈øume the Oyl, and make it into pouder, ≈øo have you the Crocus of Venus.
¬ß 2. The chief u≈øe of this Preparation of Lemery is external, being deter≈øive, and of good effects to eat away the proud Fle≈øh of Wounds and Ulcers, and remove the Callo≈øity of Fi≈øtula's.

¬ß 3. Le Febur makes it of Copper calcin'd S. S. S. with Sulphur, till at becomes ≈øpongy, and brittle as Gla≈øs, and red when ground to pouder, which pouder he reverberates for 24 hours, and repeats the Reverberation three times, by which means he has a very red and open Crocus, and a fit Ingredient for Salves and Plai≈øters.

¬ß 4. But the Crocus of the Vitriol of Venus he thus makes. ‚Ñû Vitriol of Venus lb j. put it into a Cucurbit, place it in a clo≈øe Reverberatory, and fit to it a large Recipient, which being exactly luted, give a gradual fire, and keep it 48 hours with Coals; then after this u≈øe very dry Wood, to give it the la≈øt degree of flaming fire, for the ≈øpace of 12 hours, ≈øo will you be ≈øure to have extracted the Flegm, Volatile Spirit, Acid and Corro≈øive Spirit or Oyl of the Vitriol of Venus, and in the bottom of the Retort an a≈øtringent Crocus high and ≈øubtile, called al≈øo Caput Mortuum of the Vitriol of Venus.

¬ß 5. Some order the calcination of this Vitriol to be done in a Crucible, to reduce it to a Crocus; but why ≈øhould one lo≈øe the Co≈øt and Pains, and the be≈øt Sub≈øtance and mo≈øt full of Vertue, which mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily be, if the Work be done in a Crucible? for all that is found in the Recipient after di≈øtillation, will exhale in the open Air; and the Crocus made by di≈øtillation will not be inferior, but rather ≈øuperior, better and purer than that made in a Crucible.

¬ß 6. And if all the Liquor be rectified in A≈øhes or Sand, and drawn off to dryne≈øs, without any di≈øtinction or ≈øeparation of Sub≈øtances, it will be a ≈øpecifical Spirit, good again≈øt cephalick and uterine Di≈øea≈øes, being mixt in Julaps or Apozems to a plea≈øant acidity, or u≈øed in the ordinary Drink of the Patient.
¬ß 7. But as to the Crocus, it is an infallible Remedy to ≈øtop bleeding in any part, outward or inward, and to dry and cicatrize Wounds and Ulcers.

¬ß 8. It is al≈øo a Specifick internally applied in Opiates, and externally by Injection, for the cure of Gonorrhoea's and heat of Urine, and an excellent Remedy again≈øt immoderate loo≈øene≈øs of the Belly, Dy≈øenteries, Lienteries, and ≈øpitting or pi≈ø≈øing of Blood, if it be exhibited √† gr. vj. ad xv. vel xx. in Con≈øerve of Ro≈øes, the Patient being purged beforehand with a Tincture of Rheubarb, or of Rheubarb and Sena made with Endive and Succory-water.

¬ß 9. Marggrave makes it in all re≈øpects as Le Febur, putting the Vitriol into a gla≈øs Retort, but di≈øtils in Sand with a fire of the third degree for 5 or 6 hours, or till no more will come forth: This Caput Mortuum he edulcorates by ≈øeveral times wa≈øhing it in fair warm Water, then dries it and keeps it for u≈øe. Collect. Chym. cap. 497.

¬ß 10. And if you ab≈øtract or evaporate this Water to dryne≈øs, you will have at bottom a Salt of Venus, or of the Vitriol of Venus, which is the true Gilla Theophra≈øti, which as ≈øome think, is not to be given but to ≈øtrong Bodies.

¬ß 11. Zwelfer Manti≈ø≈ø. Spagyr. par. 1. cap. 4. ≈øaith, That the Caput Mortuum left after the di≈øtillation of the Spirit of Venus, having an ex≈øiccating and a≈øtringing Vertue, profitable for the drying of Ulcers, which
abound with a flux of Humors.

¬ß 12. Charras has a Sulphur of Venus for external u≈øes, thus made: ‚Ñû Filings or thin Plates of Copper, and calcine per ≈øe, in a Fornace of Reverberation to redne≈øs. Or thus: ‚Ñû Thin plates of Copper, which lay in an earthen Ve≈ø≈øel or Crucible S. S. S. with decripitated Salt in fine pouder, which reverberate to redne≈øs, then quench them in Water, and clean≈øe them well with Iron Bru≈øhes; repeat the calcination S. S. S. with decripitated Salt three times, ≈øo will you have a very red Crocus Veneris, which wa≈øh well and reduce into fine pouder for external u≈øes.

¬ß 13. Or thus: Di≈ø≈øolve Copper in A. F. or Spirit of Nitre, ab≈øtract the Spirit by di≈øtillation, ≈øo will the Crocus be at bottom in a red pouder, which wa≈øh, dry, and keep for u≈øe. Or el≈øe precipitate the Di≈ø≈øolution, by putting in a thin plate of Iron, and pouring hot Water upon it, the Di≈ø≈øolvent lets fall a red pouder, which, ≈øays Charras, is to be kept as a true Crocus Veneris. But it is chiefly for external u≈øes, as that of Le Febur at ¬ß 3. afore, being not ≈øo fit to take inwardly.

¬ß 14. Hartman in his Notes upon Beguinus, ≈øet the Pre≈øcript of Calcining with Salt, to Charras; but he ≈øays, it ought to be by degrees, and gently calcin'd, and then at la≈øt the Calx being freed from the ≈øaline Particles by boiling Water, the Crocus Veneris will remain at bottom of a mo≈øt red colour, like Blood.

¬ß 15. Schroder Cements Plates of Venus S. S. S. with common Salt and Tartar, which ≈øays Hofman, for its mighty power of con≈øolidating, is commended to dry up and heal old Sores and Ulcers; but it ≈øucceeds not, being calcin'd with Tartar alone: the Tartar mu≈øt be joyn'd in equal proportion with either Salt or Sulphur, and then laid S. S. S. in order for the Cementation, &c.

div.head: LI. Diacreta; Pouder of Chalk Compound.
div.p:
Bate.] ‚Ñû White Chalk four times wa≈øh'd in Violet-water ‚Ñ•j. Liquorice, Quince≈øeeds, Crabs-eyes, A. ‚Ñ•≈øs. Nutmegs, ≈øtone of a Carps-head, A. í ij. Pearl, Red Coral, A. í ≈øs. Saffron, Mace a little torrified, A. ‚Ñà≈øs. mix, and make a ≈øubtile pouder. It prevails wonderfully
in Pains of the Stomach. quenches Thir≈øt, and removes the Cau≈øe of the Evil. Do≈øe í j.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Chalk ought to be levigated, ≈øo al≈øo the Crabs-eyes, the Stone of a Carps-head, the Pearl and Coral, and that by the help of Violet or Damask-Ro≈øe-water.
¬ß 2. The Liquorice ought to be in a very ≈øubtile and fine Pouder, ≈øo al≈øo the Saffron, Mace, and Nutmegs; but how the Quince-≈øeeds will be reduced as they ≈øhould be, I know not.

¬ß 4. This Remedy prepared with the Terra Sigillata, I have given many times in Pains of the Stomach, (≈øo vehement, as to be beyond almo≈øt all manner of expre≈ø≈øion) but never without Succe≈øs, for tho≈øe Pains being commonly cau≈øed from the biting of the Acid Humor, this Pouder being an Alcali, ab≈øorbs the Acid, and ≈øo delivers the Sick. Do≈øe √† í ≈øs. ad í ij.

div.head: LII. Diatartarum; Pouder of Tartar Compound.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Ro≈øin of Scammony, Tartar Vitriolate, A. ‚Ñ•j. Turbeth, Hermodacts, A. ‚Ñ•≈øs. Oyls of Cinnamon and Cloves, A. gr. xij. mix, and make a pouder. Do≈øe √† ‚Ñàj. ad ‚Ñàiv.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. How the Ro≈øin of Scammony is made, you may ≈øee in our Pharmac. Londinen≈øis, lib. 1. cap. 8. ≈øect. 68. as al≈øo in our Doron Medicum, lib. 2. cap. 9. ≈øect. 2. where you may have its Vertues, U≈øes, and Do≈øe.

¬ß 2. The Tartar Vitriolate is thus made: ‚Ñû Pure white Salt of Tartar melted per deliquium q. v. put it into a large and high gla≈øs Cucurbit, where there may be room enough for the Ebulition, and affu≈øe thereon the Spirit or Oyl of Vitriol, which do gradatim ≈øtirring the mixture from time to time, the better to unite them well; continue to pour in the Spirit or Oyl, ≈øo long as there is any Ebulition, and when that cea≈øes give over, for that is a ≈øure ≈øign that the fixt Salt and acid Spirit have ≈øufficiently penetrated and ≈øatiated one another, and are mixed in their due proportion; then place the Cucurbit in a gentle
≈øand-heat, and evaporate the ≈øuperfluous humidity to a Pellicle, and ≈øet it to cry≈øtalize, or otherwi≈øe evaporate to dryne≈øs, and the Tartar Vitriolate will remain at bottom purely white.

¬ß 3. Or thus: ‚Ñû Pure, white, dry Salt of Tartar in pouder, put it into the bottom of the gla≈øs Cucurbit, and gently pour upon it as much good Spirit or Oyl of Vitriol as it can ≈øuck up, forbearing to pour any more when you ≈øee the Ebulition cea≈øes, ≈øo will you have Tartar vitriolated, very white and dry, and without any ≈øuperfluous moi≈øture, and fit for your occa≈øion.

¬ß 4. The Turbith ought to be re≈øinous, and the Hermodacts pure and white, which are to be reduced into Pouder by beating in an Iron Mortar, adding a few drops of Oyl of ≈øweet Almonds, to keep them from ≈øticking to the bottom of the Mortar, &c.

¬ß 5. It is a general Purge, and carries off all Humors by Stool chiefly, being an excellent thing again≈øt the Scurvy, Drop≈øie, Gout, Jaundice, King's-Evil, Pox, and Ob≈øtructions of the Womb: It is to be taken in the morning fa≈øting, drinking after it warm Broth or Po≈ø≈øet-drink, and avoiding the taking cold as much as may; with Ob≈øervations as in other Purges.

div.head: LIII. * Diatrachia; Pouder of Wind-pipes Compound.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû The Wind-pipes of Sheep clean≈øed and dryed in an Oven ‚Ñ•iv. Wind-pipes of Capons in like manner prepared ‚Ñ•iij. Ivory ra≈øped A. ‚Ñ•ij. Salmon.] ¬ß 1. In my opinion, after the clean≈øing and gently drying of the Windpipes, tho≈øe and all the re≈øt of the Ingredients will be be≈øt reduced into Pouder, by a Philo≈øophical Calcination, by the Vapors of di≈øtilled Waters in di≈øtillation, exactly in the ≈øame manner as you perform the Philo≈øophical Calcination of Harts-horn, which you may ≈øee in its place.

¬ß 2. Con≈øidering the Intention of the Medicine, I think it convenient to add white Henbane-≈øeeds ‚Ñ•xij. becau≈øe this ≈øimple thing alone has a ≈øtrange and admirable
Vertue for performing Cures o ‚Ä¢ that kind: And I have cu

≈øect; 3. And with the ≈øame ≈øimple thing I have cured ≈øeveral of a Diabetes, when ≈øuppo≈øed incurable, and given over, after u≈øing very much other means: For the≈øe Rea≈øons it is that I think it nece≈ø≈øary that this Ingredient ≈øhould be added.

div.head: LIV. * Elleborus albus preparatus; White Hellebor prepared.
div.p: Bate.] It is done by affu≈øing the Water impregnated with Spirit or Oil of Vitriol, after the di≈ø≈øolution of Coral upon the Root reduced into pouder, dige≈øting for 24 hours and drying it, and repeating the woik thrice. Do≈øe √† ‚Ñà≈øs. ad í ≈øs.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It is the nature of Acids to de≈øtroy the emetick power of any mixture what≈øoever; and if they will do it in Antimonial Preparattons, as the Correction of Mercurius Vitae, much more may it be ≈øuppo≈øed to be done in meer Vegetable ‚Ä¢ roductions.

¬ß 2. And therefore as Vegetables are more porous, and apt for di≈ø≈øolution, than Metals or Minerals, ≈øo a weaker Acid may be employed in the performance of that Work; for if the ≈øtronge≈øt Acids (or Oils of Vitriol or Sulphur, &c.) were made u≈øe of, they would totally enervate and de≈øtroy all the Faculties and Operation of the Vegetable Mixt they ≈øhould be applied to.

¬ß 3. This Preparation is ≈øafe enough, and in many will work only downwards; but in ≈øome weak Stomachs, and where the Tone of the Vi≈øcera is debilitated or de≈øtroyed, it will (notwith≈øtanding all this preparation) work upwards.

¬ß 4. In this ca≈øe the Do≈øe ought to be a little larger, for this proportion will only make ≈øick, and ≈øcarcely induce Vomiting, whereby the Patient will truly be made more ≈øick and out of order (for want of its due Operation) than if a larger Do≈øe was given.

¬ß 5. It is de≈øigned again≈øt Melancholy, and all the Efforts of a Manical Di≈øpo≈øition of the Mind: it removes Vapors, and helps Ob≈øtructions of the Spleen and Hypochonders, re≈øtoring Rea≈øon and the Imagination to their right Stations and Habitudes.
¬ß 6. If you give it only as Cathartick, u≈øe it thus. ‚Ñû Jallap, Scammony, Ana, gr. vj. Of the prepared Hellebor √† gr. x. ad xx. mix for a Do≈øe.

¬ß 7. Or thus‚ñ™ Make an Infu≈øion of ‚Ñ•≈øs. of Sena in half a Pint of White-wine, ≈øtrain out, then add the Hellebor √† ‚Ñà≈øs. ad í ≈øs. for one Do≈øe to be taken in the morning fa≈øting again≈øt Melancholy.

¬ß 8. If you de≈øign it for a Vomit, you may give it either Per ≈øe, in any proper Vehicle, a gr. 15. ad ‚Ñàij. Or thus compounded. ‚Ñû White Hellebor prepared √† ‚Ñà≈øs. ad í ≈øs. Tartar Emetick a gr. i. ad ij. mix for a Do≈øe to be given in the morning fa≈øting with all the precautions of a Vomit.

div.head: LV. * Ens Veneris, The Ens or being of Venus.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû The Vitriol of Mars, well reverberated and wa≈øht, p. j. Sal-Armoniack, p. ij. mix and ≈øublime according to Art, with three Cohobations. It is an Anodyn, and pacifier: of admirable u≈øe in the Rickets, and to kill Worms in Children. It prevails again≈øt the Pleuri≈øie, and Hy≈øterick Fits. It al≈øo opens Ob≈øtructions, &c. Do≈øe, √† gr. iiij. ad xij.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is rather Ens Martis, or Ens Vitrioli Martis than Ens Veneris for as much as it is only Sal-Armoniack ≈øublimed from the Reverberated Vitriol of Mars, or the Caput Mortuum of the Vitriol after the Di≈øtillation of the Oil.
¬ß 2. It may al≈øo be made by ≈øubliming the Sal-Armoniack from the Reverberated Crocus Martis, and it will be no ways inferior to the former.

¬ß 3. And from the≈øe Flowers edulcorated, you may extract a Tincture with S. V. and then drawing off the S. V. you will have an E≈ø≈øence of Vitriol at Bottom: This as Ke≈øler ≈øays will precipitate Mercury.

¬ß 4. It may al≈øo be done thus. ‚Ñû Sal-Armoniack poudred, filings of Iron, Ana: mix them well and ≈øublime from Sand; ≈øo the faeces will be left at bottom, and the Sal-Armoniack will a≈øcend pure, impregnated with ≈øome of the Iron: mix the≈øe Flowers with the Caput Mort‚ñ™ again well, and ≈øublime as before, and the Flowers will contain more of the E≈ø≈øence of the Steel, and this work repeat four times at lea≈øt.

¬ß 5. By this means as the opening force of the Steel will be much ≈øharpned by the Sal-Armoniack, ≈øo the Sal-Arm. will more plentifully draw to it ≈øelf the Martial E≈ø≈øence, by which means the Medicament will be more ≈øucce≈øsful in Quartans, Hypochondriack Di≈øea≈øes, the Scurvy, and Hy≈øterick Di≈øpo≈øitions, and perfectly remove the Crudities of the Stomach, being drank in Wormwood-Wine, or other appropriate Liquor. Do≈øe √† gr. v. ad x.

¬ß 6. But here is to be noted, that if the Sal-Arm. be ≈øublimed from filings of Steel or Iron, the ≈øublimed Matter will be but little, or in ≈ømall quantity; but if you ≈øublime with a Gad of Iron, the Salt will a≈øcend of a yellowi≈øh red colour.
¬ß 7. Or thus. ‚Ñû Caput Mort. of Vitriol from which the Salt is drawn, mix it with an equal quantity of Sal-Armon. And ≈øublime it with a gradual Fire, till it a≈øcends or ≈ømoaks no more, Ba≈øil.

¬ß 8. ‚Ñû The Caput Mortuum of dried Vitriol, Sal-Armoniack in fine Pouder, A. mix them well in an Iron Mortar: put all into an Earthen Cucurbit, and ≈øublime in an open fire, ≈øo long as any thing will a≈øcend, which will be done in a few hours; the yellowi≈øh red Flowers gather carefully, and keep them without. edulcoration for u≈øe.

¬ß 9. The≈øe Flowers (≈øays Marggrave) contain the Anodyn Sulphur of Venus; which if edulcorated with fair Water, and repo≈øed for ≈øome days will fall to the bottom in a very red Pouder, which
Pouder Helmont knew how to bring to the ≈øweetne≈øs of Sugar, and appropriated it to the prolongation of Life.

¬ß 10. Or thus from the ≈øame Marggrave. ‚Ñû The red edulcorated Earth of Vitriol, Sal-Armoniack. A. lb ≈øs. make each apart into fine Pouder, which mix well, and ≈øublime a before: the Flowers ≈øeparate from the head with fair water; evaporate the water to dryne≈øs, with a very gentle fire, and in the bottom will remain the flowers of a very red colour, compo≈øed of the Sal-Armoniack and the Sulphur of Vitriol.

¬ß 11. This Sulphur (if you ≈øo plea≈øe) you may ≈øeparate from the Sal-Armoniack, if you dige≈øt the flowers with Alcohal of Wine, which is afterwards to be decanted, and evaporated, ≈øo will the pure Sulphur of Vitriol remain at bottom.

¬ß 12. It ≈øerves for many elaborate Arcanums of Chymi≈øts, and is called Ens pri
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ um Veneris (but then I pre≈øume it ought to be made of the Caput Mort. of the Vitriol of Venus) but is a chief Ingredient of the Lapis Butleri apud Helmontium, cujus de≈øcriptio in Helmontij libro Butl ‚Ä¢ r dicto, extat.

¬ß 13 This Ens Veneris, or rather Vitriolum Martis, powerfully opens Ob≈øtructions, and cures not only the Rickets (for which it is an approved Remedy) Pleuri≈øie, &c. but it is found to be a ≈øingular thing to cure Con≈øumptions in old or young, and to root out the Kings-Evil, tho' complicated with other Di≈øea≈øes; and indeed to eradicate many other Chronick Di≈øea≈øes, not to be prevailed upon with other Remedies.

div.head: LVI. Febrifugum Riverij, Riverius his Fever-frighter.
div.p:
Bate.] ‚Ñû Flowers of Antimony thrice thrice ≈øublimed with Sal-Armoniack, and edulcorated, Gla≈øs of Antimony precipitated (in ‚Ñ•iiij. of A. F. made of Nitre and Alum) Ana ‚Ñ•≈øs. Sol (di≈ø≈øolved in Aqua Regis) ‚Ñ•j. mix, and di≈øtil by a Retort gradatim to dryne≈øs, with twelve Cohobations: to the Pouder five times wa≈øhed and dryed, add the Alcohol of the S. V. lb ij. di≈øtil by a new Retort, cohobating ≈øix times: decant off at la≈øt the S. V. and put the Ma≈øs at bottom into a Crucible,
well luted in a fire of Rotation for three hours, then affu≈øe there on the afore di≈øtilled S. V. which burn off, S. A. Do≈øe gr. vj. ad xx. with an equal quantity of Scammony ≈øulphurated, &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Rolfincius Chym. Lib. 5. Sect. 6. Cap. 12. gives us the Recipe and it ≈øeems as if he was the fir≈øt Man which brought it to light: however his Proce≈øs ≈øomething differs from this of our Author, which you may take as follows.

¬ß 2. ‚Ñû Leaf-gold ‚Ñ•≈øs. di≈ø≈øolve it in A. R. Gla≈øs of Antimony ‚Ñ•≈øs. di≈ø≈øolved in A. F. Quick-≈øilver ‚Ñ•iij. di≈ø≈øolved in A. F. mix the≈øe Sollutions together, and di≈øtil by an Alembick, with twelve Cohobations: at la≈øt to the Pouder left in the bottom put S. V. which ab≈øtract from it ≈øix times, then calcine it upon a Tile, or in a Crucible, in a Circulary fire; ≈øo have you one of the be≈øt Remedies for an Ague yet known, chiefly for Tertians and Quartans.

¬ß 3. And he gives it thus. ‚Ñû Of this Powder ≈øix grains; Scammony 12 grains, mix for a Do≈øe to be given in the Morning the day before the Fit; or in the morning the ≈øame day, if the fit falls out towards night.

¬ß 4. But the Recipe of our Author is doubtle≈øs the be≈øt, and that which agrees mo≈øt with the Mind of the Riverius, if not the true thing it ≈øelf: however it is the ≈øame with that in the Arcana Riverij, publi≈øhed ≈øince his death, and adjoined to his Works in Folio, as you may ≈øee, pag. 601.

¬ß 5. But this is in the Arcana, which is not here in our Text, viz. That the Gla≈øs of Antimony be pellucid and hyacinthine: that the Mercury be ≈øuch as is revived from Cinnabar: and that the Pouder be wa≈øhed with ≈øome Cordial water: La≈øtly, That the Do≈øe of it is √† gr. vj. ad x. (in the Folio Impre≈ø≈øion) ad gr. xx. (in the Impre≈ø≈øion of Twelves) mixt with Ro≈øin of Scammony, or Scammony ≈øulphurated, √† gr. xiij. ad gr. 25. according to ≈øtrength.
¬ß 6. Or thus. ‚Ñû Of this Pouder gr. vj. Scammony gr. ix. Gambogia, gr. v. Ro≈øin of Jalap gr. iij. mix for a Do≈øe to be given in the morning fa≈øting, or ≈øix hours before the Fit.

div.head: LVII. Flores Antimonii; Flowers of Antimony.
div.p: Bate.] Sublime Antimony with a ≈øtrong Fire, either per≈øe, or mixed with Sand, or calcined Tartar; the very white Flowers gather and keep them for u≈øe. They ≈øometimes provoke Vomiting. Do≈øe gr. 2. ad 4. they are al≈øo ≈øudori≈øick.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. We have explained the whole Proce≈øs at large in our Pharmacopoeia Londinen≈øis, Lib. 3. cap. 8. Sect. 75. with ≈øeveral Ob≈øervations thereon, ≈øo that no more need be ≈øaid of that Method in this place.
¬ß 2. But ≈øince there are other methods and ways of doing it, and that that Book may not be at ≈øome times in the Reader's Hand, we ≈øhall here deliver other Proce≈ø≈øes from variety of Authors.

¬ß 3. ‚Ñû Pouder of Crude Antimony, put it into an earthen Still, ≈øet it deep in Sand, fit an Alembick with a Neck and Receiver to it, or add three or four Necks one within another, make a gradual Fire, not too ≈øtrong, nor too weak; If you order the Fire aright you will have white, yellow, and red Flowers; and Flegm in the Receiver. Thus Schroder from Sennertus.

¬ß 4. Now here is to be noted, That Beguinus u≈øes Stibium or Gla≈øs of Antimony in fine Pouder in≈øtead of Crude Antimony, but in my Opinion the latter may do well enough; and he ≈øublimes by degrees of fire, ten or twelve hours, whereby he rai≈øes the white Flowers; and twenty four hours to rai≈øe the yellow Flowers: and thirty ≈øix hours by which he rai≈øes the red Flowers, the fire being all the time continued and augmented.

¬ß 5. This Sublimation ≈øays the Commentator on Beguinus may be commodiou≈øly done in a ≈øhort time, from an Earthen Cucurbit with a gentle fire from Crude Antimony in Pouder, ob≈øerving Schroder's Directions, which are,
¬ß 6. That the Cucurbit may may have a pipe in its ≈øide, by which you may ca≈øt in the Pouder of the Antimony, by degrees with a Spoon or other fit In≈øtrument, and ≈øo fired by degrees.
¬ß 7. That the Cucurbit be ≈øet oblique in the Furnace, that the Tube may a≈øcend perpendicular.

¬ß 8. That you may ≈øublime in a wind Fornace, and mix with Antimony ‚Ñ•ij. Sand ‚Ñ•iij. Others mix Pouder of Charcole with the antimony, and draw forth the Sulphur, a blew Matter remaining at bottom, in which is the Mercury of Antimony.
¬ß 9. That a little hole be in the top of the Alembick, and this you mu≈øt ob≈øerve, or you will do all in vain.
¬ß 10. The Receiver ≈øhould have a Hole or Canale into another Receiver, through which the Acid flegm may fall, for if there be not a hole for the Wind to go forth, your labour will be in vain.
¬ß 11. If you govern the fire rightly ≈øays Hofman, you will have three kinds of Flowers, viz: white, yellow, and red, according to the diver≈øity of the In≈øtruments.

¬ß 12. The≈øe red Flowers of Antimony are not to be u≈øed in Phy≈øick, unle≈øs they be fir≈øt Corrected, as Glukradius rightly affirms; and the white Flowers, if they be circulated with S. V. loo≈øe their emetick Property, and work only by Stool, Beguinus.

¬ß 13. Le Mort makes them thus. Take a tubulated Retort with a long and wide Neck which being red-hot, ca≈øt into it by degrees in ≈ømall Spoonfuls Antimony in Pouder; and with a Pair of Bellows blow ≈øo that the humid Matter may be forced into the Receiver: when the fumes cea≈øe put in more Antimony, and this continue ≈øo long, till you have a quantity ≈øufficient.

¬ß 14. Where note, That without the Bellows, the Flowers would ri≈øe, but more ≈ølowly; and that being done in this manner, almo≈øt all the Antimony will a≈øcend in flowers, except a little only remaining at bottom. That the Fire be the more ≈øtrong. otherwi≈øe the Operation will be hindred, and the Flowers will ≈øcarcely a≈øcend. That you beware of the fumes, for they are commonly mortal.

¬ß 15. The Action of the≈øe Flowers vary according to their colour and fixity the white≈øt and lighte≈øt work by Vomit and Stool, violently enough, and are given, √† gr. j. ad iv. The yellow Flowers ≈øays Le Mort do the ≈øame more gently, and therefore he gives them, √† gr. ij. ad vi.

¬ß 16. But in this I fear he was mi≈øtaken, for if you will believe Thibaut, he affirms, That the white contain nothing of the Venomous Sulphur
of the Antimony, but a good quantity of the Volatile Salt, and therefore are of its colour; provoking Sweat, and ≈øometimes Vomiting, √† gr. iij. ad vij. The yellow contain a little of the ≈øaid Sulphur, and are therefore ≈øomewhat tinged, containing a part of the Body of the Regulus, and a little of the Volatile Salt; the≈øe provoke vomiting with violence. The red Flowers abound much with the ≈øaid malignant Sulphur, and are therefore highly died; the≈øe cau≈øe Vomiting with Convul≈øions, and many times the Death of the Patient, and therefore are no ways to be given inwardly till corrected.
¬ß 17. The≈øe red Flowers ≈øays Le Mort, ≈øticking to the Neck are ea≈øily fixed into a Sudorifick Pouder with Spirit of Nitre, and then they may be given in ≈øome proper Bolus, √† gr. iv. ad x.

¬ß 18. But if any of the kinds of Flowers be u≈øed uncorrected, it is much better to u≈øe their Infu≈øion in Wine, than their Sub≈øtance becau≈øe of their Violence. One of the late Duke of Buckingham's Servants was killed with a ≈øingle Do≈øe of them, given by an Outlandi≈øh Phy≈øician: he was a young lu≈øty Man, and as ≈øtrong and likely to live as any Man in London, but the fatal Do≈øe being given he never cea≈øed Vomiting till he died, and the Vomiting was accompanied with dreadful Convul≈øions. The Duke ≈øent for me, but too late, I came ≈øo as to ≈øee the mi≈øerable Object alive, but 'twas ≈øo wretched a ≈øight as my Eyes never beheld before, and in a few hours after he expired. As I remember he was the Porter at the Gate at Wallingford Hou≈øe.

¬ß 19. Rolfincius Chym. Lib. 5. Sect. 6. Cap. 2. Makes them thus. ‚Ñû Choice Hungarian Antimony lb j. pouder it and put it into a Cucurbit with its Aludel, or two or three Earthen-pots ≈øuperimpo≈øed, the uppermo≈øt of which let it have a ≈ømall hole in its top, for ≈øo the Flowers will the more freely a≈øcend, but without it with ≈øome difficulty; increa≈øe the Fire to the ≈øecond degree, and gather the Flowers.
¬ß 20. The≈øe ≈øaith he purge vehemently by Vomit, and therefore are not to be given alone without correction: they are rarely given, becau≈øe much ≈øafer Vomits, are commonly near at hand.

¬ß 21. Lemery makes them thus, ‚Ñû A good unglazed Earthen-pot, with a ho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ in its ≈øide (about the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ dd ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ f
its height) and a ≈øtopple to it, ≈øet it in a Furnace of an equal proportion, and fit to it three Pots more of the ≈øame Earth, all open at the bottom, and fill a Gla≈øs-head to the uppermo≈øt Pot, without any Receiver (for there is no Liquor to fall into it, ≈øo that a blind head might do.) Lute the Junctures well, and let the Fire tran≈øpire only through ≈øome little holes, and be but ≈øtrong enough to warm the bottom of the lowermo≈øt Pot, then give fire gradatim to heat this Pot, by little and little till it is red hot; which done ca≈øt into it a ≈ømall Spoonful of Antimony through the hole, and ≈øtir the Matter at the bottom of the Pot with a crooked Iron Spatula, which pre≈øently draw out, and ≈øtop the hole, ≈øo will the Flowers ri≈øe and ≈øtick in the upper Pots: Continue a great Fire, that the Pot may ≈øtill remain red hot, and when you ≈øee nothing more ≈øublime, ca≈øt in ≈øo much more Antimony doing as before: this ca≈øting in repeat through the hole, ≈øo long till you have Flowers enough: let the fire go out, and when cold unlute the Ve≈ø≈øels, and you'll find the Flowers all about the three upper Pots and the Head, gather them together with a Feather, and keep them in a Vial for u≈øe.
¬ß 22. The≈øe Flowers ≈øays he are powerfully Emetick, and given in Quartan-Agues and other intermitting Fevers, and in the Falling-≈øickne≈øs: Do≈øe √† gr. ij. ad vj. in Lozenges or Broth.

¬ß 23. In this Preparation we ought to have room enough; otherwi≈øe the Flowers of Antimony being forced by the Fire, would be apt to break the Ve≈ø≈øel for want of room to move in; and this is the Rea≈øon why ≈øo many Pots are thus placed one upon another.

¬ß 24. Le Febure makes them wholly after the ≈øame Method, with three or four Pots, but without a Gla≈øs-head, the uppermo≈øt having a hole of an Inch diameter, which he as need requires ≈øtops with a piece of Clay, and at the end of your Operation you will find the Antimony ≈øublimed in gray, white, yellow, and ≈øometimes red Flowers, according to the management of the Fire.

¬ß 25. The≈øe Flowers (≈øays he) are not much in u≈øe, by rea≈øon of their violent Operation, for they are properly the Sulphur of the Antimony; but they are fit to prepare other Remedies after due correction. They may neverthele≈øs be admini≈øtred √† gr. ij.
ad iv. in Con≈øerve of Ro≈øes; or make an Infu≈øion of them in White-wine.

¬ß 26. But to make the≈øe Flowers more gentle you mu≈øt ≈øublime thus. ‚Ñû Pouder of Regulus of Antimony (which is already deprived of mo≈øt part of its impure Sulphur) pouder of pure Sal-Armoniack A lb ≈øs. mix and put them into a Gla≈øs-body in Sand cover it with its Head, and a fit Receiver, lute the Junctures, and give five till all is a≈øcended; ≈øo will you have Flowers of a yellow Colour, which edulcorate by wa≈øhing and keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 27. The≈øe are much gentler than the former, and are given to lunatick or mad People, ≈øuch as are melancholy, or are afflicted with Quartan-Agues. Do≈øe √† gr. ij. ad vj. in Con≈øerve of Ro≈øes, or in an Infu≈øion in Wine or Ale.
¬ß 28. In this Operation, the Sal-Armoniack carries along with it, the pure≈øt Sulphur and Mercury of the Antimony.

¬ß 29. You may al≈øo put the ≈øimple Flowers ‚Ñ•iij. with pure Nitre ‚Ñ•iv. into a crucible in the open Fire, and edulcorate them afterwards, then dige≈øt them with S.V. for fiveteen days, and deflagrating the Spirit, you will have a diaphoretical Pouder of excellent u≈øe for purifying the Blood, being given √† gr. vj. ad vij.

¬ß 30. The Correction of Flowers of Antimony. ‚Ñû Pure white and ≈øubtil Flowers ‚Ñ•j. Salt of Tartar of Sennertus ‚Ñ•j≈øs. mix and put them into a good Crucible, and with a ≈øtrong Fire melt them in a Wind-fornace, ≈øo will they turn to ared lump: reduce it to a Pouder in a hot Mortar, adding to it a di≈ø≈øolluble magi≈øtery of Pearl and Coral, A. ‚Ñ•ij≈øs. put all into a Matre≈øs and affu≈øe thereon S. V. aromatiz'd with Spices) ≈øo much as to overtop it four Inches: cover the Matre≈øs with a blind Head, and dige≈øt in a Sand heat for three days, after which ab≈øtract the S. V. in B. M. ≈øo will you have a well corrected and plea≈øant Antimony, which keep in a Vial well ≈øtopt for u≈øe, for otherwi≈øe in the Air it would melt.

¬ß 31. Do≈øe √† gr. iv. ad xvj. in ≈øome proper Vehicle, again≈øt all inveterate Di≈øea≈øes chiefly again≈øt the ≈øtronge≈øt and mo≈øt ≈øtubborn Impre≈ø≈øions of Melancholy, intermitting Fevers or Agues, and all kinds of Ob≈øtructions: it works variou≈øly, according to the Matter it meets with in the Stomach; for it ≈øometimes
provokes Vomiting, but not always; it al≈øo purges by Stool and Urine, but its chief Operation is by in≈øen≈øible tran≈øpiration, for by irradiation, and emanation of its Vertue, it ≈øtrengthens all the Natural dige≈øtions, and cau≈øes the internal Archaeus to drive away or expel from the Center to the Circumference all the ob≈øtructing Particles, and what≈øoever is de≈øtructive or hurtful to the Health, Life, and Welfare of the humane Frame.

¬ß 32. Lemery has al≈øo red Flowers of Antimony, which are chiefly the more Sulphurous parts of the Antimony rarified by fire. ‚Ñû Antimony in Pouder lb j. common Gla≈øs in pouder lb iv. mix and put them into a coated Gla≈øs Retort, ≈øo as it may be but half full, ≈øet in a Reverberatory Furnace, fit to it a large Receiver, luting the Juncture, give fire at fir≈øt but to warm the Retort, and augment it gradatim, ≈øo will red Flowers come forth into the Receiver, continue the fire till all is come forth, then gather the Flowers and keep them for u≈øe.

¬ß 33. The≈øe are more emetick than any of the former, and are to be u≈øed with much caution; but the ≈øafe≈øt way is fir≈øt to correct them as is before taught. The red colour proceeds from the great quantity of Sulphur with which they are ≈øo added.

¬ß 34. In taking the≈øe Flowers of Antimony, or any other Antimonial Emetick, you ought often to drink Broth or Po≈ø≈øet-drink, both to facilitate the Vomiting, and dull the activity of the Medicine: but becau≈øe it ≈øometimes happens that Antimonial Pouders ≈øticking on the Membranes or Tunicles of the Stomach, or ≈øome of its folds, does cau≈øe a continual Vomiting, notwith≈øtanding the continual u≈øe of Broths, you mu≈øt then add the Cream of Tartar, and di≈ø≈øolve it in the Broth ≈øcalding hot, and which is ≈øo hot to be taken a quarter of a Pint at a time, every quarter of an Hour; ≈øo the Acid of the Tartar joyning with the Sulphur of the Antimony, fixes them, and ≈øo ≈øtops the Vomiting, making the remaining part of the Operation by Stool.

¬ß 35. Lemery has al≈øo another Preparation of Flowers of Antimony, which you may ≈øee at large at Sect. XXIV. ¬ß 25. and 26. of this Chapter afore-going being ≈øublimed with Nitre; the≈øe Flowers will not be ≈øo emetick
as others tho' unwa≈øht, becau≈øe the Acid of the Nitre which ari≈øes with them, hinders their activity.

¬ß 36. And as you make Flowers from the Regulus with Sal-Armoniack, at ¬ß 26. above, ≈øo al≈øo may you make Flowers from the Gla≈øs of Antimony, and from Crocus Metallorum and Regulus Martis having the ≈øame Vertues with tho≈øe Flowers from the Regulus afore≈øaid. The≈øe Flowers, ≈øays Rolfincius purge „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , ≈øur≈øum & deor≈øum, upwards and downwards.

¬ß 37. Charras makes his Flowers after Lemery's Method, whether ≈øimple or mixt, with Nitre, or Sal-Armoniack; ≈øave that in ≈øubliming with Sal-Armoniack, he takes double the quantity or weight of Salt to the quantity or weight of Antimony, whether it be Crude Antimony, Vitrum, Crocus, or Regulus.

¬ß 38. And he affirms, that the diver≈øity which happens to Flowers of Antimony in ≈øeveral or the ≈øame Preparations or Sublimations, as to their colours being white, yellow, or red, in re≈øpect to their vomitive or purgative Qualities may be u≈øed all alike, provided they be well wa≈øht or dulcified: And (≈øays he) ≈øometimes a Grain of the≈øe Flowers is mixed among other Purgatives, or with Mercurius dulcis upon certain occa≈øions; for ≈øerving as a Spur to tho≈øe Remedies with which it is mixt, it a≈ø≈øi≈øts their activity, working only downwards.

¬ß 39. Zwelfer's Method (which is that which Le Mort ≈øeems to imitate) is thus. Get a Retort made almo≈øt like a Ball or Globe, having two Pipes more on each ≈øide of the middle, place it in a proper Furnace (≈øee the Figure) and kindle under it a fire ≈øufficient to melt the Antimony, which put in by one of the Pipes, fitting a Receiver to the other Pipe, having a little hole in its hinder part, and when the Vapours begin to appear in the Recipient, blow gently with a ≈ømall pair of Bellows into the oppo≈øite Pipe to the Recipient, ≈øo will the Vapours forced there into, conden≈øe there, in Flowers, Manti≈ø. Spagyr. Cap. 6, and 8, pag. 817, 833.

¬ß 40. Margrave prepares the Flowers thus. ‚Ñû Crude Antimony in pouder ‚Ñ•iij. put it into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit with its head, on which affu≈øe Spirit of Nitre Bezoardick, or Aqua Regia for the di≈ø≈øolving
of Antimony ‚Ñ•ix. or xij. or ≈øo much till the Efferve≈øcence cea≈øes: ≈øhake the Gla≈øs till they are well mingled, cover it with its head till (which a great Efferve≈øcence and Ebulition) the Antimony in the bottom of the Gla≈øs is reduced into a very white Sub≈øtance: then by affu≈øion of a great quantity of Water precipitate the whole Ma≈øs, ≈øo will the Water become milky, and a yellow pouder (which is an inflamable Sulphur of Antimony) precipitate to the bottom: decant immediately this white water from the ≈øaid Pouder, and let it re≈øt till the whitene≈øs ≈øettles to the bottom; decaut off the clear water; and ≈øo the white Matter left at bottom affu≈øe more fair Water, and edulcorate it by many wa≈øhings: then filter through brown Paper, and the white Coagulum left behind dry by a gentle fire, and make into fine Pouder, which keep for u≈øe.
¬ß 41. The≈øe are called the white fixed Flowers of Antimony; and they purge by Stool only, and that gently, and not by Vomit, from which Operation they are called fixed. Do≈øe gr. iij. or iv.

¬ß 42. La≈øtly, Ma√´t's prepares them thus. ‚Ñû Flowers of Antimony fixed by a continued flame into the highe≈øt redne≈øs; Sal-Armeniack Ana. mix and ≈øublime them together; ≈øo will a part of the Flowers a≈øcend: to that remains in the bottom add Sal-Armoniack Ana. and ≈øublime as before, continue this Work till the greate≈øt part of the Flowers are ≈øublimed with the Salt. gather the Flowers together, and edulcorate them by much wa≈øhing with fair water.
¬ß 43. They have the Vertues of all the other, but are accounted ≈øafer, and may be given √† gr. j. ad iv. They al≈øo ≈øerve for the Preparation of the E≈ø≈øence of Antimony.

div.head: LVIII. Flores Antimonii Diaphoretici; Sweating Flowers of Antimony.
div.p: Bate.] They are made of Antimony ≈øprinkled with Oil of Sulphur, and calcined in a clo≈øe Crucible, S. A. They have the ≈øame Vertues with the former.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. You have the Proce≈øs more at large in Sala his Anatomy of Antimony, S. 3. but there is no difficulty in it, and therefore needs no great Explication;
≈øave that you may perform the Operation with a Coal fire.
¬ß 2. Some affu≈øe thereon Spirit or Oil of Vitriol, which is again ab≈øtracted, then edulcorated and calcin'd with a red-hot Heat.
¬ß 3. The≈øe Flowers are le≈øs Emetick than the former, and ≈øweat more, and may be given √† gr. j. ad vj. in Con≈øerve of Ro≈øes, Mithridate, or other proper Vehicle.

div.head: LIX. Flores Benzoini, Flowers of Benjamin.
div.p: Bate] They are made of the Pouder of the be≈øt Benjamin, being put into a Gla≈øs Ve≈ø≈øel, and covered with a double Paper Pyramid, ≈øubliming with a gentle fire S. A. the Flowers adhering to the Paper (by often changing the Pyramid) are to be ≈øwept off for u≈øe. See the London Di≈øpen≈øatory. They are admirable Pulmonicks, Bechikiks and Antia≈øtmaticks, ≈øtop Catarrhs, and provoke Sweat. Do≈øe √† gr. v. ad xij.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. A ≈ømall hole ought to be in the top of the Pyramid, for there by the Flowers will the more ea≈øily a≈øcend.

¬ß 2. Every half hour, if the fire be ≈øtrong enough the Flowers are to be removed with a Feather, for which rea≈øon you ought to have two of the Pyramids at lea≈øt, that the ≈øecond may be put on while the other is a clearing.

¬ß 3. The≈øe Flowers which are only the lighter and purer re≈øinous parts of the Benjamin, or an Exaltation of the Volatile Salt of the Benjamin, white and almo≈øt like Snow, are to be gathered and kept in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt.

¬ß 4. The ≈øign of the ab≈øolute Sublimation is when the Paper or Alembick ≈øhall appear to be moi≈øtned with the Oily parts of the Benjamin, for then all the Flowers are a≈øcended, that are po≈ø≈øible to a≈øcend pure.

¬ß 5. From lb j. of pure Benjamin you will not have above ‚Ñ• ij. of pure Flowers, which are very profitable in A≈øthma's, and in all Di≈øtempers of the Brea≈øt and Lungs; they al≈øo provoke Sweat, and may be given a ‚Ñà≈øs. ad ‚Ñàj.

¬ß 6. From the≈øe Flowers a Tincture may thus be prepared. ‚Ñû S. V. Twice di≈øtilled from Carminatices ‚Ñ•j. Flowers of Benjamin í ij. mix,
dige≈øt with a very gentle fire in a bolt head, till the Tincture is of a yellow colour. It is much more powerful than the ≈øimple Flowers, di≈øcu≈ø≈øes Wind, cures inveterate Coughs, difficulty of Breathing, and the Cholick. Do≈øe √† gut. vj. ad xx.

¬ß 7. An E≈ø≈øence of Benjamin. ‚Ñû Flowers of Benjamin í ij. be≈øt Styrax Calamita í j. Oil of Rhodium, or Je≈ø≈øamy, or rather of Damask Ro≈øes gut. iv. Civet, gr. ij. Musk gr. ij. mix the Civet and Storax with the Oil, which put into a Phial, putting thereon, the Flowers of Benjamin; S. V. rectified ‚Ñ•ij. vel q. s. dige≈øt two days, then decant the clear and keep it for u≈øe.
¬ß 8. Where note, That if a little Salt of Tartar be mixed with it before dige≈øtion, the Tincture will be the more ea≈øily extracted.

¬ß 9. It is a mo≈øt egregious perfume, by which Cloaths, Gloves, Linen, &c. may be made odoriferous in this manner. ‚Ñû Damask Ro≈øe-water, or other Odoriferous-water, as Orange Flower-water ‚Ñ•j. of this Tincture gut. 40. mix them: and therewith moi≈øten the things you would perfume, drying them in the Shadow.

¬ß 10. Le Febure makes the Flowers after the ≈øame manner, and ≈øays, that they po≈ø≈øe≈øs a Volatile ≈øulphurous Salt, very ≈øubtil and penetrating; for as ≈øoon as there is heat enough to drive it out from its Body, it invades the No≈øe, Eyes, and Brea≈øt, by rea≈øon of its ≈øubtil and volatile Salt, in which lies all the Power and Activity of the Benjamin.

¬ß 11. Thibaut makes them thus. ‚Ñû Benjamin in pouder, q. v. put into a Crucible, proportioned to the quantity of your Matter, ≈øo as it may be but half full, put your Crucible into an Iron ring which has two Arms, one on each ≈øide, which place upon a ≈øecond row of Bricks of a Circulatory Furnace, ≈øo that your Crucible may be ≈øu≈øpended in the middle of the Furnace, and the fire may immediately ≈øtrike upon it fit to the top of your Furnace an Earthen Pyramid, much like a Sugar Loaf, as broad in the bottom as the Furnace, with a ≈ømall hole in its top to give the Fire air, lute it to the Furnace, and make a moderate fire, ≈øo will the Flowers ari≈øe in dry fumes and ≈øtick to the ≈øides of the Pyramid in form of white Snow, or Meal-du≈øt: at half an hours end take off the Cap≈øula
or Pyramid, and with a Feather gather all the Flowers, which pre≈øently ≈øtop clo≈øe up in a Gla≈øs bottle, and in the Crucible there will be remaining nothing but black, oily Faeces.

¬ß 12. Now the Rea≈øon why he applies the Cap≈øula to the brim of the Furnace, and not the brim of the Crucible is, le≈øt the heat ≈øtriking the out-≈øide thereof ≈øhould make the Flowers melt and re≈øolve into their fir≈øt Nature; but to this I an≈øwer, That if the Heat ≈øtriking on the out-≈øide thereof ≈øhould endanger the melting of the Flowers; much more, would it do it, when it has the liberty of ≈øtriking within, where the Flowers are.

¬ß 13. The≈øe Flowers mu≈øt be white, becau≈øe it is their volatile Salt, which predominates over them, and which con≈øequently inve≈øts them with that colour, which is natural to all ≈øimple Flowers. but particularly to volatile Salts.

¬ß 14.
