Lemery makes it thus. ‚Ñû An Earthen pot or Crucible high and narrow, with a little Border round it, put into it ‚Ñ•iv. of pure Benjamin gro≈øly poudered, cover the Pot with a Pyramid of Paper, and tie it round about under the Border; ≈øet the Pot into hot A≈øhes, and when the Benjamin is heated, the Flowers will a≈øcend, take off‚ñ™ the Pyramid every two hours, and fix another in its place, putting the Flowers up quickly into a Gla≈øs, which ≈øtop clo≈øe: continue this Sublimation, till the Flowers begin to appear Oily, and then cea≈øe: put what remains into a little Gla≈øs Retort, fitted with a Receiver and di≈øtil off a thick fragrant Oil, in a Sand heat, till nothing more comes forth, there remaining in the Retort nothing but a ≈øpungy Earth.

¬ß 15. Benjamin being a Sub≈øtance full of Volatile parts ea≈øily ≈øublimes over the ≈ømalle≈øt Fire, the Flowers ari≈øing in little white needles; but if the Fire be never ≈øo little too much, the Oil will a≈øcend with them in ≈øome ≈ømall quantity, which will make them yellow and impure; you mu≈øt therefore do the Operation in hot A≈øhes or Sand, to have the Flowers fair. They have a plea≈øing Acidity, and are allowed by Lemery to be given but √† gr. ij. ad v. other Authors allow them to be given to 20 grains.

¬ß 16. Flos (Dixit Rolfincius) aequivocum e≈øt vocabulum, & variis rebus accomodatur:
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
flos ≈øalis in Nitrariis & ≈øalinis invenitur officinis, aeris in aerariis, farinae in Molendinis, lactis, qui & Cremor, in pecuariis, ‚Äî in Chymicis erga≈øteriis flores nominantur tenuiores & ≈øubtiliores partes Corporis, √† Cra≈øcioreper ≈øublimationem ≈øeparatae.

¬ß 17. Rolfincius, Beguinus, Schroder, Le Mort, Charras, and almo≈øt the whole herd of Authors, follow one and the ≈øame way of making the≈øe Flowers, which is that of Lemery's at ¬ß 14. aforegoing: but there is another way by Di≈øtillation, wherein they are made in greater plenty, which according to Charras his Method is this.

¬ß 18. ‚Ñû Choice Benjamin lb j. in pouder, put it into a large Gla≈øs Retort, and affu≈øe thereon good S. V. lb iij. ≈øtir and incorporate them well together; lute to it a Ve≈ø≈øel of Rencounter; and keep the Retort twenty four hours with the neck upright upon a gentle Sand heat, ≈øhaking the Sub≈øtances often, to ha≈øten the di≈ø≈øolution of the Ro≈øin in the Spirit; which done, place the Retort in a Sand heat fitting to its beak a middle ≈øiz'd Receiver, and with a gentle fire first di≈øtil off the S. V. after which the Flowers will a≈øcend; but as ≈øoon as they appear, change the Receiver, which let be dry, and lute it ≈ølightly, that you may be able to draw out from time to time the Flowers, (which you must immediately ≈øtop clo≈øe up in a Gla≈øs) putting another Receiver in its place, which now you may lute up very exactly, and continue the fire, ≈øo will a thick Liquor di≈øtil from the Retort, which is the fir≈øt Oil of Benjamin: if you continue ≈øtill the fire you will have an Acid Liquor, and after that a yellow, clear and odoriferous Oil, and then la≈øtly an Oil thick and greazy.

¬ß 19. Le Febure makes the Flowers by di≈øtillation after the ≈øame manner, but he advi≈øes, 1. To rectified S. V. lb iv. 2. To dige≈øt five whole days. 3. To di≈øtil in a great large Retort having a long and broad Neck. 4. To put into the Ingredients pure clean Sand lb j. Scales of Iron falling from the Anvil lb ≈øs. 5. The Retort to be ≈øo large as not be above ‚Öì part full, 6. To lute the Juncture with a wet Bladder, that it may the ea≈øier be removed in changing the Receiver. 7. That the fire be
≈øoft at fir≈øt and increa≈øt but little, ≈ølowly and by degrees. 8. That the S. V. and a new Receiver being put to for the Flowers, the Juncture is not to be luted, becau≈øe it must be often taken off to gather the Flowers out of the mouth of the Retort le≈øt they ≈øhould wholly ≈øtop it, and ≈øo break it. 9. That the fir≈øt Flowers are the white≈øt and pure≈øt. 10. That when the buttery Sub≈øtance begins to come, you may then lute the Juncture again with a wet Bladder, and increa≈øe the fire a little, that all the Acid and Mercurial Liquor may follow the Butter: which done. 11. That then the Receiver is to be charged again, to receive the true Oil of Benjamin, which will be of a fragrant Odor, and yellow colour, ≈øomewhat re≈øembling a Hyacinth. 12. That when the drops begin to appear red, you mu≈øt immediately ≈øub≈øtitute a new Receiver, which is to take the thick and dark Bal≈øam, which in this Work is the la≈øt action of the Fire.

¬ß 20. Thus according to Le Febure there is, 1. a S. V. impregnated with a portion of the volatile, ≈øulphurous and ≈øpiritual Salt of the Benjamin. 2. The Volatile Salt or Flowers in the neck of the Retort. 3. A Butter-like Oil, which is the gro≈ø≈øe≈øt part of the Salt and Sulphur. 4. A ≈ømall quantity of Mercurial acid Spirit. 5. The Odoriferous yellow or Hyacinth Oil, which will be but little. 6. A thick blacki≈øh Bal≈øam.

¬ß 21. This S. V. alone and without mixture, or adding any more of the Gum to it may ≈øerve for an Excellent Co≈ømetick, becau≈øe it is already filled and impregnated with the Volatile Salt of the Benjamin, in which the deter≈øive, mundifying and re≈øolutive Vertue of the Benjamin does confi≈øt; and is more powerful than the vulgar Tincture, becau≈øe that is mixt with the unctuous Body of the Benjamin which ≈øtops the Pores and dries the Skin. And with this Spirit, a famous Tincture may be drawn from the Flowers of Benjamin (if pure and white, and dive≈øted of their thick Oily parts) after the manner as is before declared at ¬ß 6.

¬ß 22. The Flowers or Volatile Salt of Benjamin are Pulmonick, Antia≈øtmatick, Sudorifick, and a great Specifick again≈øt the French Pox, if given √† gr. vj. ad xx. in a Gla≈øs of Infu≈øion of Sa≈ø≈øafras
in Wine, or a Decoction of Sar≈øa, China, and Guajacum bark; for it is a Searcher which immediately penetrates the whole Body.

¬ß 23. The Buttery Oil is Vulnerary, and contains a portion of the Flowers, which you may thus ≈øeperate. ‚Ñû Of the white≈øt Butter of Benjamin ‚Ñ•j. di≈ø≈øolve it in boiling water, and immediately filter the Liquor through Paper, ≈øo will the Flowers be in≈øtantly coagulated under the hand: then draw back again the white Water by inclination, and let it ≈øettle, and you ≈øhall have in the bottom, a Magi≈øtery, of equal Vertue, with that made by precipitation of the Tincture: let the Flowers dry, and the Magi≈øtery ≈ølowly and lei≈øurely between double Paper, and keep it for u≈øe.
¬ß 24. The Mercurial Spirit, is an Antidote again≈øt Malignity and Venom, and proper again≈øt the Poy≈øon of the Pox. Do≈øe gut. 20. ad 30.

¬ß 25. The Odoriferous Oil, be≈øides its excellency for making Perfumes, is an admirable Vulnerary, and has all the Vertues of the Salt, and may be given √† gut. iij. ad x. in any proper Vehicle. A Perfume may be thus made with it. ‚Ñû Of the Odoriferous Oil ‚Ñ•≈øs. pure Salt of Tartar ‚Ñ•j. Butter of Benjamin ‚Ñ•j. mix and grind them well together in a Mortar, to which add this: ‚Ñû Musk gr. x. Ambergrea≈øe gr. vj. Civet gr. iij. Salt of Tartar ‚Ñà≈øs. mix or grind them together, and mix it with the former: Of this: Tincture may be made with rectified S. V. for perfuming Cloaths, Gloves, &c.

¬ß 26. The thick blacki≈øs Bal≈øam, is al≈øo an excellent good Vulnerary, and has a real Excellency for curing Punctures of the Nerves, old Sores, running Ulcers and the like: and if it be applied to Gouts, Sciaticaes, Aches or Pains proceeding from a cold Cau≈øe it cures them to admiration. It is al≈øo prevalent again≈øt Pal≈øies, Contractions of the Nerves, Cramps, Weakne≈ø≈øes, and other Di≈øtempers of the Nerves; ≈øo that in the≈øe ca≈øes there are not many Remedies more effectual: put into a hollow Tooth it ea≈øes the Pain thereof, and dropt into the Ears (mixt with Oil of Ben) it helps Deafne≈øs, noi≈øe and pain in the Ears, &c.

div.head: LX. Flores Bi≈ømuthi, Flowers of Bi≈ømuth, Marca≈øite, or Tin-Gla≈øs
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Marca≈øite calcin'd, Sal-Armoniack. Ana; mix and ≈øublime S. A. It is „Äà‚óä„Äâ celebrated Co≈ømetick to whiten the Skin, being mixed with a double quantity of Pomatum: it is good again≈øt Cutaneous defections, as Tettars, Ring-worms, Pu≈øtules, &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. In a word (≈øays Le Mort) the Flowers of Bi≈ømuth, Znick, &c. are made exactly in the ≈øame manner as Flowers of Antimony; but you have another way of preparing the Flowers in our London Di≈øpen≈øatory, Lib. 3. Cap. 10. Sect. 11. according to Schroder's Method.

¬ß 2. Bi≈ømuth is a ≈øulphurous Marca≈øite found in the Tin Mines, being nothing but the Excrement of a Metal Or an Earth impregnated with Metalick parts, Or an imperfect Tin, mixt with a good quantity of Ar≈øenick: There are ≈øeveral kinds of it, but the principal one Bi≈ømuth and Zinck, of each of which, like preparations are made.

¬ß 3. Lemery makes them thus. Calcine Bi≈ømuth as you do Lead, then mixing it with equal parts of Sal-Armoniack proceed to its Sublimation, as you do in that of Tin following: So will you have Flowers which you may di≈ø≈øolve in Water, and precipitate with Spirit of Sal-Armoniack, or Oil of Tartar per deliquium.

¬ß 4. Le Febure makes them after this manner. ‚Ñû Bi≈ømuth (as it comes from the Mine, and before it has ever felt the fire) in fine Pouder lb. j. New White-wine lb. ij. mix and dige≈øt in a double Ve≈ø≈øel the ≈øpace of three days: after which, decant the Wine and affu≈øe lb ij. more in the place: and this Work repeat the third and fourth time: The fourth part of the Wine dige≈øted affu≈øe on the Marca≈øite in a Cucurbit, which place in Sand, and cover it with an Alembick, draw off the Men≈øtruum with a moderate heat to dryne≈øs: cohabate it with another fourth part, and di≈øtil off to dryne≈øs; and ≈øo proceed with the third fourth part, and the last fourth part; di≈øtilling to dryne≈øs. When all the Moi≈øture is come over, increa≈øe the fire, and there will ≈øublime into the head ≈øilvered Flowers, which you may keep without any farther preparation
in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt; or being put into a Cellar upon a Gla≈øs Plate, they will di≈ø≈øolve into an Oily Liquor.

¬ß 5. The di≈øtilled Liquor being put into a large Cucurbit you may draw off the S. V. from it, to be u≈øed in other univer≈øal Operations: The remaining part put into a ≈øtone kind of Earthen Pan, and evaporate in Sand, till it comes to a Pint: after which ≈øet it to Cry≈øtallize for three days: if it Cry≈øtallizes not, evaporate it again, till it will; then ca≈øt in ≈øome little Straws or Sticks, and in a cold place the Cry≈øtals will ≈øhoot and ≈øtick to them, which are the Salt of the Marca≈øite: the≈øe Cry≈øtals dry ≈ølowly, and keep in a Gla≈øs al≈øo, clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 6. The Flowers are prefertable to the Magi≈øtery for outward u≈øes on the Face and Skin: the Liquor made per deliquium, takes away all Spots and Freckles from it, whether u≈øed alone, or mixt in a Pomatum. And the Liquor and Salt are an admirable Remedy again≈øt Fi≈øtula's old running Sores, and all kinds of Cancerous and malignant Ulcers.
¬ß 7. The Arti≈øt who ≈øhall be ≈øo prudent as to apply them to their proper u≈øes, ≈øhall find them to be ≈øuch external Remedies, as are not inferior to any other Topical Medicament what≈øoever.

¬ß 8. You may mix them with Injections or Vulnerary waters, with which you may inject, wa≈øh, and foment Ulcers, e≈øpecially ≈øuch as participate of a Cancerous and Corroding Nature; for this Mineral being endowed with a Volatile Sulphur, and a Bal≈øamick Salt cannot be ≈øufficiently valued for ≈øoftning Tumors, and allaying Pains, and mortifying the Malignity, and mundifying and bringing to a perfect Cure the mo≈øt de≈øperate, earing and malign Ulcers.

¬ß 9. Charras makes the Flowers exactly after the ≈øame manner as Le Febure, ≈øave, that he pre≈øcribes, but the weight of the Bi≈ømuth in Wine, to be affu≈øed thereon each time; but then he advi≈øes the Repetition of the dige≈øtion five or ≈øix times one after another: the≈øe Flowers (≈øays he) are very proper to take away blemi≈øhes (Defedations I ≈øuppo≈øe he means) out of the Face and Skin, and to cure Fi≈øtula's, and malign and Cancerous Ulcers.

div.head: LXI. Flores Joviales, Flowers of Tin.
div.p: Bate. ‚Ñû Jupiter p. j. Nitre p. ij. ≈øublime according to Art, wa≈øhing the Flowers in warm water. They are of great u≈øe in Hy≈øterick Fits, or ≈øuffocation of the Womb, being both inwardly u≈øed and outwardly applied. Do≈øe √† gr. jj. ad vj. being ≈øeveral times repeated.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Lemery prepares them thus. ‚Ñû Tin ‚Ñ•ij. Sal-Armoniack in pouder ‚Ñ•iv. mix and put them into a ≈øtrong Earthen Cucurbit, able to endure the fire, ≈øo large as it may not be above ‚Öì full; fit to it a blind head, luting the Juncture well, place it on a Seat in a Furnace, with a naked fire, but covered ≈øo as that the fire may only pa≈øs through the Regi≈øters, the top of the Furnace being ≈øtopt up with Brick and Lute, &c. The Cucurbit mu≈øt al≈øo be ≈øet ‚Öì part of its height deep in the Furnace, to which give a fire, gentle at fir≈øt, which increa≈øe by degrees, till the bottom is become red-hot, which heat continue till nothing more will ≈øublime, which you will know by the growing cold of the head.

¬ß 2. The Flowers ≈øticking to the top of the head are nothing but Particles of Tin ≈øublimed by the help of Sal-Armoniack; and at the bottom of the Cucurbit you will find the re≈øt of the Tin revived. The≈øe Flowers being di≈ø≈øolved in Water q. s. and filtered, you may there from precipitate a very white pouper by dropping into it drop by drop either Spirit of Sal-Armoniack‚ñ™ or Oleum Tartari per deliquium; which being edulcorated by many times wa≈øhing in warm Water, and dried, is chiefly u≈øed as Paint, being a very curious White, and ≈øo mixed with Pomatums

¬ß 3. In this operation it is only the Acid Salt which is in the Sal-Arm. which divides the Jovial Particles, and makes them a≈øcend; and therefore it is that any Alcalious Spirit or Oil makes them precipitate in water.

¬ß 4. But Lemery has another kind of Flowers made with Nitre, from which this of our Author ≈øeems to be taken, which more explicitely is thus. ‚Ñû Tin lb j. Sal-Nitre lb ij. mix them; then take an unglaz'd Earthen Pot, with a hole in the mid≈øt of its height, and a ≈øtople to it, place it in a Furnace of a ju≈øt fitne≈øs, wherein the Pot may enter only as high as the hole, and with Bricks and Lute or Mortar, take care that the fire may not tran≈øpire; On this Pot fit three Aludels, with a head to the top-mo≈øt, luting well the Junctures; then make
a fire, ≈øoft at first, and gradually increa≈øe it till the part of the lower Pot lying within the Furnace is red hot; then through the hole ca≈øt in your former Mixture, by Spoonfuls, and pre≈øently ≈øtop up the hole, ≈øo will there be a Detonation, which when over; ca≈øt in another Spoonful, and thus continue till all your Mixture is ≈øpent; which done, you'll find in the Recipient a little Spirit of Nitre, and in the ≈øides of the Aludels very white Flowers of Tin, which being gathered, you are to edulcorate with warm Water, and dry in the ≈øhade between two Papers to be kept in a Vial clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 5. The≈øe Flowers (≈øays he) ≈øerve for Paints, and make a delicate White when mixt with Pomatums, or in ≈øome proper Liquor. And at bottom of the Pot, there is a Calx of Tin mixt with the fixt part of the Nitre; which by boiling in Water may be edulcorated, and then dryed, and is of good u≈øe in Deficcative Ointments.

¬ß 6. The Flowers are wa≈øht in order to edulcorate them, and free them from the Volatile Salt of the Nitre; and they are dryed in the Shade, for that the Sun, or Fire would dull their Lu≈øtre and Whitene≈øs, which is cau≈øed from the finene≈øs of the Particles, whereby having another kind of Superficies, they make a new Reflexion of Light.

¬ß 7. Charras makes the Flowers by ≈øubliming with four times the Weight of Sal-Armoniack, but with Ve≈ø≈øels like tho≈øe of Lemery's at ¬ß 4. above, increa≈øing the fire by degrees, till the Aludel be red-hot in all the lower part; then he throws in at the hole ‚Ñ•≈øs. of the Pouder, ≈øtopping it immediately, by which means the Tin and Sal-Armoniack will ri≈øe together in Vapours which will conden≈øe in Flowers within ≈øide the Pots: this done, ca≈øt in another like quantity, ≈øtopping the hole in like manner, and thus continue, till all your whole mixture is ≈øpent.
¬ß 8. Now there is to be noted in this Operation with Sal-Armoniack, that the Tin mu≈øt fir≈øt be made into a Pouder by Calcination, otherwi≈øe you will have few or no Flowers worth looking after.

¬ß 9. That if you u≈øe only equal parts of Tin and Sal-Armoniack, the Tin would remain almo≈øt all of it at the bottom of the Aludel, which is not to be wondred at ≈øince it is impo≈ø≈øible to make Metals
a≈øcend in Flowers without the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of three or four times their weight of volatile Salts mixed with them, or ≈øeveral con≈øequent Cohobations of more Salts.
¬ß 10. That through the whole time of the Operation, a good fire ought to be kept, by which means the Sublimation will be the more ea≈øily ab≈øolved.

¬ß 11. That among the many Preparations of Tin, the Sublimation thereof into Flowers is e≈øteemed to be one of the be≈øt, for though they cannot be made without any mixture (which ≈øome may fault, though without cau≈øe) yet by rea≈øon of the ea≈øie ≈øeparation of tho≈øe Salts by Lotion, the Medicament is found to be really prai≈øeworthy.

¬ß 12. The Flowers being gather'd from Pots, put into a great Earthen Pot full of fair warm Water, let it ≈øtand quiet for twenty four Hours, then decant the clear Water, and the Flowers, or rather Calx of Tin, will be found at bottom in the form of a Magi≈øtery, which being ≈øufficiently edulcorated by many Lotions, are to be dryed in the Shade as before directed.

¬ß 13. But becau≈øe of the length of time and trouble which is found in the Calcination of Tin by the ways which Authors have ≈øet down, they have ≈øought for a more ea≈øie and advantageous Method, which is the ≈øubliming it with Nitre in the way afore≈øaid at ¬ß 4. which Charras does with a trebble proportion of Nitre, whereas Lemery makes u≈øe but of a double.

¬ß 14. Now whereas it is evident that Tin contains a Sulphur, for that being mixt with Nitre, and put into a red-hot Pot it will flame, which Nitre of it ≈øelf will never do alone, without mixture of ≈øome ≈øulphurous Matter: ≈øo you mu≈øt take care, if you would rightly make your Detonations, to proportion the Nitre to the Sulphur.

¬ß 15. For if there be too little of the Nitre, it will have too few Volatile parts, to unite with the Sulphur, and ≈øo not be able to rai≈øe it all up; And if there be too much of the Nitre, whereby its Volatile parts exceed tho≈øe of the Sulphur, it will cau≈øe but a Sublimation in part, becau≈øe the great quantity of the fixed part of this Salt, which remains at the bottom
without firing, will fix ≈øome part of the Sulphur, and cau≈øe but a very ≈ømall Detonation.

¬ß 16. From whence 'tis concluded, that a double proportion of Nitre will rai≈øe more Flowers from Tin than a treble ‚Ä¢
becau≈øe the Detonation of the double proportion is greater than that of the trebble, ≈øince experience ‚Ä¢ hews that a more perfect detonation rai≈øes more Flowers than that which is le≈øs perfect.
¬ß 17. For the fixt Nitre remaining at the bottom ≈øixes ≈øome part of the Sulphur of the Tin, and hinders it from ≈øubliming as it ≈øhould do.

¬ß 18. And note, That three Aludels and one head are u≈øed, becau≈øe of the great quantities of Vapours and force of the Detonation, which ought to have room enough, for otherwi≈øe the Ve≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ls would break, notwith≈øtanding the ca≈øting in the Matter by little and little.

¬ß 19. Charras advi≈øes that if you u≈øe the Flowers inwardly, you ≈øhould (after edulcoration with Water, and drying) pour upon them rectified S. V. to over-top them two Inches, and then ≈øet it on fire, reiterating the Operation three or four times: But what great need there is of this Work I ≈øee not, and therefore leave every Arti≈øt to his own Prudence and Ingenuity.

¬ß 20. You may al≈øo make the≈øe Flowers according to Zwelfer's Method (Manti≈ø. Spagyr. Cap. 6. Pag. 817.) and u≈øe his Ve≈ø≈øels, as you may ≈øee in the Preparation of the Flowers of Antimony aforegoing.

div.head: LXII. Flores Sulphuris albi, white Flowers of Sulphur.
div.p: Bate. ‚Ñû Lapis Prunellae calcined for two hours in a Crucible covered (which do with live Coals laid above and below and round about it) ‚Ñ•iij. Sulphur ‚Ñ•vj. mix and ≈øublime in a Sand heat, S. A. They are equal in Vertues to L ‚Ä¢ c Sulphuris. Do≈øe ‚Ñàj. ad í j.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Lemery makes the≈øe white Flowers with Sal-Polychre≈øtum in≈øtead of Lapis Prunellae after this manner. ‚Ñû Sulphur in pouder lb ij. Sal-Polychre≈øtum lb j. mix them together; put this mixture by half Pounds into a Gla≈øs body, which place in a ≈ømall open fire, and cover it with a Pot, or another Cucurbit of unglazed Earth, ≈øo as the neck of the lower may enter into the neck of the higher: change the
upper Cucurbit every half hour, and fit another in its place, adding likewi≈øe new Ingredients: gather your Flowers in the upper Cucurbit, and continue this work, till all your mixture is added, and there remains at bottom only a little infignificant ≈øpungy Earth.
¬ß 2. The Salt remaining at bottom of the Cucurbit may be calcin'd, and if afterwards you purifie it by Solution. exhaling and filtering, it will be as good as before.
¬ß 3. The whitene≈øs of the≈øe Flowers proceeds from the attenuation of the ≈øulphurous Particles by the adjoyned Salt.
¬ß 4. And exactly as Lemery makes them, you have them in Mon≈øieur Charras both for Method and proportion of Ingredients; but he u≈øes in his Preparation Sal-Nitre.

¬ß 5. But the true Author of the Pre≈øcript was Angelus Sala, as you may ≈øee in his Opera Medico-Chymica, pag. 745. A. who makes it of fixed Nitre, or Sal-Prunellae in the ≈øame proportion, whom our Author is plea≈øed to follow.

¬ß 6. They are a mo≈øt famous Pectoral, drying up all Catarrhs and Rheums after a mo≈øt admirable manner: and yet withall open Ob≈øtructions of the Bre≈øt and Lungs; are good again≈øt Coughs, Colds, Hoar≈øne≈øs, A≈øthma's, ≈øhortne≈øs of Breath, difficulty of Breathing, and other Vices of tho≈øe parts.

¬ß 7. Motus ∆≤tendi. ‚Ñû Of the≈øe white Flowers ‚Ñàij. Bezoar mineral gr. xvj. Mithridate í i≈øs. mix for a Do≈øe to be given at Night going to Bed. ‚Ñû Of the≈øe Flowers í j. Syrup of Comfrey ‚Ñ•j. mix for a Do≈øe again≈øt a Catarrh. ‚Ñû Of the≈øe Flowers í j. Syrup of Poppies ‚Ñ•≈øs. mix for a Do≈øe again≈øt a Cough. ‚Ñû Of the≈øe Flowers ‚Ñàij. Catechu í ≈øs. Venice-treacle í j. mix for a Do≈øe again≈øt Fluxes of the Bowels.

div.head: LXIII. Flores Viridis aeris, Flowers of Verdigri≈øe.
div.p: Bate.] Di≈ø≈øolve Verdigri≈øe in Spirit of Vinegar, then filter and Cry≈øtallize S. A. It is the greate≈øt clean≈øer of Ulcers.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It ≈øerves to make the ∆≤nguentum Fu≈øcum Wurtzii, the Compo≈øition, Preparation, Vertues and U≈øes, of which you may ≈øee in our Doron Medicum, Lib. 3. Cap. 6. Sect. 13. which is a famous thing of the kind.

¬ß 2. Le Mort takes the Verdigri≈øe, and pouders it finely and adds ≈øo much Sp. of Vinegar as may overtop it ≈øome Inches, after which he boils it gently, till the Verdigri≈øe is di≈ø≈øolved, then filters the Liquor, and puts into it little Oak Twigs or Sticks, and ≈øets it to Cry≈øtallize.

¬ß 3. This he had from Swelfer in Append. ad Animadver≈øiones, pag. 43 where (though they are really Cry≈øtals of Verdigri≈øe) he calls them Flores Aeris; and out of the ≈øame he prepares his ≈øo wonderful and much magnified Spirit of Venus.

¬ß 4. Lemery has it thus. ‚Ñû Verdigri≈øe q. v. put it into a large Matra≈øs: Spirit of Vinegar, ≈øo much as to over-top it four Inches: dige≈øt in a Sand heat three days, ≈øtirring it now and then, till the Spirit becomes blew; then decant it, and affu≈øe new Spirit of Vinegar, which dige≈øt as before three days, and decant again; thus affu≈øe, dige≈øt and decant fre≈øh Spirit till about ¬æ of the Verdigri≈øe is di≈ø≈øolved, and nothing but an Earthy matter remains: mix the≈øe Impregnations, filter, and in a Gla≈øs body evaporate ‚Öî of the moi≈øture, then ≈øet it four or five days in a cool Cellar to Cry≈øtallize: from which decant the Liquor and gather them: evaporate again ‚Öì of this Liquor, and Cry≈øtallize again as before, thus continuing till you have got all your Cry≈øtals, which dry and keep for the Clean≈øing of Wounds, making the Spirit of Venus, and the ∆≤nguentum fu≈øcum Wurtzii.

¬ß 5. But Schroder makes Flowers after another manner by Sublimation thus. ‚Ñû Calx Vive lb ij. Sal-Armoniack lb j. mix and make a Lixivium: coagulate it into a Salt, and mix with it three times as much Bole, and draw a Spirit from it like A. F. which rectifie: take of this Spirit p. iv. Verdigri≈øe p. j. ≈øet them in the Embers in a luted Ve≈ø≈øel, ≈øo will the Matter di≈ø≈øolve: decant and pour on more, till only light black Faeces remain; ab≈øtract the Men≈øtruum, and force the remainder in a naked Fire in a Still, ≈øo will the Verdigri≈øe be elevated in Flowers, which will di≈ø≈øolve in the Air into a green Liquor.

¬ß 6. It is good again≈øt malign and ill-conditioned Ulcers; and if you free it from the Spirit of Sal-Armoniack it will, as Clo≈ø≈øaeus ≈øays, cure Wounds and Ulcers ≈øafely without biting, being mixt with Bal≈øams, Unguents, &c.

¬ß 7. Le Febure follows the ≈øame Method with Lemery, and calls it the Volatile Vitriol of Venus: but (≈øays he) if you de≈øire to be yet more accurate and ≈øucce≈øsful in you Operation, proceed in the Di≈ø≈øolution of the≈øe Cry≈øtals in new Spirit of Vinegar, till you can di≈øcover by trying a Di≈øtillation in B. M. or in A≈øhes, whether the a≈øcending Vinegar be in≈øipid; which if it be ≈øo, go on in the Di≈ø≈øolution, Filteration, Evaporation and Cry≈øtallization, till the Vinegar comes forth with the ≈øame Strength and Acidity, with which it was put in; then have you attained the true point of the de≈øired Perfection, which this noble Flos is to be brought to, dry it gently between two Papers, which dige≈øt in Alcohol of S. V. three Inches above it in a double dige≈øting Ve≈ø≈øel for twenty four hours, ab≈øtract the S. V. and repeat this Operation thrice in B. M. opening it no more till you make the Spirit of Venus thereof; ≈øo will it be endowed with tho≈øe Vertues and Perfections, which do ≈øhine, and are required in the Spirit to be drawn from it.

div.head: LXIV. Flores Zinci, Flowers of Zinck, or Spelter, called al≈øo Tin-gla≈øs.
div.p: Bate.] They are made as are the Flowers of Bi≈ømuth. And they have the ≈øame Vertues.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Zinck is only a differing Marca≈øite from Bi≈ømuth, and therefore its Flowers are made exactly after the ≈øame manner, which you may ≈øee at large in Sect. LX. ¬ß 3. of this Chapter aforegoing.
¬ß 2. They are u≈øed as a Paint and Co≈ømetick (being of an exqui≈øite whitene≈øs) and for that rea≈øon are put into Pomatums, Wa≈øhes, &c.

¬ß 3. They are proper again≈øt Cancerous Ulcers, Strumatick and Sirrhous, as al≈øo again≈øt Lentils, Freckles, Pu≈øtles, and other Defedations of the Skin; and in a word, have all the Vertues of the Flores Bi≈ømuthi, ≈øo that in like ca≈øes, each may be indifferently u≈øed.

div.head: LXV. Gilla Theophra≈øti, the Vomiting Vitriol.
div.p: Bate.] It is nothing el≈øe, but white Vitriol depurated.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Paracel≈øus de Rebus naturalibus, Lib. 1. Cap. 8. (where he treats of the Vertues of Crude Vitriol and Colcothar, calls it Grillus non Gilla. This word Gilla, Schroder interprets to be the Vomiting Salt of Vitriol. Gilla apud Paracel≈øum e≈øt Vitriolum ≈øua ≈øponte re≈øolutum in Aquam, Lexic. Chym. But the Word is barbarous, and without any known Etymological Derivation from the Learned Languages.
¬ß 2. Beguinus make it of white Vitriol di≈ø≈øolved in common Water, then filters and coagutes, which he repeats a ≈øecond time, and a third time di≈ø≈øolves in Ro≈øe-water.

¬ß 3. Or, He evaporates to a Cuticula, then ≈øet it in a cold place to Cry≈øtallize: di≈ø≈øolving, filtering and cry≈øtallizing to the third time, which la≈øt time is al≈øo done in Ro≈øe-water, then drying the Cry≈øtals with a gentle fire.

¬ß 4. He gives it with happy Succe≈øs in Feavers, Catarrhs, Crudity of the Ventricle, fulne≈øs of the Stomach, Worms, Plague, &c. √† ‚Ñàj. ad í ≈øs. in a Draught of Wine or Ale, or Con≈øerve of Ro≈øes. But his Commentator ≈øays this Do≈øe is too large, and that it may ≈øcarcely be exhibited to ‚Ñà≈øs. let it go ≈øo; but I have oftentimes given it to í j. in Broth with good ≈øucce≈øs, never in my whole practi≈øe having any evil Symptoms following it; yet I ≈øay for the Caution of the ≈øaid Commentor let it be u≈øed with Prudence and Di≈øcretion; po≈ø≈øibly one may find that by it, which another may not; nor are all Con≈øtitutions alike.

¬ß 5. Beguinus al≈øo extracts it from the Caput Mortuum of Vitriol, after the Sublimation of the Flowers of Sulphur: This he gives ad ‚Ñàj. in Fennel-water; and it moves Vomits, Stools, and Sweat: and ≈øometimes al≈øo conciliates Sleep.
¬ß 6. It may be univer≈øally exhitibited in all Vomits, but is carefully to be avoided in an A≈øthma, and other Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Lungs.

¬ß 7. Schroder di≈ø≈øolves white Vitriol in Water, filters, evaporates and cry≈øtallizes, which he repeats the third time with
Ro≈øe-water; this, ≈øays he, is a gentle Vomit, good again≈øt all the aforenamed Di≈øea≈øes, as al≈øo the Falling-≈øickne≈øs, and may given √† ‚Ñàj. ad í j. in Wine, Broth, or other Liquors: But Centory-water more effectually promotes its emetick Property, as Crollius thinks.

¬ß 8. This Preparation, ≈øays Hofman, de≈øerves prai≈øe, for that it exerts its Emetick property without any ≈øu≈øpicion of a Colliquative Malignity. This following Preparation al≈øo he commends. ‚Ñû White Vitriol. q. v. di≈ø≈øolve by boiling in fair Water. Take al≈øo prepared Nitre, and di≈ø≈øolve in Water: this latter di≈ø≈øolution ≈øprinkle in Guttatim upon the former, ≈øo will all the Impurity fall to the bottom; then filter the Clear, evaporate the one half, till it grows (as it were) milky, and in le≈øs than the ≈øpace of an hour, it will Cry≈øtallize.

¬ß 9. There are four ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Gilla's, 1. That which is made of Sky-colour'd Vitriol, di≈ø≈øolved and precipitated with Oil of Tartar, which is the ≈øtronge≈øt and ≈øharpe≈øt Gilla, and ≈øcarcely ≈øafe unle≈øs given by a prudent Hand. 2. That which is made of the Vitriol of Iron, according to Crollius, which has a ≈øtiptick Sweetne≈øs; this is le≈øs Violent. 3. That which is made of white Vitriol, which is this of our Author, and is yet more ≈øafe. 4. That which is made out of the. Caput Mortuum of Vitriol after the ab≈øtraction of its Spirit and Oil, which is called Salt of Vitriol; this is the mo≈øt innocent Gilla, and fit only for Children.
¬ß 10. But to the≈øe you may add a fifth which is extracted out of the Caput Mortuum of the Vitriol of Venus, which ≈øome will have to be the only true Gilla Theophra≈øti.

¬ß 11. Lemery makes it thus. ‚Ñû White Vitriol q. v. di≈ø≈øolve it in flegm of Vitriol, filter and evaporate ‚Öî ≈øet it in a cool place for three days to Cry≈øtallize which ≈øeparate: evaporate again ‚Öì, and Cry≈øtallize again as before, thus continuing till you have gotten all the Cry≈øtals, which dry in the Sun and keep for u≈øe.
¬ß 12. By this Operation the Vitriol is freed from its Earthy parts; and white is cho≈øen, becau≈øe it is milder in its operation. Do≈øe, √† gr. xij. ad í j. in Broth, or ≈øome other proper Liquor.

¬ß 13. Here note, That ≈øometimes after taking of this Vomit, the Stools will be black like Ink; but this is when the Vitriolick Particles de≈øcending into the Guts meets with ≈øome ≈øaline Matter which joyns with it, much re≈øembling its Union with Galls.

¬ß 14. Le Febure does it the ≈øame way, ≈øave that he does it with Rain-water, or May-dew, and then dige≈øts a Philo≈øophical Month, ≈øeparating and dige≈øting till no more Impurity will precipitate, then filtrates, evaporates and cry≈øtallizes.

¬ß 15. The fir≈øt Cry≈øtallization (≈øays he) does only take away the ≈øuperficial and outward foulne≈øs: but the ≈øecond ≈øeparates the very Central Impurities, and is to be kept for extraordinary Preparations, which are Tinctures and Arcana's: this is Vitriol purified from its Metallick Earth.

¬ß 16. That prepared from the Blew (≈øays he) is violent, and therefore to be ab≈øtained from, and this of the white rather to be u≈øed, which may be given √† gr. x. ad ‚Ñàiv. in ≈øome warm Broth, Ale, or Decoction, &c.

¬ß 17. Charras al≈øo ≈øaith, if you would perfect the Preparation, and ≈øeparate it from its Terre≈øtial parts, we are obliged to have recour≈øe to long Dige≈øtions, by means whereof its Terre≈øtrieties and Metallick parts will precipitate to the bottom of the Liquor (as Le Febure has ≈øaid before him) whereby the Cry≈øtals will be much fairer, and more tran≈øparent.

div.head: LXVI. Jupiter Diaphoreticus, Diaphoretick or Sweating Tin.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of the Caput Mortuum of the Flowers of Jupiter, boiled in Water, precipitated, and edulcorated, S. A. Do≈øe, √† gr. iij. ad x. It powerfully moves Sweat, and is profitable in Hy≈øterick Fits, Gout, Plague, or Pe≈øtilence, French-Pox, &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Beguinus Tyroc. Chym. Lib. 2. Cap. 14. makes it thus. ‚Ñû Filings of Engli≈øh Block-Tin, or Calcined-Tin ‚Ñ•ij. Mercury ≈øublimate ‚Ñ•iv. mix them together, and di≈øtil by Retort in a Sand heat, having adjoyned a Receiver half full of Water; to take what ≈øhall begin to di≈øtil; give a moderate Fire of ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion, till all the Liquor is come over, which will precipitate
in the Water: that which ≈øublimes to the neck of the Retort is to be taken away, and dige≈øted with that which was di≈øtilled, for one night: the water (impregnated with the Spirit of Vitriol) ≈øeparate, and dry the Calx. Do≈øe, √† gr. iv. ad vj.

¬ß 2. Charras takes Filings or Calx of Tin, and double quantity of Corro≈øive ≈øublimate, mixes them and di≈øtils in a Gla≈øs Retort in a ≈ømall Furnace of clo≈øe Reverberation and having ≈ølightly fitted a Receiver, he di≈øtils fir≈øt with a gentle fire, which he continues till the Butter-like Liquor cea≈øes to di≈øtill: then changes the Receiver, and increa≈øing the Fire Gradatim, forces it at length till all the Mercury in the Sublimate is revived and dropped into the Recipient: then pouring fair Water upon the white and thick water in the fir≈øt Receiver, he precipitates the Sub≈øtance of the Tin, and leaves it to ≈øettle till it is exactly dulcified, which he dries in the Shade and keeps for u≈øe.
¬ß 3. This is given for the ≈øame Di≈øtempers which the other Preparations of Tin are given for. Do≈øe, √† gr. iij. ad vj.
¬ß 4. This Diaphoretick is only a more perfect Calx of Tin made by the Corro≈øion of the Corro≈øive Sublimate, and may be reduced into Tin again.

¬ß 5. Schroder makes it with Filings or Calx of Tin p. j. mixed with Precipitate p. iv. and di≈øtils by Retort in Sand or a naked Fire into a Receiver half full of Water, in which a Pouder precipitates, which he wa≈øhes, drys and keeps for u≈øe.

¬ß 6. Where note, That if after the Butter of Tin is made, you make a Fire of Suppre≈ø≈øion by degrees, you will have. Silver Flowers to ≈øublime in the neck of the Retort. Do≈øe, of the Diaphoretick and of the Flowers, gr. iv. ad vj.

¬ß 7. Le Febure does it after the ≈øame manner with Charras, but u≈øes a tripple quantity of Corro≈øive Sublimate di≈øtilling in a Retort with a large neck in Sand; from whence he has, 1. A Spirit continually ≈ømoaking. 2. A Butter or Corro≈øive Oil. 3. A revived or running Mercury; this done, increa≈øing the Fire downwards, and giving a Fire of Suppre≈ø≈øion, the Sub≈øtance of Jupiter, a≈øcends in the neck of the Retort in form of a grey Gum very hard: which being immediately reduced to pouder, and put on a
Sheet of white Lattin edged about, will melt into a yellow Oil, which may run into a gla≈øs Receiver, and being precipitated is an excellent Diaphoretick.

div.head: LXVII. Magnes Praeparatus, Load≈øtone prepared.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of the Pouder of the Magnet heat Red-fire-hot in a Crucible: and affu≈øing thereon an equal quantity of the Oil of Mars, it is with a gentle fire evaporated to dryne≈øs, S. A. mixt with Wax, and ≈øo made into an Emplai≈øter, being applied, it admirably ea≈øes pains of the Gout.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Load≈øtone is found in divers parts of England, Scotland, Germany, Norway, Sweethland, Italy, and the Iron-Mines; and that is to be cho≈øen which is mo≈øt of an Iron colour, and draws Iron ≈øtrongly to it.

¬ß 2. In this Preparation Schroder advi≈øes the Cementation to be made with Lime at a gentle Fire, and then after to quench it in the Oil of Mars, or Solution of Iron, in order to the ≈øtrengthning of it.
¬ß 3. The Emplai≈øter is de≈øcribed by Boetius, and is commended highly to ea≈øe the pains of the Gout, as Hofman affirms.

¬ß 4. This I know by experience, that it ≈øtops Fluxes of Blood, but evacuates gro≈øs and melancholy Humours if rightly given in a proper Vehicle. ‚Ñû Elect. Lenitivum ‚Ñ•j. Magnet prepared ‚Ñàj. mix for a Do≈øe to evacuate melancholy Humours. Or thus: ‚Ñû Syrup of Sena ‚Ñ•j. Magnet Praep. ‚Ñàj. mix for a Do≈øe.

div.head: LXVIII. Mars Diaphoreticus, Sweating Mars.
div.p: Bate.] Sublime Sal-Armoniack with an equal quantity of Mars, S. A. di≈ø≈øolve the Sublimate in a ≈ømall quantity of Fountain-water, which filter, and precipitate by affu≈øing thereon Oil of Tartar per Deliq. or Spirit of Sal-Armoniack then dry the Precipitate S. A. It moves Sweat, and is Diuretick, of great u≈øe in Hypochond, Melancholy, Quartans, &c. Do≈øe, ‚Ñà≈øs. ad ‚Ñàj.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Schroder advi≈øes to take the Filings of Mars and ≈øublime them with the Sal-Armoniack, ≈øo will a part of the Mars or Iron be elevated therewith: if this (≈øays he) be wa≈øht from the Sal-Armoniack it will be like Gun-pouder or Thundering-gold.

¬ß 2. But if you ≈øublime from Filings, the Filings will be coroded by the Salt, and but little of them a≈øcend; it will be better therefore to ≈øublime with Gads of Iron, ≈øo will all the Flowers a≈øcend of a yellowi≈øh red colour: but this Medicament is better prepared from Crocus Martis than from either of them.

¬ß 3. Lemery makes this Diaphoretick after this manner. ‚Ñû Ru≈øt of Iron in fine Pouder, Sal-Armoniack Ana. mix them well and put them into an Earthen Cucurbit, which ≈øet in a little Furnace, ≈øtoping up the bottom with Bricks and Mortar; that the Fire may only pa≈øs through certain Regi≈øters: fit to the Cucurbit a Ve≈ø≈øel of Rencounter or Blind-head, making at fir≈øt only a ≈ømall fire; augment it gradatim till the Cucurbit is red-hot, which degree of heat continue till no more Vapors ari≈øe. The Ve≈ø≈øels being cold gather the Flowers, put them into water ≈øufficient only to di≈ø≈øolve them, which filter through brown Paper; and drop thereon Guttatim Oleum Tartari per Deliq. or Spirit of Sal-Armoniack, ≈øo will a pouder precipitate to the bottom of the Ve≈ø≈øel, decant the Liquor, and dry the Precipitate.

¬ß 4. It is indeed an excellent Medicament again≈øt all manner of Di≈øea≈øes proceeding from Corruption of Humours and Defilements of the Blood; it is Sudorifick and Diuretick, carrying off Di≈øea≈øes ≈øometimes as well by Urine as Sweat, according as Nature is mo≈øt di≈øpo≈øed to the Action. It is famous again≈øt Hypochondriack Melancholy, Ob≈øtructions of the Spleen and Me≈øentery, and Quartan Agues. Do≈øe, √† gr. x. ad xxiv. in Pills, Bolus, or ≈øome proper Syrup, as Syrup of Mars.

¬ß 5. Its Sudorifick property ≈øeems to come from the Particles of the Sal-Armonia ‚Ä¢ k, yet joyned to the precipitated Mars (by rea≈øon of the Acid of the Salt, which makes a ≈øtrict Conjunction with them) for when the≈øe ≈øaline Particles are actuated by the internal heat of the Body, and thereby
brought into a Ferment, they become of a Volatile Nature, and rather fly in≈øen≈øibly into all the Pores of the Body, than take their cour≈øe (as fixt Salts do) by way of Urine; whence Sweating or in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration follows.

¬ß 6. But if they meet not with a fit Matter ≈øufficient to excite this Fermentation, and cau≈øe their Volatibility, they then open the Lymphatick Ve≈ø≈øels, and take their ordinary cour≈øe by the Reins and Ureters, evacuating the Di≈øea≈øe that way, by which mo≈øtly a greater benefit is found than by Sweat, becau≈øe the way by Urine is more natural and ea≈øie, and debilitates le≈øs.

div.head: LXIX. Mars Fulminans, Thundering Mars.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Nitre í iv≈øs. Salt of Tartar í j≈øs. Sulphur í ij. mix and make a Pouder, S. A. It is diuretick, and provokes the Terms.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. What rea≈øon there is for the Name of this Medicament (there being nothing of Mars in it) I know not: Its u≈øual Appellations are Lapis Fulminans, and Sal Fulminans, by which Names you may meet with it in Authors.

¬ß 2. Lemery makes it of Nitre í iij. Salt of Tartar, í ij. Sulphur í j. mix together. This Pouder being heated in an Iron-Ladle or Fire-≈øhovel to the weight of í j. gives as thundering noi≈øe as a Canon it ≈øelf. Now the fixt Salt of Tartar cau≈øes the thundering noi≈øe in this Pouder, which Gold cau≈øes in the Aurum Fulminans, viz. it ≈øo chains and locks up the Spirits of the Nitre and Sulphur, that they cannot break forth out of their Pri≈øon, not be ≈øeparated without an extraordinary violence.

¬ß 3. But if you would have it Martial, and to an≈øwer the Name given to it, you ought to add to it a proportional part of the Mars Fulminans at Sect. LXVII. ¬ß 1. ju≈øt aforegoing. after this manner. ‚Ñû Fu ‚Ä¢
minating Mars í iv. Nitre í iij. Salt of Tartar í ij. Sulphur í j ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . mix and make a Pouder, which keep in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt from the Air.
¬ß 4. Marggrave calls it Nitre Fulminans, and makes it in the≈øe proportions. ‚Ñû Nitre p. 18. Salt of Tartar, p. 7. Sulphur p. 6. make each into a fine Pouder and mix them.

¬ß 5. Le Mort, who calls it Pulvis Tonitruans, makes it in the≈øe proportions. ‚Ñû Nitre í 18. Sal-Tartari í 12. Sulphur í 6. mix them S. A. It is by many Tryals that you mu≈øt find out the true Proportion of the Ingredients; for tho≈øe quantities which give in firing, the greate≈øt blow or noi≈øe, are tho≈øe which are truly adapted to the Compo≈øition.

¬ß 6. It is a ≈øingular Diuretick, opens Ob≈øtructions of the Vi≈øcera, but chiefly of the Reins and Womb, and has a ≈øingular Property in taking away the heat and ≈øharpne≈øs of Urine. Do≈øe, √† ‚Ñàj. ad í j. in any proper Vehicle.
¬ß 7. It is indeed a curious Experiment, for that it demon≈øtrates the thundering Property to re≈øide in the Nitre, which con≈øi≈øts of an Acid and Alcali, ≈øhut up by the Sulphur.

div.head: LXX. Mercurij Purgatio, The Clean≈øing or Purification of Mercury.
div.p: Bate.] It is done divers ways; either by ≈øtraining it through Leather; Or wa≈øhing it with Vinegar and Salt mixt together; Or with Aqua Calcis Vivae, by often ≈øtirring it; Or by ≈øtrongly ≈øhaking of it with S. V. in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt; Or by di≈øtilling it in Sand by Retort with a ≈øtrong fire, and that either by it ≈øelf; Or with the addition of Salt of Tartar, Quick-lime, &c. Or by Amalgamating it with Sol, or Luna, and then ≈øeparating it from the ≈øame again by Retort.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Some only wa≈øh it with the be≈øt Vinegar and Salt, and when it is dry, then they ≈øtrain it thr√¥ Leather; but by this way it may carry Lead or Bi≈ømuth, or ≈øome other Mineral wherewith po≈ø≈øibly it may be mixt, and therefore this mode of purifying is not ≈øufficicient.

¬ß 2. Others put the Mercury into a Gla≈øs or Iron Retort, and di≈øtil it into a Receiver half full of Water, by which means if it has been increa≈øed by Lead, Tin, Zinck, or Bi≈ømuth, tho≈øe Metals will remain in the bottom of the Retort, whil≈øt the Mercury runs ≈øimple into the Receiver; but by this way if the Mercury has been mixt with any Metal or Mineral which has a Volatile Ar≈øenical Poy≈øon, it imbibes it, and carries it along with it.

¬ß 3. Some put it into a ≈øtrong Lye made with Quicklime or Pot-a≈øhes, or both, which they put into a double Gla≈øs bottle well ≈øtopt, and then ≈øhake them together, to ≈øeparate the Impurities, then decanting the Liquor, they dry the and Quick-≈øilver, and ≈øtrain it through Shammoy Leather; but if it be mixt with any Foreign matter, it will pa≈øs the Leather with it as afore≈øaid.

¬ß 4. But a much better way is to mix it with Salt of Tartar Quick-lime equally mixt and poudered; then to put it into an Iron Retort, and di≈øtil into a Receiver fill'd half full of Water, ≈øo will the Impurities remain behind, and the fixed Alcali will fix the Volatile Poy≈øon of the mixt, by which means the Quick-≈øilver will be very pure.

¬ß 5. And not inferior to this is the Amalgama of Gold and Silver, from which it may again be purely ≈øeparated by di ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ illing from a Gla≈øs Retort in Sand with a gradual Fire, leaving all its Foeces, Filth, Impurities and Heterogenities behind it.

¬ß 6 But the be≈øt way of purifying Mercury, and the fitte≈øt for all Chymical Operations, is to revive Cinnabar into fluid Mercury, by which means you will be ≈øure to have pure Mercury as it comes from the fir≈øt hand; becau≈øe all the Cinnabar is made near the Mines of Mercury.

¬ß 7. Moreover, the mixing of Quick-≈øilver with Sulphur by Sublimation is the way by which Cinnabar is made, and it does in ≈øome ≈øort graduate and perfect the Mercury; and then the reviving of Mercury into fluid Quick-≈øilver from the Cinnabar by Filings of Iron, deliver it from all impurity: how therefore Quick-≈øilver revived from Cinnabar (being mo≈øt ≈øought for) is to be done we now come to ≈øhew.

¬ß 8. But in the fir≈øt place we ≈øhall ≈øhew you the making of the Artificial Cinnabar of Quick-≈øilver and common Sulphur, and then from thence the reviving of it again. ‚Ñû Sulphur in pouder lb ≈øs. melt it in a large Earthen Pan (glazed within ≈øa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Charras) and put Quick-≈øilver lb j≈øs. into a piece of Shammoy Leather which tie up hard, through which ≈øqueeze it upon the melted Sulphur: ≈øtir the Matter in fu≈øion with a wooden Sputula, and continue
‚Ä¢ re≈ø≈øing forth and ≈øtirring, ‚Ä¢ ill all the Mercury is ≈øqueez'd ‚Ä¢ hrough the Leather, and ≈øo ‚Ä¢ nited with the Sulphur, that ‚Ä¢ he Quick-≈øilver appearing no ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ore, they both ≈øeem reduced ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ to a black Ma≈øs: being cold, ‚Ä¢ educe it into a Pouder, and ‚Ä¢ ublime it in an Aludel or Earthen Subliming pot, with „Äà‚óä„Äâ clo≈øe Fire, (luting well the ‚Ä¢ unctures:) let the Fire be ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ft at fir≈øt, and gradually in
‚Ä¢ rea≈øe it, which continue for ≈øome hours; ≈øo will the Mer
‚Ä¢ ury being incorporated with ‚Ä¢ hat portion of Sulphur which „Äà‚óä„Äâ fit for it, ≈øublime into a very hard Ma≈øs of a very red ‚Ä¢ olour, leaving ≈øome Feces at ‚Ä¢ ottom, e≈øpecially if any Me
‚Ä¢ al or other Matter had been mixt with it before.

¬ß 9. The reviving the Quick-≈øilver from the Cinnabar, which is its ultimate purification. ‚Ñû Of this Ar
‚Ä¢ ificial Cinnabar in fine pouder lb j. Filings of Iron lb j. mix them well together, and put them into a Retort of Earth or Gla≈øs well luted, and ≈øet it in a Furnace, and put Coals round about it till it be covered „Äà‚óä„Äâ put lighted Coals above, ≈øo that the Fire may kindle by degrees; then having filled the whole largene≈øs of the Furnace with Coals, cover the Retort and fit a ≈ømall Receiver to its neck half full of water; leave the Coals to kindle of them≈øelves, and the Fire to act at his own plea≈øure. When the Retort begins to be red, the Mercury will come into the Receiver drop by drop; for the Acids of the Sulphur ≈øticking to the Mars, (with the Pores whereof the Figure of its parts does better agree, than with tho≈øe of the Mercury) and quiting the other, the Fire forces it out of the Retort, and makes it (falling into the water) to re≈øume its former body: by which means all extrin≈øecal Sub≈øtances mixed with the Cinnabar, will be ≈øtopt in the Retort with the Filings of Iron (which Filings will be much rarified. black and increa≈øed in weight, becau≈øe of the addition of the Sulphur, &c.) and the Quick-≈øilver will be at bottom, very pure and fit for any kind of operation.

¬ß 10. But Lemery does it otherwi≈øe with Quick-lime, after this manner. ‚Ñû Pouder of Artificial Cinnabar lb j. Quick-lime in pouder lb iij. mix, and put them into an Earthen or Gla≈øs Retort, ≈øo large as ‚Öì may be empty: put it into a Furnace of Reverberation, with a Recipient almo≈øt fill'd with Water: give fire gradatim, increa≈øing it
at length to the height, ≈øo will the Mercury run guttatim into the Recipient: continue the fire till no more will come over, which will be fini≈øhed in about ≈øeven hours time: the Quick-≈øilver at bottom (which will be very pure) dry with Linnen and keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 11. This Mercury thus revived is very pure; for if any Metal was mixed with it in the Mine; or if afterwards the Cinnabar ≈øhould be adulterated, the ≈øaid Metals, or Heterogene Sub≈øtances would either remain at bottom, and not ri≈øe with the Mercury, or be ≈øeparated from it in the Receiver; and if your Cinnabar was good‚ñ™ you would have out of each Pound of the Artifical ‚Ñ• 12¬Ω of flowing Quick-≈øilver.
¬ß 12. A third part of the Retort is left empty, becau≈øe the rarified Quick-≈øilver expands it ≈øelf with ≈øuch a vehemency, that it would otherwi≈øe be in danger of breaking the Retort.

¬ß 13. Now as Cinnabar is nothing but a mixture of Acid Spirits and Mercury together with ≈øome terren Particles of the Sulphur: ≈øo if you mix it with an Alcalious body, and force it upwards by fire, the Acid leaves the Mercury, and finding the Quick-lime very porous, cleaves thereto; ≈øo that the Quick-≈øilver being di≈øingaged from what held it in Chains before, and being forced by the fire, comes forth of the Retort in form of Spirit, which by the coolne≈øs of the water in the Receiver conden≈øes and becomes again Quick-≈øilver.

¬ß 14. Having mixt your Cinnabar and Quick-lime together, you ought to let it re≈øt one or two days before you begin your Di≈øtillation, that the Lime may ≈ølake as it where a whil ‚Ä¢ for otherwi≈øe the Retort would bur≈øt.

¬ß 15. But if you u≈øe ≈øuch Quick-lime, as has been already ≈ølakt in the Air, you may then begin to di≈øtil immediately upon the mixtion: but the former which is un≈ølakt is ≈øaid to be better in the Revivification, becau≈øe the Alcali will the more ≈øtrongly ab≈øorb the Sulphurous Acid.

¬ß 16. Upon the Di≈øtillation, a great Sulphurous fume is ≈øeen to come out of the Retort, for which rea≈øon the Juncture is not to be luted, but the ≈øaid Sulphurous fume is to be permitted to fly away, for fear, that being kept in, it ≈øhould joyn
with ≈øome part of the Mercury and ≈øo unite, whereby you might be put to the trouble of a ≈øecond Revivification.

div.head: LXXI. Mercurius Sublimatus ruber & Flavus, Mercury Sublimate red and yellow.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Mercury, Salt, Vitriol, calcined, A. ‚Ñ•iv. mix them exactly and ≈øublime: to the Sublimate add Nitre and Alum a little calcin'd, A. ‚Ñ•iij. mix and make them into a Pa≈øte with Vinegar, and ≈øublime again: ≈øeparate the Red from the Yellow, wa≈øh each by it ≈øelf with water, dry, and deflagrate from each S. V. S. A. It purges chiefly downwards, and is a great Secret again≈øt the Drop≈øie, French Pox, Gout, Scabs, Ulcers, Cancers, &c. Do≈øe, gr. 5, 6, 7. &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. That is, take Corro≈øive Sublimate, and mix it with Nitre and Alum, and ≈øublime again‚ñ™ and you ≈øhall have red and yellow Sublimate: But how the Corro≈øive Sublimate is to be made we ≈øhall here ≈øhew you out of Otte Tachenius his Hippocrat. Chymic. Cap. 24. and 25.

¬ß 2. ‚Ñû Red Precipitate made either per≈øe, or otherwi≈øe of what Condition ≈øoever, mix it with common Salt: urge this Compo≈øitum with a moderate fire, and it will he elevated into a Sublimate Corro≈øive.

¬ß 2. ‚Ñû Of this Corro≈øive Sublimate lb 20. Quick-≈øilver lb 280. common Salt, Salt-peter, A. lb 200. of the Caput Mortuum re≈øerved lb 50. Vitriol rubified lb 400. reduce all the≈øe ≈øeveral to ponder (the Quick-≈øilver excepted) under a Mill Stone, grinding them: then mix the Mercury and Sublimate together, with a part of the common Salt and Salt-peter; and although the Salts be dry, yet by this mixture they become moi≈øt, ≈øo the Mercury in being mixt with the ≈øaid Pouders dies; after add the other part of the Salts, proceeding to mix them with t an Iron In≈øtrument, till the Mercury appears no where quick. This mixture is very moi≈øt, to which if you have a mind to add the rubified Vitriol (which is very dry) it con≈øumes the Humidity in a moment, and they become altogether as hard as a Stone; wherefore in≈øtead of the afore≈øaid Vitriol, you mu≈øt add the Caput Mortuum either re≈øerved from the fir≈øt Sublimation,
from A. F. 'tis all one, ≈øo the, mixture becomes moderately dry, which then you mu≈øt pa≈øs through a Sieve: then you may conveniently mix the ≈øifted Pouder with the rubified Vitriol, ≈øo will the mixture be made. With this fill ≈øixteen great Gla≈øs Ve≈ø≈øels, a fourth part of each of them to be empty; place them on Stillatories, and ≈øublime in an A≈øh heat (not with a naked fire) in four little Fornaces, each of which is to hold four Ve≈ø≈øels: ≈øet Limbecks to the Ve≈ø≈øels at lea≈øt loo≈øely, with their Receivers; and with a ≈ølow Fire in twenty four hours, the Salts will di≈ø≈øolve the Mercury (in which operation it ≈ømells like A. F. and may hazard the ≈øtrangling of ≈øuch as ≈øuck, it in; after twenty fours the Smell cea≈øes) and then the Mercury begins to ≈øublime: (the A F. which is fortified by the other Ingredients, and ≈øerves for Precipitation of Mercury ≈øave:) and continue the heat‚ñ™ till the Mercury is wholly ≈øeparated from the Caput Mortuum and ≈øublimed to the top, in form of a Cake, which commonly happens about the fifth day, if ‚Ä¢ ou have operated rightly, When all is cooled, the Gla≈øs Ve≈ø≈øels (by rea≈ø ‚Ä¢ n of the great weight of the Sublimate) w ‚Ä¢ ll break of their own accord: the pieces gather up by them≈øelves, for they have ≈øome Sublimate upon them, which ≈øcrape off, and therewith you may at another time mortifie running Mercury, in order to make more Corro≈øive Sublimate, according to this pre≈øent Proce≈øs.

¬ß 4. Now here is to be noted, That the Cakes mu≈øt be curiou≈øly taken off with both Hands (avoiding the A≈øhes) and laid a≈øide, which they call Loaves; of which every one will weigh lb 25. or thereabouts, according to the capacity of the Ve≈ø≈øel, which held more or le≈øs of the Mixture. So that of lb 280. of Quick-≈øilver, and lb 20. of Sublimate, you will have lb 380. of fre≈øh Sublimate: and this is the true way of making Corro≈øive Sublimate, which every Arti≈øt knows not.

¬ß 5. Now the Sublimate thus increa≈øed in weight lb 80. is not from the Acidity of the rubified Vitriol, as many Chymi≈øts think; but only from the Common Salt, which is thus proved: Sublime the ≈øame Mercury with the ≈øame proportion of Nitre and rubified Vitriol, without common Salt; and the Mercury will a≈øcend Red, acquiring nothing of weight,
or taking from the Corro≈øive.

¬ß 6. So al≈øo if the ≈øame Mercury be precipitated with A. F. made of Sure and Vitriol, it will be of a ≈øhining Red, but require no farther weight. The rea≈øon is, that the Sulphur of the Nitre being joyned with the Sulphur of the Vitriol, do act jointly upon the external Sulphur of the Mercury, whereby it can encrea≈øe nothing at all, nor a≈ø≈øume a Corro≈øive Vertue.

¬ß 7. From what has been ≈øaid it appears, that rubified Vitriol is not added to increa≈øe the weight of the Mercury, as mo≈øt Chymi≈øts think; for then it ≈øhould not be calcined to the highe≈øt red, but to whitene≈øs only, ≈øo that its Spirit is net needful to be added to the weight of the Mercury; but the ≈øaid rubified Vitriol is added that the Sulphurous Nitre, might apprehend the Sulphur of the immature Metal lying hid in the rubified Vitriol, and ≈øo by their joint forces di≈ø≈øolve the Mercury.
¬ß 8. But the quantity is Quadruple to that of the Salts, becau≈øe they are of ea≈øie fu≈øion in the Fire, from which by the rubified Vitriol, they are pre≈øerved.

¬ß 9 Authors to perfect the Sublimate, ≈øay that it mu≈øt be twice or thrice repeated with new Pouders of Salt and Vitriol: But why, and to what purpo≈øe is this repeated Sublimation with new Pouders? Mercury being once ≈øaturated with the Acid Spirits, what needs any reiteration of the Labour? for it ab≈øorbs and imbibes as much as it can bear, and as much as it wants from its fir≈øt Sublimation; and though it be re≈øublimed afterwards an hundred times either by it ≈øelf, or with new Pouders, it will ≈øtill remain the ≈øame ≈øublimated Mercury:≈øo that that Repetition ≈øeems only to be Labour in vain.

¬ß 10. And becau≈øe the ≈øame ≈øublimed Mercury puts not off, nor depo≈øes the Acid Spirits it has once ab≈øorbed, ≈øo as to need a re≈øuming the ≈øame again from new Ingredients, therefore it needs no Re≈øublimation, nor if it ≈øhould be re≈øublimed an hundred times with fre≈øh Salt and Vitriol would it become ever the purer or more efficaous.

¬ß 11. Having thus ≈øhewn you the true way of Making the Corro≈øive Sublimate, the remaining part of the Proce≈øs, for making the Sublimate
red and yellow, is ≈øo plain that it needs no Explication: It is thus. ‚Ñû Corro≈øive Sublimate ‚Ñ•v. Nitre, Alum a little calcind, A ‚Ñ•iij. mix and make a Pa≈øte with Vinegar, and ≈øublime, S. A. ≈øo will you have red and yellow Flowers which ≈øeparate, &c. according to the Pre≈øcript.

¬ß 12. Schroder teaches two ways of making this Sublimate which you may ≈øee at large in Our Pharmacopoeia, Lond. Lib. 3. Cap. 7. S. 52, ¬ß 53. The latter of which he calls Metallick Laudanum; and may be given either of them √† gr. iv. ad viij. They purge all vitious Humours chiefly, downwards, and admirably ea≈øe pains.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Precipitation is an Operation which belongs to all Magi≈øteries; but that Medicament which is ≈øignified by the ≈øimple name of Precipitate is chiefly Mercury or Quick-≈øilver di≈ø≈øolved in A. F. and ≈øeparated again according to the following Method.

F. ‚Ñ•xiij. mix and di≈ø≈øolve, then precipitate with Oil of Tartar per Deliq. or with Salt-brine, i. e. water in which common Salt is di≈ø≈øolved; decant the clear Liquor, and edulcerate the Precipitate with many affu≈øions of fair water, till it is freed from all its Acrimony. ¬ß 3. This is the ≈øame way with that declared in our Pharm. Lond. Lib. 3. Cap. 7. Sect. 21. but the Proportions differ, for the Colledge pre≈øcribes to Quick-≈øilver, P. ij. A. F. p. j. which is indeed too little of the A.F. by p. ij. for if the Quick-≈øilver be ‚Ñ•ij. the A. F. ought to be ‚Ñ•iij. for that with a le≈øs quantity a compleat and perfect Di≈ø≈øolution

F. and to Quick-≈øilver ‚Ñ•viij. takes of Spirit of Nitre ‚Ñ•x. and precipitates with Salt-water filterated, made of water lb iv. common Salt ‚Ñ•x. adding unto it Volatile Spirit of Sal-Armoniack ‚Ñ•≈øs. and then wa≈øhes the Precipitate ≈øeven times with Fountain-water, drying it in the ≈øhade.

¬ß 5. If you would have the Precipitate very white, the Q. S. ought to be di≈ø≈øolved in a Ve≈ø≈øel who≈øe mouth is very large, that ≈øo the red Vapours of the Sp. N. may vani≈øh the more ea≈øily: and if the Di≈ø≈øolution is made without Fire, it will yet be the whiter.

¬ß 6. Nor need you religiou≈øly retain the exact quantity of Spirit of Nitre here limited, you may either u≈øe a little more or le≈øs, according to the ≈øtrength of the Spirit, or its being deflegmated; if perfectly deflegmated, an equal quantity may do.

¬ß 7. In the Precipitation, you mu≈øt not make the Water too Salt, becau≈øe the quantity of Salt would keep the Precipitate from falling. But it may ≈øeem ≈øtrange that an Acid Salt (≈øuch as Sea-Salt) ≈øhould be able to precipitate that which the Acidity of Spirit of Nitre had di≈ø≈øolved.

¬ß 8. To which is an≈øwered, that the Acids do all perform the ≈øame things, in pricking and piercing; yet they all differ in the Figure and Sharpne≈øs of their Points, as their Fermentation is more or le≈øs, ≈øo their Points are more ≈øubtil, ≈øharp and light; or more thick and dull, which not only the Ta≈øte but the Sight al≈øo evinces: if you Cry≈øtallize various Acids, you will have as many kinds of Cry≈øtals, each different in figure, as there were different Di≈ø≈øolutions.

¬ß 9. And as the Cry≈øtals of Vinegar will be ≈øharper than tho≈øe of Spirit of Nitre; ≈øo tho≈øe of Spirit of Nitre will be ≈øharper than tho≈øe of Spirit of Vitriol; and tho≈øe made by Spirit of Vitriol ≈øharper than tho≈øe made by Spirit of Alum; and tho≈øe made by Spirit of Alum ≈øharper than tho≈øe made by Spirit of Salt; each kind of Cry≈øtal retaining the figure of its Con≈øtituent parts.

¬ß 10. This being known, it will not be difficult to explicate the Phaenomenon; for
that Salt or its Spirit containing Points more gro≈øs than tho≈øe of Spirit of Nitre, and falling on this di≈ø≈øolution, they move, ≈øhake, and ea≈øily break the Points of the Nitre, impregnated with the Quick-≈øilver, making them let go their hold, and ≈øo the Mercury falls down by its own weight.

¬ß 11. But to facilitate this Precipitation he adds a little Volatile Spirit of Sal-Armoniack. which contains a great Alcali, which by rea≈øon of its ≈øubtilty and agility penetrates every rece≈øs of the Liquor, where po≈ø≈øibly the Sea-Salt (by rea≈øon of the obtu≈øene≈øs of its points) cannot go.

¬ß 12. This is evident by this demon≈øtration. Fir≈øt precipitate with Salt-water, the Liquor being clear decant it: into this decanted Liquor drop Volatile Spirit of Sal-Armoniack, and you will find a con≈øiderable quantity of Precipitate more to fall, which plainly ≈øhews, that the Salt-water had not precipitated all: And if in≈øtead of the Spirit of Sal-Armoniack you u≈øe Oil of Tartar per Deliquium, you will have more Precipitate, but of an Orange tawny colour.

¬ß 13. The Precipitation may be made as well with the Spirit of Salt, as with the Salt in Sub≈øtance: but this Precipitation is not ≈øo ea≈øily made in Mercury, as in Zinck or Bi≈ømuth, becau≈øe the Pores of the former are ≈ømaller than tho≈øe of the latter, and therefore retain more ≈øtrongly the Acids with which they are joyned: Al≈øo Mercury (being of a Volatile Nature) does more ea≈øily ≈øwim in the di≈ø≈øolvent than Zinck, &c. the latter being bodies more ≈øixt.

¬ß 14. The Do≈øe of white Precipitate is le≈øs than that ‚Ä¢ f Mercurius dulcis, becau≈øe it contains a greater quantity of Acid Spirits; but if you ‚Ä¢ ublime it alone in a Matra≈øs in a gradual Sand heat (as Charras ≈øpeaks) you will have a Sublimate as ≈øweet as the other; for that the Fire having acted upon it, de ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ roys mo≈øt of its Acid points, ≈øo that it may then be given in full as large a Do≈øe as the common Mercurius dulcis, in Vencral and other inveterate Di≈øea≈øes! it is given in a Bolus a gr. 10. ad 20. or 30. or mixt with ≈øome Con≈øerve, or other purgative Remedy.

¬ß 15. Charras makes his white Precipitate with Q. S. ‚Ñ•viij. A. F. (made of Nitre and Alum without Vitriol) ‚Ñ•xij. which he mixes and di≈ø≈øolves: and then precipitates with water ‚Ñ•24. or ‚Ñ•32. in

¬ß 16. From this clear decanted Liquor you may with Volatile Spirit of Sal-Armoniack produce more Precipitate as afore≈øaid, which remains in≈øen≈øibly in the Particles of the Liquor; or you may have an Orange tawny, by doing it with a fixt Alcali, as Oil of Tartar per Deliquium.

¬ß 17. The rea≈øon of this Precipitation has in part been explicated at ¬ß 8.9.10. and 11. aforegoing; but to ≈øuch as that may prove no ≈øati≈øfaction to, we ≈øay that po≈ø≈øibly the ‚Ä¢ recipitation may be cau≈øed by other means; as, either from the Sympathy of Acids one with another by which means another differing Acid joyning with the former, the former to lay fa≈øt hold of the latter, lets go its hold of the Mercury, and ≈øo lets it fall down to the bottom.

¬ß 18. Or el≈øe from the Antipathy of their Natures (for there are Acids which will be de≈øtroyed one by another, as well as by Alcali's) the latter Acid oppo≈øing the former, and weaking of it ≈øo much, as that it cannot be able to ≈øu≈øpend the Particles of the Matter di≈ø≈øolved, whereby mixing together they make a kind of new body.

¬ß 19. But 'tis certain that the quantity of water, not only weakens the A. F. or Spirit of Nitre, but al≈øo gives the Salts the liberty of Motion and Action, making them able to penetrate other Bodies: for though the Cry≈øtals of each Salt are all of a different bigne≈øs and ≈øhape, yet they are either thicker or ≈ølenderer, blunter or ≈øharper according to the quantity of Water in which they are di≈ø≈øolved and cry≈øtalliz'd; for being di≈ø≈øolved in a larger quantity of Water the Cry≈øtals are much ≈ølenderer, finer, and ≈øharper, than if di≈ø≈øolved in a ≈ømall quantity; for the quantity of Water making a more numerous divi≈øion of their Particles, it dimini≈øhes their quantity, and ≈øharpens their Points, whereby it renders them more ≈øit to enter one in another,

¬ß 25.
