But Lemery has a more exact way, which is this: ‚Ñû Quick-≈øilver revived from Cinnabar ‚Ñ•iv. put it into a gla≈øs Retort, and affu≈øe thereon rectified Oyl of Vitriol ‚Ñ•xvj. mix and di≈ø≈øolve, and di≈øtil off the humidity in ≈øand, making the fire ≈øo ≈øtrong towards the end, that it may drive out ≈øome of the la≈øt ≈øpirits; at bottom you will find a white ma≈øs; break the Retort, and take it, pouder it in a gla≈øs Mortar, (it will weigh about ‚Ñ•v≈øs.) and affu≈øe thereon warm Water, ≈øo will it pre≈øently change into a yellow Precipitate or Pouder, which edulcorate by many repeated Ablutions, then dry it in the ≈øhade, and you will have ‚Ñ•iij ¬º. then put it into a Gla≈øs, and keep it clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 3. Le Mort u≈øes the ≈øame Ingredients and Proportions, but he evaporates the Humidity over a ≈øtrong Fire, after di≈ø≈øolution, becau≈øe that which is di≈øtilled off is exceeding weak, the Mercury retaining the greate≈øt part of the acid Spirits, which are the matter that purge ≈øo vehemently, though many of them be taken away by the Lotion.
¬ß 4. He would have the Ve≈ø≈øel to have a red-hot heat, but it ought to be ≈øhort, le≈øt mo≈øt of the Salts vani≈øhing, the Mercury ≈øhould become a grey pouder.

¬ß 5. And though Authors ≈øay, that the greater quantity which the Mercury drinks up of the Oyl, the greater will be its fixation; yet that is quantity ≈øufficient enough, which will di≈ø≈øolve and retain the Mercury; what is more does but encrea≈øe the labour and augment the price of the Medicament.

¬ß 6. The Water which is decanted off in the edulcoration is not to be rejected, becau≈øe it contains di≈ø≈øolved in it ≈øome of the Mercury, thro' the mediation of the Spirit adhering: This by ≈øome fix'd Salt (as of Tartar) is precipitated of an inten≈øe yellow, or an Orange-tawny colour, nearly of the ≈øame nature with the Turpethum Minerale, but more mild or gentle.

¬ß 7. Beguinus u≈øes Oyl of Sulphur per Campanum, in≈øtead of Oyl of Vitriol, but his proportions and way of doing it are wholly the ≈øame with the former. And this Turpethum Minerale, he ≈øaith, is the be≈øt Precipitation which is prepared from ≈øimple Mercury; and in this, I think, he is in the right.

¬ß 8. That Oyl of Sulphur is better for this Preparation than Oyl of Vitriol, you have the Suffrage of Crolliuc, who not only pre≈øcribes Oyl of Sulphur, but prefers it before all other corro≈øive Oyls, and affirms, that it far more powerfully precipitates and coagulates it than Oyl of Vitriol, ≈øo that it will endure a much ≈øtronger Fire. His method of making it is thus:

¬ß 9. ‚Ñû Quicksilver purified ‚Ñ•iv. rectified Oyl of Sulphur per Campanum, q. ≈ø. mix and di≈ø≈øolve, dige≈øting two days in Sand, afterwards by Retort; di≈øtil with a gentle heat; the liquor which comes off cohobate and repeat it the third time; the fourth time add a little more fre≈øh Oyl of Sulphur, in a new and well-luted Retort; di≈øtil again, and about the end encrea≈øe the Fire, that the Retort may grow very hot, and ≈øo di≈øtil, that the Mercury may be precipitated or left at bottom in a white ma≈øs: Break the Ve≈ø≈øel with an Iron Ring, take out the matter, grind it on a Marble very well, and with di≈øtilled Rain-water warm, wa≈øh away the Acrimony in a Gla≈øs with a wide mouth; work it well for four hours together, let it ≈øettle and decant: This wa≈øhing ≈øo often repeat, till no ≈øharpne≈øs be perceived, and the Precipitate becomes a pure yellow pouder; this pouder put into a Bolt-head, which tye over with a paper, and place it in a pretty ≈øtrong Sand-heat, to dige≈øt for eight days, in which time, if any of the Mercury is not ≈øufficiently di≈ø≈øolved and precipitated, it will ≈øpontaneou≈øly ≈øublime it ≈øelf in the neck of the Gla≈øs, which afterwards with a red hot Iron Ring cut off; the ma≈øs at bottom take out, and burn off thrice from it Spirit of Wine, then carefully put it up for u≈øe.

¬ß 10. Now, a ≈øign that the Preparation is well performed is, that if it be ≈øtrongly ≈øtirred with Gold, the Gold will not be made white at all thereby, (as it is when it is touched with crude Mercury) the Precipitate is therefore better, and may more ≈øecurely be taken inwardly into the Body.
¬ß 11. Nor is it needful that it be altogether fixt, for ≈øo it lo≈øes its purging Vertue, nor will it operate then in Man's Body at all.

¬ß 12. And though Oyls of Vitriol or Sulphur be the ≈øtronge≈øt and mo≈øt cau≈øtick Acids of tho≈øe Minerals, yet they are much weaker than Spirit of Nitre, and ≈øo require a greater quantity of them,
and a longer time to di≈ø≈øolve the Mercury in, for the di≈ø≈øolution will hardly be di≈øpatch'd in ten hours.

¬ß 13. This Precipitate, as well as all others, may be revived into Quicksilver again, by mixing with Lime, and di≈øtilling them, as in the Revivification of Cinnabar, for the Alcali of the Lime de≈øtroys the Acids which di≈øgui≈øe the Quicksilver.

¬ß 14. Mercury, ≈øays Crollius, is the Bal≈øam of Nature, in which is an incarnative vertue, whereby it wonderfully re≈øtores and purifies the microco≈ømick body infected with the French Pox; for when the whole ma≈øs of Blood is corrupted and tainted with the Seminaries of many Di≈øea≈øes, then the≈øe Metallicks, rarified like Fire, acquire ≈øuch a penetrating force, that they pa≈øs through the whole habit of the Body.

¬ß 15. Schroder, Zwelfer, Marggrave, and Maets follow Crollius, in making it with Oyl of Sulphur; but Charras makes it with either Oyl of Sulphur or Vitriol, and di≈øtils as afore≈øaid, in which, he ≈øays, the fir≈øt Water that comes away will be almo≈øt in≈øipid; but towards the end the acid Spirits will al≈øo come over in part, the Mercury retaining a good part of the Spirits which di≈ø≈øolved it.

¬ß 16. But whereas tho≈øe who make it with Oyl of Vitriol u≈øe only a double quantity of it, if you u≈øe Oyl of Sulphur in≈øtead thereof, you ought, ≈øays Le Mort, to have a greater proportion: And Maets u≈øes it in a triple, viz. to Mercury ‚Ñ•j. Oyl of Sulphur ‚Ñ•ij.

¬ß 17. Haec ma≈ø≈øa ≈øi in crucibulo, igne aperto, fundatur, habebis ≈øub≈øtantiam fixam, quam Poterius elaborat in ≈øub≈øtantiam auream, ex qua formari po≈ø≈øunt annuli, & ulterius in Mercurium fixum elaborari. Collect. Chym. cap. 258. pag. 289.

¬ß 18. The Vertues a≈øcribed to this famous Medicine are many, we will deliver you them from Crollius him≈øelf, though po≈ø≈øibly the Author of this work has had as large Experience thereof as any man living upon Earth. It is a Remedy (≈øays he) again≈øt Di≈øea≈øes from putrefaction of Humors, and in de≈øperate Di≈øtempers there is ≈øcarcely any thing that gives more ≈øpeedy relief.

¬ß 19. It expels all vi≈øcous Humors, helps Defluxions of the Brain, purifies the Blood in the Veins, and the Marrow in the Bones; it is a Specifick
in the Drop≈øy and Gout, given in a Cathartick Pill, and in the Pleuri≈øie with a Specifick Vehicle, (given to Infants afflicted with Coughs and Shortne≈øs of Breath, or fulne≈øs of the Praecordia, it is wonderfully profitable, the fir≈øt day being exhibited half a grain, the ≈øecond and third days a grain, in ≈øome pectoral Syrup.)

¬ß 20. It is good again≈øt venereal Poy≈øons and Scabs, all ≈øorts of Feavers, continual and intermitting, the French Pox, though inveterate, for it heals and eradicates all venereal Ulcers, Gums, Tophs, Nodes, Warts, &c. by reiterating the Do≈øe; cures the Jaundice, and all ≈øorts of running Sores.

¬ß 21. Paracel≈øus, in curing the Lues Venerea, exhibited it in Electuary of Juice of Ro≈øes: And Phoedro very happily removed Venereal Tumors, giving it with Spirit of Tartar: Heu≈øerus (who publi≈øhed Paracel≈øus's Works) affirms, that in his mo≈øt frequent exhibiting thereof, he never found any detriment to en≈øue, unle≈øs ≈øometimes in cholerick Vomitings, where it excited ≈øometimes pain or heat in the Throat and Mouth, which pre≈øently by u≈øing a Gargari≈øm or Terra Sigillata was removed.

¬ß 22. The Do≈øe is √† gr. ij. ad v. or vj. but now in our days bold Arti≈øts will venture to give it to gr. viij. or xij. ≈øuch great Do≈øes ought not to be adventur'd on, except to very ≈øtrong per≈øons. It is given mixt with Pil. Ruffi, Pil. Rudii, Confectio Hamech, or purging Extracts, and it operates better being given in Juice of Liquorice, than in Mithridate or Venice Treacle; Con≈øerve or Sugar of Ro≈øes are good Vehicles, or it may be ≈øwallowed made up into Pills with white Bread, drinking a little Wine or Cordial Water after it.

div.head: LXXVI. Mercurius Praecipitatus gri≈øeus; Grey Precipitate.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Turpethum Minerale, wa≈øh it in Ro≈øe-water, and dry it, then imbibe it in rectified S. V. and add Camphir di≈ø≈øolved in a like quantity of the ≈øaid rectified S. V. from whence with a gentle fire ab≈øtract the Spirit S. A. Do≈øe √† gr. iij. ad viij. &c. It purges downwards, or by Stool.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. That is, to ‚Ñ•i. of Turbeth Minerale wa≈øhed
in Ro≈øe-water, ‚Ä¢ ried and imbibed with rectified S. V. you mu≈øt add Camphir ‚Ñ•j. di≈ø≈øolved in a ≈øufficient quantity of rectified S. V. and then with a very gentle Fire ab≈øtract the Spirit. See the Officina Chymica.

¬ß 2. It has all the vertues of Turbeth Mineral, but works chiefly downwards, for which rea≈øon it makes not the Patient ≈øo ≈øick, nor ≈øo much out of order, and therefore may be given in the larger d ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ , as √† gr. iv. ad x. according to Age and Strength.

¬ß 3. It cures the French Pox, and all the Symptoms attending it, as virulent Gonorrhoea's, Gleets, Gums, Tophs, Nodes; and particularly it is a Specifick again≈øt Nocturnal Pains, being given in a little Mithridate, or Con≈øerve of Ro≈øes, at night going to bed, and ≈øleeping upon it, repeating the do≈øe for two or three nights together, and then cea≈øing two or three nights, or purging with ≈øome gentle Cathartick, to carry off the Recrements of the matter, and prevent Salivation, after which it is to be taken in like manner for two or three nights more, and the ≈øame method to be continued till about 10 or 12 do≈øes are taken.

¬ß 4. It is an excellent thing al≈øo again≈øt the Scurvy, Drop≈øy, Gout, Jaundice, Scabs, Itch, Lep ‚Ä¢ o≈øy, Tetters, Ring-worms, Feavers, and all Di≈øea≈øes what≈øoever, proceeding from corruption and putrefaction of the Humors, but it mu≈øt be u≈øed with the Caution aforementioned, to avoid Salivation: In Agues give it ≈øix hours before the coming of the Fit.

div.head: LXXVII. Mercurius Praecipitatus Incarnatus; Fle≈øhcolour'd Precipitate.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Mercury or Quicksilver ‚Ñ•i. which di≈ø≈øolve in A. F. ‚Ñ•ij. add to it boiling Water ‚Ñ•iij. and precipitate with new made ∆≤rine, wa≈øh and dry S. A. It only works by Stool, and has the ≈øame vertues with the Arcanum Corallinum. Do≈øe gr. vj. ad xij.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Urine ought to be the Urine of a ≈øound man, which, as Hartman ≈øays, mu≈øt be ≈øo much as may be ≈øufficient to moi≈øten the Mercury, by which means the Mercury will be precipitated Incarnate. This only works downwards, ≈øays he,
and may be given √† gr. vj. ad xij.

¬ß 2. But Charras advi≈øes, to put in the Urine ≈øo long till the Ebulition cea≈øes: The colour, ≈øays he, proceeds from the union of the Spirit of Nitre with the Salt of Urine, and the impre≈ø≈øion which that conjunction makes upon the Mercury.

¬ß 3. And the unition of the Urine with the Spirit of Nitre renders the effects of this Precipitate more gentle than that of Turbeth Mineral, who≈øe effects depend chiefly upon the la≈øt Spirits of Vitriol or Sulphur, which have di≈ø≈øolved it, and are as it were concentrated with it, for which rea≈øon this Precipitate purges only downwards.

¬ß 4. It is an excellent thing again≈øt the French Pox, and all its numerous Symptoms or Attendants, but is found to be a Specifick again≈øt the Stone, whether in the Reins or Bladder (for which I have prov'd it an excellent thing) as al≈øo in the Gout, Drop≈øy, Jaundice, and Rheumati≈øm.
¬ß 5. It is a valuable Remedy, and as it may be given ≈øafer than many other Precipitates, ≈øo al≈øo with more eminent and certain effects.

¬ß 6. Now, by rea≈øon Urine contains an alcalious Salt di≈ø≈øolved, when drop'd or put into the di≈ø≈øolution of Mercury in A. F. or Spirit of Nitre, it breaks or de≈øtroys the edges or points of the Acid, which held up the Mercury imperceptible, and ≈øerved like as Finns to make it ≈øwim in the di≈ø≈øolvant, ≈øo that the Quick≈øilver having nothing to bear it up, it precipitates by its own weight.

¬ß 7. And in this all Alcalies agree, in enervating or de≈øtroying the power of the Acid; yet neverthele≈øs they always do it with ≈øome difference in their action, which evidently appears in the different-colour'd Precipitates, which can only be attributed to proceed from their ≈øeveral ways and manners of working upon Acids, whereby they di≈øpo≈øe and modifie the Particles of the precipitated body, ≈øo as to be capable of breaking various ways the beams of Light, and ≈øo by reflection to make as many appearances of colour.

¬ß 8. For corro≈øive Sublimate being di≈ø≈øolved in boiling fair Water, if you drop into it Oil of Tartar per deliquium, you have a reddi≈øh or Orange-tawny Precipitate; if Urine, another colour'd
Pouder; if Spirit of Sal Armoniack, the Precipitate will be white; but if Lime-water, the Precipitate will be yellow.

¬ß 9. Now, in all the≈øe the Mercury and its Di≈ø≈øolvent is one and the ≈øame, and all the Precipitants are Alcalies, yet you ≈øee different colours ari≈øe, which can only be from the difference of the Alcali, and its different way of working upon the Acid.

¬ß 10. The≈øe Precipitates now are no longer Poy≈øons, though they are produced from corro≈øive Sublimate; for the Acid which made the Mercury poy≈øonous, being now enervated and de≈øtroyed, and the Mercury being thereby delivered, it re≈øumes its former innocent nature, and becomes ≈øweet‚ñ™ and friendly to Nature.

¬ß 11. If upon the Liquor of the Orange-tawny Precipitate you ≈øhould affu≈øe Oyl of Vitriol or Sulphur, the Acid, by contending and penetrating the Oleum Tartari, would cau≈øe an Ebulition, whereby the Alcali would be de≈øtroyed, and the Precipitate again di≈ø≈øolved, and the liquor becoming clear, would be a Poy≈øon, as before.
¬ß 12. But by affu≈øion again of fre≈øh Oyl of Tartar, then Spirit of Sal Armoniack upon it, you would have again new reddi≈øh and white Precipitates.

¬ß 13. La≈øtly, If upon this Liquor and Precipitates you ≈øhould affu≈øe again more Oyls of Vitriol or Sulphur, (but in a larger quantity than before, becau≈øe the Acid has not only the Mercury to di≈ø≈øolve anew but al≈øo a greater quantity of the Alcali to contend withal) you will find the whole to be clear again, and re≈øume its former poy≈øonous nature.

div.head: LXXVIII. Mercurius Praecipitatus Laxativus; Laxative Precipitate.
div.p:
Bate.] It is made of Mercury or Quicksilver, by putting to it Oyl of Vitriol or Sulphur, and dige≈øting in a Sand-heat, till the Mercury is cry≈øtallized; the≈øe Cry≈øtals are put into a Crucible, and made red-hot, for an hour, by the help of a proper fire, then being ca≈øt into hot water, a yellow pouder precipitates: Decant the water, and take the pouder, which wa≈øh and dry, burning off from it. S. V. S. A. It purges „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , ≈øur≈øum & deor≈øum, upwards and downward. Do≈øe gr. iij. ad x. It is of wonderful force in
rooting out and de≈øtroying the French Pox, Gout, Yellow Jaundice, Drop≈øie, Scabs, &c.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Hartman was the Author of it, and out of his Pract. Chym. pag. mea, 8. b. we will give you it word for word, tran≈ølation only excepted.

¬ß 2. ‚Ñû Quicksilver q. ≈ø. upon which affu≈øe Oyl of Sulphur per Campanum, ≈øo much as to overtop the Mercury an inch; ≈øet them ≈øo long in a hot A≈øh-heat, till by the heat the Mercury is coagulated, which will be in the ≈øpace of thrre hours; cover the Ve≈ø≈øel with Paper, through which the volatile ≈øpirits may pa≈øs, then cool the Ve≈ø≈øel, and take out the matter, and if any of the Quicksilver happen to remain in the bottom, ≈øeparate it: The matter pulverize, and put it into a Crucible, letting it ≈øtand in an open fire for an hour, till the whole is red-hot, which done, remove the Crucible, and put the matter into warm water, and it will become a very bright pouder: Decant that water, and affu≈øe more, wa≈øhing it and drying it; then dige≈øt it with S. V. fiften days; afterwards decant the S. V. and dry the Mercury upon hot Iron Plates.

¬ß 3. It purges both by Vomit and Stool, and evacuates all malign and evil Humors in the French Pox, Rheumati≈øm, Scurvy, Gout, Drop≈øy and Jaundice, and removes mo≈øt Di≈øea≈øes proceeding from Ob≈øtructions of the Vilcera. Do≈øe √† gr. v, ad x, or xij. if in ≈øtrong Bodies.

¬ß 4. Modus Utendi. ‚Ñû Mithridate í ≈øs. or í j. of this Precipitate √† gr. iv. ad x. Oyl of Citrons or Limons gut. iij. mix for a Do≈øe, to be given at night going to Bed, and repeated for two or three nights, then intermitting it for three or four days, it may be given in like manner again.

¬ß 4. But if the Sick ≈øhould be in danger of fluxing, (as ≈øome ea≈øie Bodies will be) you mu≈øt either take a purging Do≈øe or two after every ≈øecond or third Do≈øe, or el≈øe give it in a Cathartick after this manner: ‚Ñû Confectio Hamech í ≈øs. ad í j. of this Precipitate gr. viij. Oyl of Limons gut. iij. mix for a Do≈øe. Or thus: ‚Ñû Pil. Cochiae í ≈øs. of this precipitate gr. vj. ad x. Oyl of Oranges gut. iij. mix for a do≈øe.

div.head: LXXIX. Mercurius Praecipitatus per ≈øe; Mercury precipitated by it ≈øelf.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Mercury put it into a Gla≈øs with a broad bottom, high and very clo≈øe-neckt, place it exactly in Sand, and give fire by degrees, till the Mercury is converted into a rubicund pouder, which take and wa≈øh with S. V. It is a work of many days, it wonderfully provokes Sweat, and at 6 or 7 times taking perfectly eradicates the French Pox. It takes away all Feavers, kills Worms, and in many cau≈øes violent Vomiting. Do≈øe √† gr. iij. ad vj. but the Precipitate will be more effectual if it be made with an eighth part of Sol; as hereafter is declared.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is a ≈øingular Preparation, and the be≈øt of all the Precipitates, and therefore we ≈øhall be a little more exact in ob≈øerving what Authors have ≈øaid concerning it. Crollius makes it thus: Take a Gla≈øs flat and broad, (near a cubit in breadth) high, and very clo≈øe-neck'd, having an Orifice no bigger than a Needle may go into, turn'd in with a wide mouth, that the Mercury may be poured into it: Into this Gla≈øs put purified Quicksilver, ≈øo much as may every where cover the bottom, place it ≈øo exactly in Sand, that no part of the Mercury, by the unequal placing of the Gla≈øs, be either higher or lower; this done, decoct it at fir≈øt with a gentle heat, then with a more ≈øtrong fire, till it becomes a mo≈øt red pouder like Cinnabar, which edulcorate with Cordial Waters, or S.V.

¬ß 2. This, ≈øays he, powerfully provokes Sweat, and being 6 or 7 times exhibited in a Lues Venerea, it wholly roots out and exterminates the Di≈øea≈øe; more e≈øpecially if other things nece≈ø≈øary in this Cure be al≈øo duly performed, it cures all ≈øorts of Feavers, both continual and intermitting.

¬ß 3. Schroder makes it exactly after the ≈øame manner, but ≈øays it is a work of thirty days. Be≈øides the former Vertues, he ≈øays, it kills Worms, but vomits violently, and commends it more if it be made with an eighth part of Gold.

¬ß 4. Rolfincius Chym. lib. 5 ≈øect. 6. cap. 3. Prepares it in a like Ve≈ø≈øel, and almo≈øt after the ≈øame manner; in the ≈øpace of eight days he coagulates it, then breaks the Ve≈ø≈øel, grinds the matter into a mo≈øt ≈øubtil pouder in a gla≈øs Mortar, then
puts it again into a gla≈øs Ve≈ø≈øel, and dige≈øts in a ≈øand-heat for four or five days more, or till all things within grow black; he breaks the Ve≈ø≈øel again, and pulverizes the matter anem, putting it into a new Phial, and makes a calcination with an inten≈øe degree of Fire, till the Mercury ri≈øes up or ≈øhoots forth into a kind of Grove (as it were) of little Trees, or a company of young Shoots and ≈ølender Sprigs growing together as out of the Ground, of an Orange-tawny or red colour, which by little and little fall down again. This, ≈øays he, loo≈øens the Belly, provokes Sweat, and oftentimes cau≈øes vomiting.

¬ß 5. Le Febure makes it thus: ‚Ñû A double Ve≈ø≈øel, called by Chymi≈øts Infernus, or A Hell, flat and broad in the bottom; put into it purified Quicksilver, i. e. revived from Cinnabar ‚Ñ•iij. or iv. ≈øtop the upper part of it with a ≈øingle Paper, and place it in Sand equally in its poi≈øe, ≈øo as the Quicksilver may be evenly ≈øpread upon the whole bottom of the Ve≈ø≈øel, lying no thicker on one part than on another, that the Fire may equally work on the whole: Make at fir≈øt a ≈øoft Fire, and encrea≈øe it by degrees, till all the Q. S. be changed, calcined, or precipitated into a red Pouder, like Mineral-Cinnabar, very bright, ≈øhining and ≈øparkling to the Eye, then dige≈øt it the ≈øpace of 21 days in Alcohol of S. V. afterwards, deflagrate from it al≈øo rectified S. V. ≈øeven times, ≈øo will the decoction and fixation of it be perfected.

¬ß 6. This, ≈øays he, is an univer≈øal Remedy again≈øt all Agues, and a true Specifick again≈øt the French Pox, which it radically cures, if given ≈øeven times to the Patient, to provoke Sweating, for it is an infallible Sudorifick. It kills al≈øo Worms in the Stomach, Guts, and Inte≈øtinum Rectum.

¬ß 7. The Do≈øe is √† gr. ij. ad viij, in ≈øome Con≈øerve, Confection, or Cordial Extract; the Sick mu≈øt keep his Bed when he u≈øes it, and mu≈øt be ≈øure to be well covered, patiently expecting the Diaphore≈øis, which will not fail to bring along with it the de≈øired effects.

¬ß 8. Nor mu≈øt the Arti≈øt him≈øelf grow weary in the preparation of this Medicament, though the Operation be long and tedious, for he mu≈øt take care to govern and manage the Fire with Judgment and Di≈øcretion, otherwi≈øe he will be often forced to begin his work anew, for
a ≈ømall fault in the Fire will cau≈øe the Ve≈ø≈øel to break.

¬ß 9. This Operation is very tedious, by rea≈øon of the length of time in which it is a doing, for it can ≈øcarcely be perfected under fourty days; yea, ≈øometimes it may be 90, 100, or 120 days, before it may be accompli≈øhed, according as you take care to prepare your Mercury well or ill, and according to your care and a≈ø≈øiduity in keeping and managing your Fire.

¬ß 10. Now 'tis only Sulphur can rubifie Mercury, as evidently appears by its reduction into Cinnabar, from which rea≈øon and the former operation of calcining it per ≈øe, it is evident, that common Quicksilver has a Sulphur external and ≈øeparable from the E≈ø≈øence of Mercury. To this Experience we may add the Te≈øtimonies of Geber, and many other of the Ancients, and learned in this Art, who continually te≈øtifie the ≈øame.

¬ß 11. When it is re≈øu≈øcitated or regenerated out of Silver, or any other perfect Metal, ≈øo as to be exqui≈øitely clean≈øed from any foreign or poy≈øonous matter, and then according to Art precipitated to a redne≈øs, it becomes a Medicine not to be de≈øpi≈øed, which provokes neither Stool nor Vomit unle≈øs it be given in an unrea≈øonable Do≈øe.

¬ß 12. The external Sulphur in Mercury (≈øays Tachenius) is the cau≈øe of Vomit and Salivation, and not the corro≈øive Spirits with which it is precipitated or ≈øublimated, which the very anointing with crude Quicksilver proves; wherein the acid Sulphur of the Mercury, piercing the Skin, after the manner of other Acids, joyning with the inward occult Acid of the Body, ab≈øorbs the Alcaly of the Ventricles, and by making the internal Acid of the Body more acid, and a mo≈øt ≈øtrong Poy≈øon, it extingui≈øhes the alcalious faculty, and then re≈øolves, as Cau≈øticks do, all the Aliments and Juices of the Body into a putrid Recrement.

¬ß 13. So this occult venomous acidity of the Sulphur of Mercury does primarily hurt the Gums and Teeth, for all Sulphur (witne≈øs the Oleum Sulphuris per Campanum) has an occult Acid: And as Mercury has an external Sulphur, (containing in it an occult venomous Acid) ≈øo by vertue of that Sulphur it is precipitaed per ≈øe (as before declared) by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of a gentle and con≈øtant fire.

¬ß 14. For this rea≈øon it is that Tachenus would have Mercury regenerated out of Silver, or other perfect Metals, that it may be freed from its external and poy≈øonous Sulphur; then, ≈øays he, wanting that Sulphur, as it can never be precipiated per ≈øe, though decocted a whole year in the abovenamed flat-bottom'd Ve≈ø≈øel, with a proper Fire, yet will it move Sweat, and ≈øweetly perform its Operations, Rea≈øon and Experience confirming as much.

¬ß 15. And being thus divided in its e≈ø≈øential parts, (viz. freed from its poy≈øonous Sulphur) it may be reconjoyn'd with new and perfect Sulphur, and then it will become the ≈øubject of all Wonder. And if it be ≈øublimed with Sulphur to rubifie it, (as in the Preparation of Cinnabar) yet will it gain little or nothing in weight: which is an Ob≈øervation worth the con≈øidering.

¬ß 16. It remains only that we ≈øhew you Charras's way of performing the Operation of the vulgar Precipitate per ≈øe, and ≈øo conclude this Section. Get an Infernus, which is a Ve≈ø≈øel of double Gla≈øs, the neck whereof mu≈øt be long and very much like a Funnel, and the bottom thereof large and very broad; put into it Mercury revived from Cinnabar ‚Ñ•iv. ≈øet it in a Lamp-Fornace, in a ≈øand-heat, &c. then having filled a Lamp with Oyl, and lighted three Cotton Wicks of a fit bigne≈øs, and put them under the Sand Ve≈ø≈øel; ≈øo order it that they may burn without cea≈øing, and that the Oyl may not fail for fifteen days, at the end whereof make every Wick a third part bigger, and keep them lighted for fifteen other days: After thirty days make every Wick bigger by one half, burning as before for another month, or till the Q. S. becomes a red and ≈øhining pouder.

¬ß 17. Where note, that it is enough all the time to cover the top of the Ve≈ø≈øel with a ≈øingle Paper, and to take care that the Oyl be not wanting in the Lamps, but that all the Wicks may burn equally, and continually ca≈øting their Flame at an equal di≈øtance, to the bottom of the Sand-ve≈ø≈øel: This work is tedious, but that trouble not great, if you have a Ve≈ø≈øel and Fornace proper, and that the Ve≈ø≈øel be ≈øet in an equal poi≈øe.

¬ß 18. The Pouder wa≈øh with Cordial Waters, or dige≈øt for ≈øome days in Alcohol
of Wine, then ab≈øtract the Spirit, and keep the Pouder for u≈øe.

¬ß 19. It is diaphoretick, and apt to provoke great Sweats, but often cau≈øes vomiting withal; but it is one of the be≈øt Preparations of Mercury, for the rooting out Venereal Di≈øtempers; and curing Agues; and it is a Specifick for killing Worms of all ≈øorts, being given √† gr. ij. ad viij. in ≈øome proper Con≈øerve or Sweating Electuary or Bolus.

div.head: LXXX. Mercurius Praecipitatus ruber; Red Precipitate.
div.p: Bate.] Di≈ø≈øolve Quicksilver ‚Ñ•i. in A. F. ‚Ñ•ij. ab≈øtract the A. F. from the Mercury by di≈øtillation with three cohobations, till the Mercury becomes a red pouder. It has the vertues of the former.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is called Vigo's Precipitate, becau≈øe he was the Author of it; and he made it by di≈ø≈øolving Quick≈øilver in A F. and then evaporating to dryne≈øs, the Fire being encrea≈øed, till the bottom of the Ve≈ø≈øel is made red-hot, whereby is made a mo≈øt red ≈øparkling Pouder, which is the vulgar red Precipitate.

¬ß 2. And of this is made that Medicament which is called The Prince's Pouder, a thing much famed of late years in London, thus: ‚Ñû Of the former red Precipitate ‚Ñ•i. grind it upon a Porphyry to a ≈øubtil Pouder; add to it í ij. of Oleum Tartari per deliq. which dige≈øt together 24 hours, ≈øtirring it now and then; upon this put tartari≈øed S. V. to overtop it an inch, and deflagrate it, which repeat twenty times, and it is done.

¬ß 3. This is the true Recipe, as it came from the Prince's own Hand, and was communicated to me by Sir Francis Blundel Baronet, of Kings-County in Ireland, who purchas'd it of the ≈øaid Prince with a con≈øiderable ≈øum of Money. It is given in the Yolk of an Egg or Con≈øerve of Ro≈øes, Mithridate, &c. The Prince gave it í≈øs. ad íj. which in my opinion is too great a do≈øe, it may be given √† gr. iij. ad x, xij, xv, or xx. according to the age, ≈øtrength, and malignity of the Di≈øea≈øe.

¬ß 4. It is famous in curing the French Pox, and all the Symptoms attending it, as al≈øo the Scurvy, Drop≈øy, Gout, Sciatica, and mo≈øt Chronick Di≈øea≈øes which afflict the extream parts; and
I have known it to be a Specifick again≈øt the Stone, Sand, Gravel, and all manner of Ob≈øtructions of the Reins and Bladder, doing that in tho≈øe ca≈øes which none of the vulgar Nephriticks and Diureticks could po≈ø≈øibly perform.

¬ß 5. From the proce≈øs of the Prince's Pouder it appears, that it is nothing but Common red Precipitate corrected with Oyl of Tartar and Spirit of Wine, by which the greate≈øt part of the Acid remaining in the vulgar Precipitate is ab≈øorbed or de≈øtroyed, and ≈øo thereby the Medicament made more mild and gentle.

¬ß 6. And of this Opinion was Tachenius in his Clavis, where he ≈øays, If upon red Precipitate you pour Alcali of Tartar, and leave it for an hour in a warm place, the whole pouder will become ob≈øcurely yellow, or of an Orange-tawny colour, becau≈øe the Alcali has in part ab≈øorbed the Cau≈øtick Acid left by the Aqua-fortis.

¬ß 7. But the Vertues of the ≈øimple Red Precipitate without correction is ≈øtrongly and without almo≈øt any pain, to ab≈øume and eat up the thicker Sordes of Ulcers, callous proud Fle≈øh, Apo≈øtemes in the Fundament, and other like Excre≈øcencies; yea, it cures all ≈øordid, putrid, mattery, callous Shingles, ≈øometimes alone, and ≈øometimes in Empla≈øters or Unguents, as nece≈ø≈øity requires.

¬ß 8. Rolfincius Chym. lib. 5. ≈øect. 6. cap. 2. makes it after the vulgar manner, and ≈øays, that it is very rarely given inwardly; but if ≈øo exhibited, that it works powerfully „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , both by Vomit and Stool, which after many Lotions in Ro≈øe-water he gives √† ‚Ñà≈øs. ad ‚Ñàj. which is a Do≈øe in my opinion too large by two thirds of it, unle≈øs corrected as above≈øaid after the manner of the Princes Pouder. See my Pharm. Lond. lib. 3. cap. 7. ≈øect. 22.

¬ß 9. Charras makes this vulgar Red Precipitate thus: ‚Ñû Good Quicksilver, or refined, A. F. or Spirit of Nitre A. put them into a gla≈øs Retort in a gentle ≈øand-heat to di≈ø≈øolve, then bury the Retort in Sand all over, fitting to it a Receiver; encrea≈øe the fire gradually, and continue it till the A. F. or Sp. Nitri is almo≈øt all drawn off; letting all cool, cohobate the A. F. or S. Nitri upon the Mercury in the Retort, and draw it off again as before: Cohobate this three times and ab≈øtract forcing the
fire at la≈øt more than ordinary to augment the colour of the Precipitate, which will be of a much fairer red than that which is calcined at the end in a Crucible, where you lo≈øe of the weight of the Mercury, and are endangered by the poy≈øonous Vapors of the A. F. or Sp. Nitri, &c. The ≈øhining red ma≈øs at bottom, if you intend to give it inwardly (≈øays he) mu≈øt be pouder'd, and rectified S. V. is to be deflegmated from it, and ≈øo kept in a gla≈øs Bottle clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 10. He gives it inwardly to men of ≈øtrong Con≈øtitutions ad gr. vij, or viij. at mo≈øt at a time; but its principal u≈øe is for outward applications, as well in Pomatums and other Remedies to cure the defedations of the Skin, as to be mixed with other Oyntments and Bal≈øams to con≈øume proud Fle≈øh and other ≈øuperfluities of malign and venereal Ulcers; and it is the u≈øual Remedy which Chyrurgions apply to Cankers and Warts upon the ≈øecret parts.
¬ß 11. But here is to be noted, that if you intend to give it inwardly, you mu≈øt not u≈øe A. F. in the preparation thereof, but Spirit of Nitre, or an A. F. made only of Nitre and Alum.

¬ß 12. Maets and Marggrave both make it after the ≈øame manner, but without any cohobation of the ab≈øtracted Spirit, and at la≈øt calcine it a little, (for if the Fire ≈øhould be continued too long, all the corro≈øive Spirits would be forced from the Mercury, whereby ≈øome part of it would be revived, and the other not revived, of a dirty, dull, red colour, without any ≈øparkling brightne≈øs or ≈øhining:) then edulcorate it by wa≈øhing it in Rain-water, and burning off from it S. V. five or ≈øix times.

¬ß 13. This Precipitate (≈øays he) if it be corrected, (I ≈øuppo≈øe he means with Oyl of Tartar, as above≈øaid) it is given for a Sudorifick in the French Pox, Drop≈øy, Quartan-Ague, profound Scab and Lepro≈øy, being mixed with Venice-Treacle, Mithridate, Con≈øerve of Ro≈øes, Confectio de Hyacintho, &c. but if for purging in Extractum Catholicum, Extract of the Juice of Ro≈øes, Confectio Hamech. Do≈øe √† gr. ij. ad v.

¬ß 14. Marggrave ≈øaith, it has a Cathoeretick force, and is u≈øed to take away Carno≈øities or fle≈øhly Excre≈øcencies, which it does ea≈øily,
and without pain; for which rea≈øon it conduces to the healing of Fi≈øtula's, Pu≈øtuls, and other external Di≈øea≈øes, if ≈øprinkled upon any Empla≈øter and applied, or injected with a Syring in Plantane-water: but then the Water ought to be made ≈øomewhat thick with Honey of Ro≈øes or ≈øome proper Syrup, that the Powder may not immediately ≈øink, or ≈øeparate it ≈øelf from the Vehicle.
¬ß 15. And being corrected he ≈øays, it is u≈øed by many as a Panacea for curing the French-Pox, given √† gr. iv. ad vj. ad Summum.

¬ß 16. According to Lemery it is thus. ‚Ñû Quick≈øilver revived from Cinnabar ‚Ñ•iv. Spirit of Nitre ‚Ñ•iv≈øs. di≈ø≈øolve in a Gla≈øs Matra≈øs with a ≈øhort Neck and in a Sand heat evaporate all the Humidity till a white Ma≈øs remains: then augment the Fire to the third degree in which keep it, till it is turned Red, then letting all cool, break the Gla≈øs and take your Precipitate, which will weigh ‚Ñ•iv≈øs.

¬ß 17. Some mix it (≈øays he) with burnt Alum, Aegyptiacum and the common ≈øuppurative, for the external U≈øes above-mentioned: and ≈øome give it inwardly, ad gr. iv. to rai≈øe a Flux, but this ≈øays he, is dangerous unle≈øs rectified S. V. be burnt two or three times off from it.

¬ß 18. Now it is to be ob≈øerved, that ≈øome think by two or three Cohobations of the Sp. Nitre to increa≈øe its Redne≈øs or its Virtues, but Experience ≈øhews the contrary, and that tho≈øe Cohobations are of no u≈øe.

¬ß 19. The white Ma≈øs remaining after evaporation of the Sp. Nitre, is a mixture of the Mercury with much of the Acid Spirit; ≈øo that of ‚Ñ•iv. of Quicksilver, you will have ‚Ñ•v≈øs. of that white Matter, which is very Corro≈øive: but according as it is calcin'd to make it red, the points and edges of the Spirit ≈øtrike off and vani≈øh in the Air; for which rea≈øon the more you calcine it to increa≈øe its redne≈øs, the le≈øs it weighs, and the le≈øs corro≈øive it is.

¬ß 20. If you put this red Precipitate into an Earthen Pan deflagrate from it well rectified S. V. and repeat this deflagration ≈øix times, you have Lemery's Arcanum Coralinum: in this Operation the S. V. by burning makes ≈øome part of the Acid Spirits to fly away, in place of which the Alcali of the S. V. joyns it ≈øelf to the Mercury, and thereby renders it more
≈øweet and fit to be taken inwardly.

¬ß 21. If you continue your red Precipitate for ≈øome hours over the Fire, it will ≈øublime of a red colour; but this red Sublimate, is nothing near ≈øo corro≈øive as the common white corro≈øive Sublimate. It cannot ≈øublime before it is calcined red, becau≈øe there is too much of the Acid Spirit which fixes it; but being freed from it in a great mea≈øure by Calcination, it has power to ari≈øe or ≈øublime with that which remains; And by rea≈øon the Acid has an aptne≈øs to fix, it checks the Volatility of the Mercury, and makes it ≈øtop in the middle of the Gla≈øs.

¬ß 22. If upon common Red Precipitate you affu≈øe volatile Spirit of Sal-Armoniack it becomes of a grey colour: ≈øo al≈øo if into the Solution of Quick≈øilver in Sp. Nitre, you drop in the ≈øaid Spirit of Sal-Armoniack you will have a grey Precipitate; and if upon either of them you affu≈øe a good quantity of fair Water, you will have a milky Liquor, tho' none of the white≈øt.

¬ß 23. If on common red Precipitate you affu≈øe Spirit of Salt; it becomes pre≈øently a delicate White; for the ≈øame thing mu≈øt happen here, as when Spirit of Salt is ca≈øt into a Solution of Q. S. in Spirit of Nitre; for tho red Precipitate be a dry body, it is nothing but a Conjunction of Mercury with the Nitrous Spirit.

¬ß 24. But the immediate change of the colour ≈øeems ≈øtrange, that ≈øo red a Sub≈øtance ≈øhould in a moment of time as it were become ≈øo exceeding white: this without doubt mu≈øt be attributed to the new ≈øituation of the Mercurial Particles, whereby their Superficies reflect the Light in right Lines, or a different Po≈øition from the former to our Eyes, thereby to give room for this white Colour.

¬ß 25. Again, ≈øhould another Acid Liquor, or any Alcali be affu≈øed thereon, it would be again changed, and ≈øome other colour would ari≈øe, or el≈øe it would revive into Quick≈øilver; from which Experiments a kind of demon≈øtration is made, that Colour is no real and ≈øub≈øtantial thing, but wholly depends on the Modification of the Particles of the Mixt.

¬ß 26. La≈øtly, if on common red Precipitate you affu≈øe Oil of Vitriol, it will be di≈ø≈øolved for the Spirit of Vitriol j'oyning with the Spirit
of Nitre in the Precipitate, an A. F. is made, which di≈ø≈øolves perfectly the Mercurial Particles without any Ebullition or Efferve≈øcence: the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe the Mercury has already been rarified by the Acid Spirit of Nitre, ≈øo that the Spirit of Vitriol enters the Pores of the Mercury, and by Conjunction of the Nitrious Spirit di≈ø≈øolves it without trouble. This Solution is clear, like other di≈ø≈øolutions of Mercury, without any redne≈øs; and thereof may be made the ≈øame Preparations as may be made of Quicksilver di≈ø≈øolved in Aqua fortis or Spirit of Nitre.

div.head: LXXXI. Mercurius praecipitatus Solaris per ≈øe: Golden Precipitate, or Precipitate with Gold.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of an Amalgama made of Quick-≈øilver ‚Ñ•iv. and Gold purified with Antimony ‚Ñ•≈øs. in a Gla≈øs Infernus, po≈øited as before directed (at Sect. 78.) which is often to be taken out and beaten in a Mortar S. A.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Rolfincius calls this Preparation Radix aurea, and Precipitatus ruber compo≈øitus; and makes it exactly in the ≈øame proportions, dige≈øting the Amalgama in a Phial, for the ≈øpace of two Months in a gentle and continual Sand heat: Sen≈øim ma≈ø≈øa ad≈øurgit in ≈øpeciem fruticeti aurei, & qua≈øi cre≈øcere Videtur: Sen≈øim rurs√πm ad fundum Vergit; then being of a re≈øplendent rubicund colour, he takes the Precipitate out, pouders it, and keeps it for u≈øe.

¬ß 2. It is accounted by Zehnerus as a Panacea of great Vertues, purging alone „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , both by Vomit and Stool, according as the Do≈øe is increa≈øed: but in a ≈ømall Do≈øe it is diaphoretick: to little Infants it is given, ad gr. j. to Children from five to ≈øeven Years of age √† gr. j≈øs. ad ij. and ≈øo increa≈øing the Do≈øe in proportion to the Age and Strength. See Our Pharm. Lond. Lib. 3. Cap. 7. Sect. 19.

¬ß 3. Zwelfer Manti≈ø. Spagyr. cap. 7. makes it thus. ‚Ñû Purified Mercury, or Mercury ≈øeven times ≈øublimed from the ≈øtellified Regulus Martis, and filings of Luna ‚Ñ•ij. fine Gold purged by Antimony í iv, or v. make an Amalgama, as the manner is by putting into a Crucible over proper fire the Mercury; into which when heated let the Gold be ca≈øt red
hot: this Amalgama oftentimes wa≈øh with Vinegar and Salt, till no more blackne≈øs appears in grinding and wa≈øhing it: to this Amalgama thus wa≈øhed, well clean≈øed and dryed, add of the former rubicund Precipitate made per ≈øe, ‚Ñ•ij. grind them together for a long time in a Gla≈øs Mortar, that they may be well united, then put all into an Infernus as afore directed, or into a Philo≈øophical Egg, which Seal hermetically, and dige≈øt or decoct by degrees of fire till the whole is reduced to dryne≈øs, and the highe≈øt Redne≈øs: Et hic demum Praecipitatus prae≈øtanti≈ø≈øimus erit, ≈øine ullo corro≈øivo factus; ≈øolius naturae opus, & Medicina ad multorum morborum extirpationem efficaci≈ø≈øima: ≈øapientibus pauca haec ≈øufficerint: ≈øub iis enim haud facile obvia aut Vulgaria latent Naturae Arcana.

¬ß 4. The thing thus made is indeed a good Medicine, as Zwelfer profe≈ø≈øes; but this tedious Work of his is Labour in vain; for fir≈øt, there is a Precipitation of the Quick≈øilver per ≈øe, which whatever Authors may affirm, is a Work of 3 or 400 Days to do it well: Secondly, there is a ≈øecond Precipitation or Calcination, by mixing this prec. per ≈øe, with an Amalgama of Mercury and Sol; which will then require as long time as if all the Mercury were amalgamated with the Sol all at once; ≈øo that it is apparent that the fir≈øt tedious Labour is lo≈øt; ≈øince Mercury amalgamated with Gold, will be calcin'd into a Redne≈øs in the tenth part of the time, that it can be done in, per ≈øe.

¬ß 5. Charras make it thus. ‚Ñû Purified Mercury ‚Ñ•j, fine Gold í j, make an Amalgama, &c. but you may, ≈øays he, add to the Mercury a quarter part of its weight of cupellated Silver, and make an Amalgama of it: Or el≈øe amalgate together Gold ‚Ñ•≈øs. Silver ‚Ñ•j. and Quick≈øilver ‚Ñ•iv. and ≈øo fix them together by a gentle Coction as afore≈øaid.

¬ß 6. Le Febure gets a Matra≈øs flat or plain at bottom (not making u≈øe of an Infernus as in the precip. per ≈øe) which he ≈øtops in the mouth only with a wooden Pin, which may be ea≈øily taken away to put down the Mercury, which ≈øhall be ≈øublimed into the neck of the Ve≈ø≈øel: into this Ve≈ø≈øel he puts an Amalgama of pure Mercury p. viij, with fine Gold thrice purged from Antimony, p. j. Or of Mercury p. iv, with fine Silver p. j. made into Leaves, or a ≈øubtile Calx,
for the ea≈øier Amalgamation; Or, an Amalgama of pure Mercury p. viij. with Gold, p. j. Silver p. ij. melted with pure Regulus of Antimony p. vj. the≈øe he dige≈øts or decocts till they become a fine red Precipitate.

¬ß 7. The ≈øolar Precipitate is given √† gr. j. ad vj. in ≈øome Con≈øerve, Confection, or Cordial Extract, the Patient keeping Bed when it is taken; it is an excellent Remedy again≈øt the French Pox and all its Symptoms, and has all the Vertues of the Precipitate per ≈øe exalted by means of the Gold, having this effect more, as to be a Specifick for ≈øtrengthning and corroborating the Heart, and to drive away all Weakne≈ø≈øes and Griefs from it.
¬ß 8. The Lunar Precipitate is al≈øo ≈øpecificated and de≈øtinated to the Head, and to the cure of Di≈øea≈øes thereof, be≈øides the general intention: Do≈øe thereof √† gr. j. ad xij.

¬ß 9. But neither the Solar, nor Lunar are to be compared in Strength and Virtue to that which is made of a mixture of Sol, Luna, and Antimony; for that this is a kind of Panacea, or univer≈øal Remedy, called by ≈øome Authors Aurum Medicum.

¬ß 10. It is of good u≈øe for prevention of Di≈øea≈øes, e≈øpecially where the Vi≈øcera are loaded with impure Sero≈øities and Tartarous Humors, proceeding from Weakne≈øs, ill Dige≈øtion, and Superfluities of Nouri≈øhment: you may give gr. vj. in the morning fa≈øting, and the Patient being covered in Bed may ≈øweat upon it; after which they may eat a Bisket dipt in Wine; then the Sweat being ended, the Sick may ri≈øe but ought to keep the Chamber for that whole day.

¬ß 11. Thus have you various Precipitates, or rather Calces of Mercury with the more perfect Metals, wholly performed without addition of any Salts or Acid Spirits: and as their Preparations are long and tedious; ≈øo are their Operations high, and much more effectual than tho≈øe other kinds of Precipitates are, which are not fitted for ≈øuch tran≈øcendent de≈øignations.

div.head: LXXXII. Mercurius Praecipitatus Viridis, green Precipitate.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Mercury ‚Ñ•iv. Venus ‚Ñ•≈øs. di≈ø≈øolve them ≈øeparately in A.F. and mix them: afterwards ab≈øtract the A. F. dige≈øt the Precipitate with Spirit of Vinegar, then filter and dry S. A. It is a Specifick in a virulent Gonorrhoea, which it perfectly takes away and cures: but it ought dayly to be u≈øed, till all the Flux is ≈øtopt. Do≈øe, gr. ij, iij, ad viij.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. See our Pharm. Lond. Lib. 3. Cap. 7. Sect. 40. where you have the Pre≈øcript in the ≈øame proportion; but you are advi≈øed to dige≈øt in the Spirit of Vinegar in B. M. for 24 hours, and then to boil, that the pure≈øt part of the Q. S. may be di≈ø≈øolved in the Vinegar.

¬ß 2. Hartman upon Crollius has it thus. ‚Ñû Purged Quick-≈øilver ‚Ñ•i≈øs. di≈ø≈øolve in A. F. ‚Ñ•iij. di≈ø≈øolve al≈øo, Copper ‚Ñ•≈øs. in A.F. mix the≈øe Solutions together; and draw off the A. F. in Sand: towards the end augment the fire more vehemently, that the greate≈øt part of the Spirits may be removed: what is left in the bottom, dry, grind and dige≈øt with Spirit of Vinegar for twenty four hours or ≈øix days, then boil it: the Vinegar thus impregnated, gently draw off in B. M. and the Precipitate will remain in the bottom green.

¬ß 3. div.head: LXXXIII. Mercurius Vitae Correctus, Mercurius Vite corrected.

div.head: LXXXIV. Mercurius Vitae purgans, Mercurius Vite, Or Laxative Mineral.

div.head: LXXXV, Panacea Aurea; The Golden Panacea, or All-heal.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Crocus Metallorum and Calomelanas, A. mix and make a Pouder. It is excellent again≈øt the French Di≈øea≈øe; moves Salivation, and purges „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , both by Vomit and Stool.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Crocus Metallorum is thus made. ‚Ñû Choice Antimony lb j. purified Nitre lb j. pouder each apart, and mix them together, then make an Earthen Pot red hot, among≈øt burning Coals, and put into it ‚Ñ•ij. or iij. of the mixture, covering the Pot immediately with a Tile, ≈øo will it make a thundering noi≈øe, ≈øending forth much Smoak, which carefully avoid: the Fulmination being over, put in more in like manner, and thus continue till your whole quantity is ≈øpent, then increa≈øe the Fire till the Matter melts, which done, take the Crucible from the Fire and leave it to cool, then break it, and you will

¬ß 2. ¬ß 4. Calomelanas is a ≈øweet Sublimate of Mercury, or Mercurius dulcis, five or ≈øix times ≈øublimed, till it lo≈øes (as it were) its Cathartick or Purging Vertue.

This Calomelanas by being ground fine and intimately mixed with the Crocus Metallorum, corrects it, and takes away much of its Emetick force, whereby it makes the Crocus a kind of Panacea, and di≈øper≈øes and carries it upon its Volatile Wings through the whole Univer≈øal Body, which otherwi≈øe might po≈ø≈øibly pa≈øs only through the Stomach and Guts.

div.head: LXXXVI. Panacea Cathartica, The Purging Panacea, or All-heal.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Mercurius Vitae (made of corro≈øive Sublimate p. ij. Antimony. p. j.) ‚Ñ•iv. The Mercurius Vitae in this ≈øublimes but in part, ≈øo that the Medicament con≈øi≈øts partly of the Mercurius Vitae, and partly of the Mercury it ≈øelf; and this Sublimate is cau≈øed from the remaining Acids in the Merc. div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Combu≈øtible Sulphur of Antimony ‚Ñ•j. rectified Oil of Vitriol or Sulphur ‚Ñ•iij. It is a perpetual Cau≈øtick, if it be kept from the Air. It takes away Warts by touching them therewith.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. See our Pharm. Lond. Lib. 3. Cap. 2. Sect. 20. But Thibaut makes it after this manner. Take A. F. ‚Ñ•j. refined Silver Filings ‚Ñ•ij. put them together into a little Matra≈øs, with a ≈øtreight long neck, ≈øo big as that ‚Öî of it may be empty: let it be Coated half way, and ≈øet it in a Round covered with Sand in a circular Fire, giving a ≈ømall heat till the Silver is di≈ø≈øolved; and the di≈ø≈øolvant is evaporated to dryne≈øs, and the
Matter remains black not unlike a P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nice ≈øtore: then increa≈øe the Fire to a melting ‚Ä¢ eat, and continue it till the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ling cea≈øes, and no more Vapors ari≈øe, which ≈øh ‚Ä¢ ws that the Matter is in fu≈øion; then without delay pour out the Matter into little Bra≈øs or Iron Moulds (for if it cools in the Mar ‚Ä¢ a≈øs it will be reduced into a white Pouder, which is the Calx of Luna, and may by the addition of Borax return to its fir≈øt Metalick nature) and keep the ≈øame for u≈øe.

¬ß 2. Lemery takes Spirit of Nitre ‚Ñ•iij. to Silver ‚Ñ•j. and di≈ø≈øolves in a Vial in a Sand heat, evaporating about ‚Öî of the moi≈øture, then puts the re≈øt as it is hot into a good large Crucible over a gentle Fire, and lets it alone till the boiling Matter ≈øinks quietly to the bottom of the Crucible, then increa≈øing the Fire, till it becomes like Oil, pours it out into ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ p ‚Ä¢ red Bra≈øs or Iron Moulds a little ‚Ä¢ iled and heated, in which it pre≈øently coagulates and bard ‚Ä¢ ns, after which he takes the Matter and keeps it in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 3. Or thus according to Charras. ‚Ñû Refined granulated Silver ‚Ñ•iv. put it into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, in a gentle Sand beat, and affu≈øe thereon A. F. ‚Ñ•xij. dige≈øt till the Silver is di≈ø≈øolved, and if you plea≈øe, cover the Cucurbit with its Head and ab≈øtract about half the A. F. or otherwi≈øe evaporate it, and let the Sediment cool and Gry≈øtallize; which then put by piece meals into a good Crucible upon a Culot in the mid≈øt of the fire-place in a ≈ømall Fordace, regulating the Fire that the Matter may not boil over; and continue it till the di≈ø≈øolved Silver becomes as it were dry in the Crucible, and the red Vapors of the A. F. cea≈øe to ari≈øe; at which time increa≈øe your fire to melt the Silver, which after ≈øome few boilings will de≈øcend to the bottom of the Crucible, of a Con≈øi≈øtency like that of thick Oil: then take out the Crucible, and gently pour out the melted Silver into proper Moulds (before hand heat and grea≈øed) in which the Silver will coagulate into brittle Stones of a blacki≈øh colour, which being half cold, take them out of the Moulds, and put them up into Gla≈ø≈øes, &c. to pre≈øerve them for the Air.

¬ß 4. This Cau≈øtick cauterizes the Fle≈øh or Bones upon which it is applied, provided you moi≈øten the end of the Stone, or the part, upon which you would have it operate.
It is a gentle and plea≈øant E≈øchatotick, and con≈øumes by touching all Warts, proud Fle≈øh, Cancers, Ulcers, and Red Spots, wetting them fir≈øt with Water, and then applying the Stone.
¬ß 5. It ea≈øes the Pain of the Teeth, u≈øing it as has been ≈øaid upon that part of the Skin and Cartilage, that makes the hollow of the Ear.
¬ß 6. The Crumbs of this Stone poudered, and incorporated with a Suppurative con≈øumes likewi≈øe proud and ill Fle≈øh, and takes away Rottenne≈øs in Ulcers.

¬ß 7. It ≈øerves likewi≈øe to dye the Hair black, if you put gr. ij. or iij. of it into a Spoonful of Water di≈øtilled from the green Shells of Wall-nuts, and then with a Bru≈øh-pencil to wa≈øh the Hair over with it two or three times, holding mean-≈øea≈øon a Comb between it and the Fle≈øh or Skin, for otherwi≈øe it will not fail to black the Skin, where-ever it touches, becau≈øe of the Vitriol which is in the A. F.
¬ß 8. If the Hair ≈øometimes grows green, it is becau≈øe there has been di≈ø≈øolved in the A. F. Silver allay'd with Copper in≈øtead of pure Cuppelated Silver.
¬ß 9. This Stone may be made of Copper in≈øtead of Silver, but then it will not keep ≈øo well, becau≈øe the Copper being very porous does more ea≈øily ≈øuffer the Air to enter it and di≈ø≈øolve it.

¬ß 10. If you u≈øe fine Cupellated Silver, you will from ‚Ñ•j. of it have í xiij. of the Lapis Infernialis; but if you u≈øe Silver with allay ‚Ñ•j. of it will not yield you above í xj. The rea≈øon of the increa≈øe of weight is from the ≈øharp Acids of the Spirit of Nitre adhearing to the Silver; but the difference of the increa≈øe comes from Cupellated Silver having finer Pores than the other, whereby it the better retains the Acid, and ≈øo makes the Stones thereby the ≈øtronger.

¬ß 11. This Strength or the Effects of the Stone proceeds from the lo≈øt Spirits which remain in the Pores of the Silver, and are petrified with it, which work more ≈øpeedily or more ≈ølowly, and with le≈øs violence, according as they were di≈ø≈øolved with a greater or le≈øs quantity of Moi≈øture.

¬ß 12. Lemery ≈øays this Stone is more Cau≈øtick than the Cry≈øtals of Silver, though compounded of the ≈øame Ingredients,
the rea≈øon of which he ≈øays is, that in the Evaporation of the Spirit of Nitre, the ≈øharpe≈øt part remains at la≈øt, which gives the ≈øtrength to the Infernal Stone; whereas in the Cry≈øtals (≈øays he) there's a much weaker Spirit, as being impregnated with watery parts.

¬ß 13. But Charras ≈øays that the Cry≈øtals of Silver of which the Stones are made are more Cau≈øtick than the ≈øtones them≈øelves: the rea≈øon he gives for it, is for that the ≈øimple di≈ø≈øolution of Silver in A. F. burns with more ≈øpeed and violence than the Stones or C ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øtals them≈øelves, as Experience teaches, for if the lea≈øt drop falls upon ones Hand, it will burn it immediately, and very deep, if you do not pre≈øently wa≈øh it to weaken and carry off the Cau≈øtick Spirits of the A. F. which ≈øays he is not to be wondred at, for that the A.F. has nothing in it hardly but what is Cau≈øtick, and the Sales are not able to act as they ≈øhould but when they are di≈ø≈øolved.

¬ß 14. Nor does this Lapis Infernal ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
burn at all, unle≈øs it be wet; and for that rea≈øon the di≈ø≈øolution of the Silver in A. F. or S. N. which are Cau≈øtick in all their parts, and able to act alone beyond the force of common Water, which is u≈øed to excite the Action of this Cau≈øtick, and make it operate.

¬ß 15. If you take Cry≈øtals of Luna, and melt them in a Crucible boiling the Liquor till it comes to the con≈øi≈øtence of Oil, and then ca≈øt it into the Moulds, you will have al≈øo a Lapis Infernalis, like to this de≈øcribed by our Author.

¬ß 16. This Silver Cau≈øtick is nothing but Cupellated Silver, di≈ø≈øolved and calcined Philo≈øophically by A. F. &c. and then coagulated by the Evaporation of the greate≈øt part of the Humidity, and at la≈øt petrefied by the fu≈øion of the ≈øaid coagulated Matter, which has retained ≈øo much of the A. F. as to make the Luna into the con≈øi≈øtence of a Stone.

¬ß 17. The Matra≈øs here u≈øed ought to be ≈ømall, becau≈øe we prepare not much of it at a time, and the fire gentle that the Matter may not run over: its neck long and ≈øtraight (if the whole Operation be done in a Matra≈øs) for the ea≈øier pouring it into Moulds; it ought al≈øo to be of ≈øtrong Gla≈øs, and coated on the bottom half way, that a naked fire, drying up
the Matter may not break the Gla≈øs.

¬ß 18. And tho' Silver may be di≈ø≈øolved in an equal quantity of A. F. yet double or treble quantities are u≈øed, as well for making a greater quantity of the Stone, as that it may be ≈øofter and le≈øs black: for the le≈ø≈øer and le≈øs black: for the le≈ø≈øer the quantity of the A. F. the harder the Stone and the more black, the Silver not being ≈øo perfectly calcin'd, nor containing ≈øo much of the A. F.

¬ß 19. In boiling of this Solution, it ought to be with a gentle Fire, becau≈øe it is apt to run over into the Fire; or el≈øe it ejects ≈øome drops or ≈øprinklings upon the hands of the Arti≈øt or his Cloaths, which upon the Skin ≈ømarts vehemently.

¬ß 20. You mu≈øt al≈øo often ca≈øt your Eye into the Crucicible, chiefly towards the conclu≈øion, for ≈øo ≈øoon as the Matter cea≈øes boiling and appears like Oil, you mu≈øt immediately ca≈øt it into the Mould; for if it be longer in the Fire, the ≈øtronge≈øt Spirits would evaporate, and the Stone be le≈øs Corro≈øive.

¬ß 21. That this Cau≈øtick may be made either of Sp. Nitri or A. F. but by the fir≈øt it will be whiti≈øh, and le≈øs Cau≈øtick; and in≈øtead of blackning the Skin and Teeth which it may touch, it will only make them look yellow; for that it is the Vitriol with blacks in the A. F. but not other Corro≈øive or Acid can corrode Silver, nor by con≈øequence ≈øerve in this compo≈øition.

¬ß 22. To make little Moulds of Lattin, you mu≈øt hold it a little time over the Fire, ≈øo will it be flexible, and not apt to break, then cut off a piece, and toul it about a Stick as thick as a Quill, and three Inches long, and ≈øo tie it clo≈øe with ≈ømall Wyar, turning up the bottom ≈øo as it may not go through, then pa≈øte it with our Lute, and let it dry; and when you u≈øe it, take out the Stick, and pour in the Matter, which will conden≈øe into petrefied Cyllinders.

¬ß 23. To make this Cau≈øtick good and ≈øtrong whether white, grey, or black, you ought to u≈øe only Cupellated Silver, for by a mixtion of Copper it will be both green and ≈øoft, and will ea≈øily melt of it ≈øelf.

¬ß 24. From hence we conclude, that it can never be made of Lead or Tin, which are yet ≈øofter: nor yet of Iron, becau≈øe it cannot be di≈ø≈øolved and brought into a potable
Liquor, by rea≈øon of its great dryne≈øs and earthyne≈øs: As for Gold, tho' it may be made of that by di≈ø≈øolution in A. R. or Spirit of Salt, acuated with decripitated Salt, you would only have your labour for your pains, becau≈øe refined Gold would be too dear. And as for the Marcha≈ø≈øites or Half-Metals, they are not fit for this Operation, becau≈øe their di≈ø≈øolution evaporated and reduced to a Calx, cannot keep the Con≈øi≈øtency of a Stone, but mu≈øt remain a Pouder.

div.head: XCI. Regulus Martis, Metal or ≈øettling of Iron, i. e. Martial Mettal of Antimony.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of Mars ‚Ñ•ij. mixed with Nitre, Tartar, and Antimony A. ‚Ñ•iv≈øs. and detonated S. A. It cures the French Pox, without any Flux at the Mouth, or Spitting.

Salmon. ¬ß 1. You may ≈øee another way of making this Regulus Martis in our Pharm. Lond. Lib. 3. Cap. 8. Sect. 66. with large Notes and Ob≈øervations thereon: this Regulus is nothing but Antimony perfectly opened by Nitre, and dive≈øted of its poy≈øonous qualities, by a long fu≈øion, tho' not long enough to evaporate all its purgative Sulphur; and its emetick Vertue is fixt by the addition of Mars.

¬ß 2. It purges by Stool very well without provoking to vomit, if it be infu≈øed in White-wine, or made into Cups, or Pills, which they call everla≈øting Pills: you may infu≈øe ‚Ñ•j. of the Pouder in a Quart of Wine, Sack, Ale, &c. of which you may give ab ‚Ñ•j. ad iv. in the morning fa≈øting.

¬ß 3. If you make it into Pills (which is not ≈øo good) one large Pill may ≈øerve you for ever, taking it out of the Clo≈øe-≈øtool, and then making it clean for another time; the Pill may be made in weight from í j. ad í ij. and in ≈øome Bodies will work very well.

¬ß 4. And if you pouder 18 or 20. ounces of it, and tye it up loo≈øly in a cour≈øe Linnen-Rag, and then let it infu≈øe in lb iij. of ≈øome Sudorifick decoction of the Woods, Roots, Barks, &c. it is ≈øaid to cure the Pox without fluxing with Mercurial Remedies: but indeed this Medicament contains a Philo≈øophick Mercury of greater Excellency than the Vulgar.

¬ß 5. If you di≈ø≈øolve Regulus of Mars in Spirit of Sal-Gem, and macerate the Solution, and di≈øtil it, and then in≈øpi≈ø≈øate, you will have a good purge, and a Vomit which works gently: the Do≈øe may be two or three Grains.

¬ß 6. Le Febure from Beguinus makes this Martial Regulus thus. ‚Ñû Ends of Hor≈øe-Nails, or filings of Iron or Steel lb ≈øs, very pure and clean, put them into a large deep ≈øtrong Crucible, place it in a Wind Fornace, upon a Culot, which is a round bottom or Tile ≈øo called, cover it with a piece of Brick bury it in Charcole mixt with kindled Coals, that they may kindle by degrees: the Iron being clearly red-hot, drawing near to a white Glowing, add to it of choice Antimony in Pouder lb j. and cover it again with the Brick and Chals to make the Fu≈øion and ∆≤nion of the two Matters; which done, throw into the Crucible of good Nitre in gro≈øs Pouder, a little warmed ‚Ñ•iv. that taking flame with the Sulphur of the Antimony, it may make the Fu≈øion the quicker and clearer: this done, immediately as ≈øoon as the Ebulition is over take forth the Crucible and pour the melted Matter into a Cone or Regulus Ve≈ø≈øel bemeared with Wax; upon the brims of which ≈øtrike with a Hammer or Pe≈øtel, to cau≈øe the Regulus the better to ≈øeparate it ≈øelf: but for want of ≈øuch a Ve≈ø≈øel, take your Crucible out of the Fire, and ≈øtriking ≈øoftly upon the brims of it, let it cool, and the Regulus will ≈øettle in the ≈øame.

¬ß 7. Take the Regulus out of the Ve≈ø≈øel, or Crucible, and therein you ≈øhall find a ≈øeeming uniform Lump; but knock upon it about the middle, and the Regulus which is in the bottom, will for≈øake the Dro≈øs which is (in this Operation) uppermo≈øt, and is nothing el≈øe but the Martial Sulphur, and Terre≈øtial Impurieties of the Antimony, with ≈øome little remainings of the Nitre, which al≈øo frame by them≈øelves a kind of clo≈øe compacted Lump, which every day di≈ø≈øolves it ≈øelf in the Air into a dry Pouder, re≈øembling dirty filings of Iron.

¬ß 8. The Regulus not being pure enough in the fir≈øt melting, beat it therefore into pouder, and add to it ‚Ñ•iij. of Antimony in pouder to ha≈øten its fu≈øion, and put it in a new Crucible, and cau≈øe it again to flow in a Wind Fornace, and being in fu≈øion, ca≈øt into it of very dry Nitre ‚Ñ•ij. or iij. being
warmed and in gro≈øs Pouder, upon which there will be yet again a ≈ømall Detonation or Ebulition, which being over, ca≈øt is again into the Iron Cone, knocking upon it as before: and from this Regulus ≈øeparate the blacki≈øh Impurities as before, and you will find your Regulus twice as pure and white as the former: proceed thus the third time, and you will find the Scoria more grey or whiti≈øh, which is a ≈øign that it begins to draw nearer to a ≈øtate of Purity.

¬ß 9. Proceed now to a fourth fu≈øion but always with new Nitre dry and warm, giving a very ≈øtrong fire this la≈øt time, that the Nitre may be in a very good fu≈øion; then ca≈øt it quickly, and with ≈øwiftne≈øs ≈øtir the Ca≈øting Ve≈ø≈øel, being fir≈øt well warmed, and turn it round, and you ≈øhall have a bright S ‚Ä¢ ellate or ≈øtarry Regulus of Antimony, to the very Center, white as Silver, and repleat with a Solar Sulphur‚ñ™ for the Nitre which was on the top of it, is all yellow, an infallible ≈øign, (with the Star on the top of it) that it has attained to its purity and perfection.

¬ß 10. Charras makes it exactly according to Le Febure's Method now declared, and adde, that the Antimony u≈øed in this Preparation, affords in proportion to its quantity, much more Regulus, than in that which is ≈øimply Antimonial; becau≈øe the Mars not only hinders the di≈ø≈øipation, which would otherwi≈øe happen of ≈øeveral Particles of the Antimony, but al≈øo augments its quantity by joyning with it in its own pure parts in the Fu≈øion; nor can the Nitre make ≈øo great di≈ø≈øipation as in the ≈øimple Regulus, becau≈øe it is here u≈øed later, and al≈øo mixed by degrees in a ≈ømall quantity.
¬ß 11. But this is al≈øo true, that ≈øhould you long continue to mix it, it might at length con≈øume all the Mars, and change all the Qualities of the Antimony, rendering it Diaphoretick.

¬ß 12. Rolfincius Chym. Lib. 5. Sect. 11. Cap. 1. ≈øaith that the oftner the Calcination is reiterated with Nitre, the more the Regulus decrea≈øes, and at length is all turned into Scoria, and that the iteration of the Calcination to the end the Star may appear, is done all in vain: this he ≈øays he knows by experience; but we will bring Experience again≈øt Experience, and ≈øay that for the three or four Iterations, the Regulus becomes apparently more bright and
pure; but after the fourth time, it may dimini≈øh not only in the quantity, but in the Vertues al≈øo, and ≈øo we agree with him.

¬ß 13. Marggrave makes the Regulus after Beguinus his Method, but only with one ≈øingle Calcination, and with a quarter part of the Nitre which he puts in, in the fir≈øt Calcination: but this Regulus he beats into pouder, and melts it again in a clean Crucible, which he performs with a very ≈ømall Fire, ≈øo ≈øays he, it comes forth more pure and bright, adding towards the end a ≈ømall proportion of Nitre.

¬ß 14. Le Mort makes it with pieces of Steel p. iv. which being made red hot, he adds to it. Antimony in ≈ømall bits p. ix. melt them together, and fu≈øes them with a Pouder prepared of Nitre and Tartar, ‚Ñ•j. letting them flow in the Fire for an hour, then pours them forth, ≈øhaking or ≈øtriking the Cone, and ≈øeparates the Regulus from the Scoria: this Regulus he again melts, and ca≈øt in by degrees, about a ≈øixth part of pure Nitre, for a farther ≈øeparation of the Scoria; then ca≈øting it into the Cone, he lets it ≈øtand till it is perfectly cold, ≈øo obtains a ≈øtellified Regulus: this Regulus ≈øays he, may be done without addition of Salts, but then it will not be ≈øo pure.

¬ß 15. Lemery makes it exactly after Le Febure's Method with four Calcinations adding fre≈øh Antimony ¬º part the ≈øecond time, but no Antimony the two la≈øt times, but each time the ≈øame proportion of Nitre; ob≈øerving the la≈øt time to melt it well, before you ca≈øt the Nitre into it, that the Star may appear.

¬ß 16. From Antimony ‚Ñ•xvj. and Iron ‚Ñ•viij. after the fir≈øt purification you will have ‚Ñ•x. of Regulus, and ‚Ñ•xiij. of Scoria: after the ≈øecond purification ‚Ñ•ix≈øs. of Regulus: after the third purification ‚Ñ•viij. íij. do remain; and after the fourth time you will have only ‚Ñ•vij. ívj. of this Martial Regulus.

¬ß 17. Now the Iron in its fir≈øt fu≈øion with the Antimony, turns almo≈øt all of it into Scoria, or Dro≈øs, becau≈øe it joyns with the more impure Sulphur, ≈øo that the Reguline or Metalline part being more weighty falls down to the bottom.

¬ß 18. The Nitre is u≈øed only in order to open the Body of the Antimony, and cau≈øe a more perfect fu≈øion, the better to make a ≈øeparation
of the gro≈ø≈øer parts, and to carry off ≈øome of its offen≈øive Sulphur by its Volatile parts; ≈øo that the Scoria con≈øi≈øts of Iron, Sulphur and fixt Nitre.
¬ß 19. This Fu≈øion is thrice repeated becau≈øe ≈øome Particles of the Mars (which ea≈øily joyns with Antimony by rea≈øon of a gro≈øs Sulphur it contains) may leave the Regulus and joyn with it.

¬ß 20. The Star appearing in the Martial Regulus (tho' not in the ≈øimple Regulus) is from the Antimony it ≈øelf, which is apt to ≈øhoot into Needles, as they who ≈øhall be plea≈øed to make its Vitriol may ea≈øily prove; but before it is purified from many of its ≈øulphurous and impure parts, the≈øe Star-like Needles cannot app ‚Ä¢ ar, unle≈øs confu≈øedly: but being purified with Mars (which attracts to its ≈øelf mo≈øt of its ≈øoft and impure Sulphurous parts, which hinder the Stars appearance, and the Cry≈øtallization of the Antimony) the Particles of the Cry≈øtaline ≈øub≈øtance of the Antimony remain and ≈øtick clo≈øe together, which being joyned with the mo≈øt pure parts of the Mars from that Star, by a natural ≈øhooting or di≈øpo≈øition of the ≈øame: and this Star appears in the purified Regulus Martialis becau≈øe it was naturally in the Antimony before, and not from any thing which was in the Mars, the Iron only helping to purifie it, expatiate its Cry≈øtaline Particles, and harden it; for which rea≈øon the Martial Regulus is found to be harder than the common or ≈øimple Regulus, tho' never ≈øo often purified.
¬ß 21. The Do≈øe of this Martial Regulus, if it be given in its own ≈øub≈øtance in pouder is from gr. x. ad ‚Ñàj. in ≈øome Con≈øerve, or other proper Vehicle.

¬ß 22. To make the Golden Diaphoretick Sulphur of Antimony. ‚Ñû Scoria of Regulus Martis, q. v. boil a quarter of an hour in fair Water, in a Bra≈øs or Iron Ve≈ø≈øel, ≈øo have you a dark yellow Lixivium: filter the Liquor into a Gla≈øs or Stone Ve≈ø≈øel (not a glazed Earthen one, le≈øt the Salts ≈øhould corrode the Lead) and affu≈øe thereon two or three Spoonfuls of Spirit of Vinegar, Nitre, Vitriol or Sulphur (the ≈øtronger it is, the higher the Colour of the Precipitate) ≈øo will the Liquor coagulate the Curd being ≈øettled, decant the clear Liquor (which keep to wa≈øh Bed≈øteds with to pre≈øerve them from Buggs) and on the
Curd affu≈øe common Water, ≈øo will a Saffron coloured Precipitate or Pouder fall down: decant this fir≈øt water, and affu≈øe more in great quantity, to ≈øweeten it, and take away its ill Smell, and Emetick quality; la≈øtly, dry it between two Papers lei≈øurely in the Shade for u≈øe.

¬ß 23. The Acid poured on the Lixivium cau≈øes 1. A coagulum, 2. Gives the dull yellow colour. 3. Cau≈øes it to ≈øtink abominably: for the Antimonial Sulphur is di≈ø≈øolved by an Alcali in the Liquor, and therefore it will not let it go till the Alcali is weakned by an Acid. And as to the colour, Sulphur is naturally yellow but the Acid enlivens and heightens the Colour, ≈øo that being wa≈øht from the Alcalious Salts, the Pouder becomes of a fine light yellow. And Sulphur being heat, always ≈øtinks, therefore being heated by the Action of the Acid and re-action of its Di≈ø≈øolvant, it cau≈øes that extreamly abominable ≈ømell.

¬ß 24. That a great quantity of Water being poured upon the Coagulum, it pre≈øently precipitates into a yellow Pouder, of a much livelier colour; for the Water di≈ø≈øolves all the Salts of what kind ≈øoever, and thereby frees the Antimonial Sulphur from all its tyes and bonds; ≈øo that the Sulphur having thrown off its Salts, it then appears of its own natural colour.

¬ß 25. This Golden Diaphoretick Sulphur, is nothing but a fixed Sulphur of Antimony, drawn from the Scoria of Antimony, opened and melted by Nitre: for the Volatile Sulphur of Antimony, is ≈øo much the more poy≈øonous; as it is Volatile; and that which is lea≈øt Volatile is violently Emetick and Cathartick; but this being once fixed it is only Diaphoretick and opening.

¬ß 26. For a Demon≈øtration that this Diaphoretick Sulphur is but a fixt Sulphur of Antimony, do but let the Scoria lie two or three days upon the ground, and there will ri≈øe of it ≈øelf, without any Artifice, a kind of yellow Mo≈øs, which is nothing but the true Sulphur of Antimony purified.

div.head: XCIX. Sulphur Auratum, The Golden Sulphur of Antimony.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of the Scoria of the Regulus of Antimony, being ≈øeparated from it, boiled in water and filtred, precipitating the Sulphur with Vinegar, and wa≈øhing it. Do≈øe, gr. í. ad xv. In ≈øome it vomits before it ≈øweats; with others it ≈øweats, and then provokes ≈øtools: it wonderfully conduces to the cure of Tertian and Quartan Agues, being given an hour before the Fit: it often prevents the Infection and Contagion of the Plague, Small-Pox, &c. being given, and two or three times repeated, or otherwi≈øe it happily makes them to come forth: it is profitable al≈øo again≈øt the French Pox.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It is called Sulphur, but Sennertus lib. de con≈øen≈øu & di≈ø≈øen≈øu. Cap. 19. will ≈øcarcely allow it: Sulphur illud auratum non e≈ø≈øe Sulphur, ≈øed calcem ≈øubtilem Antimonij, quae etiam in Antimonij facil√® reducitur, docet. But it is without doubt a Sulphurous part of the Antimony di≈ø≈øolved by Alcalious Salts, and precipitated by an Acid: Thus.

¬ß 2. ‚Ñû The Scoria or Dro≈øs of the Regulus of Antimony in fine Pouder, boil it in common Water in an Iron. Kettle or Earthen Pot half an hour, to make thereof a Lixivium, this decant and filter thro' brown Paper into a Stone or Gla≈øs Ve≈ø≈øel (not an Earthen one glazed, le≈øt the Salts ≈øhould corrode the Lead) then affu≈øe thereon Vinegar, or its Spirit, or Spirit of Sulphur or Vitriol, or Nitre, or ≈øome other Acid, ≈øo will the Liquor pre≈øently coagulate, which let ≈øtand for a while, and the Coagulum or Curde will ≈øettle of a reddi≈øh yellowi≈øh colour; then decant the clear Liquor; or otherwi≈øe, filter the whole, and ≈øeparate the Precipitate, which dry and keep for u≈øe: but if you filter it not, you may put the Coagulum into common Water, and the Sulphur Auratum will precipitate in a Saffron-coloured Pouder; being ≈øettled decant this fir≈øt Water, and put on more in great quantity, that you may at once ≈øweeten the Pouder, take away its ill ≈ømell, and dimini≈øh its Emetick force: then decant the clear Water, and filter the re≈øt thro' a brown Paper, in which let it dry lei≈øurely in the Shade, and keep it in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 3. Lemery ≈øays that from fifteen Ounces of Scoria, you will have ‚Ñ•12. í ij. of the Sulphur Auratum; which is Emetick, and may be given √† gr. ij. ad vj. in Broth or other like Vehicle; or otherwi≈øe in form of Pills.

¬ß 4. To ‚Ñ•xvj. of Scoria you may put Water lb xvj. this Liquor will coagulate like a Gelly when it is cold, by rea≈øon of the Salts and Sulphurs joyning together; the Scoria, being nothing but a mixture of the fixt parts of the Nitre and Tartar, joyned with the more impure part of the Sulphur of Antimony.

¬ß 5. The Coagulum is cau≈øed by rea≈øon of weakening the force of the Alcalious Salts (which held the Sulphur of the Antimony) through the help of an Acid, by which means the Alcalies letting go their hold, the Sulphur precipitates; and of a yellowi≈øh colour, becau≈øe it is the natural colour of Sulphur, which here is heightned and enlivened by the help of the Acid.

¬ß 6. So ≈øoon as the Vinegar or any other Acid is poured on, it cau≈øes a mo≈øt abominable ≈øtinking Scent, from the a≈øcending of ≈øome part of the Volatile Sulphur‚ñ™ of which ≈øo much as the Acid ≈øeizes on, it fixes; and this is natural to all Sulphurs being heat with Acids; and the hot Waters or Springs of the Mineral Baths are not free there from, for that mo≈øtly, they ≈øtink very much with Sulphur: the Precipitate which the Acid makes is in large quantity, and much like a Coagulum or Curd.

¬ß 7. Now this Sulphur Auratum is emetick, and not altogether pure, but is mixed with much Salt and Terre≈øtreities, which it yet retains in its precipitation; and ≈øome ≈øuppo≈øe, that it is this Salt, which gives it this colour by rarifying its parts.

¬ß 8. As to its Vertues and Operations it is much like to that of Crocus Metallorum, and therefore ought to be given in the ≈øame Do≈øe; tho' ≈øome Chymi≈øts think it may be given in a larger, as to gr. x. or xij. or more: and it is called Golden Sulphur, by rea≈øon of its colour, it much re≈øembling that of Gold.

¬ß 9. But doubtle≈øs the Golden Sulphur of Antimony of the Ancients was another thing, viz. a fixt Sulphur, like that of Gold, which was ≈øubtil tinging Sudorifick and internal: whereas this Sulphur
is gro≈øs, without Metallick Tincture, Emetick and External.

div.head: C. Sulphur Vitrioli, The Sulphur of Vitriol.
div.p: Bate.] It is made by di≈ø≈øolving Vitriol in warm Water, and affu≈øing therein Guttatim Oleum Tartari per deliquium, that the Sulphur of the Vitriol may be precipitated, which edu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ate and dry.
