div.head: CII. Sulphur Vitrioli Narcoticum, The Narcotick or Anodyn Sulphur of Vitriol.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Vitriol p. ij. Mars p. j. dige≈øt in Spirit of Vinegar, and di≈øtil in Sand to dryne≈øs: from the red Ma≈øs extract a Tincture, with Spirit of Vinegar, filter and precipitate with Oil of Tartar: the Sulphur fallen down to the bottom edulcorate, and dry. From this Anodyns are made, bearing the Name of Laudanum. It ≈øtops Catarrhs, takes away Pains, &c. Do≈øe, gr. ij. ad vj, &c. at time of ≈øleeping.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû Purified Vitriol lb ij. filings of Iron lb j. mix them together, and put them into a Gla≈øs body, affu≈øe on them Spirit of Vinegar, ≈øo much as to over-top them two or three Inches: fix a head on the body and place it in a Sand heat, fitting a Receiver thereto; give but a gentle fire at fir≈øt, to make all the Moi≈øture ri≈øe, which increa≈øe gradatim, till the Sand is red-hot: when all is cold, take out the Matter at bottom, pouder it, and dige≈øt it in a Matra≈øs with fre≈øh Spirit of Vinegar, ≈øo much as to overtop
it three or four Inches, in B. M. for three or four days: then will you find the Men≈øtruum coloured, which decant, putting on again fre≈øh Spirit of Vinegar, dige≈øting a new, and decanting as before, reiterating the≈øe ≈øame Operations, till your Spirit will be tinged no more: mix all the≈øe decanted Tinctures together, filter them; and then affu≈øe thereon Oil of Tartar per deliquium, ≈øo much as may precipitate all the Sulphur of the Vitriol to the bottom, which afterwards edulcorate with warm Water by ≈øeveral Ablutions, dry it, and keep it for u≈øe. Thus Beguinus.

¬ß 2. This lays he is a famous Anodynon, and to be preferred before many others, and Paracel≈øus commends it in the highe≈øt degree, as a Medicament of great worth: without doubt, it is an excellent thing, and a good Remedy for Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Lungs, Coughs, Colds, A≈øthma's Ob≈øtructions of the Lungs, Spitting of Blood, &c. Do≈øe, √† gr. v. ad xij. in any pectoral Syrup. Con≈øerve, Lohoch, or Confection.

¬ß 3. That it will ea≈øe pains in ≈øome mea≈øure is true; but that it is a Narcotick or Anodyn like to Opium, or as ≈øome will have it, to exceed Opium, or an Opiate Laudanum is ≈øo fal≈øe, that ≈øcarcely any thing can be fal≈øer; and this A≈ø≈øertion my own large Experience has told me to be true; yet it is an excellent Medicine, and not to be de≈øpi≈øed for tho≈øe Di≈øea≈øes it is de≈øigned again≈øt, and peradventure may exceed many others for Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Lungs, &c.

¬ß 4. Hartman upon Crollius (who ≈øeems to be one of the fir≈øt Publi≈øhers of this Medicine, and from whom mo≈øt of the others had it) makes it exactly after the aforegoing manner, but with Hungarick Vitriol which is blew, or a Vitriol of Copper: this Sulphur he ≈øays is Combu≈øtible Sulphur, which ≈øays he you may ≈øee by putting it to the Fire; for it will pre≈øently take flame, and be thereby wholly con≈øumed like other Sulphur; but this is under≈øtood of the Pouder, the Spirit of Vinegar being ab≈øtracted to dryne≈øs, and then edulcorated, before the Oil of Tartar is put into it.

¬ß 5. For the Vinegar impregnated with this „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ Sulphur of Vitriol, being mixed with a ≈øufficient quantity of the Oil of Tartar
guttatim, lets go its hold of the Sulphur, whereby it precipitates, and is rendred fixed and Anodyn.

¬ß 6. But Zwelfer has another peculiar way of making it, by di≈ø≈øolving the be≈øt Hungarian Vitriol, or Vitriol of Mars in Water and filtering &c. the whole Proce≈øs at large you may ≈øee in our Pharm. Lond. Lib. 3. Cap. 9. Sect. 1. with ≈øome Notes upon it, ≈øo that we ≈øhall ≈øay no more of it here.

¬ß 7. Rolfincius Chym. Lib. 5. Sect. 9. Cap. 8. exactly follows Hartman, making fir≈øt the inflamable Sulphur with Spirit of Vinegar; and from that the Anodyn Sulphur by affu≈øion of Oil of Tartar, as is above taught; which ≈øame Method Schroder, Sala, Charras, and others pur≈øue.

¬ß 8. Le Febure makes it thus. ‚Ñû Liege Vitriol lb vj, purified in a ≈øufficient quantity of Rain-water: this done, add to the Di≈ø≈øolution, filings of Iron or Steel lb i≈øs. put them into a glazed Earthen Pan, ≈øtir them together, and put the Pan in the Sun, leaving it till it grows thicker by degrees, which ≈øtir often, and evaporate to dryne≈øs: then beat it to pouder, and add to it lb i≈øs. more of filings, ≈øprinkling it with di≈øtilled Rain-water, till all be reduced to a ≈ømooth uniform Pap, which ≈øtir often, and dry again by evaporation in the Sun; and thus proceed to the ≈øeventh time, until the Matter becomes a very high red Tincture: then being evaporated to dryne≈øs, put it into a large Matra≈øs, and affu≈øe thereon Spirit of Vinegar ≈øo much as to overtop it four Inches: dige≈øt in a Sand heat, ≈øtirring or ≈øhaking it often, and continuing the dige≈øtion, till the Spirit is tinged of a fre≈øh red colour: decant this Tincture, and affu≈øe fre≈øh Spirit of Vinegar, dige≈øting, ≈øtirring, decanting, and affu≈øing fre≈øh Spirit, till it will extract no more Tincture; mix all the≈øe Tinctures and filterate them, and divide the Liquor into two equal parts. The one half put into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, and in an A≈øh or Sand heat, ab≈øtract all the Men≈øtruum by di≈øtillation in a gradual heat to dryne≈øs: what is left at bottom edulcorate with di≈øtilled Rain-water, till the Water comes off ta≈øtele≈øs: then dry it between two Papers in a gentle heat, ≈øo have you the combu≈øtible or inflamable Sulphur of Vitriol, mixt with that of Mars, which will ea≈øily take flame, and be con≈øumed like common Brim≈øtone,
yielding a Purple flame.

¬ß 9. This Sulphur of Vitriol may be u≈øed in≈øtead of Flos Sulpuris, being much more efficacious and vertuous in all Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Lungs, as Coughs, Colds, A≈øthma's, Catarrhs, Shortne≈øs of Breath, Whea≈øings, Spitting of Blood, Ulcers and Ob≈øtructions of the Lungs, &c. being given √† gr. iv. ad x. or xij. in Lozenges with flowers of Benjamin; or in ≈øome proper Syrup, Con≈øerve, Lohoch, Bolus, or Electuary, &c.

¬ß 10. Of the other half he makes the Fixed and Narcotick Sulphur of Vitriol thus. Being filterated as afore≈øaid, he puts it into a Cucurbit in B. M. and draws off one half or two thirds of the Men≈øtruum, then precipitates the remainder with Oleum Tartari per deliquium affu≈øing it guttatim, or drop by drop, till the precipitation cea≈øes, or no more will fall: lets the Matter ≈øettle in the bottom of the Cucurbit for ≈øome time, then decanting the clear Liquor from it, he edulcorates the precipitated Matter by many ablutions; then drys it according to Art: this redi≈øh Pouder he puts into a Matra≈øs or Philo≈øophical Egg, and in an equal heat dige≈øts or ripens it for the ≈øpace of forty days, till it becomes of a fair, high red colour, which is the fixt Anodyn Sulphur of Vitriol.

¬ß 11. This Sulphur is ≈øaid to be a true Pre≈øerver and Re≈øtorer of Health, and confirmer of the Vital Functions, being given once in five or ≈øix days as a pre≈øervative, and every other day as a Curative; for it ≈øends its Solar beams through the whole Body, expelling from it all Impurities whatever, either by Urine or Sweat, or an in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration, and ea≈øing all manner of pains what≈øoever: Do≈øe, √† gr. ij. ad viij. or x. in Confectio de Hyacintho, or ≈øome other proper Vehicle fa≈øting, drinking after it a ≈ømall Gla≈øs of generous Wine, or ≈øome Cordial Water.

¬ß 12. Out of this fixed Sulphur of Vitriol you may make a Tincture. ‚Ñû Of this fixed Sulphur of Vitriol ‚Ñ•iv. ripned as before directed, put it into a Pellican, upon which affu≈øe Tartariz'd Spirit of Vitriol, best rectified S. V. Ana. ‚Ñ•vj. united together fir≈øt by di≈øtillation in B. M. lute exactly the Junctures; dige≈øt and circulate in a vaporous B. till you ≈øee the Liquor become Bloodred: then remove the Fire, and

¬ß 13. It is a famous ea≈øer of Pains, ≈øtrengthner and re≈øtorer of the Tone of the parts weakned, driving away naturally and in≈øen≈øibly, all hurtful and corrupted Humors, which may provoke or irritate the Archaeus: it opens Ob≈øtructions of the Lungs, Womb, Spleen, and other Vi≈øcera, provokes Appetite, ≈øtrengthens the Stomach, and excites Venery, ≈øtrengthening the Matrix, and all the In≈øtruments and Ve≈ø≈øels of Generation, rectifying, ≈øtrengthning and increa≈øing the Seed, and making it prolifick and fruitful in both Sexes: it provokes Urine given in Ar≈ømart or Onion-water, expelling the Drop≈øie by Urine, and with all it is prevalent again≈øt Vapors from the Spleen, Fits of the Mother, and mo≈øt other Di≈øtempers of the Womb. ¬ß 14. Schroder and ≈øome others have al≈øo a Purging Sulphur of Vitriol, which is made after this manner. ‚Ñû Vitriol of Liege well depurated lb ij. mix it well with pure clear filings of Iron or Steel ‚Ñ•vj. put all into a great Matra≈øs, and affu≈øe upon it Acid-water of Vitriol, ≈øo much as to overtop it four Inches: dige≈øt in B. M. for four days, ≈øtirring or ≈øhaking the Ve≈ø≈øel five or ≈øix times a day: this done, filter the Liquor, and ab≈øtract one half of it by di≈øtillation in A≈øhes; then affu≈øe on the remainder, Oleum Tartari per deliquium, guttatim, ‚Ñ•ij. to every pound of the Matter, ≈øo will the Sulphur precipitate; which (decanting from it the clear Liquor) take, dry, and keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 15. ¬ß 16. This Sulphur ≈øays Le Febure, if it be put into a Matra≈øs, ≈øealed up hermetically, and dige≈øted in a ≈ølow heat for the ≈øpace of forty days, in Vertue

div.head: CIII. Sulphur Auri, ≈øeu Aurum potabile; The Sulphur of Gold, or Potable Gold.
div.p: Bate.] Purge Sol twice with Antimony, then calcine fir≈øt with Mercury and Sulphur: Secondly, with Sea-≈øalt melted: Thirdly, with Salt of Tartar, then extract with the Sulphur of Saturn, S. div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Spirit of Benjamin ‚Ñ•j. Hy≈ø≈øop or Scabious-water ‚Ñ•xij. mix them S. A. It is Antia≈øthmatick and Pectoral.

Storax ‚Ñ•j. being in Pouder put them into a Matra≈øs, upon which affu≈øe S. V. lb j. ≈øtop the Ve≈ø≈øel clo≈øe, and dige≈øt in Hor≈øe-dung for 14 days, then decant the Tincture, filter it, and keep it for u≈øe: You may add to it gut. x. or xij. of Bal≈øam of Peru, to give it a better Sent.

¬ß 7. M. to the di≈ø≈øolution of the Ro≈øin; which contains a very pure and ≈øulphurous Volatile Salt.

¬ß 8. To make a right u≈øe of this Tincture, apply it at Bed-time upon all places where you find need, as upon all Pimples, Pu≈øtules, breaking out, Inflamations, &c. and the next day wa≈øh it off with Barley-water, made into Milk with ≈øome drops of this Tincture.

¬ß 9. But to prevent ≈øuch defects of the Skin (where they are ab≈øent) you need only convert this Spirit or Tincture into a Milk by adding twenty or thirty times the quantity of Damask Ro≈øe-water to it, and then to wa≈øh therewith Morning and Evening, as with other wa≈øhes.

¬ß 10. Le Mort makes it thus. ‚Ñû E≈ø≈øence of Benjamin í j. Water of white Lillies, or any Odorif ‚Ä¢ rous Water, as of Damask Ro≈øes, or Orange Flowers ‚Ñ•ij mix them,

div.head: CVIII. Lac Mercurij, Milk of Mercury.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of Corro≈øive Mercury ≈øublimate í vj. brui≈øed ≈ømall and ≈øtirred in a Tin Ba≈øon, or Di≈øh with Fumitory-water ‚Ñ•xij. till it becomes like Milk. S. A. See the Vertues in the Aqua Mercurialis.

Bate.] ‚Ñû Scammony in fine Pouder í vj. put it into a cold Mortar; and affu≈øe thereon by little and little Aqua Cinnamomi hordeata ‚Ñ•viij. ≈øtirring them together well as you put in the Liquor: the Liquor will grow milky, which ≈øeparate (from the Pitch like ≈øub≈øtance of the Scammony) and keep it for u≈øe. ¬ß 4. It may be given from one Spoonful to two, according to Age and Strength, and difficulty of the Body to be wrought upon: It expels Watery and Tartarous Humors, from the Blood, and whole habit of the Body, and therefore is of ≈øingular u≈øe again≈øt the Scurvy, Drop≈øie, Jaundice, Gout, Kings-Evil, and all Ob≈øtructions what≈øoever in any part of the Body.

div.head: CX. Lapis Medicamento≈øus, The Medicinal Stone.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû White Vitriol ‚Ñ•iv. Sal-Armoniack ‚Ñ•≈øs, Alum, Ceru≈øe, Bole Armoniack, A. ‚Ñ•j. mix and make a Pouder, which boil with Vinegar, q. ≈ø. to the Con≈øi≈øtency of a hard Stone, S. A. Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Lemery makes it thus. ‚Ñû Colcothar, or Caput Mort. of Vitriol ‚Ñ•ij. Litharge, Alum, fine Bole, A. ‚Ñ•iv. all being in fine Pouder, mix them, and put them into a glazed Pot, upon which affu≈øe
good Vinegar, ≈øo much as to over-top the Ingredients two Inches: cover the Ve≈ø≈øel and leave it in dige≈øtion two days, then add it to Nitre ‚Ñ•viij. div.head: CXI. Lapis Salutis, The Stone of Health, or Healing-≈øtone.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Sal-Arm. ‚Ñ•j. Alum. fine Bole, A. ‚Ñ•ij. green Vitriol ‚Ñ•vj. Nitre ‚Ñ•iij. Ceru≈øe ‚Ñ•ij. mix and make a Pouder; Vinegar q. ≈ø. mix all together, and boil them with a gentle Fire, till they become a hard Stone; it has the ≈øame Vertues with the former.

Ma≈øtick, Frankincen≈øe, A. ‚Ñ•j. all being in fine Pouder, mix them, and put them into a large glazed Earthen Ve≈ø≈øel, adding ≈øtrong Vinegar q. ≈ø. boil all over a gentle Fire to the Con≈øi≈øtency of a Stone.

div.head: CXII. Liquamen Silicum, Oil or Liquor of Flints.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Calcin'd Flints p. iij. Salt of Tartar calcin'd with Nitre ‚Ñ•iv. mix them exactly; and put them by degrees into a red hot Crucible, urging the Fire S. A. afterwards expo≈øe the Ma≈øs to the Air, that it ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y melt per deliquium, S. A. It cuts Tartarous Mucilage, re≈øolves the Stone, and powerfully opens Ob≈øtructions. Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Schroder ≈øays it may be given to a ‚Ñàj. but he has a Cream or Oil of Flints de≈øcribed in the ≈øecond part of Glauber's Fornaces Pag. Mea. 44. If you keep it long in a Cellar it lets fall a Settling to the bottom, and ≈øends an Oil to the top; which mu≈øt be ≈øo long evacuating from the Jelly, as any Liquor will a≈øcend: and then be ≈øweerned: this Oil or Cream, Clo≈ø≈øaus ≈øays may ea≈øily be di≈ø≈øolved in any Liquor.

¬ß 2. In the place cited Glauber takes four times as much Salt of Tartar, as of calcin'd Flints, which extreamly differs from this of our Author, the exact Pre≈øcript you have in our Polygraphices, Lib. 3. Cap. 29. Sect. 57. conformable to Glauber's Mind.

¬ß 3. In the making of it, he ≈øhews how to get a powerful Spirit out of the Salt of Tartar, of wonderful Vertues and Effects, of which it is not our bu≈øine≈øs here to ≈øpeak, that being de≈øigned for the Officina Chymica, next to come forth after this work.

¬ß 4. But the remainder after that Spirit is extracted, is the thing of which our Experiment is to be made; What looks (≈øays he) tran≈øparent like Gla≈øs is nothing el≈øe but the mo≈øt fixed part of the Salt of Tartar and Flints, which joyning them≈øelves in the Heat, turn thus to a ≈øoluble Gla≈øs, in which lies a great Heat and Fire.
¬ß 5. As long as it is kept from the Air it cannot be perceived in it; but if you pour Water upon it, then its ≈øecret heat will di≈øcover it ≈øelf.
¬ß 6. If you reduce it to a fine Pouder, in a hot Mortar, and lay it in a moi≈øt Air, it will di≈ø≈øolve into a thick and fat Oil, leaving ≈øome Feces behind.

¬ß 7. This fat Liquor or Oil of Flints, Sand, or Cry≈øtal, may not only be u≈øed inwardly, and outwardly of it ≈øelf, but al≈øo ≈øerves to prepare Metals and Minerals into good. Medicines, or to change them into better by the Chymical Art.

¬ß 8. Many great Secrets are hid in this contemptible Flint, which the unlearned will hardly believe. The great Paracel≈øus maintains that a de≈øpicable Flint. ca≈øt at a Cow, is many times more worth than the Cow it ≈øelf; not only becau≈øe that Gold may be melted out of it, but becau≈øe the other inferior Metals may be ≈øo purified thereby, as to become like the be≈øt Gold and Silver in all tryals.

¬ß 9. This Liquor of Flints is of that Vertue in re≈øpect of Metals, that it makes them exceeding fair, (not by the common way of Cook-maids ≈øcowring them,) but by being di≈ø≈øolved therein by the Chymical Art, and then either after the wet or dry way, to be dige≈øted in it for a due time, which Paracel≈øus terms the going into the Mother's Womb, and being ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rn again: and if this be rightly done, then the Mother will bring forth a pure Child.

¬ß 10. All Metals are generated in Sand or Stone, and therefore they may be well called the Mother of Metals, and the purer the Mother is, the purer and ≈øounder will the Child be: and among all Stones, none are ≈øound purer than the Peble, Flints, Cry≈øtal or Sand, which are all of one Nature, and therefore the Flint, Peble or Sand is found to be the fitte≈øt Bath to wa≈øh the Metal with all.

¬ß 11. But this Bath, is not the Philo≈øophers ≈øecret Men≈øtruum, for that is more friendly to Gold, by rea≈øon of its affinity with it; but this more, ea≈øily di≈ø≈øolves other Metals than Gold; therefore neither can it be Bernhard's Fountain, but mu≈øt only be taken to be a particular clean≈øer of Metals.

¬ß 12. As to the kind of Flints or Pebles which you ought to take for this work they ≈øhould not be white, but a fair yellow, green, or blew, which po≈ø≈øibly may contain Gold either fixed or volatile.

¬ß 13. Then having from them made the ≈øaid Soluble, Gla≈øs, and reduced it to fine. Pouder, you may there from make a Tincture thus. Put‚ñ™ this Pouder into a Belt-head.
and affu≈øe thereon rectified S. V. (it needs to be perfectly deflegmated, or pure and fine) dige≈øt in a gentle heat till it becomes red, often ≈øhaking the Gla≈øs, that the Spirit may the better work upon it; then decant it and affu≈øe fre≈øh Spirit, which work repeat ≈øo long till the S. V. will be no more tinged. Put all the≈øe Tinctures together, and in B. M. ab≈øtract the S. V. ≈øo will the Tincture of Flints remain in the bottom like a red Juice‚ñ™ which take and keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 14. This Tincture if it be made out of Gold-Flints, Pebles or Sand, is none of the lea≈øt Medicines; for it powerfully re≈øi≈øts all ≈øoluble Tartarous Coagulations, in the Hands, Knees. Feet, Reins, or Bladder: and tho' for want of ≈øuch as hold or contain Gold, it be extracted out of the common white Peble or Flint, yet will it act its part however, tho' not full out ≈øo well as the former.

¬ß 15. This Tincture will yet be more powerful, if fir≈øt Gold has been di≈ø≈øolved in the Liquamen of Pebles, before the Extraction: Nor let any think, that this Tincture comes from the Salt of Tartar, becau≈øe that will al≈øo tinge S. V. for there is a great difference between this Tincture, and that of the Salt of Tartar.

¬ß 16. For the Tinct. Salis Tartari is no true Tincture, but only the pure≈øt part of the Salt di≈ø≈øolved in the Spirit, as you may prove by ab≈øtraction, wherein you will have, Fir≈øt, a clear Spirit of Wine: Secondly, an un≈øavory Flegm: La≈øtly, a white common Salt of Tartar remaining behind.

¬ß 17. Whereas this Tincture of Flints or Pebles is clear of another nature; for if you ab≈øtract the S. V. from it, which comes over colourle≈øs, yet there remains a deep tinctured Salt, who≈øe colour is la≈øting in the ≈øtronge≈øt Fire, and therefore may be accounted for a genuine or true Tincture.

¬ß 18. The Liquamen Silicum does precipitate all Metals which are di≈ø≈øolved by Corro≈øives, but not as Salt of Tartar does; for the Precicipitate will be much heavier hereby, than if it had been done with Ol. Tartari, becau≈øe the Particles of the Flint do mix them≈øelves therewith.

¬ß 19. Ex. gr. ‚Ñû Fine Sol q. v. di≈ø≈øolve in A. R. q. ≈ø. then precipitate with the Liquor
Silicum, till all the Gold falls down in a yellow Pouder, and the Solution becomes white and clear: decant the Liquor and edulcorate the Precipitate by many ablutions with fair Water and dry it (as Aurum Fulminans, but you need not fear its fulminating in the drying, as it u≈øes to do, when precipitated with Salt of Tartar, or Spirit of Urine) ≈øo will you have a yellow Calx, as heavy again as the Gold, before Solution, the cau≈øe of which is the Particles of the Flint or Peble precipitating therewith.

¬ß 20. This edulcorated yellow Calx put into a Crucible on a fire of live Coals, till it begins to be red-hot, but not long, ≈øo will it become a mo≈øt fair Purple, very plea≈øant to behold: if it ≈øtands longer, the Purple colour will vani≈øh, and it will be of a brown Brick colour, for which rea≈øon you must not let it remain too long.

¬ß 21. This purple Gold pouder may be given √† ‚Ñàj. ad í ≈øs. in any fit Vehicle, in all Di≈øea≈øes where ≈øweating is needful, for it provokes Sweat, comforts the Heart, and is ≈øaid to expel Stone and Gravel from both Reins and Bladder: and to cure even the Plague it ≈øelf.

¬ß 22. From this purple Calx of Gold, you may extract a Tincture with this our Liquamen Silicum, thus. ‚Ñû Purple, Calx of Sol, p. j. Liquaminis Silicum, p. iij. mix them in a good large Crucible (le≈øt in run over) and evaporate over a gentle heat to dryne≈øs, and increa≈øe the fire till the Crucible is red-hot (keeping it covered, that no Coals, Du≈øt, or A≈øhes may fall into it) then ≈øtill increa≈øe the fire in a Wind Fornace, till the Matter melts and flows like Water, keeping it ≈øo long melted till it be like a tran≈øparent fair Ruby, which will be in an hours time, or thereabouts. Then being cold reduce it into Pouder, and with S. V. extract a Blood-like Tincture, which will be much more powerful than the former Tincture.
¬ß 23. The remaining Calx, you may melt with Lead and reduce into white Gold, which being melted with Antimony will recover its yellow colour again.

¬ß 24. And as this Liquor of Flints is the Medium of opening the Body of Gold. in order to the extracting of its Tincture, ≈øo al≈øo will it do in all the other Metals and Minerals, for which rea≈øon it is needle≈øs to de≈øcribe them by them≈øelves, all the
Proce≈ø≈øes of them, being demon≈øtrated in this One of Gold.

¬ß25. By the help of this Liquor of Flints, you may al≈øo make the Golden, Silver, and Steel Trees of the Philo≈øophers as is taught in our Polygraphice, Lib. 3. Cap. 29. Sect. 54, 55, 56. as al≈øo other profitable things in Alchymie, fair Pigments for Paintings, out of Metals which will abide in all Elements; and to frame all ≈øorts of tran≈øparent hard Stones out of Cry≈øtal, which in Beauty may be as fair or fairer than the Natural, Enamels, and ≈øuch like.

¬ß26. Lemery in≈øtead of a five-fold proportion of Salt of Tartar, u≈øes a ≈øix-fold of Tartar to one of calcin'd Flints: ‚Ñû Calcin'd Flints in fine pouder ‚Ñ•iv. Salt of Tarter ‚Ñ•xxiv. mix and put them into a large Crucible in a wind Fornace, making a fire by little and little, and then gently increafing it to the la≈øt degree, in which keep it for five hours, the Matter being in Fu≈øion, till it grows Diaphanous like Gla≈øs, which you may know by putting a Spatula into it: ca≈øt it forth into an Iron Mortar, and it will pre≈øently congeal into a hard Ma≈øs, which Pouder while hot: take one half it, and ≈øet it in a Cellar in a Gla≈øs Pan' and it will di≈ø≈øolve into a clear Liquor, which filter, and keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 27. This Liquor is ≈øaid to be diuretick given √† gut. vj. ad xxvj. in ≈øome fit Vehicle: and being mixed in equal parts, with ≈øome Acid corro≈øive Spirit, they will pre≈øently become a Stone: and from this Phaenomenon the Generation of Stones in Animal Bodies may be explicated, ≈øeeing Acids and Alcalies do often meet within us; and for this rea≈øon ≈øome Authors give a Caution again≈øt the u≈øe of this Remedy inwardly, as al≈øo the Tincture therefrom; tho' they conceed, that they may ≈øometimes di≈ø≈øolve ≈øome Sulphurous Ob≈øtructions, and ≈øo thereby provoke Urine.

¬ß 28. This Liquamen Silicum has obtained mightily among ≈øome Men, in≈øomuch that they give it no le≈øs than the name of Alcahe≈øt: but it is indeed u≈øe to extract the Sulphurs of many Metals and Minerals.

¬ß 29. Upon the mixing of it with an Acid, an Ebulition is made, and a ≈øtronger Coagulation, than upon the mixing the Oil of Tartar with an Acid; the rea≈øon of which is becau≈øe this Alcali
contains more Earth than the Salt of Tartar does, whence the cau≈øe of the Lapidi≈øcent property-appears plainly enough.

¬ß 30. Upon the other half of the Pouder, put into a hot dry Matra≈øs, affu≈øe the be≈øt rectified S. V. ≈øo much as to overtop it four Inches, ≈øtop the Matra≈øs with another, who≈øe Neck may be received into that which contains the Matter, lute the Juncture with a wet Bladder, and dige≈øt in a gentle Sand heat for two or three days, ≈øo as the S. V. may ≈øimper, ≈øo will you have a very red Tincture, which decant, putting in fre≈øh S. V. to the remainder, repeating, &c. the≈øe Tinctures mix, and in B. Vap. ab≈øtract two thirds of the Spirit, and keep the remaining Tincture for u≈øe.
¬ß 31. This Tincture is e≈øteemed an excellent Medicine to cure the Scurvy, open Ob≈øtructions, and root out Hypochondriack Di≈øea≈øes, being given √† gut. 10. ad. 30. in ≈øome fit Vehicle.

¬ß 32. La≈øtly, From the melting of the Calx per Deliquium, it appears. that the Calx of the Flint is ≈øo intimarely incorporated with, and into the Salt of Tartar by Calcination, that it may truly enough be ≈øaid to be converted into a Salt.

div.head: CXIII. Liquamen Sulphuris, Liquor of Sulphur.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Flowers of Sulphur, white Sugar-Candy, A. ‚Ñ•j. mix and make a Pouder: then take four Eggs boiled hard, ≈øtit them in the middle, and take forth the Yolks, in place of which put this Mixture, which join clo≈øe together by tying them; then hang them over Coals, and the Liquor will ≈øweat forth, which keep for u≈øe. It is a famous Pectoral, prevailing again≈øt A≈øthma's, Coughs, Phthi≈øicks, Pleuri≈øies, &c. Do≈øe, gut. 20, 30. &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This ≈øupplies the U≈øe of the Bal≈øam and Tincture of Sulphur, and is to be e≈øteemed by rea≈øon of its Efficacy and Vertue: for as Sulphur is of it ≈øelf incorruptible, and pre≈øerves dead Bodies, from Putrefaction; ≈øo al≈øo it hinders the Corruption and Decay of living Bodies, and re≈øtores the Defects of the Radical Bal≈øam of Life, when once it is altered.

¬ß2. Wherefore we commend to all, the Preparations of Sulphur, becau≈øe it ≈øupplies with Medicaments,
le≈øs ≈øubject to fail in their Operations, than many other things.

¬ß3. For this is certain, that whatever the mo≈øt excellent Remedies have of Vertue, Power and Efficacy, they receive it from the Beams and Vigor of the internal Sulphur which they have in them≈øelves, whether they be extracted from Vegetables, Minerals, or Animals.

¬ß4. And for this rea≈øon it is, we recommend the Con≈øervation of Volatile and Sulphurous Salts and Sub≈øtances, for that the are the la≈øt covering or cloathing of the Light and Spirit of the Mixt, from whence proceed all the chief Actions of natural Bodies.

¬ß 5. The Sugar-Candy being an e≈ø≈øential Salt, it has a power in it ≈øelf, by help of the Moi≈øture in the Whites of Eggs, to di≈ø≈øolve, extract or draw forth the Efficacy of the Sulphur; and tho' it is not the greate≈øt Medicine that can be made of Sulphur, yet it is a very good one, and ≈øafe to be u≈øed; and much more plea≈øant than the vulgar Bal≈øam of Sulphur made with Chymical Oils, for which rea≈øon it is to be commended, and e≈øteemed.

6. This Liquamen participates of a Vitriolick Nature, for it is chiefly the Saline parts of it which di≈ø≈øolve, and are eliquiated by the di≈ø≈øolution of the Sugar; and this is evident, becau≈øe there ≈øeems to be no difference between the Salt of the Caput Mortuum of Sulphur, being extracted out of it after Calcination with Rain-water, and the Salt of Vitriol.

¬ß 7. Therefore ≈øays Le Febure, The Salt of Vitriol may always be lawfully ≈øub≈øtituted, and without any ≈øcruple, in the place of that of Sulphur, becau≈øe they ≈øpring from the ≈øame Original, and have the ≈øame Vertue, which is to clean≈øe and ≈øtrengthen the Bre≈øt, Stomach and Lungs, open their Ob≈øtructions, and eradicate from them all Seminaries of Worms and Corruption.

div.head: CXIV. Liquor Cephalalgicus, Liquor again≈øt the Head-Ach.
div.p:
Bate.] ‚Ñû Camphire í ij. di≈ø≈øolve it in rectified S. V. í ij. which with a ≈øufficient quantity of Oil or Spirit of Damask Ro≈øes (Rhodo≈øtagmatis) being put into a Di≈øh, is mixed over a gentle fire, ≈øprinkling in al≈øo Nutmegs in pouder
‚Ñàj. Zedoary í ≈øs. Applied to the Forehead, it gives ea≈øe in the Head-Ach.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. What the Author means by his Rhodo≈øtagma is uncertain, it being a word of a various, dubious, and uncertain Signification, and be≈øides a Word not u≈øually to be met with in Medical Authors, being a a Greek compound, ≈øignifying a Liquor drawn from Ro≈øes; but whether it be Ro≈øe-water, Spirit or Oil of Ro≈øes who can tell?

¬ß 2. But con≈øidering the Intention, and with what it was to be mixt, viz. the Alcohol of Wine and Camphire; and by rea≈øon the Spirit was rectified and an Alcohol, it was not rea≈øonable to ≈øuppo≈øe, that Ro≈øe-water (which is only the Flegm of Ro≈øes) could be intended, for then an ordinary Spirit of Wine might have ≈øufficed; nor in re≈øpect to the Camphire, becau≈øe Aqueous Bodies are apt to cau≈øe that Gum or Ro≈øin, to coagulate again.

¬ß 3. You may pour it gently upon the pained part, and then rub it with your Hand, it will ≈øink in as fa≈øt almo≈øt as you lay it on; be≈øides which the Patient is to ≈ønuff ≈øome of it up the No≈øtrils: if it be well u≈øed, it will take away the pain in three or four Minutes time: you may u≈øe it cold, without heating, nor need it be u≈øed near any fire.

¬ß 4. If the Pain ≈øhould return again pre≈øently, you mu≈øt then immediately take the ≈øame cour≈øe again, I can a≈ø≈øure you upon my own Experience, that at two or three times u≈øing, ≈øometimes at once, it takes away (in a few Minutes) the pain ≈øo perfectly, as that it no more returns at that time, or from that pre≈øent Cau≈øe.

¬ß 5. Inwardly taken to the quantity of half a Spoonful or more in a Gla≈øs of Sack, it not only prevails again≈øt Megrims, Head-Aches, Vertigoes, Lethargies, Pal≈øies, Convul≈øions, Apoplexies, and other cold and moi≈øt Di≈øea≈øes of the Head and Brain; but al≈øo is a mo≈øt powerful and in≈øtant Remedy again≈øt the Colick, Gripings of the Bowels, Hy≈øterick Pa≈ø≈øions and the like.
¬ß 6. Outwardly bathed on places pained with the Gout, and Pains and Aches from a cold Cau≈øe, it gives great comfort, and in a ≈øhort time relief.

div.head: CXV. Liquor Limacum, Liquor of Snails.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of Red Snails cut in pieces and Salt, A. put into Hippocrates his Sleeve, and hung up in a Cellar, that the Liquor may fall from them, which is kept for u≈øe. Being bathed upon the place or applied, it ea≈øes the Pains of the Gout. It cures Warts. A certain Woman by giving ≈øome Drops hereof in a Draught of Beer, was wont to cure the Chin-Cough, or Suffocative cough in Children.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It is a ≈øingular Arthritick, Univer≈øals being before premi≈øed; otherwi≈øe Topicks unskilfully applied tho' they may give ea≈øe, as to the part, yet are apt to drive the Di≈øea≈øe into the Stomach, which ≈øometimes proves the Death of the Patient.

div.head: CXVI. Oleum Talchi per Deliquium, Oil of Talck by melting or di≈ø≈øolving.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Pouder of Talck Tartar calcin'd with Nitre, Ana. mix them S. S. Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Clo≈ø≈øaeus calcines the Talck with double its weight of Salt of Tartar: and without doubt it will be be≈øt to ≈øet it to melt per Deliquium; ≈øeparating that which melts not, and calcining as before, melting, ≈øeparating and calcining again,

¬ß 2. There are many other ways of calcining the Talck, (upon which work being well done, the ≈øtre≈øs of the Operation almo≈øt lies) which you may ≈øee in our Pharm. Lond. Lib. 3. Cap. 13. Sect. 102. to which I ≈øhall now refer you.

¬ß 3. But Hartman has an Oil of Talck made by Di≈øtillation, which is thought to be more valuable for all the Purpo≈øes aforementioned, and other Vices of the Skin; thus ‚Ñû Venetian Talck cleave it into ≈ølices, or rub it into fine pouder; then put it into a Phial, and affu≈øe thereon Spirit of Vinegar made of Canary; ≈øtop it clo≈øe and dige≈øt in Hor≈øe dung or an equivolent heat for a Month, adding every day new di≈øtilled Vinegar to the former, till the Vinegar be Mucilaginious: then put it into a Coated Gla≈øs Retort, fixing a large Receiver, and luting the Juncture; di≈øtil with a naked Fire, fir≈øt there comes forth the Vinegar, then a white Oil, which ≈øeparate, and keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 4. Before you u≈øe this latter by di≈øtillation, or that pre≈øcribed by our Author, you ought to clean≈øe the Skin very well by wa≈øhing it fir≈øt with warm Water, and ≈øweet ≈øcented Wa≈øh-balls‚ñ™ rubing the Face dry with a Cloth, and then wa≈øhing it again with warm Water in which Wheat Bran has been boiled, ≈øo will the Skin be prepared.

div.head: CXVII. Oleum Viridis Aeris, Oil of Verdigri≈øe.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Verdigri≈øe ‚Ñ•ij. Nitre ‚Ñ•iij. mix and put them into a little Earthen Di≈øh or Pan, and fire it with a live Coal, till the Deflagration cea≈øes: then di≈ø≈øolve it per deliquium in a Cellar. It is Cau≈øtick, cures Venereal Pu≈øtules, and takes a way Warts.

div.head: CXVIII. Plumbum album, & Ceru≈ø≈øa, White Lead, and Ceru≈øe.
div.p: Bate.] Make Plates of Lead and hang them over Vinegar, ≈øo that the Vapors from the Vin ‚Ä¢ gar may environ or go round it: ≈øo will the Lead by little and little convert into Ceru≈øe.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Lead ≈øays Lemery is converted into Ceru≈øe or white Lead, by the help of Vinegar, who≈øe Vapors it imbibes, by which means it is converted into a white Ru≈øt, which being gathered is made into little Cakes: this is called white Lead; but if into one great Lump, it is called Ceru≈øe; ≈øo that you may ≈øee there is no difference in the things, but in the Terms, and Form of making up.

Charras reduces the Lead (after purification) into thin Plates, and then hangs them up over the Vapors of Vinegar put into a proper Ve≈ø≈øel over a moderate Fire: ≈øo will a white Sub≈øtance grow upon the Lead, which he ≈øeparates and gathers together, and this is that ≈øays he, which they call Ceru≈øe.

¬ß 4. ¬ß 5. Here is al≈øo to be nored, that this White Lead or Ceru≈øe may be prepared by the Vapors of any other Acid, as A. F. Spirit of Ni ‚Ä¢ re, &c. as well as by tho≈øe of Vinegar, fora≈ømuch, as all Acids what≈øoever corrode and ru≈øt it.

div.head: CXIX. Pilulae Vomitoriae, Vomiting Pills.

div.head: CXX. Sapo Tartareus, Tartarean Soap, or Soap of Salt of Tartar.

La≈øtly, Although the Pre≈øcript only orders it to be made with Oil of Turpentine, yet it may as well be made with Oil of Juniperberries, and many other Chymical Oils, and ≈øo become more homogene, plea≈øant, and effectual to the Purpo≈øes you intend it: but this ought to be done according to the Intention and De≈øign of the Phy≈øician.

div.head: AN APPENDIX Added by the TRANSLATOR.
div.p: CXXI. G∆≤ttae Goddardianae, ≈øeu Arcanum Goddardianum, Goddard's Drops.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû Humane Bones, put them into a Retort, and join thereto a large Receiver, which lute well; and di≈øtil fir≈øt with a gentle Fire, then with a ≈øtronger increa≈øing the fire Gradatim; ≈øo will you have in the Recipient a Flegm, Spirit, Oil, and Volatile Salt: ≈øhake the Receiver to loo≈øen the Volatile Salt from the ≈øides, then clo≈øe your Receiver, and ≈øet it in the Earth to dige≈øt for three Months; after that dige≈øt it in a gentle Heat for fourteen days, then ≈øeparate the Oil which keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 2. The Author of this Recipe, was not that Goddard, many of who≈øe Recipes and Pre≈øcripts, are ≈øcatter'd up and down in ≈øeveral places of this Book, but the Famous W‚Äî Goddard, a great Philo≈øopher and Phy≈øician, who de≈øerved well of the World in his day and time, and who has even in this Remedy left him≈øelf an Immortal Name.

¬ß 3. And this is the true Medicine which was purcha≈øed of the Doctor by K. Charles the Second, ≈øo much famed thro' the whole Kingdom, and for which he gave him (as it is reported) fifteen hundred Pounds Sterling.

¬ß 4. They that plea≈øe may make it according to the Pre≈øcript; but in my Opinion (for 'tis po≈ø≈øible a Dwarf ≈øtanding upon a Giant's Shoulders may ≈øee farther than the Giant) it would be a better way, fir≈øt to rectifie the Oil from the Flegm, then to grind the Volatile

¬ß 5. You may make it of all the Bones of the Humane Body together, or if it be for a particular Intention, as for the Gout in any Limb, then of the Bones of tho≈øe parts; but if for Di≈øea≈øes of the Head, then of Skulls only, and you ought to chu≈øe tho≈øe Bones which have lain a long time a drying, for that they will have lo≈øt mo≈øt of their Flegm, and for the ≈øame rea≈øon will yield their Volatile Salt and Oil the more plentifully.

¬ß 6. The≈øe drops are of an ill and fetid Smell, but being made of Skulls are an excellent thing again≈øt the Falling Sickne≈øs, as al≈øo again≈øt the Apoplexy, Lethargy, Vertigo, Megrim, Head-Achs, Carus, Pal≈øies, Convul≈øions, and mo≈øt other Di≈øea≈øes of the Head, Brain and Nerves; they cure the Vapors in Women, and Fits of the Mother, and remove the Ob≈øtructions and Pains of the Spleen. ¬ß 7. But if you would take away their evil Scent and Elixirate them, add to every Ounce of them Spirit of Nitre rectified ≈øo much as may di≈ø≈øolve the Oil, which done mix it with four times the weight of the whole of Alcohol of S. ¬ß 9. But in this la≈øt way, you mu≈øt give it in a larger Do≈øe, as √† gut. xx. ad 60. in a Gla≈øs of Canary, in the Morning fa≈øting, a little before Dinner, and la≈øt at night going to Bed.

¬ß 10. But before we leave this Subject, let me give you this following Note, That the Bones being reduced into pouder by beating in a Mortar, and then prepared with Spirit of Nitre rectified; and that Di≈ø≈øolution mixed with double
the quantity of the be≈øt Tartariz'd Spirit of Wine makes a Medicine much plea≈øanter both in Smell and Ta≈øte, and preferrable before all the other Preparations both for Vertues and Efficacy, as I by a long Series of Experiments can truly tell. div.head: CHAP. X. Of SALTS.
I. Cry≈øtallum Minerale, Cry≈øtal Mineral.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû SAl-Prunellae, di≈ø≈øolve it in Water, filter and cry≈øtallize, S. A. ¬ß 9. div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Spirit of Sulphur ‚Ñ•iv. fine Nitre ‚Ñ•iv. mix and di≈øtil to dryne≈øs, cohobating thrice, and at length increa≈øing the Fire, till the Ve≈ø≈øel is red-hot. It has the Vertues of Sal-Primellae.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Our Text teaches you to cohobate, or to u≈øe again the Spirit di≈øtilled off; but ≈øome Authors think it would be good to u≈øe fre≈øh Spirit each time, el≈øe I fear you will ≈øcarcely have the the Spirit come as Acid off, as it went on, which it ought to do, and then you have a good Medicine indeed; but by this latter way, your Salt will be much the dearer.
¬ß 2. At la≈øt the Ve≈ø≈øel is made red-hot becau≈øe all the ≈øuperfluous Spirit (as Le Mort calls it) it may be taken away, by which means your Salt will be the dryer, whiter, and purer.

¬ß 3. It is highly aperitive, ≈øtomatick and nephritick, refi≈øts Putrefaction in the highe≈øt degree, and therefore is ≈øaid to be a ≈øingular thing to pre≈øerve from the Infection of the Plague, or any other infectious Di≈øea≈øe; it quenches thir≈øt, cools the heat of Fevers how violent ≈øoever, and provokes Urine. It is good again≈øt the Putrefaction of the Teeth, clean≈øes them, and takes away the ≈øtinking of the Mouth. Do≈øe, √† gr. iij. ad ‚Ñàj. in Canary, or other proper Vehicle.

div.head: XVII. Nitrum Vitriolatum, Nitre vitriolated.
div.p: Bate.] It is prepared from Nitre, p ij. Oil of Vitriol, p.j. being di≈øtilled to dryne≈øs, and cohobated, as in Nitre ≈øulphurated. See the Arcanum Duplex.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Arcanum Duplex ≈øee Chap. IX. Sect. XVI. aforegoing, from which this apparently differs, tho' it has much the ≈øame Vertues with that: but that is prepared from the Caput Mortuum of double Aqua Fortis, made of Nitre and Alum, ≈øay ≈øome, but of Nitre and Vitriol ≈øay others, as Schroder: whereas this is prepared from pure ≈øimple Nitre it ≈øelf, by addition of Oil of Vitriol.

¬ß 2. You may ≈øee the Preparation of it at large in Hor≈øtius his Pharm. Lib. 17. Pag. 457. but it is a Recipe
of Myn≈øicht's, in The≈øaur. Sect. 1. Pag. 29. where you will find the Proportions differing from the≈øe in our Text, viz. ‚Ñû Prepared Nitre. p. j. rectified Oil or Spirit of Vitriol p. ij. (which is four times as much as is pre≈øcribed by our Author) mix and di≈øtil by Retort with degrees of fire, fir≈øt gentle, then with a ≈øtronger fire, till the Retort grows red-hot, and no more Spirit will a≈øcend; ≈øo will a Snow white Pouder remain at bottom. To this he advi≈øes to put as much more fre≈øh Spirit or Oil of Vitriol, enough for its perfect di≈ø≈øolution, then to filter, and evaporate away the Humidity to one half, after which he ≈øets it in a cold place to ≈øhoot into Cry≈øtals, which he drys and keeps for u≈øe.
¬ß 3. This is Nitre vitriolated, which Chymi≈øts call Spiritus Vitrioli Coagulatus, who≈øe Vertues we will give you from the ≈øame Myn≈øieht.

¬ß 4. It has ≈øays he, the ≈øame Vertues and Operations with Spirit of Vitriol, ≈øaving, that this more cools, and is more diuretick than that, and has a greater power in tinging or coloring any thing: but its chief Vertues con≈øi≈øt in i ‚Ä¢ ciding, di≈ø≈øipating, mundi
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ng drying, re≈øi≈øting Putrefaction, and quenching Thir≈øt.

¬ß 5. For the≈øe Rea≈øons it is ≈øaid to be mo≈øt powerful again≈øt all malign Fevers, pe≈øtilential, putrid, hungarick, epidemick, which are cau≈øed from a ≈øulphureous, a≈øtral, and venen Influence upon the Bodies of Humane kind.

¬ß 6. It has a Bezoartick property which often times moves both Urine and Swear, thereby expelling all inward hot, noxious Vapors; it purges and re≈øtores a troubled Stomach, helps the Concoction, and excites the Appetite; and takes away the Cau≈øe of a putrid and ≈øtinking Breath, kills Worms bred of Crudities and putrid Humors.

¬ß 7. It is al≈øo good in Hepatick Di≈øtempers, which ≈øome think to be the Cau≈øes of Rubies and Pu≈øtules in the Face; and for ≈øuch as are apt to be troubled with a Diarrhaea, it is a mo≈øt excellent Remedy.

¬ß 8. It prevails again≈øt the Quin≈øie, pe≈øtilential Di≈øea≈øes Pleuri≈øie, Tumor of the Spleen, a putrid or virulent Gonorrhoea, the Flux of the Whites in Women, the Scurvy, and other like Di≈øea≈øes, for which it is ≈øaid to be an excellent Remedy.

¬ß 9. Do≈øe, √† gr. iv. ad 10. in ≈øome proper Con≈øerve, Electuary, Syrup, Julep or Liquor: in cold Di≈øea≈øes let it be given in Wine; but in burning Fevers in pure Water, or Barley-water: again≈øt a Diarrhaea, and to comfort the Liver, as al≈øo again≈øt a Gonorrhaea, and Flux of the Womb, mix it with Con≈øerve of red Ro≈øes, of which the ≈øick may take Morning and Night to the quantity of a Che≈ønut.

¬ß 10. But all ≈øuch as are obnoxious to Contractions and Convul≈øions of the Nerves, have an exceeding dry Head, and a wa≈øted and dried Body; ≈øuch al≈øo who have a very thin and debile Stomach, and a ≈øtraitne≈øs of the Orifice of the Ventricle, Women and Virgins afflicted with a ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of their Cour≈øes, are all to ab≈øtain from the u≈øe of this Medicament.

div.head: XVIII. Sal Ab≈øinthij Cry≈øtallinum, Cry≈øtallized Salt of Wormwood.
div.p: Bate.] It is made by di≈ø≈øolving Salt of Wormwood in Water, by filtering, cry≈øtallizing and drying it. S. A.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Our Author here intends the fixed or elementary Salt made by incineration, elixiviation, filteration and evaporation; which by reiterated Di≈ø≈øolutions, &c. will become pure and cry≈øtalline, as it is ≈øaid.

¬ß 2. But that the Cry≈øtals might be the more firm and durable, Oil of Sulphur ought to be added to the Lixivium, then they will ≈øhoot ≈øooner, fairer, and better: this may do in ≈øome Ca≈øes, but where the pure Alcaly is de≈øired, all Acid ≈øub≈øtances mu≈øt be avoided.

¬ß 3. But the Cry≈øtalline Volatile and E≈ø≈øential Salt is thus made. ‚Ñû Wormwood while it is fre≈øh and full of Juice before ≈øeeding, q. v. brui≈øe it in a Wooden, Stone or Iron Mortar, add to it a great quantity of fair Water, and boil to the Con≈øumption of the half part; ≈øtrain, pre≈ø≈øing it out ≈øtrongly, and after boil it to the thickne≈øs of new Honey: then put it into a Gla≈øs or glazed Ve≈ø≈øel, and ≈øet it in a cold place for nine or ten days or more, and it will ≈øhoot into a Cry≈øtalline Salt, (which decanting the Liquor) gather, dry, and keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 4. But in making thi ‚Ä¢ E≈ø≈øential Salt, if you pou ‚Ä¢ the Juice a little in≈øpi≈ø≈øate ‚Ä¢ upon fre≈øh Herbs, and the ‚Ä¢
dige≈øt, decoct, and ≈øtrain as before, you will have a larger quantity of Salt than otherwi≈øe.

¬ß 5. This Salt if not pure enough according to your Mind, di≈ø≈øolve again in Wormwood-water, filter and evaporate; and then cry≈øtallize, ≈øo will it be very pure and clear, which dry and keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 6. The fixt or elementary Salt, incides, opens, ab≈øterges, and attenuates, and is ≈øtomachick: It brings forth (≈øays Le Mort) the Stone by Urine, and provokes Sweat as all other alcalious Salts do: it prevails again≈øt Fevers (e≈øpecially intermitting) of what kind ≈øoever, and is given √† gr. vj. ad ‚Ñàj. in ≈øome ≈øudorifick Vehicle.

¬ß 7. But the fixt Salt being cry≈øtallized with Oil of Sulphur, it ≈øeems to be more powerful again≈øt Tartarous Di≈øea≈øes, and a greater Stomatick, re≈øi≈øts Corruption and Putrefaction, and the Infection of the Plague. Do≈øe, the ≈øame with the former.

¬ß 8. In making the E≈ø≈øential Salt, after you have gotten all the Cry≈øtals you can, the remaining Liquor you may evaporate to the con≈øi≈øtency of an Extract, and keep it under the Title of the in≈øpi≈ø≈øate Juice of Wormwood.

¬ß 10. The extract or in≈øpi≈ø≈øate Juice is ≈øtomatick, and removes Ob≈øtructions of the Spleen and Me≈øentery, and kills Worms in the Stomach, being inwardly taken, and outwardly applied about the Navel and Stomach. Do≈øe, ‚Ñà≈øs. ad í j.

div.head: XIX. Sal Aceti E≈ø≈øentiale, E≈ø≈øential Salt of Vinegar.
div.p: Bate.] Boil the Caput Mortuum of the Spirit of Vinegar in Water, filter and cry≈øtallize, S. A. it is ≈øudorifick, and re≈øi≈øts Putrefaction. Do≈øe, √† gr. v. ad 10. in any proper Vehicle.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Ab≈øtract Vinegar to the con≈øi≈øtence of Honey, then ≈øet it to cry≈øtallize: the≈øe Cry≈øtals you may purifie by di≈ø≈øolving them in the Flegm of the Vinegar, evaporating, and cry≈øtallizing again.

¬ß 2. Marggrave does it in a Gla≈øs Retort, and then ab≈øtracts but to the con≈øi≈øtency of a Syrup or new Honey; le≈øt it ≈øhould contract an Empyreuma: but di≈øtilling the Spirit of Vinegar in a low Cucurbit in B. M. he di≈øtils to dryne≈øs: a quarter part of what is di≈øtilled is Flegm of Vinegar, which ought to be taken by it ≈øelf; the other there parts is Spirit of Vinegar.

¬ß 3. The Feces at bottom, whether like Syrup or dry, contain the Salt and Oil of Vinegar, or its fixt and gro≈øs Sulphur, which may each by them≈øelves be ≈øeparated, if the Feces be di≈ø≈øolved in pure Water; then pre≈øently the Water being throughly mixt with the Sulphur or Oily parts is decanted red into another Ve≈ø≈øel, and the Sal Aceti will remain in the bottom like Sand; which is the e≈ø≈øential Salt of the Vinegar, and is nothing but Crude Tartar, which by the fair Water is purified and edulcorated.

¬ß 4. Some affu≈øing the Flegm of the Vinegar upon the Feces, dige≈øt twenty four hours then filter, ≈øtrain, and evaporate in a Gla≈øs Ve≈ø≈øel to the con≈øi≈øtency of a Syrup, and call it Elixir Aceti: it is ≈øtomatick, attenuates, and excites the Appetite.

¬ß 5. The Spirit of Vinegar, cools, drys, and a≈øtringes; attemperates and thickens thin fermenting Humors; and on the contrary again opens and incides cra≈øs and vi≈øcous Humors, attenuates, provokes Sweat and Urine, and pre≈øerves from Putrefaction. Do≈øe, √† í ij. ad iv. It prevails again≈øt the Plague and all contagious Di≈øea≈øes, Pleuri≈øies and internal Inflamations.

¬ß 6. It is a noble and egregious Men≈øtruum in Chymi≈øtry for di≈ø≈øolving Stones, Shells, Coral, Pearl, and Metals, as Venus, Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, and for making Mineral and Metalick Tinctures and Extractions.

div.head: XX. Sal Aceti fixum, The fixed Salt of Vinegar.
div.p: Bate.] Calcine the Caput Mortuum left after the di≈øtillation of the Spirit of Vinegar, di≈ø≈øolve it in Water, filter and cuagulate, S. A. It does the ≈øame thing as the former.

of Vinegar, which if you plea≈øe you may take by it ≈øelf: then continues the di≈øtillation longer till only lb ≈øs. or thereabouts remains in the Retort, ≈øo will you have a ≈øtronger Spirit.

But whereas our Author ≈øays it does the ≈øame thing as the former; we are not altogether of the ≈øame Opinion, becau≈øe the one is an E≈ø≈øential, and Acid Salt, the other is a fixt, elemental and alcalious Salt; ≈øo that, ≈øo much as an Acid and an Alcalie differ one from another; ≈øo much do the≈øe two Salts differ in their Natures, Qualities, Properties and Operations.

¬ß 4. 'Tis true, that both are openers and di≈ø≈øolvers in their kind, but it is, when they meet with proper Bodies or Subjects to work upon: ≈øo the E≈ø≈øential and Acid Salt will di≈ø≈øolve te≈øtaceous and fixt alcalious Bodies, as Pearl, Crabs Eyes Crabs Claws, &c. and the like ≈øub≈øtances in Man's Body: and the fixt alcalious Salt, will di≈ø≈øolve other acid Bodies, if in quantity it is able to over power them.

¬ß 5. The former are good for ≈øuch as are Ah≈øtmatick, and have Tertian and Quartan Agues: the latter for ≈øuch as have the Stone in Reins or Bladder, or the Gout, or other Di≈øea≈øes proceeding from an acid and vi≈øcous Tartar, &c.

div.head: XXI. Sal Alcali, Sweet or Alcalious Salt.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Quicklime lb j. A≈øhes of Wood lb ≈øs. Tartar, Nitre, A. ‚Ñ•j. boil in Water, filter, and coagulate to dryne≈øs.

¬ß 4. All Alcalies powerfully attenuate, open, re≈øolve, melt Humors, and efferve≈øce with Acids, not only to attemperate them, but al≈øo totally to de≈øtroy them; from whence they conduce to the cure of almo≈øt infinite Di≈øea≈øes, viz. of all ≈øuch, as proceed from and are generated of an Acid ferment, as flegmatick Di≈øea≈øes, Scurvy, Epilep≈øia, &c. ¬ß 5. But all the≈øe things are properly ≈øpoken only of Marggrave's Sal Alcali, not of Schroders, which is the Text of our Author: the u≈øe of which Schroder ≈øaith, is only Chymical, and ≈øerves to ≈øeparate Gold from Copper, if it be ca≈øt on when it runs: as al≈øo, to make Silver run ea≈øie and melt.

But there is another kind of Salt of Alum, which is cry≈øtalline, and according to Charras is thus made. ‚Ñû Burnt Alum, or the Caput Mort. now mentioned, put it into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit in a Sand-heat, and affu≈øe thereon as much good Vinegar, as is requi≈øite to di≈ø≈øolve it, filter the di≈ø≈øolution, and evaporate in the ≈øame heat, till a Cuticle covers it, then let it cool and ≈øet to cry≈øtallize, which Cry≈øtals dry and keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 3. The≈øe are given upon occa≈øion, in ≈øome proper purging Liquor, √† gr. xij. ad xx. or xxiv. twice a Week for the Cure of Tertian Agues, a little before the Fit. Schroder ≈øays they move Sweat,

div.head: XXIII. Sal-Armoniacum fixatum, Fixed Sal-Armoniack.
div.p: Bate.] Mix Sal-Armoniack with half the quantity of Quicklime, and giving a mo≈øt ≈øtrong fire, with the help of Bellows melt it, which afterwards wa≈øh with water, S. A. Its chief u≈øe is for making a Liquor of it: it is Sudorifick, re≈øi≈øts Putrefaction, and opens Ob≈øtructions. Do≈øe, gr. v. ad x. &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Charras makes it thus. ‚Ñû Sal-Arm. Quicklime, Ana. mix them, put them into a Crucible upon the Iron ≈øquare in the mid≈øt of a Wind Fornace, where it may be at length forced into fu≈øion: then it is taken and di≈ø≈øolved in Water, after which it is filtered and coagulated: ≈øo have you fixt Sal-Armon. this being put on a Gla≈øs Plate in a cool moi≈øt Cellar di≈ø≈øolve by little and little into a Liquor, fit to di≈ø≈øolve Gold or Silver.

¬ß 2. It is the nature of two Volatiles to fix one another; and thus the Volatile Salt of the Quicklime ha≈øtily joyning with the Volatile Salt of the Sal Armon. and in the Calcination and Fu≈øion, invading one anothers Properties fix one another, tho' in the doing this, before the intimate Mixtion can be made, ≈øome part of the Volatile Salts mu≈øt be lo≈øt.

But Lemery has an other kind of fixt Sal Armon. which he makes after this manner. ‚Ñû Sal-Armoniack, Salt of Tartar, Ana. ‚Ñ•viij. both being in pouder, mix them and immediately put them into a Gla≈øs body, and ≈øprinkle it with ‚Ñ•iij. of Rain-water fix on it a Head and Receiver, luting well the Junctures with a wet Bladder: di≈øtil in Sand, fir≈øt with a gentle fire, to warm the Ve≈ø≈øel gradatim, and to di≈øtil the Spirit drop by drop: when no more will come over; take away the Receiver, ≈øtop up the neck, and increa≈øe the Fire to the third degree, for the ≈øpace of about two hours, ≈øo the white Volatile Sal Armoniack will ≈øublime, which will ≈øtick about the bottom of the head like Meal: and at the bottom of the Cucurbit a good quantity of white fixt Salt.

This Febrifugous Salt is nothing but a mixture of Salt of Tartar, with the Acid part of the Sal-Armon. which makes it to work much by Urine, but ≈øeldom Sweat, becau≈øe that being fixed it penetrates more ea≈øily than rarifies, for which rea≈øon it opens Ob≈øtructions, which are the rooted or original Cau≈øes of all Fevers.

¬ß 8. In performing this Operation, you might u≈øe in≈øtead of the Salt of Tartar, the fixt Salt of Nitre, Salt of Pot-A≈øhes, or any other Alcali that you plea≈øe: the Volatile Salt does proceed from ≈øome part of the Sal Armon. which the Salt of Tartar had not ≈øufficiently opened and ≈øeiz'd upon: this when the Fire begins to heat the Matter ri≈øes up into the head, in a delicate Cry≈øtalline form, but the moi≈øt Vapors coming upon it, di≈ø≈øolves it into Spirit, but the moi≈øture being ≈øpent, what Salt afterwards ari≈øes keeps in a dry form.

¬ß 9. This Spirit then is a di≈ø≈øolution of the Volatile Salt in Water; in which if there be not Flegm or Water enough, the Volatile Salt will lie at bottom undi≈ø≈øolv'd; this may all be turned into Spirit, by only adding more Water; thus the Pores of the Water are filled with the Volatile Salt: but if there be more Water than the Volatile parts require, the Spirit is then weak, and mu≈øt be given in a larger Do≈øe.

¬ß 10. If equal quantities of this Spirit and Spirit of Wine be mixt together, there will be a Coagulum, as thick as Butter, which may be cut with a Knife; this proceeds from the Sulphurous part of the S. V. which uniting with the Saline parts of the Sal-Armon. they filling the Ramous parts of the ≈øaid Sulphur of the Wine, immediately fix it, and ≈øtop their Motion, from whence proceeds their Coagulation: to which 'tis po≈ø≈øible that the Acid in the S. div.head: XXIV. Sal Armoniacum Volatile, i. e. Febrifugum Salis, Volatile Sal-Armoniack, or Febrifuge of Salt.
div.p:
Bate.] It is made of Sal Armoniack and Salt of Tartar, Ana. by ≈øubliming, S. A. It may be al≈øo ≈øublimed (by the order of the Phy≈øician,) with a third part of Ca≈øtor, or Amber. It takes away the Crudities of the Ventricle. Do≈øe‚ñ™ √† gr. iij. ad x. It is a S ‚Ä¢
dorifick, and a Specifick in the Gout.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This Preparation is nothing but the ≈øame with Lemery's in the la≈øt Section; by which it appears that both a fixt and a volatile Sal-Armoniack may be made by one and the ≈øame Operation; that is the Volatile, which after the Mixtion of this Quicklime or Salt of Tartar a≈øcends and ≈øticks to the head: and that is the fixt Salt which after the Di≈øtillation and Sublimation is ended, remains at bottom of the Cucurbit, having had a reverberatory or melting Heat.

¬ß 2. How to make it with Quicklime, we have ≈øhewed from the ≈øame Lemery, in Chap. II. Sect. XXIV. ¬ß 14. and 18. of this Book aforegoing, ≈øo that it is needle≈øs here to repeat it again: but this is ob≈øervable, that out of ‚Ñ•viij. of Sal-Armon. and ‚Ñ•24. of Quicklime with the addition of ‚Ñ•iv. of Water, you will have of Spirit ‚Ñ•v. í vj. and the Caput Mort. in the bottom will be thirty Ounces; ≈øo that abating the ‚Ñ•xxiv. of Quicklime, you will have ju≈øt ‚Ñ•vj. of fixt Salt.
¬ß 3. This fixt Salt is to be gotten out of the Caput Mortuum by elixiviation in Water, filteration, and evaporation to dryne≈øs, &c. according to the u≈øual Method.

¬ß 4. In Sect. more powerfully work than the Sub≈øtances purely and meerly natural; this Vitriol has more efficacy, and acts with much more quickne≈øs than the apperitive Crocus, in all the Di≈øea≈øes it is applicable to, but the Do≈øe is much le≈øs, beginning with gr. 3. and ≈øo increa≈øing gradually till you come to gr. 10. or 20. either in ≈øome Bolus, Wine or Broth.

¬ß 13. But here is one Note worthy of Ob≈øervation, the Remedies extracted from Mars mu≈øt be long continued and taken, increa≈øing their Do≈øe a Grain, or more every day, till it begins to cau≈øe a nau≈øeou≈øne≈øs in the Stomach, and then to dimini≈øh it to what the Stomach can well receive, and ≈øo continuing it; for that it appears, Nature then is bringing forth its de≈øired effects, without any force or violence.

¬ß 14. You ought al≈øo to ob≈øerve that ≈øuch as u≈øe Steel Remedies ≈øhould be purged every fourth or fifth day, in ca≈øe it does not ≈øo provoke Nature as is de≈øired; and every other day, the Bowels ought to be opened by a ≈øolutive Cly≈øter, or a Cly≈øter made of new Urine.

¬ß 15. Wherefore every fourth or fifth day take this gentle Purge. ‚Ñû Veal or Chicken Broth ‚Ñ•viij. vitriolated Tartar ‚Ñàj. choice Sena í ij. infu≈øe twelve hours, ≈øtrain, and give it for a Do≈øe. This carries off, and expels out of the Body, tho≈øe Recrements which this great Remedy has made fit for Evacuation.

¬ß 16. Le Febure's Salt of Mars, which Schroder and others call the ≈øweet Salt of Mars. ‚Ñû Filings lb ≈øs. put them into a Stone Di≈øh or Pan, ≈øprinkle them with good Spirit of Vinegar, till they become a Pa≈øte, which gently dry: grind it on a Marble, and moi≈øten in like manner again with the ≈øame Spirit; then dry again, grind and moi≈øten again, which work ≈øo often repeat till you di≈øcern by the Ta≈øte the Ma≈øs to be of a ≈øweeti≈øh ≈øavour or relli≈øh: then put this Pouder into a Cucurbit, and affu≈øe thereon Flegm of Vinegar, ≈øo much as may overtop it ≈øix Inches; cau≈øe the Liquor to boil, ≈øo will it extract the Salt, always ob≈øerving to put in new Flegm of Vinegar, as you ≈øee the other evaporates away: the Men≈øt being ≈øufficiently impregnated decant it, and being cold filterate it, and in B. M. ab≈øtract two or three parts, and in a cool place, ≈øet it to ≈øhoot into Cry≈øtals: ≈øeparate the ≈øupernating Liquor, evaporate again
and cry≈øtallize, which work ≈øo often repeat till it will yield no more: then dry them, and put them into a circulary Ve≈ø≈øel, affu≈øing thereon Alcohol of S. V. ≈øo much as may overtop them three Inches: lute it clo≈øe up, and digest in B. V. with a very gentle heat for ≈øeven days: then unlute the Ve≈ø≈øel and ab≈øtract the S. V. and at bottom you will have a very pure and plea≈øant Salt of Mars.

¬ß 17. It is famous in opening and removing of Ob≈øtructions, chiefly in weak and tender Bodies; and is good generally, again≈øt all Melancholick Affections, and Di≈øea≈øes of the Reins and Bladder; but is particularly a Specifick for the Cure of Drop≈øies, opens Ob≈øtructions of the Womb, and cure Fits of the Mother. Do≈øe, √† gr. iv, ad 20. in Broth, Decoction, or Wine.

¬ß 18. Beguinus makes his Vitriol of Mars, with Oil of Vitriol or Sulphur, putting to ‚Ñ•j. of the unrectified Oil, ‚Ñ•ij. of Water, which he puts upon ‚Ñ•j. of Filings, and then performs the Operation in all re≈øpects as at Sect. XI. aforegoing.

¬ß 19. Others make the Vitriol thus. ‚Ñû Filings lb j. put them into a large Matra≈øs; and affu≈øe thereon of the best corro≈øive Oil of Vitriol lb iij. mixt with Rain-water lb9. putting on the Liquor by degrees: digest in a Sand-heat for two or three days, in which time most of the Filings will be di≈ø≈øolved (which would not be without the addition of the Water, which hinders the Oil of Vitriol from being ≈øuckt up, and congealed by the Filings of the Steel;) and the di≈ø≈øolution will be green, then filter, and cry≈øtallize as before directed.

¬ß 20. With this Vitriol Artificial Mineral Waters may be made, either ≈øtrong or weak, according to the Intention of the Phy≈øician: but for the mo≈øt part í j. of this Vitriol ≈øerves for two Quarts of Water.

¬ß 21. Some in making the Salt of Mars at Sect XVI. above, repeat the Operation of moi≈øtening the Filings with Spirit of Vinegar, drying and grinding, at least a dozen times, the better to open the Body of the Steel, and then if the Filings were at first but lb ≈øs. (putting them into a Gourd in B. M.) they affu≈øe thereon lb xij. of di≈øtilled Vinegar, and continue it in the heat till a third part of the Men≈øtruum is con≈øumed; then being cold, they decant the Solution, and
affu≈øe new Men≈øtruum to the Steel, &c. repeating this Operation thrice: mix the Solutions, filter, evaporate, and cry≈øtallize, &c.

¬ß 22. This Salt has a great u≈øe in Phy≈øick, for the Acids with which it is prepared, carry it into the mo≈øt remote and difficult places of the Body: and the Acids them≈øelves (which being alone might do mi≈øchief) being as it were fettered and corrected by the Alcali of the Steel or Iron, act not with their wonted or natural Violence.

¬ß 23. Thibaut makes his Salt or Vitriol of Mars thus. ‚Ñû Of the opening Crocus in fine Pouder lb vj. put it into an Iron Kettle, and affu≈øe thereon fair Water lb xij boil, continually ≈øtirring it for two hours with an Iron Spatula, till the Water be half boiled away, then filter whilst warm, afterwards evaporate and cry≈øtallize, as before directed.

¬ß 24. The≈øe Cry≈øtals are of a tran≈øparent green colour, becau≈øe that Mars is made out of a Vitriolick Earth, as afore-hinted, which does contain nothing but pure Vitriol, which by the violence of the Fire is changed into a Metalick body, this being opened again by di≈ø≈øolvants re≈øumes its ancient colour.

¬ß 25. They ought to be kept in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt, becau≈øe the Air will ≈øoon change their colour, and cover them with a kind of white Meal, which will change their tran≈øparency and greenne≈øs.

¬ß 26. The≈øe Cry≈øtals of Mars are nothing but Particles of the Body of Mars, intimately joyned with an Acid Salt, and extracted out of the opening Calx of Mars, by the ≈øweete≈øt of all di≈ø≈øolvants, which is common Water, by boiling, and then evaporated and cry≈øtalliz'd.

¬ß 27. Charras makes two kinds of the Salt of Mars, the fir≈øt is exactly agreeable with that of Le Febure at Sect. XVI. above, ≈øo that no more need be ≈øaid of it here: his other is the ≈øame with that of Riverius at Sect. VI. aforegoing, with whom Lemery exactly agrees; but they differ from him, in the Proportions of the S. V. and Oil of Vitriol: for whereas Riverius doubles the Proportions of S. ¬ß 28. This Salt ≈øays Charras is much beyond that made with Spirit of Vinegar, and is a ≈øingular Example of the Change of the Liquid Forms of the Spirits of Wine and Vitriol into a ≈øolid, by the common Union with the Particles of Iron: and is given √† ‚Ñà≈øs. ad í ≈øs. as one of the be≈øt Remedies which can be drawn from Mars, and which may be truly called the Soul of that mixt.

¬ß 29. In making this Salt a Frying-pan (which ought to be new) is mo≈øt proper becau≈øe of its flatne≈øs: and if you u≈øe ‚Ñ•iv. of S. V. and ‚Ñ•iv. of Oil of Vitriol, you will have ‚Ñ•x. of the Salt of Mars: which proportion Experience has convinced us of, is more agreeable with Rea≈øon, than that of Riverius.

¬ß 30. This Salt al≈øo is more agreeable with the Stomach, than that made with Vinegar, and is indeed more ≈øubtil and efficacious, for that nothing but the more ≈øoluble parts of the Iron, incorporates with the Men≈øtruum, to make a Salt of: It is al≈øo preferrable before the Vitriol of Mars made with the Oils of Vitriol or Sulphur: and if it be put into a cold moi≈øt place, upon a Plate of Gla≈øs, it will melt per Deliquium, which is Liquor vel Liquamen Martis, by ≈øome (but improperly) called Oil of Mars.
¬ß 31. Charras makes his Vitriolum Martis exactly according to Le Febure, ≈øo al≈øo does Lemery, but with limited proportions of the Ingredients thus:

¬ß 32. ‚Ñû Clean filings of Iron lb j. put them into a large Matra≈øs, and affu≈øe theron fair warm Water lb iv. and of good Oil or Spirit of Vitriol lb ij. ≈øtir them mell together, and ≈øet the Matra≈øs in a gentle Sand-heat, and dige≈øt twenty four hours, in which time the pure≈øt part of the Mars will be di≈ø≈øolved, decant the clear Liquor, ca≈øting away the Earthy parts which remain at bottom; filterate and evaporate in a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, to a Pellicle, over a Sand-heat, then ≈øet it in a cool place to cry≈øtallize, ≈øo will you have green Cry≈øtals: decant the Liquor, evaporate again to a Pellicle, and cry≈øtallize as before, which work repeat till you have got all the Cry≈øtals, then dry them, and keep them in a Bottle clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 33. Where note, That if Water ≈øhould not be added, there would want moi≈øture to ≈øeparate the pure parts of the Mars from the
Impure, ≈øo that the Oil of Vitriol would not be able to di≈ø≈øolve the Mars, but only to incorporate with it: now in the di≈ø≈øolution of the Liquor it heats and boils con≈øiderably, becau≈øe the Acidity of the Vitriol does violently penetrate the body of the Mars, making a ≈øeparation of its parts.

¬ß 34. This Vitriol being calcin'd in a Crucible in an open fire, till it is reduced to a very fine red Pouder, makes a very beautiful Crocus Martis which is properly that part of the Steel which the Spirit of Vitriol has di≈ø≈øolved: this Lemery will have to be u≈øed like an Aperitive Crocus.

¬ß 35. This Vitriol of Mars, may al≈øo be di≈øtilled by a Retort in the ≈øame manner as ordinary Vitriol; and the Spirit drawn from it, is ≈øaid to have the ≈øame Vertues with ordinary Spirit of Vitriol (but ≈øome que≈øtion, whether full out ≈øo ≈øtrong) and may be made u≈øe of for the di≈ø≈øolution of Iron; after which you have the Caput Mortuum at bottom, which is the true Crocus Martis.

div.head: XXVII. Sal Coralliorum, Salt of Coral.
div.p: Bate.] It is drawn forth from the A≈øhes after the common manner: Or thus. Di≈ø≈øolve Coral in Spirit of Vinegar filter and exhale S. A. Do≈øe, √† í ≈øs. ad í j.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Calx or A≈øhes is made by a gentle reverberating Fire, with a heat of the ≈øecond degree (according to Quercetan) le≈øt by the force of a violent fire the Tincture or Colour ≈øhould exhale: but if you would have the Salt of Coral, you mu≈øt calcine it with a ≈øtrong reverberatory Fire to A≈øhes (which is done in about three days time) then after the u≈øual way you mu≈øt make a Lixivium, and from thence a Salt.

¬ß 2. Or thus, ‚Ñû Coral, calcine it two days in a Potter's Fornace till white; then di≈ø≈øolve it in Spirit of Vinegar, by dige≈øtion in a gentle Sand-heat for eight days, ≈øo will you have a red Solution, ab≈øtract the Men≈øtruum with a gentle fire to dryne≈øs; di≈ø≈øolve this Salt often in May Dew, filtring and coagulating, which keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 3. Reduce Coral into an impalpable Pouter by grinding upon a Porphyry Stone, put it into a Gla≈øs Matra≈øs, and affu≈øe thereon Spirit of Vinegar, ≈øo much as to overtop it four Inches, ≈øo will there be a great Efferve≈øcency, which being over, dige≈øt in a gentle Sand-heat for two or three days, often ≈øhaking the Matra≈øs, leave the Coral to ≈øettle at bottom and decant the clear Liquor; pouring on ≈øo much more Spirit of Vinegar on the remainder, dige≈øting as before, and decanting; this work continue till all the Coral is in a manner di≈ø≈øolved: then the Di≈ø≈øolutions being mixed together, put them into a Gla≈øs Cucurbit, and in a Sand-heat evaporate all the Moi≈øture, ≈øo will a Salt of Coral remain at bottom, which keep in a Vial clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 4. This is the way by which Crollius, Beguinus, Schroder, Rolfincius, Lemery, and mo≈øt others make this Salt, but it may be made with other Men≈øtruums, as Schroder witne≈ø≈øes, with Spirits of Vitriol, or Sulphur, or Salt, or by the Spirit of Guajacum, which then it is ≈øaid to purge the Blood excellently in the French-Pox, as al≈øo with the Juices of Limons, Citrons, and Barberries. But Thibaut makes it with Spirit of Sulphur, as before we have taught with Spirit of Vinegar.

¬ß 5. It is Cordial, revives and chears the Spirits, ≈øtrengthens Nature, re≈øtores in Con≈øumptions, and takes away the Preternatural heat of Fevers and Hecticks; it is given al≈øo to quench thir≈øt with ≈øucce≈øs, and to open Ob≈øtructions, which it does by virtue of the conjoyned Acid Salt: it purifies the Ma≈øs of Blood, and expels Melancholy.

div.head: XXVIII. Sal Margaritarum, Salt of Pearls.
div.p: Bate.] It is to be prepared as Salt of Coral.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It is made exactly as the Salt of Coral; but Pearls heed no poudering, for they di≈ø≈øolve whole, by meer dige≈øtion in di≈øtilled Vinegar: it is made al≈øo with Juice of Limons, and with all the other things with which Salt of Coral may be made.

¬ß 2. It is al≈øo made with Juice of Citrons thus. ‚Ñû Pearls brui≈øe them, and affu≈øe thereon Juice of Citrons purified by dige≈øtion, ≈øo much as may overtop them four Inches: dige≈øt till they are di≈ø≈øolved: then
add di≈øtilled May Dew, or Bawm water, and decant the Solution: add fre≈øh Juice of Citrons depurated, dige≈øt, and add more di≈øtilled May Dew, or Bawm-water, and decant; this work repeat till the Pearl are nearly all di≈ø≈øolved, a few Feces only remaining; joyn the Solutions, and in≈øpi≈ø≈øate with a gentle fire, to dryne≈øs.

¬ß 3. But Crollius ≈øeems mo≈øt to approve of its Preparation with Spirit of Vinegar, which Hartman a≈ø≈øents to, as being a proper Men≈øtruum, and herein ≈øays he, (Crollius) is not be≈øides the Mark; yet the u≈øe of other Juices for this purpo≈øe is not to be contemned.

¬ß 4. When the Evaporation is made, in Salt of both Pearl and Coral, &c. the flegmy or watery parts only go forth, the Acids ≈øtay behind, being joyned to the Particles of the Coral or Pearl, and ≈øo make a kind of Salt.

¬ß 5. This Salt, ≈øhould it be put into a Retort and di≈øtilled in Sand, would only yield a kind of ≈øtyptick Liquor, without any con≈øiderable Acidity, which plainly enough demon≈øtrates, that the Acids are in a great mea≈øure de≈øtroyed, and come not forth of the Alcali with that Strength, Life, and Form or Figure, with which they went in.

¬ß 6. We will give you the Vertues of this Salt of Pearls from Crollius. It is (≈øays he) a mo≈øt noble Cordial, not much inferior to Aurum Potabile, in Temperature and Operation; as in helping Contractures, Re≈øolution of the Nerves, Convul≈øions, Phren≈øies: it keeps the Body ≈øound; and if hurt re≈øtores it to its pri≈øtin ≈øtate of Health, amends Womens Milk, and corrects and increa≈øes the Seed of either Sex.

¬ß 7. It comforts the Brain, Memory and Heart; is a Prophylactick again≈øt the Vertigo and Apoplexy; drying up and con≈øuming all the depraved Humors in the Body from whence all kinds of Gout and Fevers are wont to proceed; it is good again≈øt a Con≈øumption, and the withredne≈øs of Age, renewing, increa≈øing and confirming the radical Humidity, by which it pre≈øerves from extream debility in Age.

¬ß 8. It is admirable again≈øt the Stone, and pre≈øerves from the Gout, if daily taken for ≈øome time: it pre≈øerves from the Pal≈øie, taken in Wine;
and is a Confortative in the Drop≈øie, Univer≈øals being premi≈øed: it alleviates the Venereal Evil; and is a ≈øingular Medicament again≈øt the Epilep≈øie, being taken Morning and Evening for ≈øix Weeks together.

¬ß 9. It ≈øtrengthens the Child in the Womb; is good again≈øt Trembling and Palpitation of the Heart, and Swoonings; being given in Cinnamon-water: it fortifies the Vital principal, and the Internal nature through the whole Body. Do≈øe, √† í ≈øs. ad í j. If it will do the half of all this, it is a wonderful Medicine.

¬ß 10. But Paracel≈øus attributes great Vertues to the Salt of Pearl, and ≈øome other of its Preparations: and (≈øays he) tho' the Proce≈øs be ≈øimple yet believe my Experience, for Pearls have a wonderful Operation, not from Art but Nature: The Vertue lodged in the gro≈øs Sub≈øtance, cannot work but like a dead Body; but Re≈øolution being made the Body is revived, and they become an excellent Cordial, re≈øi≈øting Poy≈øon, Putrefaction and the Pe≈øtilence, chear the Spirits and ≈øtrengthen the Bal≈øam of Life, ≈øo that the greate≈øt Agonies are removed thereby.

div.head: XXIX. Sal Oculorum Cancri; Salt of Crabs Eyes.
div.p: Bate.] It is made and prepared as Salts of Corals and Pearls.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. As to the Proce≈øs of making the Salt nothing more need be ≈øaid than what has been ≈øaid in tho≈øe of Coral and Pearl.

div.head: XXX. Sal Corte Cervi Succinatum, Ambred Salt of Harts-horn.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is an odd Medicament, and to be found in very few Authors (except in Hippocrates and Galen, as they found out in

C. Succinatum, Cinamomi≈øatum, Citratum, &c.

¬ß 3. It is made, ≈øays he, of the≈øe three things, viz. of the Spirit of Harts-horn, of the Volatile Salt of Harts-horn, and of the Volatile Salt of Amber, mixt together, dige≈øted and di≈øtilled.

¬ß 4. It is a mo≈øt famous thing again≈øt the Falling-≈øickne≈øs in Infants and Children, as al≈øo in Catarrhs, and all Rheumatick Di≈øea≈øes, Defluxions from the Head upon the ∆≤vula and Ton≈øils, particularly in a Coryza, which is a Defluxion of ≈øharp, ≈øalt, and thickened Humors into the Mouth, Lungs and No≈øtrils, from the Entricles of the Brain, as ≈øome think by the Nerves of Smelling.

¬ß 5. Now this Volatile Salt may be made either in a liquid or in a ≈øolid and dry form: in a liquid form, you may follow the Pre≈øcript of Etmuller aforegoing: but if in a ≈øolid form, then you may make it, after the Text of our Author: or according to this following Pre≈øcript: ‚Ñû Pure Volatile Salt of Harts-horn, Volatile Salt of Amber, Ana. mix them together, put them into a Gla≈øs Matra≈øs or Ve≈øica, affixing thereon a blind Head and Sublime, S. To conclude this Section, we will here give you Tillingius his Antepilepticum Cervinum, which you may find in his Prodomos Chym. pag. 508. ‚Ñû The ≈øimple Pouder made of young Harts-horns (i. e. ex Typhis) ‚Ñ•vj. Chymical Oils of Coriander, Marjoram, and Lavender, A. í j. mix and make a Pouder for the Falling-≈øickne≈øs, which keep in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt with Cork waxed over. Do≈øe, √† ‚Ñàj. ad í ij.

div.head: XXXI. Sal Decripitatum, Decripitated or calcin'd Salt.
div.p: Bate.] It is made by calcining it in a covered Crucible, till the Salt has done crackling.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Some advi≈øe to put the Salt into an Earthen-Pot covering it, and then to put fire round about it (called Ignis rotae) that it may be red fire hot, ≈øo will the Salt crackle, and be reduced to pouder: then to continue the fire till the noi≈øe cea≈øes.

¬ß 2. Lemery heats an unglaz'd Pot or Crucible red hot, and puts into it a Spoonful or two of Sea-≈øalt, and then covers the Ve≈ø≈øel, till the crackling is over, and the Salt falls into Pouder; which done he puts in more Salt, and continues the ≈øame Operation as long as need requires: the noi≈øe being over, and the P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ taken out of the Fire and cool ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚ñ™
‚Ä¢ e takes the Salt and keeps it in a Gla≈øs bottle clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe that the Air may not enter in to moi≈øten it a new.

¬ß 3. The rea≈øon of the crackling in the Fire is an inward Humidity, which being rarified by the heat of fire, and finding the Pores of the Salt very clo≈øe ≈øhut up, it breaks through them with a kind of Impetuo≈øity and Violence, and ≈øo cau≈øes that crackling noi≈øe.

¬ß 5. Its Mechanical u≈øe is for Refiners, who Regalize their Aqua fortis therewith, to make it able to di≈ø≈øolve Gold, thus, ‚Ñû Of this Salt decripitated lb j. put it into a Retort and affu≈øe thereon good A. F. or Spirit of Nitre lb ij. then draw off the Spirit in a Sand-heat, and keep it for u≈øe: But ≈øome only di≈ø≈øolve the Salt in the A. F. &c. without di≈øtillation, which they e≈øteem the ≈øtronger Preparation.

¬ß 6. Here is to be noted, that when you have occa≈øion to make u≈øe of decripitated Salt, it will be be≈øt to u≈øe that which is newly done,
