div.head: XXXII. Sal Diureticum, A Diuretick Salt‚ñ™ Or Sale provoking Urine.
div.p: Bate.] Di≈ø≈øolve the Caput Mortuum of Volatile Sal Armoniack in fair warm Water; filter and coagulate, S.A. It is profitable in intermitting Fevers. Do≈øe, í ≈øs. ad í ≈øs. and prevails very much again≈øt the Jaundice, Scurvy, Drop≈øie, and all kinds of Ob≈øtructions.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Caput Mortuum here mentioned and intended, is that which is left from that Volatile Sal Armoniack which is made of equal parts of Sal Armoniack and Salt of Tartar.

¬ß 2. Its chief u≈øe is in Ob≈øtructions of the Reins, Ureters and Bladder, and to expel Sand, Gravel, or any Tartarous matter filling tho≈øe parts: it is good al≈øo to open Ob≈øtructions of the other Vi≈øcera, and is profitable, again≈øt Cachexies, Drop≈øies, Yellow Jaundice, Scurvy, Gout, and Rheumatick Di≈øtempers.

¬ß 3. Outwardly u≈øed, being di≈ø≈øolved in Water, and any part pained with the Gout, being wa≈øhed with it, and Cloths wet in the ≈øame being applied, it gives immediate Relief: but the Wa≈øh ought to be u≈øed as hot as conveniently it can be endured, and to be continued for a quarter of an hour at lea≈øt, and that twice a day.

¬ß 4. But in this ca≈øe, before the external u≈øe of it, it will be nece≈ø≈øary to purge and clean≈øe the Body very well by Univer≈øals, that as much as may be, the morbifick Cau≈øe of the Di≈øea≈øe may be mo≈øtly carried off, le≈øt by repercu≈ø≈øion the Humour ≈øhould a≈øcend upwards, and cau≈øe Stomach and Heart-≈øickne≈øs.

div.head: XXXIII. Sal Febrifugum, The febrifuge Salt, or Salt again≈øt Fevers.
div.p: Bate.] It is drawn forth out of Oi≈øter-≈øhells, being fir≈øt made very clean, and then calcin'd to whitene≈øs; by di≈ø≈øolving in Water, filtering, and coagulating, S. A. Do≈øe, ad í j. before the coming of the Fit.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Some take the lower Shell only; and of that, the limy white part; whil≈øt others take the Oriential part only, which look like or re≈øemble, Oriental Pearl: Others make choice of the upper Shell and reject the Nether, and of them chu≈øe ≈øuch, as (being made very clean) are mo≈øt Oriental, and in a manner tran≈øparent.

¬ß 2. But if I may deliver my Opinion, the Matter of both Shells (being fir≈øt purely clean≈øed) may do, and the whole Sub≈øtance of them both, but if a Choice is to be made, this is certain, that the upper Shell and that part which is mo≈øt Oriental, and mo≈øt re≈øembles Oriental Pearl, is that which ought chiefly to be taken for this work.

¬ß 3. The Calcination ought to be very gentle, and not with a violent fire, becau≈øe of a Volatile Salt which they contain, which tho' it is volatile, is not ≈øo volatile as to be made to flye with a ≈ømall heat, yet will in no wi≈øe ≈øu≈øtain an inten≈øe ≈øtrong heat, or a fire of long reverberation.

¬ß 4. The gentler the Calcinatory heat is, the greater quantity of Salt you will have; the greater the Heat, the le≈ø≈øer the quantity of Salt, for by that means the volatile being made totally to evani≈øh, you will only have the fixt Salt remaining, whereas otherwi≈øe, a con≈øiderable quantity of the Volatile will be joyned with the fixt, whereby a Salt of a middle nature being compo≈øed, the quantity will be proportionably augmented.
¬ß 5. This Salt is indeed a ≈øingular Antifebririck, being compo≈øed of a double Alcali, to wit a volatile and a fixt, both which ab≈øorb the Acid Humors, of which Fevers are mo≈øtly generated.

¬ß 6. And therefore this Salt has immediately an intimate mixtion with the Blood and other Juices; whereby, being carried all over the whole Humane; Frame, it certainly and pre≈øently performs that in a ≈ømall Do≈øe, which a Cart-load of ≈øome other Medicines would do nothing at all in. You may give it in the Juice of the le≈ø≈øer Centory. See our Doron. Medic. Lib. 2. Cap. 10. Sect. 16.

div.head: XXXIV. Sal Jovis, Salt of Jupiter or Tin.
div.p:
Bate.] It is made by di≈ø≈øolving the Magi≈øtery of Jupiter by dige≈øtion in Spirit of
Vinegar, filterating, and coagulating. It is a pre≈øent Remedy again≈øt the Suffocation of the Womb, or Fits of the Mother, which it helps after a miraculous manner, being both inwardly taken, and outwardly applied. Do≈øe, gr. 2, 3, 4, &c. repeating it.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Magi≈øtery of Tin ≈øome make thus. ‚Ñû Filings of pure Tin ‚Ñ•iij. Spirit of Nitre ‚Ñ•jx. put them into a Matra≈øs upon a Sand-heat; decant the Solution into a great glazed Earthen Pan, full of pure Water ‚Ä¢ which by its quantity may weaken the Spirit of Nitre, and make it for≈øake the Tin which it had di≈ø≈øolved, ≈øo will it precipitate to the bottom of a very white Pouder, which edulcorate by many Ablutions, and dry it between Papers in the Shade: 'Tis a very fair white, and is u≈øed for Pomatums for the Face.

¬ß 2. Lemery makes the Magi≈øtery thus. ‚Ñû Flowers of Tin, di≈ø≈øolve them in a ≈øufficient quantity of Water, filter, and precipitate, by dropping thereon drop by drop, Spirit of Sal Armoniack, or Oil of Tartar per Deliquium, ≈øo will you have a very white Magi≈øtery, which being edulcorated by many Ablutions in fair warm Water, becomes a mo≈øt admirable and delicate White which ≈øerves for a Fucus, being mixed with Pomatums, and of this our Author's Salt of Tin is made.

¬ß 3. Some make the Salt of Tin thus. ‚Ñû Flowers of Tin dryed, put them into a Matra≈øs, and affu≈øe thereon Spirit of Vinegar, ≈øo much as may overtop them í Inches: dige≈øt in a Sand-heat for three days, then decant the Solution by inclination: affu≈øe to the remainder new Spirit of Vinegar, q. ≈ø. dige≈øting and decanting as before, which work repeat with fre≈øh Spirit of Vinegar ≈øo often till all the Flowers are di≈ø≈øolved: mix all the Solutions, filter; and with a gentle heat evaporate to dryne≈øs ≈øo will you have remaining at bottom the Salt of Jupiter or Tin, which you mu≈øt free from the Acidity of the Vinegar by the help of S. V. thus.

¬ß 4. Put the Salt into a little Gla≈øs Gourd, pouring thereon good S. V. ≈øo much as to overtop it two Inches: fit an Alembick to the Gourd, and a little Receiver, and with a very gentle fire ab≈øtract the Spirit, which work repeat five or ≈øix times always with new or fre≈øh Spirit, ≈øo will the Spirit carry off with it, a great part of the Acid Salt of the Vinegar, and you will have
a Salt of Jupiter free from all Acrimony, and endued with very great Venues, which may be given √† gr. iij. ad vj. as Crollius and others, but ≈øome Authors ≈øay it may be given ad gr. 20.

¬ß 5. Crollius makes it thus. ‚Ñû A≈øhes of Tin, prepared in an open fire, without ≈øophi≈øtication from it, not with Water (as by vulgar De≈øcriptions is vainly taught) but with Spirit of Vinegar, extract a Salt, which afterwards by filtering, and with a mo≈øt gentle heat in B. M. ≈øeparate from the Salt, ≈øeven times edulcorate it with Rain water, which afterwards re≈øolve per Deliquium into a Liquor.

¬ß 6. This ≈øays he, is a Secret, and mo≈øt efficacious again≈øt the Suffocation of the Womb, the Navel being bathed therewith hot; as ≈øoon as the Matrix perceives the heat, it is pre≈øently ≈øettled in its own place, nor does it afterwards any more ea≈øily remove: and it may be given inwardly in Mugwort-water in the Morning fa≈øting for ≈øeveral days together, or in ≈øome other Hy≈øterick-water.

¬ß 7. This Liquor of the Salt of Tin is (≈øays Crollius) otherwi≈øe profitable for the French Di≈øea≈øe, all fetid Ulcers, Fi≈øtula's, Cancer, Wolf Noli me Tangere, and other grievous Di≈øea≈øes: it cures them given from one drop to two or three, at mo≈øt, the Do≈øe being repeated: in tho≈øe of ripe Age it vehemently and largely, moves the Belly.

¬ß 8. Beguinus di≈ø≈øolves Engli≈øh Tin in A. F. (made of Nitre and Alum) from which he has a Calx as white as Snow, this he ≈øublimes into Flowers as we have taught in the former Chapter, and from tho≈øe Flowers with Spirit of Wine Vinegar, by a total di≈ø≈øolution of the Matter he makes a Salt according to the Method in ¬ß 3 aforegoing, this Salt he di≈ø≈øolves in good Spirit of Wine, dige≈øts and decants, and affu≈øes fre≈øh Spirit, till the whole Salt is re≈øolved, then in B. M. he ab≈øtracts two thirds of the Spirit, and ≈øets it in a cool place to Cry≈øtallize, which being ≈øeparated from the Liquor, he puts them upon a Marble, and in a cold moi≈øt place re≈øolves them per Deliquium: And this is Crollius his Liquamen Jovis, which he ≈øays will cure malign Cancers, inwardly u≈øed, and outwardly applied, in the quantity of three drops, as at ¬ß 7. aforegoing.

¬ß 9. Etmuller makes a Cry≈øtalline Salt after this manner. ‚Ñû Mineral of Tin in fine Pouder lb j. affu≈øe thereon the be≈øt Spirit or Oil of Vitriol ≈øeven times rectified lb j. dige≈øt for ≈øome time in B. M. then affu≈øe thereon common Water lb ij. being well mixed together, whil≈øt hot filter, and ≈øet it to Cry≈øtallize: the Cry≈øtals edulcorate with Water, and reduce into Pouder.

¬ß 10. This, ≈øays he, is given √† gr. j. ad ij. again≈øt the Drop≈øie, Scurvy, and de≈øperate Fi≈øtula's, as al≈øo Uterine Affections: outwardly it is applied, being mixed with Honey of Ro≈øes: It purges or carries off the Water in Hydropick Per≈øons gently by Stool. This he had from Fr. Hofman out of whom we have ≈øupplied the Proportion of the Oil or Spirit of Vitriol, which is wanting in Et???mullor.

¬ß 11. Le Febure ≈øays its Salt and Magi≈øtery are made the ≈øame way as tho≈øe of Saturn, but in order to the well making of the Salt, the Calx of Jupiter mu≈øt be reverberated, taking it as it is already prepared for Potters to u≈øe: this reverberation mu≈øt be continued for at at lea≈øt two days, that its body may be ≈øufficiently opened, as is fitting, otherwi≈øe very little Salt will be obtained.

¬ß 12. The true Magi≈øtery and Salt ≈øays he, are ≈øpecifical Remedies, and ≈øingular again≈øt the Suffocation of the Womb, or Fits of the Mother, which are wonderfully allayed by it, whether inwardly admini≈øtred or outwardly applied: they are al≈øo admirable Topicks again≈øt putrid, ≈øtinking, hollow and fi≈øtulous Ulcers, as al≈øo again≈øt Wolfs, malign Cancers, and cancerous Ulcers.

¬ß 13. But after the u≈øe of the≈øe Remedies to Womenkind, you mu≈øt beware of purging them, le≈øt you irrerate the Womb, and be forced to begin your work again; for after it is once quieted and laid a≈øleep by the irradiating Vertue of Mineral Sulphurs (in which a potential and mighty Anodyn power is lodged) it is not prudent to di≈øturb it again by Emetick or Cathartick Medicaments, but rather Diaphoretick and Diuretick Clean≈øers are to be cho≈øen.

¬ß 14. Charras al≈øo in like manner makes it of the Lime, or reverberated Calx of the Metal, and ≈øo does Zwelfer; but that certainly
is be≈øt which is made of the Flores Joviales, as is taught at Sect. 3. above, and tho' Authors ≈øay, that Salt of Tin differs nothing in making from Salt of Lead, yet there are ≈øeveral difficulties in the making of the one, which are not in the making of the other.

¬ß 15. For 'tis impo≈ø≈øible to di≈ø≈øolve the Calx of Tin, tho' very well reverberated in Spirit of Vinegar, which neverthele≈øs di≈ø≈øolves the Calx of Lead ea≈øily enough; 'tis true, the mo≈øt Corro≈øive Aci ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , ≈øuch as A. F. Spirit of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e‚ñ™ Vitriol, &c. di≈ø≈øolve it; but in re≈øpect, that a great quantity of them is nece≈ø≈øary for a very ≈ømall proportion of Tin; the Remedies drawn from it by means of tho≈øe Corro≈øives mu≈øt needs be very injurious: but if you reduce Tin into Flowwers by Sublimation, then it will be ≈øo opened that the Spirit of Vinegar will ea≈øily penetrate and di≈ø≈øolve it.

¬ß 16. Lemery makes it thus. ‚Ñû Calx of Tin lb ij. put it into a Matra≈øs, on which affu≈øe Spirit of Vinegar, ≈øo much as to overtop it four Inches: dige≈øt three days, and decant the Solution, affu≈øing fre≈øh Spirit dige≈øting and decanting, and continuing this work till all or mo≈øt part of the Calx is di≈ø≈øolved: filter the Solution, and ab≈øtract in a Sand-heat three quarters of the Humidity, and ≈øet the remainder in a cool Cellar to cry≈øtallize, decant the Liquor from the Cry≈øtals, evaporate and cry≈øtallize again; which Operation continue till you have got all your Salt of Tin, which dry in the Sun, and keep clo≈øe ≈øtopt in a Vial: or otherwi≈øe, you may at once evaporate to dryne≈øs, and the Salt will remain at bottom, as good as the former.

¬ß 17. Where note, That if the Calx of Tin be not well calcin'd, and di≈øpo≈øe≈øt of ≈øome quantity of its Sulphur, the Acidity of the Vinegar will never be able to di≈ø≈øolve it, becau≈øe it would be pre≈øently dull'd, and all its Points broken, by the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
≈øi≈øting Sulphur, and ≈øo „Äà‚óä„Äâ out of a capacity of acting ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ be≈øides, that an Acid may be able to di≈ø≈øolve a Body it is requi≈øite that the Pores „Äà‚óä„Äâ that Body be fitly di≈øpo≈øed, and not ob≈øtructed or filled with any heterogeneous Matter, or clammy Sulphur, th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the Motion and Action „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Acid being pre≈øerv ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ for ≈øome time it may mak ‚Ä¢ its way perfectly through
