div.head: XXXV. Sal Lithargyrites, Salt of Litharge.
div.p: Bate.] It is drawn out of the Litharge with Spirit of Vinegar, after the ≈øame manner as in making a Saccharum Saturni; then the Solution is decanted, filtred, and coagulated, S. A. If the Solution is precipitated with Oil of Tartar per Deliquium, it is called the Magi≈øtery; It is given inwardly in Diarrhaea's Dy≈øenteries, and other Di≈øea≈øes proceeding from hurt of the Tone of the Parts and Weakne≈øs. The Bowels being hurt or ulcerated it heals and con≈øolidates them; and cools the fermenting or boiling Blood. Do≈øe, í ≈øs. with ≈øome Sudorifick Treacle or Anodyn.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. In our Doron Medicum, Lib. 2. Cap. 10. Sect. 1. we have given an ample De≈øcription of the whole Proce≈øs, with a Rationale upon the ≈øame, ≈øo that referring the Reader to that, no more need be ≈øaid of it here.

¬ß 2. But this is ob≈øervable, that if you de≈øign to Cry≈øtallize the Salt, it will be be≈øt done in a Tin Ve≈ø≈øel or Ba≈øon, becau≈øe Tin has in it a mighty coagulating Spirit, which cau≈øes all the Matter which you fit to ≈øhoot into Cry≈øtals in this Liquor, ≈øooner to a≈ø≈øume a Cry≈øtalline form, than it would do in another Ve≈ø≈øel, as tho≈øe who ≈øhall be plea≈øed to try the Experiments may find.

¬ß 3. Many Authors will have this Salt to be cold, becau≈øe ≈øay they, Lead is terre≈øtious, and of a cold Nature; al≈øo Vinegar an Ingredient in its Preparation is cold, and yet they attribute to it effects, which are only produceable by heat, and ≈øay a Spirit may be drawn from it, which is of an active, ≈øubtil, and penetrative Vertue, Sudorifick, and which drives away by Sweat the Malignity of Venene, Pe≈øtilential and Veneral Di≈øea≈øes, which Qualities and Effects are oppo≈øites in Nature.

¬ß 4. But Lead truly is a Metal which has much Sulphur or Fire in it, and is called Aurum Lepro≈øum, and tho' very unripe and earthy, yet is repleat with the two noble≈øts Metals, indivi≈øibly mixt in its original Chaos, or fir≈øt undige≈øted Matter, which communicates to it much Vertue.

¬ß 5. Moreover its internal Fire is excited and ≈øtirred up, by the activity of the external Fire, which concocts and dige≈øts all its immaturities or unripen≈øs, driving away its Imparities, exalting its more pure internal Sulphurs, and bringing to perfection the Seeds of that purity which lay hidden and dormant in it: all which things being con≈øidered makes me think, that this Salt is rather of a hot nature, and has ≈øome Specifick Vertues in it, not to be found in marry other Medicines.

¬ß 6. Some Authors ≈øay it is a good Remedy again≈øt all ≈øorts of Agues, whether continual or intermitting, and a Specifick in Di≈øea≈øes of the Spleen, as al≈øo Vapors ari≈øing from it; it is al≈øo given again≈øt Di≈øea≈øes of the Bre≈øt and Lungs, being di≈ø≈øolved in Scabious-water, and mixt with an equal quantity of purified Nitre, and then cry≈øtallized: tho≈øe Cry≈øtals are good again≈øt Coughs, Colds, A≈øthma's or Shortne≈øs of Breath, and Stoppages of the Bre≈øt and Lungs: and thereof you may give √† gr. iv. ad xxx. in proper Liquor.

¬ß 7. This ≈øweet Bal≈øamick Salt for Saturn, is no le≈øs excellent for external Di≈øea≈øes, for it obtunds or kills all corro≈øive, har≈øh and biting Salts or Humors which cau≈øe pain in Wounds, Ulcers and Fi≈øtula's, whereby the Grief and Inflamation of the part is excited, and from which flow all other Accidents.

¬ß 8. It re≈øolves and mollifies all hard and ≈øcirrhous Tumors, and ≈øome ≈øay it cures Cancers and cancerous Ulcers, de≈øtroying the malign Acrimony which feeds them: it takes away the lividity, and ill colour of Brui≈øes and Contu≈øions, and hinders extrava≈øated Blood from producing ill Accidents.

¬ß 9. It is an unequall'd Remedy again≈øt Itching, Inflamations, and other Di≈øea≈øes of the Eyes, being u≈øed as a Collyrium in Eyewaters, Salves, Liniments, Ointments and Bal≈øams, and ≈øo applied to the affect according as the prudent Phy≈øician ≈øhall direct.

div.head: XXXVI. Sal Martis Catharticus, Purging Salt of Mars.
div.p:
Bate.] Di≈ø≈øolve the Caput Mortuum of the Flowers of Sal Armoniack martiated in Warm-water; filter, and coagulate. Do≈øe, ad gr. xij.
it purges gently, and is diuretick.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. We will give you the whole Proce≈øs from Schroder.‚Ñû Sal Armoniack, Filings of Iron, Ana. grind them gently on a Marble, then put them into an Earthen Still, and ≈øublime them, fir≈øt with a gentle fire, then with a ≈øtronger, increa≈øing the fire by degrees: after which, let it cool, break the Ve≈ø≈øel, and keep the upper part which is white for a new Sublimation, with new filings of Iron: the middle yellow Flowers are diaphoretick Flowers of Mars: then take out the Caput Mortuum in the bottom, and with Water extract the Salt, which purifie by Solution and Coagulation, which keep in the Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 2. This Salt purges gently being given from half a Scruple, ad ‚Ñàj. in any proper Vehicle: Of thus, ‚Ñû Of this Salt í j. Gum Guajici in fine Pouder í ≈øs. ad í j. Syrup of Ro≈øes ≈øolutive ‚Ñ•j. mix for a Do≈øe: It purges Rheumati≈øms admirably, and po≈ø≈øibly beyond mo≈øt other things in the World.

¬ß 3. It is good again≈øt Tertians and Quartans, as al≈øo again≈øt the mo≈øt inveterate Rheumati≈øms (being u≈øed as la≈øt directed) and in particular again≈øt the Gout in any part of the Body: It opens Ob≈øtructions of the Reins and Womb, clean≈øes tho≈øe parts from their Feculencies, and is very effectual to remove a ≈øterile Di≈øpo≈øition in Women-kind, and cure the Green-≈øickne≈øs in Virgins. Kill Worms in Children, and re≈øtore them, if over-run with the Rickets.

¬ß 4. It is a Remedy al≈øo again≈øt the Cachexy, and opens Ob≈øtructions in the Liver, Spleen, Stomach, Pancreas, and Me≈øentery; but the u≈øe of it mu≈øt be continued for ≈øome time, as is u≈øual in other Remedies extracted from Mars; and the Do≈øe mu≈øt likewi≈øe be increa≈øed by little and little, as you find the Stomach can bear it; and it may be u≈øed where-ever there is occa≈øion for any aperitive Preparations of Mars.
Sal Perlarum, Salt of Pearls. See the Preparation in Sect. XVIII. of Sal Margaritarum aforegoing.

div.head: XXXVII. Sal Philo≈øophorum, The Philo≈øopher Salt, or Salt of the Wi≈øe.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Common Salt decripitated, Sal Gem. A. ‚Ñ•j≈øs. Galangal, Mace, Cubebs, A. ‚Ñ•≈øs. mix and make a pouder S. A. It facilitates the Concoction of the Stomach, and con≈øumes Crudities. Do≈øe, √† gr. iv. ad xij. in the Morning fa≈øting.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The way of decripitating of common Salt we have explicated at large in Sect. 31. aforegoing: the re≈øt of the Proce≈øs or Compo≈øition is ≈øo plain that it needs no farther Elucidation.

¬ß 2. Being given in a Gla≈øs of fair Water in a Morning fa≈øting, √† ‚Ñà≈øs. ad í ≈øs. or ‚Ñàij. or more, according to the Age of the Per≈øon, it kills Worms in them, and expels them: if it be given in a very large Do≈øe, it will be apt to cau≈øe Vomiting, but then it clean≈øes the Stomach admirably: otherwi≈øe given in a mean or moderate Do≈øe it only corroborates it, and cau≈øes Appetite.

¬ß 3 By u≈øing it for ≈øome time it is found to open Ob≈øtructions, ≈øtrengthen the Vi≈øcera, and provoke the Terms in Women: but this it more effectually does, if it be given with martial Aperitives, and other proper Emmenagogicks.

div.head: XXXVIII. Sal Polychre≈øtum, Salt of many Vertues.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of Nitre and Sulphur exactly mixt in an equal proportion, by detonation, ≈øolution in Water, filtration, and coagulation, S. A. It purges ≈øerous Humors by Stool, and ≈øometimes by Urine: Do≈øe, í j. ad í iij. di≈ø≈øolved in a quart of fair Water, that it may be made like a Mineral Spring-water.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû Fine or purified Nitre, Sulphur Ana. lb j. reduce them together into Pouder; then take a good ≈øtrong Earthen Pot with a flat bottom, and which is able to re≈øi≈øt the fire; ≈øet it in a Wind Fornace with Coals round about it, which kindle gradatim to pre≈øperve the Pot; when the Pot is red-hot, put in about ‚Ñ•ij. of the Mixture, and ≈øtir it: the Matter will flame, and the Volatile parts of the Nitre will exhale with part of the Sulphur: when the Flame cea≈øes, put in ‚Ñ•ij. more, ≈øtirring the ≈øame continually. This work repeat till all your
Mixture is ≈øpent, then calcine it, ≈øtirring it ≈øix hours more, during which, the Matter mu≈øt be always red-hot without melting, which would retain the Empyreuma of the Sulphur, and the Salt would be greyi≈øh; but with the≈øe cautions, your Salt will be of a Ro≈øe colour, without Smell, and of a bitteri≈øh Ta≈øte.

¬ß 2. Thus done, it may be u≈øed without any more preparation; but if you de≈øire it yet purer, di≈ø≈øolve it in a good quantity of warm Water, filter it, and evaporate gently, till it has a Pellicula upon it, then ≈øet it in a Cellar to ≈øhoot into Cry≈øtals, at the bottom and ≈øides of the Ve≈ø≈øel, who≈øe Figure will be cubical, much like that of common Salt.

¬ß 3. It is u≈øed chiefly again≈øt Ob≈øtructions of the Liver, Spleen, Pancreas, and Me≈øentery, di≈ø≈øolves the vi≈øcous Matter which afflicts them, and purges gently downwards, being given √† í ij. ad í vj. you may di≈ø≈øolve it over might in Spring-water and give it the next morning.

¬ß 4. But if the Sick are affected in their Nerves, or have an exceeding weakne≈øs of the Stomach, they ought wholly to ab≈øtain from all ≈øorts of the Preparations of Nitre, as Sal Prunellae, or Cry≈øtal Mineral, and this Sal Polychre≈øtum, which are not to be put into other Compo≈øitions but only to ≈øharpen them, temper their heat, and make them more penetrating, in which ca≈øes, their Do≈øes mu≈øt be much le≈øs: for Example ≈øake, to Sen ‚Ä¢
‚Ñ•ij. or iij. you may put of Cry≈øtal Mineral í ≈øs. or ‚Ñàij. and of this Sal Polychre≈øtum í j. or ‚Ñàiv.

¬ß 5. It is called Polychre≈øtum, from the Greek Word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
ad multa utilis, as being profitable again≈øt many Di≈øea≈øes; becau≈øe it not only cures many Di≈øtempers, but al≈øo operates to the ≈øame Intentions many ways, for that it purges by Stool and Urine too, and in ≈øome mea≈øure opens the Pores, cau≈øing after tho≈øe Operations a gentle Sweat.

¬ß 6. Being di≈ø≈øolved in any Men≈øtruum, it makes it the more powerful to extract the Verrues of any Cathartick, and to draw forth its Purgative force, as in the Example of Sena aforegoing. But whereas ≈øome give it to í vj. as afore≈øaid, to purge ≈øtrongly, I mu≈øt confe≈øs I never do it to ≈øo large a Do≈øe, by rea≈øon of the trouble it gives
the Stomach in palling thro' it; yet that ill Property is much abated if not taken away by mixing a good quantity of double refined Sugar with it, or giving it in a Vehicle well ≈øweetened with Sugar.

¬ß 7. It ought not to be u≈øed by any means till it is made very white by Solution, Filtration and Cry≈øtallization; for if any gro≈øs portion of Sulphur remains in it, it is apt to cau≈øe, nau≈øeou≈øne≈øs of the Stomach, Vertigo's, and ≈øtupefaction of the Nerves.

¬ß 8. From ‚Ñ•xvj. of fine Nitre, and as much good Sulphur, you will have at la≈øt but ‚Ñ•iij≈øi. of pure Sal Polychre≈øtum: whereas, if you u≈øe the common Nitre, in≈øtead of the purified, you will have ‚Ñ•v, of Salt as white as the other; which difference of weight proceeds from the common or unpurified Nitres having more fixt Salt, than the fine or purified Salt-Peter.

¬ß 9. Charras makes it exactly after the former manner, but in a large Crucible ≈øet upon a Trevet in a Wind Fornace, then at la≈øt continues the fire for two or three hours, and letting it cool, he di≈ø≈øolves in Water, filters, evaporates and cry≈øtallizes as afore≈øaid.

¬ß 10. The Di≈ø≈øipation of the Acid and Spirituous parts of the Nitre, during its calcination with the Sulphur, is the rea≈øon that the Cry≈øtals lo≈øe the Form, which tho≈øe of Nitre had before: not could you have it in Cry≈øtals, had not the fixt Salt retained ≈øome part of the Acid of the Sulphur, during its Calcination with it.
¬ß 11. Now becau≈øe this Salt contains only the fixt part of the Nitre, joyn'd with ≈øome part of the Acid of the Sulphur, it acts not, but like Salt of Tartar, or ≈øome other fixt Salt.

¬ß 12. And tho' it is ≈øometimes given √† í ij. ad í v. or vj. in a Quart or three Pints of Water, or in ≈øome Pri≈øan, to be drank at ≈øeveral draughts, as you drink Mineral waters, for the cutting and loo≈øening of gro≈øs Humors, afterwards to be expelled by the ordinary ways, yet in my Opinion, it is much better to be u≈øed‚ñ™ with proper Catharticks as is before hinted.

¬ß 13. If to lb j. of Sal Polychre≈øtum, you add Sal Armoniack ‚Ñ•iv. incorporating them, and cry≈øtallizing them together, you will have a Compo≈øitum
much more de≈øerving the Name of Polychre≈øtum than that of which we have all along been ≈øpeaking: for as the ≈øimple Sal Polychre≈øt. Works with much Acrimony, and not with any delectation to the Bowels; ≈øo the latter being by the reciprocal Mixtion dulcified, operates in every re≈øpect with much more gentlene≈øs; and more ea≈øily penetrates the parts of the Body, which require its help and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, e≈øpecially the Arteries, Veins and Urinary Ve≈ø≈øels, leaving no Impre≈ø≈øions of ≈øharpne≈øs in any place behind it.

¬ß 14. Lemery makes the ≈øimple Sal Polychre≈øtum in all re≈øpects as does Charras at ¬ß 9. aforegoing but calcines it afterwards for four or five hours; then pouring it forth into a Copper Ve≈ø≈øel, he afterwards pouders it, di≈ø≈øolves, filterates, and cry≈øtallizes as afore directed.

¬ß 15. If the Salt be not yet ≈øo white as it ≈øhould be, it is becau≈øe it retains ≈øome Particles of the Sulphur in it: therefore it ought to be calcin'd in a Crucible in a ≈øtrong fire, ≈øtirring it continually with a Spatula three or four hours until it becomes purely white, then repeating the di≈ø≈øolution in Water, filtration and evaporation, as afore≈øaid till it becomes exceeding pure.

¬ß 16. Marggrave makes it al≈øo after the ≈øame manner as at ¬ß 1. and 9. and ≈øays it is a mo≈øt admirable deob≈øtructive, prevailing again≈øt intermitting Fevers or Agues if given in the ordinary drink of the Sick; but he pre≈øcribes but í j. at a time in Drink, or pure Water.

div.head: XXXIX. Sal ≈øeu Saccharum Saturni; Salt or Sugar of Saturn.
div.p:
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Lemery makes it thus, ‚Ñû Ceru≈øe lb iij. or iv. pouder it finely and put it into a large Earthen or Gla≈øs Ve≈ø≈øel: affu≈øe thereon Spirit of Vinegar, ≈øo much as to overtop it four Inches: dige≈øt in a gentle Sand heat for three days, ≈øhaking the Matter often: let it ≈øettle, and decant the clear Tincture; upon the remainder affu≈øe new Spirit of Vinegar, dige≈øting and proceeding as before, thus continuing the affu≈øion of new Spirit, till you have di≈ø≈øolved about the one half of the Ceru≈øe. Mix all the≈øe Tinctures together in an Earthen or Gla≈øs Ve≈ø≈øel: evaporate with a gentle Sand-heat about two thirds of the Moi≈øture, or till a Pellicle comes over it,
and then ≈øet it in a cool Cellar to cry≈øtallize: decant the Liquor from the Cry≈øtals or Salt, evaporate again to a Pellicle, and ≈øet it to cry≈øtallize again, thus continuing till you have obtained all your Salt, which dry in the Sun or otherwi≈øe, and keep it in a Gla≈øs for u≈øe.

¬ß 2. The Colledge makes it with Minium or Red-Lead, as you may ≈øee in our Pharm. Lond. Lib. 3. Cap. 6. Sect. 3. others as Zwelfer and Marggrave make it with the greyi≈øh Calx of Lead after the ≈øame manner. Beguinus makes it of Minium; ≈øo al≈øo Crollius, and Rolfincius, which two latter make it al≈øo of Ceru≈øe: but Zwelfer in his Manti≈ø≈øa Hermetica pagin√¢ me√¢ 458. ≈øaith, that it is not made only of the Calx of Lead, but al≈øo from Plates and granulated Lead, as well as from Ceru≈øe‚ñ™ Litharge, and Minium: notwith≈øtanding (≈øaith he) it is made more pure‚ñ™ from one than from another, and by the help of Spirit of Vinegar, or ≈øome other acid Liquor drawn forth, according to the Method before directed. But Thibaut and Maets make it of Litharge only: Le Febure makes it of a Mixture of equal parts of Minium and Litharge: Schroder out of the Calx of Lead, or Red-Lead: Le Mort and Charras (as Lemery) out of the Ceru≈øe.

¬ß 3. Thus you may ≈øee, Quot homines tot capita, and every Man thinks his own way be≈øt; but he that has tryed all of them can be≈øt tell: for my part I ≈øhould rather chu≈øe Ceru≈øe or White-Lead, than my of the other, for the Preparation thereof; for it appears to me to be more open, and ea≈øier to di≈ø≈øolve than the re≈øt, by rea≈øon of the Vinegar with which it is already-impregnated: and this ≈øeems to me to be reasonable, becau≈øe I can with more ea≈øe make a greater quantity of Sal or Saccharum out of that, than I can out of any of the other; yea with a very little labour more than ordinary, the whole body of the Lead will turn to a Saccharum, whereas the other Preparations of Lead, yield it ≈ølowly, and with much difficulty, nor can be totally di≈ø≈øolved without a va≈øt labour.

¬ß 4. If you would have the Sal or Saccharum very white, you mu≈øt di≈ø≈øolve it again in equal quantities of Spirit of Vinegar, and common Water, then filter and cry≈øtallize again, as before;
which purification you may repeat three or four times, as you ≈øee need requires it.

¬ß 5. This Salt is called Saccharum or Sugar, by rea≈øon of its ≈øweetne≈øs, which proceeds from the ≈øulphurous Particles of the Lead, joyned with the Salt of the Vinegar, whence re≈øults that delightful ta≈øte, which ≈øo admirably affects the Nerves of the Tongue in ta≈øting it.

¬ß 6. This is not to be ≈øuppo≈øed to be a true Salt of Lead, but only a di≈ø≈øolution of its Sub≈øtance by‚ñ™ Acids, which ≈øo clo≈øely unite with it, as to give it the form of a Salt: for if by di≈øtillation, you ab≈øtract the Humidity of the di≈ø≈øolution, you will find nothing but an in≈øipid Flegm to come off, deprived of all its Acidity, which ≈øhews that the acid Salt is actually joyned with the Particles of the Lead.

¬ß 7. The Ebullition in the making of it from Ceru≈øe ari≈øes from the violent Penetration of the Acids, which with violence ≈øeparate the Plumbou≈øe Particles; but if they be affu≈øed on any other Preparation of Lead, the Ebullition is very much ≈øtronger; becau≈øe when the Acid meets with a Body not ≈øo open as Ceru≈øe is, it mu≈øt u≈øe a greater power to enter into it, and ≈øo con≈øequently rai≈øe a greater Efferve≈øcency.
¬ß 8. But in all the≈øe Ebullitions or Efferve≈øcencies (as well as in many others) the lea≈øt degree of heat is not perceived, but rather (as ≈øome think) the Cold is much increated.

¬ß 9. Vinegar impregnated with this Salt, being ground with Oil of Ro≈øes, or ≈øome other Oil, in a Mortar, makes an Ointment called Nutritum, or Butter of Saturn, which is good for Burnings, Scaldings, Tettars, Ring-worms, and other Defedations of the Skin.

¬ß 10. This Salt of Saturn powerfully ab≈øorbs Acids, and therefore it is ≈øaid to be good for Diarrhaea's, Dy≈øenteries, and Lienteriaes, as al≈øo Fluxes of the Haemorrhoides and Men≈øes, which are all cau≈øed by ≈øharp and corro≈øive Salts falling into the Ve≈ø≈øels, or upon tho≈øe parts.
¬ß 11. And indeed it is good for any Di≈øea≈øe proceeding from ≈øharp Humors, becau≈øe it blunts or dulls their Points, and a≈ø≈øwages them, taking away their keenne≈øs.

¬ß 12. Taken inwardly it is ≈øaid to be very good for the Quin≈øey and Pleuri≈øie, and the aforenamed Di≈øea≈øes at ¬ß 10. above, becau≈øe they mo≈øtly proceed from a Saline, or acid Sero≈øity, which falling too abundantly upon any of tho≈øe parts, rai≈øes a fermentation which dilutes the Fibres of the Mu≈øcles, cau≈øing Inflamation of the Throat, &c. as is ≈øeen in a Quin≈øey, &c. or a corro≈øion of the Tunicles and Membranes of the Ve≈ø≈øels Do≈øe, √† gr. ij. ad iv. or vj. in Wine or Water; and in Plantain-water for Gargles.

¬ß 13. Mixt with Water, it makes that Preparation called Lac Virginis, or Virgins Milk, and is u≈øed in that manner, or mixt with Pomatums again≈øt Inflamations, Burnings, Scaldings, Tettars. Ring-worms, Herpes, and other Di≈øea≈øes of the Skin.

¬ß 14. If Sal Saturni be mixt with Sal Tartari and put into a Crucible over a melting Fire, the Acid of the Spirit of Vinegar will quit the Lead, and unite with the Salt of Tartar, whereby the Salt is reduced to what it was before, to wit, Ceru≈øe or Calx.

¬ß 15. Some who are afraid of the Coldne≈øs of this Salt, and the Acrimony of the Spirit of Vinegar, impregnate it with the Heat and Sulphur of S. V. well rectified, ≈øo much as to overtop it four Inches, dige≈øting it three or four days, then ab≈øtracting the S. V. drying die Salt and keeping it for u≈øe.

¬ß 16. Taken inwardly, it not only takes away Inflamations and Heats of Fevers, but abates Lu≈øts and Venereal De≈øires; it di≈ø≈øolves al≈øo hard and ≈øcirrhous Tumors, ab≈øorbs the Acidities of Cancerous Humors, and di≈ø≈øipates Contu≈øions, ≈øtops Fluxes of all ≈øorts, and is prevalent again≈øt the Gonorrhoea in Men, and the Whites in Women.

¬ß 17. It may be al≈øo u≈øed in an Injection for a Gonorrhoea, &c. as al≈øo for Ulcers of the Bladder, Womb, and their Pa≈ø≈øages; and is excelent in Gargari≈øms for mo≈øt Di≈øea≈øes of the Mouth, and Throat, &c. which are cau≈øed by fixt or volatile Salts; the≈øe are mortified, by the Acid of the Vinegar, ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øi≈øted by the cold Quality of the Lead.

¬ß 18. And this is ≈øo much the more rea≈øonable to believe, becau≈øe we find by Experience that Sal Prunellae, Spirits of Salt, Sulphur and Vitriol,
and all ≈øorts of Acids, even ≈øimple Vinegar it ≈øelf, are very good for the≈øe kind of Di≈øea≈øes, which are irritated by the u≈øe of all other Salts of what kind ≈øoever, whether fixt or volatile.

¬ß 19. Made into a Collyrium with ≈øome proper Water or common Spirit of Wine, it ≈øtops Fluxes of Humors into the Eyes, cools Inflamations in them, and di≈ø≈øolves Pearls, and con≈øumes the Pin and Web, or Films, at the beginning; a Scruple or two, being di≈ø≈øolved in five Ounces of common S. V. or Brandy, or in as much Celandine-water, augmenting the quantity of the Salt-as you ≈øee occa≈øion.

¬ß 20. Crollius ≈øays, that Saccharum Saturni makes all ≈øublimate, and corro≈øive Mercuries ≈øweet, and unhurtful; therefore in corro≈øive Ulcers, which ari≈øe from venene and malign Salts it is an excellent Medicament. And as in Vegetables common Sugar tempers and corrects their Acrimony and Bitterne≈øs; ≈øo this Sugar of Saturn mitigates and amends Minerals, and Mercurial Ar≈øenicks, both in the greater and le≈ø≈øer World.

¬ß 21. It is ≈øays he, good again≈øt Putrefaction, ≈øore Mouths, malign, corroding and cancerous Ulcers, Tettars, Ring-worms, red Pimples in the Face, inflamed Tumors, and ≈øuch other like Saturnian Evils: It clean≈øes old Ulcers, Apo≈øtems, and running Sores, and is a ≈øingular Arcanum again≈øt an Ery≈øipelas, and ≈øuch like, by di≈ø≈øolving it in Plantane or Night≈øhade Water, and wa≈øhing therewith, Linnen Cloths dipt in the ≈øame being al≈øo laid thereon.

¬ß 22. Mixt with Oil of Camomil and applied, it di≈øcu≈ø≈øes Tumors: mixt with Oil of Turpentine it cures all Ulcers, Wounds, and contracted Members, being con≈øtantly for ≈øome time anointed therewith.

¬ß 23. It prevails again≈øt Cancers and Fi≈øtula's, all ≈øorts of Ulcers in Womens Brea≈øts, and all Aches and Pains in the Members, being outwardly applied; and takes away all Inflamations to a Miracle. It may be mixed with Emplai≈øters, Ointments, Bal≈øams and Oils, or be di≈ø≈øolved per ≈øe in appropriated Waters and applied.

¬ß 24. It gives ea≈øe in the Cholick, ≈øome Grains of it being given in White-wine, and in all internal Inflamations and Heats, it is of extraordinary
u≈øe. It prevails again≈øt Quartan Agues, as al≈øo again≈øt di≈øaffections of the Spleen, and Pains of the Hypochonders: Spirit of Wine may be affu≈øed thereon, which will extract its Vertue; this e≈ø≈øentificated Spirit may be given in≈øtead of the Salt or Saccharum again≈øt all the Di≈øea≈øes aforementioned.

div.head: XL. Sal Spongiae Volatile, Volatile Salt of Sponges.
div.p: Bate.] It is made by di≈øtillation in a Retort, and rectifying the Salt S. A. From the Caput Mortuum, with warm Water, a di≈ø≈øolution is made of the fixt Salt, and it is drawn forth. It is good to break the Stone in the Reins and Bladder. It is powerful al≈øo to di≈øcu≈øs Struma's or Swellings of the King's Evil. Do≈øe, gr. 5. ad 12.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. How this Volatile Salt of Sponges is particularly to be made, we have ≈øhewed at large, where we have taught the Di≈øtillation of the Spirit, in Cap. 2. Sect. XXXIII. ¬ß 1. aforegoing.

¬ß 2. In the Di≈øtillation thereof, part of the Volatile Salt will ari≈øe and ≈øtick to the top and neck of the Retort, and part of it will mix and be di≈ø≈øolved in the Spirit; you may rectifie each apart if you ≈øo plea≈øe, or di≈ø≈øolve all the Salt, in the Spirit and rectifie them together from the Oleaginous Particles‚ñ™ as we have in many places taught in our Sepla≈øium, lately emitted into the World.

¬ß 3. This Volatile Salt and Spirit of Sponges is ≈øaid to be one of the greate≈øt Specificks in Nature‚ñ™ for the Cure of the King's Evil being daily given Morning and Night, √† ‚Ñà≈øs. ad gr. xvj. in any proper Vehicle, Univer≈øals being al≈øo premi≈øed.

¬ß 4. That the Volatile Salt is truly thus effectual, may be deduced from the vulgar u≈øe of the ≈øimple Pouder of Sponges, (being ju≈øt ≈øo much calcined or ≈øcorched, as to be reduced to ≈øuch a Form or Con≈øi≈øtence) which Experience has confirmed to be an ab≈øolute cure for all kinds of Struma's or Scrophula's what≈øoever, being given to a Dram or more, Morning and Evening, with due purging: but this, by rea≈øon of the great quantity, many, e≈øpecially Children cannot be brought to take, for which rea≈øon, we rather commend the u≈øe of the Votatile Salt afore≈øaid, as being le≈øs nau≈øeous by rea≈øon of its quantity, and more
effectual by rea≈øon of its quality.

¬ß 5. From the Caput Mortuum as it is left in the bottom of the Retort, you will get but little fixt Salt, without a new and open Calcination, and therefore it is nece≈ø≈øary to calcine it again in a Crucible till it is white, after which you may draw forth the ≈øaid fixt Salt after the vulgar Method.

¬ß 6. This fixt Salt is of the Nature of other fixt Alcalies, as Salt of Tartar, Salt of Oi≈øter-Shells, and ≈øuch like, and may be given in the ≈øame Ca≈øes, √† gr. xij. ad xxiv. or í ≈øs. in Ar≈ømart, Par≈øley, or Onion-water again≈øt, Ob≈øtructions in the Reins and Ureters, Stone and Gravel in tho≈øe parts, and to ab≈øorb Acid Humours, which are the Cau≈øes of many pernicious Di≈øea≈øes.

div.head: XLI. Sal Sulphnris, Salt of Sulphur or Brim≈øtone.
div.p: Bate.] Di≈ø≈øolve the Caput Mortuum of the Spirit of Sulphur in Water, filter and coagulate, S. A. It is a powerful Remedy again≈øt Worms, and the breeding of Worms. Do≈øe, √† gr. 5. ad 10.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. Hartman makes it of the Caput Mortuum of Oil of Sulphur made per Campanum; but Schroder of the Caput Mortuum of the Oil of Sulphur made by Retort, thus:

¬ß 2. ‚Ñû A Retort that has a Pipe in the hinder part, place it in a Fornace, and fit a Receiver with Water in it, without luting; when it is hot, ca≈øt in peices of Sulphur now and then, ≈øhutting the Pipe after every time; the Spirit or Oil ≈øeparate from the Water in B. M. and rectifie it; This Spirit (≈øays Schroder) is only Spirit of Vitriol, and has the ≈øame Vertues; but if you give no vent in making it, you will labour in vain, and have only a milky Liquor for a Spirit, without any acidity; from the Feces remaining (after the common manner) make a Salt.

¬ß 3. Le Febure ≈øays, there remains in the bottom of the Di≈øhes which have been u≈øed in the burning of Sulphur for making its Oil or Spirit, a kind of Feces, or blacki≈øh Caput Mortuum, light, ≈øpongy, and as it were in Leaves or Beds, which mu≈øt be calcined and reverberated in a Crucible, till it become of a whiti≈øh Grey; afterwards with di≈øtilled Rain-water or Ros or Dew of Vitriol, a Lye or Lixivium is to be made, which filterate, and evaporate ≈ølowly in A≈øhes, either to a Pellicle or to dryne≈øs,
≈øo will you have the Salt, which will be but little.

¬ß 4. Wherefore (≈øays he) that of Vitriol may lawfully be ≈øub≈øtituted in the place thereof, viz. in place of that of Sulphur, without any ≈øcruple or que≈øtion, becau≈øe they ≈øpring from the ≈øame Original, and have the ≈øame Vertues, which is to clean≈øe and ≈øtrengthen the Stomach, and root from it all Seminaries of Worms, and the Crude corrupt Matter from which they breed, expelling the ≈øame.

¬ß 5. Lemery makes it another way, and ≈øays that Salt of Sulphur is a Sal Polychre≈øtum, impregnated with Spirit of Sulphur: Thus. ‚Ñû Sal Polychre≈øtum ‚Ñ•iv. put it into an Earthen Pan, or Gla≈øs Ve≈ø≈øel, and affu≈øe thereon Oil of Sulphur ‚Ñ•ij. ≈øet the Ve≈ø≈øel in Sand, and evaporate in a gentle Sand-heat to dryne≈øs, ≈øo will there be remaining ‚Ñ•iv. í vj. of a plea≈øant acid Salt, very agreeable to the Ta≈øte, which keep in a Bottle clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 6. This Salt (which is improperly called Salt of Sulphur, it being nothing but Sal Polychre≈øtum impregnated with an Acid Spirit) is of excellent u≈øe in Tertians, and continual Fevers, and on all occa≈øions where there is need of quieting the turbulency and efferve≈øcency of the Humors (for that Acids generally fix the Volatile Salts and Sulphurs, which mo≈øt commonly are the principal Cau≈øe of ≈øuch Di≈øea≈øes:) it opens all Ob≈øtructions, and works by Urine, and ≈øometimes by Stool.

¬ß 7. The Do≈øe of it is from ‚Ñà≈øs. ad í≈øs. or ‚Ñàij. in Broth, or other ≈øpecifick Vehicle; or it may be di≈ø≈øolved √† í j. ad í ij. in a Quart of pure fair Water, to be given as a Drink to quench thir≈øt, and abate the Preternatural heat in Fevers.

¬ß 8. Many large de≈øcriptions have been made of Salt of Sulphur‚ñ™ which being truly examined do all come to the ≈øame thing as this, and is called by many Authors Sal Febrifugum. But the true Salt of Sulphur, is only a little of the Vitriolick Sub≈øtance, which remains in the Earth of the Sulphur (as is declared above by Le Febure) after that the Spirit and Flowers have been ≈øeparated from it; and ought to be ≈øeparated from the ≈øaid Earth by El ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ iviation, as other fixed Salts are

¬ß 9. The Union of Acid Spirits with Acid Salts is very different from that of Acid Spirits with alca ‚Ä¢ ous Salts,
for the Acid Spirits not being able to open the Bodies of the Acid Salts, they lo≈øe nothing of their ≈øtrength and acidity, but remain the ≈øame; whereas, being mixed with Alcalies, they make ≈øuch a penetration, that they immediately lo≈øe their whole ≈øtrength, and become in≈øipid.

¬ß 10. For this Rea≈øon, when Oil of Sulphur is affu≈øed on Sal Polychre≈øtum, or Nitre, there is no Ebullition or Efferve≈øcency, they being both Acid Salts: And therefore al≈øo Salt of Sulphur (thus made) is very acid, whereas Tartar Vitriolate is but a little acid, although proportionally, there is double the quantity of the Aid Spirit or Oil, for making the latter, or Tartar Vitriolate, which is u≈øually taken for making the former.

¬ß 11. Charras has ≈øeveral Preparations of Salt of Sulphur: His fir≈øt is exactly the ≈øame with the aforementioned of L ‚Ä¢ nery: His ≈øecond is thus made. ‚Ñû Nitre in pouder lb j put it into a large Retort, and affu≈øe therein rectified Oil of Sulphur, enough to entirely di≈ø≈øolve the Nitre, and having fitted and luted to the Retort a very large Receiver, di≈øtil in a Sand-heat; fir≈øt with a gentle Fire, which augment by degrees to the highe≈øt, the better to force what is to be got out of the Nitre; ≈øo will you have a good Spirit of Nitre, very proper for all ≈øorts of u≈øes, while the Spirit of Sulphur ≈øtrictly unites with the fixed Salt of the Nitre, and makes therewith but one Body, which will be found in a lump in the Retort when broken, of a very white colour, and of a plea≈øing acidity in Ta≈øte, having the ≈øame Vertues with that of Lemery afore de≈øcribed.

¬ß 12. In this Operation, you obtain the Spirit of Nitre, which would el≈øe vani≈øh, when the Salt is calcin'd with Sulphur in a Pot or Crucible: and the Con≈øideration of the Spirit of Nitre leaving the Mixture, makes me believe that the Salt which remains in the Retort, is of very ≈øafe and innocent u≈øe, and therefore not to be feared in its Effects, ≈øince there remains nothing of the Nitre but its fixed part. which is not only of its ≈øelf an excellent Remedy, but by rea≈øon of its union with the Spirit or Oil of Sulphur, becomes infinitely more grateful to the Stomach, and much more efficacious in opening Ob≈øtructions‚ñ™ and allaying the Preternatural heat of violent burning, malign, or pe≈øtilential Fevers.

¬ß 13. Charras his third and la≈øt Preparation of the Salt of Sulphur. ‚Ñû Volatile Salt of ∆≤rine very pure and white lb j. put it into a large and high Cucurbit, and affu≈øe thereon ≈øo much well rectified Oil of Sulphur, till the Ebullition cea≈øes; then in a gentle Sandheat evaporate the Humidity till a film or ≈øcum comes over it, and ≈øet it to cry≈øtallize, ≈øeparating the Cry≈øtals; or el≈øe continue the Evaporation to dryne≈øs.

¬ß 14. This Volatile Salt of Urine, tho' fixed for a time by the Oil of Sulphur, lo≈øes not its fir≈øt Nature, but may ≈øhew its effects, if the Acid of the Sulphur, (which has fixt it) ≈øhall meet in the Stomach with ≈øome other Salt or Sub≈øtance, with which it can unite; for then the Volatile Salt of Urine is re≈øtored to its pri≈øtine Nature and Quality: and therefore this compounded Salt, may be thought nothing inferior to the former, but much more proper to purifie the Ma≈øs of Blood, and to expel by Sweat or in≈øen≈øible Tran≈øpiration, ≈øharp and malign Humors, which are the Roots and Cau≈øes of almo≈øt an infinite number of Di≈øea≈øes. Do≈øe, √† ‚Ñà≈øs. ad í≈øs. and ≈øometimes ad í j. in ≈øome proper Vehicle.

¬ß 15. The ≈øame thing may be done in like manner with Volatile Sal Armoniack, and the Salt re≈øulting, will have all the ≈øame Vertues and Effects, with the former made or compounded with the Salt of ∆≤rine, as has been even now declared.

div.head: XLII. Sal Tartari; Salt of Tartar.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of calcin'd Tartar, after the ≈øame manner as all other Salts which are extracted from A≈øhes. It may al≈øo be prepared by Elixiviation from the Caput Mortuum remaining after the di≈øtillation of the Spirit of Tartar, being yet longer calcin'd, even to whitene≈øs. Or it is made from crude Tartar and Nitre, Ana. made into a Pouder and calcin'd in a Crucible, S. A. It is one of the be≈øt Remedies again≈øt Ulcers, Serpigines, Scall'd-Heads, Scabs, &c. being internally given, as well as externally applied.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The la≈øt way of making this Salt with equal parts of Nitre, we have ≈øufficiently explicated in our Pharm. Lond. Lib. 3. Cap. 11. Sect. 99: ≈øo that no more need be ≈øpoke of it here: but this we have to ≈øay in relation
to this Preparation, that it is not ≈øo genuine and good as is that which is made of Tartar alone; for refine and purifie the Nitre as well as it is po≈ø≈øible, there will be a fixt part remaining, which will unite it ≈øelf with the Salt of Tartar, and by its acidity much dimini≈øh the Vertues of the true Salt.

¬ß 2. The other two ways whether from the Caput Mortuum, or from ≈øimple calcin'd Tartar, are but one and the ≈øame, for they are both of them but the A≈øhes of the Tartar, ≈øave the one of them is calcin'd in an open and naked fire, the other in a clo≈øe Gla≈øs or Stone body: thus.

¬ß 3. ‚Ñû The black Caput Mortuum remaining after the di≈øtillation of the Oil and Spirit of Tartar, Calcine it in a Reverberatory Fornace, in a flat open Pot till it becomes white; let it cool, and pour upon it hot Water in an Earthen Ve≈ø≈øel, ≈øo much as may overtop it ≈øix Inches and ≈øtir it from time to time for ≈øome hours, ≈øo will the Salt di≈ø≈øolve in the Water, which decant, adding more hot Water to the remainder, which repeat ≈øo often till all the Salt is extracted: mix and filter all your Solutions, and evaporate the Humidity till the Salt becomes dry, and white as Snow in the bottom of the Ve≈ø≈øel, which keep in a Gla≈øs well ≈øtopt (el≈øe the Salt will di≈ø≈øolve into Liquor) for u≈øe.

¬ß 4. This Salt is very diuretick, as all other fixt Salts and Alcalies of Vegetables are; and therefore is given with ≈øucce≈øs again≈øt Ob≈øtructions of the Vi≈øcera, Di≈øea≈øes of the Reins, Bladder, Drop≈øies, and all ≈øorts of Di≈øea≈øes proceeding from Ob≈øtructions and watery Humors, being given √† gr. x. ad xxx. in any proper or ≈øpecifick Vehicle.

¬ß 5. If this Sale is laid upon a Marble or Plate of Gla≈øs in a Cellar, or put into a Flannel Bag, and placed in ≈øome moi≈øt place, it will re≈øolve per Deliquium into an Oil or Liquor, which may be u≈øed in≈øtead of the Salt, being no other than the Salt di≈ø≈øolved, but its Do≈øe mu≈øt be increa≈øed √† í ≈øs. ad í j. or í ij. as the Prudence of the Phy≈øician ≈øhall direct.

¬ß 6. How the Spirit and Oil of Tartar are made, from whence this Caput Mortuum is to be had, we ≈øhall at large explicate (thro' God's A≈ø≈øi≈øtance) in our Officina Chymica: however out of forty eight Ounces of Crude
Tartar you will have four Ounces of Flegm, eight Ounces of Spirit, three ounces of Oil, and thirty two ounces of Caput Mortuum, out of which you will by the former Method have twelve Ounces of Salt, and no more; and this Salt is of great u≈øe in the drawing forth the Tinctures of Vegetables.

¬ß 7. But ≈øhould you de≈øire only the Salt, without the other Sub≈øtances, you need only brui≈øe it, wrap it up in Paper, which wet well in Water, and calcine it till it turns into a white Ma≈øs after which you may draw forth the Salt by Elixiviation, as is before directed.
¬ß 8. Out of every four Ounces of Crude red Tartar, once Ounce of pure Salt may be got, and from the ≈øame quantity of white Tartar, ≈øomewhat more: but it is no ways better than the former.

¬ß 9. The Ancients will have Salt of Tartar to be fixt, being prepared according to the common way, with a violent Fire: but doubtle≈øs this Salt of it ≈øelf is not ≈øo, but naturally very volatile, and would continue ≈øo, did not the Volatile Acid Salt (which makes one part of its Compo≈øition) fix it, by making a ≈øtrict Union with it, during its Calcination.

¬ß 10. But notwith≈øtanding this alteration, it is not ≈øo unalterable in its Property, but that you may re≈øtore to the greate≈øt part of this Salt, its fir≈øt volatility, if you free it from its Chains, by ≈øeparating, or augmenting the Acid, ≈øo that it may ma ‚Ä¢ ter it; or if you prevent its Union with it.

¬ß 11. Yet their Conjunction is not without a ≈øingular advantage, becau≈øe that by fixing the volatile Salt, it hinders its di≈ø≈øipation, and is made ≈øerviceable for ≈øeveral other u≈øes, which being only Volatile it would not be applicable to.

¬ß 12. In making this Salt of calcin'd Tartar, Lemery only affu≈øes hot Water, letting it ≈øtand for ≈øome hours, ≈øtirring it now and then; whereas Charras boils it in the Water, as thinking it a more effectual way of di≈ø≈øolving the Salt in the Water: without doubt both ways may do, but the latter is the more ≈øpeedy, and not inferior to the other, ≈øince the boiling, is certain to extract all the Salt, nor can di≈ø≈øolve any Particles of the Tartar, except the Saline.

¬ß 13. Some calcine the Sale of Tartar with Sulphur, to hinder it from di≈ø≈øolving ≈øo ea≈øily by the Air, or to pre≈øerve it in its beauty and dryne≈øs; Thus. They mix three Ounces of the Salt with one Ounce of Sulphur in Pouder, cau≈øing it to burn and con≈øume over a good Charcole fire, then elixiviate, filter, and evaporate the Humidity to a Pellicle, in a Gla≈øs Cucurbit over a Sand-heat, and ≈øet it to cry≈øtallize, ≈øeparating the Cry≈øtals, &c.

¬ß 14. But this ≈øays Lemery is no good Practice, becau≈øe the Acid of the Sulphur de≈øtroys ≈øome part of the Alcali; and this happens becau≈øe the Pores of the Salt by being thus calcin'd, are not ≈øo open as they were, whereby the Air cannot ≈øo ea≈øily penetrate them.

¬ß 15. The aptne≈øs of Alcalious Salts to di≈ø≈øolve in the Air, is natural to them, not can it be taken from them, but by de≈øtroying their Nature; for having had in their Calcination as much of the Acid as was requi≈øite for their fixation, but not to fill up all the Cavities or Pores which the force and violence of the Fire had left there, they have their Pores open, and ≈øubject to any penetration, e≈øpecially that of the Air, when expo≈øed to it: But when they meet with an Acid more powerful, ≈øuch as that ari≈øing from the Sulphur, mixt and calcin'd with them in their la≈øt Calcination they fill them≈øelves ≈øo much, that having no more vacuities, the Acid of the Air cannot break the ≈øtrict Union which is between them, and ≈øo pre≈øerves the Salt from ≈øuch a facile di≈ø≈øolution.

¬ß 16. The ≈øame thing is to be under≈øtood of the addition of Nitre in the Calcination of Tartar, becau≈øe the Volatile, parts of the Nitre being ≈øublim'd, or made to fly away, the fixt do remain, which by their Acidity do dimini≈øh the Vertue of the Salt of Tartar, as we have already hinted at ¬ß 1. aforegoing.

¬ß 17. But there is a Cry≈øtalline Salt of Tartar, prepared with equal parts of Salt of Tartar and Nitre together well purified, di≈ø≈øolved in Ro≈øewater heated, filtred, coagulated and cry≈øtalliz'd after the ordinary manner, which ≈øome call Sal Tartari Nitratum, very proper to open the Liver, Spleen, Reins, Ureters, and Womb, as al≈øo to a≈ø≈øwage Inflamations of the Mouth and Throat given √†
‚Ñà≈øs. ad í ≈øs. in ≈øome proper Vehicle.

¬ß 18. And tho' Salt of Tartar be of a good whitene≈øs after the fir≈øt Purification; yet if you do calcine eighteen Ounces of it, then di≈ø≈øolve and filtrate as afore directed, you will have yet abundance of Earthy ≈øub≈øtance, which being dryed would weigh a compleat Ounce.

¬ß 19. But I think it not the be≈øt way for to expo≈øe this, or any other Vegetable alcalious Salt to ≈øuch vehement and frequent Calcinations; for it cannot be done without a notable Diminution of ≈øome of their be≈øt parts, and among the re≈øt, of the ≈øpirituous Sulphur: as is ob≈øervable in the di≈ø≈øipation of the Scent and Savour of the Plant, which happens always to Salts thus calcin'd, which otherwi≈øe were they not ≈øo expo≈øed to the violence of the Fire, would pre≈øerve a good part of them.

¬ß 20. Hence it appears that there is great rea≈øon, to pre≈øerve the e≈ø≈øential Salts of Vegetables, which may be drawn from Plants with a moderate and gentle Fire, before tho≈øe that undergo ≈øuch violent Calcinations.

¬ß 21. Alcalious Salts are aperitive, di≈ø≈øolving vi≈øcous, mucilaginous and tartarous Humors, which cau≈øe Ob≈øtructions in almo≈øt all parts of the Body: And Salt of Tartar as the chief of them, does it with advantage: It corrects Sena, and keeps it from griping, rarifying and altering its vi≈øcous Sub≈øtance, and cau≈øing it to work quicker: it di≈ø≈øolves and expels vi≈øcous Flegm lodging in the Stomach and Bowels, which becau≈øe of its Acidity cau≈øes Gripings, Cholicks, and the like.

¬ß 22. This Salt in the chief Exemplar of all Vegetable fixt Salts, none being more u≈øed in either the one or the other Pharmacy, not only u≈øed in opening and purging Medicines to mortifie the Acids, which excite Fermentations in our Bodies; but al≈øo in extractions, di≈ø≈øolutions and precipitations of ≈øeveral Sub≈øtances, e≈øpecially of Minerals.

¬ß 23. Outwardly al≈øo, it is of ≈øingular u≈øe in lotions again≈øt the Gout, and to take away Scars and Blemi≈øhes in the Face, and as a Specifick in all Di≈øea≈øes of the Skin proceeding from Acids.

¬ß 24. The Oil of Tartar per Deliquium is made of the Salt as at ¬ß 5. aforegoing: but if you would make it
quickly, you may di≈ø≈øolve it in Rain-water q. ≈ø. filtred, which may be u≈øed in all the Ca≈øes of the Oil.

¬ß 25. If Salt of Tartar be di≈ø≈øolved in di≈øtilled Waters from fre≈øh green Plants, (immediately after they are di≈øtilled) they will turn green; and the greener the Plant was from which the Water was di≈øtilled, the greener will it make the Water.

¬ß 26. The Rea≈øon is, becau≈øe the Alcali of the Salt does ≈øtir up and make appear the latent or hidden little parts of the Plant, which ro≈øe with the Water in di≈øtillation: But if you would have this appearance, you mu≈øt be ≈øure that the Water is but newly di≈øtilled, and done not in B. M. or a gentle heat, but with a ≈øtrong and violent Fire.

¬ß 27. Tincture of the Salt of Tartar. ‚Ñû Fine Salt of Tartar lb ij. put it into a Crucible, and in a great Fire of Fu≈øion, melt it, covering it with a Tyle, and put Coals round it; blow about it ≈øo as to make a greater heat than for the melting of Gold, which degree of heat continue about ≈øix hours, or until the Salt is of a red Marble colour, which you may know by putting the end of a Spatula into the Crucible, and looking upon it: then taking the Crucible out, turn it up≈øide down into a very hot Iron Mortar, in which it will pre≈øently coagulate; pouder it immediately, and put it into a Matra≈øs warmed before-hand, upon which affu≈øe Tartari≈øed S.V. ≈øo much as may overtop it four or five Inches: ≈øtop the Matra≈øs with another, making a double Ve≈ø≈øel: lute the Junctures clo≈øe with a wet Bladder, dige≈øting in a very gentle Sand-heat, ≈øo as the S. V. may boil (as it were) for eight or ten hours, and become impregnated with a red Tincture: let the Ve≈ø≈øels cool, and decant the Tincture and keep it for u≈øe, in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt. To the remaining Salt affu≈øe fre≈øh S. V. and operate as before ≈øo long as it will yield any Tincture. Thus Lemery.

¬ß 28. This Tincture is a famous Aperitive, and one of the greate≈øt Sweetner of the Humors or Juices that is in nature; it purifies the Blood, acuates the Spirits, and re≈øi≈øts Putrefaction and Malignity in the highe≈øt mea≈øure; prevailing again≈øt the Scurvy, Surfeits, Mea≈øles, Small-Pox, and all ≈øorts of malign and pe≈øtilential Fevers, being given √† gut. 10. ad 30.40. or 60. in any fit Vehicle.

¬ß 29. In the making of this Tincture ≈øome things are ob≈øervable; As fir≈øt, That the Crucible be placed upon a Culot or Tyle, le≈øt the Wind which comes thro' the A≈øhhole, or el≈øe where ≈øhould cool the bottom, and hinder the Fu≈øion.

¬ß 30. That altho' ≈øome Authors ≈øay, it is ≈øufficient to calcine the Salt of Tartar two hours in a violent Fire, or till it becomes blewi≈øh, yet that will yield little or no Tincture, or but a very faint one; whereas it ≈øhould be red like Wine; and that it will be, if it be kept beforehand a good while melted in the Crucible.

¬ß 31. That as the Tincture grows old, it lo≈øes its red colour, and becomes of a pale Amber or Sack colour, by rea≈øon that the more ≈øubtil part of the S. V. is lo≈øt, thro' often opening of it, and other accidents, ≈øo that the Spirit remaining has not ≈øtrength enough to keep the Salt of Tarta ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n its exalted ≈øtate.
¬ß 32. That for this rea≈øon, you mu≈øt be very careful to u≈øe S. V. perfectly deflegmated; for if any Flegm be left in it, it will never turn red.

¬ß 33. That the Salt of Tartar being thus melted and poudred, if you add to ever Pound of it, lb ij. of Bone-A≈øhes in pouder, that thereby the Particles of the Salt may be ≈øeparated one from another, you will have a much deeper Tincture, and a much greater quantity, for fre≈øh S. V. may be continually affu≈øed upon the Salt, at lea≈øt ten or a dozen times or more, whereas twice is as much as it will bear the other way.

¬ß 34. Some think that this Tincture proceeds from a Sulphur contained in the Salt, but that is a mi≈øtake, for it is only an exaltation of ≈øome Particles of the Salt in the S. V. and this is evident, not only by the diminution of the weight of the Salt, (which I have ≈øeveral times proved) but likewi≈øe by di≈øtillation, for no Tincture will ri≈øe, but only a colour le≈øs S.V. leaving the ≈ømall quantity of Salt (which the Spirit had ≈øuckt up into it ≈øelf) at bottom, of its u≈øual whitne≈øs: from what has been ≈øaid, it appears that the whole body or quantity of Salt of Tartar, will by degrees be converted to Tincture.

¬ß 35. La≈øtly, That Salt of Tartar having been a while melted in a Crucible, if live Charcoals be ca≈øt into it, it will flame as ea≈øily as Nitre or Salt-peter; which proceeds from the attenuated Particles of the Salt, being made fit to be exalted with the Sulphur of the Coals: and from this Ob≈øervation ≈øome light is given to the making of Artificial Salt-peter.

div.head: XLIII. Sal Tartari Volatile, Volatile Salt of Tartar.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Pure Salt of Tartar ‚Ñ•iv. Alcohol of Wine ‚Ñ•viij. di≈øtil in Sand, thrice cohobating, ≈øo will the Salt ≈øtick to the ≈øides of the Alembick. It is a famous Diuretick and Aperitive, purifies the Blood, and re≈øi≈øts Malignity. Do≈øe, √† gr. 10. ad 20. and more.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. In our Doron Medicum, Lib. 2. Cap. 10. Sect. 20. we have given you five other ≈øeveral ways of preparing this Volatile Salt of Tartar; the fourth of which is Lemery's Method, ≈øo that referring you thither, we need ≈øay no more of it here, only make ≈øome ≈øhort Ob≈øervations concerning the ≈øame.

¬ß 2. It is my Opinion (from an Experiment which I accidentally made) that Salt of Tartar is naturally Volatile, and ≈øo that no great Study or Labor need be u≈øed to change its Nature; and Volatile it will be, if you hinder the Acid of the Tartar from fixing it, or otherwi≈øe ≈øeparate them when united and fixed together.

¬ß 3. The Ancients and many of the Moderns in ≈øearching after this volatile Salt, generally met with ill ≈øucce≈øs, or wholly mi≈øt their end, becau≈øe they under≈øtood not the aptne≈øs which volatile and fixt Salts have to joyn with Acids; nor the indi≈ø≈øolubility of their union when joyned together, and therefore they determined that (becau≈øe they under≈øtood not the way) there was no ≈øuch thing in nature.

¬ß 4. And tho' the Acid and Volatile Salts, naturally found in Tartar, are not to be ≈øeparated but with much difficulty, and are always inclin'd to unite them≈øelves as ≈øtrictly together as is po≈ø≈øible, e≈øpecially in Calcination which (di≈ø≈øipates the Watery parts, which ≈øen≈øibly kept them divided, and) manife≈øtly clo≈øes up the Earthy parts, ≈øerving as a means to their Union, leaving a ≈øufficiency of the
Acid to maintain that Union (notwith≈øtanding the large diminution of the Acid in that Operation;) yet this ≈øeeming invincible Difficulty, this Gordian-knot, this almo≈øt indi≈ø≈øoluble Unity, Nature it ≈øelf has lead us by the hand to ≈øurmount and overcome.

¬ß 5. For ≈øince it is the Acid which fixes the Volatile part, and keeps it in its Chains, if you would brake its Bands, and deliver the Pri≈øoner, you mu≈øt ≈øurmount that Acid, by the addition of ≈øome new Acid, which may unite it ≈øelf with that fixt Salt.

¬ß 6. For the Salt of Tartar having lo≈øt in Calcination much of the Acid parts which ≈øtopt it, and there being only ≈øo much left to pre≈øerve the quality of the fixt: the mo≈øt fixed part of this Salt, being hungry, and as it were, half ≈øtarv'd for want of Acid enough, it comes to pa≈øs, that ≈øwiftly uniting it ≈øelf to this new Acid, who≈øe Particles are ready to fill all the Vacancies which the violence and action of the Fire had made empty, by this Union it relinqui≈øhes the Volatile parts, and they re≈øume their natural Liberty and Volatility, which is evident by its Smell, and all the other ≈øigns, e≈ø≈øential to Volatile Salts.

¬ß 7. And this is clear in the Volatile Salts of Animals, which have been fixed by Acids, where we have recour≈øe to fixed Salts, which are only able to force the Acid Salts to abandon the Volatile, to unite them≈øelves to them‚ñ™ whereby, the Volatile being di≈øengaged it appears with all the Qualities and Di≈øpo≈øitions proper to it.

¬ß 8. Lemery makes this volatile Salt of Tartar of Lees of Wine, becau≈øe, ≈øays he, they are incomparably more fermented than the Tartar, which is found in the ≈øides of Ve≈ø≈øels, and therefore it is no wonder if its Salt is more volatile.
¬ß 9. But this Salt of Lees, ≈øeems to be all Acid, notwith≈øtanding that ≈øome affirm that they abound in an Alcalious volatile Salt and a ≈øulphurous Spirit, containing but a very little Acid.

¬ß 10. To which we an≈øwer, That if ≈øo, it mu≈øt follow, that the more the Lees ferment, the more they mu≈øt lo≈øe of their Acidity‚ñ™ becau≈øe the Alcaly would ab≈øorb or de≈øtroy it; the contrary of which we every day ≈øee, for they by ≈øo much, glow the
more ≈øowre; as the Vinegar-makers can experimentally tell you, who u≈øe Lees to make them ferment with that Wine, which they would ≈øpeedily turn to Vinegar: and this Tartar does all di≈ø≈øolve in the Wine, and turns into Vinegar, for very little or no Lees, or other Tartar is to be found in tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels in which the Vinegar is made, tho' there was ≈øome naturally before, or other Tartar had been added to it.

¬ß 11. Out of what has been ≈øaid, it plainly appears, that the Volatile Salt in the Lees, is a Volatile Acid, and is the ≈øame, that makes the Acid Spirit of Vinegar, (being more volatile than many other Acids) to volatilize with its Flegm in the di≈øtillation.

¬ß 12. But the Salt of Tartar drawn by Retort (after Lemery's Method) does ri≈øe more ea≈øily, than the Spirit of Vinegar, which comes to pa≈øs from its being volatiliz'd by the violent heat of the Fire.

¬ß 13. Again≈øt what has been ≈øaid, ≈øome may object, that Lees are ≈øometimes added to Wines grown ropy, to make them good again, without ≈øowering them in the lea≈øt, or making them grow hard: which is true, becau≈øe the fir≈øt Fermentation was imperfect, as appears by the ropine≈øs of the Liquor; for had it been ≈øufficiently fermented, it would never have grown ropy: this ropyne≈øs or gummyne≈øs, contains manife≈øtly a great quantity of Oil (which by Retort may be drawn from it:) The Salt of the Lees then, conjoyning with tho≈øe Oily Particles of the Liquor, does rarifie and exalt them into that Sub≈øtance of which Spirit of Wine is made; and ≈øo long as the Saline Particles of the Lees, ≈øhall find Oily Particles to act upon, the Wine will not grow ≈øowre, but refine, and grow better: but being added, after a perfect Fermentation, wherein tho≈øe Oily Particles are all di≈ø≈øolved, it changes the Liquor into a ≈øowerne≈øs, and makes it become Vinegar, as at ¬ß 10. aforegoing is proved.

¬ß 14. This Salt is ≈øublimed in a Bolt-head, that the Flegm which is too heavy to ri≈øe ea≈øily ≈øo high may not mix with it: but it is difficult to keep this Salt dry, becau≈øe it ea≈øily grows moi≈øt and di≈ø≈øolves into a Liquor; for which rea≈øon it is much better to draw it in a Spirit, for thereby le≈øs of the Volatile
parts would be lo≈øt being detained by the Flegm.
¬ß 15. The rea≈øon of its aptne≈øs to di≈ø≈øolve and melt per Deliquium, proceeds from the more E≈ø≈øential parts being volatiliz'd, there remaining much of the fixt Acid Salt in the Earth or Feces.

¬ß 16. From whence it appears, that tho' in the Lees it was a Volatile Acid Salt, (as we ≈øaid at ¬ß 11. above:) Yet after di≈øtillation in a Retort, it becomes an Alcali by the means of the Fire, as other Volatile Salts do; there being no probability that it could be of this nature either in the Plant or in the Lees

¬ß 17. But if you had rather have the Salt in a dry Form, than in a ≈øpirit or liquid Form, mix the Spirit or Liquor with a ≈øufficient quantity of Bone-A≈øhes finely poudred, and make thereof a Pa≈øte, which make into little Balls or Pellets, put them into a Bolt-head, and fit to it a blind Head, ≈øo will the Salt ≈øublime very pure, white, and dry, which keep in Gla≈ø≈øes clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 18. Out of the Feces left in the Retort (being after calcin'd in an open Fire) you may extract a fixt Alcalious Salt, as out of common calcin'd Tartar, but it will be in a va≈øtly le≈øs quantity, from whence it appears, that the greate≈øt part of the Salt of the Lees is truly volatiliz'd, which is the thing propo≈øed to be done.

¬ß 19. This Volatile Salt is of excellent u≈øe, to ab≈øorb Acids in the Body, of what kind, or how malign ≈øoever, and to cau≈øe Sweat, purifying the Blood and other Juices by per≈øpiration: for by their volatility they penetrate momentarily all parts, enliven the Animal Spirits, and open Ob≈øtructions to a wonder if prudently given: having much the ≈øame effects, as volatile Salt of Beans, and other like ≈øub≈øtances, and is indeed a ≈øingular Specifick again≈øt mo≈øt Di≈øea≈øes of the Head and Brain, proceeding from Cold Moi≈øture, and Ob≈øtructions. Do≈øe, √† gr. vj. ad xvj. in ≈øome proper Vehicle.

¬ß 20. From what has been ≈øaid it appears, that a very volatile and alcalious Spirit may be drawn from the Lees of Wine; which po≈ø≈øibly may be that very Spirit which Paracel≈øus and Van Helmont do ≈øpeak ≈øo much of, and has cau≈øed many Authors to affirm that Tartar does contain a mo≈øt volatile and admirable Spirit.

¬ß 21. Marggrave makes a volatile Salt of Tartar after this manner. ‚Ñû White Crude Tartar, Crude Antimony, Nitre, A. lb j. Calx Vive lb j≈øs. beat them all apart, ≈øift, and mix them, put it Cochleatim into an Earthen tubulated Retort in an open Fire, affixing a very large Receiver, and in the Receiver you ≈øhall have a Golden coloured Liquor, which being rectified in a Cucurbit, goes forth or a≈øcends in a volatile Salt.

¬ß 22. But his Commentator Muykens makes it after this manner. ‚Ñû Rheni≈øh Tartar lb v. pouder it gro≈øly, moi≈øten it with common Water, and keep it in a moi≈øt place, till it begins to putrefie, and the Tartar grow black; put it then into a Ve≈ø≈øel which ≈øtop clo≈øe, and dige≈øt in Hor≈øedung, for its further Exaltation, adding a little quantity of Spirit of Wine, to make a Precipitation, which continue ≈øo long till it does yield a ≈øpirituous Saline Odor: Put this Earth like Tartar into a Coated Gla≈øs Retort, and di≈øtil fir≈øt with a gentle fire, ≈øo long as any Flegm will ari≈øe; then increa≈øe the Fire to a ≈øtronger beat, and at length augment it to the highe≈øt degree, ≈øo will you have a Spirit and Oil, which ≈øeparate per Tritorium, and mix with the Volatile Salt ≈øticking to the ≈øides of the Receiver, and with the fixt Salt to be extracted from the Feces, and di≈øtil again, after the ≈øame manner as you di≈øtil Volatile Salts, ≈øo will you have a mo≈øt penetrating Volatile Salt of Tartar, which keep in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 23. This Volatile Salt is that which is ≈øaid to bear away the Palm from all other Volatile Salts, having all their Vertues, but much more powerful in its Operations and Effects: and it is one of chiefe≈øt of Chymical Arcanum's ≈øupplying (in the Opinion of Helmont and ≈øome others) the place of the Alcahe≈øt, being able to re≈øolve radically ≈øimple Bodies for extraction of their E≈ø≈øences, and to penetrate into the mo≈øt remote parts of the Body. Do≈øe, √† gr. vj. ad xij. or more.

div.head: XLIV. Sal Viperarum Volatilis, Volatile Salt of Vipers.
div.p:
Bate.] It is made of dryed Vipers by Retort, as you make the Volatile Salt of Harts-horn, from the Caput Mo ‚Ä¢ tuum, a fixed Salt is drawn or extracted, after the common manner. It is a Medicament of a mo≈øt penetrative force, re≈øi≈øting
Putrefaction, opening Ob≈øtructions, taking away Fevers, and prevailing again≈øt Melan ‚Ä¢ holy, Gout, Stone in the Reins and Bladder. Do≈øe, gr. vj. ad x.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The way how this is performed we have taught in our Sepla≈øium, Lib. 7. Cap. 61. Sect. 6. from Charr ‚Ä¢ s; where, and in the three following Sections of the ≈øame Chapter, you have ≈øeveral Notes and Remarks worthy Ob≈øervation: and in Cap. 2. Sect. 39. ¬ß 1, 2, & 3 of this Book aforegoing, from Lemery, to which for the particular Exemplification of the Proce≈øs we refer you.

¬ß 2. Here is to be noted That in the fir≈øt di≈øtillation the Flegm comes before the other Principles; but in the rectification the Volatile Salt and Spirit rifes fir≈øt, becau≈øe it is at liberty, and leaves the Flegm behind.

¬ß 3. The Ve≈ø≈øel for Sublimation mu≈øt be very high, that the Volatile Salt may ari≈øe without any Flegm; for ‚Ä¢ f the Ve≈ø≈øel be low or ≈øhort, the Flegm will ri≈øe with the Volatile Salt liquifie it, and turn it into Spirit.

¬ß 4. A Bolt-head, or a long Body with its Head, may ≈øerve for this Operation, becau≈øe the Flegm being too heavy cannot a≈øcend ≈øo high and therefore the Volatile Salt in its flight, leaves it, and ≈øublimes alone, which is after to be rectified and made more pure.

¬ß 5. To do this, you mu≈øt mix it with the di≈øtilled Spirit, and repeat the Sublimation as before. But becau≈øe this Salt always carries along with it, ≈øome few Particles of the fetid Oil, it quickly lo≈øes its whitne≈øs, and turns yellowi≈øh.

¬ß 6. To remedy this, when you have put it into the Bottle, affu≈øe thereon S. V. tartarized, ≈øo much as to overtop it an Inch, ≈øtop it up clo≈øe ≈øhake them well together, and dige≈øt for a week or ten days, ≈øo will the Salt grow white, and be pre≈øerved from di≈ø≈øolving, and the S. V. will ≈øuck up all the fetid Oil which gives the Empyreuma to the Salt, and become reddi≈øh or Amber-coloured.

¬ß 7. But in this Operation, care mu≈øt be taken, that the S. V. be perfectly deflegmated; for if the lea≈øt Flegm ≈øhould remain in it, a part of the Salt would di≈ø≈øolve therein to fill it: after it is thus wa≈øht in S. V. you may ≈øublime it again, and then it will be very dry, white and fair.

¬ß 8. There is another way of rectifying the Volatile Salt, which is by mixing it with four or five times as much Bone-A≈øhes, or Horns burnt white, putting the Mixture into a Gla≈øs or Earthen body, and then fitting to it a blind Head, luting well the Juncture, and then with a gentle fire ≈øubliming in Sand, the Volatile Salt will ari≈øe very white, and ≈øtick to the head almo≈øt like hoar Fro≈øt.

¬ß 9. This Salt is hereby purified from mo≈øt, if not all its fetid Oil, which remains at bottom in the Bone-A≈øhes, and hereby becomes whiter than it was, and plea≈øanter to the Palate: which yet by another rectification from Bones, will be ≈øtill more pure and de≈øirable, the Empyreuma in a manner totally vani≈øhing.
¬ß 10. This Volatile Salt, if it be di≈ø≈øolved in a little di≈øtilled Rain-water, will cry≈øtallize like Sugar-Candy, and then will be ea≈øier to keep than before.

¬ß 11. This Salt, and indeed all others drawn from Animals, are of almo≈øt infinite Vertues, and may be e≈øteemed even as the Pillars of true Pharmacy, for they penetrate to the places farthe≈øt removed from the fir≈øt dige≈øtion, even to the mo≈øt remote parts of the Body, and di≈ø≈øolve all vi≈øcous and tartarous Matters, open all Ob≈øtructions, cure all Fevers, principally Quartans, pre≈øerve from the Plague, and ≈øtrongly re≈øi≈øt all Putrefaction.

¬ß 12. It prevails not only again≈øt all continual and intermitting Fevers, but are good again≈øt the Pal≈øie, Falling-≈øickne≈øs, Leprofie, King's-Evil, Rickets, French-Pox, Elephantia≈øis, bitings of Serpents, Vipers, Rattle-≈ønakes, and of any other venomous Bea≈øt, cures Fits of the Mother, expels Poy≈øon, and pre≈øerves from all malign, infectious, and pe≈øtilential Di≈øea≈øes; and po≈ø≈øibly may be one of the greate≈øt Remedies in the World for the Cure of Hecticks, Phthi≈øis, and Con≈øumptions, &c. Do≈øe, √† gr. vj. ad xvj.

div.head: XLV. Sal ∆≤rine Volatile, Volatile Salt of Urine.
div.p:
Bate.] It is made of fermented ∆≤rine di≈øtilled by Retort S. A. From the Caput Mortuum a fixed Salt is drawn, according to the common Method. It is a famous Anodyn, and takes away Pains, being mixt with ≈øome
proper Liquor, and the place afflicted bathed therewith. Inwardly given it opens tartarous Ob≈øtructions of the Vi≈øcera and Men≈øentery; for which rea≈øon it is ≈øaid to be of admirable u≈øe again≈øt the Scurvy, Cachexia, yellow and black Jaundice, &c. It breaks the Stone in the Reins and Bladder, and ea≈øes Pains thenceari≈øing. Do≈øe, gr. 15. ad 30‚ñ™

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. How this is to be made we have taught in our Pharm. Lond. Lib. 2. Cap. 1. Sect. 12. and 14. as al≈øo in our Doron Medicum Lib. 1. Cap. 25. Sect. 128. and 129. and Lib. 2. Cap. 2. Sect. 22. which latter it exactly according to Lemery's Method. There are other Methods of making it, which you may ≈øee at large in our Sepla≈øium, Lib. 7. Cap. 63. Sect. 8. ad 15. and in Sect. 18. a compound Volatile Spirit and Salt of Urine and Tartar from Ma√´ts, which is a thing of good u≈øe.

¬ß 2. Others, as Le Mort and Charras make it thus: ‚Ñû Fre≈øh ∆≤rine, evaporate it in B. M. to the thickne≈øs of Honey, put it into a Gla≈øs Matra≈øs or Ve≈øica fitted with its Head and Receiver luting the Joynts, and di≈øtil with a gradual Sand-heat, that the Matter may not ri≈øe and run over, fir≈øt you have the Volatile Spirit; after that, the Volatile Salt ari≈øes, which ≈øticks to the Head; then a little ≈øtinking Oil, which tricles over into the Recipient, with the Volatile Salt which it di≈ø≈øolves: the Ve≈ø≈øels being cooled, the Oil and Volatile Salt are to be taken and ≈øeparated from the fetid Oil, by putting into the Receiver ≈øo much warm Water, as is needful to di≈ø≈øolve the Volatile Salt which was congealed: filter the Solution thro' Paper, ≈øo will the Oil be left behind: the filtred Liquor put into a large Bolt-head, with a long Neck, and fit to it a large Head round and flat, with a Receiver, luting the Joynts, and di≈øtil in a very gentle Sand-heat, ≈øo will the Volatile Salt be ≈øeparated (even by the lea≈øt heat) and ≈øublime into the head of the Still like Snow, white and pure, leaving whatever is in≈øipid or ≈øtinking behind it in the bottom, as not being able to ri≈øe becau≈øe of the height of the Ve≈ø≈øel and weakne≈øs of the Heat: this Volatile Salt gather and keep in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 3. This ≈øubtil Salt is of great Vertue and Power, whether inwardly u≈øed or outwardly applied, in the Cure of Di≈øea≈øes: it opens all Ob≈øtructions,
and is of ≈øingular u≈øe in all Melancholick Diea≈øes to break and di≈ø≈øolve Stones and Gravel, whether in Reins or Bladder and to expel them by Urine. Do≈øe, √† gr. vj. ad xx. in ≈øome fit Vehicle.

¬ß 4. Outwardly applied it prevails admirably again≈øt the Gout, or any external Pain being di≈ø≈øolved in Aqua Vitae (in which a little Flegm is left, for a pure rectified Spirit will not di≈ø≈øolve it) and it is ≈øaid to be confirmed by experience, as an excellent di≈ø≈øolver of Nodes, Tophs Gums.

¬ß 5. This Volatile Salt of Urine (≈øays Charras) powerfully mortifies Acids, which u≈øually rai≈øe the Fermentations in our Bodies, and are the Cau≈øes of ≈øeveral Di≈øea≈øes: it is very much e≈øteemed in all Di≈øea≈øes of the Liver, Spleen, and Me≈øentery, to purifie the Ma≈øs of Blood, and cure the Scurvy Cachexia, Jaundice and Hypochondriack Melancholy: it is pre≈øcribed with good Succe≈øs in Lethargies Apoplexies, Epilep≈øies, and Convul≈øions; as al≈øo in Suffocations of the Womb and difficulty of making Water. ¬ß 6. A Compound Volatile Saline Spirit of ∆≤rine and Tartar is thus made, according to Ma√´ts. ‚Ñû Recent ∆≤ rine lb iv. Salt of Tartar made with Nitre lb j. mix and dige≈øt in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt in Hor≈øe dung for three Months; ≈øo will the Volatile Salt of the ∆≤rine joyn it ≈øelf by Putrefaction with the igneous Spirit of the Tartar; after which with a gentle fire draw forth the Volatile ≈øaline Spirit, which will be indeed of an Aqueous Con≈øi≈øtence, but extreamly fiery and ≈øaline.

¬ß 7. This ≈øerves principally for drawing forth or extracting the Tinctures from the Calces of Metals and Minerals, and opening the ≈øeveral Bodies, to which it is applied: From the Crocus of Sol it extracts a yellow Tincture, which by di≈øtillation is freed from the Men≈øtruum, leaving the Tincture behind in the form and thickne≈øs of Oil: this being mixed with Alcohol of S V. q. ≈ø. and dige≈øted for ≈øome time unites it ≈øelf with the Spirit, and becomes an Aurum Potabile of great Vertue, which is gives √† gut. vj. ad xvj.

¬ß 8. After the ≈øame manner you may extract a Tincture from the Crocus of Mars, of admirable Vertues, which may be given √† gut. vj, ad xxvj. And from the
Crocus Veneris, a Tincture of Venus, which is a Specifick again≈øt the Epilep≈øie: Thus. ‚Ñû Crocus of Venus (made with Nitre) calcin'd till it is of a blood-red Colour, made into a ≈øubtil Pouder ‚Ñ•j. of choice Nitre ‚Ñ•xij. mix and calcine in a ≈øtrong Crucible with degrees of heat in a naked Fire, till the Venus with the Nitre is turned into ≈øubvirid or blewi≈øh green Scorias: on this affu≈øe the afore≈øaid Men≈øtruum, and extract a Rubicund Tincture, which ≈øeparate, adding fre≈øh Men≈øtruum, and dige≈øting as before, which ≈øo often repeat till the whole Tincture of the Venus is extracted: mix the≈øe ≈øeveral Tinctures, and by di≈øtillation ab≈øtract to the thickne≈øs of Oil; on which affu≈øe the Alcohol of S. V. dige≈øting in a warm Sand heat, ≈øo will the Tincture of the Venus unite it ≈øelf with the S. V. (as before in that of Gold) and become potable Venus. Do≈øe, √† gut. vj. ad x.

¬ß 9. And it is much more convenient for u≈øe than the other Preparations, becau≈øe it not only di≈ø≈øolves and mixes in any cold Liquor, but is al≈øo more vertuous and effectual, for that the Tincture of Mars is though to contain only the more E≈ø≈øential and Saline parts of the Tartar.

div.head: XLVIII. Tartarum Eme ‚Ä¢ icum, Emetick, or Vomiting Tartar.

div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Salt of Tartar melted ‚Ñ•viij. div.head: LII. Vitriolum Camphoratum, Camphorated Vitriol.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Vitriol calcin'd ‚Ñ•vj. Camphire (di≈ø≈øolved in S. V.) ‚Ñ•j. mix, and by a gentle fire ab≈øtract the Spirit, S. A.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. As to the Calcination of the Vitriol, it is my Opinion, it ought to be Philo≈øophically done, which is performed two ways; Fir≈øt, By a ≈øolar Calcination with the Sun-beams, as Antimony is calcin'd, the full way of doing of which you will have in our Officina Chymica, now in the Pre≈øs, and in a ≈øhort time to be publi≈øhed: Secondly, By the following Method of Le Febure.

¬ß 2. ‚Ñû Vitriol purified by dige≈øtion, dry it between two Papers in a very ≈ølow heat, till it turns of it ≈øelf to a dry Pouder, which put into one or more Matra≈ø≈øes, with a flat bottom, the thickne≈øs of a Shilling or Half Crown, ob≈øerving well this Note, el≈øe you will come ≈øhort of your de≈øign: Seal up the Ve≈ø≈øels hermetically, and put them in A≈øhes as deep as the Matter is high, and half an Inch more; then give it a fire, which ought not to exceed the heat of the Sun in Summer, and continue the ≈øame without interruption for forty days, and the Vitriol will turn by degrees from a white into a yellowi≈øh Colour, and from a yellow to a red, which will come to the height of Blood reduced to Pouder; then remove the fire, break the Ve≈ø≈øel, and keep this Philo≈øophick Vitriol as an excellent thing both for inward and outward ∆≤≈øes.

But there are ≈øome which profe≈øs to bring it to a higher degree of Perfection, by mixing it with burnt Alum, or Alum extreamly calcin'd, and then di≈øtilling the Liquor by Retort, which will be both red and ≈øweet, and having the afore-enumerated Vertues, but to be given in a ≈ømaller Do≈øe.

div.head: LIII. Vitriolum Lunae, Vitriol of Silver.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of Silver di≈ø≈øolved in Spirit of Nitre, coagulating and cry≈øtallizing, S. A. It is called al≈øo Cry≈øtallum Lunare, and Magi≈øterium Lunae. Do≈øe, gr. ij. ad vj. Salmon.] ¬ß 1. We have explicated the Proce≈øs at large after Lemery's Method in our Doron Medicum, Lib. 2. Cap. 10. Sect. 3. and according to Charras in Lib. 1. Cap. 25. Sect. 148. of the ≈øame work, ≈øo that no more from them need be ≈øaid here.

Beguinus makes it after this manner. ‚Ñû Leaf Silver ‚Ñ•j. put it into a Cucurbit, and affu≈øe thereon Spirit of Nitre, q. ≈ø. or ≈øo much as may overtop it one Inch: cover it with a blind head, and dige≈øt in B. Vap. for thirty days, in which ≈øpace of time the Luna will be changed into a white vi≈øcous Water, which placed in a cold place will congeal into a greeni≈øh blew Vitriol.

¬ß 3. Now here is to be noted, That when the Silver is all of it di≈ø≈øolved, the Liquor will become clear and tran≈øparent, but yet a little blewi≈øh, which proceeds from the ≈ømall quantity of Copper which is mixed with it; for if the Silver had been perfectly freed from the Copper, it would not have the lea≈øt Eye of blew in it, but be perfectly free from blewne≈øs or greene≈øs like Spirit of Nitre: but becau≈øe there is ≈øcarcely any Silver to be found ≈øo perfectly pure and free from Copper, therefore it is, the Solution is as ≈øeldom colourle≈øs, but for the mo≈øt part tinged more or le≈øs with an Eye of Blew.

F. ‚Ñ•iij. put them together into a Matra≈øs in a Sand beat, where leave them till the Silver is di≈ø≈øolved: pour the warm Solution into a little Gourd, warm'd a little before‚ñ™ le≈øt the heat of the Solution break it: leave it to cool ≈øome hours, and the Liquor will turn almo≈øt all into Cry≈øtals: the remaining Liquor evaporate half away in a Sand-heat, and put it again in a cool place to cry≈øtallize: the yet remaining Liquor put into an Earthen Pan, into which put ≈øome Water and a piece of Copper, ≈øo will all the Silver contained in the Liquor fall down in Pouder, which you may wa≈øh and dry, and melt with a little Nitre and Tartar, in a Crucible, to re≈øtore it to its fir≈øt Body again. ¬ß 5. The≈øe Cry≈øtals, Salt, or Vitriol of Luna are of a very bitter Ta≈øte, and apt to black the Skin, with an enduring Black, not to be removed, till the Skin wears off: they purge very ea≈øily, and are given √† gr. iij. ad vj. ≈øome ≈øay gr. viij. in ≈øome ≈øpecifick Vehicle, for ≈øuch as

¬ß 6. It is a Specifick for all Di≈øea≈ørs of Head and Brain, as inveterate Head-Achs, Megrims, Apoplexies, Lethargies, Vertigo's, Epilep≈øies, Pal≈øies, &c. And is a famous thing again≈øt Drop≈øies, and to purge the Brain from ≈øuperfluous Humors.

F. in the≈øe Cry≈øtals, I think it not ≈øo ≈øafe to give gr. 8. or gr. 10. as ≈øome Authors allow, for their Effects will be too violent, and their Qualities too cau≈øtick to be given in ≈øo great a Do≈øe: You may give √† gr. j. ad iij, or iv. or in very ≈øtrong Bodies to gr. vj. as our Author has limited, which ≈øeems to be the utmo≈øt Do≈øe: for in ≈øome Con≈øtitutions, a Do≈øe of gr. iv. will work above an hundred times, yet without making the Body much the weaker for it.

¬ß 8. MaeÃÑts from Angelus Sala, having made the Cry≈øtals according to the vulgar Method at ¬ß 4. above, di≈ø≈øolves them de Nova in May Dew, or di≈øtilled Rain-water (dige≈øting for twenty four Hours, that the Feces, if any be, may ≈øub≈øide) then filters, and evaporates to a Cuticle, and then ≈øets it to concreet into Cry≈øtals again, which he drys and keeps for u≈øe.

¬ß 9. The≈øe Cry≈øtals are much more freed from the Acid of the Spirit of Nitre or A. F. than the other; and if to the Solution, you add an equal part to the Cry≈øtals of fine Nitre, it will yet much more infringe the corro≈øive Quality of the remaining Acid Spirits, and become a Specifick Antihydropick, beyond any other Medicament yet known.

div.head: LIV. Vitriolum Martis, Vitriol of Mars or Iron.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Alcohol of Wine ‚Ñ•iv. Oil of Vitriol ‚Ñ•ij. keep them together in an Iron Ve≈ø≈øel for twelve or fifteen hours, or to dryne≈øs. Do≈øe, √† gr. ij. ad vj. to open Ob≈øtructions.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is exactly Riverius his Sal Martis, of which we have already ≈øpoken ≈øomething at Sect. XXV. ¬ß 6. & 27, 28, 29, & 30. aforegoing of this Chapter.

This Vitriol or Sal ‚Ä¢ , is of greater Vertue than any of the aperitive Crocus's, not only becau≈øe it is acuated with the Oil of Vitriol, but becau≈øe its piercing Particles, being the more ≈øoluble parts of the Iron, are ≈øeparated from the more gro≈øs and terrene, which will always carry a Stypticity in their nature, and be a Remora to the more Aperitive principles; for which rea≈øon it is always given in le≈øs Do≈øe than the Aperitive Crocus, and with much greater and more certain

div.head: LV. Sal Antimonij, Zwelferi, Salt of Antimony from Zwelfer.
div.p:
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It is made of that Ma≈øs which remains in the Retort after the di≈øtillation of the Butter of Antimony, and that by help of Spirit of Vinegar, a little acuated with Spirit of Nitre; and this by ≈øo much the more ea≈øily and ≈øpeedily, if the ≈øaid Ma≈øs be made into fine Pouder, and fir≈øt, twice or thrice calcin'd with Sulphur, after the manner of the Calcination of Chalybs with Sulphur for the Preparation of its Vitriol, by mixing an Ounce and half of Sulphur at a time, with lb j. of the Antimonial Ma≈øs: Then extracting with Spirit of Vinegar. the Salt will be drawn forth, and by ab≈øtracting with the Spirit there from, the ≈øaline Matter will remain at bottom of a yellowi≈øh Colour, which you are to di≈ø≈øolve aagain in ≈øimple fair Water, filter, and evaporate to a Cuticle, and la≈øtly in a cool moi≈øt place ≈øet it to cry≈øtallize, which diligently gather, dry, and
