¬ß 2. They purge gently, and are given to Infants again≈øt Worms, which they effectually kill and bring forth; they al≈øo prevail again≈øt the Drop≈øie, continual, malign, and pe≈øtilential Fevers; and are famous for purifying the whole Ma≈øs of Blood, re≈øtoring the Sick miraculou≈øly to their pri≈øtine Health.

¬ß 3. Zwelfer (Manti≈ø≈ø. Spagyr. Cap. 8. pag. 838.) has another Salt of Antimony purging, made from the Vitrum (after the Extraction of a purging Tincture from it) after this manner. The purging Tincture. ‚Ñû Gla≈øs of Antimony (made without any addition) q. v. put it into a ≈ømall Cucurbit, and affu≈øe thereon ≈øo much dephlegmated Oil of Vitriol, as may overtop it about two Inches: dige≈øt in a gentle A≈øh-heat for ≈øome days, till the Oil is imbued of a black Colour, which gently ≈øeparate and keep for u≈øe.

¬ß 4. This Tincture purges plea≈øantly being given √† gut. v. ad x. it purifies the Blood, and brings forth ≈øuperfluous and tartarous Humors, kills Worms, and conduces to the Cure of Gouts and Rheumati≈øms.

¬ß 5. From the Gla≈øs remaining after the extraction of the afore≈øaid Tincture a Sal Antimonij is thus made. ‚Ñû The ≈øaid remaining Gla≈øs, and add to it a fourth part of Sulphur beaten ≈ømall, and calcine it with a gentle Fire in an Earthen Pan, continually ≈øtirring it with an Iron Spatula or Rod, till the Sulphur is wholly burnt up: beat the remaing Ma≈øs into pouder, and again with a fourth part of Sulphur calcine it as before, which Calcination three or four times repeat: then from this Gla≈øs thus calcin'd; with Spirit of Vinegar, q.≈ø. and by many affu≈øions of fre≈øh Spirit, extract the Salt: ab≈øtract the Spirit of Vinegar to dryne≈øs, and the Salt will remain at bottom, which di≈ø≈øolve in ≈øimple Water, filter and cry≈øtallize as afore≈øaid.
¬ß 6. It has all the Vertues of the former Salt, purges gently, and may be given both to Infants, and Women with Child with all ≈øecurity imaginable. Do≈øe, √† gr. v. ad x. in any proper Vehicle.

¬ß 7. Le Febure makes the Salt much after the ≈øame manner, Of the Gla≈øs after the Extraction of the Tincture, but he mingles the Vitrum with its equal weight
of Sulphur in Pouder, and then calcines gently (as in calcining Antimony to make the Gla≈øs thereof) ≈øtirring well the Matters till all the Sulphur is con≈øumed: this fire he makes not too inten≈øe, le≈øt the Matter ≈øhould melt, and ≈øo return to Antimony again: thus once calcin'd, he grinds it on a Porphyry to an Alcohol, puts it into a Matra≈øs, and affu≈øes thereon Spirit of Vinegar ≈øo much as to overtop it four Inches, dige≈øts in Sand for eight days, decants the Men≈øtruum, and affu≈øes new, this continuing till all the Salt is extracted, the≈øe Extractions he mixes, filters, and ab≈øtracts the Spirit to a Pellicle, and cry≈øtallizes as afore-directed, or otherwi≈øe evaporates to dryne≈øs: afterwards di≈ø≈øolves the Salt in Flegm of Vinegar, filters, evaporates, and thus continues till it is pure and white; la≈øtly dige≈øts it in Alcohol of S. V. for fifteen days, and ab≈øtracting the Spirit, keeps the Salt in a Gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt for u≈øe.

¬ß 8. The ≈øame Le Febure has another way of making this Salt, which is thus. ‚Ñû The black Matter after extraction of the Tincture from the Vitrum afore-mentioned, dry it in an Earthen Di≈øh, and without any other previous Calcination put it into a Matra≈øs, upon which affu≈øe ≈øubtil Spirit of Vinegar; dige≈øt together for many days in a gentle heat, to make an Extraction of the Salt; filter, evaporate to dryne≈øs, di≈ø≈øolve again and depurate, as in the former Preparation; then dige≈øt with Alcohole of S. ¬ß 9. The Vertues of both the≈øe Salts are one and the ≈øame, they purifie and clean≈øe the Blood, and purge the Body from all the Filth, Putrefaction and ≈øuperfluous Humors, cure the Lepro≈øie and French-Pox, and after a wonderful manner make the Gout to vani≈øh: they dige≈øt and evacuate as it were in≈øen≈øibly, and cau≈øe inward Ab≈øce≈ø≈øes or Apo≈øtems, to break or di≈øcu≈øs.

¬ß 10. They have all the Vertues mentioned at ¬ß 2. above, be≈øides which, they are ≈øaid to cure all inward and outward Ulcers, and to expel and drive away all ≈øorts of Fevers and Agues, chiefly Quartans, and ≈øuch as proceed from Malignity and Putrefaction. div.head: LVI. Sal Vitrioli Compo≈øitum, Compound Salt of Vitriol.
div.p: Salmon.] ¬ß 1. ‚Ñû Common Vitreol, or in≈øtead of that, Vitriol of Mars, di≈ø≈øolve in di≈øtilled Rain-water, dige≈øt in a Matra≈øs for ≈øome time, after filter this Liquor precipitate with Oil of Tartar per Deliquium, or Oil of Pot-a≈øhes, decant the clear Liquor from the Feces which dry; the≈øe are the ≈øweet Sulphur of Vitriol. ¬ß 3. ¬ß 4. For they are emetick, whereas this works generally by Stool, and rarely provokes Vomiting; it is commended as an admirable thing again≈øt intermitting Fevers or Agues, e≈øpecially when there is a nece≈ø≈øity to purge Melancholy.

¬ß 5. For the Lixiviate Salts correcting the emetick Quality of the Vitriol, which lay in its too pungent Acidity, renders this Salt in a condition only to operate by Stool or Urine: and it may with much ≈øafety be given from í ≈øs. ad í j. in any proper or ≈øpecifick Vehicle.

¬ß 3. It provokes Sleep, and cau≈øes re≈øt, and therefore ought to be given at Night going to Bed.
¬ß 4. Given, ad í ij. iij. or iv. in a Cly≈øter it heals the Bloody-flux, and ≈øtops all other Fluxes of the Bowels.

div.head: II. * Bal≈øamum Faeminarum, The Bal≈øam for Womenkind.
div.p:
Bate.] ‚Ñû Of the ≈ømall Flowers of the musked Crane's Bill ‚Ñ•iv. Oil of ≈øweet Almonds
new drawn lb j≈øs. in≈øolate forty days; then expre≈øs out: add fre≈øh Flowers of Water-lillies and of white Lillies, A. ‚Ñ•iv. in≈øolate again twenty days; and expre≈øs the Oil; to which add Oil of Ja≈ø≈øemy ‚Ñ•iv. Civet í j. mix S. A. and make a Bal≈øam. Anoint therewith the Perinaeum, Groins, Loins, Flanks of Women, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , in pariendi difficultate, who have hard Labour, or are not ea≈øily delivered.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Oil is much better made by boiling till the Flowers are cri≈øp; and they may all be put in at once, as well as at ≈øeveral times, by which means it will al≈øo be ≈øooner done.

¬ß 2. But it will be no perfect Bal≈øam without the addition of ≈øome proper Re≈øin; of which kind are Turpentines of all ≈øorts; to the former Oil, after expre≈ø≈øion you may add, Strasburg Turpentine, Bal≈øam Capivi, Bal≈øam of Tolu, Chio Turpentine, A. ‚Ñ•j≈øs. Liquid Styrax ‚Ñ•iv. which mix well.

¬ß 3. Being thus compounded, it will be much more powerful for the intended purpo≈øe, be≈øides which it will be a very good Vulnerary; and if any of the parts be hurt or torn in the bringing forth of the Child, it will ≈øpeedily and ≈øafely heal them.

div.head: III. * Bal≈øamum Lucatelli, Lucatellus his Bal≈øam.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû The be≈øt Oil-Olive lb iij. Spani≈øh Wine lb j. Venice Turpentine wa≈øht in Ro≈øe-water ‚Ñ•viij. Wax lb j. boil S. A. adding red Sanders in fine Pouder ‚Ñ•ij. Bal≈øam of Peru ‚Ñ•j. mix them. Outwardly applied, it is good again≈øt Burnings, Inflamations, Ulcers, Wounds, &c. Inwardly it is given, ad í j. or í ij. in Wine for inward Brui≈øes, Ulcers of the Reins, Stone in the Reins and Bladder, Difficulty of making Water.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. In making of this Bal≈øam ≈øome few things are ob≈øervable, fir≈øt, That the Turpentine is better unwa≈øht than wa≈øht, becau≈øe ≈øome of its mo≈øt Volatile, Spirituous and E≈ø≈øential parts are lo≈øt in that Agitation.
¬ß 2. Secondly, That Stra≈øburg Turpentine much exceeds the Venice in this Occa≈øion, as being much more Fragrant and Bal≈øamick; and Cyprus and Chio are yet ≈øtill better than that.

¬ß 3. That where ≈øuch bal≈øamick Re≈øins are u≈øed it is not good to boil much the Bal≈øam, after the mixing of them, becau≈øe much of their Spirituous and Volatile parts flye away in that Action, and therefore it is be≈øt to boil the Oil and Spani≈øh Wine together fir≈øt, to the Con≈øumption of the Humidity; and then to add the Re≈øins, mixing them only by a gentle melting together, not boiling.

¬ß 4. That the Bal≈øam of Peru is too little in quantity ‚Ñ•iv≈øs. is as ≈ømall a proportion as can be put into this quantity, to add any thing of Vertue to the Medicament; and if in≈øtead of ‚Ñ•iv≈øs. you allow ‚Ñ•ix. the Bal≈øam will be very much the better.
¬ß 5. In our Pharm. Lond. Lib. 5. Cap. 2. Sect. 50. you may ≈øee it, according to the Colledges Pre≈øcript, which is in much differing Proportions.

¬ß 6. The Red Sanders ought to be added after it is off the Fire, and the boiling heat abated, otherwi≈øe it will not be of any good colour, and then to be ≈øtirred continually, till it is almo≈øt cold.

¬ß 7. When I make it for my own u≈øe, my Proportions are the≈øe. ‚Ñû Oil-Olive lb j≈øs. Spani≈øh Wine lb j. boil to the Con≈øumption of the Wine; then add the be≈øt Bees wax lb j. when it is melted, put in Strasburgh, Cyprus, or Chio Turpentine lb j≈øs. Bal≈øam of Peru ‚Ñ•viij. Red Sanders in fine Pouder ‚Ñ•ij. melt, mix‚ñ™ and ≈øtir it till it is cold. 'Tis a Bal≈øam without compared.

div.head: IV. Bal≈øamum Momordicae, Bal≈øam of the Balm-Apple.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû It is made of the Fruit thereof, being in≈øolated for a long time in Oil. It is one of the be≈øt of things, again≈øt Wounds and Ulcers; a mo≈øt admirable thing again≈øt the Haemorrhoides or Piles, Ulcers of the Womb, Ruptures, &c.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. I humbly conceive that by Momordica our Author intends nothing more nor le≈øs than the Balm-Apple, and in that Sence we have taken him.
¬ß 2. But mo≈øt Herbali≈øts take Momordica to be the Bal≈øamitamas, which is clearly another Plant, and bears no ≈øuch Fruit as the Bal≈øamina, Viticella, or Balm-Apple-Plant does.

¬ß 3. This Oil is temperate in re≈øpect of the fir≈øt qualities, vulnerary, and

div.head: V. Bal≈øamum Nuci≈øtae, Bal≈øam of Nutmegs.
div.p: Bate] ‚Ñû Nutmegs brui≈øed, or beaten lb j. Spani≈øh Wine lb ≈øs. pure new made Butter without any Salt in it lb ij. put them all into a Ve≈ø≈øel which ≈øtop clo≈øe, and in≈øolate for five days; then boil gently to the Con≈øumption of the Wine, and ≈øtrain out the Bal≈øam. Its u≈øe is as well internal as external. It expels the dead Child, and brings forth the Secundine or After-birth, &c. Salmon.] ¬ß 1. This is nothing more or le≈øs but an Artificial Oil of Nutmegs by expre≈ø≈øion made by addition of the fre≈øh Butter.

¬ß 2. The in≈øolation and boiling being over; whil≈øt very hot, you mu≈øt pre≈øs out the Oil, but it mu≈øt be with an Almond Pre≈øs as they make Oil of Almonds, or Oil of Nutmegs by expre≈ø≈øion; otherwi≈øe a great deal of the Strength and Oil of the Nutmegs will be left behind.
¬ß 3. It comforts the Head and weakned Vi≈øcera, and is an excellent thing again≈øt Ulcers of the internal parts; it di≈øcu≈ø≈øes Wind, and gives ea≈øe in the Cholick to a wonder.

div.head: VI. Bal≈øamum Sclopetarium, A Bal≈øam for Gun-≈øhot Wounds.
div.p: Bate] rx; Oils of Line≈øeed and Turpentine, A. lb j. Verdigri≈øe ‚Ñ•≈øs. boil them a little, S. A. It is u≈øed again≈øt Gun-≈øhot Wounds, and old Ulcers, for which purpo≈øes it has no equal.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It is an excellent thing again≈øt Burnings and Scaldings of all kinds, whether with naked Fire, boiling Water or Oil, boiling Pitch or Wax, melt-Lead, or other Metals, Nitre, Gun-pouder, &c.
¬ß 2. Lay it on with Lint (the part being anointed with it) and then a proper ≈øticking Plai≈øter over it; it will take out the Fire in a very ≈øhort time, and ≈øoon after heal the Ulcer.

¬ß 3. It is e≈øteemed al≈øo a mo≈øt excellent thing for the healing all ≈øorts of putrified Sores, old Ulcers, running Fi≈øtula's, &c. doing tho≈øe things which ≈øacarcely any other outward Medicine will do.

div.head: VII. Bal≈øamum Spinale, A Bal≈øam for the Back.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Man's Grea≈øe ‚Ñ•iv. Goo≈øe Grea≈øe, Badgers Grea≈øe, A. ‚Ñ•iij. Oil of Bays ‚Ñ•ij. Sage, Marjoram, Elder, dwarf Elder, Calamint, Origanum, Lavender, A. Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It is de≈øigned as an external help again≈øt the Rickets, and it is of good u≈øe for ≈øuch Children, as cannot be ea≈øily made to take things inwardly.
¬ß 2. But be≈øides anointing the Back-bone, it will be nece≈ø≈øary to anoint the Stomach therewith Morning and Evening, as al≈øo all the Joynts affected.

div.head: VIII. Bal≈øamum Spleneticum, A Bal≈øam for the Spleen.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Rue, Ground-Ivy, Camonile, Time, A. M.j. beat them together, and add Ox-Gall, Neats-feet Oil, A. lb j. Aqua Vitae ‚Ñ•j. boil for an hour, and ≈øtrain out. It is of ≈øingular Vertue again≈øt Pains of the Spleen, and all other Pains and Aches proceeding from a cold Cau≈øe.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It is a good thing as it is, but if you add to the Compo≈øition, Camphire ‚Ñ•ij. it will be much more effectual.

div.head: IX. * Bal≈øamum Sulphuris Bateanum, Dr. Bate's Bal≈øam of Sulphur.
div.p:
Bate] ‚Ñû Flowers of Sulphur ‚Ñ•j. Florence Oil-Olive ‚Ñ•v. boil all with a gentle Fire, (continually ≈øtirring of it) till it comes to the con≈øi≈øtence of a

div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Lin≈øeed Oil ‚Ñ•x. Sulphur in fine Pouder ij. boil gently, continually ≈øtirring it, till it comes to the Con≈øi≈øtency of Honey. Let it be applied to the place pained and weakned with the Gout, ≈øpreading it on Leather or Cloth, and renewing it every third or fourth day.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of OINTMENTS.
I. Butyrum Amygdalinum, Almond Butter.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû LArge ≈øweet Almonds (i. e. Jordan Almonds) lb j. macerate them in cold Water and blanch them brui≈øe them well in a Marble Mortar, ≈øprinkling them often (whil≈øt beating) with a little fair Water. Then add fair Water, q. ≈ø. till it grows thick like Cream; ≈øtrain it hard out by pre≈ø≈øing, and put it upon a gentle Fire often ≈øtirring it, till it begins to boil: then add (that it may coagulate or thicken) Juice of Limons ‚Ñ•j. ≈øu≈øpend it in a good thick Cloth, that there may be a ≈øeparation of all the ≈øerv≈øe or thin parts, the Butter remaining behind in the Cloth, which mix with Sugar and Ro≈øe-water, till it is of a plea≈øant Ta≈øte. Salmon.] ¬ß 1. The Sugar with which the Condiment is made ought to be trebble refined; and the Ro≈øe-water ought to be that of Damask Ro≈øes.
¬ß 2. For external U≈øes, it is a good Maturative, and therefore ought to be mixt with Ripners; and mixt with Turpentine, and the Yolk of an Egg, it makes one of the be≈øt Dige≈øtives in nature.
¬ß 3. Inwardly again≈øt the Griping of the Guts you may give it from í ij. ad í vj. or more, mixing with it, gut. i. ij. or iij. as you ≈øee convenient of the Oil of ≈øweet Fennel-≈øeeds.

div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Pouder of Columbines, Sage, Mint, Nutmegs, A. ‚Ñ•≈øs. burnt Alum ‚Ñ•j. Honey ‚Ñ•iv. mix them. It is good again≈øt Ulcers of the Gums, Inflamations, Loo≈øene≈øs of the Fle≈øh about the Teeth, &c.

Bate.] ‚Ñû Common Soap, Honey, A. ‚Ñ•iv. Salt of Tartar ‚Ñ•≈øs. Fumitory-water í ij. mix

div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Fre≈øh Oranges, but green, and not ripe; No vj. beat them into a Pulp with their Peels; Bay-leaves, M. iv. Sage, Sorel, Marigold, A. M. ij. Nutmegs ‚Ñ•≈øs; boil again, till the Herbs are cri≈øp, and then pre≈øs out again. It is an excellent thing again≈øt Scabs, Itch, &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. What good it will do in the Itch, I know nothing of (the ∆≤nguentum de Enula cum Mercurio, or Neapolitanum, are a thou≈øand times better:) but as to Scurf, Dandrif, Pu≈øtles, Pimples Scabs, and other like Breakings out, it is a ≈øingular good thing.

div.head: X. * ∆≤nguentum de Betonica Aquatica, Ointment of Water Betony.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Water Betony, Sorrel, A. M. vj. brui≈øe them, and add fre≈øh new made Butter lb ij. boil till the Herbs are cri≈øp, and pre≈øs out ≈øtrongly; repeat the boiling with fre≈øh Herbs three times, ≈øtrain or pre≈øs out again, and add Sulphur Vive in fine Pouder ‚Ñ•ij≈øs. div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Styrax Calamita í vj. Benjamine ‚Ñ•j. Labdanum í ij. white Sanders, Cloves, A. í j≈øs. Marjoram, Damask Ro≈øe-Leaves, A. ‚Ñàiv. Musk, Ambergri≈øe, A. ‚Ñà≈øs. Being held to the No≈øe, they ≈øtir the Blood by their grateful Odor, and chear the Heart above mea≈øure in Apoplexies, Epilep≈øies, Pe≈øtilential Airs, &c.

Salmon.] ¬ß 1. If they be made into the u≈øual Magnitude for Pills, they may be taken every Night going to Bed, ad í j. again≈øt the ≈øame Di≈øtempers, and that way u≈øed they will be more powerful to the Intentions, than by bare ≈ømelling to them.

div.head: XXVII. Pilae Odoratae, Sweet Balls.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Venice Soap ‚Ñ•vj. Styrax Calamita, Benjamine, A. ‚Ñ•≈øs. Marjoram ‚Ñàiv. Cloves, No 12. Musk, gr. ij. Damask Ro≈øe-water, q. ≈ø. mix and make Balls, S.A. They clean≈øe well, and have a grateful Scent, comforting the Nerves, Skin of the Hands, &c. They ≈øerve to wa≈øh withal.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It is good to wa≈øh in the Morning with them, for clean≈øing, and whitening the Skin, the con≈øtant u≈øe of which will make it very pure and ≈øoft.
¬ß 2. It is good to wa≈øh the Head al≈øo with them in a warm Larder, which is troubled with Scurf, Dandrif, or other Defedations u≈øual to tho≈øe parts.

div.head: XXVIII. Suffimentum Hy≈øtericum, An Hy≈øterick Fume.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû A≈øa fetida ‚Ñ•j. Rue, M. j. be≈øt Wine-Vinegar lb j. boil them in a Pot with a narrow Mouth, S. A. The hot Fumes are to be received often in a day up the Mouth (being open) and No≈øtrils.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. If at the ≈øame time the Patient takes fifty or ≈øixty Drops of the Liquor inwardly in any proper Hy≈øterick water, it will be much more effectual.
¬ß 2. But u≈øing it as a Fume, there ought to be added to it Oil of Harts-horn ‚Ñ•≈øs. whereby the Power of it for this purpo≈øe will be ten times increa≈øed.

div.head: XXIX. * Torquis Infantum, A Necklace for Children.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of the male Peony-root and Henbane-root fre≈øh gathered, cut into round pieces and bored thro' the middle, and ≈øtrung in order upon a Thread or String. Which being wrapped in fine Linnen or Lawn, are to be worn about the Neck in the time of breeding of Teeth. They are ≈øaid to facilitate the breeding of Teeth, and prevent Convul≈øions.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It is u≈øed as an Amulet, in which I believe there is no more Vertue for driving away Pains in breeding of Teeth, than there is in the Words being worn about the Neck as a Pentacle.

¬ß 2. But for ≈øuch as have Faith in the thing (and I know not but their Faith may do the Work) they may put it about their Childrens Necks, and let them wear it as long as they are breeding their Teeth.

¬ß 3. If in this time, the Child ≈øhould be cro≈øs and froward, and peevi≈øh, with the angui≈øh of its Teeth cutting, the Parent or Putter on thereof mu≈øt wholly blame them≈øelves (and not the Medicine) for that they were People of little Faith.

div.head: XXX. * Turundae Acou≈øticae, Ear Tents to help the Hearing.
div.p: Bate.] ‚Ñû Galbanum, Ship Pitch, A. í ij. white Hellebore in fine Pouder ‚Ñà 5. Civet, gr. vj. mix them; divide the Ma≈øs into eight or ten parts, making each into the form of a Clove; which wrap or tie up in a very thin piece of fine Linnen or Lawn, fixing a Thread to the greater end thereof, for the more ea≈øie pulling it forth again out of the Ear. It is one of the be≈øt of Remedies again≈øt Deafne≈øs.
Salmon.] ¬ß 1. It may be a good thing for all that I know, but I have had no Experience of it, and therefore only recommend it to your Prudence in making Tryal.

¬ß 2. I mu≈øt confe≈øs, I admire not the white Hellebore in it (becau≈øe it is of a putrefactive Quality) and within ‚Ñàj. it is nearly half as much as the re≈øt of the Ingredients; but po≈ø≈øibly the Empla≈øtick Bodies of the Gum and Ro≈øin, may ≈øo chain or fetter it up, as that it may do no great mi≈øchief.
